subject: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Hello Travelers, Tripadvisor has created this thread to be an ongoing resource for anyone seeking information about Coronavirus (Covid-19) and travel to Hong Kong. Many travelers have already contributed to information about the Coronavirus, and we are hoping you will share any new updates or recommendations pertaining to Coronavirus in Hong Kong here. Some of the information we're seeing travelers seek out is: What attractions have been closed, or have re-opened for business? Are there any specific local resources for following news or other information? Have there been any significant disruptions to government services (such as public transport or airport/train stations)? What types of disruptions to local businesses have been noted? For more details on the situation globally please visit this Tripadvisor guide: https://www.tripadvisor.com/COVID-2019 Additional threads with useful information that have already been started by our travelers can be found here: https://www.tripadvisor.com/Search?q=Coronavirus&searchSessionId=278DDBC04137C1CB25BEF8F5870603511583185600562ssid&sid=483988A424AE731DAB9F83D0D70F8FBB1583762990200&blockRedirect=true&ssrc=f&geo=294217&rf=1 Please feel free to respond to this post with questions or information about this important issue, or share links to existing forum posts with useful information. As we at Tripadvisor, and more specifically our community of travelers have more information, please check back here to see how the situation is evolving in Hong Kong. Colleen Tripadvisor Content Team

subject: 4. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Hong Kong is currently working towards normalisation of the situation, with things slowly slowly reopening. Of importance for visitors continuing to a second destination in Asia: many countries have restrictions on travellers from Hong Kong. This includes at least Taiwan, Philippines and Thailand. The many flight cancellations to/from Hong Kong should be another concern. I'm not aware of a central, reliable repository of information on this, it changes all the time at the whim of the various governments involved. For updates & more questions about the situation in Hong Kong best use the other sticky: https://en.tripadvisor.com.hk/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k12734994-o1000-Is_HK_save_to_travel-Hong_Kong.html That sticky started due to the protest situation, then morphed into a virus-related thread, and with the protests picking up again likely soon back to the protest situation. Edited: 4 years ago

subject: 6. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Hotel Situation in HK during the CoronaVirus Outbreak At present, hotel room rates around the city remain at deeply discounted levels. I'm finding properties in the 2-4 star range offering prices, even on weekends that are 25-33% their normal rates of the past few years. Some 5 star properties are offering discounts as well but not at the same level of concessions that you will find with the midrange category places. As such, it is not necessary to reserve hotel rooms far in advance this year. You can wait until much closer to your intended dates of travel, to ensure your trip isn't cancelled. Then book with 1 week or so of your intended travel to Hong Kong. This situation may change later in the year but many of us feel that it is not likely as we have a major protest movement that is presently set on pause while the city deals with the Coronavirus Outbreak. After the virus outbreak settles, if the protests return to the same levels of activity that we saw last autumn, visitors will likely continue to remain away from HK in mass numbers. If this happens, hotel room rates will probably stay quite low as well. Edited: 4 years ago

subject: 8. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: It is now being reported that Hong Kong will impose new quarantine requirements for anybody who arrives in the city having previously been in Italy, or parts of Japan, Germany or France, in the past two weeks starting midnight on Thursday (see link) https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1513568-20200310.htm This is similar to the travel restrictions that are currently in effect for those who have visited mainland China, South Korea or Iran within 14 days prior to attempting to enter Hong Kong. Given the vastly rising infection counts in places like Spain and the United States, it is quite possible that we are going to see the same/similar travel restrictions into Hong Kong slapped on even more nations in the near future.

subject: 9. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong

As usual no explicit mention of transit passengers, who did not leave the airport. So can't say either way whether such a traveller will be allowed entry or not. Edited: 4 years ago

subject: 12. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Some museums are partially reopening their exhibition facilities from today (11th March) although interactive exhibits remain suspended' "The Hong Kong Museum of Art, the Hong Kong Heritage Museum, the Hong Kong Film Archive and the Flagstaff House Museum of Tea Ware will partially open their exhibition facilities on March 11, with interactive exhibits and public programmes temporarily suspended. Special opening hours from 10am to 5pm daily (except on the regular closing day) will be implemented. Among the four museums, the Hong Kong Museum of Art and the Hong Kong Heritage Museum will arrange visits by sessions, each lasting two hours, to limit visitor flow. Visitors will be able to enter the museums on a first-come, first-served basis"

subject: 21. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Post #12 Update - on updated museum reopenings I visited the Heritage Museum yesterday and HKMOA this afternoon. The procedures are simple. They have three 2 hour slots with 30 minute closings in between in order to clean and disinfect. Small number of visitors are allowed to enter, not sure the exact count but there were very few during my visits. There are announcements starting 10 minutes before the end of the session, informing you to begin exiting the museum. You'll find hand gel tubs in quite a few of the galleries as well. All rather straight-forward, very few others in the museums and everyone is quite spread out, making it potentially a safer place to be than out on the streets or in the malls. A last word - The HKMOA renovations are really nice and the Turner to Hockley exhibition of British landscapes from London's Tate is a great way to kick off the reopening of the museum.

subject: 22. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Thanks for the report! I'm so eager to see the re-opened HKMOA. Meanwhile, back in the US we are working from home, closing schools, online teaching, washing hands, social distancing, closing restaurants and businesses. No whining from me - I know what Hong Kongers have lived through and hope our citizens will also sacrifice to stop this outbreak. I'm happy to hear that HK is on a better footing than a month ago - hoping we find the same on the other side of this. Amazing - and to think that my first knowledge months ago of the outbreak in Wuhan was from a poster on TA.

subject: 23. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: I haven't seen much in the way of social distancing in HK (pretty hard considering how many people there are in this small area), no restaurants are closed (well, those targeting tourists may have gone bankrupt), and most non-tourist businesses go on as usual. Worst by far is the schools being closed for two full months now, and at the very least another month to go and probably even longer, easily another month before it's all reopened. No idea what's going to happen to all those cross border students, and the year end (or even school end!) exams... Also schools are bound to require their students to wear masks, but no-one knows where to get that extra million or so of masks needed daily for that to happen.

subject: 24. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: There is overall social distancing as evident by the lesser number of people walking around, using public transport and eating out. A lot of restaurants have gone out of business or are operating with more limited hours. Many people I know still work from home. Even my office is letting staff out an hour early to avoid the worst of the traffic (=crowds). There have been no hard rules to close any business though. The only closures were facilities controlled by the government. Many of them are starting to open again though some with just limited service. I have a friend with two children (8 and 10) who has only gone out just once to dine since the virus hit. On most days, she stays home while her husband goes to work and does all the shopping. I also know people who have been working from home since CNY. Some elderly folks I know have scrapped their weekly mahjong meetings. This past weekend though, it was noticeable that more people were out and about. A restaurant that I walk past often was at 70-80% capacity, vs maybe just 30% two weeks ago. We visited the HKMOA several months ago before the virus hit. It's indeed a nice place. The architecture is very interesting. Even though I don't know much about Chinese art, the exhibits are very well done. They have a small section on Western art as well though obviously, European museums and the NY Metropolitan offer more famous works.

subject: 25. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Public transport: sure, with the schools closed that's less people. The lack of tourists is also telling in transport. Transport has been getting notably more crowded over the past two weeks, East Rail Line is much less crowded than normal, in a large part thanks to the lack of cross border traffic. Walking around: not any less crowded than normal in Tai Po (an area that normally sees little to no tourists). Last Saturday the malls were as crowded as ever. Restaurants had their usual lines; I have yet to see a restaurant that closed or that's significantly less crowded. I did notice two dispensaries that closed down (permanently), and at least one Chow Tai Fook closed (temporarily - shop is still there, just closed for business). I've also not seen any closed shops in Ap Lei Chau where I currently work; another corner of Hong Kong that rarely sees tourists normally. As I started there early Feb I can't tell whether the current crowds (which to me feel normal for such areas) are less than normal. So it seems the locals don't go out much less than usual; but if you live in a tourist-heavy area no doubt you will see relatively quiet streets and struggling restaurants. I haven't visited Lan Kwai Fong or Soho recently, especially the latter area I've heard starts to resemble a ghost town with most units boarded up.

subject: 28. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: I just wanted to update in here about the time it takes to get out of the airport as in the past few days, there were lots of reports and stories that were quite frustrating and many visitors were concerned what to expect upon their arrival in the next few days. The airport immigration was overwhelmed with many returning to HK , especially students from overseas in the past couple of days. Reporting that it took 4-5 hours to get out of the HK airport to get the health declaration, immigration, the wrist bands, and questions asked...etc. As of today, it seemed the process is much faster. It was about 15 minutes to 30 minutes. However, there seems to be a long delay in getting the tracker wristband to activate because one needs to wait for the text message to your phone to activate, Some says it's up to 12 hours delay. But no matter, the 14 day quarantine rule applies to all visitors from any country coming into HK now, except Taiwan and Macau. Very amazed by HK government implementing such measures. Edited: 4 years ago

subject: 29. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: If they manage to get the wristband and app system to work, then HK is ahead of just about every country worldwide. Sure, there could be loopholes that some folks would like to pick on. However, we aren't seeing any other country offering a better solution at this point. In fact, I know somebody who was going to head to New Zealand (dual citizen HK/NZ so allowed entry there) at the end of this month originally. She was going to ignore NZ's 14-day self-isolation ban since she said it would be impossible to police. She was forced to cancel her trip only when HK implemented the 14-day quarantine procedure.

subject: 30. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Yes, it sad to see people ignore the self quarantine order but that is a reality. Almost all western countries weren't prepared for the outbreak and now they (including my own) all had learned the "speed" of the virus and resort to asking citizen to practice social distancing, personal hygiene and WFH. Good for HK to use GPS tracking devices for people under quarantine order. We have similar devices but they are mostly for DUI offenders and other convicts. There is whole rack of privacy issue to use it on travelers here. Edited: 4 years ago

subject: 31. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Just an update: it was reported that 41 people violated the self-quarantine procedure. They were caught by the new wristband/app tracker system. Charges could be filed against these folks. In today's social media world, a couple of the offenders even posted how they slipped off the wristband and went out. Social media has created a lot of idiots. Edited: 4 years ago

subject: 33. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Travel Ban Update CE Carrie Lam announced this afternoon that starting Wednesday, non-residents would banned from entry into Hong Kong for the next 14 days (see link). This ruling excludes non-residents arriving from the mainland, Macau or Taiwan who will still be allowed in, as long as they hadn't been anywhere else in the world in the past 14 days. However, those coming from Macau and Taiwan will also have to go into quarantine for 14 days. Further exclusion - Macau residents who have been in other countries over the past 14 days will still be allowed to fly into Hong Kong airport, but will be taken straight to their home city by coach. https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1516270-20200323.htm South China Morning Post adds that effect Wednesday, there will be ban the sale of alcohol at more than 8,000 bars and restaurants to contain the spread of the coronavirus (see link) https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3076426/hong-kong-ban-all-tourists-battle-coronavirus-spread

subject: 34. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: The alcohol ban is to be self-policed for now by the establishments. I am sure there will be places that find ways to get around it or just blatantly ignore it. Some sort of legislation might be necessary. Yesterday, at least several people were caught on video/photos walking around while wearing the quarantine wristbands. A couple even begged others to give them a chance when they were dining out. The government is "considering" charges. This baffles me at times. The government should just come out and prosecute all violators aggressively instead of giving them any chances. Also, why is it so hard to set up a hotline to report violators? It should be a one day thing, not a multiple day exercise.

subject: 36. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: There is no timeline for an actual alcohol ban as it requires a change of the law, as basically the liquor licenses have to be suspended. Considering the government has proven unable (or unwilling?) to close places where large groups of people spend extended time in close proximity such as cinemas, I doubt they can really stop the sale of alcohol in bars/restaurants. Limiting opening hours will be pretty tough already, and I'm not sure if Carrie Lam is willing to risk using the emergency laws again.

subject: 37. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: If they write the legislation, then it becomes illegal. However, our government has proved to be non-assertive when it comes to enforcing any of these measures. Just keep in mind that ignoring any government advice or laws aren't limited to HK only. You see plenty of that worldwide--Italy, UK, US. It's human nature so not a specific problem that only the HK government faces.

subject: 50. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: You can always find rule breakers and rule abiders. Walking in Central yesterday, there were far far fewer domestic helpers hanging out. The ones that were there mostly followed the rules. I didn't see the really large groups. TV showed the pedestrian tunnel underneath Connaught Road Central, claiming there were lots of people. Believe me, the density is way lower than it normally is. A faction of the city loves to criticize the government regardless of what they do. If we shut down the city and tell all dining outlets to close, they will probably criticize as well. I have no problem with the criticism but let's see them come up with some proposed solutions at the same time. Also, make sure to compare HK's situation to Italy, Spain, UK and even the US. Please tell me what they are doing better. If I must guess, HGY, sans face mask, and hanging out at parties, probably was one of the first ones to get exposed. Edited: 4 years ago

subject: 58. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: >> Since nearly all "bars" are actually licensed as restaurants this will, I predict, have minimal effect, It is defined as places where alcohol is sold as main business, something like that. So indeed watering holes that happen to also sell food (indeed pretty much all of them in HK) are now closed. Restaurant/bar combos have to close the bar part only, not the restaurant part. There it's no more than four people per table; 1.5m distance between those tables; and max half capacity. But indeed there are many establishments that are unsure of whether they have to close wholly or partly: https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1518700-20200403.htm?spTabChangeable=0 Anyway, another step on the road to total shutdown of daily life in HK... subject: 61. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: >>> Recently, there will be a lockdown in Hong Kong for the next 14 days. This may or may not happen. At this point, we don't know. Malls, shops, offices, restaurants - all are still open, albeit restaurants at limited capacity and limited evening hours. Public transport is fully up and running, bar some MTR service reductions on currently redundant routes, such as the Airport Express and the Disneyland Resort Line. Happy praying, but don't count on this virus to go away. Pray for it to run its course not too fast so we can build some basic immunity while hospitals don't get too overloaded, and it can find its place between all the other viruses we call "flu" or "cold", and life can go back to normal. That's going to take easily another 6-12 months.

subject: 69. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Recently in the news a complaint that many deaths in the UK were not appropriately credited to the coronavirus, especially for people dying in a care home. Only by looking back we can get an estimate; an unusually high peak of deaths (normally in winter the number of deaths is far higher than in summer) which can be accredited to this virus, plus probably a good number of others, people who would have died that winter anyway but it just happened to be the coronavirus that was the last straw. Then the problem that measurements of the numbers of people that are infected are often way too low - today it was reported that based on recently donated blood some 3% of the Dutch now have been infected with the virus (and of course recovered, as otherwise they wouldn't be allowed to donate), that'd mean half a million infections, while there are just over 28,000 confirmed infections in the country. That suggests just 5% of the infections makes it into the statistics. There is no extensive testing for the disease, only severe cases are formally tested. Then there rae the many people that may die or lose part of their remaining life due to cancelled/delayed medical procedures, including cancer treatment. Plus the years lost due to the stress caused by having your business collapse and ending up riddled in debt, maybe losing your home in the process, etc. The economic cost will be very hard to estimate. Many businesses collapse, quite a few of whom no doubt were the weaker ones, creating openings for new businesses to pop up (a recession is not necessarily a bad thing). People out of jobs, but likely the economy can revive quickly when it's all over and jobs will return, especially the tourism related ones as people are most likely just postponing travel plans rather than cancelling forever. Too bad the HK government doesn't seem to care much about the unemployed. Even the US is doing a lot better on that front at the moment.

usertext: I just had a call with Hong Kong Airport and she said I can enter Hong Hong via ground from Mainland China as a USA citizen if I have been there for at least 14 days. I then called immigration to confirm and they told me to read the website and follow the rules stated there (which I have many times). "Health quarantine arrangements on inbound travelers from the Mainland, Macao or Taiwan, including Hong Kong and *non-Hong Kong residents*: " Compulsory quarantine at designated places (home or other accommodation) apart from the exempted persons under the "Compulsory Quarantine of Certain Persons Arriving at Hong Kong Regulation" "Restrictions on Entering Hong Kong The Hong Kong SAR Government restricts any Hubei residents, and non-Hong Kong residents who have visited the Hubei Province in the past 14 days upon arrival from entering Hong Kong since January 27, 2020. With effect from 0.00am on March 25, 2020 until further notice: All non-Hong Kong residents coming from overseas countries and regions *by plane* will be denied entry to Hong Kong; and Non-Hong Kong residents coming from the Mainland, Macao and Taiwan will be denied entry to Hong Kong *if they have been to any overseas countries and regions in the past 14 days." So from this, As a non-resident, I can enter HK through Shenzhen by as I have not been to any other overseas countries and regions in the past 14 days. Then would go through the 14 day quarantine at a hotel. Is my understanding correct? I wish immigration could be clearer on this, but no one there wants to take the blame if they give the wrong information when asked. I'm a US citizen in Mainland for the past 5 months and used up my 60day visa, + the one time extension + the 30 day stay permit and the entry/exit bureau here say I need to leave by the end of my permit. subject: 116. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Hong Kong Covid testing on airport arrival (27 June 2020) Any person entering Hong Kong through the Airport must undergo Covid testing. Those who test positive are taken to hospital for treatment, while those who test negative are required to isolate for 14-days. There seems to be some discretion as to whether the incoming traveller must serve the quarantine at their home or a government facility. Our flight touched down shortly before 11am. Upon disembarking the aircraft, we were channelled to a section of the arrivals hall. The health clearance involves multiple steps. First, to show a health declaration - either complete through the government's app and show the QR code or on a paper form available at the arrivals hall. All arriving passengers must download a government app and provide a mobile telephone number to be monitored. Fortunately, we had a Hong Kong mobile number otherwise we might have incurred a large roaming bill. Members of one household can share the mobile number. Next, a quick interview on the quarantine procedure. We would have to undergo a Covid-19 test. Those who test negative could leave for their own place of quarantine for 14 days. Those who test positive would be sent to a hospital. Following the interview, a health official installed a wrist band that must be worn for the entire quarantine period. Then, another interview to receive and accept the notice of quarantine. Following that, we went to the immigration counters, which process is the same as pre-Covid. After passing through the immigration and collecting luggage, we exited through the Customs green lane. Outside, staff directed us to a bus. Then began the waiting. Initially, about 10 minutes for the bus to move and then after 20 or so metres, to wait again along the road. After another 10 minutes, the driver started the bus again and drove the short distance to the EXPO. At the EXPO, we alighted and walked into the Hall, only to be told that the stop was just to deposit checked luggage. We (with only hand held luggage) should have remained on the bus. Anyhow, after another 10 minutes, the other passengers had deposited their luggage and reboarded the bus. The driver took us for another short drive to the other side of the EXPO, where we alighted - finally for the Covid-19 test. We were briefed on the test, given the test materials - a paper funnel and plastic screw-top tube in plastic bags. We skipped the video explanation and walked to the next section to deliver the saliva. It was quite easy for me to fill the small tube (about 10 ml?) but challenging for my wife. Finally, she completed the work and we handed the sealed tubes to the waiting staff, and walked to the next section. And then the long wait began. In the cavernous hall, about 75 metres square, small tables were placed at distances of about 2 metres. Each traveller is assigned to a separate table, but families are allowed to pull chairs to sit together. By the time that we arrived, at around 1pm, the hall was about two-thirds full. The official document stated that we could expect to wait for 8 hours. Passengers whose flights arrived before 12pm could wait in the Hall. Those on later flights would be sent to a hotel to wait overnight. In the hall, passengers on the early morning flights from North America had been waiting since 7am. Some had come well prepared and pitched portable tents in the hall. Around 1pm, staff served sandwiches - either turkey sausage and cheese or vegetarian (tomato, cucumber and cheese). The sandwiches reminded me of national service in the Singapore Army. We could get bottled water from a table on one side of the hall. The staff also helpfully provided some electric power sockets from which travellers could charge their phones. At 3pm, health officials came with forms to release the first batch of travellers. My guess is that the test specimens are despatched in batches to some off-site laboratory and then the forms returned in batches. There was another long wait until 5pm, when a second batch of travellers were released. I guessed that the bureaucracy worked on two hour batches and that we would have to wait until 7pm. Happily, I was wrong. We (the third and last batch in our Hall) were released at 6.30pm. We missed the 6.45pm Airport Express train and had to wait half an hour for the 7.15pm train. And then home to self-quarantine. On arrival, we had to initialize the wristband. The traveller has 60 seconds to walk around their home to enable the wristband detect nearby bluetooth devices. These serve to fix the location of the wristband. (I wonder if we could take a walk with the wristband and all of the nearby Bluetooth devices.) The next day (first day of quarantine), the health authority called to confirm that we were at home. My wife got the Cantonese version which seemed to take twice as long as my version in English. Another 13 days to go.

usertext: New increased measures for entry into HK The SAR has gazetted new measures against imported cases of Covid-19 with people who have visited areas deemed high risk having to provide detailed proof that they don't have the disease. From next Saturday (25 July 2020) anyone who has visited Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Nepal, Pakistan, the Philippines or South Africa in the past 14 days will need to provide documentary proof from a healthcare institution of a negative Covid-19 nucleic acid test result, with the sample taken in the past 72 hours. Authorities in the country concerned will also have to verify the institution by letter. Original test results, with name and passport number included, will also be needed as will proof of a 14-day hotel booking in Hong Kong for quarantine purposes. https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1538479-20200718.htm

subject: 122. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: EFFECTIVE 00:00 25 JULY 2020: Arrivals from multiple high-risk countries must obtain proof of negative test results before embarking on flights to Hong Kong. Specifications under the Prevention and Control of Disease (Regulation of Cross-boundary Conveyances and Travellers) Regulation gazetted *********************************************************************************** In view of the development and severity of the COVID-19 epidemic situation in Hong Kong, the Government announced today (July 18) that it had gazetted the specifications under the Prevention and Control of Disease (Regulation of Cross-boundary Conveyances and Travellers) Regulation (Cap. 599H) to impose conditions based on public health grounds on travellers who has visited specified high risk places within 14 days before arrival in Hong Kong, in order to further reduce the number of imported cases. The Government is very concerned about the considerable number of imported cases. New cases recorded during the period from June 20 to July 17 include 234 imported cases. A spokesman for the Food and Health Bureau said, "As the epidemic situation evolves and develops, taking into account the limited capacities of our quarantine and isolation facilities, the Government needs to implement measures to prevent imported cases. To this end, having regard to the latest public health risk assessment, we consider it necessary to impose conditions on travellers coming to Hong Kong from high risk places to reduce the health risk they may bring to Hong Kong." Specification by the Secretary for Food and Health ==> A traveller who, on the day on which the traveller boarded a civil aviation aircraft that arrives at, or is about to arrive at Hong Kong (specified aircraft), or during the 14 days before that day, has stayed in any specified place (i.e. Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Nepal, Pakistan, the Philippines and South Africa), must provide the following documents: (1) a letter or certificate in English or Chinese issued by a laboratory or healthcare institution bearing the name and identity card or passport number of the relevant traveller to show that: (a) the relevant traveller underwent a nucleic acid test for COVID-19 the sample for which was taken from the relevant traveller within 72 hours before the scheduled time of departure of the specified aircraft; (b) the test conducted on the sample is a nucleic acid test for COVID-19; and (c) the result of the test is that the relevant traveller was tested negative for COVID-19; (2) the original of the report for the test issued by the laboratory or healthcare institution bearing the name and identity card or passport number of the relevant traveller; (3) a letter in English or Chinese issued by the relevant authority of the government of the place in which the laboratory or healthcare institution is located certifying that the laboratory or healthcare institution is recognised or approved by the government; and (4) the relevant traveller has confirmation in English or Chinese of room reservation in a hotel in Hong Kong for not less than 14 days starting on the day of the arrival of the relevant traveller in Hong Kong. The operator of the specified aircraft should submit to the Department of Health (DH) before the specified aircraft arrives at Hong Kong a document in a form specified by the DH confirming that each relevant traveller has, before being checked-in for the flight to Hong Kong on the aircraft, produced for boarding on the aircraft the above documents. ===> The relevant specifications will come into effect at 0.00am on July 25, 2020, and will remain effective until further notice. In addition, a person who is in transit in Hong Kong, and a person exempted by the Chief Secretary for Administration from compulsory quarantine under section 4(1) of either the Compulsory Quarantine of Certain Persons Arriving at Hong Kong Regulation (Cap. 599C) or Compulsory Quarantine of Persons Arriving at Hong Kong from Foreign Places Regulation (Cap. 599E) will not be affected. If any conditions specified by the Secretary for Food and Health is not met in relation to any relevant traveller on the conveyance, each of the operators of the conveyance commits an offence, and is liable on conviction to the maximum penalty of a fine at level 5 ($50,000) and imprisonment for six months. If an operator fails to comply with a requirement to provide information, or knowingly or recklessly provides any information that is false or misleading in a material particular, he or she is liable on conviction to the maximum penalty of a fine at level 5 ($50,000) and imprisonment for six months. As for travellers, if a traveller coming to Hong Kong fails to comply with a requirement to provide information, or knowingly or recklessly provides any information that is false or misleading in a material particular, he or she is liable on conviction to the maximum penalty of a fine at level 3 ($10,000) and imprisonment for six months. Travellers to Hong Kong should note that they will be mandated to wait for their test results at a designated location after their deep throat saliva samples are collected for conducting testing for COVID-19 at the DH's Temporary Specimen Collection Centre pursuant to the Prevention and Control of Disease Ordinance (Cap. 599). If their test results are negative, they will be allowed to go to the hotel for which they made the reservation to continue the 14-day compulsory quarantine until completion. If their results are positive, the travellers will be transferred to hospital for isolation and treatment. The Government will continue to monitor closely the situation including the development of the epidemic situation both globally and locally and changes in the volume of cross-boundary passenger traffic, and will not hesitate to adopt further measures if necessary. Ends/Saturday, July 18, 2020 Issued at HKT 1:47 NNNN https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202007/18/P2020071800038.htm

subject: 126. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: FRIDAY 24 JULY 2020 HKG ARRIVAL AND COVID TESTING PROCESS Friend flew Friday 24 July from Manila to HKG on Philippine Airline. She beat by one day the new rules requiring a negative Covid test 72 hours before boarding the plane (now in place for passengers from high risk countries such as Pakistan, Iran, India, Kazakhstan, Philippines, the USA) - short flight, said 100% of passengers with masks & 85% with plastic face shields for additional protection, plane arrived an hour early @9:00 am due to less air traffic - prior to leaving Manila, she downloaded the HK electronic travel form so as to save time in HK and not have to fill-in the paper copy - cleared immigration and customs and then was bused to the adjacent Asia-World convention centre where she provided a saliva sample at 10:00 am and was put in a large room with tables and chairs (2 meters apart) to wait for test results. - Around 3:00 pm staff provided stale sandwiches. No other food options available in holding area. - 10 hours later, at 8:00 pm I showed up outside waiting for her. - 3:00 am (17 hours later) test results finally came back - negative as expected, although on her flight there were 9 women who tested positive and will be immediately hospitalized in HK. Suggestions to consider: - consider arriving after 12:00 noon so that you don't have to wait at the airport for 10-18 hours. Instead you will be bussed with other passengers to a Kowloon hotel and provided a private room where can sleep, get modest food, and await test result. - If waiting at the airport, bring large battery bank to keep electronics charged for 12-18 hours. There are charging stations but they are crowded and not much social distancing - Transfer some food into your carry-on bag before leaving customs zone. Once you leave customs, you will be separated from you luggage until you are released from holding area with negative Covid result, then you can collect you bags and go to quarantine hotel (required if from high risk country...list changes so check website). Note, HK customs has almost no food restrictions so fresh fruit, meat, etc can all be brought from other countries. Zero duty on beer and wine. - You can sleep at your table, maybe bring a pillow. Some people brought yoga mats to sleep on the concert floor, but staff said no, it's not clean there. After receiving negative test result she was released to pick up her luggage and went outside where I picked her up with private car and delivered her to a quarantine hotel in TST, Butterfly on Prat (14 nights @US$60/night). Other available transportation options at 3:00 am were taxis. There didn't seem to be any enforcement of transportation options.

subject: 152. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: >> have seen restaurants and bars turn away customers without an proper N95 or better surgical mask. N95, let alone better, you won't be able to find anywhere in the world unless you have special access to medical stocks. Any mask on the market now is not certified, the production process and raw materials are possibly not even tested. Some will advertise with testing certificates, but unless you can verify that this certificate is for the actual product, and is indeed issued by a trustworthy and independent organisation, such a certificate is worth no more than the paper it's printed on. i have never been turned away at a restaurant with my reusable cloth masks (the government issued one actually works quite well with the filter removed: now my breath goes mostly through the cloth instead of almost all around it to the extent that I'm blowing in my own eyes). Restaurant owners are too desperate for business, just to have a fighting chance to keep their business alive. Point in case, just last week I was having my breakfast in a Cafe de Coral outlet where the temperature checking machine was not monitored and generally just didn't work, and where occupancy was way over 50%. I was sitting on a shared table without screen between me and the stranger - I don't know if that is allowed. I do know that in the school where I work it's definitely not allowed due to government regulations! Corona-fatigue is definitely setting in. Hong Kong kept it up for very long already, 9 months or so by now. Not many countries can claim such a willingness of the population to cut down on activities to help slowing the spread of this virus. I haven't been advertising my local guided tours for a year, yet tour or information requests are coming in on a regular basis - nearly daily. More than when I was advertising, and I have the feeling the rate is increasing. Sitting at home all day long does get old after a while!

subject: 153. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: N95? I have not seen any normal people walking around wearing one since March when there weren't enough masks of any kind to go around. These days, surgical (or ones that look alike without the function) are easily available. Most restaurants enforce the mask and temperature taking policy pretty well. On the other hand, most also ignore the capacity restriction. The tea cafes next to my office are often 75% to 80% full for breakfast and lunch. Only the large chains and hotels have reduced their seating capacity. I have no problems with the social distancing policies currently in place. They are easy enough to follow. The only inconvenience I experience is office lunch and family gatherings when we have more than 4 people. Yesterday, we had 9 so we sat 4-3-2 across three tables which felt ridiculous. Otherwise, post summer, mask-wearing doesn't feel as suffocating as a few weeks ago. As to "fatigue", I haven't cut down on going out so I am not experiencing it much. I have gone to work and gone out on weekends just as I normally would. I am past the party age so the late night restrictions have no bearing on me. On the other hand, I know there are families, especially ones with younger children, that were so afraid to leave the house that they have mostly stayed home for months. I am sure they feel less "balanced" as a whole. Finally, based on numbers alone, I see justification in opening the border between HK, China and Macau for selected people. Politics aside, they should at least allow business folks with testing to travel back-and-forth and see how it goes. Edited: 4 years ago

subject: 166. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Passengers on flight arriving in the afternoon and evening will be sent to the government designated holding centre for test result hotel for the first night of their arrival, and are only allowed to proceed to their 14 day quarantine hotel the next day after receipt of a negative result from their Covid-19 test administered at the airport on arrival. This is done as tests administered later in the day cannot produce results the same day. Currently the designated hotel is the Rambler Garden Hotel at Tsing Yi. It is not a very nice hotel at all. Below is my review of my one night stay at the hotel while awaiting my test result in November 2020: As my flight into Hong Kong International Airport arrived in the evening, I was required to stay in the government designated holding center for test result hotel - Rambler Garden Hotel - for the first night of my arrival to await the result of my Covid-19 test administered at the airport on landing. The whole arrival process was very tiring. I exited the plane door at around 7:10 pm and it was about 12:30 am before I arrived at my hotel room at Rambler Garden Hotel with almost the entire process being standing in line waiting for the next step. On arrival at the hotel on the shuttle bus, hotel staff dressed in full protective gear quickly took out our luggage from the shuttle bus before we were then allowed to get off the bus, collect our luggage and proceed to line up to check in. Check in was quick since we only needed to collect our room key, the cost of the stay being paid for by the government. While I was very conscious of keeping some distance between me and the other guests in the check-in line, most people lined up right behind each other, though everyone was required to wear a mask. Just before the elevators to the rooms, the hotel set up a table to hand out a boxed meal dinner, in this case a very mild curry chicken and potato stew with rice and a box of oolong tea. The hotel room is small and very basic. There were two twin beds right next to each other with a little bedside table at the side. There was a TV set up high on the wall at one corner of the room, an empty cabinet except for the hot water kettle and coffee and tea packs, and a very small low table or seat. The bathroom was very tiny and my knees could almost touch the door when seated on the toilet. There was no toilet paper in the holder but there was a new roll of toilet paper on the counter. There was a brand new mini fridge but it was not installed and instead sat on the window sill still wrapped in plastic. The room seemed fine for one evening except that the next morning, in the light of day, I could see that the floor was very dirty and does not appear to have been swept or vacuumed, and that the paint on the wall had piece sticking out and cracks near the bottom where the wall joins the baseboard. There was also paint splatter on the door. Everything seems to have been cheaply put together and not in good condition. The next morning, around 8:30 am, a box set breakfast of glutinous rice wrap and dim sum, with a box of apple juice, was left at my door. We were told we would receive our test results between 11 am and 3 pm, and that if it was negative we must leave the hotel within 25 minutes. Until then, we were strictly forbidden from leaving our room. In fact, there was a sign taped to the door indicating if you leave your room to smoke, you will be reported to the police. Confusingly, while I was in the room the next morning waiting for my result, around 11:15 am housekeeping actually used their master key to open my door causing me to shout out that I am in a mandatory quarantine stay and had not left yet. About 5 minutes later, reception called me around 11:20 am advising I could now leave the hotel. Check out was quick as again we did not have to pay for the stay ourselves. I then took a taxi to travel to the quarantine hotel I arranged for myself for my mandatory self-quarantine. I did note though that staff were very friendly and helpful offering to help with luggage and directing guests to the taxi line or other mode of transportation they selected. Fortunately it was a one night stay only, and as it was mandated and paid for by the Hong Kong government, there is really no choice involved and nothing to be done to avoid this hotel other than to make sure you take a flight arriving in the morning rather than afternoon or evening or to wait until the government's contract with this hotel expires and the government selects another hotel.

subject: 167. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: @VancTraveller: thanks for the detailed report. Just yesterday, I happened to see a video of a local couple documenting their first night quarantine stay at the same hotel. It seems to be consistent with what you described. One thing they noted was lack of cleanliness. They found hairs on the bed. There is some debate as to whether one should plan to arrive early or late. The benefit of arriving late is they will put you in the hotel instead of making you wait for your test results (which could take anywhere from 3-12 hours). The drawback is you have to stay at this not-so-great hotel even though it's free. Within the few days, the government might introduce a policy to quarantine arriving passengers at designated hotels.

subject: 168. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: >> One thing they noted was lack of cleanliness. They found hairs on the bed. Doesn't surprise me based on the description of the hotel and its facilities, but quite disturbing considering it's a quarantine hotel with high guest turnover.

subject: 169. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: There was definitely no enhanced cleaning in the room I was put in on arrival while waiting for my test result the next day. There were all kinds of debris on the floor that I could see the next morning in the daylight. That said, I suspect they probably have a policy that if you do test positive, then your room would probably get a disinfectant clean. If you test negative, I suppose they think your risk of contaminating the room you occupied with transmissible virus might be low. Hong Kong government just announced today that arriving passengers to Hong Kong will in the future be required to quarantine at designated hotels. Hotels have to opt into this program and if they become a designated hotel for quarantine passengers, then they cannot accept other guests. In addition, they must arrange bus transportation for the quarantine guests to the designated hotel so that guests will not need to take public transportation. When I arrived, after I received my negative test result the next morning, I was allowed to leave Rambler Garden Hotel and travel to my quarantine hotel by whatever means I chose such as taxi, MTR subway, bus etc. It was not clear when the new quarantine hotel rules would come into effect as they would need to allow time for hotels to sign up for the program and clear out their other guests so they can be an exclusively quarantine guests hotel. The reason given for the change in rules is that as Christmas approaches, a lot of overseas students would be returning to Hong Kong for the holiday season.

subject: 223. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: @senior travelers (post 222) My guess is that sometime in Spring 2022 is more realistic than October 2021 at this juncture in time and here some things you can watch for Hong Kong and Macau officials have just recently restarted talks about opening a quarantine-free travel bubble. This may happen in July 2021 and will be a big test for how and when HK go about reopening to the rest of the world. I would guess that it is most likely that we will be reopen to mainland China in some restricted/limited capacity for quarantine free travel by October. There is also a HK <> Singapore bubble that has been attempted twice but yet to materialise. That will likely be the next if things work out with quarantine free travel to Macau and mainland China. I'd give this a 33-50% chance by October 2021 There is some chance that other regional places that are considered low-risk for quarantine free travel by October 2021. Candidates would be the likes of South Korea, Japan, Cambodia, Australia and New Zealand. I'd say there is 25-33% chance that some form of other regional bubbles start to open this Autumn. By January 2022 I would say this is 50-66% likely. Any way you look at it, you need to see travel restrictions relax for these places first before the HK Authorities begin to consider lifting restrictions more broadly and to countries that are considered higher risk. As for travellers from Europe, North America and the likes, I'd say 1-5% chance by October 2021. In all honestly, I would say 0% but you never know. If further helpful, based on how HK authorities have handed travel restrictions to date, I'd would guess January 2022 (33% chance), April 2022 (50-66% chance), July 2022 (66-75% chance), Sept 2022 (80%+ chance) for open quarantine free travel into HK. These could easily change depending on vaccination drives, how the pandemic is handled by various other countries and other factors but these are the odds I'd give based on what we know today.

subject: 225. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Based on recent reports, I think the HK/SIN travel bubble will not happen (or not last), and that quarantine-free travel from Europe/US/most of Asia to HK will also be a very long term thing. First the Singapore bubble: this is based on both sides having less than n local cases a day for x number of days, upon which a limited number of (vaccinated) travellers may go quarantine free. Singapore appears to have completely blown this up: https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/singapore-covid-plan-intl-hnk/index.html?utm_source=pocket-newtab-intl-en Basically, Singapore wants to halt their (so far unattainable) zero-infection policy, instead letting covid be. Stop testing, cancel restrictions, making sure people take their responsibility (are you sick? stay at home) and live with it like we live with so many other diseases such as the common cold and the flu, and allow visitors in without quarantine basically like it used to be. That's not compatible with the travel bubble idea, that will result in way too many virus carriers. HK not opening to the world quarantine free: that's not going to happen until China does so, and China so far has one of the most restrictive entry regimes. The current priority for HK is to reopen travel between the city and China and Macau (both supposedly the same country), and for that the zero-infection policy must stay: https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1598982-20210703.htm China has been making a HUGE point on how the CCP managed to protect their country from covid, how they managed to keep their people safe and healthy from this disease, while most of the rest of the world made a huge mess with everybody getting sick and scored dying. How that propaganda can be made compatible with opening the borders and allowing the disease to go around like what Singapore is suggesting, I don't know. HK apparently chose to give priority to travel between HK and China (and Macau). That means that until China changes its policies on covid, travel between HK and the rest of the world will have to remain severely restricted, with 21-day quarantines regardless of vaccination status, pre-flight testing, and total entry bans for certain groups like travellers from the UK. On top of all that, HK is in an election year (for what it's worth), so the 4-person social gathering ban is politically very convenient.

usertext: I've been supportive of HK's anti-Covid policy, reducing cases to near zero and keeping them there but this insistence on fully quarantined borders and reduced school hours is not sustainable in the medium- or long-term. Whereas vaccination is. Incrementally but fully opening up race tracks, theme parks, stadiums, gyms, pools, hotels, restaurants and bars to VACCINATED PEOPLE ONLY (and schools to the children of vaccinated parents) is the only sensible policy to nudge a reluctant population towards herd immunity. And then we might even have safe travel too! Languishing at below 50% double jabbed is just embarrassing and will leave the city behind its competitors and its residents trapped. How can they not see this?

subject: 239. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Having no COVID whatsoever in the city is not exactly an incentive to get vaccinated - if it's not a risk, what's the reason to protect yourself against it? The general depression the government is instilling on the people nowadays is another disincentive. This is of course not limited to not having a clear, sensible and workable COVID exit strategy - there is none - but also the general political situation. Mind also that the vast majority of the population doesn't have the means to travel or so anyway. For many the closed border is very much a relief from the overcrowding caused by tourists and parallel traders. This zero-case policy has been a dead end from the get go. Edited: 3 years ago

subject: 247. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong

subject: 248. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong

subject: 257. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: As this is all omicron-based I wonder how long before the whole world is added to that list. That variant appears to be spreading fast (which in itself is of course rather unsurprising). Singapore reported its first local omicron transmission already as well... so probably will also be added to that list. This also means that arrivals to HK are severely restricted as Penny's Bay can't handle the load, the numbers I find indicate there are only 2,300 units total, minus the 1,000 in use for quarantining domestic helpers leaving a mere 1,300 for general quarantine. This means no more than some 200 arrivals a day from this group A list, or 400 a day if all units house two people. Many travellers are likely forced to rebook their flights as they have to secure quarantine accommodation in Penny's Bay. On the upside, finding space in quarantine hotels should become a lot easier with these restrictions on inbound numbers. It also really makes me wonder what is going to happen if there's another case such as those Cathay pilots which saw 260 people put in mandatory quarantine, as Penny's Bay will now most of the time be full.

subject: 258. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Having just gone through the tough 21 days quarantine (also triple vaccinated) and more than 10 PCR tests from start to finish. And all necessary documents with matching First, middle, last name. Not to mention hotel (now Penny Bay for first 7 days), flights (many are being cancelled--CX, AA for example flying from the US), 72 hrs PCR test, CLIA certificate etc etc all coordinated exactly, any change for even a day can upset the whole arrangement. I have a feeling those who choose and do end up entering Hong Kong have to be determined, flexible and got time to spare and staying for awhile. Plus all the expenses. I can't imagine the casual tourist will want to waste 14-21 days coop up in a hotel (or Penny Bay for 7) and then leave HK shortly thereafter (returning students for holidays??) That's the price HKSAR is willing to pay to severely restrict importation of the virus. Their focus is to open up with Mainland first.

subject: 278. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: I agree they are trying to fight a battle that's impossible to win. With their frequently changing policies, they are just creating panic unnecessarily. Zero-Covid is simply impossible to achieve. Let's say they "win" this battle and get themselves to zero infections in a couple of months. Guess what? The moment they open up the border to a foreign place (including China), the disease will creep back into the population. A very good example is New Zealand. They held out for the longest time with an excellent managed isolation quarantine program. Once Omicron hit, they realized the zero Covid goal has become futile changes were made regarding. They have already opened to Australia and they will open to the rest of the world's vaccinated travelers in a few weeks. At present, it's the HK government's fault that they are overloading hospital capacity. It's also entirely unnecessary to shut down so much of the economy trying to achieve an impossible goal. I don't think expats and companies were leaving due to the social movement a couple of years ago. Now, they are really moving because you just don't want to live in or do business in a place that continues to make daily life difficult.

subject: 281. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Outbound is generally not affected by these flight bans - at least not directly. And indeed, for the past two years or so, there's been a major outflow of people. As Hong Kong is enclosed by a vast ocean on one side and a vast country (the borders of which are well and thoroughly shut) flying is effectively the primary way of getting in or out at the moment. subject: 290. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: The "circuit breaker" flight suspension mechanism whereby airlines have been penalised for carrying infected passengers is amended from 1st April so that the suspension period is reduced from 14 days to 7 days; "On the premise of continuing the measures to guard against the importation of cases, the Government requires that all airlines must stringently enforce the boarding requirements for inbound travellers, so as to reduce the risk of importation of cases as far as practicable, and will continue to impose the flight suspension mechanism against specific non-compliant routes based on the streamlined triggering criteria, where if on the same flight there are (i) three or more passengers tested positive for COVID-19 by arrival test, or (ii) one or more passenger(s) is/are tested positive for COVID-19 by arrival test and one or more non-compliant case(s), i.e. failed to comply with the requirement(s) specified under (Cap. 599H), the passenger flights of that route from the relevant airline from the same origin place will be prohibited from landing in Hong Kong for seven days". I doubt that will encourage airlines to increase flight schedules but hopefully a step towards ending this measure altogether.

subject: 292. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: The main problem for inbound travellers at them moment is the lack of quarantine hotel rooms. Mandatory quarantine is now 14 days, there's talk about reducing that to 7 days, but no confirmation yet. Of course changes in regulations can come at any moment - this "circuit breaker" change came just a few hours after Carrie Lam herself said there were no plans of changing this. Quarantine hotel space should start to increase soon again, as a good number of these designated hotels were taken out of the pool to serve as isolation facilities for covid patients that don't need treatment. Those hotels are slowly being transferred back to the quarantine pool. This means more overseas travellers can enter Hong Kong, including a great number of residents now stuck in UK, US and other restricted countries, and of course a replenishment of the foreign domestic helper supply (I know, it's about people, but this particular cohort is commonly talked about as a commodity). Now of interest: Hong Kong has scheduled the 7s for later this year (November, iirc), and the financial secretary has said already that HK will host a major business forum at the same time: https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1640548-20220323.htm The only way such a forum - and the 7s event itself - has any chance of success is a full reopening of the border, and a full cancellation of all covid related restrictions. This is not even part of the current "roadmap", which sees social gathering limits to increase to 8 people by this summer. I recall reading about other government bureaus expecting to restart inbound tourism soon, talking about some 9-10 million arrivals within this year. I can't find the reference at the moment. It was unclear whether they were thinking of mainland or overseas visitors. The government has also not given any explanation on how their current restrictions, or the relaxed restrictions promised for this summer, are remotely compatible with the mass events they plan to organise for the 1 July 25th anniversary of the establishment of the HKSAR. However the fact that this has been announced as such is very interesting. On the other hand, Carrie Lam has said that opening the border with the mainland is still top priority... for that to happen we would need to find all infected people and isolate them, and tighten the border restrictions big time.... totally opposite the current trend. https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1640466-20220323.htm So there are clear hints of Hong Kong opening up within this year, but uncertainty remains. Over the next few months more details are bound to appear.

subject: 293. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Like all governments worldwide (HK is not any worse in my view), all the different agencies have their own agendas. To me, that's just a way to ensure they get funding. It might be tourism bureau, HKTDC, or any other agency involved. Also, it's unlikely that they receive any concrete information from the heads of the government anyway. Therefore, they are all acting "business-as-usual." Meanwhile, the CE continues to waffle between relaxing the policies and still wanting to achieve "dynamic zero" Covid. It would be much better if they just choose one way and stick with it. Now, HK is just disconnected from both China and the rest of the world. We just don't know how long this will last.

subject: 294. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: The financial secretary has (or at least should have) regular close contact with the CE, as one of the highest ranked ministers, so I really do expect them to be on the same page... but then the same accounts for the health secretary (especially now), and she and the CE also often appear to contradict one another. Tourism Board and even the HA are not involved in policy making indeed. Indeed it seems that the government has no idea what they want, and can't (don't want to? are not allowed by China to?) make up their mind on this and pick a clear direction. This ongoing uncertainty is one of the main sources of stress with the Hong Kong people, both those now in HK and those currently overseas trying to go home.

subject: 306. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Alan J Per the https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk - website details about the 7 day self monitoring, there is a full breakdown of what requirements are included (see link) https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/pdf/selfmonitoring_travellers_ENG.pdf To the point of highest interest for you see #6 - Use the"LeaveHomeSafe" mobile app to record your whereabouts and check whether you have visited any venue as with a COVID-19 patient at about the same time What this means is that you are free to move about in the city but must make use of the 'LeaveHomeSafe' mobile app to record where you go and the times you enter pretty much all buildings, parks or anywhere you see the green sign with barcode while you are out of your home/hotel accommodation.

subject: 321. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: You will have to direct that question to the Department of Health. When leaving HK myself a week ago we did not have to show any test certificate, though temperature checks were done (luckily for those infected, fever is one of the less common symptoms for those that have symptoms to begin with). Unless obviously sick, we'd have been able to leave without issues. Your case is different as when testing positive on your mandatory test you may be incarcerated in a hospital until fully recovered. After all, the government would definitely be aware of your infection. My guess is that they will not let you leave just like that, however for a sure answer again contact the Department of Health.

subject: 328. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: The current quarantine requirements are detailed in the link below; https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202208/08/P2022080800803.htm Provided you don't test positive during your quarantine period you would be free to leave the quarantine hotel on the Thursday morning. If I interpret the following paragraph correctly as long as you meet the vaccine requirements you'll be issued a green QR code on confirmation of DQH booking and subsequently a provisional vaccine pass enabling you to visit premises subject to both active and passive checking. However, it all seems ridiculously complicated and I may be wrong; "If inbound persons' vaccination declaration meets boarding requirements, they will be issued a green health declaration QR code upon successful confirmation of DQH booking information by the system. Persons holding a green health declaration QR code will not be required to further verify vaccination records and confirmation of DQH booking at check-in for their flights. Upon arrival at Hong Kong, they can also use the "express channels" with the green health declaration QR code and board the point-to-point transportation to DQHs. The system will issue quarantine orders, medical surveillance notices, vaccination records and Provisional Vaccine Pass QR codes electronically, thus saving them from presenting the documents repeatedly, and hence significantly cutting down the time they need to spend at the airport."

subject: 354. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: "all posts are too old to be relevant." Please look at the most recent forum posts, several are discussing the matter of layovers in Hong Kong which you are asking about. In short, if you decide to exit the restricted area of the airport in order to access Regal Airport Hotel, you will have to take a PCR test and be hopeful that you don't turn positive as if that occurs, you will not be able to reenter the airport and board your outbound flight. As such, the prevailing view on this forum is that, at this time, it is best to stay in the airport and forget about leaving the airport in Hong Kong while in transit. The risk far exceeding any possible convenience of sightseeing for a few hours or even grabbing a bit of sleep at the nearby hotels.

subject: 360. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: One of the few to go after the removal of quarantine, with some trepidation. Airport is empty compared to before and the medical testing on arrival was quick and painless. The multitude of information and tests for a stay take sometime to get used to and requires a level of mobile phone sophistication that many elderly people may find challenging. Daily RAT test , with photo proof was easy , only uploading into app didnt work. PCR test at various centres can be a swarm of people or empty depending on luck. The test there was easy and painless, albeit that you need to be somewhat technical with a phone and good eyesight to read a desktop form on a screen. It was here that I was told that many people could not upload their RAT tests - obviously no remedial corrective feedback loop in place. From arrival to 3rd day your code is amber meaning you can travel about but can not go to restaurants , bars or anywhere that requires you to scan your VACINE/TESTING STATUS. Post 2nd day PCR is negative your code changes from amber to blue and theoretically you can go anywhere , including bars and restaurants. HOWEVER, IF YOU HAVE HAD LESS THAN 3 VACCINE SHOTS you may be blue but will be denied entry to restaurants and bars. The plethora of documentation explaining HK's covid and vaccine information doesn't mention this - maybe I missed it. OVERALL, the system is very disjointed and lacks any feedback and corrective system but individual parts work very well. I wont make any mention of the policy, only wanted to outline the covid arrival process and its biggest failing for stays longer than 3 days.

subject: 364. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: More important unwinding of Covid restrictions beginning tomorrow the Leave Home Safe app and inbound visitors (amber code) are both being axed. In short, the three-day amber health code for incoming travellers is no more and providing they test negative for Covid, arrivals can visit restaurants and bars as soon as they land in the city. However, incoming travellers will still be required to take a PCR test at the airport and do a second one two days later, and perform a rapid antigen test every day for five days. https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1679572-20221213.htm https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1679613-20221213.htm

subject: 388. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: COVID testing requirement as of end of Jan 2023 to enter HK is as minimal as it gets. Get a RAT (rapid antigen test) while in Korea and test yourself within 24 hours prior to your flight from there to HK, take a photo of it and present to your airline to prove negative. That's it. It's the return trip that might be somewhat complicated depending on where you are heading out from HK as the entry requirement of the country you are entering might be different (COVID test), so check the most current rule. When I entered HKG very recently, it felt almost like pre-pandemic. Edited: 2 years ago

subject: 418. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: {And can it just be a standard rapid Covid test? } Any self-administered RAT will do. You simply need to have evidence of the negative test cartridge with penciled name, date and time of test on it on your mobile phone at this juncture in time. The wife and I returned to HK from Europe last week and weren't checked at any stage of the flight by airline, airport or HK Immigration staff. Yet, I would still go ahead and take the test and have the photo on record just in case.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 419. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: How do you pencil the name in for the self administered ones?

subject: 420. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: {How do you pencil the name in for the self administered ones?} Just like you would use a pencil to write on paper. Take the test cartridge that shows a negative result. Physically write your name in the small empty space on the front side of the cartridge where you can see the negative result. Also write the date and time that you took the test. Take a clear picture and keep it on your mobile phone. It is that easy...

subject: 421. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: (How do you pencil the name in for the self administered ones?) I would suggest using a ball pen or felt point marker. That will be clearer in the photo.

subject: 424. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: Post #423. Your understanding is correct. Any self-administered RAT test will do, just keep a photo of it on your mobile phone and you will be fine. Temperature screening at the airport will be the only check of any sort you will have upon arrival. Nobody will ask or be interested in seeing your RAT test upon arrival. Those days are thankfully finished. However, they do ask that you keep a photo of your negative PCR (within 48 hours) or RAT (within 24 hours) test for 90 days for the time being.

subject: 433. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: @uop1497 I believe i might have confused you with the post 430. My response is missing important text that makes it confusing. I've rewritten it below. There are no testing requirements for those who transit through HKG airport. However, there are testing requirements (within 48 hours - PRC) or (within 24 hours - RAT) but they only for Inbound passengers clearing immigration and entering Hong Kong. And interestingly enough, they are not even checking these upon arrival. You are simply requested to have a photo copy of the tests handy. But importantly.... for your transit related question... there are no testing requirements you are only connecting flights in HK and don't plan to leave the airport. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 450. Re: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information in Hong Kong
usertext: HK first began temperature checks on air passengers from 17th April 2003, in respect of departing passengers; https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/200304/16/0416242.htm Checks were extended to arriving and transit passengers from 24th April 2003; https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/200304/23/0423199.htm Checks on departing and transit passengers, but not arriving passengers, were subsequently scrapped sometime after the SARS outbreak subsided but were reintroduced during the covid pandemic from Feb 2020 until being scrapped again in September 2022; https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202209/09/P2022090900694.htm Looking back through archived web pages for the UK Foreign Office travel advice for HK from 2013 right up to the end of 2022, even during the covid pandemic there appears to be no mention of temperature checks. The first reference to temperature only appears to have occurred quite recently, possibly as a reminder of the last remaining inbound travel requirement. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 14. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: We recently received our right to abode and reviewed these issues. The following is worth noting: " Right to Land A person who ceases to have the status of a permanent resident of the HKSAR will automatically acquire the right to land in Hong Kong in accordance with the law. He/She will be able to enter Hong Kong freely to live, study or work without restriction. " My reading is that losing your right of abode is not necessarily a game changer since you appear to have the right to arrive, work, study and stay indefinitely. Those are the rights that were of most interest to our family. Losing our right to vote isn't especially concerning to our family. Perhaps you will feel the same?

subject: 29. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: Adding my experience for anyone interested. I am an overseas born individual that has Permament Resident status with right of abode. Both my parents are HK born and I gained permanent resident status with a 3 star ID card in 1998. After gaining citizenship I returned 3 times within the 3 year windows (2001,2003,2006). I returned after a 7 year hiatus in 2013 for work. Whilst in HK I had no problems gaining long term employment, renewing an expired Home Return permit, obtaining a driving licence or receiving the Cash Payout Schemes (including the most recent handout). To the best of my knowledge I still have 3 star status since I have been able to renew my Home Return permit which is only available to Chinese citizens, even though I had not returned to HK for a 7 year period prior. I came across this thread only because family members and family friends (60+ y/os) were reiterating the same misinformation constantly, which I know from experience to be incorrect. They sourced the information from some Heung Yee Kuk youtube video that's been doing rounds on WhatsApp groups. Hope this helps. Stay safe

subject: 65. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: Departure date, of course. Otherwise people who didn't leave HK for three years straight (I for one have come a long way towards that) would lose their right of abode status instantly... and that just doesn't make sense. Mind: right of abode is about long term residents. Not occasional visitors. Of course you can maintain that status with short visits after having obtained it by long term residence, a nice perk but not the intended purpose of having a resident status. If you fail to visit Hong Kong for three years straight (if your excuse is the corona crisis it meant you were gone for at least 2 1/2 years already showing not much bond with or interest in the place) then you lose the ROA status, and that I think is a very sensible and fair arrangement.

subject: 78. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: it can be confusing but basically the definition of permanent residency in HK does not include those with RTL - even though as an RTL holder you can live and work in HK without restriction. In practical terms the only difference (afaik) is that PR holders are immune from deportation and can register to vote in local elections. As the last few years have shown as well, non-PR's have been excluded from the various Govt handouts (there was a 6k handout a few years ago plus the ongoing 10k handout currently). As an RTL holder, you are still classed as having residency, just not their definition of permanent, so you should be able to enter HK without any issue at the moment. HOwever, please bear in mind that there are certain limitations on all HK residents returning from certain "High risk countries" at the moment (this includes the US and UK) whereby you will need a negative nucleic covid test 72 hours prior to catching your flight, and proof of 14 days hotel accommodation - at a certified quarantine hotel. Without the preflight covid test you will probably be refused by the airline and without the latter...well, I can only assume you will either be carted off to a Govt quarantine camp and charged for the pleasure, or you will simply be refused entry and returned to your country of origin.
