subject: 92. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: @Vinay: Forget the politics. The HK Government is simply like any other government--it's a huge bureaucracy. I know people who work in the government who are middle to high level. I have read their chats and it's amazing how inflexible they are. Also, anything that requires cross departmental cooperation is unlikely to happen quickly. The US or UK governments aren't doing any better though. At least here, we have a low percentage of Covid cases. As to the 2-week quarantine at a hotel, you have zero chance of avoiding it. I already know boarding school and university students who are fleeing the UK due to infections in their dorms. Some of them are still under 16 so a parent must quarantine with them for the entire duration. At this point, they are stuck in a dilemma as to whether they should still pay all that expensive tuition to take Zoom classes, or whether they should enroll back in their old HK school for the next term.

subject: 94. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: One of the students I know actually got very sick. He said he was absolutely miserable with a 40C fever for an entire week. UK hospital would not admit him. All he could do was take panadols to keep the fever down while fearing for his life. Another student said pretty much his whole hall got sick. All the local Brit students were sent home as the school wanted to avoid a further mass breakout. With classes being taught online, there was little reason for him to stay in a foreign land with little support while facing a higher infection risk. That's why he chose to come back. Remember Covid affects people differently. For every story where people said symptoms were minor, there are also stories of people dying, including ones who called Covid a hoax. At the end of the day, it's not up to us to judge whether people are overreacting. We are not their parents. Most parents I know are very worried. Maybe they are all not very smart, or maybe it's really the other way around? This discussion reminds me of a local YouTuber (UncleBob) who went to the UK to avoid Covid here back in February. Eventually, he had to come back to HK where the infection rates are much lower. Edited: 4 years ago

subject: 142. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: Without *** / HK passport, you are not a citizen but if your HKID says "The holder of this card has the right of abode in Hong Kong", then even if you cannot return here within 3 years you will still be allowed to land and live here visa-free under current rules. The *worst* that would happen is that your status would be downgraded to "right to land", which under most circumstances makes little material difference.

subject: 145. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: "do i lose my citizenship / right to abode if i don't turn up?" Because you are not of Chinese descent and don't have *** on your card then your ROA will be downgraded to RTL. However, with RTL you can still live and work in HK as a resident. The actual consequences are really in name only (except for some limited rights extended solely to those with full ROA which have been discussed in this thread previously). I doubt Immigration will extend your time, so unless you make it back here within your 36 month limit, you will be downgraded. FWIW you can still travel to HK from the UK as long as you spend 21 days in another country prior to your HK flight. (you would need to consult the Govt COVID webpage to determine which countries would be allowed).

subject: 146. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: Once again we need to reiterate that if your HKID contains *** then the HK and Chinese Govts consider you to be a Chinese citizen (regardless of whether or not you consider yourself to be one) and YOU ARE NOT SUBJECT TO THE 36 MONTH LIMIT. However, something more important has also been made public recently which impacts many of the people writing on here. If you are born and bred British, American, Canadian, Australian (OR WHEREVER) BUT have a HKID with *** then your foreign nationality is no longer recognised in Hong Kong (it has always been the case for Mainland China). If you enter Hong Kong on your *** ID card, then you will no longer be able to receive foreign consulate help within HK should you need it. The *** means the HK and Chinese Govts consider you to be first and foremost of Chinese Nationality. If you wish to retain your foreign consulate protection whilst travelling in HK and China then you will need to explicitly renounce your Chinese nationality. Unfortunately, this means you will also lose your *** on your HKID. This is why having *** on your ID card means you are no subject to the 36 month limit. There is so much misunderstanding in the overseas Chinese community because they have a habit of relying on poor information via online groups. Conversely, if your HKID gives you ROA but DOES NOT have the *** THEN YOU NEED TO RETURN TO HK EVERY 36 MONTHS TO RENEW YOUR FULL ROA - FAILURE TO DO SO WILL DOWNGRADE YOUR ROA TO RTL. Maybe tripadvisor can put this on a sticky someone where because responding to clueless idiots in this thread is getting to be pretty tedious TBH.

subject: 148. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: There is a significant difference between Right of Abode and Right to Land. For people purchasing HK real estate, there is a 15% Buyer Stamp Tax on the property for people without the Right of Abode. This can be a significant consideration for people who intend to move to HK and purchase a home. Being able to pass on your Right of Abode to your children can also be important, long term considerations (RTL offers no special status for your children even if they're born in HK).

subject: 164. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: I'm not sure that the *** means that HK/the commies regard you as a Chinese national as you have advised. I believe you can have *** and still not be regarded as a Chinese National. The *** only means you are ages over 18 and eligible for a HKSAR re-entry permit. For myself, I had ***RO but I am not classed as a Chinese National as I am Born in UK and both my Hong Kong born parents have already settled aboard at the time my birth. This means I still fall under the 36month rule. According to paragraph 2 of Schedule 1 to the Immigration Ordinance, Cap. 115 (the Schedule), a permanent resident of the HKSAR is - (a) a Chinese citizen born in Hong Kong before or after the establishment of the HKSAR; (b) a Chinese citizen who has ordinarily resided in Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 7 years before or after the establishment of the HKSAR; (c) a person of Chinese nationality born outside Hong Kong before or after the establishment of the HKSAR to a parent who, at the time of birth of that person, was a Chinese citizen falling within category (a) or (b) Under Article 5 of the Nationality Law of the People's Republic of China (CNL), any person born abroad whose parents are both Chinese nationals or one of whose parents is a Chinese national shall have Chinese nationality. But a person whose parents are both Chinese nationals and have both settled abroad, or one of whose parents is a Chinese national and has settled abroad, and who has acquired foreign nationality at birth shall not have Chinese nationality. This is also an interesting read: https://www.sm128c.com/hk/ Edited: 3 years ago

subject: 179. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: Sorry about that, I thought you were allowed to view of a limited number of articles without subscribing. It covers most of what has already been discussed in thread including that Permanent Residents automatically have "right to land" if unable to comply with the 3-year rule and quotes the cases of some who have already spent a considerable amount of money on air fares and hotel quarantine solely to preserve their status. Others have been hoping the Immigration Dept would allow an extension for those unable to travel during the pandemic including some who wish to preserve their status owing to "emotional connections" with HK. In response to the SCMP, the Immigration Department said it did not have the power to waive the 36-month rule or extend the period on the grounds of unforeseeable circumstances, such as the pandemic. But the Director of Immigration can determine whether an individual "has ceased to be ordinarily resident in Hong Kong or is only temporarily absent" through factors such as employment by a Hong Kong-based company and the whereabouts of principal family members. If the person was deemed to be "temporarily absent", he or she would not lose their permanent residency, adding that cases would be assessed individually.

See the following link for details: https://www.ha.org.hk/visitor/ha_visitor_index.asp?Parent_ID=10044&Content_ID=10045&Ver=HTML from which: "Only patients falling into the following categories are eligible for the rates of charges applicable to "Eligible Persons": * holders of Hong Kong Identity Card issued under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Chapter 177), except those who obtained their Hong Kong Identity Card by virtue of a previous permission to land or remain in Hong Kong granted to them and such permission has expired or ceased to be valid; * children who are Hong Kong residents and under 11 years of age; or * other persons approved by the Chief Executive of the Hospital Authority. Persons who are not Eligible Persons are classified as Non-eligible Persons." The charges for "Eligible Persons" exist to stop time-wasters, but are essentially negligible.

subject: 222. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: I've just come back from HK and have managed to retain and keep my PR and ROA despite being absent for 4 years due to the COVID-19 pandemic (I last went back to HK in January 2019). There is somewhat leniency for those who haven't been able to go back to HK, but obviously, the longer you leave it - the harder you will challenge Immigration to retain and keep your PR and ROA. All of this has been confirmed twice - once when my sister asked on my behalf and second when I asked an Immigration Officer when replacing my HKID just last Monday 29th May. I also know a few fellow foreigners who are in the same situation - and they've also kept their 3*** with AO. However, Immigration previously stipulated that everything will be considered on a case-by-case basis when reviewing PR and ROA.

usertext: As far as I know you don't need to be in HK every three years if you have those three stars on your HKID - as that means you're considered a Chinese national. It is different if you got your HKID through 7 years of residency in HK. Then you will use the ROA and end up with RTL instead.

subject: 224. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: Not if you're a foreigner and haven't renounced your nationality to become a Chinese national. You can still lose the 3 stars if you don't go back once every three years. I don't have any stars on my HKID simply because of the above, but have PR and ROA. I was able to gain this status through my mother who is a Hong Konger. Apparently, I was able to get 3 stars at some point during the handover, but because my mum didn't go back to sort out the paperwork, I missed out on it. A couple of my friends have 3 stars but they are also foreigners and still have to go back to HK for the 3 years because they have not renounced their British nationality to Chinese. Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 225. Re: Travelling to HK before 3 years run out
usertext: If you was born overseas and have 3*** on HKID, you still have to go back to HK every 3 years. HK doesn't recognise dual nationality as it is part of China. So unless you renounce your foreign citizenship, you're not classed as a Chinese national.

usertext: Yes, Bangladeshi nationals require a visa when transiting through HKIA even when remaining airside during transit (which is the situation when using SkyPier). subject: Hong Kong Cancels PCR Tests
usertext: Passengers will still have to take a RAT within 24 hours of their flight's departure to Hong Kong, but that is it. Online health declaration no longer required and no more PCR tests on arrival and on Day 2. RAT tests for the first five days after arrival will be "advised" but apparently not required. Effective Thursday, December 29.

subject: Covid Testing Required For All Flying From HK to the US
usertext: Probably should be noted (and maybe already has in another post) but starting on 5 January there is: "...a requirement for a negative COVID-19 test or documentation of recovery for air passengers boarding flights to the United States originating from the People's Republic of China (PRC) and the Special Administrative Regions of Hong Kong and Macau". "The requirement applies to these air passengers regardless of nationality and vaccination status. This will also apply to persons traveling from the PRC via third country transit and to passengers connecting through the United States onward to further destinations. Along with applying this requirement to direct flights from the PRC, passengers transiting Incheon International Airport, Toronto Pearson International Airport, and Vancouver International Airport on their way to the United States The full CDC order can be found here: https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2022/p1228-COVID-china.html

subject: 1. Re: Covid Testing Required For All Flying From HK to the US

subject: 3. Re: Covid Testing Required For All Flying From HK to the US
usertext: As far as I'm aware no test or vaccination requirements on transit passengers, however your airline may have different ideas when it comes to letting people on their planes so if in doubt ask them.

subject: 4. Re: Covid Testing Required For All Flying From HK to the US
usertext: I would contact your airline directly to find out what they will require for your boarding in Saigon and in Hong Kong, though it's so early in the release of this CDC directive and the actual requirement doesn't begin until 5 January, it may be a few days before these gray areas are sorted out by the airlines. The wording in the CDC directive is "flights to the United States originating from the People's Republic of China (PRC) and the Special Administrative Regions of Hong Kong and Macau. " Several websites define an "originating flight" as "First flight of an itinerary, the top most flight listed on a ticket." So in your case, assuming both flights were purchased on one ticket, the flight originates in Saigon not in Hong Kong and as long as you stay airside and not enter Hong Kong through immigration you likely shouldn't need to do testing. But only your airline can tell you for sure what they expect of you; and if the flights are purchased on one ticket not bought as separate flights may make a difference, where a flight purchased separately from Hong Kong to the USA may very likely be considered an originating flight, but that's just my speculation.

subject: Connection Time
usertext: In March we are flying into Hong Kong and looking to fly straight onto Vietnam. As we have a reward flight BA have said they cannot add a connecting flight to our existing booking. They have suggested that we try to check our luggage straight though at the checking desk (our onward flight will be with Cathay Pacific) but they cannot guarantee we will be able to do this. If they are unable to check the luggage straight through we will only have 2 hours 50 mins to collect our luggage and check in for the next flight. This is also dependent on the flight being on time! I just wondered if anybody could give advise on whether that would be sufficient time to make the connection?

subject: 1. Re: Connection Time
usertext: Three hours is pretty much the minimum you should allow for such a connection - mind that it takes 30-60 mins to get landside (luggage claim, immigration), and check-in desks typically close 45-60 mins before departure, depending on the airline chosen. That leaves about an hour margin. If your flight arrives on time, that's fine. If your flight is an hour late, you may not be able to make your connection and you will have to buy a new, possibly very expensive ticket. Your connection is after all not protected as it would be if you were travelling on a single ticket.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

usertext: Thanks I was going to ask the same question and have decided to stay overnight as well.

subject: 4. Re: Connection Time
usertext: Note that in the reverse direction (first flight Cathay, second flight BA) there would be no problem checking your bags through between the flights.

usertext: HKTV Mall is the major online market in Hong Kong and they have a section filled with contact lenses. Browse through and see if they have what you need, remembering that those $ prices are in Hong Kong dollars (1US$ = 7.8HK$). They give delivery time for each option and are normally reliable. subject: From Hong Kong station to J link hotel near causeway bay
usertext: I need to get from Hong Kong station to j link hotel near causeway bay with one trolly bag and a backpack. I will be using airport express to reach Hong Kong station. Is it okay to change metro at Hong Kong station to reach causeway bay and walk to the J link hotel on foot ? J link hotel is situated across the flyover ,and walk through the vegetable market, to reach at the hotel according to the message from hotel. Or it's advisable to take a taxi from Hong Kong station to reach hotel?

subject: 1. Re: From Hong Kong station to J link hotel near causeway bay
usertext: Should be no problem walking from Causeway Bay MTR assuming you can read a map. It's only about 300m from exit A (although that exit, in Times Square, is quite a long walk underground from the train platform). But a much cheaper way to get there would be to get the A11 airport bus to stop 13: Tonnochy Road, Hennessy Road. The walk from the bus stop is significantly shorter than the walk from the train at Causewayy Bay MTR.

subject: 2. Re: From Hong Kong station to J link hotel near causeway bay
usertext: A11 airport bus is much better because you don't need to change from Airport Express to MTR. Just get on the bus at the airport, alight at stop 13, and walk to your hotel.

subject: 3. Re: From Hong Kong station to J link hotel near causeway bay
usertext: Thanks a lot.

subject: 4. Re: From Hong Kong station to J link hotel near causeway bay
usertext: If you opt for the Airport Express, it's best to change to a taxi when you arrive Hong Kong station. Otherwise, A11 is a good option. It's probably going to be 20-30 minutes slower but it's also much cheaper.

subject: 5. Re: From Hong Kong station to J link hotel near causeway bay
usertext: Thanks .

subject: Going to the city during layover?
usertext: In about 2 weeks I have a 4 hour 45m layover in HKG with Cathay Pacific. I am considering going out of the airport during that time to see a few places and have some food. Reasons I think this will work: -My luggage will be transferred to the next flight so I won't have to check it in when I go back -I will have my boarding pass so I won't have to check in at all, only airport security. I know that technically it's less that 4h45m since I have time since landing to connect to a gate and get out and such. However. I really wanna make it work even if I'll only have an hour in the city to have food and see a place or two. What do you think? Could I make it work? How long will I need for TSA?

subject: 1. Re: Going to the city during layover?
usertext: You don't have enough time to see any place. The best you can hope for is maybe take the Airport Express train to the Hong Kong station, get out and take a look at the harbour, then back to the airport. BTW, TSA is a US government agency. They don't work in HKG. HKG's security is not called TSA.

subject: 2. Re: Going to the city during layover?
usertext: Thanks for the tip, however, the arrogance there was hilarious. I know it isn't called TSA in HKG, as I already said airport security earlier in the article. Just a figure of speech to call airport security.

subject: 3. Re: Going to the city during layover?
usertext: layovers of less than 5 hours are really tight. You basically have a couple options of things you can do in that little of time. 1) Airport Express (24 min) to Hong Kong Station, walk around Central, have a quick look at the harbour, have a quick dim sum and then get back to the airport. 2) Taxi (10-15 min) to Tung Chung, take the Ngong Ping 360 cable car up to the Ngong Ping village on Lantau, have a brief look at the Big Buddha than take a taxi from the village back to the airport or cable car back down to Tung Chung depending on how much time you have left, have a look around CityGate shopping mall, then taxi back to the airport. Note that the cable car starts running at 10am. Also, you mention coming in about 2 weeks, if this is the weekend leading into Chinese New Year, it could potentially be crowded and not recommended activity with such a short layover. Lastly, if sky conditions are poor on the day of your layover, you might want to give it a pass as well.

subject: 4. Re: Going to the city during layover?
usertext: Hey, thanks for such a detailed response, you're awesome! I'm landing Monday 16th Jan at 06:15 AM Knowing this, could you expand on the Chinese new year and cable car alternative etc?

subject: 5. Re: Going to the city during layover?
usertext: To be honest, 6.15am is really early for a short layover visit to the city. Ngong Ping 360 cable car doesn't open until 10am so forget that option altogether. And visiting the city, nothing will be open that early other than a few casual eateries, bakeries and coffee shops which you can find at the airport anyway so I wouldn't make the journey in just for that. Given the early layover, I'd give a layover visit into the city a pass and just rest up in the departure lounge prior to flying onward and out of HKIA.

subject: 2. Re: lLatest covid rules for leaving H.K.
usertext: Macau authorities dropped most of the travel restrictions limiting travel into the SAR on 23 December 2022. There are still requirements for you to have a certified NAT test within 72 hours of trying to enter Macau as well as need to update RAT results until the 5th day of your stay there. Mandatory quarantines and Red Health Code have been scrapped. Yellow code for 5 days remains in effect, businesses have been granted discretion to decide if they will allow those with Yellow Code to enter premises or not. https://www.gcs.gov.mo/ncv/annex/index.html?p=0&l=en As HK Ga Yau points out however, travel itself into/out of Macau is very limited still. Golden Bus over the HKMB bridge has increased frequency of journeys and there are few private bus charters from Kowloon to Cotai Strip (Macau) but the regular ferry service that has been paused for the past 3 years are not yet authorised to resume service to/from Macau. As such, travel to Macau now and in the immediate future is possible but may be a time consuming, logistically slow and frustrating endeavour that will require planning, patience and a real desire to endure all in order to visit our sister SAR. Until they ramp up travel avenues and frequency and smooth things out, many if not most will likely give Macau a pass at the moment. Here is link to the Covid-19 Info - Macau thread if helpful https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k13265615-Coronavirus_Covid_19_Information_in_Macau-Macau.html https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14211033-Macau_Pandemic_Quarantine_Update_Dec_2022-Macau.html Edited: 2 years ago

subject: 4. Re: lLatest covid rules for leaving H.K.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Australia after city visit during transit
usertext: Any thoughts on the requirement to provide a test result entering Australia if we are visiting HK for half a day during a layover? Australia guidance is: What about for passengers transiting through China, including Hong Kong and Macau? Travellers on flights transiting through China, including Hong Kong and Macau originating in other countries do not need to undertake pre-departure testing. For example, people boarding a flight in London that transits through Hong Kong and ends in Sydney do not need to test. However, the testing requirement does apply to those who travel to China, including Hong Kong or Macau from another country and spend several days there prior to travelling to Australia. We don't fly until Feb by which time the rules may have changed again, and if they don't we may get supervised RAT tests done just in case before we leave the UK. subject: Hiking trips
usertext: Hey! I want to go on a hiking trip tomorrow morning, what is the best place in Hong-Kong?

subject: 1. Re: Hiking trips
usertext: Here you go: https://www.alltrails.com/hong-kong

subject: 2. Re: Hiking trips
usertext: We'd need to know something first about what you're looking for, your hiking experience and your familiarity getting around Hong Kong. There are some easy walks in Hong Kong. But there are also some very challenging hikes, surprisingly challenging if you're new to HK and think of it as essentially urban. Point is, unless you're doing a simple paved "Family Trail" sort of walk, you need to be prepared as you would hiking in any wilderness, with the right equipment, like shoes, clothing, map etc. Take water -- it's rarely available on the trail -- and your phone.

subject: 3. Re: Hiking trips
usertext: Or look up MeetUp worldwide organization, join them and look at the many choices available in HK that you can join after reading descriptions http://www.meetup.com Edited: 2 years ago

subject: 4. Re: Hiking trips
usertext: There is no 'best place' to hike in HK. Instead we have a wide range of hiking opportunities varying greatly in length, difficulty and time required to complete. Trail recommendations are also very much dependant on where you staying in HK, how much time you have available, your hiking experience, shape and fitness, what gear you have with you (proper shoes, hiking sticks). It is also important to know how familiar you are with getting around Hong Kong. Some of our very best trails are on Lantau Island and up in the New Territories which require using local buses to get as close to trailheads. This is usually easy for those familiar with getting around HK but not so much for tourists. So if you can fill us in with the above, we can offer some trails that you might find appealing while here.

subject: 1. Re: Long layover in HKG

subject: 4. Re: Long layover in HKG
usertext: The restricted departure area has been mostly empty and quiet during the pandemic. There are more flights coming in and going out now but I suspect it remains very easy to find chairs, seats and quiet space to rest there. In the unrestricted area, there are open restaurants like Wolfgang Puck with comfortable seating and opportunity to grab a round of drinks while checking email. Otherwise, a couple of rows of seats facing the check-in counters but not sure how long you'd want to sit there awaiting entry into the restricted area.

subject: 5. Re: Long layover in HKG
usertext: Quite a bit you can get done with a 9 hour layover starting in the morning. You can get in some focused sightseeing and a meal with fairly little planning. You might want to start by doing a search for 9 hour layovers in the Search Box at the top of the forum. Past responses are most likely still relevant as attractions haven't changed much during the pandemic. Those threads and responses can give you an idea and feel for what is possible for that period of time. Once you have a look-see and start to formulate a plan for your layover, do feel free to post what you are thinking here and forum regulars can look over and make sure you'll on the right track.

subject: 14. Re: Long layover in HKG
usertext: A layover of 4 hours and 45 minutes is fairly short, and it may not be realistic to try to see too many places within that time frame. Keep in mind that you will need to allow for time to go through security and immigration procedures upon your return to the airport, as well as any travel time to and from your destination. If you do decide to leave the airport, it may be more realistic to focus on one or two nearby attractions, such as Victoria Harbour or the Avenue of Stars, rather than trying to see multiple places.

subject: RAT Covid Test in Hong Kong
usertext: Hi everyone, I have already searched the forum but to no avail. We will be in HK early March and as it appears the EU is now imposing pre-arrival RAT tests on passengers from China and Hong Kong. My questions is, where can I get an RAT test in the city with a certificate valid for leaving HK? Thanks

subject: 1. Re: RAT Covid Test in Hong Kong
usertext: RAT tests are self-administered and I have never heard of a certificate being given for you having done a RAT test correctly. The Hong Kong government does offer regular PCR testing at their test centres, see https://www.communitytest.gov.hk/en/

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: RAT Covid Test in Hong Kong
usertext: >>> My questions is, where can I get an RAT test in the city with a certificate valid for leaving HK?<<< I don't know whether all EU members will choose to require covid testing (which at the moment is strongly recommended but not mandatory) or whether those that do will have the same requirements but France is one EU country which does not accept RAT's and requires a hard copy or electronic test result certificate. The French Consulate in HK has more information including details of Community Testing Centres and Recognised Laboratories; https://hongkong.consulfrance.org/Health-measures-for-passengers-from-China-including-Hong-Kong-Macau

subject: 3. Re: RAT Covid Test in Hong Kong
usertext: Not sure whether the RAT with telehealth option is available for purchase where you came from. Abbott Lab is one of the major manufacturers in the US and this option is available if one were to fly out of HK to the US and from the article it is also acceptable for the EU. https://www.fiercebiotech.com/medtech/abbott-s-at-home-rapid-antigen-covid-19-test-cleared-europe-for-dtc-sales The telehealth option means you have to do the at home RAT test via video where a health care professional on the other side actually see you do the test from start to finish and certify it. That being said, HK has many paid for service (government and private labs) PCR tests and printed results that would be a gold standard and universally accepted by all. Last I checked only costs a few hundred HK dollars.

subject: 4. Re: RAT Covid Test in Hong Kong
usertext: "RAT tests are self-administered" Not always. When I was leaving Germany for the USA about a year ago (when the US was still requiring negative COVID tests for all air passengers), there were lots of labs that advertised "quick tests" that gave results within 20 minutes. They were RATs, but they did not use the home-test cartridges. They administered the test and read the results, and then issued a certificate that I showed the airline on check-in. It was free for German citizens; as a foreigner I had to pay 15 euros. But I don't have any info, unfortunately, on whether and where such services are available in HK.

subject: Taxi to Wan Chai
usertext: How much is a taxi from Hong Kong airport to Wan Chai area on Hong Kong Island?

subject: 1. Re: Taxi to Wan Chai
usertext: This page on the HK Airport website gives estimated taxi fares to various areas of HK. The number quoted includes tunnel/bridge tolls, but excludes a charge of HK$6 for each piece of luggae in the boot/trunk. https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/to-from-airport/taxis.page A PDF document from the Transport Department is available here with similar information: https://www.td.gov.hk/filemanager/en/content_276/202012_airport.pdf If you are nervous about HK Airport taxis then, on request, you can get a "Passenger Record" from the airport staff at the taxi stand which records the taxi number, date/time, destination and estimated fare.

subject: 2. Re: Taxi to Wan Chai
usertext: There are other transport options from HKG to Wan Chai.

subject: 3. Re: Taxi to Wan Chai
usertext: taxi fares in Hong Kong can vary depending on several factors such as the time of day, the specific route taken, and any tolls that may be encountered along the way. In general, however, you can expect to pay around HKD 300-400 for a taxi from the airport to the Wan Chai area

subject: Best area in Hong Kong?
usertext: Will be doing 1 night in Hong Kong in a week Want to book a hotel/airbnb I'd like to know what the best area is to stay in so that I'll be the closest to the "center" Closest to the most top things to see and the most popular part of the city I'd love if you could add a screenshot of the map and circle the area. Also, what is Covid situation atm? Anything I should know?

subject: 1. Re: Best area in Hong Kong?
usertext: Just go to Google Maps and find Jordan MTR Station (seriously). Stay within walking distance of it and you'll be in the heart of Hong Kong.

subject: 2. Re: Best area in Hong Kong?
usertext: Anywhere near an MTR station on the stretch fromTsim Sha Tsui to Prince Edward in Kowloon or Tin Hau to Sai Ying Pun on the island is fine. Basically anywhere near an MTR station is fine, really. Wong Chuk Hang area also has a few hotels now. For the current covid situation read the latest posts in the sticky at the top of the forum.

subject: 3. Re: Best area in Hong Kong?
usertext: Hong Kong is a multi center city, so there is no one place that's "central" to everything. In fact, the area called "Central" is the business center, and is relatively quiet during the evening.

subject: 4. Re: Best area in Hong Kong?
usertext: I'd stay near the TST MTR Station on the Kowloon side of the harbour or near Central / Sheung Wan on the Island side. Both keep you in the thick of things when it comes to shopping, dining and access to the harbour and promenades. As long as you close to the MTR, you can get to the other side very quickly if you have sightseeing interests away from your hotel.

subject: 5. Re: Best area in Hong Kong?
usertext: For just one night, I suggest you opt for a hotel in the areas listed above. Forget Airbnb. Once you include the Airbnb fees and cleaning charges, a hotel is probably a better deal. You will also be guaranteed a certain quality of furnishings and be at a location you will know in advance. There will be no guess work.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Acceptable test for entry into HK
usertext: Hello, I'm coming from the UK in a few days- I know we are allowed a "self administered" rapid antigen test. But what is considered proof of my negative result, ie. To show to the airline?

subject: 1. Re: Acceptable test for entry into HK
usertext: You don't need a certificate version of the RAT test, any self-administered RAT test will do. From what I understand airlines will accept a photo of the test. Best to write your full name, date/time of test in pencil on the RAT test as well. I'd also keep it just in case the airline wants to see the physical test for some reason and don't accept only the photograph.

subject: Store luggage at Disney or lockers at Kowloon?
usertext: Hi, we will be travelling with kids and the plan is roughly as follow: Day 1: land in HK in evening, check in hotel in Tung Chung Day 2: check out, visit Big Buddha, take MTR to Kowloon TST area, at night check in at hotel in Disneyland Day 3: Disneyland Does it make sense to deposit luggage at Disney after visiting Big Buddha before heading to Kowloon? With kids in tow, I'm afraid it will be a drag and risk getting stuck in hotel at Disney. Should we just head straight for Kowloon instead?

subject: 1. Re: Store luggage at Disney or lockers at Kowloon?
usertext: Lots of travelling :-) For me it'd make most sense to leave your luggage at your hotel in Tung Chung (I assume it's the one next to the MTR station), they will normally allow you to do so, a common service for guests. Then you can in the morning go to the Buddha (cable car up and down, or bus one way and cable car the other way is another interesting option), afternoon MTR to TST, and when you're tired MTR back to Tung Chung, collect your luggage, and then a taxi from there to your Disneyland hotel. The Disney hotels are quite far from the Disneyland MTR station. From Tung Chung you'd take MTR to Sunny Bay, change to the Disneyland Resort Line, and then at Disney station change to a shuttle bus. Perfectly doable of course but taxi is much easier and faster on this route. In any case you may want to schedule a ride on the Disneyland Resort Line just for the fun of riding the Disney themed trains.

subject: 7.5 hr layover in Hong Kong...Star Ferry?
usertext: Hi, later this month I have a 7.5 hr layover in HK. I arrive at 5am and depart at 12:30pm. I'm wondering if this is enough time to see some of HK. Based on what I've read in the forums, I'll need 30 mins to clear customs and 45 mins to get to the Central Station. Then, on the return, I'll need 45 mins to get to the airport and 2 hrs for checkin/security. That leaves me about 3 hrs. Given the time of day and shortness of my time it looks like the best idea would be taking the Star Ferry from Central Station (which start @ 6:30am) to Tsim Sha Tsui, walk around a bit, then return. Are there other options? Or, is the best idea just to stay put in the airport? Thanks.

subject: 1. Re: 7.5 hr layover in Hong Kong...Star Ferry?
usertext: 7.5 hours is a fair amount of time to spend in the city Airport Express starts early (see link) - 24 min to HK Station https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/timetable_index.html Star Ferry starts early (see link) https://www.starferry.com.hk/en/service You could also try a ride on the historic Ding Ding street tram (see link) 7.5 hours is a fair amount of time to spend in the city. and the Tram up to Victoria Peak (see link) https://www.thepeak.com.hk/en/getting-to-the-peak/opening-hours Places like HK Park will also be open early, lots of casual places to eat and grab a coffee, have dim sum for late breakfast before heading back to the airport on the Airport Express (HK Station - 24 min ride

subject: 2. Re: 7.5 hr layover in Hong Kong...Star Ferry?
usertext: Assuming you have onward tickets you don't need more than an hour before departure at the airport, normally 30 mins will do. The airport is still rather quiet but with the loosening restrictions that may change in the near future. Hard to predict when it will change and how well the airport will cope with the influx of traffic.

subject: 3. Re: 7.5 hr layover in Hong Kong...Star Ferry?
usertext: Be sure to get the same-day return ticket on the Airport Express; half the price of two one-ways. Most shops open late, 10 or later, but Kowloon Park in TST is a good place to visit earlier. Also the waterfront promenade.

subject: What open in CNY?
usertext: Hello, we will be in HK during CNY (21/1 - 27/1). I know most of the places close on the first two days of CNY. What else can we do on those two days? Will Ngong Ping 360 and the Peak close? How about the outlets in Tung Chung? Thank you!

subject: 1. Re: What open in CNY?
usertext: In the recent past prior to the pandemic, the businesses that closed are mostly small places that cater to residents and locals not tourist geared businesses nor tourist attractions. There may some shops at the CityGate Outlet in Tung Chung that close but the mall will certainly be open and possibly very busy at times. Some places will also simply have adjusted opening hours for CNY as well. The opening days/times for the Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car can be found on the opening launch page of their website - see below Ngong Ping Cable Car service operation hours during Lunar New Year is as follows. Operation hour is from 9am to 8pm from 22 to 25 January, Operation hour is from 9:30am to 6pm on 26 and 27 January, Operation hour is from 9am to 6:30pm on 28 and 29 January.

subject: 2. Re: What open in CNY?
usertext: BC the lines for the cable car were huge on CNY, 2-3 hours wait or more. This largely as many locals want to go to Ngong Ping to make offerings and pray to the Buddha. Likewise many temples are totally overcrowded on those days.

subject: 3. Re: What open in CNY?
usertext: Shops and restaurants will be opened. Extra service charges may apply to some local food outlets during the CNY period.

subject: 4. Re: What open in CNY?
usertext: There will be restaurants open for sure. Some will charge a premium and/or offer a limited menu. Some (but not) all shops will be open. *Most* shops will be closed, at least on the very first day of CNY. Some will be closed for longer.

subject: 2 Hour Layover - PCR / Antigen Test needed
usertext: Hi, we are on our way back to Canada this Saturday and we have a 2hour layover in Hong Kong. I want to ask if we needed a PCR / RAT test administered by a test center or self administered tests are ok? Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: 2 Hour Layover - PCR / Antigen Test needed
usertext: No test needed for airside transit.

subject: 2. Re: 2 Hour Layover - PCR / Antigen Test needed
usertext: That's what l thought But l received an email from Air Canada. " We're contacting you today in regard to your upcoming flight to Canada. Due to government restrictions, all customers aged 2 or older travelling from the People's Republic of China, Hong Kong or Macao must provide a negative COVID-19 test result upon departure to Canada or connecting to the United States. The requirement applies regardless of nationality and vaccination status. The test must be no more than 2 days before departure and can either be a negative molecular (such as a PCR test), or a negative antigen test that has documentation to show that it has been monitored by a telehealth service or an accredited laboratory or testing provider. Customers who've tested positive more than 10 days before their departure flight, but no more than 90 days, can provide documentation of their prior positive, in place of a negative test result. We look forward to welcoming you on board soon. Air Canada"

subject: 4. Re: 2 Hour Layover - PCR / Antigen Test needed
usertext: sonny0215 - Are you also flying Air Canada into Hong Kong and the originating flight and connecting flight were purchased on the same ticket? If not, and the flights were purchased separately, Air Canada may be assuming (and perhaps rightfully so) that you're on a flight originating in HK and not in transit. While, testing isn't required by the Canadian Government if in transit, Air Canada could have imposed a stiffer requirement rather than sorting out who on a plane is in transit and who isn't. You need to contact Air Canada and get their answer to this as they're the ones who could prevent you from boarding your flight.

subject: 5. Re: 2 Hour Layover - PCR / Antigen Test needed
usertext: My answer applies only to the HK COVID requirement for a transit flight. You didn't say where you are traveling from. Are you traveling from China, HK, or Macau? Or just transiting?

usertext: Yes HKA will check in our luggages from Manila straight to our final destination. I called Air Canada Manila and they confirmed that we don't need to have tested. Im just worried if we are in HK and then they will ask for a test result.

subject: 10. Re: 2 Hour Layover - PCR / Antigen Test needed
usertext: Since you got confirmation from Air Canada that they aren't requiring testing for all transit passengers through Hong Kong and you'll be staying airside during the transit, I doubt you'll have an issue. If still concerned, print out the webpage linked in post #3 to show anyone who says you need to be tested what the Canadian government requirement is. Should you decide to be tested, plan on getting PCR tests within 2 days of your flight from Hong Kong as a "monitored" self-test RAT is probably not an option for you.

subject: 11. Re: 2 Hour Layover - PCR / Antigen Test needed
usertext: Get it in writing from AC that you don't need a test.

subject: Budget in hongkong
usertext: I will be staying for five nights in hongkong before I move to Beijing later this month. How much money will be enough for a single person for vegetarian meals and some sight seeing. I have already booked and paid hotel rent.

subject: 1. Re: Budget in hongkong
usertext: Nobody knows you spending habits. If you just want regular meals, I doubt you can spend more than HK$500 daily for food on average but again, the sky is the limit. If you stick to public transport, you shouldn't spend more than $100 a day. Sightseeing cost depends on where you go. You can find specific admission prices on their respective websites.

subject: 2. Re: Budget in hongkong
usertext: You can survive (just) on HK$100/day for food, or you can spend $10,000+. It's entirely up to you. If you are from South Asia or just like their food then you can readily get cheap vegetarian food at the various outlets in Chungking Mansions. For sightseeing it really depends on what sights. Disneyland will set you back several hundred HK$, but a ride on the Star Ferry or the ding-ding tram costs lest than HK$5.

subject: 3. Re: Budget in hongkong
usertext: Thanks

subject: 4. Re: Budget in hongkong

subject: 12 Hour Layover Plan
usertext: Hi - now Hong Kong is open again I am planning to make good use of approx 12 hrs to visit the city during our layover. I have searched the forum but lots of threads are old or left me with some questions so hopefully I can find some answers here. We fly UK to Australia with Cathay on a through ticket and will arrive in HK at 8am and fly out again 10pm. Our plan at the moment is the 360 Cable Car to Budda, then into centre. I have been to HK once before about 30 years ago. 1. It looks like the Cable Car runs 10-6 so will probably go there first and hope to get on as soon as it opens. May mean hanging around for an hour but I guess thats better as it will be a waste to travel to and from Central later on in the day to do it. How long for Cable Car there and back and a wander around at the top, was thinking about a couple of hours? 2. . Airport Express - Is this the quickest option into Central, so we would be best going back to Airport from Tung Chung after the cable car and catching Airport Express? 3. City - Probably head over to Island on Ferry first and get something to eat then go up Peak and wander round parks/temple and Ding Ding if enough time. Then back to Kowloon early evening for something to eat, wander along waterfront and up Nathan Rd a bit then back to Airport for about 8pm. 4. Octopus Card - bit confused by this. It is worth getting these and if so it there any advantage to the loan ones or the mobile app. 3 of us travelling so will need one each or should we just use credit cards. 5. Cash - do we need cash? Rarely carry cash these days but I read somewhere Star Ferry is cash only and maybe that also applies to some food stalls and some other things? Any other recommendations for things we should try and see/do in HK or if we are making any unknowing errors with the outline plan? Should we pre-book things like Cable Car and Peak Tram (or just get bus up Peak if queue is long). I may just book the cable car as if we don't get much rest on the plane over we will be shattered and scale back what we can do in HK. Thanks

subject: 1. Re: 12 Hour Layover Plan
usertext: I think it'll be a waste of time to go back to the airport to catch the airport express train after Ngong Ping. Just take the MTR to Central from Tung Chung. You'd be taking the Star Ferry from HK Island to Kowloon. For one day, it may be overkill to get an Octopus card. But personally I think the convenience factor weighs towards getting an Octopus, even just for one day. You can load it with some cash and use it for food purchases.

subject: 2. Re: 12 Hour Layover Plan
usertext: 1. 2-4 hours depending on how much time you spend up there and the lines for the cable car (unpredictable to me as the situation has changed so much). 2. Just take MTR from Tung Chung instead. That's the fastest from there. 4. Octopus is very convenient for all those public transit rides; if your phone supports NFC and their payment methods that sounds like a good option. No personal experience, my phone doesn't do NFC. Credit card doesn't work for public transport. Many small restaurants do not take credit cards; they're far more likely to take octopus for payments. Star Ferry takes cash or Octopus. You can use credit card to pay for the cable car, the Peak Tram and Airport Express, all other public transit is cash (usually no change given) or Octopus.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: 12 Hour Layover Plan
usertext: Star Ferry entry barriers accept Octopus Card or tokens (but not cash). You can use cash to buy tokens from vending machines on the pier concourse.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: 12 Hour Layover Plan
usertext: Thanks for replies. Not sure if Octopus card is worth it for the day. I m being a bit put off by reading somewhere else that on loan Octopus Cards are no longer issued, and the Octopus App for Tourists having just one review, which is 1 star complaining about poor exchange rates when loading it. The Octopus website does seem to push Tourists to the "Octopus Card for Tourists App" with just that one poor review. The standard Octopus App I guess is not intended for Tourists who want to use it just for a short time and then get a refund. Should be able to get around OK with Credit Card and Cash and save the hassle of sorting out 3 Octopus Cards half a day in HK

subject: Singapore to Osaka on Cathay Pacific (via HKG)?
usertext: Hello folks: I am planning to fly from Singapore to Osaka in March. I can fly direct for a much higher cost with SQ, for a more affordable cost with Scoot, or for a cost in between (still USD 300 below SQ) with Cathay. The last option is via Hong Kong. It's going to be a short stop and I have lounge access in HKG. My questions: 1. Is Cathay reliable, given that they've cut lots of flights during Covid (and perhaps even now)? I do not prefer Scoot because it's a low cost carrier, which may cancel my flight without notice and without compensation. 2. How much should I trust Hong Kong in terms of letting transit passengers through? I recall that they once banned transfers due to Covid (correct me if I am wrong).

subject: 1. Re: Singapore to Osaka on Cathay Pacific (via HKG)?
usertext: Reply to #2, HK is now pretty open for transit and entering. Yes, once they allow only airside transit, but that's now in the past.

subject: 2. Re: Singapore to Osaka on Cathay Pacific (via HKG)?
usertext: On point 1, I have flown with Cathay a few times a year for the last seven years (except during COVID), and they have always been quite reliable I have found. Post-Covid I cannot say exactly but no one I know who has booked with Cathay has had anything cancelled in the past few years (which is something I cannot say of other airlines). As for question two, there is currently No testing whatsoever at HKG so you should be fine even if you are unlucky enough to have picked something up on the way here.

subject: 3. Re: Singapore to Osaka on Cathay Pacific (via HKG)?
usertext: There were lots and lots of HK flight cancellations during the period when the HK government's main COVID prevention policies were to punish anyone connected with international travel, in an effort to make HK more like mainland China, so that the "internal" border could be opened. Airlines were abruptly banned from operating flights to HK for two weeks if they inadvertently allowed passengers onboard who tested COVID-positive on arrival. This threw the airlines' operational planning into a tizzy. Many airlines (and not just Cathay) were affected by this. However, HK is Cathay's base and it was most affected by this. Fortunately, "getting on the same page as the mainland" now means rapidly opening up and that is what HK is doing. The airline punishment policies were abandoned some months ago and I haven't heard much about any flight cancellations since November.

subject: 4. Re: Singapore to Osaka on Cathay Pacific (via HKG)?
usertext: You can always go to the page below and check to see the number of cancellations daily. Of course, it doesn't mean your flight won't get cancelled or massively delay. It just gives you a rough picture of what's happening: https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/flights/departures/passenger.page

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 5. Re: Singapore to Osaka on Cathay Pacific (via HKG)?
usertext: #2 No testing at all? Does that include people travelling on 2 separate tickets ?? Thanks

subject: 7. Re: Singapore to Osaka on Cathay Pacific (via HKG)?
usertext: >>> Does that include people travelling on 2 separate tickets ?? For Hong Kong - yes. For your final destination - not so sure. Entry requirements for travellers from Hong Kong vary, more and more places have reinstated restrictions. Whether a 2-ticket itinerary is automatically seen as transit I wouldn't assume either way, check with your destination representatives.

subject: 8. Re: Singapore to Osaka on Cathay Pacific (via HKG)?
usertext: HK is Cathay's main hub so the First class and Business lounges are quite nice. Though Singapore lounge (in Singapore) is also top notch. Both airports are considered the best in the world so lounge access is not needed.

subject: 1. Re: Transitting through Hong Kong on separate tickets

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Transitting through Hong Kong on separate tickets
usertext: If your transit is airside (ie you do not need to pass Immigration) there are no boarding or arrival testing or vaccination requirements as per the answer to General Question 2 on the HK Government Covid website; https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/eng/inbound-travel-faq.html#FAQA4 If your transit involves entering HK the boarding requirement for vaccination and either RAT test within 24 hours before or PCR test within 48 hours scheduled departure of the flight to HK applies. On arrival there is no mandatory test requirement, only recommendation. See under "Persons Arriving from Overseas Places"; https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/eng/inbound-travel.html

subject: HK hotels with fast, reliable internet?
usertext: I need to go to HK for some personal matters for a month. Unfortunately, for half of the month I need to work US hours. I do a lot of Zoom video meetings. I'm looking for a hotel in Mid-levels, Central, or Wan Chai - somewhere ideally closer to the US Consulate. This isn't corporate sponsored, so budget is a bit of a concern. (Otherwise I'm sure the Conrad would have great internet... or maybe not!) Any ideas on how to figure out which hotels have better internet than others? A fall back plan I had was to rent a co-working space, but I don't think many of them are 24x7 as working US hours would be.

subject: 1. Re: HK hotels with fast, reliable internet?
usertext: If you do a search on booking.com, there are wifi ratings for each of the properties available on that platform. Generally speaking wifi is pretty good at the vast majority of hotels as long as they are midrange or above. I few lower than 5 star hotel places I can think of where I've done online work from the rooms include 99 Bonham. Stayed at a few times during the pandemic when rates were basement level prices. Worked online from the rooms there and had no problem. They are in Sheung Wan, 15 minute walk to the U.S. Consulate. This is the most comfortable living/working property I can think of but isn't the cheapest option. If you are ok with staying on the TST side, Royal Garden is a good property that often has very reasonable room rates and I've had good wifi/internet for zoom calls when we've stayed there for long weekends. They are 5 minute walk to the TST MTR Station, two stations from Central and a walk up to the consulate as well. Good luck with your hotel search.

subject: 2. Re: HK hotels with fast, reliable internet?
usertext: Buy a local sim card.

subject: 3. Re: HK hotels with fast, reliable internet?
usertext: 5G is now widely available in Hong Kong. I'd go with a cheaper hotel and if it doesn't work out well get the sim.

subject: Food tours - google maps
usertext: Hi everyone, We have already booked a food tour by a professional guide in the city, that aside, we were wondering if you know of any readily available google maps that highlights "must visits" restaurants/street food spots across the city and we could do on our own? Thanks

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Food tours - google maps
usertext: The Dining section of HK Tourism Board's "Discover Hong Kong" website features some district and themed guides with Google Maps such as this; https://www.discoverhongkong.com/uk/explore/neighbourhoods/western/insiders-favourites.html https://www.discoverhongkong.com/uk/explore/dining.html

subject: 2. Re: Food tours - google maps
usertext: That is a tough one. The food tour leaders in the past sort of protected the names of the establishments/food shops they would take guests so as not to give away their tour path, details (and business). The person I knew who was into leading food tours stopped due to the pandemic and having no guests, had to pay the bills so they moved on to another line of work and job. Some online magazines like Time Out, Sassy and the likes highlight restaurants, coffee shops and foods to try in various districts around the city but much of what they promote is paid for advertising and from what I've experienced of their highlighted places, some are good, others are not. Similarly, there used to be travel blogger food recommendations in HK that while somewhat random and other times almost copycat in fashion, weren't bad lists of places to try. Not sure if these are still around and online but could be worth a search online. Last problem is that quite a few places went out of business during the pandemic, even some of our legacy restaurants, bakeries and old time favourites. Others have moved locations around the city as well. As such, older food trails you might come across online might need a good spot check to make sure places are still in business and located at the same place. On the bright side, while many places closed during the pandemic, many more opened or in the case of Little Bao in Sheung Wan, for example, reopened. One of the interesting developments during the pandemic was the surprising number of modern, urban coffee shops have popped pretty much throughout the city, in fairly great numbers and in interesting spots one might not have expected 5 years ago. For years, Sham Shui Po has seen probably 20 coffee shops that have opened, mostly between Boundary and Nam Chong Street in the past 3-4 years. As such, I'm not certain how confident I'd even be in food trail lists and suggestions around the city. Some might remain relevant, others perhaps not. If you do come across something that looks interesting, feel free to post it here and some of us who support the forum can have a look at it. Or if through research, you come up with foods/places on your own that you are interested in trying, do the same. Post it here and we can spot check it for you. Good luck with your food/drink/restaurant research in HK.

subject: 3. Re: Food tours - google maps
usertext: I usually rely on Eater for my local city. Apparently Eater also covers HK. Here is their list: https://www.eater.com/maps/best-restaurants-hong-kong Just a word, HK is not that good with street food, unlike Bangkok or cities in Vietnam. The street food stalls have mostly moved into food courts, mainly for health reasons. We once did a food tour on our own around the Temple Street area. We hit 4 restaurants in one night, eating one dish at each one. Those were the days.

subject: 4. Re: Food tours - google maps
usertext: Thanks everyone for your tips and links. I will certainly post a link here, should I create a google map food tour myself.

subject: 1. Re: Staying at Regal Hotel then going to Sydney
usertext: Unfortunately not. Then for the flight to Sydney and to get back in the airport, I will need another RAT test, supposedly 48 hours before my flight which begged me to ask if I could use the same RAT test as all of this would be within 48 hours, however Cathay Pacific's response was "no". 17 hours at the airport it is! Couple of trips to the lounge will have to do. Thanks for the responses above.

subject: Do
usertext: Hello, Does anyone have any information on whether someone needs a HK visa to transit from HKIA to Shenzhen through Skypier. I'm considering booking a flight to HK and taking the skypier ferry to Shekou. However, I haven't been able to find clear information so far if I can do so without a visa transit visa. The information I've found online seems to be slightly contradictory with some sources saying its not necessary as long as you have an onward ticket or use skypier to transit, while others saying you need a visa even if you remain airside. Due to the holiday, I won't be able to get in contact with relevant HK officers for information. Any insight would be appreciated. Edit: Apologies about the subject. Noticed after it was posted. Edited: 2 years ago

subject: 1. Re: Do
usertext: {However, I haven't been able to find clear information so far if I can do so without a visa transit visa.} The HK immigration information is pretty clear that certainly nationalities (other than diplomats and public officials) must obtain and be in possession of prearranged visa even just for transiting onward from HKG airport. https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/visas/visit-transit/visit-visa-entry-permit.html#notes Additionally, making use of Skypier at HKG is a transit procedure through the restricted passenger area of the airport, which requires certain passengers as mentioned above to obtain a transit visa. In this manner, it is only different from onward connecting flights in that you are using a ferry instead of an airplane. Transit visa requirements don't change based on leaving HKG by way of connecting flight or connecting ferry. And HK Immigration doesn't care how you enter to leave by way of transit connection, it makes no difference to them. The rules will apply the same. https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/mainland-connection/ferry-transfer.page {The information I've found online seems to be slightly contradictory with some sources saying its not necessary as long as you have an onward ticket or use skypier to transit} Can you send a link to this information you have read. It seems patently wrong that transit visas are not necessary as long as you have onward tickets (defeats the entire purpose of requiring transit visas in the first place) or using the skypier (for the reason mentioned above).

subject: 2. Re: Do
usertext: Your question has been answered here: https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k13828253-Do_Bangladeshi_citizens_need_a_transit_visa_to_go_to_HKIA-Hong_Kong.html

subject: 3. Re: Do
usertext: >>> The information I've found online seems to be slightly contradictory with some sources saying its not necessary as long as you have an onward ticket or use skypier to transit This could very well be outdated information: I remember that until some five years ago Cathay Pacific had a special transit visa waiver arrangement where if transiting CX-CX certain nationalities would not have to apply for transit visa (I don't recall this applying to transits using the ferries, though). No matter, that arrangement is no more.

subject: Hong Kong visit February 2023
usertext: How is the vibes in hong kong right now in regards to COVID-19. ?? Are tourist areas fully accessible now?? Is it enjoyable to visit HK these days or better to hold on for some time??

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong visit February 2023
usertext: a) Economic activity is clearly picking up. The pre-lunar new year period saw lots of people on the streets and markets and shops. On the other hand, the economy has been withering for two years and it will take time to fully recover. There are plenty of "for lease" signs on closed-up storefronts. b) To my knowledge, all the tourist stuff has re-opened. (But I don't focus on tourist locations, so somebody else may have a useful alternative view.) c) I landed in HK a week ago. I think this is a very enjoyable time to visit. Travel formalities have been virtually eliminated. Weather is pleasant, and the city is not too crowded (mainland tourism has not fully resumed yet). Just be prepared to wear face masks. They are worn here almost everywhere (excepting the country parks.) And when I ride the jam-packed MTR trains, I am glad this is the case. Edited: 2 years ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong visit February 2023
usertext: Theme parks haven't fully reopened yet. Except during public holidays both Ocean Park and Disneyland remain closed on two days a week (Ocean Park on Tuesday & Wednesday, Disneyland on Tuesday & Thursday).

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong visit February 2023
usertext: Ladies Market (was) completely aiming for tourists $$$. With no tourists means no business, so it had to evolve with many stall keepers swapping tourist trinkets for consumables and low-cost items that locals might be buying. Far fewer stalls bother setting up now as well. Compared to the past, the Ladies Market scene now feels like a less interesting version of nearby Fai Yuen Street market. Perhaps when the tourists return, the Ladies Market in Mongkok will revert back to what it was like prior to pandemic but that could take some time.

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong visit February 2023

subject: 7. Re: Hong Kong visit February 2023
usertext: The COVID rules are different for HK permanent residents (my category) and foreign visitors. Foreign visitors have to show proof of vaccination and a photo of a rapid COVID self-test. Here is the page with the government's rules, expressed succinctly: https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/eng/inbound-travel.html#pointstonote However, I don't know how strictly the rules are being enforced -- it depends on the check-in staff of the airlines concerned. I read those rules as requiring HKID holders to also show a rapid test photo, but I was not asked for this, and I understand from many friends they were not asked either. I think the airlines are not all clear on all the rules (surprise surprise). So I would suggest that you be prepared at check-in with digital copies of your vaccination certificate and a photo of a completed rapid test done at home. Then, you can be assured of no problems. If they don't ask, don't tell.

subject: 8. Re: Hong Kong visit February 2023
usertext: From 6 Feb there will be no more vaccination requirements for non-residents.

subject: Hong Kong in August weather?
usertext: Hello everybody. I will visit Bali in Aug and I can transit in Singapore or Hong Kong and stay for a few days. Singapore is not so appealing to me and I always wanted to visit HK. I can stay for 5 days. Is it a great risk concerning weather conditions to do so? I was in Kyoto in August and I experienced humid and rain but the rains were brief within the day, not stopping us for sightseeing. What do you think? Thank you!

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong in August weather?
usertext: Likely to be hot, humid, wet and thundery with a with a possibility of tropical storms. You can find detailed information from the HK Observatory's monthly reports for August. The last three years monthly reports; 2022; https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/wxinfo/pastwx/mws2022/mws202208.htm 2021; https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/wxinfo/pastwx/mws2021/mws202108.htm 2020; https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/wxinfo/pastwx/mws2020/mws202008.htm

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong in August weather?
usertext: August is one of the sunniest months of the year in Hong Kong. It's also one of the wettest.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong in August weather?
usertext: August is the least attractive month for tourism - just too hot, humid and wet.

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong in August weather?
usertext: Some truly beautiful beaches in Hong Kong, like Shek O, but otherwise you'll find being outside really saps you of energy in August.

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong in August weather?
usertext: >>> August is the least attractive month for tourism Not sure if historical arrival numbers agree with this. My personal experience is that August has at least as many visitors as other months.

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong in August weather?
usertext: HK will feel better than Kyoto in August overall. The worst luck during that period are typhoons and sometimes, days of rain. Otherwise, though it's uncomfortable, it's not as bad as Kyoto. Kyoto also requires more time walking outdoors in unshaded areas.

subject: 7. Re: Hong Kong in August weather?
usertext: {Is it a great risk concerning weather conditions to do so?} I think heat exhaustion which can be mitigated by staying hydrated is a much greater risk for the majority of August visitors than typhoons which can occur at that time of year. {>>> August is the least attractive month for tourism ->Not sure if historical arrival numbers agree with this. My personal experience is that August has at least as many visitors as other months.} That is true, visitor numbers are high in August but I have always believed that has much more to do with people having more opportunity for travel during the summer than anything else. I doubt many come specifically in August for preference of the weather expected during the month.

subject: 8. Re: Hong Kong in August weather?
usertext: Aug is a huge sauna in the whole country. I want to think sauna is dry but HK is extrememly humid, almost 100% so 5 min outside will make you drench in sweat! Horrible time to visit

subject: HK tourist scene
usertext: Hello all who are in HK or have recently travelled to HK, How are most of markets/touristy places in general? Are they up and running already? I'm planning to visit in May this year but still thinking if its a good time since HK just opened its border end of last year/beg of this year and still recovering from the pandemic. Thank you

subject: 1. Re: HK tourist scene
usertext: The vast majority of main attractions are open and running but with far fewer tourists compared to the past so conditions are less crowded and queues won't be nearly as long. For example, you can walk up and take ride on the Peak Tram at any time of day right now where in the past you might have had to wait in queue for 30-60 minutes or possibly longer. A few places like the Ladies Market in Mongkok took big hit during the pandemic and changed with stall keepers pivoting to selling low-cost consumables and every day items that locals might want to buy instead of tourist trinkets and souvenirs. That may revert back in time but it will probably take a while. Other attractions like the 1 hour Star Ferry harbour cruise stopped during the pandemic. This will likely restart at some point in the future as well but I've not heard if/when. Ferries and buses to/from Macau restarted before Chinese New Year. We have had a couple of major museums open in West Kowloon in the past couple of years including M+ and the Palace Museum. Boatloads of modern coffee shops have opened up around the city during the pandemic as well. Otherwise, things are more or less the same in terms of what you can do/see/eat in Hong Kong from a tourist perspective.

subject: 3. Re: HK tourist scene
usertext: I happened to be at Harbour City yesterday. For the first time in years, there were quite a few Chinese tourists dragging their suitcases to carry purchases. Still, the crowd is way down from its peak days.

subject: 4. Re: HK tourist scene

I have actually been to HK but it was close to 10 years ago so I'm pretty a lot have changed since then after the pandemic and protest. Excited to know that the ferry to Macau is running as well. Would you know if the dai pai tongs (local food hawker stalls) are still around as well? I missed it the last time I was there. I assume the weather isn't too much of a difference in April and May?

subject: 7. Re: HK tourist scene
usertext: The Star Ferry is a commercial business, but, particularly in the absence of tourists, a loss-making one. But I would expect the government to subsidise it in some way to keep it going since it is one of HK's iconic attractions. Having said that, the question will eventually become moot because Beijing's long term plans for Hong Kong include completely reclaiming the central part of Victoria Harbour.

subject: 8. Re: HK tourist scene

I really hope that won't happen anytime soon. Pretty sure HK will lose its charm when they really take over and start developing etc. I have read that most of the highly valued properties were bought by mainland customers, that of course is a topic for another day :)

subject: 9. Re: HK tourist scene
usertext: {Would you know if the dai pai tongs (local food hawker stalls) are still around as well? I missed it the last time I was there.} They have been slowly ridding the city of dai pai dongs for sometime now. Probably the most central place to try is in Central near Stanley Street, Gage Street and the area nearby. Here is a Timeout publication where you can still find some form of the old dai pai dongs and outdoor food courts around the city. https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/restaurants/best-dai-pai-dong-hong-kong {I assume the weather isn't too much of a difference in April and May?} The rains generally start around the 3rd week of April give or take but there is no exact schedule or science to predicting when/if or how much it will rain from around mid-April onward. There is a fairly noticeable difference in temperatures from early April which can still be cool for some and mid to late May. Last year, May wasn't so bad but in 2021 we were reaching 30+ degree days quite a lot. https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/wxinfo/pastwx/mws2021/mws202105.htm#:~:text=The%20monthly%20mean%20temperature%20of,highest%20on%20record%20for%20May.

subject: 10. Re: HK tourist scene
usertext: BradJill Ohh.. that's relieving to know that there are still some available. It's a waste to totally ridding them off but as with modernisation, I guess at some point in time they will be gone too I was contemplating to visit at the end of April or May but settled for fourth week of May. Hopefully there will be more sun that week. I dont mind the heat but dont like the dampness caused by the rain and it makes travelling around more troublesome as well.

subject: 11. Re: HK tourist scene
usertext: Peak Tram also has increased its capacity over the past few years, that should also help in keeping the queues down. However only time will tell what happens when tourism numbers are back to normal - the promise of shorter lines may attract so many more riders that in the end there's little difference in waiting times...

subject: 12. Re: HK tourist scene
usertext: @wvmarle Out of curiosity, we passed by the tram stations yesterday (Sat 23 Jan 2023) and were surprised to find rather full trams leaving the lower terminus late morning. This compared to a couple months ago when it was just a handful of locals trying out the new 6th generation trams definitely indicates that tourists are back and starting to congregate around our top attractions again. What I did notice is at the Lower Tram, there seems to be a slow by steady number of people entering and making it through the till where a queue is forming for the next available tram. Still nowhere near the long queues of yesteryears but there were some short queues forming. At the Upper Terminus we went ahead and entered to ride back down. There were no queues to enter the boarding area and perhaps 40 people on the platform waiting for the tram when it arrived for boarding. The ride back down had many empty seats. This wasn't surprising as it was always quicker to board and fewer passengers going back down compared to the ride up. When I took the Peak Tram last in November, probably 25 people on the way up and less than 10 of us on the way down. Anyway, it is interesting to see the difference two months makes when it comes to tourist numbers and activity on the Peak Tram. I've noticed similar rise in passenger traffic on the Star Ferry this month and am already dreading the shoulder-to-shoulder conditions on the Ave. of Stars returning at some point. It has been so nice walking the promenade in the evenings the past few years. That will likely change sooner than later this year as visitor numbers continue to pick up.

subject: 13. Re: HK tourist scene
usertext: >>> the shoulder-to-shoulder conditions on the Ave. of Stars returning at some point I think that'll be mostly when the mainland tour groups are back - I always had the feeling that most of the visitors to that part of the waterfront were participants of such tours. In contrast, the promenade near the Star Ferry, with it's upper viewing deck, appeared to be mostly frequented by tourists not locked into tour groups.

subject: 14. Re: HK tourist scene
usertext: Avenue of Stars sees a lot of visitors on weekends nowadays even without the mainlanders. A lot of locals take their kids and dogs. It's also a popular place for joggers. It's still very pleasant to visit but when the mainlanders do return, I have my doubts.

subject: 3. Re: hong kong airport transfers
usertext: Back in the BC era, I used to advise friends to allow 3 hours for this type of transfer. Now it MIGHT be a little longer, but IMHO either of those flights would be okay. Note that all of the time-consuming COVID inspection folderol at the airport has been abandoned. When I arrived at HKG two weeks ago, the process was almost as smooth as it was BC. So that's one positive point. You might want to check the last check-in time for Cebu Pacific and PAL, just to be sure. Also: note that foreign travelers (without HK ID cards) are only admitted to HK if they have been fully vaccinated, and they have to conduct a COVID rapid self-test before travel (take a picture of the test cartridge showing negative result, in case some airline check-in clerk asks for proof.) The government's COVID info page is here: https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/eng/inbound-travel.html#pointstonote
