subject: 10+ hours layover in Hong Kong alone with 2 young kids
usertext: I know... What was this person thinking? I'm traveling from the US to Asia as a single mom with 2 kids (5 and 7 years old). I spent hours finding flights with the shortest duration and somehow at the last minute accidentally chose the trip with 10+ hours layover on the way back in Hong Kong (before a 16-hour flight to New York). We'll have to stay in Hong Kong from ~ 3pm to 2am. Cathay Pacific would require $600 in fees to change the flights, plus any price difference. Do you think I should just eat the cost and switch flights now? I still have 2 months before the trip. And what should I do with 2 kids in Hong Kong? Is there any "au-pair" service? I'd love to see Hong Kong for the 1st time with kids, but would need to have a guide (a second set of hands is even better). My kids can walk long distance, but the thought of them getting lost is terrifying. I looked up layover tours online but most of them are limited for kids 12 years or older. Any advice/experience/idea is welcome

subject: 1. Re: 10+ hours layover in Hong Kong alone with 2 young kids
usertext: HK is very safe, but can be confusing as it can be very crowded, and people tend to walk pretty fast. If your kids (or you) are not too tired, you can take the airport express train to the Central Station. There is a big shopping mall on top of the station, where there are restaurants and coffee shops. Outside the mall is just a short walk to the harbour. You can even take the (iconic) Star Ferry to the Kowloon side.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: 10+ hours layover in Hong Kong alone with 2 young kids
usertext: Are you travelling on single tickets for both legs of your flight - ie will your luggage be checked straight through to New York, or will you have to collect your bags, find somewhere to store them and then check them back in when you return to the airport? If so, that could take quite a chunk out of the time you have available. Even if you don't have to worry about your luggage you'll still have to pass through customs and security when you leave and re-enter the airport and on the way back that will be quite late at night, so with two young kids to sort out, I'd allow a couple of hours to avoid any last minute rushing or panics. My advice would definitely be not to try to do too much. One suggestion would be to get a bus from the airport to Tung Chung and then take the cable car up to Ngong Ping. If you have the energy you can climb the 268 steps up to the Big Buddha, have a mooch around the shops in the village and, as sunset won't be until about 6.30pm in April, you would even have time to walk one of the shorter Lantau Peak trails - the Wisdom Path and Tree Trail should only take about half an hour. On the way back, you could stop off at Citygate Mall in Tung Chung to get something to eat and see the fountains lit up in the square before heading back to the airport.

subject: 3. Re: 10+ hours layover in Hong Kong alone with 2 young kids
usertext: >> One suggestion would be to get a bus from the airport to Tung Chung and then take the cable car up to Ngong Ping. That's not going to work well if at all considering the OPs travel schedule. For your situation I'd suggest something like The Peak and Star Ferry. Airport Express, bus or taxi between airport and city. If looking for a private guide, try e.g. this site or Viator, or one of the many private guide services. In your situation I totally understand the desire; Hong Kong is safe and fairly easy to navigate though can be overwhelming, especially with two your kids in tow. I used to do guiding, but have left that business (and Hong Kong) myself, no idea who is still doing this after three years of no tourism to speak of.

subject: 4. Re: 10+ hours layover in Hong Kong alone with 2 young kids
usertext: Thank you. That's good to know. subject: 7. Re: 10+ hours layover in Hong Kong alone with 2 young kids
usertext: A quick suggestion: --Airport Express up to HK station, get something to eat if necessary, taxi to Lower Peak Tram Terminus, take Peak Tram up --After the Peak visit, taxi down to Star Ferry HK side. Take ferry across the harbor to Tsim Sha Tsui. Walk the Avenue of Stars toward Tsim Sha Tsui East for the iconic view --Dinner in Tsim Sha Tsui somewhere. Then taxi all the way to the airport or taxi to Kowloon station to ride Airport Express. The taxi + AE option is considerably cheaper but you might just want to make things as easy for yourself as possible You will probably end up having 4 hours or so before your flight time. However, by then, you might just want to rest and your kids might be sleepy.

subject: How to supply Covid test results for arrival
usertext: Hello! Sorry if this has already been covered, I'm struggling to find info. I'm flying UK to Hong Kong via Zurich in a couple of weeks. I understand I can do a rapid antigen test 24hours before flight departure. How do I show the results? Can I simply use an nhs RAT Covid test and photograph the negative line? I used to work in a Covid test centre so I have many to use. Thanks! R

subject: 1. Re: How to supply Covid test results for arrival
usertext: To be honest, I don't know if they are even checking the tests anymore upon arrival at the airport anymore. They are not checking at the ferry terminals or the HZMB bridge to/from Macau this month at all. Probably best to just take a photo of the negative RAT test with your name, date and time of test penciled on the cartridge. If you are asked to show it to the airline taking you to HK you'll have it. Same if you are asked in HK. Probably doesn't hurt to download that photo to your laptop in case your phone battery is dead for some reason when you arrive. As another backup, just carry an extra test with your as back-up so you could simply take it at the airport if all your tech goes kaput and someone wants to see a negative test result.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: How to supply Covid test results for arrival

subject: 4. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: Sha Tin is fairly decent for our New Territories country parks. Pak Tam Au is on the road that splits Sai Kung East and Sai Kung West Country Parks. Loads of good hiking in the Sai Kung country parks and some good opportunities in Ma On Shan Country Park, which will be right behind you as well. I see you have posted a separate question about transport into Sai Kung East for the Tai Long Wan (4 beaches) trail. Great choice! And you are receiving detailed description of the transportation options there so I won't duplicate here. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14265573-Tai_Long_Wan_Hike-Hong_Kong.html Note: Courtyard Marriot Shatin is a short walk to the Shek Mun MTR Station. There are two commercial properties there with a fair amount of casual eateries and even a couple decent coffee shops. There is also a long promenade that runs along the Tolo Harbour which you will be near. You can rent bicycles and ride all the way to Tai Mei Tuk on the northern end of the harbour and back. This can be a fun way to spend a day as well. Some decent sightseeing around Sha Tin for temple viewing and the highly underrated Hong Kong Heritage Museum if you are looking for other things to do near Shek Mun. Edited: 2 years ago

subject: 5. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: Hi BradJill, thanks for your recommendation. i am keen on the bicycle ride to Tai Mei Tuk from Shek Mun. May i know is this a straight forward ride along the Tolo Harbour or will i need to navigate along pedestrian pathways in Shatin? I would also love to hike Ma Onn Shan, just wondering is there a hike all the way to Sai Kung? I have taken part in some trail races before organised by Action Asia but that was many years back so now i just want to enjoy a slow and scenic hike

subject: 6. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: {May i know is this a straight forward ride along the Tolo Harbour or will i need to navigate along pedestrian pathways in Shatin?} The bike lane path mostly runs along the promenade and sea between Tai Wai and Tai Mei Tuk and is very easy to follow. Here is a link to Discover Hong Kong website with a map with details of highlights along the way and map. https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/great-outdoor/sha-tin-to-tai-mei-tuk.html There are a handful of places you can rent bikes as well. You can do so at Tai Wai near the beginning of the trail and Shing Mun River. It is just a few minutes walk from the MTR Station. There are also bike rentals at the Bike Park which is closer to Tai Shui Hang MTR Station or in Sha Tin Park, which is across the river near Sha Tin MTR Station. {I would also love to hike Ma On Shan, just wondering is there a hike all the way to Sai Kung?} Actually yes. You can hike quite a few places in Ma On Shan country Park starting on the promenade side cutting across the park and ending in Sai Kung. I particularly like hiking the Hunchbacks, a gorgeous series of peaks with excellent panoramic views. You can include Ma On Shan Peak, one of HK's highest or places like Ngong Ping where paragliders sail along the ridge line before descending down to Sai Kung village. If you mean to Sai Kung West Country Park, yes, you can hike the MacLehose trail stage 4 through Ma On Shan. It ends at the northeast boundary and Sai Sha Road which is where the Stage 3 begins. This stage transects Sai Kung West Country Park and ends at Pak Tam Au. I wouldn't try combining these two in one day though unless you are in serious hiking shape and condition. One stage is well enough for a single day's hike if you ask me. https://www.alltrails.com/parks/hong-kong/sai-kung/ma-on-shan-country-park Hope this is helpful.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: If you want to hike to Sai Kung via Ma On Shan Peak you can do this by taking bus 299X from Shek Mun towards Sai Kung along Sai Sha Road to the Shui Long Wo bus stop and then following a section of the MacLehose Trail to Tai Shui Tseng as described at the link below which includes a YouTube video; https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/great-outdoor/wellness/maclehose-trail-section-4.html When you finish the descent from the MacLehose Trail at Tai Shui Tseng you can take green minibus 3A into Sai Kung Town or if you still have energy left continue walking to the town (its all downhill); https://www.16seats.net/eng/gmb/gn_3a.html However, to reach the summit of Ma On Sha you need to take a fairly short, steep diversion off the MacLehose Trail (the path is pretty obvious) and ignore the warning signs advising not proceed. Its a bit of a scramble over loose earth and stone near the top but nowhere as precarious as it looks from below. Its quite an ardous hike until you reach finish the ascent but as mentioned by BradJill there are some superb panoramic views from Ma On Shan and the Ngong Ping Plateau and its a very rewarding hike; https://www.flickr.com/gp/hongkongviews/5F8986T715 If you decide to take the challenge sure to take plenty of water, its easy to become dehydrated if the weather's hot and humid. Edited: 2 years ago

subject: 9. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: {As for hiking in Sai Kung, Shatin is not the most convenient location, as it is on the other side of Hong Kong. The easiest way to get to Pak Tam Au for hiking would be to take the MTR East Rail Line to Tai Po Market Station, then take a taxi or bus to the Sai Kung area. Once in Sai Kung, you can take the minibus or bus to the Pak Tam Chung bus stop, which is the closest stop to Pak Tam Au.} James???? Your post is very strange, especially the part about sending people the wrong direction up to Tai Po Market, which is on the opposite side of Tolo Harbour to the Sai Kung country parks to then taxi over to Pak Tam Chung. That would make no sense at all for the original poster starting their journey from Shek Mun.

subject: 11. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: Thanks BradJill and SolentTraveller for your invaluable inputs. I did exactly what were advised and had a great time hiking from Ma On Shan all the way to Sai Kung via Tai Shui Tseng. The sceneries were amazing but due to constant fog in the late morning, the views over Sai Kung piers were just periodical. However, I need to mention about the difficulty of the hike especially before the Hunchback. There were sections that requires climbers' strength to hold onto some rocks so I think this hike is not for beginners. The NgongPing plateau were scenic and the end section before reaching Sai Kung, one has to navigate endless stairs but the bamboo forest provided some relief. There is even mini bus that 'waited' for me and brought me back to Sai Kung for a delicious lunch after the hike. I have a question, I saw some hikers took the other way to Mau Ping after NgongPing and not Tai Shui Tseng. Where does this leads to? I may want to try this route next round. Thanks! Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 12. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: I strongly recommend getting a map. This will answer all your questions on where the trails lead, and perhaps avoid you getting lost! The Countryside series of 5 maps covers the whole SAR. https://www.landsd.gov.hk/en/survey-mapping/mapping/thematic-mapping.html Available at good bookshops, hiking equipment stores. Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 13. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: Sounds like you started the hike near Ma On Shan town or Wu Kai Sha if you took the route over the Hunchbacks. I remember doing this in the opposite direction once, and after the narrow path across the Hunchbacks ridge found the descent quite difficult. I probably went wrong somewhere but was going downhill through forest clinging on to ropes slung between trees alongside a very steep earth and stone path for ages without appearing to get any closer to civilisation before eventually ending up at Wu Kai Sha Station. If you carry on the MacLehose Trail past Tai Shui Tseng instead of descending to Sai Kung more views over Sha Tin open up but much of the route is through forest before stage 4 ends at Gilwell Camp. I would also recommend purchasing the Countryside Series maps for hiking. You can download black and white versions of sections of these maps free of charge showing mobile phone coverage along hiking trails including the MacLehose Trail, from the Office of Communications website; https://www.ofca.gov.hk/filemanager/ofca/common/consumer/mobile/country/map/OFCA-MT-S4.pdf

subject: 14. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: Yeah I started from Ma On Shan family walk after walking all the way from MOS MTR. I thought I passed two trigonometry points (can't remember) and then a final steep hill before descending onto NgongPing where I saw many picnickers. I cannot imagine if it rains, those trails must be muddy as I struggled to wipe away all the orange dusts away as I had to hold onto some rocks both ascending and descending the hills. Started at 9.30am but only ended my hike just before lunch. Had a great time. Thanks for the recommendation. Don't mind doing the reverse now

subject: 15. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: Good to see you enjoyed Ma On Shan Country Park. There are some fun places to visit there that are not on many tourist maps. {I saw some hikers took the other way to Mau Ping after NgongPing and not Tai Shui Tseng. Where does this leads to? I may want to try this route next round.} You can pass through or even target hikes around the old village of Mau Ping. The Buffalo Hills just south of Mau Ping makes for a good hike (see link) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g294217-d593161-r871839539-Ma_On_Shan_Country_Park-Hong_Kong.html If you like the bamboo forests, there is a really cool bamboo tunnel (see hiking notes below) along the old Pak Kong Ancient Trail just south and east of Mau Ping as well. https://tripadvisor.com.hk/ShowUserReviews-g294217-d593161-r826477655-Ma_On_Shan_Country_Park-Hong_Kong.html If you want to try a stream trail, the Ma Dai Stream hike (see notes) from Tai Shui Hang which is quite fun https://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g294217-d24994607-Reviews-Ma_Dai_Stream_Trail-Hong_Kong.html Last, if you want to try something really different, there is giant stone forest in Ma On Shan Country Park with a huge field of large boulder stacks that you can climb up and down. The rocks are craggy at times so gloves are essential (see notes) https://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g294217-d23309919-Reviews-Luk_Chau_Shan_stone_Forest-Hong_Kong.html Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 16. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: It's only by sheer chance I stumbled on this hiking discussion in a hotel thread. All I can add to the above is, OpenStreetMap in HK is absolutely excellent for hiking; the trail detail is superb thanks to the efforts of local mappers. Various apps provide OSM in offline mode; I've hiked all over HK's hills using Locus Map (for Android) which is quite recommendable. Here's an online preview. It's cycling focused but you can see the trails. https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=14/22.2499/114.1871&layers=C A good app lets you choose language, so if you can't read Chinese script, it'll show English instead; HK is mapped for both.

subject: 17. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: The big problem I have with OpenStreetMap is that all trails appear equal - a dash line on the map could be a maintained, clearly signposted, official country trail, or it could be an unmarked scramble over steep rocks requiring gloves, ropes and a machete that was only ever done once by some fanatic. There's no way of knowing until you get there. It also needs batteries! I would strongly recommend a good old-fashioned paper map, i.e. the Countrysdie Series.

subject: 18. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: When it comes to trail type/quality, the Countryside maps have by and large the same issue as OSM, where OSM tends to be more up to date with the actual situation. Too often I've tried to follow paths on the paper maps that didn't exist any more. Use the Cycle Map overlay for contour lines, very important when planning hikes in Hong Kong's mountainous terrain. The Hunchbacks is a great hike, but indeed definitely not when you're inexperienced.

subject: 19. Re: Courtyard Marriot Shatin
usertext: Trail-quality info often *is* in the OSM database, but the particular map you're using (derived from it) may not show any distinction. Some maps do, typically as a thinner series of dots for a faint trail, maybe a thick colored stripe for a famous trail like the Maclehose. Many many different maps are built from the OSM data, for different purposes. (EG, forget the transport map for hiking, once you've reached the trailhead.) Added up, I've spent appx. 2 months on HK trails of all qualities. OSM has been all I ever needed (specifically, OpenAndroMaps in Locus Map; both these are specifically focused on hiking.) Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Tai Long Wan Hike
usertext: Any idea how do i get to the start point of TLW-Pak Tam Au from Shek Mun ? Thanks!

subject: 1. Re: Tai Long Wan Hike
usertext: Best (shortest walk) would be to just get a New Territories (green) taxi and ask to go to the pavilion at the end of Sai Kung Sai Wan road https://www.google.com/maps/place/Sai+Wan+Pavilion/@22.3942552,114.3491837,16z/data=!4m13!1m7!3m6!1s0x34040646d6b7bd87:0x790ec172ae013386!2sShek+Mun!3b1!8m2!3d22.3889593!4d114.2088722!3m4!1s0x340410748df1ad35:0x279439cdd2b1c016!8m2!3d22.3947978!4d114.3601788 The taxis can go through the Country Park entry gate at Pak Tam Chung, and take you all the way. Note that this is a different starting point than you requested at Pak Tam Au, but it is a shorter walk into the TLW beach. Alternatively, you can take buses from Shek Mun. The government's e-mobility app offers point-to-point journey planning. https://www.hkemobility.gov.hk/en You will want to get a bus to Sai Kung bus terminus (I dunno which bus will get you there from Shek Mun, but there will certainly be one), and then KMB bus No. 94, whose terminus will say Wong Shek Pier. The buses have electronic signboards that will announce the stop for Pak Tam Au (which is in the middle of the country park without buildings around). Edited: 2 years ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Tai Long Wan Hike
usertext: To get to Pak Tam Chung or Pak Tam Au by bus no need to go to Sai Kung Bus Terminus, you can take KMB route 299X (Sha Tin to Sai Kung every 20 mins, 6am to midnight) from Shek Mun (Ravana Garden) to Mak Pin (Tai Mong Tsai Roundabout) to connect with KMB 94 route (Sai Kung - Wong Shek Pier) to Pak Tam Chung or Pak Tam Au or with green minibus 7 for Pak Tam Au / Pak Tam Chung; https://www.saikungplb.com/e-route7.html or green minibus 9 for Pak Tam Chung; https://www.saikungplb.com/e-route9.html On Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays, KMB bus route 289R (Sha Tin - Wong Shek Pier) offers a direct service from Shek Mun (Ravana Garden Bus Interchange) to Pak Tam Chung and Pak Tam Au. It operates from Sha Tin every 30 mins from 7am to 3pm and from Wong Shek Pier every hour from 9-10am to 2-10pm then every 30 mins 2-10pm to 7pm. At weekends there's also a green minibus service 9A from Pak Tam Chung which goes inside the country park to High Island Reservoir; https://www.saikungplb.com/e-route9a.html

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Tai Long Wan Hike
usertext: There's also a residents bus service (29 seats) which any one can use from outside McDonalds on Chan Man Street in Sai Kung Town to Sai Wan Pavilion (referred to by HK Observer in above post). It also stops on request near the roundabout on Tai Mong Tsai Road; https://www.td.gov.hk/filemanager/en/content_4796/WCONTE/20191120_nr29_eng.pdf

subject: 4. Re: Tai Long Wan Hike
usertext: I'd suggest taking the MTR to Choi Hung then any bus or public van to Sai Kung. If you're doing the full circuit, best to start at Sai Wan Pavilion (take a taxi there from Sai Kung unless you manage to catch the public van) and end at Pak Tam Au because transport back to Sai Kung is much easier from there: you won't have to wait too long for a bus or public van to Sai Kung. Or you can start at Pak Tam Au and just return there after visiting TLW. Edited: 2 years ago

subject: 5. Re: Tai Long Wan Hike
usertext: My only add would be based on what time of day you wanting to hike and if you are going on weekend or not. If early morning on weekend, I'd go with the taxi as public buses run less regular into the park early on. I like hitting the beaches there before the crowds show up (9-10am) and if the weather is fairly nice, they will start showing up by late morning even during the cooler months. Also note, that transportation out of Sai Kung East on weekends can be a bit hectic. As there will many hikers trying to exit the park from mid to late evening onward and transportation is somewhat limited. We've sat at the bus stop near Pak Tam Au for long waits as one full bus after another goes by. For this reason, I'd recommend loading the HK Taxi app (see link below) to your phone (if you are a data plan) so that you can arrange transport out of the park if the queues at the bus stands are too much https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.cornermation.calltaxi&hl=en&gl=US&pli=1 Another great way to exit country park after the Tai Long Wan trail if the sea conditions are good is to take speed boat from Sai Wan or Ham Tin beach back to Sai Kung village (see review below with details of the speedboat option). https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g294217-d2003133-r787533938-Tai_Long_Wan-Hong_Kong.html Sai Kung is a fun seaside village with good restaurants, coffee shops a few bars as well. There is a large bus hub as well where you can get on the buses back towards your hotel.

subject: 3. Re: Best area for families in August
usertext: I would suggest staying in the Wan Chai or Causeway Bay areas of HK Island or Tsim Sha Tsui in Kowloon for the easiest transport connections to places of interest, but with 4 nights, public transport is so good in HK that as long as you're close to an MTR station, you should be ok. A few other places that I would suggest may be of interest are Ocean Park (possibly more interesting than Disney for your two older children), Victoria Peak, the Science Museum, Ngong Ping village and Kadoorie Farm.

subject: 4. Re: Best area for families in August
usertext: Royal Park Hotel in Mongkok has long been a popular choice for families on the Kowloon side. It is next to the Mongkok East MTR Station which is part of the East Rail Line. Note: The long awaited extension of the East Rail Line to Admiralty Station on HK Island finally happened last year. As such, there is now direct connection from the Mongkok East Station to HK Island with a journey time of just 10 minutes.

subject: 3 bedroom suites

subject: 1. Re: 3 bedroom suites
usertext: Some of the luxury hotels offer 3 bedroom suites but when it comes to mid and lower range properties, not so much. If you are looking at mid-range options, I'd suggest reviewing what family rooms are available on booking sites like booking.com. This will give you an idea of what is generally available around the city and multiple room booking combinations you might want to consider based on the number of people in your family.

subject: 2. Re: 3 bedroom suites
usertext: I struggle to think of any hotel with 3 bedroom suites, even here in the US. Unless you are willing to book with a high end hotel, 3 rooms suites are very uncommon. Salisbury YMCA has dorm rooms which sleep 4. How many are in your group? Can you book 3 separate rooms?

subject: Big Buddha on a 6 hour 50 minute layover
usertext: Hey all, I searched the forum for things to do during a long layover at Hong Kong airport and seems that visiting the Big Buddha is something that would be doable given my time constraints. I'm just hoping for some guidance from the kind folks on here about what would be the best way to pull this off. I am arriving in Hong Kong at 9:35am in the morning and my connecting flight departs at 4:25pm. Its the same airline (Cathy) so much bags will be checked in to my final destination. Firstly would this visit be manageable in my time frame? Regarding getting there, I was reading that I have to take the MTR to Tung Chung and then take the cable car up from there. What I was a little confused about was where I could obtain an Octopus card and can it be used for things other than transit? Any input about any other details that I'm missing/easier public transit options to get there are greatly appreciated.

subject: 1. Re: Big Buddha on a 6 hour 50 minute layover
usertext: " Firstly would this visit be manageable in my time frame? " <---------------------------------------- It is a bit a rush, manageable though. " I was reading that I have to take the MTR to Tung Chung" <------------------------------------ MTR trains from the airport do not stop in Tung Chung. You must first go to Tsing Yi Station and change trains for Tung Chung. In fact, right outside the passenger terminal, there are several buses for Tung Chung. It is way cheaper and it takes around 20 to 30 minutes only. Of course, the most convenient way is taking a taxi. If you want you may take a taxi directly to the Big Buddha. Either red or blue taxi is ok. The blue one is cheaper. " where I could obtain an Octopus card " <----------------------- If it is such a short stay, forget about Octopus. Just pay cash. Edited: 2 years ago

subject: 2. Re: Big Buddha on a 6 hour 50 minute layover
usertext: If you want to be conservative with time, I wouldn't bother with the shuttle buses or taxi between the airport to Tung Chung as you are still quite far from the Big Buddha. Instead, I'd take taxi from the airport all the way to the Ngong Ping village where you will find the Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery. You can then take the 360 cable car back down to Tung Chung as long as time is playing in your favour. From there quick taxi or bus back to the airport and you are good to go. If your time is a bit short after seeing the Big Buddha, then just grab a taxi from the village directly back to the airport.

subject: 3. Re: Big Buddha on a 6 hour 50 minute layover
usertext: Assuming you aren't coming on crowded days, 6:50 should offer you enough time for a relaxing trip. From the airport, you can take a taxi or the bus S1 to Tung Chung station. The cable car station is next to Tung Chung station. You can then easily take the cable car up and spend 1-2 hours up there. If everything goes smoothly, you should still have at least 3 hours before your flight. Find a restaurant at the Citygate Outlet Mall as it offers more choices than dining at the airport. You can buy an Octopus at the airport station though when you surrender the card, you will need to pay a small handling fee in order to get back any unused credit.

subject: 4. Re: Big Buddha on a 6 hour 50 minute layover
usertext: +1 for taking taxi up first; this as the lines for the cable car are almost always much longer going up than going down. 9:35 arrival; immigration; 10:15ish on the taxi, almost an hour later arrive at the Buddha. 2:30 on the cable car down (likely no line at that hour), arrive by 3 at the lower terminal, taxi to the airport. That leaves just over an hour to get through security and immigration, which is normally enough. So up to three hours up there which is nice. Time for a meal as well. The only thing I'm concerned about is that when HKIA gets more passengers that the normally smooth security and baggage handling breaks down like we've seen in Europe. Time will tell whether they can get enough staff fast enough to deal with this. Do keep an eye out on e.g. this forum closer to your planned trip date. Schedule of airport formalities is based on BC performance.

subject: 6. Re: Big Buddha on a 6 hour 50 minute layover
usertext: @jamezyd32 {To get to the Big Buddha, you'll need to take the MTR to Tung Chung Station} This is not possible. There is no MTR service between HKIA and Tung Chung. If passengers want to go to Tung Chung from the airport, they will need to take bus or taxi as has been described above in posts above.

subject: 7. Re: Big Buddha on a 6 hour 50 minute layover
usertext: It's a worthy trip. As mentioned. Use a taxi the whole way. Id skip the Octopus card unless it's totally necessary for the Big Buddha .

subject: 8. Re: Big Buddha on a 6 hour 50 minute layover
usertext: The cable car is GREAT. Worth riding up and down just for the sake of it (in good weather, of course).

subject: Prepaid SIM at the Airport
usertext: Havent been to HK in ages. Is the 1010 shop still there? Do they still sell prepaid SIM?

subject: 1. Re: Prepaid SIM at the Airport
usertext: You don't necessarily need to head to 1010. Convenience stores like 7-11 and OK sell them as well.

subject: 3. Re: Prepaid SIM at the Airport
usertext: When you buy at a convenience store etc you don't register at the time of purchase. You register yourself afterwards online, and the sim won't be activated until you have registered. If you're looking for a particular sim package -- and there are many different ones -- you may have to visit several stores since most stores only have a few in available stock. Further, this is Hong Kong so don't expect any help from the clerks. You need to know in advance exactly what you're looking for. Edited: 2 years ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Prepaid SIM at the Airport
usertext: Some excellent guidance from Traveltomtom in this recent video; https://youtu.be/OEpBSoy0ac4 Edited: 2 years ago

subject: 6. Re: Prepaid SIM at the Airport

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: Prepaid SIM at the Airport
usertext: All new SIM cards have required registration since March 2022. The Feb 2023 deadline is for existing SIM cards.

subject: 8. Re: Prepaid SIM at the Airport
usertext: New cards simply won't work until you have registered.

subject: 9. Re: Prepaid SIM at the Airport
usertext: Thanks

subject: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: In the UK since Covid, a large number of shops/restaurants etc are 'cash free', we are hoping to visit Hong Kong in the spring, is it best to just bring a card or is cash preferable? Thank you

subject: 1. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: Cash is still accepted pretty much everywhere. There are still plenty of places that don't accept cards, but I haven't yet seen any that don't want cash.

subject: 2. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: There are some barbershops at least that are Octopus-only.

subject: 3. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: What you can do in HK can be severely restricted if you have no cash.

subject: 5. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: When everything is cashless, if negative rate goes negative, people simply have no where to hide.

subject: 6. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: Cash is widely acceptable. If you are going to use public transport, it is better to get an Octopus card (a pre paid card) It can also be used to make small purchases.

subject: 8. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: @alamigo -- interesting about barbershops. I did come across two days ago my first shop that would not accept cash -- a Starbucks that proudly advertised they have "gone cashless." So maybe we are seeing the camel's nose peeking underneath the tent.......

subject: 10. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: Cash + Octopus card = OK! Every time I went to HK I prepare cash Using visa cards when in hotels and big stores, sometimes China Unionpay cards or app have discount.

subject: 11. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: Wow the UK has really turned Orwellian. I was just in Laos, where cash remains king. It's difficult to find a place where credit cards are accepted. Restaurants that claim to accept cards, don't have working terminals. Not a single gas station in the entire country accepts credit cards, though Thai owned PTT stations do accept the Lao QR code payment system. Also, a lot of businesses accept QR codes but not credit cards, meaning the whole plastic revolution (credit/debit cards) has largely bypassed Lao. Only businesses reliably accepting cards are supermarkets in Vientiane such as Parkson (which is Chinese owned and only accepts VISA and UnionPay but not Mastercard), Thai owned Rimping (which accepts all major credit cards) and large 4 and 5 star hotels. Cash is accepted everywhere. Unlike in Malaysia where some family mart stores are now electronic only, meaning cards or QR code payment.

subject: 12. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: Can you pay with the octopus card at Starbucks?

subject: 13. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: @orangenlemon {Can you pay with the octopus card at Starbucks?} Yes! All Starbucks accept Octopus Card.

subject: 14. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: Can I add money into Octopus card using credit card?

subject: 15. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: #14, RE: "Can I add money into Octopus card using credit card?" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = No. Cash only.

subject: 16. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: What types of credit / debit cards can I use to add a new Octopus or to top up an Octopus via the Octopus App for Tourists? Any non-Hong Kong issued Mastercard, UnionPay and Visa credit or debit cards supported by Apple Pay can be used. https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/customer-service/faq/tourist-apple-pay/get.html

subject: 17. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: You can add value to the Octopus via a credit card if you load the card onto apps like Apple Pay and similar Android apps like Samsung Wallet. Another way is to apply for the Automatic Add Value Service. I don't know if you can use either with a foreign based card though. Either way, one normally cannot go about daily life in HK entirely cashless. If you are staying for 6 days or so, you will likely need to use cash at some point even if you can use a credit card to recharge your Octopus.

subject: 18. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: See the following octopus Card info (link below). Get an Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch (using non-HK issued credit/debit cards) You can get an Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch by: Issuing a new Octopus via the Octopus App for Tourists A new Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch can be added via the Octopus App for Tourists, with a minimum initial stored value of HK$100 and a deposit of HK$50, paid for by a non-Hong Kong issued Mastercard, UnionPay or Visa credit or debit card using Apple Pay. There is no fee associated with adding a new Octopus. https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/customer-service/faq/tourist-apple-pay/get.html#:~:text=Issuing%20a%20new%20Octopus%20via,debit%20card%20using%20Apple%20Pay.

subject: 19. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: How widely is credit card accepted across HK? I am asking because forex rates are much better on credit card than debit card so need to manage accordingly

subject: 20. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: We have just been in Hong Kong for 4 days and used cash pretty much the whole time. Never had an Octopus card. We did use our UK bank card a few times and had no issues, but we have one that gives very good exchange rate, no fees etc.

subject: 21. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: Apart from some low-cost barber shops, cash is accepted in virtually every business. There are even a lot of shops, especially some small business, which are cash-only.

subject: 22. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: Unlike China, cash is still widely accepted in Hong Kong. Many small shops prefer cash as it is easier to hide actual sales with cash in order to pay less taxes.

subject: 23. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: I think I've also seen a lot of parking garages which are Octopus-only, though that's not going to affect the casual tourist.

subject: 24. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?
usertext: Just about all parking garages accept Octopus these days. Some might indeed be Octopus only. Most (but not all) also accept credit cards. Strangely, I parked at a garage the other day that took both Octopus and Visa but no Mastercard. American Express is often the exception.

subject: 25. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?

subject: 26. Re: Is cash still widely accepted?

subject: Octopus card vs Forex card
usertext: Hi, I am planning to visit HK from March 5th to 10th. I am wondering if buying an octopus card after arriving in HK is a better option than to load a Forex card. Can someone please give me suggestions on how many places accept/deny Forex card? Is Octopus card acceptable everywhere in HK? Thanks for your time. Regards, Sri Harsha.

subject: 1. Re: Octopus card vs Forex card
usertext: Such Forex card might give you a terrible exchange rate to start? Even if they give you a fair rate, make sure they are Visa or Mastercard if you want them to be accepted. In HK, you need cash for sure. Octopus just lets you put cash onto the card so you don't have buy tickets or use coins for transport. You can also use it for cashless transactions at convenience stores, chain supermarkets, and some merchants. There will still be merchants that only take cash (no credit, no Octopus, no prepaid cards).

subject: 2. Re: Octopus card vs Forex card
usertext: The Octopus card's main use is for public transportation (subway, bus, trams, etc). A Forex card is no use for that.

subject: 3. Re: Octopus card vs Forex card
usertext: Thanks for the inputs... So what % cash and what % can I keep in a mastercard or visa forex card? I'm traveling with my wife for 5 or 6 days. How much cash should I consider in a day for transport, food and attractions on average?

subject: 4. Re: Octopus card vs Forex card
usertext: {How much cash should I consider in a day for transport, food and attractions on average?} That is a really tough question to answer as we don't know you or your spending habits. Some very good attractions are free or very cheap but others cost quite a fair amount. Related, some food/meal options are cheap/affordable while fine dining in HK can be very expensive. It is all going to depend on what you want to do/see/eat while you are in Hong Kong.

subject: 5. Re: Octopus card vs Forex card
usertext: There are ATMs all over the territory, so assuming you have a bank account and an ATM card then you can withdraw cash whenever you need it (but check with your bank about charges - as long as you stick to the major bank ATMs there are no charges from the HK banks for using their ATMs to withdraw cash)

subject: 6. Re: Octopus card vs Forex card
usertext: This is a great input. Thanks. Is HDFC Mastercard/Visa card OK? Are international Debit cards accepted across all ATMs? Regards, Sri Harsha.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: Octopus card vs Forex card
usertext: If you're in Hong Kong for 5 nights, you'll probably be using public transport quite a lot and I'd say that getting Octopus cards is a no-brainer! They save you so much time and hassle when, instead of fiddling around with cash and tickets, you only have to tap them as you get on a bus, tram, ferry or MTR - some of which don't even give you change if you only have notes to pay with!

subject: 8. Re: Octopus card vs Forex card
usertext: All ATMs (at least all the ones from major banks such as HSBC, Hang Seng, Bank of China, etc) will accept all Cirrus/Maestro/Mastercard and Visa/Plus cards. But for 5 nights, definitely get Octopus Cards (you need one for each person for public transport). You can top up Octopus cards (with cash only) at all MTR stations and all convenience stores (7-Eleven, CircleK).

subject: 1. Re: Passport expiry in Apr/May and travel in Mar
usertext: https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/plan/traveller-info/immigrations-and-customs.html {In general, all visitors to Hong Kong must have a passport that is valid for at least one month after the period of their intended stay in Hong Kong. However, documents issued to stateless persons must be valid for a minimum of two months after the period of intended stay. Please contact the Immigration Department for further details.}

I barely have a couple of weeks and if I buy flight tickets and book hotels, cancellation will be unbearable for me. Please advice.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Passport expiry in Apr/May and travel in Mar
usertext: The result of online Pre-Registration for Indian Nationals is instant. See FAQ 17; https://webapp.es2.immd.gov.hk/applies2-client/static/faq/i-par-reg/en-US/i-par-reg-faq.html There's no point in making any arrangements until the application has been approved. Approval does not guarantee entry and you will still be subject to normal immigration entry requirements including passport validity Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Passport expiry in Apr/May and travel in Mar
usertext: The FAQ page says Indian Passport should be valid for 6 months. The previous link shows that validity of at least one month. Which one is more accurate? Please help.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 5. Re: Passport expiry in Apr/May and travel in Mar
usertext: I believe the 6-month validity requirement relates to the date of application for Pre-arrival Registration (PAR). This is different to the entry requirement of at least one month at date of entry.

subject: Victoria peak
usertext: I was wondering when the best time is to arrive? I will be going there on a Tuesday in March.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Victoria peak
usertext: If its the views you're going for then consider the Peak circle walk, starting in the afternoon before sunset; https://www.hellohongkong.com.hk/blog/peak-circle-walk

subject: 2. Re: Victoria peak
usertext: Make sure it's not a foggy or misty day if you go up to the Peak.

subject: 3. Re: Victoria peak
usertext: If its cloudy of foggy, the view during the daytime is quite underwhelming by comparison to the famous photos you would have seen of Victoria Harbour and the HK Skylines during blue sky days. However, it is still pretty neat after dark when the skyscrapers below and across on the Kowloon side are lit up. If the sky conditions are favourable, I love it at late morning when the sun on top of you, lighting up the entire harbour and skyscrapers in front of you - all set against deep blue background - just so beautiful. Otherwise, if you time it right, you can do evening with softer and lighter colours as the sun goes down and also see it the bright city under the dark skies of night as well - sort of a 2 for 1 deal on the views.

subject: 4. Re: Victoria peak
usertext: March can be iffy when it comes to misty and foggy days. We get those even in February sometimes. Just this past Sunday, visiting some friends living up in Mid-Levels, we couldn't see a thing outside.

subject: 5. Re: Victoria peak
usertext: It depends on what you want to see. My suggestion is 5:00 PM is a good time. Stay there for 2 to 3 hours. You can see the sunset and appreciate the night view of the harbour.

subject: Transferring at Hong Kong Intl Airport
usertext: Hi there, please can someone shed some light on how the transfer procedures are smooth at HKG Intl Airport? I'm arriving at 22:30 from Hanoi by Cathay Pacific and should connect at 23:45 with Lufthansa to Frankfurt. Is the transfer time enough for me to connect onto the LH-flight? Anyone any experiences how quick the transit is for inbound passengers but not entering in HKG? I'm a foreign (EU) citizen and should find the transfer desk for LH too.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Transferring at Hong Kong Intl Airport
usertext: Minimum connection time for airside transfers at HKIA is 50 minutes. Provided your flight from Hanoi is not delayed the connection time should be sufficient. Lufthansa uses transfer desk E1 and the transfer process is described at the link below; https://www.hongkongairport.com/iwov-resources/file/passenger-guide/transfer-transit/transfer_transit_guide.pdf

subject: 2. Re: Transferring at Hong Kong Intl Airport
usertext: If this is booked as one ticket then Cathay should be able to provide your onward boarding LH pass when you check in at Hanoi. In any case they should be able to check your bags through (75 minutes is not enough time for you to do this transfer if you need to go landside, collect bags and recheck them).

subject: 3. Re: Transferring at Hong Kong Intl Airport
usertext: The key is whether the two flights are booked under the same ticket. If yes, you are protected against a missed flight which could mean a hotel night in HK for free. I am not sure if CX can provide you with an LH boarding pass. If not, stop by the transfer desk as mentioned. Alternatively, you can just use online check-in to get your LH boarding pass.

Hope the transfer desk can quickly arrange that for me. Thanks anyways! Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Transferring at Hong Kong Intl Airport
usertext: I have no idea whether CX will let you board with just a Standby ticket. Even if they do, since you cannot control whether LH will have a seat available for you, I wonder if they will still consider you a transit passenger. Technically, today's requirement is you must be able to show a negative RAT for Covid if you want to enter HK. If you board as a transit passenger though, you don't need to show the RAT result. If you can't produce a confirmed onward ticket, I don't know if CX will let you board without the negative RAT result. I suggest you get a test kit just in case. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 8. Re: Transferring at Hong Kong Intl Airport
usertext: If you bought your ticket out of HKG separately, then presumably you paid the airport tax. Since you're arriving and departing by air the same day, you can get a refund of it. https://www.cad.gov.hk/english/departure_tax.html

subject: 10. Re: Transferring at Hong Kong Intl Airport
usertext: You have to go through security when arriving in HK airport. TiP. If there is a line use the entrance on the right and tell the staff member that your connection time is really short. In the past a member of Cathay met me at the incoming flight and guided me to the next gate and jumped the security que. that was when both flights were Cathay. HK has an internal train to take you from one gate to another.

subject: 13. Re: Transferring at Hong Kong Intl Airport
usertext: Maybe you confused HKG airport with a USA airport. Except from a few ports like Dublin and Canada where pre-clearance is done, inbound passengers to the USA cannot transfer to another international flight without clearing USA immigration and customs. At HKG, like most other airports worldwide, as long as you hold an onward ticket and your bags are tagged to your destination (or if you have no checked bags), there is no need to go through immigration and customs in order to reach the departure area of your onward international flight. @jamezyd32: we all make mistakes posting here. However, almost all of your posts so far contain incorrect information. You are going to confuse travelers instead of helping them. Assuming you aren't a troll, please check carefully before posting. >>>As a foreign citizen, you will need to clear immigration and customs, so be sure to allow enough time for this process.

subject: 18. Re: Transferring at Hong Kong Intl Airport
usertext: If it helps. I had a layover in HK more than once. One day our flight came in in the early afternoon and the next flight was 10am the next day. We exited the airport went to HK island via subway . Rode the tram, ate dinner , did touristy stuff. Came back to the airport before midnight. Went through security - didn't have bags as Cathy nicely kept them for us - and at that time - they had lounge chairs that were sleepable. So we were lucky to find two together and we slept on them. They were close to a bathroom and food court. This was PRE COVID. Today. Who knows the deal. But a night in the HK is doable for sure. No one approached us. Another time I had the same deal. In on cathay at night. Next flight was the 10am to shanghai. Walked around the airport. Ate food. Walked around more. Free carts so it's easy.

usertext: Hi guys, have just came back from HKG and just a few update for you in case interested on my original post: Well, transferring without a confermed ticket is officially not possible, but maybe as I am an airline staff they did issue me a standby boarding pass after arriving from the Cathay flight, but then at the LH Gate - unfortunately due to the flight was fully b ooked I was offloaded (plus was told that next time I have to go to the check-in desk and have to ask for a boarding pass there as it is not possible to transfer with a standby pass only!)... anyway, to make the storeey short I had to overnight an the airport which was super easy of course I had to enter HK but they didn't ask for any Antigen tests or so, just fill in the arrival form (with a random hotel name getting from booking.com) and they just let me enter the country. Overnightng as said was good enough, no one approached me or so and could board the flight the next day by going throigh the whole check in process, security etc.

subject: 1. Re: 12 Hr. Layover
usertext: At the current time neither of the hop on / hop off bus tours operates on Thursdays. Both the Big Bus Tour and Rickshaw Sightseeing bus tour operate Friday - Sunday and public holidays only.

subject: 4. Re: 12 Hr. Layover

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

I thought it rather soulless and wouldn't stay there out of choice for leisure purpose. The room was spacious but the decor made it appear rather dark and dingy.

subject: 8. Re: 12 Hr. Layover

Since my cousin was there just to have a quick tour and the same time morning back to hongkong City tour. Any advice recommendations the flight details august 12 Saturday night 8:15pm.. Thanks in advance for the tips of how to experience my connecting flight and have a long lay over

subject: 11. Re: 12 Hr. Layover
usertext: Hello Cindy, {Manila-dubai I have lay over of 21hrs I will be reach hongkong at 8:15pm since I'm holding Philippine passport it's ok I can visit Macau from hongkong airport to Macau? } Even during pre-pandemic times, it is generally not recommended to try making a day trip over to Macau during flight connections out of Hong Kong. There may be enough time to make this happen but if for some reason you miss transportation back from Macau, you will miss your outbound flight out of HK as well. As such the risk is generally considered too high compared to just enjoying your day here in Hong Kong. Best to just enjoy a day in Hong Kong and save Macau for another trip when you can explore our sister city more thoroughly. There is quite a lot to do/see there now compared to 15-20 years ago. Its worth 2-3 days to visit well.

subject: 13. Re: 12 Hr. Layover
usertext: Hi James, Thank for sharing all this information it's a big help for me since this is my first time to have this long Lay over. You think it will go smoothly when reached evening and go directly to Macau?

subject: 14. Re: 12 Hr. Layover
usertext: So 20:15 arrival and 21 hours layover, meaning departing 17:15 next day. Well, technically you could. With your arrival time, luggage check immigration, transport, etc you can xpect to arrive in your Macau hotel a little before midnight. You'll have to leave your hotel latest 13:00 the next day, better leave noon or earlier as you're not familiar with transport so need more of a buffer. Expect 2-2.5 hrs travel from leaving your hotel to arriving at HKIA if all goes smoothly. So that gives you a night starting midnight and a very early morning in Macau. With those hours you may consider to forego the hotel and just hang out in the casinos until it's light enough outdoors to go and see some of the heritage sights... if you have the energy for a schedule that grueling.

subject: 15. Re: 12 Hr. Layover

subject: 16. Re: 12 Hr. Layover
usertext: That's a good reason to want to make that trip :-) Though I think it'd be much better (for you, mostly - less stressful) to have your cousin come over to Hong Kong for a day. Nothing beats having someone pick you up from the plane in a foreign place :-) Have a great trip!

subject: 2. Re: Quick visit to Hong Kong wih 12 hour lay over.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Quick visit to Hong Kong wih 12 hour lay over.
usertext: Yes; https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/eng/public-transport-faq.html#FAQ1

subject: 7. Re: Quick visit to Hong Kong wih 12 hour lay over.
usertext: @jamezyd32 { If you plan to leave the airport during your layover, you will need to take a Covid-19 test prior to re-entry. The airport has testing facilities available for travelers, or you can arrange to take a test at a local medical clinic or hospital} This is not correct, James. There are no local testing requirements to enter or re-enter the airport to fly out of Hong Kong. The only HK gov testing requirement which remains is for inbound travellers (from Taiwan or outside of China) to have a self-administered RAT test within 24 hours or PCR test within 48 hours of their original departure to Hong Kong. As such, if you are making a connection and want to do a day out in HK, you do need to meet the same testing requirements for arriving inbound passengers mentioned above. You may also have to meet other foreign country testing requirements applied to individuals who have been in China (inc. Hong Kong). However, there are no local (HK gov) testing requirements for when you are ready to return to the airport to take connecting flight to final destination.

subject: Kai Tak port, Kowloon
usertext: Is Kowloon the best place to stay if taking a Celebrity cruise?

subject: 1. Re: Kai Tak port, Kowloon
usertext: Depends on your requirements for making a location qualify as "best". At least transport wise, it doesn't really matter much where in Hong Kong you stay.

subject: 2. Re: Kai Tak port, Kowloon
usertext: Where do you want to stay, Kai Tak Port or Kowloon? For the former, there is not much to see and transportation is not convenient at all. I would recommend staying somewhere else in Kowloon.

subject: 3. Re: Kai Tak port, Kowloon
usertext: Stay somewhere central. That usually means anywhere from Mong Kok to Tsim Sha Tsui along the Tsuen Wan Line in Kowloon. Over at the HK Island side, anywhere from Causeway Bay to Sai Ying Pun is quite convenient. To reach Kai Tak port with any sort of luggage, you would want to use a taxi or Uber anyway. Don't let that dictate where to stay. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 1. Re: HK Disneyland
usertext: 1) Whether it fits in your budget depends on your budget. Entrance fees etc are on their web site. 2) A hotel that you like and fits in your budget and fulfills whatever other requirements you have. 3, 4) If so they'll no doubt give that info on their web site. 5) if fast pass still exists it helps skipping lines - so no you don't need it but it does save on time waiting in line. Visa info: https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/visas/visit-transit/visit-visa-entry-permit.html 6) yes 7) never really quiet there, though the number of shows and so hosted on a particular day offers a clue: less shows means less visitors expected. Those months are likely all similar. Do try to avoid public holidays as those are more crowded, and the first week of October (national day golden week).

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: HK Disneyland
usertext: Do be aware that Hong Kong Disneyland is the smallest of all the Disney Parks. If the main purpose of your trip is to see Disneyland, you would probably be far better off going to Paris.

subject: 4. Re: HK Disneyland
usertext: You should go on a weekday if possible. The good thing about HK Disney vs Tokyo Disney is that HK likely has smaller crowds and shorter queues. HK is also usually more friendly with better support for English speakers

subject: Update on Ride Share Apps 2013 update
usertext: A lot of the info on here about ride share is dated 2019 or earlier. Does anyone know of any of these ride share apps currently work well in Hong Kong ? Uber Grab Gojek Tada Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Update on Ride Share Apps 2013 update
usertext: As far as I know Uber is the only one active in Hong Kong. I never bothered. Taxis are widely available and usually cheaper than an Uber. Also saves the hassle of actually going through the whole ride hailing process, as you can just wave one down when and where you need one.

subject: 2. Re: Update on Ride Share Apps 2013 update
usertext: As wvmarle says, only Uber as far as I am aware too. But like him, I don't really see the point when taxis are readily available and waving your arm and simply giving the driver money is a lot less hassle than faffing around with a mobile phone.

subject: 3. Re: Update on Ride Share Apps 2013 update
usertext: I take Uber occasionally because where I live now, taxis don't come into my complex often. On a recent trip, I took Uber from home to my destination and then returned by taking a taxi. As a normal tourist, you probably won't find the need to call a car very often, if at all. Price-wise, the cheapest Uber ride is probably going to cost just about the same as a metered taxi. In most circumstances, Uber is likely going to be at least 10-15% more expensive.

subject: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: It was brought to my attention that in recent years wild pigs spread over Hong Kong and I have seen many news reports about locals interacting with them. I understand these are wild animals that are not meant to be disturbed. But if I were to see them from afar, my question to you is: Which specific areas of Hong Kong and which times of day are best for me to find them?

subject: 1. Re: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: I've seen them early morning on the outskirts of Tai Po, occasionally. Reports are also common from areas around The Peak and Sha Tin. Typical times to spot these animals is dusk and dawn, as that's when they're most active. I don't know of any place that you can go to guaranteed see wild boar. Besides, I've always found it much more interesting to go look at the monkeys (a guaranteed sight at Golden Hill aka Monkey Mountain). Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: Just walk up Mount Parker Road in Tai Tam Country Park on Hong Kong Island. But remember, the boars are wild and can injure you.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: There are wild boar on the Peak. I've seen them on the road and in the vegetation outside Barker Road Tram Station. A culling operation began in late 2021 under which 363 have so far been captured and humanely dispatched; https://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/conservation/con_fau/con_fau_nui/con_fau_nui_pig/con_fau_nui_pig.html

subject: 4. Re: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: They have been roam the hills around Fortress Hill and North Point. I have also seen a few on May Road. I don't think you can just make a plan to see them though.

subject: 5. Re: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: No place I can think of which is a guarantee for seeing wild boars.... but I second the Mount Parker Road trail mention. From Quarry Bay up to Mount Parker might be the highest sighting rate for me on HK Island, probably encountering wild pigs around 1/3 of the hikes I've done there in recent years. The problem with wild animals is that you just never know if/when you'll see them. Sometimes they seem to be everywhere and then you do the same hike the next day and you won't see a single one. Now with our feral cows, less interesting seeing than wild pigs, but there are predictable locations in the New Territories and Lantau where you are most likely going to encounter some while out on hikes. Then you have the macaques. There are places like Monkey Mountain mentioned above and Shing Mun Reservoir where you are pretty much guaranteed to see them and in great numbers.

subject: 6. Re: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: If you're interested in getting close to nature, the birdhouse in Hong Kong Park provides a great walkthrough experience. Conveniently located right in Central.

subject: 7. Re: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: Great suggestion, Alamigo. Unfortunately, the last time I passed by the Edward Youde Aviary at HK Park I found that it was closed off for renovations. L&CS signage said that reno work would take place from Nov 2022 through the end of Dec 2023.

subject: 8. Re: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: I saw them more than once on Victoria Peak. Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 10. Re: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: I saw one today at about 5pm on the Morning trail. It was lower than us and behind a fence. It didn't seem the slightest bit bothered by us but I'm quite wary of wild creatures and was glad to have the fence between us.

subject: 11. Re: Where do I see boars or wild pigs in Hong Kong?
usertext: Not sure if you will find them very special when you actually see them. I lived in Sai Kung, and we often saw them walking on the big roads, and even in our neighbourhood. Do not go near them, but they were not very exciting to see. Haha. I agree, go see the monkeys might be more exciting. I also saw wild boars in North Point/Fortress Hill when picking up my kids from school. Agree with Sammy, don't think you can actually PLAN to see them. Good luck ! Stay safe.

subject: A week in Hong Kong - as travellers n not sightseers

Not interested in shopping, casinos, Macau, etc. Keen to visit the gorgeous islands, do off-beat activities out in nature, etc. Pls suggest what all we can include and visit to take back amazing memories. Thanks a lot

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: A week in Hong Kong - as travellers n not sightseers
usertext: Plenty of suggestions here for a range of activities in the "Great Outdoors"; https://www.discoverhongkong.com/uk/explore/great-outdoor.html

subject: 2. Re: A week in Hong Kong - as travellers n not sightseers
usertext: Hard to say too much without knowing your age fitness and familiarity with travelling. So not sending you off to hike Lantau Peak! But the ferry ride to Lamma and a walk the length of the island with a meal enroute is a good excursion.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: A week in Hong Kong - as travellers n not sightseers
usertext: I would suggest this. Catch the ferry from Central pier to Cheung Chau in the afternoon. Have a late lunch on the sea front and enjoy the beach and the Temple and walk. Catch the slow ferry back and time it to come back into the harbour as the sun goes down and the lights come on

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: A week in Hong Kong - as travellers n not sightseers
usertext: Being in our late 60s, we tend to avoid the more strenuous treks these days, but a few of the more interesting but less demanding places we've been are the Hong Kong Wetlands Park in Tin Shui Wai, Kadoorie Farm & Gardens in Tai Po and the Ten Thousand Buddhas Monastery in Sha Tin. We also loved the walk across Lamma island from Yung Shue Wan to Sok Kwu Wan.

subject: 5. Re: A week in Hong Kong - as travellers n not sightseers
usertext: Hi everyi=one, Thank you very much for all your suggestions. Made a note of them and managed to cover quite a bit in our week long stay. I would love to share our time as HK travellers if it helps anyone else visiting her to give it their best shot at Discovering HK.

subject: 6. Re: A week in Hong Kong - as travellers n not sightseers
usertext: Day 1 Must do as you land in HK: BUY an OCTOPUS card as life cannot move ahead without one. The only drawback is that its not so east to top it up :( Only via cash. After a good Vietnamese lunch, we walked to the Wan Chai waterfront and caught the ferry to Tsim Sha Tsui. Enjoyed walking thru the waterfront, HK Cultural Centre and the attractive stores. A little off the main market, we saw a lane full ot florists with the most gorgeous flowers. Lucky to witness a concert underway featuring a leading Singapore singer. The atmosphere inspite of the rains was electric. Day 2 Started with our re education of HK. Visited one of the largest temple complex in the island territory. Wong Tan Sin. Beautiful, clean n peaceful. Quintessential of HK. Worshippers of elements of nature. The public transport system is impeccable. You can reach any corner of the island by buses n the metro. On time to the T, no cash, payment by their local card The Octopus We took the bus to the south east end of New Territories to visit friends who live amidst greenery, gently sloping hills, pleasing bays n cool climes which may make you camp there forever n never leave their Hang Hau village. A long drive with them thru the New Territories took us close to Schenzen border; we only saw tree covered mountains, abundant nature parks with hardly any traffic. The views of the ocean are stunning. After a lunch consisting of varied local street food, dinner was elaborate at the Yacht Club. If you can find a member to take you, add it to your to do list :)

subject: 7. Re: A week in Hong Kong - as travellers n not sightseers
usertext: Day 3 The morning was saved for actual work and the afternoon was at the Victoria Peak. A must do but save it for a day when the weather is clear, It was very windy, cloudy and cold when we went up there in the old fashioned tram. Evening was spent walking aroung the base, bar hopping as we tried the different crafts beers brewed locally. Day 4 Visit to Lama Island and the trek across Yung Shue Wan to Sok Kwu Wan We took an early morning ferry, Gorgeous weather was the secret ingredient of the trek across the island. Took as about 3 hours with all the photo ops n stoping to take in the various sights. Lunch od fresh seafood catch was the icing on the cake!! We returned bk not to Wan chai but Aberdeen, Walk along the Promenade was interesting and figuring out a bus to return to Wan Chai even more. Bauses are frequent and work on the principle of one price n get off wherever you want or so we felt Day 5 As it was a clear day, we decided to do an educative historic simple trek. Lung Yeuk Tau Heritage Trail. Armed with a map found on a blog, we followed the recommended trail n educated ourselves with HK history. Afternoon waas the Thousand Buddhas Monastery with the evening spent in Wan Chai street markets n the Queens Boulevard.

subject: 8. Re: A week in Hong Kong - as travellers n not sightseers
usertext: Day 6 This day was dedicated to Lantau Islnd, the tallest Buddha, the ride in the glass-bottom cable car. It was scary n exhilirating experience as it was very foggy n cloudy day, The buddha is beautiful, the trek around the base peaceful. The visit to the attached monestaruy with the vegetarian lunch is a must Shopping at the the City link Malls is overhyped but good opportunity for the shopoholics I guess. We returned vis Tsim Sha Tsui end enjoyed the walk along the Avenue of Stars even though we didnt recognise most of the stars. Day 7 Having heard so much about the marine parks in HK, we felt we couldnt leave without visiting one. What a day to choose to do so! It was raining non stop. We needed 3 changes (metro n bus) to reach our destination Hoi Ha Wan Marine Park in Sai Kung. Beautiful spot to be enjoyed in good weather. But we decided to make the mosyt of it n within half hour, the skies cleared and we enjoyed the rugged trek of 3.7 miles from Hoi Ha to Tan Tai. A must for the outdoorsy folks. We earned a scrumptious sea food lunch in Sai Kung. An evening spent aroung Wan chai, the waterfront etc as we said goodbye to a place filled with varied options, much to our surprise, There is so much more to do here n we hope we get another opportunity to do so

subject: 1. Re: P.C.R tests in kowloon
usertext: There's a 24 hour test facility at the airport; https://projectscreen.co/en/predeparture-hkia-rt-pcr?gclid=CjwKCAiAl9efBhAkEiwA4TorijbERpuTY19G4Yfu6bqtCw7lj8cjrOHkcxUuu0ZMXwm-_bOkW52tHBoCAVwQAvD_BwE A list of labs with test facility is at this link; https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/pdf/List_of_recognised_laboratories_RTPCR.pdf

subject: 2. Re: P.C.R tests in kowloon
usertext: We also have normal community testing facilities that remain open and offering paid (you pay, not free) PCR testing with results messaged to you in 24 hours (HK$160) or 12 hours (HK$240) per person. https://booking.communitytest.gov.hk/form/index.jsp Seems from the government website, starting in March, only 24 of these community centres will be retained offering the paid PCR testing, I don't know which these are but almost certainly some will be in the Kowloon Peninsula. We had our pre-travel PCR tests at one of the community centres in early Feb for a trip to Europe. At that time, we were the only two people there for the morning slot we choose. You can pay in cash or Octopus and everything took no more than 5-6 minutes. Our results were messaged to us around 20 hours later. There is link sent to a print out version which may be important for showing Australian authorities. It was supposed to be for this way for Belgian authorities as well. However, when we arrived in Brussels, nobody checked, nobody cared. Just like when arriving in HK with the RAT/PCR testing requirement.

subject: 2. Re: I have 2 HK Disneyland question
usertext: For such specific questions you best contact the Disney customer service. That are the experts on Disney specific rules and regulations.

subject: Too risky to not pre-book a hotel?

Would it be too risky to just rock up to Regal Airport Hotel (for example) on the day and try my luck to get a room? Also some additional questions: 1. Is there any chance of check-in to hotels earlier as I arrive early in the morning (6am)? 2. How much to budget for food in HKD?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Too risky to not pre-book a hotel?
usertext: Regal Airport Hotel is one of HK's largest hotels with over 1,100 rooms and I think it unlikely it would be fully booked. It currently has an offer for day rooms available from 9am on onwards for 10 hours with latest check out 9pm but advance non-refundable reservation is required; https://www.regalhotel.com/mobile/regal-airport-hotel/en/promotions/DayUseRoomPackage.html

subject: 2. Re: Too risky to not pre-book a hotel?
usertext: Highly recommended to make a day out of it. Your hours are perfect for that. For food, for the super basic something like HK$200 per person, more commonly double that, and if you like to go fancy you can add a zero or even two to that number.

subject: 3. Re: Too risky to not pre-book a hotel?
usertext: HK tea cafe meal prices on average: Breakfast $40, Lunch $50-70, Dinner $60-80 So $200 sounds about right for meals plus some drinks (not alcohol). Obviously, the sky is the limit.

subject: 4. Re: Too risky to not pre-book a hotel?
usertext: Usually, hotels charge a lot more for walk-in customers.

subject: Hong Kong - Macau bus and ferry
usertext: Hi, I was planning to visit Macau tomorrow.. Very stupidly I assumed I didn't have to book tickets in advance. I now discovered there are no more tickets for the ferry left (I am staying near central). I have two questions: 1. More importantly: It looks like there are no limitations on bus tickets and I can still go tomorrow early morning by bus. Is this true? Will I have to queue for a long time at Hong Kong port? 2. And less importantly: I see I can book the ticket now on the hzmbus ticket website. Is there any point doing this? Are there chances I won't be able to get one at the port tomorrow? Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong - Macau bus and ferry
usertext: Please do not post the same question twice in twi sub forums. Which ferry you are talking about exactly? I would be surprised thee will be not tickets available anymore tomorrow.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong - Macau bus and ferry
usertext: {1. More importantly: It looks like there are no limitations on bus tickets and I can still go tomorrow early morning by bus. Is this true? Will I have to queue for a long time at Hong Kong port?} I have used the HZMB - golden shuttle bus on one occasion near the end of January and was surprised to find that things were already running very smoothly there in regard to passenger processing, expedient transfer over to Macau and vis versa. Here is a report of that experience if helpful https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g294217-d25296591-r877282096-Hzmb_Golden_Shuttle_Bus-Hong_Kong.html {2. And less importantly: I see I can book the ticket now on the hzmbus ticket website. Is there any point doing this? Are there chances I won't be able to get one at the port tomorrow?} Not really. Best to just show up and purchase ticket at the Port building. Even when things were very busy during pre-pandemic, I never had to wait more than 15-20 minutes after going through immigration before the Golden Shuttle bus boarded was fully boarded and on way to Macau.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong - Macau bus and ferry
usertext: Do note that there are two ferry terminals in Macau (Outer Harbour and Taipa). Be sure you check both. (One day last week, when I came back from Macau to HK there were no tickets available departing from the Outer Harbour, but there were plenty available from Taipa.) Also.....there are two different ferry companies (Turbojet and Cotaijet) and to know full ticket availability you have to check both websites.

subject: Transfer from HKG international airport to Shenzhen Futian
usertext: I will be landing at HKG in a few weeks (Mar 2023). I need to get myself over to Shenzhen Futian area. I have a valid China (business) visa already. Since borders have only been recently open, I am not sure of my options on how to reach the destination. Can some of the experts please help with tips. Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Transfer from HKG international airport to Shenzhen Futian
usertext: One option would be to take a taxi (green or red)) from the airport to Lok Ma Chau Spur Line Control Point (open 6-30am to 10-30pm) which should cost about HK$300 and take about 35 mins. The Lok Ma Chau Spur Line Control Point immigration building is connected by pedestrian bridge to Futian Port Control Point immigration building on the mainland which also contains Futian Port Station, served by Shenzhen Metro Lines 4 & 10. You can take the metro if convenient or taxi to your destination in Futian. Sorry I don't know the answer to your query re PCR test. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Transfer from HKG international airport to Shenzhen Futian
usertext: If cost is not a concern, hire a cross border limo to take you from HKG to your Shenzhen hotel. I think you need a negative PCR test within 48 hrs of your departure to China.

subject: 5. Re: Transfer from HKG international airport to Shenzhen Futian
usertext: Re: PCR test, yes required according to the US China Embassy website and it's "Guide on Epidemic Prevention and Control Measures For China-bound Travelers" : "I. Pre-boarding Nucleic Acid Test All China-bound travelers will need to take nucleic acid test for COVID-19 within 48 hours before boarding, and can only travel to China when your test result is negative or after it turns from positive to negative. Please always bring the proof of your negative COVID-19 test result with you for inspection. ll.Health Declaration to China Customs You are required to declare your negative test result to China Customs by filling the Health Declaration Form on the WeChat miniprogram of China Customs (scan the QR code below), or at https://htdecl.chinaport.gov.cn , or via the China Customs APP." http://us.china-embassy.gov.cn/eng/zytz/202301/t20230117_11009464.htm

subject: 6. Re: Transfer from HKG international airport to Shenzhen Futian
