subject: HKIA to Macau late at night via bus
usertext: I will be arriving at hk airport at 11pm and wondering if it's feasible to get to Macau that night via the bus? I saw the bus is running 24 hours but wasn't sure if that was pre covid info. Also, once I get to Macau it will likely be well after midnight so do the free shuttles to the casinos run 24 hours or can I rely on a taxi that late? I recall Macau taxi drivers being very difficult and refused service when k lived in Macau a few years ago. Thanks in advance.

subject: 1. Re: HKIA to Macau late at night via bus
usertext: The HZMB is open 24 hours a day and the Golden Shuttles will run on reduced schedule for overnight journeys between HK & Macau so you can definitely use this form of transportation to make way to go straight to Macau. On the Macau side, there are public buses 101X (Macau Peninsula) and 102X (Taipa and Cotai Strip) - both cost MOP$6 that run 24 hours a day. You can pay with HKD coins. There are taxis on the Macau side as well and they should be available 24 hours a day although I've not used one at overnight hours since Macau has reopened so can't 100% confirm that there will be many waiting at overnight hours. The free hotel shuttle buses don't run 24 hours a day even from the ferry terminals so you would want to go with a public bus or taxi if going straight over during overnight hours. Here are a couple reports I put together from late last month for using the Golden Bus and HZMB if helpful https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g664891-d15634642-r751918671-HZMB-Macau.html https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g294217-d25296591-r877282096-Hzmb_Golden_Shuttle_Bus-Hong_Kong.html Bus 101X - Report (2019 - no changes) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g664891-d17780254-r703724640-Tcm-Macau.html Bus 102X - Report (2019 - no changes) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g664891-d19260343-r751919331-Transmac-Macau.html Hope this is helpful and that you enjoy Macau

subject: 2. Re: HKIA to Macau late at night via bus

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Sun Ferrt formerly New World First Ferry
usertext: Hi I note that Sun Ferry now operates the services between Central 5 and Cheung Chau and between North Point and Hung Hom. Does the concessionary $2 fare provided by the On Loan Elder (Octopus) Card still apply - the official guidance still refers to NWFF? Thanks

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Sun Ferrt formerly New World First Ferry
usertext: The government supported HK$2 fare still applies to users of Elder Octopus at the current time. However, the government reviewed the scheme some time ago and decided that only Hong Kong residents will in future be eligible for the $2 concessionary fare. HK residents will be eligible via JoyYou card which is currently in the course of being rolled out in phases to HK residents age 60 and over or Personalised Octopus. At some future date to be announced (probably when roll out of the JoyYou card has been completed later this year) the $2 concession will be withdrawn from Elder Octopus. I believe that from that time the concession provided by the anonymous Elder Octopus will then revert to pre-$2 fare terms and be limited to the transport operators own concession, usually 50% of full adult fare for passengers age 65 and over. The fact that NWFF has been taken over by Sun Ferry (CKS Shipping) doesn't have any bearing on the situation.

subject: 3. Re: Sun Ferrt formerly New World First Ferry
usertext: And note that you must be 65 or over to use an Elder Octopus card; the card readers clearly indicate (big flashing light and or a different sound) when such a card is used, and nearby staff do regularly intercept and verify eligibility of people who they feel may not meet the criterion. I have personally seen this happen several times. There is a significant fine for misuse of an Elder Octopus card.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Sun Ferrt formerly New World First Ferry
usertext: Thanks for the information. Hopefully, the scheme will still be running when this 74 year old next visits!

subject: 3. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Yes.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Either the buffer hall (if the customer service desk there is open) or, if not, buy from MTR customer service centres in the arrival hall or at the Airport Express Airport Station. Concessionary MTR tickets (for Elder & Child) can be obtained from MTR ticket machines at all MTR stations but will only give discount of 50% of adult fare and do not provide the $2 max fare benefit which Elder Octopus currently provides (but will be withdrawn at a future date to be advised). Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: actually you could buy it even you are not 65+, the MTR staff will not ask for identity proof

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Yes, its an anonymous card which contains no personal information, can be obtained by anyone and is transferrable. The age restriction applies only to use of the card and systems are in place which identify when an Elder Octopus is being used at MTR entry systems and on other public transport. As well as at customer service centres they have also been available from the MTR Ticket and Octopus Selling Machines near the arrival hall exits leading to Airport Station but I believe those machines currently only sell the Tourist version of Octopus; https://flic.kr/p/29Q2TYG

subject: 7. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: "actually you could buy it even you are not 65+, the MTR staff will not ask for identity proof" This is true when buying the card, but not always when using it. I very often see MTR staff intercepting people with discount Octopus cards (which flash an orange light when passing through the gates) when they feel that the person doesn't look eligible for one.

subject: 8. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Hello there, i will arrive at Hong Kong airport next week at 9:00PM local time, is the MTR customer service center still open so I can purchase my octopus card?

subject: 9. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Yes - in general, MTR Customer Service centres are open throughout the time that MTR services run, so until about 1am at the Airport.

subject: 10. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Another question. Do all MTR stations have service centers? We will arrive at the airport but depart via a cruise ship. Our hotel is near the Olympic MTR Station. Will we be able to return our Elder Octopus cards and get a refund there? Thanks Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 11. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: The vast majority of stations have customer service counters including Olympic and you'll be able to return your Octopus Cards there. There are a small number of newer stations with lower passenger traffic such as some of those on the South Island Line which don't have customer service centres but have roving customer service staff equipped with iPads who are able to provide assistance and also video service points but they don't handle Octopus refunds.

subject: 12. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Hong Kong just started to crack down the illegal use of elder Octopus card a few weeks ago as too many people younger than 65 years old uses it. There is a fine of HK$1000 if got caught.

subject: 13. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: "Hong Kong just started to crack down the illegal use of elder Octopus card a few weeks ago..." How can a foreigner prove his/her age - will a digital copy of passport accepted?

subject: 14. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Yes, I guess so. Strictly, in the same way that HKers are legally required to carry their HKID at all times, I believe that visitors are required to carry their passport or other form of photo ID (driving licence, national ID card, etc) at all times. But in practice a copy is fine, on the understanding that in the worst case the police might escort you to your hotel to see your passport. This worst case is infinitessimally likely to happen unless the police believe you to have been doing something illegal. As a personal experience, I'm 60, and people, perhaps politely, sometimes say that I look younger. But in the 6 months that I have had it nobody has ever asked me to validate my age when my JoyYou card (a card for HK residents that gets the $2 deal from age 60) causes the "discounted fare" noise/light.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

I gather the application process for Joy You cards for people born in 1938 or earlier ends on 31 October. We're hoping it might still be around for our visit!

subject: 16. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: I think it unlikely that the $2 concession will continue to be provided by Elder Octopus beyond the end of October but the last government comment on this was in response to a question in a Legco meeting in May; "The Government will, depending on the progress of applications of JoyYou Cards made by eligible persons aged 65 or above, announce at a later date that it will cease the existing arrangement of covering Anonymous Elder Octopus Cards and Personalised Octopus Cards under the $2 Scheme and all eligible persons aged 60 or above must use JoyYou Cards to benefit from the $2 Scheme" https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202305/10/P2023051000219.htm Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 19. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: We won't know for sure but the elder cards should still work, you just won't get the HK$2 fare. You might though get half-fare with certain operators.

subject: 20. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Have Elder Octopus cards been eliminated as predicted? We arrive in February 2024 and have an Elder Octopus card issued in January 2020 around the time of the Coronavirus pandemic. We haven't been back since. How do we check if there is value left on the card? As we are seniors, do we get any sort of discount on the MRT now?

subject: 21. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: There is no suggestion that Elder Octopus cards will be eliminated. And as of today there is no change announced. You can check the balance on an Octopus card at any MTR Customer Service Centre, and at various Octopus service point machines at MTR stations, ferry piers etc. The remaining balance is always shown on a screen on the machine when you use the card for payment on the MTR, buses or ferries, and on the receipt when you use it for payment in, for example, convenience stores. Currently, using an Elder Octopus Card still gets you the HK$2 fare on essentially all public transport (and the Government pays the operator the difference between $2 and the normal fare for Elders). At some as yet undefined point in the future the card will give whatever discount the operator gives for Elders, which in most cases is 50% off the adult fare.

subject: 22. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Thanks for that info. Over 1,000 days have passed since we last used our cards. Do we go up to a customer service counter to renew them, even if we are not Hong Kong residents? When we purchased our cards, there was no requirement to be a resident but I seem to read that a resident's ID card is now required.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 23. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: No ID is required for the Elder Octopus. ID is required for the HK Residents-only JoyYou Card, which for most HK residents replaces Elder Octopus and enables residents to benefit from the governments HK$2 concessionary fare scheme at age 60. You can go to any MTR/Airport Express customer service centre to have the card reactivated. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 1. Re: September or October at HK Disneyland
usertext: October is usually significantly cooler than September, when you can still have the stifling summer heat. Avoid the 1/10 golden week, that's historically a very crowded period. This year may be different - the lasting effects of Covid and the NSL on mainland visitor numbers I can't predict, though.

subject: 2. Re: September or October at HK Disneyland
usertext: {better for summer weather } If you mean cooler weather - Near the end of October is obviously cooler and more pleasant than early September, particularly in the evenings. On the other hand not a lot of difference between late Sept and early October. {Crowds} - As Sammy pointed out, it is difficult to foresee what all looks like for crowds this Sept & Oct. We haven't seen normal days here since before Summer 2019 and are just getting our feet wet to having tourists around the city for the first in a really long time. How many will be here this coming Autumn and what will crowds look like at Disney? I bet the Disney execs are wondering the same thing?

subject: 3. Re: September or October at HK Disneyland

Some of my family just went to Ocean Park this past Thursday. It was pretty crowded with lots of mainland visitors. I am also starting to see more foreigners walking around the streets. subject: 9-10 hour stopover in Dec
usertext: Hi, We have a 9-10 hour stopover in December. We land around 3pm and our flights is 1am - we definitely want to leave the airport and explore, maybe have a little dinner before we head back - what would you suggest doing (and where to go) in that time? We'll likely store our carry ons in the airport as to not have to much more than a big/camera - and we'll likely take the express train in. It's our first time back after covid, so some suggestions would be great :)

subject: 1. Re: 9-10 hour stopover in Dec
usertext: There's a left luggage at the airport where you can drop off your hand luggage. It's in between T1 and T2, near the exit towards the buses. Your hours mean your effective hours are 4:30-11, give or take. In December, sunset is around 5:30 so it'll be dark shortly after you reach the city. Dinner is the easy part, restaurants all over the place as you probably know having been to Hong Kong before. You could consider heading up to The Peak to see the city lights (if the weather is clear), or head over to Mongkok and explore the streets and markets there. Ladies' and Temple Street took huge hits during covid but hard to predict where they'll be come December. It's going to depend a lot on the recovery of the tourism industry at large.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: 9-10 hour stopover in Dec
usertext: Since Terminal 2 closed the luggage storage facility has moved. Its now located in the arrival hall "A". After customs, on entering the arrival hall head left and its almost right at the end of the hall; https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/passenger-guide/airport-facilities-services/baggage-storage

subject: 4. Re: 9-10 hour stopover in Dec
usertext: I would take the Airport Express to the HK station. Visit the Peak if the weather cooperates and your timing works out. Dinner at the IFC mall (above the train station), or find a restaurant walking from the Peak Tram terminus back to the train station.

subject: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport
usertext: I know that there are free bathrooms in the arrival section of the restricted area. Is it possible to get to those bathrooms from the departure section? I want to take a bath before boarding. Thanks.

subject: 1. Re: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport
usertext: As far as I am aware there are only showers, not baths, and they are only available in the arrivals area airside (restricted area). https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/passenger-guide/airport-facilities-services/shower-facilities You cannot access this facility unless you have arrived on a flight, and then only until you go through transit security to the departures level. In the departure area the only baths I know of are in the Cathay Pacific First Class lounge known as The Wing, but you can only access those if you are flying First Class on Cathay Pacific, or have OneWorld Emerald frequent flyer status and are departing on a OneWorld flight (in any class). Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport
usertext: Alternatively, there are the free facilities in the government run sports centres - assuming they've reopened now covid restrictions have been (almost) completely lifted. Just shower with hot/cold water; bring your own towels and shampoo etc. Use them before getting on the bus or train to the airport.

subject: 3. Re: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport
usertext: Also, from https://www.fehd.gov.hk/english/pleasant_environment/cleansing/clean1.html "In older districts where poor housing accommodation still exists, the Department provides public bathhouses, of which 6 are on Hong Kong Island, 10 in Kowloon and 10 in the New Territories and on outlying islands. The opening hours of public bathhouses are generally from 7 a.m. to 9 a.m. and from 4:30 p.m. to 8:30 p.m. daily. The provision of hot water starts from any day in November every year when the temperature at 7 a.m. is recorded at 20C or below, and stops when the temperature at 7 a.m. is recorded at 25C or above for three consecutive days in May the following year." I've never been in one of these, so I'm not sure whether they do indeed feature actual baths, or just showers. Maybe someone more intrepid than me can comment? (Although I see that there is one within about 500m of where I live so maybe I should go take a look!)

subject: 4. Re: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport
usertext: I wouldn't send my worse enemy to one of those public baths, speaking not directly from personal experience. But I know friends who lived in those public housings and they have stories to tell.

subject: 5. Re: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport
usertext: Actually, I had first-hand experience with those public baths. Not too terrible IMHO.

subject: 6. Re: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport
usertext: I've used one once, in Sai Kung I recall, after a hike. Showers, not actual bath tubs, but then to the Chinese taking bath is synonym to taking shower. Not terrible, but the facilities in the public sports centres are much better (cleaner, nicer looking, longer opening hours, and offer hot water year round).

subject: 7. Re: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport
usertext: The problem is my flight is quite late at night. Most public sport centres may have closed already.

subject: 8. Re: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport
usertext: All the centres that I checked close at 11pm, so that's unlikely to be a problem. https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/clpss/en/webApp/Facility/District.do?ftid=0#

subject: 9. Re: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport
usertext: Indeed at least the indoor sports centres usually close late (lots of sports activities in the evening). Nothing to worry about there. Like the bath houses you can just walk in, no registration or membership or anything needed. Find the appropriate changing room and enjoy a nice shower.

subject: 10. Re: Bath in Restricted Area of the Airport

subject: June 2023, 4-day itinerary
usertext: Hi, my family is visiting HK for the 1st time. Is mid-June good weather to visit HK? Could you propose a 4-day itinerary for us, with teenage kids? Thank you!

subject: 1. Re: June 2023, 4-day itinerary
usertext: { Is mid-June good weather to visit HK?} It is pretty hot in June but some don't mind. {Could you propose a 4-day itinerary for us, with teenage kids?} Really hard to plan someone else's holiday for them, especially not knowing you or your family or what interests you have. I would suggest browsing through the Discover Hong Kong website for starters to see what is available to do/see/taste here in HK. They have some trip planning resources and lots of good information there. Then put your own itinerary together so that you know that you are choosing places that are interesting to you and your family. Do feel free to post your itinerary and thoughts you have along with related questions if you are unsure how something works in HK and the forum members here will gladly chime in to let you know their thoughts. Good luck with your trip planning and hope you enjoy Hong Kong.

subject: 2. Re: June 2023, 4-day itinerary
usertext: Disneyland and Ocean Park are must-gos. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: June 2023, 4-day itinerary
usertext: {Wondering what's the minimum number of days required.} Disneyland (1 day), Ocean Park (1 day), Victoria Peak Tram - (1 hour), Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car and Big Buddha (1/2 day), Symphony of Lights show (15 min), shopping (1/2 day) - Sounds like you are putting together something like a 3-4 day trip. {Where's best to stay too.} Somewhere near an MTR Station so that you can hop on and travel travel around the city to your sightseeing destinations {It's there any likelihood of typhoon in June?} https://www.hkfastfacts.com/weather/hong-kong-typhoon-season.html

subject: 12. Re: Covid test pre flight?
usertext: That's not how I read it. The website says: "Before departing to Hong Kong, please pay attention to the relevant inbound control arrangements. They may also voluntarily declare the test result via the Department of Health's electronic health declaration form (http://www.chp.gov.hk/hdf/) prior to their arrival at Hong Kong. For arrival via Hong Kong International Airport, the health declaration is valid for 96 hours; for arrival via land control points, the health declaration is valid for 24 hours. Inbound Control Measures All inbound persons must pass temperature checks upon arrival. Those found with symptoms will be referred to the Department of Health for further handling. No further restrictions upon arrival. The Government recommends all inbound persons to conduct daily RATs using self-arranged rapid antigen test (RAT) kits during the period between the day of arrival (i.e. Day 0) and Day 5 after arrival at Hong Kong." So the government 'recommends', but nowhere does it say you must take a test before entering, as far as I can see.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 13. Re: Covid test pre flight?
usertext: "They may also voluntarily declare the test result via the Department of Health's electronic health declaration form" That means the electronic health declaration is optional, not that the test is optional. See "Inbound persons arriving from Taiwan or places outside China" a. Except those who aged three and below on the day of arrival at Hong Kong, rapid Antigen Test (RAT) conducted within 24 hours or PCR-based nucleic acid test conducted within 48 hours prior to the scheduled time of departure (for arrivals via the airport) or before arrival at Hong Kong (for arrivals via other boundary control points), and obtained negative result; and b. Retain the photo showing the RAT result or the PCR test report for 90 days  May declare test result via the voluntary electronic Health Declaration Form"

subject: HK layover: Peak, Big Buddha, Macau - best way to do it all
usertext: Hi there, I have a very long stop over in HK on Sunday 2nd of April arriving in HK @07:45 and flying out just after midnight the next day. I would like to visit the Peak with the tram, Lantau (Big Buddha + the surrounding area) and Macau. What is the best way to do this? I suspect probably best to head straight to the Peak (on Sunday it opens early) but the downside is that it would be the busiest time of the day (Sunday morning). Reserving tickets in advance is not clear to me I gain a massive advantage while at the same time I confine myself within a time slot and if there are any delays with my flight I might miss my slot. If then I take the Ngong Ping 360 tram is there a way to continue from Lantau my journey to Macau or do I have to come back to HK and from there take a bus (?) to Macau? It appears that there is also a bus straight from the Airport to Macau, which could be another option but I think I probably prefer Macau during the night to enjoy the casino lights.... Talking about casinos, am I allowed to enter with jeans and trainers (or even shorts)? suspect not.. Bottom-line, I am willing to be on the move for 16hrs but I am struggling to see what is the most effective way to visit those 3 places... And I need to make sure I do not risk any chances of being back at HKIA on time for the next flight.... Any help on how best to schedule this and the preferable means of transport appreciated. Thanks!

subject: 1. Re: HK layover: Peak, Big Buddha, Macau - best way to do it all
usertext: Well you should plan to exit the airport around 08:30, and I guess you need to be back there at 23:00. The Peak is a hill - it never closes. The Peak Tram starts at 7am; there's no advantage to pre-booking a ticket. The Peak Tower is simply a tourist trap - it holds no attraction that I can see - the same views are free from the Lions Pavilion or the walk around Lugard/Harlech Roads. The NgongPing 360 is a cable car in the English sense (i.e. an aerial ropeway), not a tram. Sadly it only runs from 10:00 - 18:00. Which is not ideal with your schedule and requirements, at least from the perspective of taking it upwards. I think the only sensible way to combine these three things is: 1) Get a taxi from the airport to either the Buddha (in which case you'll need to get a blue taxi at the airport), or to Tung Chung (any taxi) and then get the #23 bus to the Buddha (probably the 09:10 departure). This will get you to the Buddha around 10am via great views (on a clear day) around Lantau Island. Spend maybe an hour there, and get the Cable Car back down to Tung Chung at around 11:00. 2) Take the MTR from Tung Chung to Hong Kong Station. Exit to the Ferry Piers. Take a quick round trip on the Star Ferry from Pier 7 to TST and back, maybe with a few minutes admiring the iconic HK skyline view from the TST waterfront in between. 3) Back at HK Ferry Piers if the timing fits (it goes on the hour and half hour currently) take bus 15C to the lower Peak Tram terminus, otherwise, assuming you can use a map, simply walk - it's about 1.5km, 4) (I guess it's about 13:00 now) Get the Peak Tram uphill. At the top either (quicker) go to the Lions Pavilion for the iconic view, or take the ~4km flat walk around the Peak on Lugard and Harlech Roads, getting a more varied selection of views. 5) Get bus #15 from the bus station at the Peak, and, if possible, get the front row upstairs seat, for the ride back down all the way to the end point at Central Pier 5. 6) (I guess about 16:00 now) Walk to the Macau ferry terminus. You will need to have booked a ferry well in advance - weekend ferries are all sold out these days. Note that if you miss the ferry you booked on then your ticket is no longer valid, but if you arrive early you can standby for earlier ferries. The schedule is changing rapidly as the route reopens. As it stands today I'd say book the 17:30 ferry. 7) Get to Macau at 18:30; immigration etc; then a taxi or shuttle bus to, say, The Venetian (pick one casino - you don't have time for anything more). Get there maybe 19:15-19:30. 8) You need to get a bus back to the airport - the ferries between Macau and the airport are running literally 3 times per WEEK at the the moment). I have less knowledge in this area. But I guess you might need to leave the casino at around 21:00 latest to get back to HK Airport for 23:00 (again, immigration - you need to reenter HK, you can't go direct from Macau to HK Airport airside by bus). Others can advise more on this. Overall, if you're essentially box-ticking then this is doable. It's not how I would choose to spend a day here though. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: HK layover: Peak, Big Buddha, Macau - best way to do it all
usertext: I don't know what the current situation is, but Macau immigration can have long lines. I think you are taking a risk going to Macau.

subject: 3. Re: HK layover: Peak, Big Buddha, Macau - best way to do it all
usertext: Forget Macau. You need to add 2-2.5 hrs transportation/immigration checks each way and public transportation is simply not up to par compared to what you'll have at your disposal in HK so travelling around requires a lot more knowledge and know-how in order to get around. In short, you won't really have much time there to do/see much of anything before having to make your way back to HK so that you can make it to the airport in time for your connection flight. And if there is a typhoon or delayed ferries/buses... well, you are in trouble. In short, you are simply taking risk for the sake of doing so by trying to squeeze in Macau during layovers. Even during pre-pandemic days I would not recommend this. With somewhat sketchy transportation at the moment, I'd highly recommend just focusing your time here in HK. Plenty to do/see to keep you well occupied until your outbound flight and all rather risk free by comparison.

subject: 4. Re: HK layover: Peak, Big Buddha, Macau - best way to do it all
usertext: You may have to charter a chopper, otherwise it is impossible to cover so many places. Forget about Macau.

subject: 5. Re: HK layover: Peak, Big Buddha, Macau - best way to do it all
usertext: It should be Macau OR the rest. With the long extra travel time associated to Macau, my choice would be simple: the rest. That's perfectly and comfortably doable in a day. Do Macau when you really have the time, the place warrants a stay of at least one night if only to experience Macau at night - the lights outdoors and the casinos indoors. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: HK layover: Peak, Big Buddha, Macau - best way to do it all
usertext: Excellent advice above, especially the unsolicited addition of the Star Ferry (classic!), and taking bus 15 down from the peak (most scenic bus ride I've ever taken). Leave Macau for another day.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: HK layover: Peak, Big Buddha, Macau - best way to do it all
usertext: Thanks all for the advice, I took note of the risk of going to Macau so I will leave this for another day. I will first go to Lantau and then get the "Crystal" cabin cable car to Hong Kong, TST, Peak, then the lights show. Not going to Macau leaves me with more time to explore so if there are any other recommendations (night market?) more than welcomed. Thanks everyone for your help, really helpful!

subject: 8. Re: HK layover: Peak, Big Buddha, Macau - best way to do it all
usertext: Loads you can squeeze into more or less a full day. Id definitely make time for a ride on both the Star Ferry and Ding Ding. These are cheap and genuinely unique parks of HK tourism, history and heritage. Some good museum options if you encounter a bad weather day. Night market scene isn't great post-pandemic and will take some time to recover. For example, the Ladies Market in Mongkok is presently a shell of its pre-pandemic self. Compared to the past, it is a big pass at the moment. In the evening, the TST Promenade is still very nice. Walking conditions are noticeably busier this year but still nothing like pre-pandemic scenes. You can walk and enjoy the Hong Kong Skyline views quite well if viewing conditions are nice. After dark is another great time to take the Star Ferry from one side of the harbour to the other.

subject: 9. Re: HK layover: Peak, Big Buddha, Macau - best way to do it all
usertext: What are the requirements to get back to your connecting flight once you have exited the airport during a layover? Any covid tests required to go through immigration to get airside again?

subject: Airport Subway to hotel?
usertext: Hello - is it worth taking the subway to TST hotel or am I better off getting an Uber or cab? Not sure the price and time difference. I would be landing around 7 pm at the airport on a weekday.

subject: 1. Re: Airport Subway to hotel?
usertext: Taxi or bus are the easiest options. Bus takes a little longer but is much cheaper than taxi. For detailed suggestions let us know which hotel exactly you're going.

subject: 2. Re: Airport Subway to hotel?
usertext: The subway does not go to the airport, the Airport Express Train does. But the Airport Express Train does not have a stop at TST. Actually the best option may be an Airport bus, depending on which hotel exactly.

subject: 3. Re: Airport Subway to hotel?
usertext: I've always treated the AE as yet another, albeit much more expensive, MTR line. By the way, "subway" in Hong Kong normally refers to either pedestrian tunnels for crossing a road, or a sandwich chain.

subject: 4. Re: Airport Subway to hotel?
usertext: You have some magnificent views from the bus (/taxi) that you won't see from the train. I always take the bus for that reason; the first real views of HK from the big bridges make me giddy.

subject: 5. Re: Airport Subway to hotel?
usertext: Jammer12345, Just for your information for the future, The Subway is what New Yorker's call their public transit system in NYC. Other cities have different names. In London, there is the The Underground, in San Francisco - Bart. Here in Hong Kong we call ours the MTR (short for Mass Transit Railway).

subject: 6. Re: Airport Subway to hotel?
usertext: Apologies for coming in on this topic but am arriving 21st march app 7.00.a.m we are staying at royal-plaza mongkok,we used to airport express to Kowloon and hotel bus to hotel our 1st trip back since 2019 i know the hotel bus system is not running so we were going to get the airport express to kowloon station and then a cab from there to our hotel or get a cab from the airport what are your thoughts.thanking you all.

subject: 7. Re: Airport Subway to hotel?
usertext: Airport express is not always convenient actually, for example if your hotel is in MongKok or Tsim sha tsui (which is the city center of Hong Kong), you need to get off the Airport express train in Tsing Yi , then transfer for tung chung line(orange line), and take 1 station to Lai King and transfer to Tsuen Wan line (Red line). It is quite trouble if you get big luggage And the Airport express cost 65HKD for 1 person, meanwhile a Uber to Tsim Sha tsui is only around 250HKD. For Locals, they will usually take the bus A21, which cost 33HKD, and around 40min to MongKok and 50min to Tsim Sha Tsui. The bus will make stops on the Nathan road, which most hotel located on it. The bus stop is just outside of the airport express station, follow the instruction in airport it could be easily spot.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

subject: 9. Re: Hotel with Club access
usertext: Hello SonicYouth, For some reason probably 2/3 of my post #2 is missing and that probably causes some confusion. I didn't notice the chopped off response and am not sure how/why that happened. Oh well. Firstly, I don't disagree with your very good point about staycations at all. My post wasn't really about why there were club lounge disruptions at some hotels, it was more to make the point that it happened at various properties and that is probably a major reason you won't find any publications about our best club lounge hotel options for the past several years, not even by our local publications. What I previously thought to have mentioned in post #2 was that quite a few of our hotels, including some big names which traditionally offer club Lounges did serve as self-isolation/quarantine hotels during various cycles of the DQH scheme between 2020-2022. These, at certain cycles, even included the likes of Cordis and Langham which you are mentioned above. While serving as a DQH designated quarantine hotel, guests were strictly prohibited from leaving their rooms - and as such club lounge benefits were not just disrupted for long stretches of time, they were halted altogether, and at times for many months. Here is a write up on Timeout mentioning a few DQH properties, some of which normally have club lounges that were disrupted during those times. https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/travel/the-best-quarantine-hotels-in-hong-kong Further, quite a few properties did pivot to function more like service apartments, offering long stay packages of 30 days or even up to 3, 6+ month stay promotions as they tried to survive during the pandemic. And this happened at some major hotel players like ICON, New World Millennium and Sheraton TST and other properties with club lounges. Anecdotally speaking, I can share a friend's experience. He stayed at a five star hotel for an entire year as part of a long stay promotion and made interesting observations about the club lounge service and food which he adamantly claimed to have changed fairly noticeable after a few months as most guests had become more like residents instead of hotel guests. After complaining about the waning club lounge service and experience, he was compensated in the form of free dinner vouchers at the hotel restaurants for the remaining months of his stay. I joined him for one such meal and had no reason to not believe the account regarding the disrupted club lounge experiences. In many ways, it made sense to me given how desperate many hotels had become to cut costs and pay the bills during the pandemic. Anyway, like mentioned above, I don't disagree with your very good point about the staycation packages. I just wanted to add the specifics that were somehow chopped off my post (#2) above. I think it probably helps explain what I had thought to have posted previously. As I wanted to say in that post as well, Things are getting better....... for our local hotels now so hopefully club lounges, gyms, pools, restaurants and other related disruptions are long in the rear view mirror and we can see properties return to pre-pandemic states if possible and as soon as possible.

subject: 10. Re: Hotel with Club access
usertext: {With almost 1,500 hotels in Hong Kong I'm sure there may be some examples but firmly in the minority} And just a point of clarification, as of March 2023, we have 334 licensed hotel and resorts in Hong Kong. You may be thinking of our much greater number of small guesthouses (not counting holiday camps) which is reported to be around 1567 this month by the Office of the Licensing Authority. subject: 1. Re: Ocean park
usertext: At the moment Ocean Park is still operating a reservation system which it introduced during the covid pandemic. However, whilst reservation is "suggested" it is not a requirement. FAQ 8 at the link below confirms you can be admitted without reservation provided "admission quota" is still available; https://media.oceanpark.com.hk/files/s3fs-public/online-reservation-FAQ.pdf I'm not sure whether Ocean Park has returned to operating at full capacity yet but tourists aren't yet back to anything like pandemic levels so unless you were intending to visit during public holidays I doubt there would be much risk of it selling out. The same applies to Ocean Park Water World which has separate admission arrangements; https://waterworld.oceanpark.com.hk/en/ Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 1. Re: Best Tim Ho Wan location?
usertext: I think the original shop is in Sham Shui Po, Fuk Wing Street. When it started, it was a great concept as the cheapest Michelin Star restaurant. Now that it has spread like a COVID virus all over the world, it's not so cute anymore. I have been to a couple, including the original one. There are much better dim sum elsewhere.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Best Tim Ho Wan location?
usertext: Thank you for this, I googled it and realised it had spread all over the place - did wonder if it might not be the same anymore. Thanks. I will look into some other dim sum options instead.

subject: 3. Re: Best Tim Ho Wan location?
usertext: The very first Tim Ho Wan opened in Mongkok in 2009 (see old Openrice listing) and might be the place you ate at during your 2011 visit to Hong Kong. https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/r-tim-ho-wan-the-dim-sum-specialists-mong-kok-hong-kong-style-dim-sum-r30806 They moved out of that location around early 2013 to the Tai Kok Tsui (old article in SCMP on this matter) so unfortunately if this is the branch you ate at and are remembering, it is not there anymore. https://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/food-drink/article/1068734/dim-sum-and-rise-independents Now the interesting part is that THW, riding the Michelin status of the original Mongkok branch did open 2nd, 3rd and 4th eateries in Sham Shui Po, Central and North Point, all around 2011 so it is possible that you might have eaten at one of these instead of the original place in Mongkok. The SSP branch is situated on a busy street in an old district and is fairly easy to recognise if you went there. The Central Branch is in an MTR Station - again should be easy to recall. Unfortunately, the North Point branch from around that time just closed down (March 2023) so if that is the place you ate at, it is now finished. Hope this is helpful.

subject: Long Layover Hong Kong Airport. Can I go into city?
usertext: Hello. There doesn't seem to be an answer on TA after the March 2023 changes. I have a fourteen hour layover at the airport. (USA to Sydney on Cathay Pacific. ) Is it still possible to exit the airport for that time? Or is it too difficult re-entering the airport? Would I have to take a covid test to get back into the airport for my connecting flight? Thanks.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Long Layover Hong Kong Airport. Can I go into city?
usertext: There is no test requirement to re-enter the airport and since 10th March there is no longer any pre-departure test requirement for travellers from China, including HK and Macau boarding flights to the USA. However, there is still at the current time a pre-departure test requirement for travellers boarding flights and wishing to enter HK. This can be a self-administered RAT test; https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/eng/inbound-travel.html Completion of health declaration is voluntary. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Long Layover Hong Kong Airport. Can I go into city?
usertext: @ kitchenchemist {Hello. There doesn't seem to be an answer on TA after the March 2023 changes.} What March 2023 changes are you referring to? Hong Kong? Australia? USA? The last relevant change here in Hong Kong has been the lifting of the mask mandate on 28 Feb 2023 and that had no bearing on being able to exit/enter the airport.

subject: 3. Re: Long Layover Hong Kong Airport. Can I go into city?
usertext: My question is regarding my long lay over in Hong-Kong.Can I go through immigration in Hong Kong (with proof of negative covid test) to visit Kowloon and return to the airport for my connecting flight to Sydney without further covid testing required to exit hong kong.

subject: 4. Re: Long Layover Hong Kong Airport. Can I go into city?
usertext: There are no testing requirements to exit Hong Kong, even during the strict days for inbound entry into the city, outbound testing was only relevant if you had previously tested positive for Covid while in HK and were required to test negatively in order to end mandatory self-isolation/quarantine..... No changes in March 2023 have occurred that will impact layovers beyond HK abandoning mask mandates at the end of February. If anything is unclear, just read up on local inbound travel requirements provided in post #1 above and have a nice time during your layover and eventual onward travel to OZ.

subject: 5. Re: Long Layover Hong Kong Airport. Can I go into city?
usertext: Thanks.

subject: 6. Re: Long Layover Hong Kong Airport. Can I go into city?
usertext: Thanks.

subject: 7. Re: Long Layover Hong Kong Airport. Can I go into city?
usertext: The first question is whether you can meet HK's visa requirments. If the answer is positive, why not? However, there are also other considerations and time is one of them. It may take you around 2 hours to travel back and forth the city centre. It may take you another 2 hours to go through the immigration and custom checks. Besides, you should also make some allowance for traffic incidents. My advice is don't stay in the city longer than 8 hours. It is always better safe than sorry.

subject: 8. Re: Long Layover Hong Kong Airport. Can I go into city?
usertext: I think the estimates in #7 are too conservative. The airport express train to downtown takes 25 minutes, so the roundtrip travel time could be much less than two hours. On arrival, there could be a wait at immigration -- 15 to 20 minutes would be usual. However, I'm assuming that OP would not be picking up checked bags and would not need to wait at all for baggage delivery, so Customs would be a walk-through. And on return to the airport, count 20 minutes for security check and immigration.

subject: 9. Re: Long Layover Hong Kong Airport. Can I go into city?
usertext: I've got a 6 hour layover and I'm heading into the city on the airport express. I won't have any luggage to check and will already have my boarding pass, so just out the airport through customs and immigration, and then back in through security. The Airport Express into Hong Kong is quick (25mins) and runs often. 14 hours will be plenty of time.

subject: First time in Hongkong advice please
usertext: Hello good people. We are a family of 4 and will be in Hongkong for a short 4 nights trip in the beginning of july. We would love to visit macau as heard so much about it and spend the other 3 days around hongkong. Kindly suggest a few goor hotels for family's with either interconnected rooms or family room for a budget of 150-200 gbp per night or around that budget. Which are the convinient areas to stay for using public transport etc? I see we have to do daily antigen tests recommended? Looks like hongkong is the odd one out which hasn't phased out mandatory covid testing? Many thanks in advance

subject: 1. Re: First time in Hongkong advice please
usertext: { Kindly suggest a few goor hotels for family's with either interconnected rooms or family room for a budget of 150-200 gbp per night or around that budget. } Make sure you read previous forum posts. This question (family of four needing a room in HK) has been asked many times over the years and hotel recommendations within those threads remain relevant in 2023. You can do this by using the Search Box near the top of the forum. I would also suggest using Booking.com (BC) to get a look what properties which are available during the dates of your intended visit. BC has a good feel of the hotel scene in Hong Kong, most reputable properties in the city offer rooms on that platform so you can use it to get an idea for which properties are in your price range and where they are located around the city. {Which are the convinient areas to stay for using public transport etc? } Most recommend staying in hotels within close proximity to MTR Stations. Our local rail system is by far the most tourist friendly means of transportation. Buses can fill in the gaps where the MTR doesn't work out best.Popular areas are in various districts around HK Island and the Kowloon Peninsula. {I see we have to do daily antigen tests recommended? Looks like hongkong is the odd one out which hasn't phased out mandatory covid testing?} Lucky for you. There are no mandatory daily testing requirements now. Local gov't in HK only recommends that you do daily testing but you don't have to take daily tests any longer if you don't want to. See updated Inbound Travel restrictions here (see link) https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/eng/inbound-travel.html

subject: 2. Re: First time in Hongkong advice please
usertext: Thank you

subject: 3. Re: First time in Hongkong advice please
usertext: I highly recommend staying in Kowloon or on Hong Kong Island. Both areas are very convenient for using public transport and have a wide range of hotels to choose from. Re Macau, there are many hotel options to choose from as well. The Galaxy Hotel Macau is a great choice for families as it offers spacious family suites and a wide range of amenities. In Kowloon, you might want to consider the Cordis, Hong Kong or the Eaton HK, both of which offer family rooms and are within your budget. On Hong Kong Island, the Best Western Plus Hotel Hong Kong and the Hotel Indigo Hong Kong Island are both great options for families.

subject: Feb 2023 Tourism figures in Hong Kong
usertext: HKTB is reporting through various local outlets that HK had 1.46 million visitors during February, nearly 30% pre-pandemic levels. https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1692084-20230315.htm https://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news/section/4/201485/Hello-Hong-Kong!-More-gift-vouchers-on-offer-as-1.46m-travelers-recorded-in-Feb-%C2%A0 With the dropping of the mask mandate and upcoming voucher schemes, those figures and % are likely to rise over the next few months as well. This means things will continue to change locally as we revert back to pre-pandemic conditions in the city. Have noticed some effects of increased tourist activity in recent weeks. Would be interested to hear what others are seeing/experiencing that might be worth visitors to the city being aware of. The Peak Tram is now regularly full up, at least on the two weekday visits made over the past month. While there is still not much of a queue, the trams themselves are filling up with picture taking tourists. Star Ferry riders are increasing but still no issue of getting a good seat if not an entire row to yourself. Harbour Cruise is definitely back on. The booth at the TST Ferry Pier which I hadn't seen open or a couple years is now regularly staffed and selling rides. Helicopter ride shop on the upper deck, selling the harbour flights is back open as well. Avenue of Stars - lined with tourist groups again. I admit having really enjoyed the lack of crowds here of the past three years, a rare silver lining of the pandemic. While shoulder crushing crowds are still not back, even midweek afternoon walks here have returned to what I would call crowded conditions. Country Parks - Not many come here to hike our country parks but for those who do, we are definitely seeing fewer hikers on the trails even during weekend hikes this spring. This is likely the result of HKers now being able to travel out of the city this year instead of being stuck here looking for things to do every weekend. My guess around 66-75% hiker numbers this Spring compared to what we experienced the past few spring seasons. HKMB - Last week, I encountered queues to board the Golden Bus that I haven't seen since 2018. I was really surprised to see so many making the midweek journey over to Macau already. Not a major issue though as multiple Golden Shuttle Buses were being loading simultaneously and they were departing leaving few minutes to Macau so while the queues were long, the passenger processing was very fast. Speaking of Macau, the city is ahead of HK with tourist visitors so far - seeing roughly 1.56 million visitors in Feb (44% pre-pandemic levels), packed into much more confined space. Any thoughts of visiting there before the crowds return - that window of opportunity has already passed. Do be ready for crowds in the main tourist areas around the peninsula and long queues at the famous food shops. The Cotai Strip on the other hand isn't particularly crowded by comparison to pre-pandemic levels. I believe this is much to do with several major properties opening (Galaxy Phase II, Lisboa Grand Palace, Lisboeta) during the pandemic and others reopening (Sands Cotai Central rebranded and reopened as Londoner). This has definitely helped spread tourists around more than in the past. However, once Macau climbs back up to 75%+ pre-pandemic figures, these casinos and properties will likely fill up with crowds again as well. Taipa village - Very crowded again, especially the food shops.

subject: Travel to HongKong with Dairy, peanut, treenut allergies.

subject: 1. Re: Travel to HongKong with Dairy, peanut, treenut allergies.

Might be worth contacting them directly on their fb page to ask for recommended dishes based on your child's allergies. https://www.facebook.com/dandysorganiccafe/about_details 32 Upper Lascar Row in Sheung Wan

subject: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: Since seeing someone posted about the best TimHo Wan branch to go to in one of the recent questions asked. Would anyone mind recommending one that is on the traditional side? I know Lin Heung Tea House closed down recently which is unfortunate Hopefully no other older restaurants closed down due to the pandemic.

subject: 1. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: Ritz Carlton's Tin Lung Heen has the best dim sum and environment. For less expensive price, I usually go to Sheraton's celestial court, which is also very good.

subject: 2. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: BTW, Lin Heung is dirty and rubbish.

subject: 3. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: Regent's Lai ching heen and Four Seasons Lung King Heen are also top ones.

subject: 4. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: For a nostalgic environment, you may check Fung Shing Restaurant. At Prince Edward there is Eton Restaurant, run by some old Fung Shing staffs. You can also try it if you pass by.

subject: 5. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: {Would anyone mind recommending one that is on the traditional side?} Like counting leaves in the forest, finding good dim sum is easy in Hong Kong. Some places are more tourist friendly than others and while you can certainty try of our 5 star hotel restaurants to pair quality dim sum with elegant environs and service, there are loads more plain and simple places as well. Here are a few that will A few tourist friendly places with English menus that stick out more than others include Dim Sum Square (Sheung Wan), Dim Dim Sum (Mongkok, Jordan and Wan Chai), One Dim Sum (Prince Edward) More traditional you can go with Maxim's Palace. They have several branches, the one at Hong Kong City Hall is most notable. More of a teahouse with good dim sum experience - Lock Cha (HK Park, Tai Kwan in Central) More modern take - try Dim Sum Library (Admiralty, Austin-TST) There are actually so many, its hard to list them out without missing other very good places for dim sum. Hard to imagine going wrong with these above.

subject: 6. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: Luk Yu Tea House 24-26 Stanley St, Central, Hong Kong

subject: 7. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: C'mon people, have pity on the OP. I religiously avoid anything with the word "Heen" in the name, unless I have an unlimited expense account. Someone treated me to Tin Lung Heen once. Even though I was not paying, I put my hands on my wallet just in case they can magically suck money from me just for walking on their carpet. Luk Yu is certainly old fashioned. But unless you are one of their long term customers, don't expect any service, but I guess that's the "charm" of the place. My suggestion for OP, go to the nearest shopping mall. There is bound to be at least one, if not more, dim sum restaurants in there. When we are in HK we usually go to East Ocean at The One shopping mall, Tsim sha Tsui.

subject: 8. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: From a local perspective, quality of Luk Yu's dim sum is considered substandard by many. Their dinner food is actually pretty decent but not cheap. Maxim's Palace at City Hall is a safe bet with the bonus of having a view. On weekends, go before 1130am or you will face long lines.

subject: 9. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: I don't want to be rude and not reply at all but truth is, I felt like I have opened a pandora's box  Note that I have read everyone's opinions and understand that everyone's preferences are different. Maxim is definitey on the list for now. The last time I was in HK was probably about 10 years ago and I totally forgot the prices of the dimsum were. A but higher compared to where I am from but I guess it's Hong Kong afterall.

subject: 10. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: {I don't want to be rude and not reply at all but truth is, I felt like I have opened a pandora's box } Not to worry.... just friendly banter here on the HK forum for the most part, including this conversation above. Every once in a while a chucklehead or two show up and offer combative remarks and feisty contestations of what others think but its not that common... Besides, this topic is about dim sum... Dim sum is supposed to be fun, not something to fight about! {I totally forgot the prices of the dimsum were.} Expect to pay HK$20-25+ for cheaper baskets at the reasonable priced places and up to HK$80-100+ for signature dim sum with more pricey ingredients at the fancy places. Depends on what sort of place you go to.

subject: 11. Re: Best traditional dim sum restaurants
usertext: For regular dim sum in a typical shopping mall cha-lau I'm used to paying around $120 per person for a dim sum lunch - as a rule of thumb I order two baskets per person and a dish of fried rice for every 4-5 people or so. Tends to work out well. Go cheaper and quality quickly goes down, too.

subject: Interantional PCR Test for negative result for Ferry to PRD
usertext: Hi All, I plan to arrive in Hong Kong and the following day catch ferry to the PRD Mainland. I understand i need to supply a negative PCR result that was taken no later than 48 hours to my departure from Hong Kong to Mainland but there is no guidelines to say if the PCR test has to be taken in Hong Kong or I can use a International approved provider which would be accepted for airline travel if travelling direct into Mainland. Can anyone give me some guidance. Thanks

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Interantional PCR Test for negative result for Ferry to PRD
usertext: The announcement regarding resumption of normal travel between HK and mainland China is here. There is no requirement that the PCR test be conducted in HK. See (2); https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202302/03/P2023020300649.htm The test certificate requirements are detailed at this link; http://gb.china-embassy.gov.cn/eng/visa/jiankangmaEn/202301/t20230117_11010074.htm

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Interantional PCR Test for negative result for Ferry to PRD
usertext: I must apologise as I believe I may have given misleading information. It appears that the PCR test must in fact be taken in HK as per ; https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/eng/inbound-travel-faq.html "All inbound persons from the Mainland or Macao are not required to conduct any pre-departure PCR tests or RATs. However, for persons travelling from Hong Kong to the Mainland (except those aged 3 and below), if they have stayed in overseas places or Taiwan on the day of departing Hong Kong for the Mainland or during the seven days before that day, they are required to conduct a PCR test within 48 hours prior to departure and obtain a negative results as per the Mainland's requirements. The self-paid nucleic acid test conducted in Hong Kong should meet the following criteria: The test must be conducted within 48 hours before the scheduled flight departure time (for those entering the Mainland via airport) or arrival time (for those entering the Mainland via other boundary control points); The test specimen must be a throat swab, nasopharyngeal swab or combined nasal and throat swab collected by dedicated staff; and The test result must be negative, and the test report must be issued by local COVID-19 testing institutions recognised by the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government (including community testing centres/community testing stations in various districts) for conducting reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction testing" HK Airport test facilities; https://projectscreen.co/en/predeparture-hkia-rt-pcr?gclid=Cj0KCQjw8e-gBhD0ARIsAJiDsaVnFR5ZfKFyU14cdO-Yv8__CnDQ3-dqR84566HhiMvL5nTg-oEzKjsaAosPEALw_wcB Community test centres; https://gia.info.gov.hk/general/202303/20/P2023032000588_415324_1_1679312000966.pdf Very sorry and hope this information doesn't come too late. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Interantional PCR Test for negative result for Ferry to PRD
usertext: Thanks for the guidance. I'm in a similar situation, flying from the US to HK, then taking a train to Guangzhou. If I take the PCR test at one of the community test centers, how will I receive the test results? I will not have cell phone access in HK. Is it possible to receive a hard copy of the test results? Thanks in advance for the response.

subject: 4. Re: Interantional PCR Test for negative result for Ferry to PRD
usertext: Hum.. Much of the process of the self-paid tests is predicated on you having a mobile phone with a working phone number. There will be regular message communication for appointment confirmation, test registration and results that requires your use of a mobile phone. They will even check that your phone is properly receiving messages by sending you a test text which you have to show them as having been received prior to being allowed into the actual test cubicles where the doctor will administer the PCR tests. Below is the language specifying need for phone number as well. FAQ - How to participate in the self-test 4. How to participate in the testing? Booking and walk-in services will be available. Citizens who choose to book online via the 24-hour appointment booking system only need to provide simple personal information (including their name, identity document number and PHONE number) to select the testing centre and time slot. https://www.communitytest.gov.hk/en/info/#/en/faq

subject: 5. Re: Luggage Storage near West Kowloon Station
usertext: {Have you been to the station? If so, what is the service like?} Think of this way..... West Kowloon Rail Station just reopened two months ago and won't be at full service until sometime next month based on local reports. Not likely that many English speaking travellers from mainland have used rail service into HK as of yet. Even less likely they used the left luggage facility at the Station.... and yet even less likely they are lurking on this forum to see this post..... so you're asking a needle in a massive haystack question (#4) right now. Maybe six months from now someone who checks in with this forum will have used the left luggage at West Kowloon Station and can report their experience but its doubtful you will get a detailed report on what the experience was like right now. subject: Shenzhen 5 day visa on arrival
usertext: Hi, Visting Hong Kong in two weeks and saw that China has resumed tourist visas, so would like to visit Shenzhen for 2 days. I was unable to find any official website that confirms that the 5-day visa on arrival is available again. Did anyone get one recently? Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Shenzhen 5 day visa on arrival
usertext: I'd like to know the answer to this too but its always been difficult to find any official information about the Shenzhen visa on arrival. Information usually comes by "word of mouth" from travellers and we probably won't know until, as suggested by you, someone who has actually visited the visa office at any of the control points which issue this visa is able to confirm. However, its still early days as its only been a week or so since issuance of tourist visas resumed. The announcement on the State Council website does indicate that "the country will also resume issuing all types of port visas to applicants with lawful reasons"; http://english.www.gov.cn/statecouncil/ministries/202303/15/content_WS64111fc4c6d0f528699db4a3.html The State Council website also refers to the Shenzhen visa on arrival under "Other Notices" at this link; http://english.www.gov.cn/services/visitchina/202008/04/content_WS5f290b0ac6d029c1c263738a.html At the current time there is still a requirement for HK - Shenzhen cross-border travellers who have arrived from overseas within the last seven days to produce a negative PCR test.

subject: 2. Re: Shenzhen 5 day visa on arrival
usertext: Don't forget that for some nationalities, the cost of the five-day Shenzhen pass is prohibitive. For Americans it's around US$150, the same as a full visa. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: hi all, planning to visit hk 3 of us ( mum 70++, my daughter 16 y and me) on 5-9/8/23 hotel - BP ,regal , metro park ( which one better) day 1 * arrived hotel 3pm , walk around mongkok ladies market etc.... day 2 * big buddha , ngong ping 360, peak tram if possible maybe can visit tai o or lantau (either one) day 3 * full day Disney land day 4 * shopping or any good idea . day 5 * home thanks for the opinion

subject: 1. Re: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: >>> day 2 * big buddha , ngong ping 360, peak tram if possible maybe can visit tai o or lantau (either one) Buddha & Tai O combine well to make a full day. Consider taking the route via Mui Wo (and ordinary ferry to/from Central for great views) one way. Peak Tram you had better do another day. It's far apart. Can combine easily with a day of shopping if you want to do this on Hong Kong Island. Note that Mongkok is currently still a shadow of its former self due to the drop in tourists around, it is hard to predict how it will be come August. For hotel choice: read the reviews, check the amenities, and see which one will suit your preferences best.

subject: 2. Re: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: buddha and tai o in same day? how about 360 ? peak tram can make it on day 4 shopping am i right? thanks for the reply

subject: 3. Re: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: {hotel - BP ,regal , metro park ( which one better)} Do be aware that Regal and Metropark each have several hotels around the city. Make sure which one you are viewing and thinking about before booking. Which is best along with BP (Austin Rd in TST) depends on what area of the city you want to stay, how much you want to spend and what room type is most appealing for you and your group of three. I'd look over each on booking.com to see the room types and specs. Consider proximity to MTR Stations as well. @wvmarle {Note that Mongkok is currently still a shadow of its former self due to the drop in tourists around, it is hard to predict how it will be come August.} Passed by last Friday late afternoon and found a noticeable improvement to the situation at Ladies Market. Still some gaps where stalls are not setting up but some are reverting back to selling tourist souvenirs and trinkets. And, definitely some tourists walking around, doing a bit of browsing..... but yes, still nothing like what the scene was here in past years. Will take a while to get back to normal. @3 {buddha and tai o in same day? how about 360 ?} Yes that is fine. You can visit the Big Buddha by way of the 360 Cable Car ride. Most start in Tung Chung and ride the cable car up to the Ngong Ping Village and Big Buddha. Expect queues if you go this way. Alternative is to take bus or taxi up the village and ride the 360 cable car back down instead, fewer take this approach. Obviously, you ride both ways as well if you want to but that will take up more time and limit your ability to also go out to Tai O afterwards. {peak tram can make it on day 4 shopping am i right?} That makes a lot of sense to me, especially if you are planning to do a lot of shopping in places like Causeway Bay or other districts on HK Island. Perhaps do the Peak Tram first thing in the morning before queues form or go later in the day after your shopping when time isn't a factor. The Peak Tram presently runs until 10pm and you can take taxi down even much later if you are up at the Peak very late.

subject: 4. Re: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: my budget is around hkd 1k -1.2k per night. TST and mongkok its more shopping? for tourists its using octopus is better?

subject: 5. Re: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: {TST and mongkok its more shopping?} There is more shopping in TST. In addition to streets lined with retail shops, there are 6-7 shopping malls including a couple of the largest in HK. Mongkok has more street market, emporium and arcade style shopping. There are cheaper, boutique and budget friendly shopping centres in that district as well. {for tourists its using octopus is better?} I think so. The On Loan Octopus which you can pick up at the airport is a convenient way to use all forms of public transportation and make small purchases as convience stores, fast-food, bakeries, supermarkets, coffee shops and the likes.

subject: 11. Re: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: >>>>big Buddha only stairs right?>>>> The Big Buddha is accessible via a long flight of steps; https://flic.kr/p/247Ci3g There is a car park just beneath the podium at the top of these stairs which allows access by wheelchair or short set of steps to the lower podium level of the Buddha, avoiding the main steps; https://flic.kr/p/daE6kB Prior to the pandemic there were some some tours to the Buddha and other Lantau attractions which were allowed to use this car park enabling easy access to the Buddha. However, since tourism recently resumed I can't find any such tours currently operating which use this car park. Most tours to the Buddha aren't allowed to use this car park and park near the bus terminus which means visitors need to use the main steps. Some years ago Po Lin Monastery adjoining the Buddha site would on request and subject to availability arrange transport to the car park for people with mobility problems (in a buggy I think) but I don't know whether this arrangement still exits. You can contact the monastery at info@plm.org.hk to enquire. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 12. Re: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: #10: The Buddha is normally accessed via the stairs; the slope you refer to sounds like the road leading up to it. That road is exclusive to vehicles, you're not allowed to walk there. Besides, it's a pretty steep one by the looks of it. The rest of the area is by and large flat - from the cable car terminus to the monastery and even on to the wisdom path is all more or less flat (the wisdom path itself is rough and steep).

subject: 13. Re: hong kong 5 days trip

subject: 14. Re: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: #1 is suggesting taking ferry from Central Ferry Pier (HK Island) to Mui Wo (Lantau Island) Once you are in Mui Wo on the south side of Lantau Island you can take public bus (3M) to Tung Chung where you find the Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car lower terminus. Then you can take cable car up to Ngong Ping village. Bus 3M https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/detail/7 Alternatively, you can take public bus (2) from Mui Wo all the way up to Ngong Ping Village and then take the Cable Car back down to Tung Chung Lower Terminus Bus 2 https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/detail/4 Hope this makes sense.

subject: 17. Re: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: My favourite would be cable car one way, bus/ferry the other way. Works very well in either direction, also in combination with a visit to Tai O fishing village (there's a direct bus between Ngong Ping and Tai O, and beteween Tai O and Mui Wo).

subject: 18. Re: hong kong 5 days trip
usertext: #16 - There is no direct train from where you staying at Page 148. If you use google maps, it will show you the closest route from Jordan MTR Station - take Red Tsuen Wan Line to Lai King Station. From there change platforms to the Orange Tung Chung Line and take that train all the way to Tung Chung Station. From there you can catch a bus up to Ngong Ping Village to walk over the Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car lower terminus and ride the cable car up the mountain.

subject: 2. Re: Hong kong 5days itinerary
usertext: @Minxbaby {but with travellers returning, they will recover eventually.} First, very nice to see you on our HK forum. Hope recovery in Spore is coming along nicely. Things in HK are picking up steam quite fast. Hotel rates were silly cheap during lockdown but have nearly fully reverted back to pre-pandemic levels so cheap deals are not something tourists are likely to find much of going forward. @Rainbow1112 {Is hotel in hk always so expensive? I did a search and minimum $100+ night for 3/4 star hotel..} I'm afraid so. And sadly, quite a few midrange properties that I was familiar with went out of business or are pivoting to become serviced apartments now so the supply in that range is less than pre-pandemic times as well. If you are finding something at SGD$100(?) a night (HKD$586) for a 3 star place, that is not a bad price now at all, especially if you are looking at centrally located properties. Disney is easy to coordinate a day visit. Macau - more or less but do expect a long day (2-2.5 hr - travel & immigration) each way. Ferry services are proving slower to ramp up but bus service at the HZMB is full tilt already, steady stream of travellers going in both directions. Service on the bridge is 24 hours a day as well.

subject: 6. Re: Hong kong 5days itinerary
usertext: >> What are some of the places to visit/ shop or eat?<< It depends on your interests. Do you want to visit the usual tourist attractions (Peak Tram, Big Buddha, Ngong Ping cable car, Star Ferry, Avenue of the Stars, Ding Ding tram, Sky100) some of which you may have visited 20 years ago? Good food can be found anywhere you go. You don't have to specially visit a famous restaurant. HK is famous for its dim sum, roast goose and milk tea. Macau is famous for almond cookies and Portugese egg tarts. I think the markets and retail shops have not yet recovered from the pandemic. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: Hong kong 5days itinerary
usertext: @Rainbow1112 {Do you have any recommendations on the hotels? The sub $100 are generally with bad reviews.} High end properties, which you don't seem to be considering, offer more predictable quality experiences and hence can be easily recommended. As for our cheaper places... No unfortunately I don't have personal recommendations right at this time. The fact is many lower end hotels took a beating during the pandemic, quite a few did everything they could to survive, operating on skeleton staff and letting their service go down the tubes along the way. That are remain are trying to claw back and return to being viable properties but that means that there are no guarantees for what one might experience in 2023 being similar to pre-pandemic days. Best to read up on recent reviews (TA, booking.com, google reviews) on properties that you are most interested in and make a decision. If you have places that look like they fit your requirements, feel free to post them here and forum regulars can offer their thoughts if they have any. {Which is more convenient and faster? Bus or ferry?} Most convenient will depend on what hotel you are staying at. If you are right next to a ferry terminal, then ferry is more convenient. If not, Bus might be more convenient. Bus transportation is continuous and non-stop so you can go when you feel like it, not restricted to ferry departure times. That is why I generally prefer the bus. The bus is much cheaper than ferry rides as well, if that is an important consideration. {What are some of the places to visit/ shop or eat?} Research on Discover Hong Kong for sightseeing and attractions here in the city. That is a good place to start for learning about places to visit. Shopping is very personal, only you know what you are interested in shopping for. Use google and look for business and brand names you fancy and you'll be able to quickly locate their shops around the city. Where to eat? Wow... Ten thousand ways to answer this question. You'll find many more restaurants here than you can eat at in a lifetime. Again, it all depends on your personal tastes, preferences and how much you want to spend. You can go cheap or very expensive fine dining. You can eat local Cantonese, Asian, Western and everything in between. @minxbaby {Some of the attractions are still on reduced operating hours. Hotel rates, however, are already higher than pre-pandemic.} I think you lot are ahead of us in the recovery. We are watching the flight schedules, once they are closer to normalised will be looking for a return to Spore. It has been way too long.
