usertext: >>2) What are some snacks/goods to buy as gifts? I was thinking of buying egg tarts from macau but I think those can't be kept for long?<< Egg tarts have to be consumed immediately. You can buy almond cookies and wife's cake.

subject: 12. Re: Hong kong 5days itinerary
usertext: Don't buy meat products to take home unless they are from approved countries. https://www.sfa.gov.sg/food-import-export/bringing-food-for-personal-use Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 13. Re: Hong kong 5days itinerary
usertext: 1) HKD Is accepted as equivalent to MOP. It might actually be the more common cash in circulation there. All casinos work in HKD (because there do not exist enough MOP to go around...) 2) Indeed egg tarts are for immediate consumption. Best fresh from the oven. 3) There are public buses that can take you there, Google Maps can help you planning. No free casino-run shuttles on that route. For your Macau trip: plan to leave early (and return late) as you'll need some 2 1/2-3 hours travel time each way.

subject: 14. Re: Hong kong 5days itinerary
usertext: {Day 2 - Macau} Your travel plan is fine. Ferries from the HK Macau ferry terminal go to the Outer Harbour ferry terminal in Macau which is on the main Macau Peninsula. That is where you can walk to take a short bus ride over to the World Heritage area including the Ruins of St. Pauls. Spending HKD in Macau is easiest. Everyone (incl. public buses) accepts HKD but will most likely give you MOP in change if making smaller purchases. Do note that that the Macau LRT self-ticketing machines don't accept HKD. If you end up using the LRT and only have HKD, that is still fine, just go to the ticket booth and buy from there. Otherwise, you will have problem using HKD in Macau. Your bigger problem is getting rid of your MOP upon leaving. This is one of the world's least convertible currencies, not even easy to exchange in Hong Kong. So make sure you spend as much of it as you can before returning to HK. Lord Stow's Do note that Lord Stow's isn't on the Macau Peninsula. There original bakery is down in the south of Macau in the village of Caloane. They have branches in Taipa village and at Venetian Hotel on the Cotai Strip that are convenient to visit. I don't know what the queue situation will be like in November but it is NUTS right now with mainland Chinese exercising three years of pent up demand, forming very long queues outside Lord Stows and other famous food shops and purchasing huge amounts. I was able to get into Lord Stow's in Taipa village on a visit earlier this month by going shortly after they opened on a weekday. The queue was just 15 minutes then. At other times of the day, the queue was much, much longer and this was just a weekday. Again, by Nov things may settle down a bit..... Portugalia Portuglia in Taipa Village has closed down their present location but have announced on facebook that they are reopening nearby soon. So do check for address update before your trip in November. It will be different than what you see now.

subject: 15. Re: Hong kong 5days itinerary
usertext: >>> Everyone (incl. public buses) accepts HKD but will most likely give you MOP in change if making smaller purchases. To add to this: you can always request HKD cash for change instead, that can cut down quite a bit on the quantity of MOP cash you get. On the other hand you may want to keep a few coins or small notes as souvenir. It's indeed nigh impossible to exchange MOP outside of Macau... and with that I assume the rates will be poor.

subject: Cruise Terminal to HKG Airport- How risky is this timing?
usertext: Our cruise ship is due in port at 6 am. Can we disembark (with priority) and make a 10 am flight?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Cruise Terminal to HKG Airport- How risky is this timing?
usertext: Hong has two cruise terminals, Kai Tak and Ocean Terminal (Tsim Sha Tsui). Under normal traffic conditions a taxi should take about 30 mins from Ocean Terminal or about 40 mins from Kai Tak to the airport passenger terminal. However, its difficult to predict with certainty whether you would have adequate time as this would depend on actual time taken for the disembarkation process and availability of transport. I think you would need to arrive at the airport at least an hour before flight departure time. I'm not sure what the current situation is but since its opening in 2013 until its closure during the covid pandemic Kai Tak Cruise Terminal was notorious for lack of taxi availability on ship call days and it may be advisable to pre-book a taxi. Cruise lines or the port authority have in the past arranged shuttle coaches for arriving passengers to transfer from Kai Tak to the Airport Express Kowloon Station which is a 20-minute train journey to the airport but I'm not sure what the current situation is (mention of this appears to have disappeared from the cruise terminal website). It may be worth checking with the cruise operator whether transfer arrangements are available.

subject: 2. Re: Cruise Terminal to HKG Airport- How risky is this timing?
usertext: Very helpful Thanks.

subject: Revisiting Hong Kong
usertext: Hi all, planning for upcoming HK trip, appreciate some advice please. Last visit was in 2013. Am considering between Park Hotel & Royal Plaza, may I check which has better access to more nice food options, night markets, malls? I am open to suggestion of similar range hotels too. What are the recommend pastries or cookies not to be missed to buy home? Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Revisiting Hong Kong
usertext: {Am considering between Park Hotel & Royal Plaza, may I check which has better access to more nice food options, night markets, malls? I am open to suggestion of similar range hotels too.} It is a fair comparison. Both are close to endless food and restaurant options. Royal Plaza is closer to a swath of cheap eats places and night market action in Mongkok. What I really like about this property now is that it is connected directly to the East Rail Line which is now extended all the way to HK Island (stated in 2022). You can be in Admiralty MRT Station on HK Island in just 20 minutes from the hotel. For me that is a game changer compared to the past. Park Hotel is closer to the bigger malls in TST and closer to the TST promenade where you find the Ave of Stars and lovely views of the Hong Kong Island Skyline and Victoria Harbour. {What are the recommend pastries or cookies not to be missed to buy home?} Obviously mooncakes but they won't be readily available until early August when Mid-Autumn Festival season starts. Wife cakes are easy to get year round. Mainland tourists are hell bent on Jenny Bakery butter cookies and are back to queuing up outside their shop in TST to purchase boxes to take back home. To be honest, they are just ok in my opinion. There are other local bakeries like Cookies Quartet if you want local butter cookies and there won't be a queue to get into their shops. If you try this shop, buy a package of their cinnamon twists. They are wicked good, great for dipping in coffee as well. Egg tarts are very popular but not something you should take back to Singapore, they should be eaten on the day. Proper local egg tarts can be found at many simple bakeries and eateries around the city. A recent gem that emerged during pandemic days is the sour dough egg tarts from bakehouse. They have 5-6 bakeries around the city and there are queues into much of the day at all their branches to buy their newly famous egg tarts. Fun to try and pretty darn good. Again, need to eat them on the day if possible or the next morning in your hotel. Don't bother trying to take them back home with you, they won't last.

subject: 2. Re: Revisiting Hong Kong
usertext: Hi Sharon we are currently in Hong-Kong arrived today about 7.00 am and staying at our second home the royal-plaza which we have stayed at since 2010 our last trip was 2019. one of the reasons is markets are walking distance from hotel,ladys market and tung-choi st market the hotel has a wonderful restaurant and there are plenty of food places to try,ther is also a 5sorey shopping centre attached to the hotel,and all the staff are very friendly.

subject: 3. Re: Revisiting Hong Kong
usertext: Thanks both for sharing :) Any recommendation on food/ shops which are 'not to be missed' around Royal plaza area? Thank you

usertext: Go try the stinky tofu from one of several hole-in-the-wall snack shops in the area.

subject: Meeting a friend in Shenzhen (From Wanchai)
usertext: What's the best route I should take from Wanchai to reach Shenzhen? I will be lugging around a huge golf bag with golf clubs. He will be coming from Changsha, Hunan and will probably take a train to Shenzhen. For the Shenzhen experts here, where is an ideal place for us to meet?

subject: 1. Re: Meeting a friend in Shenzhen (From Wanchai)
usertext: It really depends where in Shenzhen (it's a big place) - you can take the East Rail to Lo Wu or Lok Ma Chau, or you can take the high-speed rail from West Kowloon, you can take various ferries, or you can take various cross-boundary buses. First work out where you want to go in Shenzhen.

subject: 2. Re: Meeting a friend in Shenzhen (From Wanchai)
usertext: From Wanchai there used to be buses direct to the Lok Ma Chau / Huanggang road border crossing. That was very convenient and fast. I really don't know whether these services have been restarted already since the covid restrictions were lifted, and they've got competition: nowadays from Wan Chai there's of course also the East Rail Line (Exhibition Centre station) direct to the border (Lo Wu and Lok Ma Chau).

subject: 3. Re: Meeting a friend in Shenzhen (From Wanchai)
usertext: "where is an ideal place for us to meet?" Assuming he's spending at least one night, I would arrange to meet at his hotel, or optionally, find out which Shenzhen railroad station he's arriving at (likely Shenzhen Bei) and meet him there by taking a train from Hong Kong West Kowloon to Shenzhen Bei.

subject: 4. Re: Meeting a friend in Shenzhen (From Wanchai)
usertext: Shenzhen Bei, like all Chinese train stations, is huge. Not a good place to arrange a meetup unless you're both familiar with the place. At a hotel or restaurant would be better. Note there are luggage restrictions on both East Rail and the high-speed line. Enforcement seems pretty lax on East Rail but apparently is stricter on the high-speed line.

subject: 5. Re: Meeting a friend in Shenzhen (From Wanchai)
usertext: Meet at ShenzhenBei station is good and convenient for both of you. It takes less than 20 minutes from Hongkong Kowloon station to ShenzhenBei, why not take this route?

subject: 6. Re: Meeting a friend in Shenzhen (From Wanchai)
usertext: ShenzhenBei station is not a good place, it is too big and hard to find a place for meeting. Also, what can you do at the station ? If your frd get out from ShenzhenBei station , he can directly get on the ShenZhen metro line 4. I recommend Shangmeilin station, or Convention and Exhibition Center station in line 4, there is big shopping center right next to the metro station, with various shops and restaurant choice. For you departure from Wanchai of Hong Kong, you could go to Exhibition Centre station (MTR), and take a train to Lok Ma Chau, cross the border, and get on the line 4 in Futian Checkpoint station.

subject: mein schiff 5 CRUISE
usertext: Hey hi i am indian travelling hongkong next week I am planning to take mein schiff 5 cruise from HONG KONG TO JAPAN, SOUTH KOREA, TAIWAN and back to hong Kong I just want to confirm do i need visa for JAPAN, SOUTH KOREA AND TAIWAN to travelling on the cruise because recently i travelled in royal Caribbean cruise from singapore to Malaysia and back to singapore where Malaysia visa was not needed so something apply here please help.

subject: 1. Re: mein schiff 5 CRUISE
usertext: You really need to ask the cruise company this, or in the forums for the specific countries. But I'm reasonably sure that Indian passport holders need visas to enter all of those countries, and that one week is insufficient time to get them. For Hong Kong you need a successful Pre-Arrival Registration in order to be able to board the plane to HK. https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/visas/pre-arrival_registration_for_indian_nationals.html

subject: 2. Re: mein schiff 5 CRUISE
usertext: To be honest, you will do much better researching these very important matters on country specific consulate and embassy websites on the topic of visa requirements. If unable to find what you are looking for, I'd call each respective country's consulate nearest to where you live in India so that they can tell you specifically and directly if you need some sort of visa to enter their respective countries. Don't rely on strangers input on an international forum. Visa matters are too important for that. Use official resources instead.

subject: 3. Re: mein schiff 5 CRUISE
usertext: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visa_requirements_for_Indian_citizens I'd start here.

subject: Are Camera Tripods allowed inside the M+ Museum?
usertext: I'm going to see the Yayoi Kusama exhibit at the M+ Museum and I'm wondering if I can take and use my camera tripod inside the exhibit rooms for a photography project. No filming just photos. TIA.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Are Camera Tripods allowed inside the M+ Museum?
usertext: I think you'll need to contact the museum to clarify. The museum website states; "Ensure the flash is turned off when taking photos. Video recording is only permitted when specified. Professional photography or videography for commercial use must be arranged in advance". https://www.mplus.org.hk/en/plan-your-visit/ https://www.mplus.org.hk/en/contact-us/ Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Are Camera Tripods allowed inside the M+ Museum?
usertext: Considering you're planning on using a tripod, you are likely to fall in the "professional" category. Do contact the museum. That's where this kind of questions should be asked.

subject: 3. Re: Are Camera Tripods allowed inside the M+ Museum?
usertext: Have visited a few times but haven't thought to ask if tripods are allowed, presuming they are not. I've yet to see anyone trying to get into the exhibition galleries so far. What I might also add is that staff at M+ are rather strict with what visitors can take into the exhibition galleries when it comes to backpacks, strollers and the likes even if this is not clearly or specifically mentioned on their website FAQs yet. Just be ready to use their lockers. Generally speaking however, tripods are almost always prohibited by major museums. The other newly opened Hong Kong Palace Museum at West Kowloon does clearly state that tripods are not allowed inside, if that is anything to go on.

subject: Where in HK should I stay if I'm going to the M+ Museum?
usertext: Hi everyone. It will be my first time travelling solo to Hongkong. I will be going to the M+ Museum in May and would like to know at what area/s should I look for hotels if I'm going to the M+ Museum for 2 days? I will be staying in HK for about 5-7 days. Only 2 days in the museum and the rest are free days for me to roam. Your recommendations will be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

subject: 1. Re: Where in HK should I stay if I'm going to the M+ Museum?
usertext: Have you looked at the map? It is 10mins' walk from Kowloon MTR station so any hotel near an MTR Station is fine. If you don't want to change lines, refer to the MTR system map for stations along the same line. https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/system_map.html https://www.mplus.org.hk/en/plan-your-visit/

subject: 2. Re: Where in HK should I stay if I'm going to the M+ Museum?
usertext: Closest would be the W and the Ritz Carlton hotels, which are in the ICC building. Both are upmarket hotels. There are some far lower priced hotels in Tsing Yi, a very quick ride on the Tung Chung line to Kowloon Station and West Kowloon district. Alternatively you could look at hotels near Central Station - those are again mostly upmarket, such as the Mandarin Oriental. Other than that, lots and lots of hotels to choose from that are a quick taxi ride away from the West Kowloon district.

subject: 3. Re: Where in HK should I stay if I'm going to the M+ Museum?
usertext: {if I'm going to the M+ Museum for 2 days?} Is there a specific reason why you want to allocate two full days to M+? I hold M+ in higher regard than many and have visited several times since the museum opened. 3/4 of a day is enough to leisurely view all of the permanent exhibitions, temporary exhibitions, take in the rooftop garden and a light meal as well. I'd also say that those not particularly keen on modern and contemporary art will probably find 1/2 a day more than enough. If you really want to spend two days in West Kowloon, might I suggest 1 day at M+ and 1 day at the Hong Kong Palace Museum, which just opened last year. It is a very good museum as well, worth 1/2 a day for the permanent collections and another 1-2 hours for temporary exhibitions. {I will be going to the M+ Museum in May and would like to know at what area/s should I look for hotels if I'm going to the M+ Museum for 2 days?} If you stay in Central/Sheung Wan area of HK Island then you can use Hong Kong Station to take the MTR over to Kowloon Station on the other side of the harbour. That is the closest walking point to the West Kowloon Cultural District. If you stay in Kowloon side, there are light green buses that make it easier to reach the Cultural district than using MTR and long walk. For example, if you stay in the TST area, light green bus 77M does pick ups outside of TST East station on Salisbury Road and outside the HK China Ferry Pier on Canton before dropping off at M+ (see link) https://www.16seats.net/eng/gmb/gk_77m.html If you stay in the Mongkok area, similarly use (route 74) https://www.16seats.net/eng/gmb/gk_74.html Here is link to the recommended transportation page for West Kowloon https://www.westkowloon.hk/en/transport

subject: 8. Re: Where in HK should I stay if I'm going to the M+ Museum?
usertext: The M+ is in Kowloon - which is a large area, with many neighbourhoods. Convenient would be areas like Tsim Sha Tsui, Jordan, Yaumatei and Mongkok. You'll be able to find lots of interesting spots for street photography there. For your hotel choices: open your favourite hotel booking site, plug in your dates and your budget, and go from there. Hotels in HK are not cheap! So you may have to up your budget to find something you like. I really don't know how many hostels have survived covid. I expect most to have closed down. Many new ones will be popping up of course as tourism recovers. Do keep in mind that many hostels call themselves "hotel" so do read the descriptions of accommodations and their reviews carefully before booking anything. To get to the museum, you're probably best off taking a taxi with all your equipment. They're not expensive.

subject: Arriving HKG airport at 12am midnight
usertext: Hello everyone. I hope you have a good day! I will be arriving (and it's my final destination) at HKG Airport at 12am midnight. After immigration and luggage maybe it'll be over 1am. There are 2 people and female. So we thought it'll be risky to travel to the town and find a place for a short-time stay before we can visit our airbnb. Do you have any recommendation of places we can visit at the (or around) airport to have a rest? But we don't really want to spend lot of money for less than 10 hours stay. And for security reasons (our belongings) airport's corners are not the option since we might get really sleepy due to long flight. I know it's difficult but if there's any options I'd like to know and consider. Thanks a lot! Stay healthy.

subject: 1. Re: Arriving HKG airport at 12am midnight
usertext: The airport itself is safe if you want to save money. Otherwise, there isn't much you can do at that hour.

subject: 2. Re: Arriving HKG airport at 12am midnight
usertext: Baggage claim and Immigration & customs clearance shouldn't take longer than 40-45 minutes even during the busy hours of the day. We have had after midnight arrivals at HKIA and been completely out of the airport within 25 minutes in the past. Not sure they are processing passengers and luggage with that sort of efficiency yet (post pandemic times) but it is very doubtful that it will take a full hour. I'd plan on 30-40 minutes. The airport is very safe. You will find plenty other late arriving passengers and those awaiting early AM flights crashing out on the lounge chairs, even in the departure area in front of the check-in counters. They are doing the same thing you are asking about. There is CC TV everywhere. Little to do at the airport other than find a comfortable spot to rest and perhaps watch Netflix on your laptop. There is free wifi at the airport.

subject: 3. Re: Arriving HKG airport at 12am midnight
usertext: I would get a hotel room in town for the night, perhaps near where your AirBnB is. HK is a very safe city, but there is not much going on for tourists after midnight.

subject: Hong Kong Visa Requirement
usertext: Hi all, I'm a US green card holder with a Mainland China passport, I'm going back to China to visit some relatives and friends this summer for the first time since 2019 and I plan to fly w Cathay Pacific so I will have ~19hrs in Hong Kong. Am I allowed to go outside the airport with just my passport? Or do I still need the entry permit? Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Visa Requirement
usertext: If your trip is US-HK-mainland China or vice versa, you can enter HK for 7 days with your mainland China passport. No permit required.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Visa Requirement
usertext: And for exact language of the granted 7 day stay - see HK Immigration website and page source below https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/visas/overseas-chinese-entry-arrangement.html#c Transit: PRC passport holders who are in transit through Hong Kong to and from another country or territory may be granted a stay of seven days on each landing without the prior need to obtain an entry permit provided that normal immigration requirements are met, including possession of valid entry facilities for the destination and confirmed onward booking for the overseas journey.

subject: 6. Re: Hotel recommendations in HK
usertext: Definitely worth your time researching on the Macau forum for that part of your trip planning. For example, if you are wanting to stay on the Peninsula where the Ruins and rest of the World Heritage area is found, the HK-Macau Direct Bus isn't an ideal option for several reasons. It cost the same as the ferries, is less infrequent and drops off along the Cotai Strip, where you find the casinos that you seem to be less interested in seeing. This is the wrong side of Macau if you are most interested in staying and spending your 2 days on the main peninsula. There are better and less pricey transportation options if this is what you want to do. Look up the HZM bridge and Golden Shuttle bus for starters. This bridge crossing is open 24 hours a day, is very simple to use and has regular, frequent and cheaper buses running day and night that will put you right next to the main peninsula and much closer to the hotels there.

subject: 7. Re: Hotel recommendations in HK
usertext: We cut Macau to one night in the end as the ruins and the area could be completed at the same day, and we booked Emperor Hotel for the night. I saw that Agoda has this direct bus service (with English instructions since my Chinese is quite bad) and it runs from Shanghai Street to 6 hotels in Macau. If they are still running the service in Nov (current booking period is till end Mar), the nearest drop off would be Grand Lisboa casino and we can walk to the hotel. I read Golden shuttle buses and there is a recent review where waiting time was long, hence thinking of one direct bus all the way. But anyway, there's still time to decide.

subject: 8. Re: Hotel recommendations in HK

Perhaps even more departures by Nov.

subject: 6. Re: Foreigner friendly dim sum recommendations - not high end?
usertext: All restaurants will have dim sum in the non-fish variety but if that's important to you, make sure you know your dim sum beforehand as there's a lot that contains seafood even when the name doesn't clearly say so. For example a radish cake often has ham and/or dried shrimp in it.

subject: 7. Re: Foreigner friendly dim sum recommendations - not high end?
usertext: Not located very close to Langham but a couple of more trendy/modern dim sum places that you might want to look into: Dim Sum Library, set in an Art Deco decorated restaurant with slightly modern takes on dim sum along with traditional affair and in addition to traditional tea, they serve up some pretty good cocktails. They have two branches, one at Elements Mall (Kowloon Station) and one at Pacific Place (Admiralty Station) https://dimsumlibrary.com.hk/ Man Mo Dim Sum is offers contemporary dim sum with a French twist, a more elegant setting than your typical dim sum house with more sophisticated and some fusion dim sum on offer. They are located along Hollywood Rd (Sheung Wan). http://manmodimsum.com/hongkong/

subject: 8. Re: Foreigner friendly dim sum recommendations - not high end?
usertext: Ritz's tin lung heen dress code Dress Code: Gentlemen are requested to refrain from wearing beach sandals, open-toed shoes, sleeveless shirts or shorts. It seems no specific dress code for women. https://www.ritzcarlton.com/en/hotels/china/hong-kong/dining/tin-lung-heen HK 5 star hotel dress code is not as strict as the west. I also wear jeans and athletic shoes to Sheraton to eat dim sum.

subject: 10. Re: Foreigner friendly dim sum recommendations - not high end?
usertext: "One Dim Sum" in the heart of Kowloon is exactly what you are looking for, a very popular (and might I add high quality) place with really good dim sum that has an English menu at the entrance (you need to wait to be seated), however, the host also speaks perfect English and will help you out. We were there last month and stuffed our faces with dim sum and ended up paying 25-30 USD.

subject: 11. Re: Foreigner friendly dim sum recommendations - not high end?
usertext: Starry Terrace at 8 Observatory Road is a place I have visited a few times recently. The environment is nice with tables not packed together. It's also located well up in the building that you get some nice views. Best of all, some items can be ordered by piece. Therefore, you can sample a larger variety. Cost is reasonable for a proper decent sit down place.

subject: 1. Re: Day trip to ShenZhen
usertext: There's the cost of the five-day pass to Shenzhen (expensive for some, like Brits and Americans) and the hassle of the border crossing. Plus, you'll need a PCR test if you go within a week of arriving HK. I'd skip it.

subject: 2. Re: Day trip to ShenZhen
usertext: What is your purpose of visiting Shenzhen? It's not exactly a major tourist destination (I'd go to Guangzhou instead, if for that purpose). Of course there's the added cost and hassle of getting a visa and PCR test (though the latter requirement will likely be dropped sooner or later).

subject: 3. Re: Day trip to ShenZhen

subject: 4. Re: Day trip to ShenZhen
usertext: Yes, there's a border between Hong Kong and Shenzhen; with very few exceptions, foreigners need a Chinese visa or a five-day "Shenzhen-only" pass purchased at the border to enter the Mainland from Hong Kong.

subject: 5. Re: Day trip to ShenZhen
usertext: I won't do it. Border issues aside, Shenzhen isn't a very "touristy" city IMO. You're just looking at a modern metropolis, which can be found pretty much anywhere. I'd save the hassle and plan a longer trip to mainland China for another time.

subject: 6. Re: Day trip to ShenZhen
usertext: {I just wanted to explore somewhere new on a day trip. Thought Shenzhen would be a good idea due to the proximity of it to HK.} While I prefer overnight visits to Macau, it is pretty easy to visit this sister city as a day trip from Hong Kong. If you are looking for less visited places that take up a 1/2 to full day, you can consider visiting an island from Central like Peng Chau, Chung Chau or Lamma. These are fun and easy to visit places. If you want something more rural and with a bit of hiking, you can take Sat and Sun ferries from Ma Liu Shui (University MTR) to outer islands like Kat O or Tung Ping Chau (sort of a hidden gem destination for Hong Kongers) to see amazing geology. See link https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/great-outdoor/wellness/tung-ping-chau.html If you don't want to take a ferry trip somewhere you can look at Heritage trails like the Ping Shan Trail near Yuen Long, taking in numerous Tang Clan heritage buildings. See link https://www.amo.gov.hk/en/heritage-trails/ping-shan-heritage-trail/index.html There are other off-the-beaten-path places to explore like these above if you are looking for ways to allocate your 8 days without crossing border into China.

subject: 14. Re: Day trip to ShenZhen
usertext: I've done that hike, although in the opposite direction, starting at Chuen Lung. It was a few years ago and I don't remember anything challenging about it. I took green minibus 80 from Tseun Wan along Route Twisk to Chuen Lung Village where it terminates. https://www.16seats.net/eng/gmb/gn_80.html This is much more frequent service than KMB bus 51 which travels the full length of Route Twisk beyond Chuen Lung and passes the Tai Mo Shan Country Park Visitor Centre. From Chuen Lung I just followed the signs for the Chuen Lung Forest Walk from where the route to Tai Mo Shan Road is clearly signed. I then took bus 51 from near the country park visitor centre on Route Twisk back to Tsuen Wan; http://search.kmb.hk/TD_SS/51.pdf I think you would need to allow around three hours at a leisurely pace. There are some pictures at the link below which should give you an idea of what to expect; https://flic.kr/s/aHBqjAxCrX

subject: 15. Re: Day trip to ShenZhen
usertext: RE: "the weather station trail then back down to Chuen Lung. I think I am overly ambitious on this" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = ST has given you very clear information on minibus and KMB bus. (Hi ST!  Very pleased to see you and all the familiar names once again. I thought Covid and the no-Covid thing would have driven us all out.) This route may not be as difficult as you think. From the visitor center to the gate of weather station is on a narrow road with a gradual climb. You are only on ~1.5 km of it. Quite manageable. And the route to Chuen Lung, which is like (I used to consider it as "half way to the top of Tai Mo Shan" when I was small) not too far, on down slope, you will be fine. Take the green minibus if there is one. Or else walk out the short distance to the main road "Route Twisk" to take the "big bus" KMB.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 16. Re: Day trip to ShenZhen
usertext: Hi HappyFeet, thought you'd deserted us for good so its nice to see you back. Yes, that route's not really difficult, about 6km in all. Strenuous hikes usually stick in my memory and that one doesn't.

subject: 17. Re: Day trip to ShenZhen
usertext: Note that on weekdays the KMB route 51 runs only once per hour, so personally I would go up on 51 and walk down to Chuen Lung. It's much easier to arrange the start of the trip to hit a specific bus than at the end of a hike.

subject: buying winter clothes and wear
usertext: looking for a proper winter wear or jacket with waterproof and can wear down to -25% any recommend ?

subject: 1. Re: buying winter clothes and wear
usertext: -25C?! Maybe try an outdoors gears store, such as RC Outfitter or All Weather Outdoors.

subject: 2. Re: buying winter clothes and wear
usertext: There are several international outfitter companies in Hong Kong. Decathlon is starting to dominate the market in recent years. They have some large shops in several centrally located areas and a mega flagship in Tsueng Kwan O that is huge. Most of their product range is available to view online as well (see link) https://www.decathlon.com.hk/en/browse/c0-men/c1-clothing/c2-jackets/_/N-mmeevp

subject: 3. Re: buying winter clothes and wear
usertext: If you really need clothing rated for that frigid weather, the only reliable way to find it in HK will be mail order. Decathlon sells mostly lighter jackets.....I noticed their website did have one parka rated for weather down to -20 C, but of course it is "out of stock" at all their HK stores: https://www.decathlon.com.hk/en/p/men-s-winter-waterproof-hiking-parka-sh500-ultra-warm-20-c/_/R-p-340344?mc=8755599&c=BLACK If this is casual shopping then sure, have a look around at places in HK and see if lightning strikes. But if this is "I must have this soon because I have booked a trip to Nunavut", then I would not take chances and I'd order online for mail delivery.

subject: 4. Re: buying winter clothes and wear
usertext: I always take such ratings with a big grain of salt. It varies so much person to person, what you're used to. Temperature tolerance between my wife and me differs by 10-15 degrees. At 10 degrees she wears as much as is normal for me when the temperature drops below freezing... That's probably at least in part the difference between growing up in a cool European climate vs growing up in subtropical Hong Kong.

subject: 5. Re: buying winter clothes and wear
usertext: Try the North Face shops at HK https://www.thenorthface.com.hk But no guarantees.

subject: Personal guide in sha tin
usertext: I need a half day guide in sha tin

subject: 1. Re: Personal guide in sha tin
usertext: There are a some interesting places to visit in Sha Tin that include a mall, nice city park, a few temples and historic sites mostly situated along the Shing Mun River and within walking distance to MTR Stations. These can all be conveniently visited with minimal planning on your own.

subject: 2. Re: Personal guide in sha tin
usertext: Not to mention a retro Hong Kong roast pigeon lunch at the Lung Wah Hotel. https://www.tripadvisor.com/Restaurant_Review-g294217-d1049010-Reviews-Lung_Wah_Hotel-Hong_Kong.html

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Connection time on different airlines
usertext: Hi We are arriving in at 16:35 on a Sunday with British Airways We are then looking to connect to Bangkok, how long after should we be looking for this to be? we want o get a balance of low risk but not waiting any more than needed Inbound from London is business class so that should save a little time but I assume we need to clear immigration, collect bags, check back in and go through security again Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Connection time on different airlines
usertext: Check with BA as to whether if you book HKG-BKK with their alliance partner airline Cathay Pacific you could check your bags through to BKK and just remain in the transit area. If you can do that, 60 minutes would probably be okay for a connection and 90 minutes ample. If you cannot check the bags through, then yes you will have to go through immigration, collect your bags, exit from the customs area, go upstairs to the check-in area and check in for the onward flight. (Your business class arrival might help a tiny bit, in shortening the time you will have to wait for your bags, assuming they get "priority" tags.) But even so, in this case, I would not allow less than 2,5 hours for the connection time, and 3 hours would be safer.

subject: 2. Re: Connection time on different airlines
usertext: My understanding is that BA, en route to being a low cost carrier, no longer checks bags through on separate tickets, even to oneworld partners. Cathay, on the other hand, does, so if you return the same way, Cathay BKK-HKG, BA HKG-LHR, then your bags will be checked through and a shorter connection time will suffice. I agree with HK_Observer's timings for both cases.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Connection time on different airlines
usertext: Thanks all I will check with BA There is a Cathay flight 2 hrs after I land so if I can that might work If I don't use Cathay then it's 2hrs 30 or 4h 55

subject: 4. Re: Connection time on different airlines
usertext: Keep in mind that if you're delayed and miss your connection, you'll have to buy a new ticket. For that reason a longer connection time is safer. Also keep in mind that many carriers close their check-in counter some 45 mins before departure (exact cut-off varies per carrier), and it takes typically some 45 mins from landing, luggage collection, immigration to get to your check-in counter. So a 2 hr connection is awfully tight. That 4h55 connection sounds like the best bet for you (short of simply getting a single ticket for this itinerary).

subject: 5. Re: Connection time on different airlines
usertext: BA's policy is well known and inflexible: if your two flights are booked on separate tickets, you will not enjoy through checking. It doesn't matter if you are connecting to an partner carrier like Cathay or an LCC.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Connection time on different airlines
usertext: Great Thanks for the replies We will go with the longer connection time

subject: Immigration checkpoint for train from HK to Guangzhou
usertext: Hello I'm in need of some help with my trip. I'm taking my 80 year old mom to Japan and HK. After a few days in HK, I will return home to the US and my mom will take the high speed rail to Guangzhou to visit relatives. From what I understand, to enter China she needs to get a PCR test and a health declaration QR code, right? My mom is not tech savvy and will not have cell phone access. I plan to get a hard copy printout of the PCR test results. For the QR code, is it possible to do the online declaration, then take a screenshot of the QR code? (She'll have her iPad , which I can upload the screenshot into.) Lastly, at the Kowloon West Station is it possible for me to walk my mom all the way up to the China Immigration checkpoint? Even though she speaks Chinese, she sometimes has issues comprehending and responding to questions while under pressure. Any insight into the process is appreciated. I'm really starting to worry if this plan for her to travel alone to Guangzhou is a good idea. Thanks in advance. Calvin

subject: 1. Re: Immigration checkpoint for train from HK to Guangzhou
usertext: She doesn't need a PCR test if she goes to the Mainland after spending at least a week in Hong Kong.

subject: 2. Re: Immigration checkpoint for train from HK to Guangzhou
usertext: For the QR code, after you finish the online declaration, save the QR code image in her iPad and show the image to the staffs. Do this declaration 24 hours before her entry/exit to China. I don't know for Kowloon West Station. Once at another border, I saw a 90 years old granny who could not understand any of these cell phone declaration things. The person who accompanied her discussed with the staffs for long time and at the end she was allowed to accompany the granny to the Chinese border.

subject: 3. Re: Immigration checkpoint for train from HK to Guangzhou
usertext: No you can't. You will meet Chinese immigration counter AFTER you pass HK immigration counter. You cannot go with your mum all way to Chinese immigration except you are leaving HK as well. But the health declaration QR code could be done 24 hours before departure, so you could help her to make one and save the photo, and told her to open it when she arrive Chinese immigration. In Lo Wu or Lok Ma chau, there are usually staff helping elderly to make QR code, not sure if Kowloon West Station have or not, but i guess there will be.

subject: 4. Re: Immigration checkpoint for train from HK to Guangzhou
usertext: Calvin, just my opinion, if it were my 80 year old mother and time allows I would seriously consider getting an L or maybe a Q2 visa, which are again being issued, and accompany her to Guangzhou. Guangzhou is a nice city and you might even spend a few days there and China Southern has direct flights from there back to Los Angeles, if that is where you would return to.

subject: 5. Re: Immigration checkpoint for train from HK to Guangzhou
usertext: Thanks everyone for the insight and advice. I have a much better understanding of the situation now and will plan accordingly. Calvin

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Urgent - do tourists need to take a covid 19 test before?
usertext: The rules still say you need to provide:  a negative rapid antigen test result for COVID-19 taken no more than 24 hours prior to departure; or  a negative PCR test taken no more than 48 hours before departure. You should take and keep photos showing the negative rapid antigen test result cartridge with the test sample marked up with name, date, time or have the test report for a negative polymerase chain reaction-based nucleic acid test.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Urgent - do tourists need to take a covid 19 test before?
usertext: Thank you so much! And this is why I never trust him with any planning! We made it to the pharmacy with 2 minutes to spare before it closed. Really appreciate your help!

subject: 3. Re: Urgent - do tourists need to take a covid 19 test before?
usertext: Yes. Technically you do need to have proof of a negative RAT test taken within 24 hours (or PCR test within 48 hours) of your departure to Hong Kong. They are not checking them at HKIA airport but they do ask that you keep photo proof of the negative test. See http://Cornavirus.gov.hk official website for the official stance on testing requirements (see link) https://www.coronavirus.gov.hk/eng/inbound-travel.html

subject: 4. Re: Urgent - do tourists need to take a covid 19 test before?
usertext: We flew from melbourne australia last tuesday the 21st with cathay paciffic we did a rat test 24 hours before departure and put them on our phones,were not asked for them at departure point and also at hong-kong airport,

subject: 5. Re: Urgent - do tourists need to take a covid 19 test before?
usertext: As of today April 1, Covid tests are no longer required for entry to Hong Kong. "Arrangements since 1 April 2023: All pre-departure and post-arrival quarantine and testing requirements have been removed." The plug has also been pulled on the Health Declaration, which has been optional for several months. But as always, airline check-in clerks may not be au courant with the latest rules. https://www.chp.gov.hk/hdf/ Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Urgent - do tourists need to take a covid 19 test before?

subject: 7. Re: Urgent - do tourists need to take a covid 19 test before?

subject: Passport validity
usertext: I am planning to travel to HK in May, but my passport is expiring in Oct. Do i need to renew my passport? Some resources say, the passport validity must be 6months, but some say, passport should be valid for 1 month.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Passport validity
usertext: Hong Kong passport validity requirement is; "Passports or travel documents other than documents issued to stateless persons and refugees must be valid at least 1 month after period of intended stay. Documents issued to stateless persons must be valid at least 2 months after the period of intended stay. Documents issued to refugees are only valid in combination with a valid visa and valid documents for next destination."

subject: 8 Hour Layover, where to go?
usertext: Hi all, I have an 8 hour layover in Hong Kong on my way to Japan. I will be arriving at 8am and leave again at 16:30PM, so I guess I will have around 5 hours net to see a bit of this wonderful city! Do you think that Victoria Peak is possible? I have read mixed suggestions about how to get there. Some say better to take the taxi for 50-70USD or take the train wich takes around 26minutes? Please advise

subject: 1. Re: 8 Hour Layover, where to go?
usertext: Yes, very possible. Essentially going to The Peak is about taking in the view over HK and its harbour. If that is essentially all you want to do that actually I would recommend taking an upstairs seat on an A11 CityFlyer bus from the airport for extra views; get down at Admiralty Station. Walk through Pacific Place Mall and Hong Kong Park to the Peak Tram station. Get the Peak Tram up to The Peak. Walk around a bit to take in the views. Then get bus #15 down from The Peak (again, get upstairs, preferably front row). Get off at Pedder Street and then take a short walk in the Central District to pick up the A11 bus back to the Airport at Pottinger St/Connaught Rd. A11 bus: https://mobile.bravobus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=A11&dsmode=1&l=1 Peak Tram: https://www.thepeak.com.hk/en/the-peak-experience/the-peak-tram #15 bus: https://mobile.bravobus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=15&dsmode=1&l=1

subject: 2. Re: 8 Hour Layover, where to go?
usertext: Thank you HK Ga Yau. Is traffic unpredictable in Hong Kong? I mean, can there be any 30 mins-1 hour delays to these providers you mentioned? I plan to be back at the airport at least 2.5 hours before my next flight, just in case.

subject: 3. Re: 8 Hour Layover, where to go?
usertext: The A11 you'll board around 9, arriving at the island close to an hour later. That's past morning rush hour, and traffic will be smooth. Bus 15 down will be around 12:30 or so, that has a mild risk of delays, especially where it reaches Wan Chai. That junction (turning onto Queen's Road East) can get rather stuck but not normally at that hour. Maybe a 10-minute delay, if unlucky. The Peak Tram may have lines, you see that beforehand. At that hour no lines for the down direction so very reliable. The A11 back to airport is also reliable, or alternative use the even more reliable Airport Express train service to avoid any potential traffic issues.

subject: 4. Re: 8 Hour Layover, where to go?
usertext: Hi wvmarle, thanks for the info. Do you know the frequency of bus15? I checked online here https://moovitapp.com/index/en/public_transit-line-15-Hong_Kong-2741-904689-595552-0 and it says the frequency is every 13 minutes but only between 7:00 AM - 8:57 AM. Do they mean until 8:57PM in the evening instead?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 5. Re: 8 Hour Layover, where to go?
usertext: The timetable you have quoted only shows early morning departures from Exchange Square. From 10am onwards the service begins at Central Pier 5 then stops near Star Ferry Pier before reaching Exchange Square and continuing the route to the Peak. Bus frequency is about every 15 mins until about midnight.

subject: 6. Re: 8 Hour Layover, where to go?
usertext: Correct schedules can be found on the bus operator's web site: https://mobile.bravobus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=15&dsmode=1&l=1

subject: Taxi from Wanchai to HK Airport
usertext: Hi Guys, I'll have 10 hours transit in HK and would like t wander around, 1. Is it easy to get taxi from Tsim Sha Tsui to Airport? 2. Is it easy to get taxi from Causeway Bay to Airport? I'll travel by taxi only and still considering whether it's safe to cross to Causeway Bay and made it on time Thanks a lot

subject: 1. Re: Taxi from Wanchai to HK Airport
usertext: Taking the Airport Express is safer than a taxi. Hong Kong taxi drivers are not known for good driving skills.

subject: 2. Re: Taxi from Wanchai to HK Airport
usertext: HK Taxis are not particularly unsafe by world standards. 10 hours is plenty to spend time in both TST and CAuseway Bay, and you will easily find taxis to take you to the airport from either place. (But there are also double-decker buses which are much cheaper and offer much better views on the ride from the upper deck.)

subject: 3. Re: Taxi from Wanchai to HK Airport
usertext: I have ridden on Hong Kong taxis all my life, and do not feel that the drivers are particularly unsafe. Hong Kongers in general are very efficient, and highly anticipatory. Perhaps you are not used to their maneuvers, which sometimes are products of the crowded environment and time-competitiveness, and led you think they are unsafe. Taking the Airport Express (a train) from Causeway makes no sense. AE doesn't go to Causeway Bay (nor Wan Chai). There needs to be a transfer. It takes time. Just hail or find a waiting taxi and go straight to the airport. Airport bus A11 may work too if you happen to be near one of their bus stops in Causeway Bay.

subject: 1. Re: HK Disneyland sept or Oct?
usertext: Avoid the first week of October around Chinese National day (1 October). Otherwise much the same, but the weather may still be rather hot and humid in September. I'd choose the second half of October.

subject: 3. Re: HK Disneyland sept or Oct?
usertext: Late October weather is generally much nicer than late September weather. Crowds-wise those two periods are probably more or less the same.

subject: 4. Re: HK Disneyland sept or Oct?
usertext: Also, check HK public holidays and avoid those and weekends. As mentioned, later October weather is much nicer usually.

subject: 6. Re: HK Disneyland sept or Oct?
usertext: After living through 20 Hong Kong summers I'm used to it, too... nonetheless I still don't like it and strongly prefer the October-December weather :-)

subject: Help on Hong Kong PAR
usertext: Hi Need one advise on Hong Kong PAR. I got the PAR successful , but in the Passport Place of issue I selected "Bengaluru" , but in my passport it says "Bangalore". However In the drop down to select the cities I dont see "Bangalore" as an option. Not sure how I can enter Bangalore or it is fine with Bengaluru. If anyone faced similar issue , pls advise.

subject: 1. Re: Help on Hong Kong PAR
usertext: Well the normal response is that the info on the PAR must match EXACTLY the information in your pssport, but I think in this case common sense should prevail. The HK Government probably changed the spelling because the Indian Government changed the official spelling, but obviously passports that pre-date the change should still be good. Since the official name change was on 1 November 2014 and assuming your passport was issued before that date then I doubt that this will be a problem.

subject: 2. Re: Help on Hong Kong PAR
usertext: >>> Since the official name change was on 1 November 2014 and assuming your passport was issued before that date then I doubt that this will be a problem. The expiry date of that passport will be in the very near future... which by itself may be an issue.

subject: 1. Re: A12 bus
usertext: There is a bus terminus on the ground level, which is underneath the Arrival Level. Leave the luggage cart at the bus stop. It will be retrieved by workers, no worries. Look up the aisle for bus A12. Each route has its aisle or stop.

subject: 6h 15m layover. How feasible is this itinerary?
usertext: I'll have a 6.25 hour layover in Hong Kong on a Saturday in May. I'm from Canada, so no visa requirements. Inbound flight arrives at 11:45 a.m. and outbound flight departs at 6:00 pm. My checked bags will go through to their final destination but I will have a backpack with me. I'll have my boarding pass and will be checked in for my outbound flight, so won't need to do that at the airport. How realistic is this itinerary? Is there anything major that I'm forgetting? Is there anything you'd do differently? 11:45 am -12:40 pm: Land, taxi to gate, deboard plane, go through immigration and customs; nothing to declare, no bags to pick up 12:40-1:00 pm: Exchange money, arrive at airport express station and buy an AE return ticket. 1:00-1:35 pm: Take the next AE towards Kowloon and Hong Kong/Central. Add 10 mins if I need water / snacks; 7-11 and other shops in the airport 1:35-2:15 pm: Leave the AE at Hong Kong/Central station. Walk towards the Star Ferry Pier (Central Ferry Pier 7) and take the Star Ferry over to TST Star Ferry Pier. 2:15-3:45 pm: head east along Salisbury road and then north on Nathan Road. From Nathan Rd, make way to Kowloon Airport Express station; grab quick service food along the way 3:45-4:20 pm Arrive at the Kowloon Airport Express, take Airport Express to airport 4:20-5:20 pm: Arrive at airport, get to correct terminal, go through security, find gate 5:20-6:00pm: grab snack (if time), board flight and depart

subject: 1. Re: 6h 15m layover. How feasible is this itinerary?
usertext: Feasible. From Nathan Road take taxi to Kowloon Station, or direct to airport (about the same total time, possibly faster than changing to the train). Taxis are cash only, should be about $300 for that ride.

subject: 2. Re: 6h 15m layover. How feasible is this itinerary?
usertext: hello, I'll have long layover in HK as well and your itinerary is a good inspiration. May I know if it's easy for you to grab taxi from Nathan Road to airport? Or in case you ride UBER, which one is easier/more convenient? Thanks a lot and wishing you pleasant trip

subject: 3. Re: 6h 15m layover. How feasible is this itinerary?
usertext: Taxi is easier - they're everywhere, just wave one down whenever and wherever you need one. Uber means you first need an account and the app, then book a ride, wait for the driver to arrive, and locate your ride. The only advantage of Uber is the credit card payment.

subject: 4. Re: 6h 15m layover. How feasible is this itinerary?
usertext: We are a family of 5. Is it possible / easy to find a taxi for 5 pax? (Prefer to stay in a single vehicle rather than 2 taxis).

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 5. Re: 6h 15m layover. How feasible is this itinerary?
usertext: New taxis since 2008 are licenced for maximum 4 passengers but about one in five of the 18,000 or so fleet remain licenced to carry five and can be identified by a plate at the front and rear. A child under 3 isn't counted. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: 6h 15m layover. How feasible is this itinerary?
usertext: Thanks for your reply. I contemplate a lot between booking Klook vs Uber vs Taxi. Since I cant speak Chinese/Cantonese Im worried this might be an issue to communicate with the driver

subject: 7. Re: 6h 15m layover. How feasible is this itinerary?
usertext: Taxi drivers will know the English name of most prime tourist destinations; for other destinations such as a hotel best have the name written down in Chinese. Google Maps can help greatly in this as it can give the names of most locations in both English and Chinese.

subject: 8. Re: 6h 15m layover. How feasible is this itinerary?
usertext: @Randy: I am very confused by your 2 posts. In the opening, you have repeated use of "I" and "my". I thought you are a solo traveler. Then in reply #4, you said "We are a family of 5. " Do you have young kids? Your idea of a short-layover itinerary, taking the AE Train, Star Ferry ride, then walk along the Nathan Road north (and I presume you may walk all the way to the Kowloon Station to take the AE train back to the airport). The whole plan is like a James Bond movie plot kind of planning. If you are by yourself, you may be able to achieve it. But as a family of 5, and especially if with small children, things will take much longer and there are higher chances of unplanned issues. Such as getting a taxi which can take 5 passengers when you are walking along Nathan Road. It may take a while. Too risky with a less than 4 hour time-frame, Walking along Nathan Road really doesn't "buy" you much in touring experience, but adds a lot of risks in getting transportation. Walking is possible but not entirely "family friendly" with many streets to cross, crowded conditions, and to approach Kowloon Station there needs to be walking along some elevated walkpath and going through malls - can easily get disoriented. I would suggest you to take the AE train to Hong Kong Station. Walk outside to Central Piers. Ride the Star Ferry to Kowloon. Walk around a little waterfront promenade. But turn back to ride the Star Ferry back to Hong Kong Central Pier and ride the AE train back to the Airport from Hong Kong Station. Not attempt to use Kowloon MTR Station, either by walking there or by trying to hail a taxi mid-way along Nathan Road. If you want to take a taxi to Kowloon MTR Station, do so at the taxi stand right outside Star Ferry Terminal. Wait for a 5-passenger one. Not trying to hail one when you are walking on the street. It is very difficult (which may mean time-consuming... but time is what you don't have much of).

subject: transport from HK airport to Ibis Hotel Sheung Wan
usertext: Estimate how much is the taxi fare from HK airport to Ibis Hotel Sheung wan? Is taking airport bus the best way with 2 luggage?

subject: 1. Re: transport from HK airport to Ibis Hotel Sheung Wan
usertext: For all "taxi fare from the airport" queries you can use this page on the HK Airport website: https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/to-from-airport/taxis.page Using the airport bus you take the A11 and get off at the Macau Ferry Terminal (the first stop after the tunnel to HK Island). It's then about a 6-700m walk to the Ibis Sheung Wan, including going up and over a bridge over Connaught Road (although I think from memory that there are lifts up to the bridge). So it's your call on whether you're happy to lug your luggage that far to save about HK$300 (assuming only 1 person).

subject: 2. Re: transport from HK airport to Ibis Hotel Sheung Wan
usertext: Thank you!

subject: Where to eat Roast Goose and pork in HK
usertext: I'm looking for a roast goose eating place with reasonable price and quality near sheung wan. any recommendation? thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Where to eat Roast Goose and pork in HK
usertext: The most famous one is Yung Kee Restaurant ( Yung Kee Building, Wellington St, Central, Hong Kong), but many people say it is going downhill in recent years. You may also try Kam's Roast Goose ( 226 Hennessy Rd, Wan Chai, Hong Kong) and Yat Lok Restaurant ( Hong Kong, Central, Stanley St, 34-38 G/F). If you don't mind going a bit far away, there is one in Ting Kau, NT, Yue Kee Roast Goose Restaurant. Frankly speaking, I am no gourmet and have no idea which of them tastes the best. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Where to eat Roast Goose and pork in HK
usertext: I forgot a good one, Kamcentre Roast Goose (1/F, South China Athletic Association, 88 Caroline Hill Rd, Causeway Bay, Hong Kong).

subject: 3. Re: Where to eat Roast Goose and pork in HK
usertext: The obvious choice would be send you to Yung Kee, as mentioned in #1. They are very good. But won't be cheap. My view is it is okay, taste some of the best Hong Kong can offer. While they may go downhill, I don't know. But the culinary standard in Hong Kong and the patrons' expectation are very high. Even an "average" shop in Hong Kong would probably be better than you can find in other countries. If you don't want to pay higher price, may be just walk around the neighborhood. A lot of shops sell roast goose and other Cantonese BBQ items. It is the Cantonese specialty and you are in a place that inherited the best of the such culinary craft. Even a hole-in-the-wall may not disappoint you. You judge it with your eyes first. They all hang the roast items at the chopping counter window, which is at the front door of the eatery. See anything you like, walk in! These days they do post prices at the door or on the wall or something. You want another tip? Not sure which one to patronize? Just go to one that is most crowded with locals, but avoid the mid-day lunch hour in Central/Sheung Wan. A tidal wave of office workers eat around 12:30 pm to 2:00 pm. .

subject: 4. Re: Where to eat Roast Goose and pork in HK
usertext: For me, Kam's. Or Ki's Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: Where to eat Roast Goose and pork in HK
usertext: Becareful of low hygiene restaurants: https://www.hk01.com/%E5%81%A5%E5%BA%B7Easy/792755/%E9%A3%9F%E5%AE%89%E9%A2%A8%E9%9A%AA-%E8%8D%83%E7%81%A3%E9%85%92%E6%A8%93%E8%A1%9E%E7%94%9F%E6%83%A1%E5%8A%A3%E7%87%92%E9%B5%9D%E6%8E%9B%E5%9E%83%E5%9C%BE%E6%A1%B6-%E5%B8%B8%E8%A6%8B%E9%A3%9F%E7%89%A9%E4%B8%AD%E6%AF%92%E7%97%85%E8%8F%8C%E8%A6%81%E7%9F%A5 photos: https://cdn.hk01.com/di/media/images/dw/20220715/624582578308911104947150.jpeg/eUhENjGkNnPubW_iaswTK1nL2vb7vcCGlN5xZJTecWQ?v=w800 https://cdn.hk01.com/di/media/images/dw/20220715/624582585611587584860514.jpeg/en_ss5XhzdRlp2US8AEpOR4G76Ks1zb0mXw_RZl8P0U?v=w1920

subject: 11. Re: Where to eat Roast Goose and pork in HK

subject: 12. Re: Where to eat Roast Goose and pork in HK
usertext: If you have to ask that question, you are like me. We have not had enough roast goose. For me, I will try anything that looks good. Don't waste time go to the famous places and stand in long lines.

subject: 13. Re: Where to eat Roast Goose and pork in HK
usertext: Roast goose is typically best when freshly roasted. Walking by any place that sells roast goose, if you can see it hanging at the window, see if the skin looks plump and full. That's a sign that the goose is relatively fresh. If the skin is wrinkling big time, it's probably been sitting there for a while. The skin will likely be soft. The product will probably taste more oily.

subject: Half a day in Lantau
usertext: Greetings! Our plane arrives to HK airport at 05:15 morning. I'm trying to plan how we can spend half a day effectively in Lantau before proceeding to the HK center. Currently the itenary is: get from the airport to Tung Chung and leave luggage in lockers at either Citygate Outlets lockers or MTR Tung Chung station. From there take a taxi to Tai-O village, arriving there approx 7 am. Taking ferry could be nice, but not sure when they operate and what's the weather at sea. Spend at Tai-O 3 hours (going on promenande, maybe market if open at those times, etc) , then take a taxi (or bus?) to Ngong Ping village. Spend there up to 2 hours and take cable car down to Tung Chung. From there to take MTR to Kowloon. There is a small issue, that I already purchased tickets to Airport Express, so not sure if I have to either cancel them or to get back to the airport to take it. Any feedback on the route/means of transportation/durations and things I miss would be really appreciated! Additional details: we are 2 people. Can spend a few bucks more on means of transportation if it saves time or gets us a stop at a good spot. Thanks in advance!

subject: 1. Re: Half a day in Lantau
usertext: Can't edit, so adding a change here: Instead of going through Tung Chung, store luggage at the airport, and then take Taxi to Tai-O. On the way back, via a cable car down to Tung Chung, take a bus to airport, and then use Airport Express (can't cancel the tickets I have). Again, would love to hear any feedback.

subject: 2. Re: Half a day in Lantau
usertext: Your timing is not good for a Tai O visit. It is a small fishing village. It does rely on tourists to bring in some revenues. Nothing heats up until about noon or so. You will be there at 6:30 to 7:00 am. The tour boat rides would not be open (not until 10 am). Most of the shops may likely still be closed. Not an experience you want to have after spending time (and money) to reach there. I would do Tai O on another day. MTR from the city to Tung Chung is only about 30 minutes. It will take you 15 minutes or so to reach Tung Chung from the airport anyway. You are not really saving much time (especially you need to store your luggage away). I would suggest to take your AE ride, go to your hotel, store your luggage with bell service (since most likely you won't be able to check in until the afternoon that day). The go out and visit other places near the hotel to get started. Plan Lantau for another day. With MTR, it is really not a big deal to go to Tung Chung and Po Lin on Lantau "island".

subject: 3. Re: Half a day in Lantau
usertext: True. There is nothing in Tai O for visitors so early in the morning. Avoid. And even though you think it's easy to get to as you're on Lantau, it's not. It's a bugger of a bus ride and the frequencies are hourly and half hourly at best. Citygate only wakes up after 10:30 although the supermarket opens at 8. Sorry for the damper, best resort is to get into town and drop bags at the hotel and then venture out for the breakfast places.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Half a day in Lantau
usertext: If you just want to see the stilt houses, visit the temples, walk through the streets and along the promenades, and around harbourside and mangroves you can do all that in peace in the early morning before the tourists arrive later in the day. However, as other have said there won't be much open in the way of shops, boat tours don't begin operating until mid-morning and there are a couple of cultural and heritage museums which I think open at noon. Bus frequency is 15/20 mins and its a scenic and bumpy 50-minute ride over the mountains and along the south coast to Tai O; https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/routemap/13 There's also a scenic ferry ride operating between Tai O and Tung Chung that takes you around the headland at Tai O then along the north Lantau coastline, under the Hong Kong - Zhuhai - Macau Bridge and past the airport island to Tung Chung Development Pier, about 10 mins walk from Citygate. The 11-30am ferry from Tai O would get you back to Tung Chung just after midday; https://www.td.gov.hk/en/transport_in_hong_kong/public_transport/ferries/service_details/index.html#o07

subject: CNY/LUNAR Holidays 2024 advice
usertext: HI, I understand the CNY holidays at Hong Kong is from 10th Feb 2024 to 13th feb 2024. We are first time visitors to HK and would like to spend 5-7 days in HK from 16th February onwards, Would like to know if tourist attractions, places of interest, shops, transportation are still operating from 16th Feb onwards or are many will still be closed despite the end of public holidays? Please kindly advise. Thank you

subject: 1. Re: CNY/LUNAR Holidays 2024 advice
usertext: Everything will pretty much be open by the second day of the new year (except some banks and government offices).

subject: 3. Re: CNY/LUNAR Holidays 2024 advice
usertext: Most of the things will be open as usual, except for some local family-based shops. This may include some famous local restaurants (non-chained) but it depends. For attractions, all are open with some LNY decorations. Also look for some LNY theme activities like Lam Tsuen Wishing Festival.

subject: From Istanbul to Hong Kong?
usertext: Have someone travel to hong kong ? What airles you chose? Where dooked tickets?

subject: 1. Re: From Istanbul to Hong Kong?
usertext: Use one of the search engines to look for flights (Kayak, Google Flights, etc). Book directly with the airline. Don't use a third party agent.

subject: 2. Re: From Istanbul to Hong Kong?
usertext: Turkish Airlines has non-stop flights from Istanbul to Hong Kong. This is the flight I would book, directly with Turkish Airlines if the fare is affordable for you. There are also multiple airlines that have 1 stop flights for cheaper fares but at considerably longer flight times and you would need to confirm there are no issues (such as transit visas required) with transits in the cities/countries where you change planes.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Last day ideas
usertext: When I fly home to the UK my flight doesn't leave until midnight but I'll have to check out of my hotel. I was reading some other posts about going to city gate and wondered if there was some way to store my luggage in Citygate and spend the afternoon shopping before heading to the airport. Comments or other suggestions would be appreciated.

subject: 1. Re: Last day ideas
usertext: There are luggage lockers at Citygate Mall: https://www.citygateoutlets.com.hk/en/visit/mall-services/

subject: 2. Re: Last day ideas
usertext: Most hotels are happy to store your luggage for the day, so you can check out in the morning, enjoy the day, and after dinner collect your luggage and head out to the airport (your choice of bus, train or taxi).

subject: 3. Re: Last day ideas
usertext: Unless you really love outlet shopping, spending most of the day at Citygate might not be a great idea. Of course, you can use the day to take the cable car to Ngong Ping and visit the Buddha and Po Lin Monastery. If you give Lantau a full day, you can also bus to Tai O. With mainland visitors back in HK, locker availability cannot be guaranteed on weekends and holidays. The airport does offer luggage storage as a back up plan. The alternative is to visit Lantau on a day some time during your trip. On your last day, as wvmarle said, leave your bags (if staying at a proper place) at your hotel and then just spend the day in the city.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Last day ideas
usertext: Thankyou all for your kind answers. All lovely suggestions but I've been to HK numerous times and done all the normal tourist things hence thinking I would just leave the hotel and work my way nearer to the airport. I do enjoy shopping it's what I'm coming for really. I will see if the hotel will give me a late checkout before making any plans.

subject: 5. Re: Last day ideas
usertext: Just leave your luggage with the concierge and head into Mongkok on the MTR or bus. Shop yourself silly then head on back. It's not that long.

subject: Hong Kong cruise port to airport for 11.10am flight
usertext: Good afternoon We disembark a cruise at 07.30am and wondered whether it was realistic to get to the airport for a flight out of HK for 11.10am to Cebu Philippines? Otherwise it will have to be the 19.30pm flight, a long time to hang around the airport?

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong cruise port to airport for 11.10am flight
usertext: There are two cruise terminals in HK: Ocean Terminal and Kai Tak Cruise Terminal. The the answer may depend on which one. I am aware that there have been issues with big cruise ships disembarking thousands of people at Kai Tak and there simply not being enough transport infrastructure to move them onward quickly.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong cruise port to airport for 11.10am flight
usertext: From Kai Tak it's maybe an hour on the taxi, from Ocean Terminal 40 mins. So if you're really off the ship at 7:30 there will be no issue being at the airport on time. I have no idea on the current taxi situation at Kai Tak. There were problems at the start, but shortly BC it was usually fine. The problem is the disembarking time: you have to clear immigration and that sometimes causes delays, so I wouldn't rely on that 7:30 time. If it's delayed to say 9 you are in trouble already catching that 11:10 flight.

subject: HK to macau
usertext: Can I take taxi from HK To Macau?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: HK to macau
usertext: No, taxis are not permitted to operate outside Hong Kong boundaries. You can take ferry or Sky Shuttle helicopter from HK Macau Ferry Terminal in Sheung Wan on HK Island or ferry from China Ferry Terminal in Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon or shuttle bus from Hong Kong Port across the Hong Kong - Zhuhai - Macau Bridge or cross-boundary coach or cross-boundary hire car; https://www.td.gov.hk/en/transport_in_hong_kong/land_based_cross_boundary_transport/enquiries_on_cross_boundary_hire_car_service/index.html#hzmb%20enquiry Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: HK to macau
usertext: Can you guide from where to take bus or ferry to Macau from Wan chai?

subject: 3. Re: HK to macau
usertext: RE: "Can you guide from where to take bus or ferry to Macau from Wan chai?" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = #2, TravelSidd: From Wan Chai, it is easier and faster to use ferry to go to Macau. Simply use the Wan Chai MTR Station, take the MTR Island Line to Sheung Wan Station (the 3rd stop towards Kennedy Town). Follow the signs to use Exit D (Macau Ferry Terminal). That's where the ferries depart to Macau. 2 operators: Turbojet and Cotaijet. Take Turbojet (to sail to Macau (Outer Harbour)) if you are going to Macau old districts and center. Take Cotaijet if you are going to Cotai areas using the Macau Taipa Terminal. Match their ferry schedules. MTR Map: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/images/services/MTR_routemap_510.jpg Turbojet schedule: https://www.turbojet.com.hk/en/routing-sailing-schedule/hong-kong-macau/sailing-schedule-fares.aspx Cotaijet schedule: https://www.cotaiwaterjet.com/ferry-schedule/hongkong-macau-taipa.html

usertext: Three hi-jacks of the same thread in two days! Avoid confusion, start your own thread (after using the search function of course, as travel to Macau is discussed time and again here).

subject: 7. Re: HK to macau
usertext: Indeed, WVM. One poster from a few weeks ago said outright "I am hijacking this thread!". It is a new sport. #4, TravelSidd: "how to travel internally in Macau say from old district to Cotai?" Basically 3 ways. #1) Take the Macau public bus. Many bus routes cover that. Use Google Map to do a search with "Public Transportation", from where to where, you can get some good leads. You may want to cross-check with the Macau bus operators' websites for the route details (they are not that good): Sample Google Map search, you can just change the end points for your need. Also the time-of-day may come to play on available bus routes. You need to specify the Macau's local time converted to your own timezone in India. Link: https://goo.gl/maps/1bjRhTBgrVPhpaX36 TRANSMAC - Transportes Urbanos de Macau, S.A.R.L.: Link: http://www.tcm.com.mo/web/EV/ TCM - Sociedade de Transportes Colectivos de Macau, S.A.: Link: https://www.transmac.com.mo/en/routes-services/routes/ = = = = = #2) Use Macau taxi. From point to point. They are not that expensive. = = = = = #3) There are a few casino-hotel to casino-hotel shuttle buses (free to ride).
