subject: 1. Re: Where to stay in HK if we going to Disneyland.
usertext: It's easy to get on MTR to get to Disney. Look for hotels in Tsim Sha Tsui (Kowloon). No need to stay near Disney.

subject: 2. Re: Where to stay in HK if we going to Disneyland.
usertext: Travelling to HK Disneyland is super easy by MTR. Since you are only visiting 2 days, If you want a full Disney experience, you can book a Disney hotel, we loved staying in the Disney official hotels. But it goes both ways, you can stay in a Disneyland hotel and easily travel out for the day to see the sights of HK. You would have many more affordable choices in Hotels in Kowloon. Hope you have a great time in HK and Disneyland!

subject: 3. Re: Where to stay in HK if we going to Disneyland.
usertext: Base on "2 days and 3 nights. ", I think you will be leaving at the morning on the third day If you have more budget, of course you could stay in Disney Hotel (usually around 2500-3000HKD) If you are less budget, you could choose hotel in Tung Chung, (maybe around 800-1200) Tung chung is near disney and airport both Then you could go back to hotel faster after disneyland, and go to airport directly by 10 min on the morning.

subject: 4. Re: Where to stay in HK if we going to Disneyland.
usertext: Tung Chung is only marginally closer to Disney than Tsim Sha Tsui - 10, maybe 15 mins difference when travelling by taxi. Not worth changing hotels for. If indeed Disney on day 2 and leaving on day 3 in the morning, a Disney hotel for the last night may be a good choice if you're sufficiently into Disney.

subject: 5. Re: Where to stay in HK if we going to Disneyland.
usertext: I dont think it is necessary to travel by taxi , going from Tung Chung to Disney by metro is only 10 min and cost around 10HKD, while to Tsim sha Tsui is around 30-40 min.

subject: 6. Re: Where to stay in HK if we going to Disneyland.
usertext: There's no need to stay at Disneyland unless you want the Disneyland feel 24/7. You can stay anywhere in HK and get to Disneyland when it opens. But if you want to have pyjama parties with the characters, then disneyland it is.

subject: 7. Re: Where to stay in HK if we going to Disneyland.
usertext: @Cyrus Wong MTR says the travel time Disneyland Resort to Tung Chung is 16 mins; to E-TST or Mongkok it's 35 min. So 19 mins difference. Not worth moving hotels for (which easily takes a few hours all in all).

subject: 2. Re: Airport hotels
usertext: Based on your description the hotels in Tung Chung (such as Novotel Citygate) come to mind. Otherwise, pick a hotel somewhere in Mongkok or Yaumatei. More choice, maybe cheaper. Just a little more travel (half an hour or so each way) but in that area you'll be completely spoilt for choice when it comes to restaurants.

subject: 3. Re: Airport hotels
usertext: You don't need to be near the airport for that evening. Anywhere is connected good enough for your trip to Disney in the morning. But if you must, Silveri or Novotel at Citygate would do just fine

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Hong Kong Chinese New Year 2024 Advice
usertext: Hello all. I'm considering visiting Hong Kong next February and I'm aware that a visit will fall on around Chinese New Year. Just wanted to ask if visiting DURING Chinese New Year is a good idea or if I should perhaps wait until the celebration is over before going? Any help would be appreciated

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Chinese New Year 2024 Advice
usertext: Well, it depends. CNY is mostly a family holiday. There are activities for tourists such as the flower market prior to NY day, or going to temple after NY day. NY day will be pretty quiet.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Chinese New Year 2024 Advice
usertext: Here is my advice: If you are into Chinese culture, and really want to have a glimpse of what Chinese New Year is like, go during that week for the festivity atmosphere. If you don't really care, then go after. During the 3 day holidays, many stores/shops may be closed. Because of the holiday, transportation is likely more crowded and local tourist spots are likely extra crowded. Temples will be jam-packed. Many can use the time-off to do some outdoor hikes.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong Chinese New Year 2024 Advice
usertext: It depends on what you want to see. If you expect to see somthing very traditional, my advice is better go somewhere else. Taiwan and Malaysia are better choices. I don't know what other people think. To me, Chinese new year is just time for a lot of good food and a public holiday.

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong Chinese New Year 2024 Advice
usertext: The period in the run-up to the new year is easily as festive as the day itself, if not more so - during the first two days of the new year especially (less so the following days) I've always found the atmosphere on the streets rather dead. Most celebrations are with the family at home. The week or so before you start to see decorations appearing in shops and temples, and there are the bustling flower markets (albeit toned down badly since 2020 as the previously popular political items have been banned in the name of national security).

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong Chinese New Year 2024 Advice
usertext: It's true that many shops would be closed at least for CNY Day 1, particularly those family run businesses or sole proprietors, but nowadays many shops would open from Day 2 or 3. It's also correct that taking public transport may be more hectic during these days when HKers go around visiting, in particular more difficult to catch a taxi. As others mentioned, the pros would be there're some different things to see such as flower markets around that time. Depends on your preference then.

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong Chinese New Year 2024 Advice
usertext: Expect CNY day 1 to be very quiet. There will still be some places open for shopping and dining. Overall, on CNY day itself, it's best to look into attractions that are operating on that day to give you something to do. For example, you can go hiking or visit the Peak.

subject: 7. Re: Hong Kong Chinese New Year 2024 Advice
usertext: It is great year to attend the Chinese New Year 2024, because it is the year of Dragon. I am sure there is a great fire works on Lunar new year 2sec day. It is 3 days to celebrate of Chinese New Year. The shopping mall might close, but there are restaurant are open and a lot activity you can do or seeing sight. the temples are pack of people, but the 1 Lunar New year, you must going to Sha-Tin to see the horse race. It will pack of a lot a people, but you will have the experience of your life time. I hope this will help you. I am going too.

subject: 8. Re: Hong Kong Chinese New Year 2024 Advice

subject: Hong Kong visit in June 2023
usertext: Hey I am planning to visit hong kong and macau with kids in June 2023. As per the Google search, June is a rainy season in Hong Kong. Can anyone let me know if it is good time to visit with kids? How about rains and typhoons in June?

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong visit in June 2023
usertext: All the climate information you could want for HK is here from the HK Observatory: https://www.weather.gov.hk/en/cis/climahk.htm June is hot, humid, the month with the most rainfall, and at the beginning of the typhoon season. It rains, on average, on 20 days in June.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong visit in June 2023
usertext: Ok..Thanks for the information

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong visit in June 2023
usertext: That it rains on a specific day, doesn't mean it's raining all day. Rain tends to come in bursts that season. Note that the wettest and sunniest months in Hong Kong more or less fully overlap... as do the driest and cloudiest months.

subject: 10. Re: Affordable Restaurants
usertext: You don't need to eat at Cafe de Coral if the budget is $200/person. You certainly won't get near the luxury places or order market price seafood. However, basic dishes at mid range Chinese restaurants should be ok. Note that proper sit-down Chinese restaurants add a tea charge, condiments charge, and 10% service charge. You need to add 15-20% to the food cost on the menu when ordering. Smaller eateries usually don't levy such fees. They can be very good as well.

subject: 1. Re: Is Disney explorer lodge worth staying at?
usertext: To many people it's obviously worth it to stay there, to me personally not. I can't answer the question of whether it'd be worth it for you, that's for you to answer. Other than the Disney park itself, there's nothing else near those hotels, and they're pretty inconveniently located for anything but that Disney park. Disney provides the entertainment - see the hotel website for details on this. Whether it's worth staying depends on how much you like Disney. You may also read the reviews from other travellers on a.o. this website, to learn about their experience.

subject: Island hoping in HK
usertext: I would like to go island hopping in HK. Which top 2 places will be best for sightseeing?

subject: 1. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: Both Hong Kong and Lantau are islands, but I suppose you don't mean those two. The most popular ones are Lamma and Cheung Chau.

subject: 2. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: Both Lamma and Cheung Chau are popular. They are both small island with trails you can walk around, and restaurants where you can have some good meals. But it would not be the "island hoping" that you may be thinking of. Ferry services are all to/from Central Pier, like a star. There is no direct service between these 2 islands. Typically doing an excursion to one of these islands, walk around, have a meal, then ride the ferry back to Central (next to Sheung Wan) is already almost a day journey. I would not recommend doing both islands on the same day. If you have only one day to do this during your stay, you may want to pick one.

subject: 3. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: I like Peng Chau a bit more than sister island Cheung Chau listed above, mostly because it is a bit smaller so you can do the walk around the island in less time. Both make for nice 1/2 day visits. Lamma is also nice...

subject: 4. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: "Ferry services are all to/from Central Pier, like a star." That's not entirely true. There's also the Inter-Islands Ferry which goes backwards and forwards between Peng Chau, Mui Wo, Chi Ma Wan and Cheung Chau https://www.sunferry.com.hk/en/route-and-fare/timetable?route=inter-islands And also various kaitos from various places to islands including Po Toi, Tap Mun, Tung Ping Chau, Tung Lung, Kat O, etc https://www.td.gov.hk/en/transport_in_hong_kong/public_transport/ferries/kaito_services_map/service_details/index.html

subject: 5. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: I usually take my friends to Lamma. Yung Shue Wan, get loaded, then over the hill to Sok Kwu Wan for lobster, fish, crab and beers. With some white wine too. And some fried rice. And Choi sum. And fruit for dessert. And then get the ferry back to Central. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: It depends on what you want to do for your "island hopping." If getting loaded and eating seafood is what you fancy, then Lamma and Cheung Chau are it. But if the weather is nice and you fancy a day on the water, then look at the Kaito schedules (link posted by HK Ga Yau above) from Ma Liu Shui to the abandoned (and partially restored) Hakka village at Lai Chi Wo (Google for more info). The ferry ride (once a day on Sat Sun and public holidays -- leaves Ma Liu Shui at 9 am and spends 90 minutes going through some of HK's most gorgeous scenery, past the HK Geopark formations, through relatively unspoiled waters to green villages by the sea -- gives you a vision of what the entire New Territories must have been like, 100 years ago. You have to spent 4-5 hours at Lai Chi Wo (bring a picnic lunch) and then the returning ferry departs at 3:30 pm . A less time-consuming alternative which would still be beautiful would be just to take the boat ride from Ma Liu Shui around the Hoi Ha peninsula to Tap Mun (Grass Island). The boat leaves at 8:30 every day of the week. You can then just stay on the boat until it docks at Wong Shek Pier, in the middle of the Sai Kung Country Park, and then get the KMB bus from the Pier to Sai Kung Town. That takes about 2 hours. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: Thank youall!

subject: 8. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: Any recommendation to which seafood restaurant in sko kwu wan? Is there bicycle rental, instead of walking? Tks.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 9. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: I'm not aware of any bicycle rental places in Sok Kwu Wan. There is a bicycle rental shop alongside the main Yung Shue Wan - Sok Kwu Wan path across the island on the outskirts of Yung Shue Wan. Hoi Nam Bicycle Shop is at 37 Sha Po Old Village assuming its still there ( the Google Street View image is from 2013 but it was there at the end of 2019). It also doubles up as a grocery store; https://goo.gl/maps/jHgu6cFwmxDzd2Jj8

subject: 10. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: Lamma is not a good place for a cycling trip (the locals do it - to get home from the piers). Nor is Cheung Chau, which has quite some bike rental shops - there it's just some cycling back and forth along the waterfront, just as entertainment, and then only if you like to deal with massive crowds of unaware pedestrians. The Ma Liu Shui - Tap Mun - Wong Shek ferry is great. Take the early morning one to Tap Mun, enjoy the island for a couple of hours (there are a few restaurants), then later take the ferry from there to Wong Shek for a bus to Sai Kung, or of course back to Ma Liu Shui (infrequent).

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 11. Re: Island hoping in HK
usertext: Agree with the comments about the Ma Liu Shui - Tap Mun - Wong Shek kaito. It gives an opportunity to see a side of HK that most tourists don't get to see and even if you just stay on board all the way to Wong Shek its worth it for a very scenic 2-hour ride costing only HK$20 on weekdays, HK$30 on weekends and public holidays. Take MTR East Rail to University Station, about 10 mins walk from the pier at Ma Liu Shui Ferry Pier. Best enjoyed on a good day weather-wise and on a weekday outside holiday periods when there'll probably be only a handful of passengers on board until 90 minutes into the journey when the ferry reaches Tap Mun. There's an open section of at the rear of the lower deck where you can get close to the water. Wong Shek has a BBQ site and family trails and buses run to Sai Kung until 22-30; https://www.flickr.com/gp/hongkongviews/810KSp4ecM

subject: Hongkong Disneyland

subject: 4. Re: Hongkong Disneyland
usertext: Shops are all located inside of the entrance gates (you need to pay admission to get to them) except for a couple of Disney shops at Disney Explorer's Lodge Hotel and Hong Kong Disneyland Hotel, of which the latter is closest to the entrance; https://www.hongkongdisneyland.com/shops/#/sort=alpha/ There was a Disney store at the airport but that appears to be no longer there since Terminal 2 closed.

subject: 5. Re: Hongkong Disneyland
usertext: There is a Disneyland store in Terminal 1 airside.

subject: 6. Re: Hongkong Disneyland
usertext: It really depends on what you want to do there. The park is smaller than the US versions, 1 day would be enough to just walk around. We recently went for 2 days because we have kid with us. Apr 6 Thursday it was crowded and queues for rides take 20mins minimum, a lot more for popular rides. We went back Apr 10 Monday and there is virtually no queue, most popular rides are 5mins queue at most. If you want to queue for meet & greet with the characters, thats another chunk of your time there as some people would stay with the characters for 3-5mins.

subject: 1. Re: Hotel info please.
usertext: The Regal Airport Hotel is the closest to the airport, there's a covered foot bridge connecting to the hotel from the airport arrival hall so you basically just walk there with your lugggage trolley. I think it's quite acceptable for a one night stay. from there you could get to Disney Hotel by taxi. See what other travellers have more tips for you.

subject: 2. Re: Hotel info please.
usertext: The Regal Airport has the advantage that it is walkable from the airport. But there's nothing else around there, The Auberge has nothing to commend it - it's in a residential enclave and there's nothing much else around. Apart from the Regal Airport, the other options would be the 3 or 4 hotels in Tung Chung. You can get to these quickly and cheaply from the airport either by taxi or by bus (10 minute ride). And if you do want to go out and walk around on the Monday evening at least there are a few restaurants, shops, etc. And from Tung Chung you can simply get the MTR (subway) to Disneyland. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Hotel info please.
usertext: Novotel Citygate is probably the best option on balance? There is also a Marriott on the grounds of the airport but you need to take a shuttle between the hotel and the terminal.

subject: 4. Re: Hotel info please.
usertext: Disneyland in HK has MTR (subway) service to the door. It's very convenience and cheap. That means you don't need to stay at the Disney Discoverers Lodge. Disneyland HK is not that big and not as crowded compare to Disneyland in CA or Disney World in FL. Therefore, one day you can pretty much see everything there. I would stay at a hotel in the Mongkok area to enjoy Hong Kong and take the MTR to Disneyland for one day.

subject: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: I am looking to fly MEL-HKG (arriving at 7 am) and then HKG-CAN but there is a short 1 hour layover in Hong Kong. I am worried if the first flight is delayed and I miss the connection, the next flight to Guangzhou is not until later that night. If this were to happen, I would prefer to catch the bullet train to Guangzhou rather than wait half a day for the next flight. If I miss the second flight, can I collect my checked luggage at Hong Kong Airport or will it go all the way through to Guangzhou?

subject: 1. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: Same ticket? If yes, one hour gives you plenty of time normally.

subject: 2. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: As far as I know, there are far fewer flights between North America and mainland China. It might take you more time to reach your destination.

subject: 3. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: >>> If I miss the second flight, can I collect my checked luggage at Hong Kong Airport or will it go all the way through to Guangzhou? Considering you have only one hour in Hong Kong I assume this itinerary is a single ticket and your luggage tagged through to Guangzhou (as otherwise you have no chance of making the connection to begin with). You have to ask your airline on whether you will be able to collect your luggage in Hong Kong in that situation (my gut feeling is "no" but then I'm not an airline or airport representative).

subject: 4. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: Yes, one ticket with Cathay Pacific. I will try to contact them.

subject: 5. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: Your luggage tag will have MEL-HKG-CAN. So, no, you cannot retrieve your luggage at HKG. What you can do is to ask the airline if you can take the train without your luggage then go to CAN to get the luggage later that day. But CAN airport is pretty far from the city. So, even better if they would bring your luggage to your hotel in Guangzhou. I know this may be a lot to ask but you're talking about in the event your flight from MEL-HKG is delayed. That mean they should accommodate you.

subject: 6. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: My guess is that if the connection is missed Cathay might put you (and your luggage) on one of the coaches that run from the airport to Guangzhou. But my expectation is that you will make the connection - that HKG-CAN flight serves only as an onward flight for connecting traffic, so it will probably be held (for a while at least) if an inbound flight with connecting passengers is delayed.

subject: 7. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: >>>What you can do is to ask the airline if you can take the train without your luggage then go to CAN to get the luggage later that day.<<< I can guarantee you this will not work. No luggage without a passenger can be loaded onto the airplane. This has been a safety rule since the late 80s. The exception would be if the luggage transfer process gets delayed, and that your bags may be loaded onto a later flight and catch up with you. However, your bags will not fly if you're not flying. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 9. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: It doesn't always work that way. Not in HKG, but at a US port, we once experienced a flight delay after check-in so we were put onto a later flight. They said our bags would follow us onto the same plane. Upon arrival, we found out our bags departed with our original flight so it was laying near another carroussel. Also, when an airline miss loading your bag on your original flight, they will obviously be loaded without you on a subsequent flight. >>>I can guarantee you this will not work. No luggage without a passenger can be loaded onto the airplane. This has been a safety rule since the late 80s.

subject: 10. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: >>> I can guarantee you this will not work. No luggage without a passenger can be loaded onto the airplane. This has been a safety rule since the late 80s. I've a similar experience. In my case the luggage arrived the next day (that was pretty annoying having to come back to the airport, meaning I had to take a later train, and that route only had like three connections a day). What IS the rule: if luggage of a passenger has been loaded on the flight the passenger is supposed to be on, and the passenger is a no-show at the gate, the luggage will be unloaded.

subject: 11. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: Telling the agent you're taking the train to CAN will certainly get your luggage offloaded. Simple.

subject: 12. Re: Short connection in Hong Kong
usertext: In that situation the time OP would spend waiting for their luggage could be a bit of a deal breaker. I imagine it'll take hours for such a request to go through the system.

subject: Hong Kong airport to Guangzhou
usertext: What is the best way to go Guangzhou once arrived in the Hong Kong airport? I know I can go to Kowloon West and take the high speed train. But if there are bus service go directly from the airport to Guangzhou would be better.

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong airport to Guangzhou
usertext: There are bus companies selling tickets to various points in Guangzhou. You walk up and tell them where in Guangzhou you are going and buy your bus tickets. Buses depart from the airport.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong airport to Guangzhou
usertext: There are details of coach services from HKIA to Guangzhou here; http://www.cantontradefair.com/transportation/hongkong_airport-guangzhou-coach.aspx HKIA website also has an itinerary planner (somewhat hidden away) for coach services from the airport to the mainland although when I selected various dates for all service providers to Guangzhou only the Eternal East services appear which operate via Shenzhen Bay Control Point every 30 minutes from 7-00 to 19-00 then a final daily coach at 20-30. Journey time is indicated as 4 hours and fare is HK$250; https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/mainland-connection/mainland-coaches/itinerary-planner-to-mainland-china.page#step1 However, as TSS says, you can walk up to the ticket counters at the Mainland/Macao Transportation in the airport arrival hall and buy tickets on the spot.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong airport to Guangzhou
usertext: Thank you guys!

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong airport to Guangzhou
usertext: I think what's "best" depends on your overall journey. i.e. your more precise target destination in Guangzhou. Guangzhou is a big city. If someone asked you the best way to go to Atlanta, you would have asked more precisely in Atlanta they want to go too. The cross-border buses are departing from the airport. But there is a border to cross. It is the border crossing procedure that can get confusing - and you are on your own. The drop off points in Guangzhou are few. The bus drivers just drop you off at whatever drop off point you choose. You then need to figure out how to get from that bus drop off to your hotel or whatever place you want to go (typically by taxi). You should pre-plan which bus route to take and where to get off, with consideration paid to whether it is easy to get a taxi from there. If you have the budget, you can hire some cross-border private car service. AE Express train to Kowloon MTR Station, then take a High Speed Train from West Kowloon Station to Guangzhou is the most comfortable when you are riding the trains. But the end-to-end connections can be a bit of a headache. #1) There is a 12-minute walk from Kowloon MTR Station to West Kowloon Station. See this video (time mark "0:23": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_4n0KyQ3Ldc&ab_channel=MTRHongKong #2) More importantly, High-Speed Rail Stations are far apart. They are designed for high-speed intercity service, not local metro. You have only 2 choices for Guangzhou: A) Gangzhou South Railway Station, which is in Foshan. You would need to make another connection from Guangzhou South Railway Station to Guangzhou via the Guangzhou Metro (see subway map here): https://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/guangdong/guangzhou-subway.gif The metro ride will take another hour. (So much for "high speed") Or take a taxi. B) Guangzhou North Railway Station, which is further north of Guangzhou near the Baiyun Airport. Again you would need to connect to Guangzhou Metro (backtrack south, doesn't make sense), or a taxi. Which one is closer to where you want to go - again, depends on where you want to go. Highspeed rail doesn't go to the center of Guangzhou. I think it is because the city is old and big, and hard to build the highspeed railway track. Or for other reasons, I don't know. The Through Train serves between Hong Kong (Hung Hum Station) and Guangzhou East, and Guangzhou ("main") Railway Station. They are closer to the center of Guangzhou. But you would need to take transportation to Hung Hom Station in Hong Kong. (A21 airport bus - from Airport to Hung Hom.) The Airport Express train doesn't go there directly.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong airport to Guangzhou
usertext: Since High Speed Rail services to Guangzhou resumed in March some services run through to Guangzhou East although not all the journey is on high speed track and the journey from West Kowloon takes about 98 minutes; https://www.highspeed.mtr.com.hk/res/pdf/short-haul-train-timetable.pdf The Inter-City Through Train from Hung Hom has been suspended since January 2020 and although not yet officially confirmed, reports indicate it is unlikely to resume. https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/transport/article/3206984/1-1/2-hour-train-trip-guangzhou-high-speed-hong-kong-lawmakers-question-new-lines-slow-service-empty

Maybe they have retrofitted some of the old tracks, or that high-speed train cars are backward compatible with old tracks - only in lower speed. Sorry my advice in #5 is partially wrong. Apologies. Guangzhou East is convenient to go to many parts of "inner" Guangzhou City - as the city is quite wide spread. At any rate, the "best" way depends on the end-point of travel. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question

I booked an appointment online to renew the ID in June 2023 as part of the Territory-wide Smart Identity Card Replacement Exercise. My question is: will they take your old ID during this process? I believe it will take 7 working days before I receive the new ID. I have a short Macau trip planned during this waiting period and it just occurred to me... If they take my old ID, I may not be able to enter Macau or re-enter Hong Kong. I have contacted @immd.gov.hk but they only respond with copy and paste messages from their FAQs page. If anyone can share their renewal process, that would help me a lot. Thank you! Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: Last time I had to renew my card I'm quite sure they didn't take the old one until I got the new one (but that's been quite a few years). Wouldn't make much sense either as by law you're obliged to carry your HKID card at all times.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: They don't keep your card if it's simply an update to the new Smart card with no change of particulars. If your circumstances have changed (e.g RoA changed to RTL) then I believe they would take the card, but would give you a temporary paper ID with your new details. As I understand it, in no case are you left without some form of HKID.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: Last time I renewed they gave me a temporary paper copy and took away my old card. I didn't realize that I could've asked for expedited processing. So a friend had to pick it up for me, as I had to fly out.

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: How long did it take without expedited processing for the new card to become available? And thank you all for answering my questions! It definitely put me at ease. I will also ask during my appointment just in case.

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: Correction: from https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/about-us/pledge.html#e The new card should be available in 7 working days after application.

subject: 7. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: You can always use your passport to enter Macau and return to Hong Kong like normal tourists as well.

subject: 8. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question

subject: 9. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: My sister renewed hers this year in January and she said they gave her a photocopy of her old HKID so that she can use it to exit HK. So I think they do take your old one and get someone else to collect your new one on your behalf. That's what I'm planning on doing when I go to HK next month. I have a different question that I hope others may answer - when pre-filling the form when booking the appointment, do I say I claimed British citizenship? My current HKID says Permanent and the Right to Abode, but I am a British citizen by birth, so I'm really confused about how to complete this section. But then if I do say that, this may mean I will lose the Permanent status on the card???

subject: 10. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: On what basis do you have the Right of Abode in the first place? Here are the possibilities: https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/roa/eligible.html

subject: 11. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: >>> You mean US passport? Good to know! I'm planning to enter Macau through the new HZMB bridge. Yes, your US passport will do fine for Macau. However: if you enter HK using your HKID card, you should also leave HK (which you do when going to Macau) with your HKID card. @helen: your situation depends on your nationality status. Do you also have Chinese nationality? Then you will have the three stars on your HKID as well and you will keep your status for life (and you will be able to get a "home return permit"). If only British nationality, you will lose RoA status if you have not visited Hong Kong in three consecutive years. You don't lose the permanent resident status, but it will be Right to Land - the only differences I know are no more right to vote in local elections, and less favourable conditions when buying property in HK.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 12. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: My mother is Chinese and was born in HK.

subject: 13. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: Sorry - who was born in HK? You or your mother?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 14. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: My mother was born in HK - I was born in the UK, and therefore I automatically became a British citizen.

subject: 15. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: That's only true if you were born before 1983 - being born in the UK since then does not confer the right of British citizenship unless one of your parents is a British Citizen at the time of your birth. Anyway, there's a long and detailed discussion of this subject at: https://www.sm128c.com/hk/ Whether you are regarded as a Chinese national by the HK authorities may be an issue. But for the form, I think what they are asking is whether you have declared a change of nationality previously to HK Immigration. As discussed on the page above: "HK Chinese citizens holding foreign citizenship may make a "declaration of change of nationality" to have their foreign citizenship recognized in China. But by doing so, they will no longer be a Chinese citizen, though they will become be eligible for consular protection in China. Making a change of nationality makes it no longer possible to hold a HKSAR passport, and it may also affect the right of abode status in Hong Kong depending on one's residency history in Hong Kong." So this is all very complicated. Do you have *** on your HKID card, which is a good (but not perfect) indicator of whether China/HK regards you as a Chinese National?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 16. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: No, I don't have *** - it just has the letters AO under my DOB.

subject: 17. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: OK, so HK does not regard you as a Chinese citizen (as I understand it, if you are a Chinese citizen you will have ***, but having them is not a guarantee that you are). That being so, generally speaking you lose the Right of Abode if you don't visit HK every 36 months, and get downgraded to Right to Land (which is more or less the same thing, but you can't vote (which is meaningless anyway these days) and property taxes are higher). But for those of Chinese descent born outside HK to a HK parent pre-1997 things get a bit murky, and I've never seen a clear definition of what happens in all cases. To answer your original question, since HK apparently doesn't regard you as a Chinese citizen anyway, I see no harm in telling them what your citizenship is, but also no value in doing it. You haven't changed your nationality - you have been (only) British since birth.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

To cut the story short, my mother was born in HK and therefore has *** along with the letters AZ on her HKID naturally. She took me to HK in 1997 when I was just 6 years old during the handover so that's probably why I don't have the ***? Hopefully I will have a better answer when I ask the immigration officer on the day.

subject: 19. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: It's just the complicated situation HK is in - issuing passports and residency permits, without having its own nationality - you can't become a Hong Kong national. The current tensions between HK and the UK over their BNO immigration scheme is not helping, either. HK is dead set on making it as hard as possible for anyone linked to the UK that way. In your case, you have to contact the HK immigration department on your situation. I've heard before that around that period many mistakes have been made, with people not having the right to the three stars getting them, and the other way around. I'm still not clear on how you got your permanent HKID card to begin with. Was it through birth? Or after living in HK for a period of time after 1997? Your post #18 suggests that 1997 at 6yo was the first time you went to HK. Did you have a permanent HKID already at that time? If so that must have been a *** version obtained at birth.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 20. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: That's what I'm really confused about because my HKID says Permanent but then does not have *** only says AO on the card under my DOB - is this correct? I'm not sure how it all worked out like this. I remember going to HK every year I think since birth even in 1997 when the handover started.

subject: 21. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: Yes - that's what mine says too having got PR by living here for 7 years. The thing that indicates Permanent is the A on the front and the "Holder has the right of abode" on the back. The *** is nothing to do with residency status; it indicates that you are eligible for a Home Return Permit (which roughly, but not exactly, corresponds with being a Chinese citizen). However you got it, the worst that can happen is that you could get downgraded to Right To Land if you didn't come to HK for a period of 36 months. Right To Land is for life (or until the Commies fundamentally change the whole HK identity/immigration regime, which they could do any time of course). With RTL you can still live and work in HK without restriction.

subject: 23. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: I really suggest you to call immigration department with all your questions. Not e-mail (for the copy/paste answers) but pick up the phone and call them. Keep in mind the 8 hour time difference between UK and HK when checking their office hours.

subject: 24. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: If you want to change your name then you only need an appointment to do that because, obviously, the new card will automatically be a new SmartID. Presumably you have read https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/hkid/amend_hkid.html And the FAQ says that documents needed are on a case-by-case basis. My wife changed her name (to mine) on marriage and that was a very straightforward process which required the original marriage certificate. (Although since we were married in HK that was on their system anyway.) My expectation is that you would need the original Deed Poll if you changed your name for reasons other than to your partner's name on marriage (in which case your marriage/civil partnership certificate). But if you also have original UK Passports showing your old and new names I guess that might suffice. As wvmarle says, the safest route would be to contact them. Alternatively, make your application by mail some weeks in advance of coming to HK to give them time to repsond with details of what original documents you should bring when attending to get the new card.

subject: 25. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question

subject: 27. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question
usertext: Since you have a "China ID card" (I assume what most people call a "Home Return Permit") then you are regarded (or at least were regarded) as a Chinese national. I understand that for new issues of those permits it is necessary also to have a Hong Kong passport, but I am not sure if that applies to renewals (with a gap). Once you have Right of Abode in HK there is no way (unless and until the Commies change the whole HK nationality/immigration regime, which is a matter of when, not if) that you would lose the right to live and work freely in Hong Kong, even if you get downgraded to Right To Land, which is for life under the current rules.

subject: 28. Re: Hong Kong Smart ID Renewal Process Question

subject: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: Hi, We are arriving in Hong Kong at 22:40 on Saturday 29th April and fly out again at 23:00 the following day. I've read quite a bit about both the Airport Express and the A12 bus - some people think it's missing out to go by the train because of missing the views of the bridges at night - comments welcome - however I'm also looking for speed and convenience regarding tickets for the next day. So my questions are: 1) Is the 1 day Hong Kong Express return valid for 1 day by calendar date or for 24 hrs (which we need)? What is the most suitable ticket for someone arriving and leaving just before midnight on 2 consecutive days? 2) Is there a ticket that combines the Airport Express with all public transport including trams and Star Ferry? 3) We're staying at Harbour Plaza North Point so would change at Central or get the A12 bus directly. What is the time difference between the two including a change with luggage? 4) Could we leave our luggage at the airport and just have hand luggage for the 24 hrs? Also, what are the queues like to go up Victoria Peak on a Sunday? I've read answers to some of these but they are from so many years ago that I wanted to ask again. Thank you so much.

subject: 1. Re: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: PS - "We" is 2 people - me and my husband, both relatively able-bodied but with a dislike of faff (queuing, waiting, too many options...). At least one of us has ADHD so the not waiting is fairly important to marital bliss.

subject: 2. Re: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: 1) unsure, have to check the MTR web site. 2) there's the Octopus card, a stored value card that you can use to pay for all public transport. For one day it's maybe a bit overkill but on the other hand it's very convenient to have. 3) AE + change + taxi: about 25 + 5 + 15 = 45 mins (note: taxi is HKD cash only). A12: 60-75 mins. Better views - of the bridges and the city, no need to change, significantly cheaper. Third option: taxi all the way: about 45 mins (cost slightly more than AE + taxi for two people) 4) there's a paid left luggage service at the airport. Of course you can also leave your luggage at the hotel until you're ready to had out to the airport.

subject: 3. Re: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: Brilliant, thank you. The 1 day vs 24 hr question isn't clear on the website but thanks so much for all the rest. I'm thinking your option 3 (taxi) sounds genius for minimal faffage. Can I pay for a taxi by card? And do we tip in Hong Kong (and if so, will I need to get cash on arrival?)

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: The Same Day Airport Express Return Ticket is valid on date of issue only. The Round Trip Ticket is valid for 30 days from date of issue; https://www.mtr.com.hk/archive/en/services/19_AEL_Service_Guide_C_E_all.pdf There are promotional fares with Group Tickets for 2 or more people travelling together on Airport Express single journeys; https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/tickets/promotions_4persons.html

subject: 5. Re: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: Very many thanks! "Valid on the date" is the clarity I'd missed - much appreciated.

subject: 6. Re: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: Taxis are HKD cash only (you can get cash from an ATM at the airport), no tipping normally. That's a very US specific thing. Your ride should cost you around $350 incl tolls and luggage fees. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: Very many thanks :-)

subject: 8. Re: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: I always tip my taxi driver. Sometimes I just round up (i.e. $45 fare, no change needed.). I would just pay 10%. Believe me, people in HK tip too, sometimes even more so than Americans.

subject: 9. Re: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: "Believe me, people in HK tip too, sometimes even more so than Americans." Only Americans and tourists in my experience. Just pay the fare. The driver will round the change down to the next dollar. The vast majority of taxis are cash only, although some take other payment methods. I guess you could try waiting at the Airport taxi line in the hope that one of those came along. Note though that the views from the upper deck of the A12 are much better than those from a taxi due to roadside barriers etc. Having said that, on the current schedule the last departure of the A12 is at 23:45 (previous is 22:45, which you won't get obviously). So you'd be getting to the hotel around 1am. At that time of night I think I'd just get a taxi all the way. And if I were planning this, I wouldn't be staying in North Point at all unless for some reason you want to be in North Point the next day. I'd get a room at the Regal Airport hotel which you can walk to from arrivals. Get to bed at a reasonable time. Leave your bags there with the concierge when you check out in the morning, and pick them up when you come back to the airport in the evening.

subject: 10. Re: A12 bus or Airport Express for 24hr layover in Hong Kong
usertext: Most locals won't tip a taxi driver unnecessarily. The drivers don't expect any either. As to payment, you should expect them to accept cash only.

We'll be staying in HK on the way back so it's more about filling in time than seeing the sights. Where is worth spending a few hours but not too far from the airport? Maybe a large shopping centre or market? How long to allow for getting out of the airport and checking back in? Where to find bag storagw so we're not lugging cases around? Taxi, bus or Uber? If it matters we're arriving on Cathay and leaving on HK Express. Imagine they are in different terminals?

subject: 1. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: There is bag storage at the airport. "Maybe a large shopping centre or market? " Here are the possibilities: 1. Citygate Outlet Mall at Tung Chung, which is closest to the airport. Lots of shops (they don't open until 11 am) and restaurants and movie theatres. You can take a taxi there. 2. Element Mall. You can take the Airport Express Train to the Kowloon station. The mall is just above this station. Again, shops, restaurants, the usual mall. 3. IFC Mall. Airport Express to the Central Station. Shops, restaurants, so on, so on. You can walk out and take in some fresh air on the harbour front. Or even take a ride on the Star Ferry to the Kowloon side. Be aware that HK shopping malls do not provide a lot of free resting places. So you can't just sit down anywhere and rest. You'll have to be in a restaurant. McDonalds would allow you to sit for a long time.

subject: 2. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: Thanks so much for those suggestions. I'll do some more research and see which might work best for us.

subject: 3. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: Quick question about getting to Citygate... as it doesn't look to be on the public transport routes, I'm guessing taxi is the best option? Are taxi drivers going to turn down such a short fare, or give us a hard time about it? Or do they have to accept the fare?

subject: 4. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: There's only one terminal currently at HK Airport. And sadly, despite HKExpress being a subsidiary of Cathay, they don't take checked through bags. So yes you need to use the baggage storage at the airport. I believe that if, BTW, you had booked the HK Express flight on the same schedule as your inbound Cathay flight using the CX codeshare that exists on all HK Express flights then I believe you would have been able to check your bags through. There is a bus service from HK Airport to Tung Chung centre (i.e. Citygate) every 5-10 minutes via route S1 at a cost of HK$3.5. Payable in cash (no change given) or Octopus card. If you're coming back for a longer stay then get an Octopus card each and use that. https://mobile.bravobus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=S1&dsmode=1&l=1 Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: You can take bus S1 or S64 from the airport to Citygate. Since you will be spending time in HK on the way back, you can buy an Octopus even for this layover and keep it until you return. That way, you can use the card to swipe to pay for buses and buy items at convenience stores and supermarkets. I don't feel that Citygate itself can last you 8 hours though. The amount of time you have is enough to go take Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car to the Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery. As to Elements, it's a relatively high end shopping mall. There isn't anything too interesting there though. If you are interested in museums, the Palace Museum and the M+ Museum are located near Elements/Kowloon station. Cathay arrives at Terminal 1 (all arrivals go to T1) and HK Express have check-in counters at Terminal 1 as well. Bag storage is inside the same building to/from both locations within a few minutes on foot. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: So far, there is only 1 terminal in operation in Hong Kong, plus a couple of extension concourses within it. You won't be "changing terminal". I think you need to figure at least 2 hours of overhead getting out/in. So you don't have 8 hours. 6 hours to use at best. But your layover time does not work well for shopping. Hong Kong is a late-rising city. Shops open until late at night, thus most don't open at least until 10 am or even 11 am. You are arriving Hong Kong at 7 am, a good portion of your layover time is gone. You can shop as in "browse and look". But if you have things you intend to purchase, you may want to mention what those are as there are all kinds of shopping malls in Hong Kong. Those mentioned that are convenient to reach from the airport may not be what you have in mind. I think the most practical thing to do, and we had made similar suggestions in the past to short-layover many times, is to take the Airport Express train to Hong Kong Station. Have a meal/drink at the rooftop of IFC Mall (connected to Hong Kong Station), or the nearby Central Piers. You have close-up view of the Victoria Harbour. As the shops begin to open, you can browse the IFC Mall, perhaps more as a sight-seeing event. Then comes time, ride the Airport Express train back to the airport. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: Thank you for that useful advice. Our flight arrives at 7:30am so I would not expect to be on a bus or train until around 8:30 based on other airport experiences. Yes, the 10-11am opening times are something I'd not factored into my thinking. We're not out to buy anything in particular (luggage limits on HK Express and other forward flights won't allow much anyway), just to kill time creatively. Our HKE flight is at 4:25 so I'm guessing we'll need to be back at the airport by 2:00 or 2:30 latest. That's my 6 hour window. I think HK Station and the harbour sounds good. A day room at a hotel might sound good too after a red eye flight from Australia!

subject: 8. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: Do we only need one Octopus card for both of us? Or do we need one each?

subject: 9. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: You'll need an Octopus card for each person.

subject: 10. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: >>> Our HKE flight is at 4:25 so I'm guessing we'll need to be back at the airport by 2:00 or 2:30 latest. If you're checked in already (no luggage to check in) arriving 45-60 mins before departure is fine. If you still need to check in your luggage 2:30 is a good target time (the check-in typically closes some 45 mins before departure; ask the airline for their exact cut-off time as it may varies a bit).

subject: 11. Re: What to do for 8 hours in HK?
usertext: HK Express's website specifies that check-in opend 3 hours before departure and closes 1 hour before departure. https://www.hkexpress.com/en-hk/your-trips/check-in/airport-check-in/ Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Disneyland
usertext: Can I purchase disney tickets on the day or a day before my planned visit? Also, I just saw in the Disney App that I need to make park reservations? Does this still apply?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Disneyland
usertext: The website also insists advance reservations must be made so Disneyland still appears to operating in covid mode. I believe the government imposed strict conditions for its reopening with reduced capacity and the terms and conditions state "without prior reservation or when full capacity is reached, you will be refused entry into the Park"; https://www.hongkongdisneyland.com/static/resources/html/reservation/park-visit/terms-and-conditions/index.html

subject: 2. Re: Disneyland
usertext: Plan well ahead. The park is closed Tuesday and Thursday and they have a 3 level pricing system for the other days based on how busy they are. You can save some money if you visit Monday or Wednesday. I bought the tickets the day before and just showed the QR code on arrival. When you buy tickets you get some nice bonuses and discounts so be sure to use them. Download the Disneyland HK app on your phone, will help with navigation, and the schedule for the day.

subject: Budget food near mini hotel causeway bay
usertext: Hi.. any idea for cheap / budget food near Mini Hotel Causeway bay? Especially I am looking for place to buy some breakfast. Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Budget food near mini hotel causeway bay
usertext: For breakfast, it's easy to find a store front bakery near your hotel. There are 3 or 4 within walking distance. For budget food, I recommend Cafe de Coral for tourists who don't speak Cantonese. Again, 3 or 4 of them within walking distance. There are other options, such as restaurants with roast meat hanging at the window. But if you don't read Chinese or speak Cantonese, service can be abrupt.

subject: 2. Re: Budget food near mini hotel causeway bay
usertext: Check out http://www.openrice.com There are likely dozens if not hundreds of restaurants within 10 mins walk from your hotel.

subject: 3. Re: Budget food near mini hotel causeway bay
usertext: It depends on how budget you want to go. Local bakeries charge about $10-$13 per item. If you buy a milk tea at the same time, it'll probably double the cost. Small shops that offer takeaway items (sandwiches or streetfood style items) cost $20-$30 with a drink. At fast food chains like Cafe de Coral and Fairwood, the average cost is $30-$40 for a set with a drink. Local HK style tea cafes average a few dollars more. McDonald's and similar western fast food operations charge between $20-$35.

subject: 4. Re: Budget food near mini hotel causeway bay
usertext: At Canal Rd there is a Tong Kee Bao Dim. They sell buns. Around that area at Canal Rd there is a wet market and some small local eateries. Prices there are relatively low in Causeway Bay. I just notice there is a famous local This This Rice (sega konomi) in Causeway Bay as well lol. Google  to see the address and how it looks like.

subject: 5. Re: Budget food near mini hotel causeway bay
usertext: (and there are others similar) is a chain that specializes in takeaway boxed rice with Chinese toppings. For just $30, you get two choices. For $35, you get three. Extra is charged for fish and some other combinations. The value is certainly very good though it's not something I would want to eat on a daily basis. Note that they are not open for breakfast. Tong Kee is a chain that specialize in various steamed buns. It also serves some rice dishes. It's a budget place as well. Quality is reflected by the price overall but it doesn't mean the items are badly made.

subject: 6. Re: Budget food near mini hotel causeway bay
usertext: Yes I also notice this Bowrington Road Cooked Food Centre https://goo.gl/maps/ctYb8TBLxjSBMyYj6 have something like food canteen inside it. Really want to try local experience there, but it seems all the menu is written in Chinese. The shop keeper usually can speak English? Or they will rude to people who can not speak Chinese?

subject: 7. Re: Budget food near mini hotel causeway bay
usertext: You may also consider trying noodles. There are many noodle restaurants in the area; most of them are small in size. A bowl of noodles costs around HKD 35 Trust me, It is delicious. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 8. Re: Budget food near mini hotel causeway bay
usertext: Most such shopkeepers don't speak English, but sometimes you get lucky and you run into one who's fluent. As long as the menu is not handwritten, Google Translate will do a great job translating for you (point the camera to the menu and the translated text floats on top). Especially for the first few times, as you figure out how things work, you best avoid busy hours - particularly lunchtime which is roughly 12-2. Breakfast time is normally not that crowded. I've never had issues with staff being rude to me for not speaking Chinese (they love my minimal, broken Cantonese - most gweilos don't know any) but I can imagine that in busy times with customers lining up for a seat they're not all too happy with you taking a long time figuring out what to order or trying to get the message through to the waiter. Those $30 rice boxes are value for money. Little value for little money :-) An excellent and cheap way to get your stomach filled well. Portions tend to be generous, taste tends to be pretty OK.

subject: 9. Re: Budget food near mini hotel causeway bay
usertext: Your best bet is cafe de coral. Affordable and comfortable.

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong PAR without surname
usertext: So you have your name as Vinod Kumar Vinod Kumar on the PAR while in your passport your name is Vinod Kumar. That's likely to get you rejected as the two don't match, info in the PAR and on your passport must match exactly. A much smarter move would have been to add Vinod as given name and Kumar as surname so at least the two match, though that may still cause problems. For advice on how to deal with your situation contact the Hong Kong Immigration Department, see https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/contactus/index.html

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong PAR without surname
usertext: Per FAQ12 on the Immigration Dept website; "If there is no surname in English or given name in English in your passport, please leave the relevant field blank" https://webapp.es2.immd.gov.hk/applies2-client/static/faq/i-par-reg/en-US/i-par-reg-faq.html I would contact the immigration Dept as suggested by wvm for an opinion Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: Hong Kong PAR without surname
usertext: Your original post indicates you already have PAR but information does not match that in your passport. You can't apply for a new PAR until the current one has expired. What you seem to be asking is how to amend an existing PAR but there is no information on the Immigration Dept website as to whether this can be done. I think you need to do as already suggested and contact the Immigration Dept for advice otherwise you take a chance on being refused boarding or entry.

subject: 9. Re: Hong Kong PAR without surname
usertext: >>> But without surname PAR is showing error That appears to be an error by who-ever made that web site, nothing we can do about that. >>> kindly help what to mention instead of leaving that space blank . That's very much a question to ask the Immigration Department, i.e. the people in charge of the process, rather than a bunch of strangers who may or may not have more than cursory knowledge of the issue at hand and who may or may not be totally wrong in what they think the situation is, especially considering the potentially severe consequences of having your PAR rejected due to following the wrong suggestions from those strangers. Contact HK immigration department. Personally I'd give them a call rather than sending e-mail, now time is very much of the essence (you have barely two weeks before your scheduled trip). Edited: 1 year ago

Like Surname -NA Given name -Vinod kumar Will their be any problem in immigration, please let me know your suggestions , my travel date is on 30th april

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong PAR
usertext: Venod: Why did you remove your other thread? Have you read the replies there. There are some good suggestions, including emailing the HK Immigration Dept (with an email address on one of the replies). Have you done that? There is no need to post the same question again.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 24hours stop over in Hong Kong
usertext: Hello Guys, I am having 24hours stop over in HK before continuing my flight to Sydney, Australia. I am reaching HK around 9am 04 May and next flight is 9am 05 May and I will have a cabin bag and luggage bag (~25kg). This is my first time in HK and I know its very short time to explore this beautiful city, so wanted to get some ideas here on must things to do/visit in HK. Also, recommend me a decent place to stay for a night or any airport facility to leave the bags while I do tourism on that day/night. Appreciate your inputs. Thanks and have a nice week ahead :)

subject: 1. Re: 24hours stop over in Hong Kong
usertext: Bag storage at HKG airport: https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/passenger-guide/airport-facilities-services/baggage-storage Arriving at 9am, you can potentially visit NP360 cable car which starts at nearby Tung Chung. Service starts at 10am. You can go up to Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery. Other places to go include Tsim Sha Tsui promenade/Avenue of Stars. Tsim Sha Tsui area has a lot of the city vibe if you just want to see somewhere very busy. Ride the Peak Tram up to the Peak. If you go right before sunset, you can see the city with both day and night views. In between, the area around the pedestrian escalator starting just above Queen's Road Central up to Staunton Street gives you a mix of old and new with a wet market, traditional shops, modern cafes, murals and galleries. Then around Mong Kok, there are markets you can visit. Ladies Market sells mostly touristy cheap stuff so I am not sure whether you will find anything interesting. Just north is Fa Yuen St which is more practical (still cheap). In Yau Ma Tei, there is the Jade Market. Be sure to catch a Star Ferry ride at some point. Where to stay depends on your budget. Tsim Sha Tsui has a good selection of hotels across the spectrum.

subject: 2. Re: 24hours stop over in Hong Kong
usertext: For just one night I'd get a hotel either at the airport or in Tung Chung, thus enabling you to at least drop your bags for free with the concierge (or maybe get an early check-in). This also means a not too early start for your 9am flight the next day. Transport to Tung Chung and the airport is available until after midnight via the MTR / Airport Express if you decide to have a night on the town. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: 24hours stop over in Hong Kong
usertext: Not much time difference taking a hotel in the city proper, for that matter. Half an hour earlier departure the next day, that's it. I'd suggest to forego the Buddha this time; find a hotel in Kowloon (Monkok, Yaumatei, Tsim Sha Tsui - that general area). Taxi from airport to hotel, drop off bags, by then it's about noon and the city really comes to life. Shops are all open around that time. Star Ferry and The Peak are two of the basics that you should experience, plus some general wandering around just to take in the sights, the smells and the sounds. When it comes to your luggage: you may be able to check your bag right through, keeping just what you need for that one night in your carry-on. If no bags to check in you don't need to be at the airport that early - with check-in luggage about 90 mins before departure, without 45-60 mins is enough. Kowloon to airport is 35-40 mins on the taxi.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: 24hours stop over in Hong Kong
usertext: Thanks everyone for your great inputs :) Do you recommend Hong Kong Hop-On, Hop-Off Bus Tour instead of going to the above places on own? Appreciate any insights about such bus.

subject: 5. Re: 24hours stop over in Hong Kong
usertext: This is great information! Thanks for taking the time to provide such a thorough response.

subject: 6. Re: 24hours stop over in Hong Kong
usertext: I don't think you need the HOHO bus. Armed with an Octopus, it's very easy to get around town.

subject: 7. Re: 24hours stop over in Hong Kong
usertext: "Do you recommend Hong Kong Hop-On, Hop-Off Bus Tour instead of going to the above places on own?" If you can read maps and navigate public transport (for which there are excellent apps) then no. HK$200 for a day of hop-on/hop-off bus is vastly more expensive than seeing the same places by normal bus or MTR, and much less flexible with once per hour departures. The $39.80 per trip similarly. It seems to me that the only people who would get good value from the bus are HK residents over-60 who can use their "Joy You" cards to get $2 rides. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 8. Re: 24hours stop over in Hong Kong
usertext: MTR + walk is the faster, cheaper way of getting to/from those sites. The route of the HOHO bus includes some of the most congested areas of the city... I think the best use of that bus is if you want a quick and easy overview of some of the main tourist sites - they provide commentary so you know what you're looking at. No hopping on/off along the route, just ride it end to end. One of the best ways to experience the city I think is to just walk the streets. There's so much more to see than the sights themselves - the people, the shops, the buildings, etc.

subject: HK first visit which area?
usertext: Hi, I am visiting HK for the first time in May for 7 days. Can anyone recommend the best area to stay? I've just started planning and don't even know the common tourist sights,places yet,so any basic advice would be appreciated. Central seems to be mentioned often. I'd be looking for a 4 star type hotel. Single mature aged male. Thanks.

subject: 1. Re: HK first visit which area?
usertext: Causeway Bay, Tsim Sha Tsui are 2 areas I would be looking. Central would not be on my list.

subject: 2. Re: HK first visit which area?
usertext: The public transport system (primarily, as far as tourists are concerned at least, the subway system known as the MTR) is extremely efficient in Hong Kong, so you can get around easily. As a tourist I wouldn't stay in Central simply because of the prices being higher. For good 4-5* hotels look at those close to an MTR station between North Point and Admiralty on HK Island, or in Tsim Sha Tsui in Kowloon.

subject: 3. Re: HK first visit which area?
usertext: Popular areas for tourists are along an MTR line in Kowloon (TST, Jordan, Yau Ma Tai and Mongkok districts) and along the Island line on HK Island (NP, Causeway Bay, Sheung Wan). As mentioned in previous posts, you can stay in Admiralty and Central as well but hotels in those areas are mostly 4-5 star with some of the highest room rates in the city.

subject: 4. Re: HK first visit which area?
usertext: Tsim Sha Tsui. It's the centre of everything a visitor would want. And the iconic skyline for your photos.

subject: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: Hi there! What's mostly the weather like in Hong Kong in May and what outfits should a guy take and wear? Are jackets or coats a big NO?

subject: 1. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: Hong Kong is subtropical. May is already warm-hot. Day range is about 25'C to 30'C. Definitely no coat. A jacket is up to you but usually not needed. Except when you sit inside a restaurant where/when they blast the A/C.

subject: 2. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: You can review the upcoming weather on the Hong Kong Observatory around a week or so before you journey over. This will help you understand what to pack for your trip. http://www.hko.gov.hk/en/index.html

subject: 3. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: Are there people in Hong Kong who wears jackets or layer their clothes in the streets during the May months?

subject: 4. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: It is very possible to be 30+ degrees during the day from mid-May onward and there is always a good chance for heavy rains throughout the month so expect hot and at times muggy conditions. So perhaps bring a light rain jacket if you like. That is a common practice here but not coats or multiple thick layers as we are entering the hot summer months. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: Outside, it will be too warm/hot to make layering necessary. Indoors at some restaurants, malls and buses, the AC might be blasting cold air. If you are sensitive to sudden changes in temperature, then bring a light jacket. >>>Are there people in Hong Kong who wears jackets or layer their clothes in the streets during the May months?

subject: 6. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: I would bring some stylish outfits to suit your mood and the ambience of your selected restaurant. For cafe de coral, wear yellow.

subject: 8. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: I think it may depend on where you are from and what kind of temperature you are used to. A guy from Iceland will have different clothing needs than a guy from Thailand. It also depends on where you plan to spend most of your time - in air conditioned indoors or hot and humid outdoors.

subject: 9. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: Forget about wearing anything warm here until November.

subject: 10. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: Summer clothes + windbreaker or a very light waterproof jacket for rainy days and blasting aircon indoors.

subject: 11. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: Gonna be hot and sticky in May, a jacket and coat are overkill, although a rain jacket might come in handy!

subject: 12. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: >>> Forget about wearing anything warm here until November. Except when you want to go enjoy a movie or go to the theatre. That's when you need to break out the winter wardrobe to hopefully not be shivering at the end of the show... (it's why I rarely went to movies in Hong Kong, just too cold!)

subject: 13. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: Highly recommend to wear semi open toe type of sandles. It was hot and rainy when I was in HK at the end of April.

subject: 14. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: Not just movie theaters, but anywhere indoor can see the AC blasting arctic chill (and I am one who doesn't mind a good AC). Such places include shopping malls, restaurants and public buses. The one exception is MTR which always feel stuffy when it gets crowded. Bring a light jacket if you are sensitive to the cold. As to shoes, they don't have to be sandals. When I travel, I like wearing closed toe, waterproof shoes so my feet never get wet. In HK, shoes that can withstand some moisture (not necessarily 100% waterproof should be fine. When it rains, in most situations, you should be able to head indoors in a hurry.

subject: 15. Re: What outfits to bring when travelling to Hong Kong in May?
usertext: Short shirt with bermuda For ladies crop tees with shorts much better

subject: Travelling to hong kong with spouse
usertext: Hi, I am going to hong kong for a business trip. And i want to take my wife as well. Our PAR is cleared. But there is one problem, that the hotel booking is in my name only and for a single person. As it was done by my employer. I have mailed the hotel and they are okay to have my wife stay with me. But i am afraid that my wife does not have any hotel reservation in her name. So will that be a problem at the immigration. in her PAR she has written the address of my hotel. Please help. I fly on saturday.

subject: 1. Re: Travelling to hong kong with spouse
usertext: I don't think this will be a problem. Hotel bookings are rarely if ever actually checked. But then, you shouldn't rely on the answers of random strangers on the Internet in this kind of matters. Contact those in charge: https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/contactus/index.html

subject: 2. Re: Travelling to hong kong with spouse
usertext: None of us work with HK Immigration and can't speak on their behalf but I tend to agree that this won't be an issue for you. HK immigration, to my knowledge, they are mostly concerned that you have PAR, evidence of sufficient funds and outbound flights leaving HK. These are things I've heard that they sometimes ask for. It is much less heard of that they want particulars regarding hotel accommodations. Over the years, I'm not sure any of my family members who have come over to visit have ever been asked. If unsure, just print your communication with the hotel indicating that they are happy for you to have two guests in your room while you are there. If immigration asks you can show them that communication along with the hotel booking confirmation.

subject: 3. Re: Travelling to hong kong with spouse
usertext: Someone from India said he was refused entry as he did not make a hotel booking despite having PAR so it appears Immigration does check for hotel bookings (perhaps on a selective basis).

subject: 4. Re: Travelling to hong kong with spouse
usertext: Yes... They may check for your hotel bookings but not the particulars of the booking (i.e. how many people listed on the booking, number of nights booked vs. intended number of nights staying in HK). And sadly, a person from India said... doesn't go a long way in regard to knowing for certain why some from India are denied entry from time to time. HK immigration officers don't have to reveal why they sometimes decline entry and from what we understand they rarely if ever do. So it is all speculation at best. The good news is that hundreds of thousands of visitors from India with PAR are allowed in every year (pandemic lockdown aside) so it remains a rarity when it happens.

subject: 5. Re: Travelling to hong kong with spouse
usertext: >>HK immigration officers don't have to reveal why they sometimes decline entry and from what we understand they rarely if ever do. So it is all speculation at best. << Agree, so writing to Immigration may not help much either (after all, the decision is made by the officer on the ground rather than the one working in the back office). Nonetheless, it's a well known fact that some visitors will get scrutinised more in many countries (due to nationality, gender, age etc) so better to be prepared. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Travelling to hong kong with spouse
usertext: Anyway, this was the thread https://www.tripadvisor.com.sg/ShowTopic-g294211-i642-k14325240-Entry_in_China_after_entry_refused_in_hongkong-China.html

subject: 7. Re: Travelling to hong kong with spouse
usertext: Does any couple ever put both names on a hotel booking? I never have when I travel with my wife. I really don't think this will be an issue. If you have an email from the hotel confirming that they are fine with 2 people in the room then that must be sufficient in the unlikely event that HK Immigration start digging. And the most important thing is to be polite and respectful to the Immigration Officer. I have seen Indian men get this badly wrong, particularly if the Immigration Officer is a woman.

subject: 8. Re: Travelling to hong kong with spouse
usertext: No, i can't be rude to anyone in general. And they are also doing their job. If something goes wrong, i will only request and not blame them.

subject: 9. Re: Travelling to hong kong with spouse
usertext: Okay. Thank you very much. I have mailed hk immigration, but didn't get a reply yet. I will be flying tonight. Hope it goes fine.

subject: Hong Kong Airport Layover
usertext: The Island at the Hong Kong airport at 9:15 in the morning. I have a 6 1/2 hours lay over. - Can I visit the big Buddha and be back in time. In any other activities/attractions I can look at ?

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Airport Layover
usertext: 6 1/2 hours minus time needed at the airport means just over four hours left. That's a bare minimum to go see the Buddha - it's about an hour travel each way (taxi all the way, or taxi to Tung Chung and the cable car - line in the morning going up may be long, early afternoon going down there will be no line). Alternative: take the Airport Express to Hong Kong station; walk to the waterfront; take the Star Ferry across to Tsim Sha Tsui; see the skyline; find something to eat nearby; and the same way back.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Airport Layover
usertext: My opinion: This short layover, and you may have 4 ish hours to use, is too risky to use on visiting the Big Buddha. No matter what mode of transportation (taxi, bus, cable car), it will take at least 1 hour for transportation from airport to there, plus waiting time. If you assume taxi both ways, at the airport you are okay there probably will be blue taxi waiting, but when you are up at Ngong Ping, and there is no blue taxi around - there you have no good alternative to get back to the airport. Which makes it stressful. You may have 30 minutes to 1 hour max spending up there without having to worry about catching your flight. And if you miss your flight, then what? You need to think about the real "price" to pay if you miss it to evaluate if you want to take this one. If you are okay with it, no big deal, then go. Taking Airport Express train to Central is safer. Train rarely will be out of service. And even if that happens, you still can take taxi.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong Airport Layover
usertext: Yes makes sense . Thanks for the suggestion. Is there anything else close by that I can explore ? Was thinking maybe a quick trip to the City Gate outlet mall for shopping ? Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong Airport Layover
usertext: Citygate is not much closer (time wise) than the city. One is 10-15 mins on the bus, the other about 25 mins on the train. If you just want to do some shopping maybe Tsing Yi (the first stop on the Airport Express) is the more interesting mall. Nice waterfront promenade right outside of it, too. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong Airport Layover
usertext: I guess staying at the airport makes sense. Thanks a lot
