subject: Transit Visa for Indian passport
usertext: I will be transiting via the Hong Kong airport. Have a layover of about 6 1/2 hours both ways . Can I apply for a visa through PAR and exit from the airport and come back for the onward flight? Do I need a separate transit visa for the same? Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Transit Visa for Indian passport
usertext: If you have a PAR then you can be admitted for up to 14 days, so being in transit should not be a problem. You simply show the Immigration Officer the reservation for your onward flight. If you already have the boarding pass then so much the better, Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: There are 4 of us travelling ( 1 is only 5 yrs old), will it be more cost effective to ride the taxi or use airport expresss and mtr to go to the hotel?

subject: 2. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: Thank you for your response. Our hotel is Metropark Kowloon hotel.

subject: 3. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: That hotel is some700m walk from the nearest MTR station (Mongkok Station), which takes a few changes to get to by MTR. So AE+MTR is not a convenient option. Unfortunately also no good bus connection between that hotel and the airport, so taxi is your best option.

subject: 4. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: With 4 passengers and luggage, taxi is definitely the best option.

subject: 5. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: For this hotel, use a taxi.

subject: 6. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: Thank you! Would you say that this hotel is not conveniently located in general?

subject: 7. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: Metropark Kowloon Hotel is in a not-so-convenient location in Kowloon. The key to tour in Hong Kong conveniently is to pick a hotel that is close to a MTR station. Then you can go places much faster. From this hotel, you need to walk at least 10 minutes through crowded streets in Mong Kok. With crossing streets and fighting other pedestrians it can be 15 minutes. If you want the Metropark brand, the Metropark Mong Kok Hotel is much more convenient as it is in the same neighborhood but very close to Prince Edward MTR Station and if you take the Airport Bus A21, it drops right off the front door of this hotel. Note that this is likely a price difference, as convenience affects supplies and demands, and thus prices.

subject: 8. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: Frankly, a 15 min walk to an MTR station is not that much.

subject: 9. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: By Hong Kong standards, it's pretty far :-)

subject: 10. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: I feel like this is my obligation to point out options. If all things are equal, they may be delighted to shave off 20 minutes of walking overhead, at a minimum, everyday.

subject: 11. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: 15 minutes aren't far by absolute terms. However, in relative terms, there are so many choices that are within 5 minutes on foot that you can look into other places. Remember the extra 10 minutes per trip means at least 20 minutes per day, if not more. Let's say your hotel is close to a station, you are more likely to go back when you feel the need to nap, change, use the facilities, etc. Also, when it's really hot out (between May and early October), you will be glad your hotel is as conveniently located as possible.

subject: 12. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: I appreciate all your responses!

subject: 13. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: I would take taxi. Cost for 4 x airport express is more than a taxi.

subject: 15. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: Unfortunately there isn't much to see/do in the area around Metropark Kowloon Hotel as well. As such, if you are with a travel group who will be taken around Hong Kong that not really an issue but if travelling here on an individual basis, like HPFT's suggestion above, I'd look for a similar property and room rate closer to an MTR Station and in a more centralised area of the city.

subject: 16. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: Ladies Market and the heart of Mong Kok is roughly 10 minutes away on foot. Fa Yuen Street Market (less touristy) is just to the north a few minutes further. That's really all I can think of that's reasonably close.

subject: 17. Re: Airport Express or taxi
usertext: I was just there 3 days ago. Get the taxi. It's was around 270HKD to the airport from the hotel. Note the regular train needs at least 2 changes and if you are not familiar with their MRT it will cause you stress. The wall to the hotel from the closest station (blue line - Mong Kok EAST) is easy 10-15 minutes, but local maps are hard to orientate and it took me several minutes to just get my bearings after taking the correct MRT exit. Once checked in you can explore the area without your bags. The hotel has an hourly shuttle bus that takes you to past the blue MRT station and to the red line station (Mong Kok), which is perhaps 20 -25 minutes walk back to the hotel. If you need any info send me a message while it's fresh in my head. I stayed in the same hotel for a week. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Buying prepaid SIM cards for internet
usertext: Hi all, I'm travelling to Hong Kong, Macau and Shenzhen and am looking for a prepaid SIM card that allows internet in all 3 places. I will mainly be using it for Google Maps, social media, looking for restaurants and voice calls in Hong Kong only. I found 2 from CSL but I'm confused what the difference between them is because they both seem to work in all 3 locations. https://www.hkcsl.com/en/china-hk-macau-8-day-prepaid-sim-card/ https://www.hkcsl.com/en/china-hk-macau-8-day-roaming/ It seems the first one (non-roaming) includes more data. Or is it better if I get this local prepaid SIM and then add on the China and Macau roaming data pass? https://www.hkcsl.com/en/csl-local-prepaid-sim-card/ I know there is a new SIM registration law where you can only have a maximum amount of SIM cards under your name. If I revisit Hong Kong the following year, can I still re-use these SIM cards and just buy the add-on services on it? Also, I will be using my VPN service as well. Do you think that will be fine in China with this SIM card? How about with CMHK SIM cards? Thank you, any advice is appreciated! Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 1. Re: Buying prepaid SIM cards for internet
usertext: Get a Three HK card https://www.three.com.hk/prepaid/DIY/en/offer/travel if your phone support eSIM and do the Real Name Registration Process. You can use this card in Mainland, Hongkong and Macau. You can buy the 365 days package if you want and top if up next year to extend the card. You don't need a VPN go get access to foreign websites even in Mainland, but of course you can use one if you want.

subject: 2. Re: Buying prepaid SIM cards for internet
usertext: Thank you for the suggestion. Unfortunately my phone does not support eSIMs. :(

subject: 3. Re: Buying prepaid SIM cards for internet
usertext: Hello 179bwalada, I was wondering, which prepaid SIM card, if any, did you buy? Or which solution did you find for your needs? I'm currently looking for a similar deal: a prepaid HK SIM-card (data only, 20GB or so would do) which I could also use in Macau and mainland China (roaming), for about 2 weeks altogether. Any tips you are willing to share would be highly appreciated! Thanks in advance and best regards!

subject: 4. Re: Buying prepaid SIM cards for internet
usertext: Bear in mind that even if you can reach Google Maps on the Mainland, it's not updated and sometimes shows you positioned several hundred meters from your actual location. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: Buying prepaid SIM cards for internet
usertext: Yes, thanks for the heads-up, I realized that already while using it to choose my hotels... In any case, I need mobile Internet service mainly to be able to communicate on the go, not for Google Maps in particular, but yes, good to know.

subject: 6. Re: Buying prepaid SIM cards for internet
usertext: Hi Fred, While searching for SIM cards in Hong Kong, I was told there is not one card that works in all 3 places and even if there was, it will be super expensive. Instead, I got one prepaid card for HK only, and then a separate card that took care of both Macau and China. I believe it looked like this below (probably cheaper if you buy in HK). https://www.amazon.com/Greater-China-Unlimited-Macau-Taiwan/dp/B08BZ2DV2Z HOWEVER, I had issues with using it. I first visited Macau and had no problem using it there. However after relocating to China, I found that the card did not have service. I tried to connect to the China 5G network as per the instructions but it only showed me 3G options and even those kept disconnecting. I was in Shenzhen, a big city, so I believe 5G should've been available. I'm also not sure if these multi-country cards can only assign one phone number for one country and you're stuck with it? Luckily, my original SIM from the United States is from T-Mobile and my plan includes free international data at 2G speeds so I was able to survive from that. However, if you're planning to use China apps like Baidu Maps on 2G, it will be painfully slow. So my takeaway is that if it might be simpler to just buy 3 separate cards. Or if you can find a place that sells the pricier cards that works in 3 countries, just make sure to ask the seller how it works when you change location. These cards won't be available at convenience stores. Your best bet would be finding the phone company that sells it.

subject: 7. Re: Buying prepaid SIM cards for internet
usertext: 5G on the Chinese Mainland uses frequencies different from most other countries'. So unless you're sure your phone works on Chinese 5G, don't count on it.

subject: 8. Re: Buying prepaid SIM cards for internet
usertext: I've no idea about Baidu maps, but it is perfectly possible to use Google maps without mobile data. All you need to do is to have downloaded the relevant areas of the map to your phone in advance whilst connected to WiFi. In the Google Maps app just look for "Offline Maps" and follow the instructions.

subject: 9. Re: Buying prepaid SIM cards for internet
usertext: Hi 179bwalada, Thanks for your reply. Good information to have. I actually found some options here https://www.7-eleven.com.hk/en/service/prepaid-sim/for-travelling-to-china , but I don't know if this is up-to-date information or if you can simply walk into a 7-11 and get one of these... I hope someone reading this could shed some light! :-) Other than that, I think finding one for HK & Macau should be no problem, my main concern is finding one which also works in mainland China. Let's see... Thanks and regards.

subject: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: will taxis accept 4 passengers from airport to Marco Polo Hongkong hotel area? Are there van-type taxis at the airport?

subject: 1. Re: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: I think the majority of the Hong Kong taxi now are seated for 4 passengers. Whether it can actually carry all 4 passengers depends on how much luggage you have. Though the car may carry 4 passengers in the passenger cabin, the trunk is typically small and cannot accommodate all your luggage (especially if each of you have 2 check-in size big suitcases). There are some 5-passenger taxis. They are older and slightly bigger. Van taxi - I think I have heard of them but not many. ST can probably provide you all the statistics on the exact number of each type.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: >>>ST can probably provide you all the statistics on the exact number of each type. <<< Ha ha, only by wading through the transport dept figures. Toyota ceased production of its 5-door Comfort taxi (which I think comprised the entire taxi fleet the time) in 2008. Since September of that year almost all of the 17,000 or so new taxis licensed have been 4-passenger capacity out of fleet of about 18,000 so there are probably still about 1,000 5-passenger taxis comprising mostly the remaining old Toyota Comforts and I believe there are a few new 5-passenger taxis such as some Toyota Noah's operated by Diamond Cabs (primarily designed to accommodate wheelchairs). Jumbo Taxi operates a fleet of large capacity Ford Connect Transit 4-passenger taxis which it claims can carry up to 9 pieces of large luggage; http://jumbotaxihk.com/page1.html#

subject: 3. Re: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: I was just there. They have a type of taxi that looks like a mini van. It still only seats 4 but has a ramp in the back that can (I assume) accommodate a person in a wheelchair. Catch this specific taxi (not the sedan) and you can get 4 pax with 3-4 big luggage in no worries.

subject: 4. Re: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: I do see many taxis look like crossover/stationwagon type and they can hold more cargo. Also keep in mind Hong Kong taxi usually charge extra for luggage.

subject: 5. Re: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: Yes, I forgot to mention the luggage charge.. We had 1 large suitcase that the driver helped load but then I threw in our carry on bags (3 small back packs) into the back of the car and was charged 4 x $6 luggage fee. I assume that if my passengers simply carried their bags with them into the car I wouldn't have been charged..

subject: 6. Re: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: We usually keep the smaller items with us in the seating area and don't get charged. >>>I assume that if my passengers simply carried their bags with them into the car I wouldn't have been charged..

subject: 7. Re: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: Strictly the rule is $6 for each item in the boot/trunk, and $6 item for each item bigger than 140cm (length + width + height) that is carried in the passenger compartment. https://www.td.gov.hk/en/transport_in_hong_kong/public_transport/taxi/taxi_fare_of_hong_kong/index.html

subject: 8. Re: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: Official government rules and street-level practices are two different things. Some taxi drivers are opportunists. They take advantage of foreign visitors who do not know the rules (and charge them per item pointing to the rules regardless where the extra items are placed). One time I rode in a taxi where the driver was very eager, and very persuasive that I put everything in the trunk (our backpacks, carry-ons, and small items that we usually squeeze in to the passenger cabin - just the two of us riding). And of course a surprise bill at the end. Well... not much money, but no chance to dispute. Wiser next time.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 9. Re: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: The government was asked for a response about taxi drivers ripping off tourists in the Legco earlier this week; https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202304/26/P2023042600253.htm

subject: 10. Re: HK Taxi for 4 pax
usertext: There clearly is a returning issue of some taxi drivers trying to take advantage of tourists, particularly late at night, and particularly around LKF and Wanchai, which has been more or less absent for the past 3 years. HappyFeet's example isn't really a scam - it's just the taxi driver taking advantage of the visitor's ignorance of the taxi fare rules. He didn't do anything illegal. The problem is taxis refusing fares, taking roundabout routes and, in extreme cases, refusing to turn on the meter. To be fair we regularly read stories of police activity to catch some of these drivers; the link from SolentTraveller provides numbers of complaints received but is, sadly, silent on the number of prosecutions resulting. Taxi drivers work on the assumption that a visitor here for a few days is not going to want to spend hours doing police paperwork for the sake of maybe HK$300, There are some HK expat residents who really don't help the situation by "negotiating" with taxi drivers through the passenger side window before getting in (in the way that one tells the destination to a London cab). This is just wrong. If the taxi has its For Hire light on then just get in and then tell the driver where to go. I often need to get a taxi at around midnight from near the top of LKF. My approach is very simple: flag down a taxi with its light on, get in, and then tell my destination in Cantonese (I don't really speak the language, but a few words marks you as a resident not a tourist as far as the driver is concerned).

subject: Things to do at the Hong Kong airport ( 7.5 hrs layover )
usertext: Have a long lay over of about 7 1/2 hours. Any recommendations on what all can I do? Have read about the theatre inside which place movie all day -anything else?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Things to do at the Hong Kong airport ( 7.5 hrs layover )
usertext: There's no cinema at the airport at the moment. The IMAX cinema which was located in Terminal 2 closed a few years ago before that terminal was demolished for redevelopment. There are details of airport facilities at this link; https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/relax-fun/ If you are an Indian passport holder and have successful Pre-Arrival Registration (PAR) there should be no need for you to remain airside, you should be able to enter HK and, if you wish, leave the airport. The Airport Express train gets you from the airport to Hong Kong Station, just a short walk from Victoria Harbour, in only 25 minutes.

subject: 2024 Fireworks where to watch ? Harbor cruise
usertext: Hi There Can you share any advice on what are the best options to book a vantage point for 2024 fireworks in HK harbor ? Family 2 adults 2 teenagers . Are we best to book a hotel with views or a Harbour cruise or can you book vantage points ? Any thoughts on this would be magic and appreciated

subject: 1. Re: 2024 Fireworks where to watch ? Harbor cruise
usertext: We have seen several fireworks from Kowloon side in TST. You can probably see them from the walkway or get a room ($$$$) with harbor view. Cruise probably less crowded than walkway and less expensive than the hotel. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: 2024 Fireworks where to watch ? Harbor cruise
usertext: Assuming things return to normal then be aware that a large section of the inner harbour is closed to all boats except the barges holding the fireworks. Viewing vessels are coralled at each end of the blocked section and tend to get an "end on" view of the display. It seems to me that the display is best enjoyed from the harbourfront on either side. But getting outdoor space close to the waterfront is hard (particularly on the TST side). People set up shop several hours beforehand in the prime spots. You can also book restaurants overlooking the harbour, but these are rather expensive and I'm not convinced that fireworks are that great when viewed from indoors. You also run the risk of having a very very over-priced dinner if the fireworks are cancelled due to the weather.

subject: 3. Re: 2024 Fireworks where to watch ? Harbor cruise
usertext: And lastly, fingers crossed that the big fireworks shows return this year. They have been cancelled continuously for all major holidays autumn 2019. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: 2024 Fireworks where to watch ? Harbor cruise
usertext: *assuming the fireworks resume this year* I would suggest booking a hotel room with harbor view from the Kowloon side (a few nice one are Ritz, Rosewood etc) as you can see bigger pictures with all the fireworks from all 3 boats (plus the fireworks match with the music which will be playing on the tv, it will make the whole experience more wow). I have never see the HK fireworks from a cruise on the harbor, but I would assume it would be spectacular & impressive watching it so close.

subject: 5. Re: 2024 Fireworks where to watch ? Harbor cruise
usertext: "I have never see the HK fireworks from a cruise on the harbor, but I would assume it would be spectacular & impressive watching it so close." I believe that to be a false assumption. You are closer to the firework barges on the Admiralty or TST waterfronts than you are allowed to be in a boat. The area closed to boats during the display is normally defined as: "The area bounded on the east by a line joining Hung Hom Railway Station Cargo Pier and the breakwater at Kellet Island of the Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club, and on the west by a line joining the southwest extremity of the Ocean Terminal and the Central Government Pier."

subject: 6. Re: 2024 Fireworks where to watch ? Harbor cruise
usertext: I think the best experience is to view the fireworks from the waterfront - the promenade at TST or (imho second best) Central or Admiralty. Come well in advance (an hour or more) if you want to get reasonably close to the waterfront, and be prepared to be stuck in the crowds for easily half an hour after the fireworks as it takes time for the crowds to disperse. Of course do check closer to the date whether it goes ahead. Covid is past, but you never know, maybe the fireworks display poses some kind of possible risk to China's national security and just the idea of that possibility may be enough to cancel the event. By the way, I am assuming you're talking about the Chinese New Year fireworks rather than the 1 Jan new year count down fireworks which has always been much smaller, if it happens at all. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Looking for travel buddy or meetup in Hong Kong May 2023
usertext: Hi, I will be solo traveling in Hong Kong from May 12-15. I would love to meet up with anyone else traveling the same dates, or with locals who could show me around and provide recommendations!

subject: 1. Re: Looking for travel buddy or meetup in Hong Kong May 2023
usertext: For local events where you can meet other people you may check out http://www.meetup.com

subject: 2. Re: Looking for travel buddy or meetup in Hong Kong May 2023
usertext: Send me a pm. I can potentially show you around a bit.

subject: 2. Re: What to do near Disneyland?
usertext: If by near you mean Lantau Island, you can look into attractions such as the Big Buddha, Ngong Ping Village, Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car, Tai O historic fishing village, perhaps some time at Discovery Bay.

subject: 3. Re: What to do near Disneyland?
usertext: Well, there are indeed (mildly) interesting things to see on Lantau Island, but the realities of transportation (slow buses or taxis to get around on Lantau, compared to fast MTR connection downtown) mean that it is almost surely much more convenient to just go downtown, visit the shopping malls or explore the Mid-Levels escalator and Sheung Wan, and find a bite to eat. For first-timers in HK, these activities offer much more of interest than the artificial creations (cable car, village, Buddha statue) on Lantau. By the way, in terms of nice parks, the waterfront park along the Central and Wanchai harbourfront is a great option -- it is pedestrian-friendly and the views are unbeatable. You can just exit from the MTR Hong Kong Station and easily walk from there. Assuming, of course, that the weather is okay.

subject: 4. Re: What to do near Disneyland?
usertext: The Citygate Outlet mall is a short MTR ride from Disney. Lots of shops and restaurants.

subject: 5. Re: What to do near Disneyland?
usertext: Geographically near doesn't mean convenient to get to - Disney to DB is easily 45 mins or more. Hong Kong Island and Kowloon may be closer, time wise. Disney hotel to Big Buddha will take well over an hour, even if taking taxi all the way. The ferry from Central used to run in the morning to Disney, and a couple hours later back to Central. Obviously not meant as transport as such, more as a scenic leisure trip. For your one non-Disney day, take the MTR to the city for exploring, returning sometime in the evening. There's basically nothing out at Disney other than Disney.

subject: 6. Re: What to do near Disneyland?
usertext: Other than NP360 and Po Lin Monastery, I don't think other attractions on Lantau Island are worthy. Tai O is a small fishing village but I didn't find it very interesting. It does depend on whether you have gone to similar villages anywhere in the world. Discovery Bay is decent but it's not really a visitor destination. You can go there, walk around and chill out at a waterfront restaurant. Citygate is just a smallish outlet mall. My suggestion is you just take the MTR to anywhere you find interesting in the city.

subject: 7. Re: What to do near Disneyland?
usertext: Visit the inspiration lake located within Disney resort area for free. It a wonderful spot for picnic. There's a convenience store and u can pay for a paddling boat ride. Clean toilets available. Also consider taking a bus to Discovery Bay from Sunday bay station (one station next to Disney mtr) . At discovery bay , u can chill at the beach, have a drink at the bar and go for a short hike

subject: 8. Re: What to do near Disneyland?
usertext: The station is called Sunny Bay.

subject: Airport check in/ security clearance times
usertext: Hi all - how long should we allow prior to flight to comfortably check in luggage and clear security/ customs for an international flight? Conscious of the fact that these post covid days clearance times are slower than pre covid days and I want to make sure we're not at risk of missing our flight and at the same time not at risk of my wife divorcing me because I made her and our child get to the airport 4 hrs prior to our flight

subject: 1. Re: Airport check in/ security clearance times
usertext: Generally speaking we like to be at the airport 2-2.5 hours before our international flights to play it safe. Sometimes we arrive 3 hours early because of bus schedules, you end up with a lot of waiting time when this happens. Since the city started reopening last Autumn, we have made a handful of international flights out of HK. Time spent at airline check-in unpredictable and difficult to gauge, could be just a few minutes or 30+ if you find a long queue in front of you with lots of luggage. However, HK immigration and security clearance into the restricted area of the airport remains light years faster than what I've had to endure in European airports for our return flights. 5-10 minutes max to to clear immigration and security and you'll be freely walking around in the restricted air side of the airport. Allow another 5-15 minutes to reach your gate depending on how far away it is.

subject: 3. Re: Airport check in/ security clearance times
usertext: 2 hours should be fine with 2.5 hours allowing a very relaxed journey.

subject: 4. Re: Airport check in/ security clearance times
usertext: Thanks all :)

subject: 5. Re: Airport check in/ security clearance times
usertext: 2 hrs would be my comfort zone. Be aware that HK residents can exit immigration much faster than foreign passport holders. But still, HKG is very efficient. In prior years, the US (and probably other countries) require extra security questioning at the check in counter, and an extra security check at the gate. So that adds more time to the process. Also, all flights in and out of HKG are international flights (including flights to Mainland China). There is no domestic flight.

subject: 6. Re: Airport check in/ security clearance times
usertext: Agree. That's why as a visitor, I suggest 2 hours. 1.5 hours should be enough on most days but I have seen some occasional lines for foreigners. Also, since Hong Kong and Kowloon stations no longer offer in-town check-in services, everyone has to check-in at the airport. Airline counters could see longer lines. >>>2 hrs would be my comfort zone. Be aware that HK residents can exit immigration much faster than foreign passport holders.

subject: 7. Re: Airport check in/ security clearance times
usertext: "Also, since Hong Kong and Kowloon stations no longer offer in-town check-in services, everyone has to check-in at the airport. Airline counters could see longer lines." Onw of my favorite things about HK was bag drop off at the train to the airport in the city with Cathay Pacific. Will miss that great service.

subject: 8. Re: Airport check in/ security clearance times
usertext: The In-town check-in service suspension is temporary. It should return at some, hopefully not too distant future date, unlike the free hotel shuttle bus service has permanently ceased operation.

subject: 9. Re: Airport check in/ security clearance times
usertext: Note that at HKIA Smart Departure is available for passport holders age 11 and over for most countries, including Australia, which allows use of self-service e-gates for departure instead of having to use manned immigration counters. The landing slip you receive on arrival indicates eligibility to use Smart Departure; https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/echannel_visitors.html#sd

subject: Experiencing Hong Kong-ZhuHai-Macau Bridge (HZMB) from HK?
usertext: Hello, my mum would like to eperience the Hong Kong-ZhuHai-Macau Bridge (HZMB) but our time in HK is very limited (6days) so we don't have time to visit Macau or Zhuhai. We do not need visa to enter Macau. Would it possible to traverse the HZMB and immediately make return trip back (understanding we would need to clear customs in HK and Macau). I am aware that there may be ferries that may do some sightseeing tours but she gets seasick very easily so want to avoid that if possible as it won't be appealing for her as she may fall ill. Any suggestions how to help make it possible for my mum to experience the HZHB would be much appreciated!

subject: 1. Re: Experiencing Hong Kong-ZhuHai-Macau Bridge (HZMB) from HK?
usertext: RE: "Would it possible to traverse the HZMB and immediately make return trip back (understanding we would need to clear customs in HK and Macau)." = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Sure. You would need to clear immigration (Exit Hong Kong) at the Hong Kong Port facility for sure. Then you purchase the bus tickets. Then you board the cross-border shuttle bus to go to Macau riding on the HMZ Bridge. The shuttle bus acts much like a ferry. You have exited Hong Kong at that point. You can make the journey from one "country" to another, en-route. You haven't quite gotten there yet. On the other side of the bridge, the shuttle bus will stop at the Macau Port facility's bus terminus. Everybody gets off. Now this is where I am not entirely sure... I don't think you need to clear the immigration/custom on the Macau side. Ask the workers. There should be a door or a way or something that you can enter the ticketing lobby to purchase a bus to ride back to Hong Kong without entering Macau (not going through the Macau immigration). It happens... someone may have gotten an emergency phone call while on the bus and has to change the travel plan to head back to Hong Kong immediately. It can happen to all of us. And there are travelers who have visa or admitability issues with their passport/visa status that they are denied entering Macau. Thus I don't think you need to enter Macau (and then immediately exit Macau). If that is not possible, well you enter Macau and go right back in to the same building to "ext Macau" and to ride the bus back to Hong Kong. Just take a little longer. Our Macau expert, my friend BradJill, can comment on this when he comes back from commercial breaks.  Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Experiencing Hong Kong-ZhuHai-Macau Bridge (HZMB) from HK?
usertext: My personal opinion is that the bridge is nothing worth to "experience". It is a long bridge, nothing special in terms of view on a bus. At Tai O in HK, there is some viewing points where one can have better view of the HZMB bridge. Or South Perimeter Road on the HK airport island. Or Tai O to Tuen Mun ferry https://www.fortuneferry.com.hk/en Note that the view depends strongly on weather. You can check some youtube videos to see how it might look like (https://youtu.be/hGwIN6IroWs Tai O - Tuen Mun ferry on a so so day)

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Experiencing Hong Kong-ZhuHai-Macau Bridge (HZMB) from HK?
usertext: What you see from the Tai O to Tuen Mun ferry and the South Perimeter Road is actually the link road, not the bridge itself. The first 12km after leaving HK Port is along the HK link road to an artificial island outside the HK boundary where the road dives into 6.7km tunnel. The bridge begins on emerging from the tunnel and ends about 13km from Macau and Zhuhai Ports. The overall journey from port to port is about 55km of which 23km is bridge and the remainder is link roads and tunnel. The "golden bus" shuttle buses are both single-deck and double-deck. The views from the upper deck of the double-deck buses, particularly the front seats are infinitely better than from the single-deck bus. Normally you're expected to take whichever bus comes along first but the queue supervisor at the HK Port bus terminus may allow you to hang back for the next double-decker (I was allowed the first time but not the second); https://www.flickr.com/gp/hongkongviews/fo4NWVJ7bS If you end up stuck in an aisle seat on a single-deck bus its a pretty dull journey. I'm don't think you can return to HK without passing Macau Immigration in the vast Macau Port building but as stated by HappyFeet, BradJill will probably know better. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Experiencing Hong Kong-ZhuHai-Macau Bridge (HZMB) from HK?
usertext: #1 and #3 - Per the question above about having to clear Macau immigration or not before returning to HK. I believe HPFT is thinking about the extra ticket booth and set of self-service ticket machines you find right before you exit (outflow direction) the Macau Port to join the queue for Golden Shuttles bound for Hong Kong. I've also wondered in the past if this somehow created opportunity for arriving passengers from HK to skip Macau immigration, buy tickets here and immediately return to HK. However, when arriving into Macau, you have to use a separate Port building entrance (inflow direction) which leads you directly through to Macau Immigration and as far as I recall, there is no place or option to circle back/join the (outflow direction) which leads out of the Port and to where you will pass the extra ticket counter and self-service machines for the HK bound shuttles mentioned above. It is an interesting thought and something I'll look into with more attention next time I take shuttle over to Macau. However, as far as I can think, I don't believe this is possible.

subject: 5. Re: Experiencing Hong Kong-ZhuHai-Macau Bridge (HZMB) from HK?
usertext: SolentTraveller is also spot on correct about how the single and double deck Golden shuttles works. In short, you get in the queue and are shepherded into the next shuttle that is on deck. There is no choosing on your part. Further, even if you are sent into a queue for a double deck shuttle, it is not ascertained that you will find good seats on board. Usually those lucky to board first, get the top side seats in front. There are good views of the bridge with topside seating, not so great on lower level and single deck buses. The rest of the passengers, quickly file in and take what seat is available and the shuttle bus leaves a few minutes later. Everything is pretty quick. In my honest opinion, it can be nice to see the bridge if (1) you enjoy architecture, engineering, bridges, (2) sky conditions are good and (3) you are fortunate to get a double deck shuttle and top side seat. Personally, I like bridges and enjoyed seeing HZMB for the first few trips after the bridge opened. Now I just take a 40 minute nap on the way over and back. As for sky conditions, it makes a big difference and is something I would give consideration to before making the journey on the day. If you can't see much, it sort of defeats the purpose and is reason to wait and try another day. As for the last factor, Shuttle bus and seat choose is beyond your control. You just don't know if you get single or double deck nor what order you will board. You take what seat you can find, sometimes they are great seats, other times, you are in the back of a single deck bus and can't see much. Anyway, just something to think about it.

subject: 6. Re: Experiencing Hong Kong-ZhuHai-Macau Bridge (HZMB) from HK?
usertext: So maybe we can't do it (not entering Macau) at the bus terminus. So we follow all other zombie-like bus passengers to enter the Macau Immigration building, walk through the huge but vastly empty building, go through the snake fences maybe, go upstairs and then downstairs (for no functional reasons but to exercise), and we stand in the back of the lines for the Macau Immigration counters... Now... at that point: they gotta have some cases where the travelers are denied entry to Macau because of an expired passport, incomplete application, missing a visa, and other reasons. These people sure cannot enter Macau. What do the Macau Immigration officers do with such travelers? Maybe they would lead them to a special door or hallway and show them to the other side (which is for travelers to go back where they came from... to Hong Kong). Right? Before spending 30 minutes or whatever to go through the queue and do the "Enter Macau" procedure, can't we ask an officer-in-charge that "we have unforeseen circumstances and we just want to return to Hong Kong without entering Macau... and would you show me the secret hallway to go back to the bus ticketing lobby without us waiting for 30 minutes to get through this (and maybe another 30 minutes to exit Macau)?" Well it doesn't hurt to ask. If a no means a no then it is a no. But may save you some time.

subject: 7. Re: Experiencing Hong Kong-ZhuHai-Macau Bridge (HZMB) from HK?
usertext: You need to pass through HK immigration at the HK side, before you board the HZMB bus. If your passport are not eligiable to enter Macau , I guess you will be stop in the HK Side. But if you are visa free for HK and Macau, you could just enter Macau and go back to departure level immediately and go back to HK. But since there is 6 days in your trip, Macau worth 1 day to travel in my view.

subject: Transport Hong Kong airport to TST
usertext: Hi, first time visitor to Hong Kong. After advice on best way to get from airport to Holiday Inn TST. How much is a taxi? It seems the easiest way? TIA

subject: 1. Re: Transport Hong Kong airport to TST
usertext: Taxi fare from the airport to Tsim Sha Tsui is about HKD $270, plus HKD $6 per luggage. Check these links here: https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/to-from-airport/taxis.page https://www.td.gov.hk/en/transport_in_hong_kong/public_transport/taxi/taxi_fare_of_hong_kong/index.html But I would suggest taking the airport bus A21 from the airport. It takes just slightly longer but it is a great sight-seeing opportunity sitting on the top deck of the 2-story bus. (Basically a Hop-On/Hop-Off like big bus). Here is the route detail: https://mobile.bravobus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=A21&dsmode=1&l=1 One departure every 15 to 30 minutes depending on time-of-day. HKD $33 per adult. Alight at bus stop #15 "Middle Road, Nathan Road". Back track on Nathan Road then make a quick right turn onto Mody Road. ~600 feet of walking to Holiday Inn Golden Mile's main lobby entrance. Map here: https://goo.gl/maps/rGD2v359ud6trkpb7 Picture of the hotel front: https://goo.gl/maps/VGNZftsTetHgWy6v6 Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Transport Hong Kong airport to TST
usertext: New airport bus route A25 also serves Tsim Sha Tsui but currently only on Saturday, Sunday and public holidays at 30 min frequency from the airport between 10-00 and midnight; https://www.bravobus.com.hk/en/uploadedPressRelease/20078_Citybus%20Launches%20Cityflyer%20Route%20A25%20and%20Strengthens%20Cityflyer%20Services.pdf

usertext: I will be staying at Novotel Citygate and anticipate reaching the hotel by 7+am latest. It is too short to go Tai O or disneyland and I am not exactly very fond of shopping especially at Citygates mall. I will be going to Tai O the next day as well. subject: 3. Re: Recommendations for things to do in early morning 7am
usertext: Go from the airport to Novotel Citygate first thing. Drop off your luggage with them. Then walk to the Citygate Mall. No shop will be open that early. Only eateries. There should be a dim sum restaurant there (maybe multiple ones). Spend 1-2 hours and have a leisure breakfast, relax. No use to go up to Ngong Ping too early. The bus ride from the Tung Chung bus terminus to Ngong Ping takes about 1 hour. In the afternoon, too late to go to Tai O or Disneyland. You can take the MTR (Hong Kong's metro/subway) to Hong Kong Station. It is really fast. Can jump start your sight-seeing before you return to your hotel to rest. With the convenience of MTR, no need to "go Lantau Island" because you are on Lantau Island. Going to the center of the city is really not a big deal. Just a short ~30 minute subway ride.

subject: 4. Re: Recommendations for things to do in early morning 7am
usertext: The timetable for the #23 bus from Tung Chung to the Buddha is here: https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/routemap/21 The journey is about an hour, maybe a little less. You'll be up on a plateau in the hills - there's nothing much there except the tourist-trap shops in the "village", the monastery and the Buddha. Beyond that there are plenty of trails where you could go for a walk.

subject: 5. Re: Recommendations for things to do in early morning 7am
usertext: There is another mall outside of Citygate. You walk through a walk way just outside of the McDonald's. This mall serves more locals. There is a Cafe de Coral and a dim sum place, both should be open early. This mall is called Tung Chung Crescent Shopping Arcade, .

subject: 6. Re: Recommendations for things to do in early morning 7am
usertext: The bus ride to Ngong Ping is about an hour; at that time no shops up there will be open, likely even the 7-11 is still closed. On the other hand it will give you a rather unique peaceful experience there. As you have plenty of time, a visit to the Wisdom Trail is a nice addition. It's common and convenient to combine Tai O with the Buddha, it's only about 15 mins bus ride between the two. This are the two main sights on Lantau. Especially good for you as you're having an early start. You could be in Tai O around noon which is a great time to arrive there, have lunch in one of the many restaurants there, maybe enjoy a boat ride through the village, explore the place on foot, and mid afternoon head back to your hotel. From Tai O you have options: there's the ferry to Tung Chung (really nice ride but infrequent - weekdays departing at 10, 14, 16, 18 - more departures on weekends/holidays, actually I'm surprised as it used to be far fewer), the bus direct to Tung Chung (frequent and efficient though mostly the same route as the bus you had to Buddha), or bus back to Buddha and the cable car down (also a very nice ride). That would get you back to your hotel late afternoon - have dinner, maybe walk a bit in Citygate, and have an early night.

subject: 7. Re: Recommendations for things to do in early morning 7am
usertext: Thanks for the really helpful suggestions! I was thinking to do the following as my flight touched down around 5.20am. By the time I come out from the airport, it should be about 6.30am. Then take bus #23 from Tung Chung Bus Terminal at around 8am to reach the Poh Lin Monastery (which opens 8am) around 9am, then Ngong Ping Village, then the Tian Tian Buddha (which opens 10am). subject: 10. Re: Recommendations for things to do in early morning 7am
usertext: Few dolphins left indeed. Probably you have a better chance to see them by taking a boat tour from Tai O or even from the ferry. In both cases you're closer to the dolphins, easier to spot them. You can also ask people that just got off the boat whether they saw any - if so, your chances of course improve. Indeed it's usually just a glimpse, the second or so they need when surfaced to take a deep breath and then they dive down again.

subject: 11. Re: Recommendations for things to do in early morning 7am
usertext: Be aware that the so-called "infinity pool" near Tai O is actually a reservoir for local residents. It is forbidden to enter the reservoir, and, certainly prior to Covid, this was actively policed with prosecutions and fines.

usertext: RE: "Bus to Fu Shan Viewing Point (how to get to Fu Shan from Tai O - is it same bus #1 or #11?)" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = You cannot take a bus to Fu Shan. There is no road. It is a small hill behind the Tai O village. About 1 mile (~1.5km) to walk there, ~200 ft (~70m) elevation gain. Just my eye-ball estimate. Walking there is the only way. subject: 19. Re: Recommendations for things to do in early morning 7am
usertext: I'm going to chip in for the part after breakfast. Assuming the weather is good, a walk along the TST promenade and taking the Star Ferry across would be good at any time of day and especially when it's early and shops are closed. From the Central side, take bus 15 up to the Peak for a walk around Lugard Road and take in more views. Bowen Road is also a decent walk a bit further downhill (same bus but get off at Adventist Hospital on Stubbs Road. Early morning hikes are wonderful to avoid the tourist crowds and you'll likely see more locals exercising at that time of the day.

subject: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Would you recommend Nina Hotel South if I will be going HK Science Museum, Cheung Kau Island and Ocean Park and Kowloon Walled City? What are there to do or eat around Nina Hotel South? Thanks! Or would Royal Plaza Hotel be better? However it is so much more expensive or if anyone would recommend any promotion or discount code for this? Thanks!

subject: 1. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Nina Hotel Island South is all right. Not in an entirely desirable location for tourists. But if it fits your budget I don't see why not. The key is the hotel is near a MTR Station. In this case, the hotel is near Wong Chuk Hang Station. From there you can reach other places all over Hong Kong fairly easily. Hong Kong Science Museum - Tsim Sha Tsui MTR Station. Ocean Park, you can even walk to Ocean Park's entrance. Cheung Chau Island, go to Central Station and walk to the pier to take the ferry. Now Kowloon Walled City is NOT convenient to get to no matter where you stay. Without learning Hong Kong's many bus route and where to board and where to alight, ride MTR to Sung Wong Toi Station and take a short taxi there. Or you can walk, about 0.5 to 1 mile. Be warned that this is not much of a site for tourists to visit, unless you are very enthusiastic about Hong Kong's history. Hong Kong MTR's System Map: https://www.mtr.com.hk/archive/en/services/routemap.pdf Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Thanks Happy Feet. How about Dorsett Mongkok Hong Kong? They seem to have a promotion now that is similar pricing to Nina Hotel South.

subject: 3. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Well overall the Nina Hotel south gets somewhat better reviews than the Dorsett Mongkok, and for the places you list to visit I'd say there's not much between them location-wise (the Dorsett is more in Tai Kok Tsui than Mongkok, maybe 10 minutes walk from what people normally think of as "core" Mongkok). But since that isn't even on your list anyway personally I'd go with the Nina. There are fewer restaurants around Wong Chuk Hang, but still plenty, and you're only a few minutes on the MTR from Admiralty/Wanchai/Central.

subject: 4. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Ok thanks I will book Nina then!

subject: 5. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: To experience HK, I think Dorsett MK is actually better than Nina South. While both are not "conveniently" located by HK standard, Dorsett MK locates in an old neighborhood of HK where you can actually have a taste of "old Hong Kong". The catch is there isnt any MTR station in close proximity but the 10-15 mins walk to the nearest MTR station can be interesting as you get to see and experience what life is like in HK. There are shops and restaurants everywhere so you can get to experience a lot more if you so wish. In comparison, Nina south locates in a quiet part of Wong Chuk Hang and there is almost nothing around it except the Ocean Park. While it is not far away from the MTR station, it is still very isolated and there is not much you can do if you stay there. The hotel bascially locates in a dead corner surrounded by industrial buildings. If all you want to do is to visit the places you mentioned, then Nina south (closer to the MTR station and locates in hk island) supposedly is better in that sense. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Strictly looking at the hotel locations, without knowing the inside conditions or level of service of these hotels etc, I also think that Dorsett Mong Kok may be a better choice if all other factors equal. Nina is located at an industrial stretch (but you can say that about Dorsett), yet from Dorsett you can walk for 10 minutes or so you can be in the heart of the busy corner in Mong Kok, full of shops and eateries. No need for a bus or MTR. Can't say the same for Nina. Your first daily goal is to walk to the Wong Chuk Hang MTR Station. To stay there, in fact, I would recommend finish your dinner somewhere else when you sight-see (maybe the closest nearby Causeway Bay neighborhood) before you go back to your hotel to rest for the evening. To maximize your time utilization. Dorsett is much closer to the airport than Nina. Which may come handy on your departure day, catching a taxi, paying lower fares, getting to the airport quicker, (and also last-minute souvenir grabbing...).

subject: 8. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Thanks, it is really a dilemma. If first Day Check into Dorsett Mongkok Kowloon Walled City Park (take taxi?) Explore the rest of Mongkok? Not sure what else to pair for the day 1Day Ocean Park 1Day Water World Ocean Park 1Day Take MTR to Central then take ferry to Cheung Chau Island 1Day Hong Kong Science Museum Not sure what else to pair for the day

subject: 9. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: 1st day: After landing, go straight to the hotel and drop your luggage - breakfast (restaurants open early) - Kowloon Walled City Park (take taxi - consider asking the driver to follow the google map route: taxi drivers in HK are notoriously untrustworthy and they love to take advantage of tourists so if you're new to hk, easiest way to avoid being scammed is to ask them to follow the google route even it may not be the best route. And take all the changes!) I wouldn't recommend it as it is really not a site for tourists so you may find it quite underwhelming. 2-3 hours max. Then take taxi or mtr to science museum Explore TST or MK depends on where you want to go (it appears that you are not very into ordinary tourist spots so it is hard to make recommendations without further info) 1 Day Ocean Park (if you plan to visit both the Ocean Park and water park, then it may be sensible to stay somewhere close to the parks. You don't have to worry much about your luggages. Just check with Dorsett if it is okay to leave your extra luggages there for one night and take whatever you need for one day with you for the theme park trips. If you are returning to Dorsett after 1 night, I don't see why they'll say no. Sometimes I'll just say I'll come back the get the luggages later that day, most hk hotels (except the budget ones) don't really care if it's just a day or two) 1 Day Water World Ocean Park 1 Day Take MTR to Central then take ferry to Cheung Chau Island 1 Day TBD Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 10. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Actually I will be coming from Novotel Citygates actually (staying there for 3 nights to cover Ngong Ping, Buddha, Tai O & Disneyland) and then 5 nights at Mongkok, so I will likely not try to change hotel another third time but I will think about it. Ok I will pair kowloon walled city with the science museum with the taxis. Many thanks for the suggestion! This will be my third trip to HK - mostly shopping and eating but my last trip was about 10 years back. I am not keen to go back to the Peak on the Peak tram, nor the usual touristy areas. The 3 themeparks are more for my 11-year-old son. I think I have booked too many days and still have 1 day free. I really like Royal Plaza Hotel but it is really too expensive for 5 days on my budget :-( Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 11. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: I realise that there is also another legoland discovery center but it is too kiddish for my son already, who is more into science and technology.

subject: 12. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Hotel price in hk after its re-opening is actually very unreasonable and massively overpriced and I'm definitely against visiting hk at this moment. For the last day, you may consider more in-depth experience that are way less touristy. Sai Kung, Unesco Geopark, Mai Po Nature Reserve and wetland park, Wong tai sin temple, M+ and palace museum, numerous beaches and hiking trails, Stanley, sheung wan, Aberdeen, east soho and Tai On Building, walled villages etc. These are all important and integral aspects of HK that many tourists miss, regrettably. If you venture deep enough, i am sure you can make good use of the last day. Since hong kong is an extremely safe place, you can go absolutely anywhere, even those seemingly underprivileged regions.

subject: 13. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: ok thanks I will pick Sai Kung - looks quite picturesque and has a folk museum. My hub is not keen to move to another third hotel, so think we will stay put in Dorsett. Do you have any idea how we should travel from Dorset Mongkok to Ocean Park and Water World Ocean Park?

subject: 14. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: From Mong Kok station - Mong Kok to admiralty (Tsuen Wan line towards central), then admiralty to ocean park (South Island Line towards South horizons), then walk to Ocean Park/ take taxi to Water park From Olympic Station - Olympic to Hong Kong station (Tung Chun Line towards Hong Kong), then central to admiralty (Tsuen Wan line towards Tsuen Wan), then admiralty to ocean park (as above) If you have time, you may also visit Sky 100 Observation Deck, seeign HK from 100th floor is quite something! Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 15. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Mong Kok Station is farther to walk to from Dorsett, but will save you one extra MTR transfer. I probably would go with that. That would get you to the front entrance of the Ocean Park. For Water World, watch the beginning of this video. There is an extra shuttle bus step involved. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sj6KHex0BTk&ab_channel=LaughTravelEat

subject: 16. Re: Recommend a hotel in HK
usertext: Sai Kung is definitely a good choice. Picturesque and refreshing. From Dorsett MK to Sai Kung is a bit challenging. Quickest way is to go to Mong Kok first, then take a minibus to Sai kung (final stop).

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Is Kowloon Walled City worth a visit?
usertext: I recently saw some photos of the Kowloon Walled City - is it worth visiting? Is it easy to find? Thankyou

subject: 1. Re: Is Kowloon Walled City worth a visit?
usertext: The Walled City is now a park and a museum. The actual Walled City is no longer in existence (since 1997?). So are you interested in visiting the museum? When we lived in HK, the Walled City was an active and mysterious place for us. So we visited the museum a couple of times to revisit HK history. Are you interested in doing that?

subject: 2. Re: Is Kowloon Walled City worth a visit?
usertext: If you are looking at old photos showing big dilapidated buildings.....all that is completely gone. On the other hand, the park and museum (which shows off some ancient fortifications built a couple hundred years ago), are fairly interesting. But not easy to get to, unless you ride the local buses.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Is Kowloon Walled City worth a visit?
usertext: The LCSD website has useful information about Kowloon Walled City Park; https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/en/parks/kwcp/historical.html KMB Bus 1 from Star Ferry Bus Terminus in Tsim Sha Tsui stops on Tung Tau Tsuen Road, outside one of the entrances to both Kowloon Walled City Park the connected Carpenter Road Park.

subject: 4. Re: Is Kowloon Walled City worth a visit?
usertext: "I recently saw some photos of the Kowloon Walled City - is it worth visiting?" Yes, no... maybe.... as others have pointed out above, make sure you research and find out what is actually here to see these days. "Is it easy to find? " In the past, a bit out of the way and not the easiest place to find. Now, since the Sung Wong Toi MTR Station on the Tuen Ma Line opened - it is easy peasy to find. Just go to Exit B2/B3 for Kowloon City. From there you are straight 250 metre walk north to the Kowloon Walled City Park. Walk into the park around 200 metres and you'll find the historic buildings, fortifications and old Walled City exhibition.

subject: 5. Re: Is Kowloon Walled City worth a visit?
usertext: Depending on where you are staying, I also suggest using the MTR in most cases. Bus going through the traffic in Kowloon can be quite slow.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Is Kowloon Walled City worth a visit?
usertext: We spent a couple of hours wandering around the park. We found the history fascinating and the gardens are absolutely beautiful.

subject: 7. Re: Is Kowloon Walled City worth a visit?
usertext: I find the neighbouring grid of streets to be more interesting with small local shops, a dwindling # of Chiu Chow specialist stores, and Thai restaurants. A lot of these blocks are slated for a massive redevelopment project pushed forward by the government so will disappear for good soon.

subject: 8. Re: Is Kowloon Walled City worth a visit?
usertext: I get the feeling that locals like me find the shops and eateries more interesting while foreigners find the park's history fascinating.

subject: 9. Re: Is Kowloon Walled City worth a visit?
usertext: Agree with comments above. The Kowloon City district is worth visiting, personally love the building style. Lots of locals go there for restaurants as well. You can visit Kowloon City wet market as well if you are interested. By MTR or bus is convenient. Personally prefer the bus, due to the view, but it's considerably slower, depending from where you are coming from. If you have time, Tokwawan has some old buildings as well. It's a more residential area, there's not much to do but I like the vibes there, walking around and taking street photos. Also, there is a tiny porcelain shop called If you happen to pass by, you can pick up some clay/ porcelain souvenirs. It's not expensive but the quality is normal, nothing special. Short walk from Kowloon City.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Opal ring
usertext: Visiting Hong Kong next year. Where could go in Hong Kong to buy a reasonably priced white gold Opal ring in Hong Kong?

subject: 1. Re: Opal ring
usertext: I'd start looking at one of the many, many jewellery shops that line Nathan Road in Tsim Sha Tsui and Mongkok. Chain stores are a safe bet that you get what you think you get (no lower grade gold than stated or so).

subject: 2. Re: Opal ring
usertext: I don't know anything about jewelry, but I do know I'll never set foot into one of those jewelry stores (or camera stores or medicine stores) in Tsim Sha Tsui.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Opal ring
usertext: Thank you. I'll try that.

subject: 4. Re: Opal ring
usertext: The chain stores (Chow Tai Fook, Luk Fook, ...) you find in TST are fine. It's the small/independent shops in that area that are notorious. In less touristy districts the independent shops tend to be fine, too. Make sure you know what to look for when buying jewellery, I for one know just about nothing about those minerals so have to rely on the salesfolk telling me what I'm looking at so I'd prefer to stick to the established chains even though they tend to be a bit more expensive.

subject: 5. Re: Opal ring
usertext: I lived in Hong Kong for a decade. I don't know why you would buy jewellery there rather than in the USA or UK. The prices certainly are not lower, especially at a place like Chow Tai Fook or Luk Fook. You will not be cheated at one of those well know chain stores, but you won't get a bargain. You would do better to buy online from one of the reputable online sellers like Blue Nile. See this link for example: https://www.bluenile.com/jewelry/gemstone-jewelry/gemstone-rings/opal-rings

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Opal ring
usertext: Apsara Travels, someone told me that Hong Kong was very competitively priced for good quality Opal rings in comparison to UK.

subject: 7. Re: Opal ring
usertext: I can't imagine why HK would be a good place to buy Opals - 95% of opals come from Australia, that would be a better place to find a deal. HK sells a lot of jade- perhaps this was what someone was thinking of? The jade prices however are also very high. Honestly, Hong Kong is no longer a shopping paradise if you are interested in high quality items. From clothing to shoes to jewelry to watches to art you will find things more expensive than prices in the US or UK. If have your heart set on jewelry, honestly have a look at Blue Nile. Go across the border into Shenzhen for more interesting shopping and better prices. You can take the MRT subway system right to the border and walk across. It makes an easy and fun trip.

subject: 8. Re: Opal ring
usertext: I hope you know your stuff (quality and prices) and can haggle with the best of them.

subject: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: Sai Kung Explore Sai Kung Town after alighting from pier Lunch at Big Fish Seafood & Grill or Tung Kee (early lunch) Sheung Yiu Folk Museum - how do I get there from Sai Kung Town? Can I take a cab from Sai Kung Town or bus? MacLehose Trail - can anyone recommend which is the easiest or most scenic route (Section 1 or 2?) and how to get there from Sheung Yiu Folk Museum? Is it very hot in the afternoon in first week of December? Can any one recommend a dinner restaurant here? Cheung Chau Island Pier along Pak She Praya Road I really do not know what is there to do here. Can you give me any ideas or should I drop this itinerary? Thanks in advance!!

subject: 1. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: >> Sheung Yiu Folk Museum Bus 94 from Sai Kung bus terminus; get off at Sheung Yiu and 5-10 mins walk. >> MacLehose Trail Note that starting points of the trail itself and the various sections are seemingly randomly placed - no easy connection from those points to public transport. Roads are crossed mostly in the middle of sections. It's a really long trail, really don't know which parts would be best. I've done most of it but never intentionally walked that route... A very scenic hike is East Dam - Long Ke - Sai Wan beach - Sai Wan Pavilion. That's part of the McLehose trail. Not to much height difference, only about 500m climb total on that route. Allow a full day, including some time at the beach. You may also consider taking a speed boat from Sai Wan back to Sai Kung; ask at the restaurants at the beach for boats.

subject: 2. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: {Cheung Chau Island...I really do not know what is there to do here. Can you give me any ideas or should I drop this itinerary?} Here is a trip list with a handful of things to do/places to visit at Cheung Chau https://www.tripadvisor.com/Trips/97899048/Cheung%20Chau%20Island

subject: 3. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: A very scenic hike is East Dam - Long Ke - Sai Wan beach - Sai Wan Pavilion - how to hike to here? I hear quite a lot of people complaining that they totally got lost. How do we find our way? Regarding the speed boat from Sai Wan back to Sai Kung, where to take this speed boat and how much does it cost? Regarding Cheung Chau, Take ferry at Central Pier 5 to Cheung Chau Island (40 mins) Pier along Pak She Praya Road Tung Wan Beach - kayaking? Lunch at New Baccarat or Hing Lok Cheung Chau Island Trail - Mini Great Wall and Cheung Po Tsai Cave - how do we get to this Mini Great Wall and Cheung Po Tsai Cave and back to Pier?

subject: 4. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: {Cheung Chau Island Trail - Mini Great Wall and Cheung Po Tsai Cave - how do we get to this Mini Great Wall and Cheung Po Tsai Cave and back to Pier?} Start your research by referencing google maps and you should be able to locate everything you are looking for on the island very quickly and easily. Google maps also shows the loop trail. You can also try sites like All Trails (see link) https://www.alltrails.com/trail/hong-kong/islands/cheung-chau-loop?u=i as well as the useful reports by bloggers like Drone and DSLR team to help with general guidance on how to get around the island to find the sights (see link) https://droneandslr.com/travel-blog/hong-kong/cheung-chau/

subject: 5. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: >> How do we find our way? OpenStreetMap is very useful. The route is really easy to find, no need to get lost. There are even occasional signposts I remember. >> speed boat from Sai Wan back to Sai Kung, where to take this speed boat and how much does it cost? As said, ask in the restaurants. Cost will be $120-150 per person. I don't know the current fares, and it may vary a bit weekday/weekend. I should add that there's no pier; you have to wade to get to the boat.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: You can book a speedboat from Ham Tin, a little further along the MacLehose Trail beyond Sai Wan, up to one day advance via the "Sai Kung Ham Tin Speedboat" app which you can download from the Apple App Store or Google Play. For today (3rd May) there are two trips from Ham Tin at 14-30 and 17-00 and the fare is HK$200 one-way or HK$360 round-trip. High Island Reservoir East Dam is served by taxi and on Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays only green minibus 9A from Pak Tam Chung; https://www.saikungplb.com/e-route9a.html Pak Tam Chung is served by KMB bus route 94 (Sai Kung Town - Wong Shek Pier), green minibus 7 ; https://www.saikungplb.com/e-route7.html and green minibus 9; https://www.saikungplb.com/e-route9.html Sai Wan Pavilion is served by taxi and residents bus service 29R/NR29 (which any one can use) from outside McDonalds on Chan Man Street in Sai Kung Town; https://www.td.gov.hk/filemanager/en/content_4796/WCONTE/20191120_nr29_eng.pdf If you don't want a speedboat or there's none available and keep following the Maclehose Trail Stage 2 beyond Sai Wan and Ham Tin to its end you end up at Pak Tam Au which is served by KMB bus 94 and green minibus 7. Along the way you pass Chek Keng Pier which, on Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays is served by kaito to Wong Shek Pier where you can also catch bus 94 at its terminus; https://www.td.gov.hk/en/transport_in_hong_kong/public_transport/ferries/kaito_services_map/service_details/index.html#k06 At other times you may find locals touting for business offering unlicensed boat rides from Chek Keng to Wong Shek Pier.

subject: 7. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: wow that's very helpful. Thanks all!

subject: 8. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: After much analysis of the above information, the itinerary to Sai Kung from Dorsett Mongkok is as follows: Take hotel shuttle to Langham Place, take Mongkok MTR to Choi Hung MTR Station Exit C2, take Green Minibus A1 to Sai Kung Pier (depart every 5 min, 25 min-ride). Explore Sai Kung Town. Buy some egg tarts & pineapple buns for breakfast the next day. Lunch Sheung Yiu Folk Museum - Take #9 bus from Sai Kung bus terminus get off at Pak Tam Chung station (7 stops, 33 mins) or #94 from Sai Kung bus terminus get off at Sheung Yiu station (15 stops abt 45 mins) and a few mins walk and cross the Pak Tam Bridge near the Fat Kee Store and walk along 15 mins down the Pak Tam Chung Nature Trail. This short and pretty nature trail leads to the Sheung Yiu Folk Museum. On the way it passes lime kilns and an old pier. Walk back to Pak Tam Chung station (1.2km) High Island Reservoir East Dam, , Sai Kung, Hong Kong - take bus # 9A (only avail on sat & sun) from Pak Tam Chung station (2 stops, 30 mins) to High Island Reservoir East Dam UNESCO Global Geopark, Sai Kung, Hong Kong Hexagonal Columns, Sai Kung Man Yee Rd, Sai Kung, Hong Kong Biu Tsim Kok Viewing Point, 998J+59, Sai Kung, Hong Kong Walk up MacLehose Trail Section 2 to  (2km one way) then walk back to High Island Reservoir (East Dam) (I don't know if I can walk up and down 2km each way). Take 9A back to Pak Tam Chung station then bus #7 or #9 back to Sai Kung Pier. Then take 1A bus from Sai Kung Pier to Choi Hung MTR Station. The whole day planning is so tedious :-( Minus away all the walking, having to wait for each of the infrequent bus schedules is another problem. Is there an easier way? Is there a day tour that can do all the above or if we can book a taxi to take us to all these attractions? How much will it cost if we book a taxi for whole day at Sai Kung? Or do you think we can or should rent a car instead?

subject: 9. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: Getting to East Dam by taxi is easy, take the taxi from Sai Kung bus terminus. Takes about 40 mins. From East Dam taxis may be in short supply, but it varies. Earlier in the day it's usually easiest to get a taxi, as that's when the hikers start there day - by taking taxi there. Later in the day traffic direction is reversed.

subject: 10. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: but I will be at Sheung Yiu Folk Museum, will it be easy to take a taxi there? Doesn't make sense to take a 30 mins ride back to take the taxi from Sai Kung bus terminus? Can I take a taxi back from East Dam back all the way to Dorsett Mongkok? Should cost around HKD300-350?Easy to find a cab back around 4-5pm at East Dam? I just cannot imagine I have to drag myself back 2-2.5hours back by public buses. I think I might drop Sai Kung even though it is so beautiful. There is no way to travel all these 4-5hrs journeys by public buses with a 11-year-old child. Just Dorsett Mongkok to Saikung Pier is 1.5hrs. Then 30 mins by bus, walk 15 mins to Sheung Yiu Folk Museum. Walk 15 mins back to Pak Tam Chung station then another 30 mins to East Dam by bus. Walk up another 30+mins by foot to  and another 30+ mins down. Then bus back to Pak Tam Chung station 30 mins and bus back to Saikung Bus Terminal another 20 mins and MTR back to Dorsett Mongkok another 1.5hrs. Just add up the bus travelling times amount to 4-5hrs and that hasn't taken in the individual bus waiting times.

subject: 11. Re: Sai Kung Day Itinerary and Cheung Chau Island Itinerary
usertext: From Sheung Yiu Folk Museum: walk back to the road and wait for a taxi. Shouldn't be long. At East Dam likely you will only find green taxis, they can't take you to Mongkok. Change in Sai Kung for a red taxi. Late afternoon it may be hard to get a taxi at East Dam.

subject: Free Bus Day - Route 25 (Hong Kong Island ) May 7
usertext: To celebrate New World First Bus' 25th birthday and imminent brand disappearance, route 25 on Hong Kong Island will be free this Sunday (May 7). This bus route travels between Central's ferry piers (near the Star Ferry) through Wan Chai, Causeway Bay, and uphill towards Braemar Hill where you can do a short hike to the famous Red Incense Burner skyline lookout point. https://www.travellingwithnikki.com/2019/01/the-braemar-hill-lookout-hong-kong/ You can look up the route map here : https://mobile.bravobus.com.hk/nwp3/index.php?golang=EN

subject: 1. Re: Free Bus Day - Route 25 (Hong Kong Island ) May 7
usertext: One day (a Sunday). One minor route. What a generous celebration!!! The bus company is making a real contribution to Happy Hong Kong.

subject: 2. Re: Free Bus Day - Route 25 (Hong Kong Island ) May 7
usertext: I suppose route 25 does let one see a good bit of HK from Central up to Braemar Hill. It goes through Admiralty, Wan Chai, Causeway Bay before heading up Tin Hai Temple Road to Braemar Hill. Braemar Hill indeed offers good hiking if interested. Just note that there aren't many shops up there so stock up on drinks and snacks before leaving.

subject: Do the hotels in Hong Kong restrict # of persons in a room?
usertext: We seem to have trouble booking for a family of 4--2 adults and 2 children, ages 14 and 7. This is very upsetting.

subject: 1. Re: Do the hotels in Hong Kong restrict # of persons in a room?
usertext: All hotels (pretty much everywhere in the world) have a limit on how many people can stay in a room, normally driven by fire regulations. But 2 adults plus 2 children isn't an issue. For example, I just went to booking.com and searched for a single room in Hong Kong for 2 adults and 2 children aged 14 and 7 for 15-17 May. It returned 408 possibilities. So your distress is obviously due to your inabaility to use the internet, not any issues with HK hotels. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Do the hotels in Hong Kong restrict # of persons in a room?
usertext: Perhaps the situation is further complicated by trying to book using marriott hotel points. I was initially trying to book a room for my sister's family-- 2 adults, 2 children for Sheraton TST. I tried most of the marriott properties and had the same issue. We called the customer service number and was informed The Mira, under same mgmt, accepts more than 3 persons in a room. However, when i was ready to book, same issue! Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Do the hotels in Hong Kong restrict # of persons in a room?
usertext: Well then the problem is Marriott points, because for money the following hotels all accept 2 adults + 2 children in a single room: Hong Kong SkyCity Marriott Hotel Hong Kong Ocean Park Marriott Hotel Courtyard by Marriott Hong Kong Sha Tin Sheraton Hong Kong Tung Chung Hotel Sheraton Hong Kong Hotel & Towers Courtyard by Marriott Hong Kong and maybe others (I've lost track of which brands are under Marriott these days)

subject: 4. Re: Do the hotels in Hong Kong restrict # of persons in a room?
usertext: Having traveled with two teenage sons I have encountered this problem in many hotels in many countries. In those instances I was forced to book two rooms which doubled my hotel budget. Suggest you to post your query in Family Travel Forum: https://www.tripadvisor.com.au/ShowForum-g1-i9658-Family_Travel.html

subject: 5. Re: Do the hotels in Hong Kong restrict # of persons in a room?
usertext: @Diasperth35 --thanks for the tip in posting in the Family forum. I spent 3 freaking hours last night, exhausted as hell, doing something that should take a few mere minutes. After posting here and getting insulted by someone about my internet abilities, I called 2 of the hotels directly. this has nothing to do with redeeming points, as in my 3 hour search, i've tried purchasing the nights, same issue. When using booking.com, it allows it, however, we do not want to risk having my sibling denied upon arrival, etc. When i called 2 of the hotels directly, i was then transferred and it went to a VM, asking to book online! Finally, i contacted customer service for marriott and thankfully, a live person answered and i told him the issue and he put me on hold and contacted the hotel directly--he tells me that it's ok to have 2 adults and 2 chil children, but we better get it in an email to avoid issues upon check in...before contacting customer s service, I found another family who had the same issue booking 2 adults and 2 children in HK, so clearly, this seems to be a pretty common issue, not just with marriott properties, but other properties as well in hk (per the other family's 1st hand info).

subject: 6. Re: Do the hotels in Hong Kong restrict # of persons in a room?
usertext: There are a number of issues in play here. The main issue is the terms for the use of Marriott rewards. Like most reward programs for the largest hotel groups, the contract between Marriott group and the properties requires a standard room and double occupancy for award stays. Anything beyond a standard room and two people in a room is up to the discretion of a particular hotel property. They can allow four people in a room, but they are only required to allow two. (This is rarely an issue in the United States, most hotels here do not care and do not enforce the occupancy limit. But they may charge for additional persons beyond two) Because the reservations are handled automatically by a computer, the properties may set it up to accept only up to two people in a room by default. Another issue is many hotel rooms in Asia and Europe are relatively small, that they can physically accommodate only two people sleeping. It does you no good for them to accept a reservation for four people in a room, but give you a room with two twin beds. Where are the two kids suppose to sleep? Some hotels in Hong Kong do have family rooms, but they will be charged at a higher rate and not considered "standard rooms", and therefore not bookable with points.

usertext: Impossible to say. It's also CNY period which affects this greatly, and tourism will be increasing over the next year - so current waiting times may have nothing to do with next year. In general though, weekdays will be less crowded than weekends, and weekends less crowded than holidays.

subject: 2. Re: Disneyland wait times Saturdays?
