Under long holiday in HongKong (Usually Easter, Chrismas, CNY) or China (first few days of May and Oct), it will be very crowd , one ride may take up to 1 hours. But in my experience, usually one ride wont be over 1 hour

subject: Advice on transportation from Kowloon stn to Nathan Hotel
usertext: Hihi, I am thinking of taking Airport express to Kowloon Station. However I'm not sure what is the best transportation ways to Nathan Hotel (Kowloon). I'm not really good in speaking cantonese hence is abit fearful of taking cabs. Is it easy to take uber from Kowloon side or should I take mtr instead? Appreciate all the kind advice n recommendations in advance! :)

subject: 1. Re: Advice on transportation from Kowloon stn to Nathan Hotel
usertext: Taxi will be fine. Drivers know most major hotels by their English name, or print out the name in Chinese. Note that if you're more than two people you're better off taking taxi all the way from the airport to the hotel (faster, cheaper). At two people it's barely more to take taxi all the way. Travel time that way is less overall.

subject: 2. Re: Advice on transportation from Kowloon stn to Nathan Hotel
usertext: For Nathan Hotel on Nathan Road, don't take Airport Express, don't take MTR, don't take taxi. Take my word for it. Take Airport Bus A21. Especially if you travel by yourself (just one person, no sharing the cost of taxi). The bus stop is literally right outside the front door of Nathan Hotel. Taxi cannot get you any closer than that. The bus takes longer, but it is a sight-seeing experience sitting on the top deck en-route. See the bus route details, time-table and fare (HKD $33, versus taxi about HKD $270 plus luggage fee) here (Bus Stop #11 "Nathan Hotel, Nathan Road", Route "A21"): https://mobile.bravobus.com.hk/nwp3/index.php?golang=EN Link for taxi fare estimate: https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/to-from-airport/taxis.page

subject: 3. Re: Advice on transportation from Kowloon stn to Nathan Hotel
usertext: HappyFeet is correct - assuming you're arriving between 8am and 11pm then take the A21 bus, which runs every 15-20 minutes. If you will travel back to the airport the same way, you can buy pre-paid round-trip tickets from the kiosk at the entrance to the bus station at the airport (which is well-signed) for $55, saving you $11 per person. Having said that, taxis here aren't that scary, and from the airport you can ask the dispatcher to tell the taxi which hotel you want to go to, and they will tell you the estimated fare. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Advice on transportation from Kowloon stn to Nathan Hotel
usertext: Thank you all for the kind advice! Really appreciate for taking precious time to answer

usertext: Hihi, I have yet to try out on that route.. :) my hols in another few months time haha

subject: 7. Re: Advice on transportation from Kowloon stn to Nathan Hotel
usertext: {And How long does the bus take?} A21 bus to hotels along Nathan Road in TST should take no longer than 55-60 minutes. It is a very good way to make your way into the city. Bus is easy to find at the airport bus depot, just $33 per person, there is a large luggage rack inside the bus for your bags..... a nice and very comfortable ride into the city.

subject: Around Wharney Hotel
usertext: We are family travellers with young kids in our group for our upcoming HK trip, and have non-refundable bookings at the Wharney Hotel. Only afterward did I read that the location is lined with bars and night entertainment (haven't been to this part of HK before). As such, would like to request for anyone in the know to share what the current situation in the area is these days (as those posts I've read were about 5 years ago or more). Anything to note or watch out for, areas to avoid, dos and dont's, etc? And also, on the positive side, any good dining places, bakeshops, cafes to try, places to visit, etc? Thanks in advance.

subject: 1. Re: Around Wharney Hotel
usertext: That location is fine, perfectly safe. Nothing specific to worry about. Tons of restaurants in that area as well - see http://www.openrice.com for listings.

subject: 2. Re: Around Wharney Hotel
usertext: The location is fine. During the day you won't notice anything hardly. It is the night time, especially late night, that certain "industry" would become more active. But even at night, along the streets you probably only see some bars with open fronts and some may be crowded. But these are only places where people "meet". Lockhart Road, and the one in parallel - Jeffe Road, are fairly well-known redlight areas in Hong Kong. All started way back with WW2, the Korean War, and the Vietnam War, where American sailors/GI went to Hong Kong for R&R. Jumped on a walla-walla and land the first thing... and the closest place (can't wait) is Wan Chai. The landing is only 1 to 2 short blocks from Jeffe/Lockhart, a 5-minute walk from your hotel's location. Back then, the Victoria Harbour coastline was much closer. What you see today is landfill upon landfill over the past many decades. Wan Chai (this hotel's location) and Causeway Bay are the food mecca in Hong Kong. Hundreds of restaurants with all kinds of styles. You want concrete suggestions, ask with more specifics (type of food, budget, environment). You want 5-star hotels? Or you want hole-in-the-wall along the streets? Chinese food? Non-Chinese food? Thought I throw in a couple of honorable mentions: #1) Honolulu Coffee Shop (Hennessy Road) Link: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/p-honolulu-coffee-shop-hennessy-road-p4598862 Their signature is egg tart, pineapple buns with slice of butter, and Hong Kong style milk tea type of items. #2) Yee Shun Dairy Company Link: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/r-yee-shun-dairy-company-causeway-bay-hong-kong-style-dessert-r11167 Their signature is milk custard. Pic: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/dish/%E9%A6%B3%E5%90%8D%E9%9B%99%E7%9A%AE%E7%87%89%E5%A5%B6-yee-shun-dairy-company-d395683

subject: 3. Re: Around Wharney Hotel
usertext: A combination of Covid and Tinder (and similar apps) have pretty much killed off most of the "curtain bars" (i.e. brothels) in Wanchai. It's still a late-night bar area, but they are interspersed amongst many restaurants, office buildings etc. Within 5 minutes walk in any direction from the Wharney you're in complete different areas. And nowhere is particularly unsafe. Obviously late at night there may be a few people staggering around the worse for a few beers, but nothing that isn't trivially avoided.

subject: 4. Re: Around Wharney Hotel
usertext: Thank you everyone for the detailed and informative replies. I will just post a separate thread on food recommendations.

subject: 2 days alone in HK for single lady
usertext: Can anyone recommend any day itinerary for single lady in Mongkok/TST area or near Ocean Park area? Thanks!

subject: 1. Re: 2 days alone in HK for single lady
usertext: Do a search on this forum for "itinerary" for lots of suggestions and pick and choose whatever you are interested in. Lots of things to do, and most of that works for solo travellers just fine.

subject: 2. Re: 2 days alone in HK for single lady
usertext: It really depends on your interests, which we do not know. Can be shopping, eating, museums, outdoors, etc. Or just walking around the neighborhoods.

subject: 3. Re: 2 days alone in HK for single lady
usertext: A concert or talkshow or comedy show will be great. I adore Eason Chan, Dayo Wong, Hacken Lee and Zhou Shen :-). A movie or spa will be okay too. I will be coming around in first week of December. Any suggestions will be appreciated. Thanks!

subject: 4. Re: 2 days alone in HK for single lady
usertext: You can check what events are scheduled for the time of your visit on Discover Hong Kong (events page) -> https://www.discoverhongkong.com/hk-eng/what-s-new/events.html There are always quite a few art exhibitions taking place around city museums and galleries. This site shows what is on slate for December -> https://www.cultureplus.asia/events/today/ Perhaps spend some time exploring the Ya Mau Tei/Mongkok/Sham Shui Po neighbourhood for historic and culturally interesting spots. You can find a handful of suggested self-walk neighbourhood routes on Discover HK as well -> https://www.discoverhongkong.com/hk-eng/explore/neighbourhoods.html By early December, Winterfest will be up and running, you should be able to see Xmas decorations in various places around the city. Some places put up neat Xmas displays, West Kowloon might be good this year, 1881 Heritage in TST is usually pretty good, Landmark Atrium in Central is quite interesting most years. https://www.westkowloon.hk/en/2022-hong-kong-winterfest?tab=overview https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/what-s-new/events/dhk-highlighted-events/hong-kong-winterfest.html Also, early December is prime hiking season in Hong Kong. Cool weather means and rainless days are quite common at this time of the year so you can do some gLireat hikes, even in the centrally located areas around HK like Lugard Rd around the Peak (HK Island) and Lion's Rock (Kowloon). Or consider day trips to outlying islands like Cheung Chau, Ping Chau or Lamma.... Or go to Macau for a day. They do a great job with Xmas decorations, especially in the Catholic churches that form part of the UNESCO World Heritage area.

subject: Harbour Grand Hong Kong or Kowloon?
usertext: We will be in Hong Kong for just 3 days from 30th June till 3rd July. Have narrowed it down to Harbour Grand Hong Kong or Harbour Grand Kowloon. Things to consider are: We arrive late afternoon from UK and will be tired so distance from Airport by taxi A nice swimming pool where we can lounge after or between sightseeing Distance by Taxi to Disneyland (we are going on Sunday 2nd July....are we mad???) Food Options in hotel Rooms best suited to 2 adults and 1 Child Best Views. I think Harbour Grand Hong King looks slightly nicer and maybe better tourist location but Kowloon looks like better pool and closer to airport/Disney. Could anyone who is familiar with these hotels offer any thoughts on which to pick. Thanks so much.

subject: 1. Re: Harbour Grand Hong Kong or Kowloon?
usertext: I thought the Kowloon is the nicer of the two - but never stayed in either for obvious reasons. For the inside of the hotel and quality of their amenities etc read the reviews. Location wise, both are fine. The Hong Kong one is near a more convenient MTR station but the Kowloon one has the great Hung Hom waterfront promenade. Great for evening walks, done that routinely when I lived in that vicinity. Hung Hom may also still be a bit less crowded than Fortress Hill district.

subject: 2. Re: Harbour Grand Hong Kong or Kowloon?
usertext: Harbour Grand HK is the newer one (though it's not exactly new either). I felt it's a bit nicer. However, I would rate it as less convenient overall. The closest MTR station is Fortress Hill which is built way deep into the underground. From HGHK to the Fortress Hill platform might take 15 minutes. For the Kowloon location, from Whampoa MTR, you can get to Mong Kok very quickly. I believe they run a shuttle to Tsim Sha Tsui as well.

subject: 3. Re: Harbour Grand Hong Kong or Kowloon?
usertext: Food: Food in both hotels are mediocre, but there are multiple options within walking distance. Nearest major tourist area (by taxi): Kowloon to TST (5 mins), Hong Kong to causeway bay (5 mins) Harbour view: Harbour Grand kowloon has nice habour view but the top floor of Grand Harbour HK offers a even better one. Hotel conditions: Harbour Grand Kowloon is nicer and newly renovated and i believe it has better pool and, closer to airport and Disney if you take taxi (but I wouldn't recommend taking taxi simply because taxi drivers in hk are notoriously untrustworthy and Disney line may be something you want to check out if you're a Disneyland fan) I'd recommend HG kowloon

subject: 4. Re: Harbour Grand Hong Kong or Kowloon?
usertext: "taxi drivers in hk are notoriously untrustworthy" As someone who's lived in HK for the past 25 years and takes taxis very regularly I think this is unfair. There are a very small number of dodgy taxi drivers who hang around places where tourists go and try to scam them, but they are a tiny fraction of the total. The standard rules for taxis anywhere will keep you away from them: always pick your taxi - never let a taxi driver pick you; hailing a moving taxi is better than one that is "loitering" unless it is sitting on an official taxi rank; make sure the meter is switched off before you enter and switched on after you enter; in case of any issues make it clear to the driver that you will happily call the police (112 and 999 both work on your mobile, but the driver will recognise it immediately if you show him 999 as the dialled number waiting for you to press call.)

subject: 5. Re: Harbour Grand Hong Kong or Kowloon?
usertext: Aside from Lan Kwai Fong area, I have not heard of any rougue HK taxi drivers.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Harbour Grand Hong Kong or Kowloon?
usertext: I think the vast majority of taxi drivers are honest but scams do occasionally happen outside LKF; https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3214016/hong-kong-tourist-rip-british-writer-reports-falling-victim-overcharging-taxi-driver-trip-airport

subject: 7. Re: Harbour Grand Hong Kong or Kowloon?
usertext: Another popular location for taxi scammers is Harbour City/Canton Road area. Whether at LKF or Canton Road, just avoid any taxis that have their flags covered. Those could be the scammers waiting for you to ask for a rate. At LKF late night, the best strategy is to walk back down to Queen's Road Central and flag a moving cab or pick one up at Pedder St right outside Landmark/Louis Vuitton. Near Harbour City, Star Ferry/Star House has a proper taxi stand. Most drivers are honest.

subject: 8. Re: Harbour Grand Hong Kong or Kowloon?
usertext: To #4 As someone who lives in Hong Kong for more than 30+ years, taxi is my and my partner's main form of transportation other than driving (at least 2 rides/d). I also have friends who own taxi license or work as taxi driver. I have to admit I'm extremely surprised if a local like you is not aware of the terrible reputation of taxi drivers among locals and the persisting and notorious problems of taxi drivers not using the most direct practicable route, having bad attitude and terrible road safety awareness. When I say they are notoriously untrustworthy, I am not referring the less common cases where taxi drivers being rogue or trying to overcharge a tourist by proposing an unreasonable fee, I am referring to their dishonest practices as mentioned above. If you are an asia who speaks fluent Cantonese and knows the roads well, you should not be surprised by what I've said. However, this is just my opinion so if you're happy with the taxi drivers in Hong kong, then please ignore my comments. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Question about Octopus card
usertext: Hello. Wondering if i should buy the Tourist Octopus or the regular one please. If i buy the tourist one for 39$, does it mean 39$ is loaded onto the card for use on the MTR, OR is 39$ the 'cost' of the card only and i will need to further top up to travel? Also for the regular octopus for 50$, is that amount usable, or i need to top up for any travel to be initiated please? I will be in HKG for a week. I need the card only for the MTR and bus rides. Appreciate the help. Thank you! -Shirley

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Question about Octopus card
usertext: The Tourist Octopus is a sold product which you buy for HK$39 which is non-refundable. You have to load the card with stored value to be able purchase transport fares or other goods with it. Any unused stored value which has been added to the card can be refunded at any MTR Customer Service Centre before leaving HK and you keep the card which is deactivated; https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/octopus-cards/products/sold-tourist/index.html The Standard On-Loan Adult Octopus costs HK$150 of which HK$100 is stored value and HK$50 is a deposit. If the card is handed in at any MTR Customer Service Centre any unused stored value is refunded together with the deposit less an admin fee of HK$11. You don't keep the card. https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/octopus-cards/products/on-loan/standard.html Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Question about Octopus card
usertext: The decision is really simple. No need to get into the cost/benefit analysis. Ask yourself: Do you want it as souvenir? If so, get it. Try to use up most of the balance before you leave. If not, get the on-loan Octopus, return it for refund at the airport before departure.

subject: 3. Re: Question about Octopus card
usertext: Thank you so much.

subject: 4. Re: Question about Octopus card
usertext: @happyfeet naah...dont need a ticket as a souvenir. Just needed to understand how it works. Thanks.

subject: 5. Re: Question about Octopus card
usertext: Nothing says you have to return the on-loan version when you leave HK. Mine is in the money drawer in the travel room upstairs, in a baggie marked "HK" along with a wad of cash, ready for the next trip. A souvenir that becomes useful from time to time.

subject: 6. Re: Question about Octopus card
usertext: Those keeping old Octopus cards for future use should note that "first generation" cards (i.e. those that do not have brackets around the last digit of the card number) have now stopped working, and will normally incur an extra administrative fee for replacement. See here and various other pages on the Octopus website... https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/customer-service/faq/card-replacement/about-card-replacement.html#3665

subject: 1. Re: Summer Holiday Hong Kong Disney Peak Plus
usertext: There aren't any additional shows or attractions during the summer school holidays but Disneyland takes the opportunity to charge peak period admission prices as demand is high during this period. It issued its annual report today and it appears the next new attraction to open will be "World of Frozen" in November. At the moment Disneyland opens five days a week but it will extend opening to either six or seven days a week from mid-June depending on market conditions.

subject: China visa for Guangzhou
usertext: Hi We will be in Hong Kong for 12 daysin in October and planning a trip to Guangzhou. I do have a question that I can't find an answer to though. When applying for a Chinese visa the notes seem to suggest we need to provide travel details from Hong Kong to Guangzhou and back, dates, return tickets etc. We were kind of hoping to decide which day to go to Guangzhou on the fly, rainy day activity perhaps, nad just book a train ticket, rather than decide in advance. If we get an L visa how should we answer these questions on the application? Thanks in advance

subject: 1. Re: China visa for Guangzhou
usertext: You need to submit an itinerary to get the visa but once you have the visa, you do not need to comply with it. You can go whenever it fits you during the visa duration.

subject: 2. Re: China visa for Guangzhou
usertext: To add to the above, you need to abide by the "Duration of Each Stay" and "Enter Before" date on your visa - everything else in your itinerary can change. If you can't travel within those two requirements you would need to apply for a new visa.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: China visa for Guangzhou
usertext: Thanks both. So to clarify, we can say we are going to travel to and from Guangzhou on any of the days we will be in Hong Kong on the visa application, we just need to identify it's before our Hong Kong departure date. We wouldn't need to travel on the exact date but we would need to go for the correct duration requested, in our case just one day? Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: China visa for Guangzhou
usertext: At least pre-pandemic, China always seemed to ignore the date you planned to enter and just started your visa from the issuance date. Some who applied too far in advance got caught by that.

subject: 5. Re: China visa for Guangzhou
usertext: You will also need to provide an address in China - you can basically just use any hotel for that. I've never been asked for actual tickets, if they ask you can tell them you intend to take the East Rail to the border and the Shenzhen-Guangzhou train from there, buying tickets for that train on the spot in Shenzhen. That's a very common route. My experience is also pre-pandemic, things may have changed since.

subject: 6. Re: China visa for Guangzhou
usertext: I have visited Guangzhou about 30 times on business, done the visa applications many times in 30 years. I just filled in general dates within reason, but never exactly because I didn't have the exact dates yet. As for hotel or address in Guangzhou, I always filled in Garden Hotel, but often stayed in other hotels. Never any problem, they don't check.

subject: 7. Re: China visa for Guangzhou
usertext: I am going to do the same trip in two weeks (starting in hong kong, then entering mainland via train). my L tourist visa was approved last friday, it has the start validity date as last friday. in the application i just provided data about my flights in/out hong kong and a booking for an hotel in mainland which was refundable and i will probably change

subject: 1. Re: Day trip to include Ngong Ping Cable-Car, Buddha and Macao.
usertext: You could go to Macau by Hong Kong - Zhuhai - Macao Bridge (HZMB) Bus. When you return to Tung Chung, take a bus B6 to the HZMB Border (10min), then take a HZMB bus to Macau (65 HKD for single ride, 45 min to arrive Macau border). There is no reason to go back to downtown for the ferry. However, I think Macau worth 1 night to stay,

subject: 2. Re: Day trip to include Ngong Ping Cable-Car, Buddha and Macao.
usertext: Actually if you open Google map, you could see there is a highway connecting Lantau and Macau.

subject: 3. Re: Day trip to include Ngong Ping Cable-Car, Buddha and Macao.
usertext: Macau essentially is a different country. You have ignored the time it takes to cross the borders (exit Hong Kong, enter Macau, and vice versa) in addition to transportation time (plus waiting time) between Hong Kong border and Macau border, and transportation time between where you are and the borders and where you want to go (that's on both sides). It takes a good 2 to 3 hours, one-way, of transportation overhead between Hong Kong and Macau. If you go as you planned, @1000 am take the cable car up Ngong Ping, by the time you reach Macau it is late afternoon or near dark. Many of the places you are thinking of visiting/sight-seeing can be closed or close to closing. Seems to lose the meaning. If your aim is to visit casinos/hotels, or Macau Tower, and perhaps play a few hands then return to Hong Kong it would be all right.

subject: 4. Re: Day trip to include Ngong Ping Cable-Car, Buddha and Macao.
usertext: Another thing to keep in mind in regard to Macau is that traffic is a mess there and travelling around from one place to another is often very slow and unpredictable compared to what you will experience in HK. As such, you need to budget buffer time for getting around between the Port Passenger Building and downtown and/or the Cotai Strip. The good news is that if you do want to visit both, there is 24 hour a day transportation between HK and Macau. The best news in addition to the slow travel around Macau, most World Heritage attractions and museums close around 6pm so you might find little sightseeing time once you arrive. The major casino properties are open late so if this is what you want. In the end, like HPFT says... Macau is basically like visiting a different country and there is a heck of a lot to see/do there now so a 1/2 day visit is really short. You are going to wish you invested a full day at least if not an overnight stay.

subject: 1. Re: Food Itinerary Questions
usertext: Check openrice for reviews and suggestions. Maxim is nice, but I wouldn't call it "must eat". And certainly don't include McDonald's in a list of food itinerary for Hong Kong.

subject: 2. Re: Food Itinerary Questions
usertext: {Kowloon Station - M+ Museum - HK Palace Museum - Kowloon Station - which option will work better? Is the cafe at M+ nicer than that at Palace Museum (Crepes & Bakes, Lucky Star Food Truck?} Note that M+ and HK Palace Museum are both fairly large museums with many exhibition halls. They are both very different types of museums as well. Best to allow 2-3 hours for each to visit leisurely. The food scene at West Kowloon Culture District is just ok. Little in the form of amazing food. Crepes & Bakes is just ok, quite pricey for French style crepes and galettes if I'm to be honest. We tried most of the places out here, probably Caf Bohme is perhaps the best option - pretty good pizza there. If you want better dining, head back to Elements Mall at Austin Station, 15 minute walk from M+ Museum. There are some good eateries there, I like Dim Sum Library for sort of upscale dim sum. ;-) {I understand that this  near Science Museum is opened by a HK actor which I like very much. Is the food very nice here?} Haven't tried this place. Here are local reviews on openrice (see link) https://www.openrice.com/zh/hongkong/r-%E6%B8%AF%E6%BD%AE%E6%A8%93-%E5%B0%96%E6%B2%99%E5%92%80-%E7%B2%B5%E8%8F%9C-%E5%BB%A3%E6%9D%B1-%E6%B5%B7%E9%AE%AE-r49160

subject: 10. Re: Food Itinerary Questions
usertext: Most of the places you mentioned aren't "must eats." There are many similar restaurants or eateries. Maxim's Palace at City Hall is often recommended because they have a nice harbor view and they still push the dim sum carts around like the old days. In terms of food quality, they are just ok. Prices are on the high side for what they give you. For places like One Dim Sum, there are many, many of such places in the city now. Federal Restaurant is rather non-descript. You might want to try Very Good Restaurant at TST for breakfast. I have no idea whether Very Good is really very good, but it's been around for a long time. They also serve some traditional dim sum that you don't easily find elsewhere these days.  is ok (I have been there multiple times, including a few times this year). It's nothing to rave about though. Overall, their price/quality ratio is probably slightly above average. As to the actor you mentioned, I once saw him at the restaurant many years ago but I am not sure if he still has a share in the business.

subject: 13. Re: Food Itinerary Questions
usertext: Add Wanchai itinerary - lunch Kam's Roast Goose, Wan Chai Market - dried goods shopping & Blue House, Lee Tung Avenue and Starstreet Precinct, early dinner in Francis & then Pacific Place window shopping.

subject: 14. Re: Food Itinerary Questions
usertext: Many dried seafood products from tai o or cheung chau island are actually from China.

subject: 15. Re: Food Itinerary Questions
usertext: Kam's Roast Goose became famous because it's an offshoot from the family that owns Yung Kee in central. In terms of food quality, it's ok but if you see a very long line, it's probably not worth the wait. The restaurant is very popular with tourists. HK Island's most famous dried seafood area is located at Des Voeux Road West at Sai Ying Pun. Most shops there have been around for a long time and they should be reputable. In Kowloon, some of my relatives go to Tak Hing at Woosung St (one block north of the rear entrance of Wing On department store). On Kee is a chain with multiple locations. I think they are a bit more expensive. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 16. Re: Food Itinerary Questions
usertext: Yes, I went to Sheung Wan to buy dried seafood. Dried Seafood Street and Tonic Food Street https://www.landmark.hk/en/visit/around-central/dried-seafood-street-and-tonic-food-street

subject: 17. Re: Food Itinerary Questions

subject: 18. Re: Food Itinerary Questions
usertext: On Kee is one of the famous and reliable dried seafood stores. You can check the prices https://www.onkee.com/categories/featured-products On Hing Ho is another good but smaller store. https://m.facebook.com/onhingho

subject: 19. Re: Food Itinerary Questions
usertext: I am sure there are stores at the Wan Chai Market area that sell dried seafood items. The area just isn't famous for it. You will also find vendors at the Cross St Market just around the corner. Those are small merchants so they don't have any sort of reputation. At Queen's Road East, the one shop I know of that sells high-end dried seafood, condiments and sauces is Goodies (). They trend more on the expensive side. They also have a shop at Kowloon City.

subject: 20. Re: Food Itinerary Questions
usertext: Not in Wan Chai. Not along Queen's Road East for dried seafood. You will be disappointed. The more "in" area for dried seafood is at Sheung Wan. Along Des Voeux Rd W as mentioned. (Basically along the ding ding tram tracks, on both sides of the street). From Wan Chai, just hop on a ding ding tram going west board (destinations Shek Tong Tsui, Whitty Street, Kennedy Town are all okay). You alight at around Wing Lok Street (there are lots of such shops on Wing Lok Street too), along the ding ding tram tracks, for about 3 blocks or so. Full of seafood shops. You need shop with your eyes, and your nose, LOL. You need to know your goods and general pricing. You will find quality products. But bear in mind quality demands higher prices. You should have in mind what kind of price you are willing to pay for "what". Prices vary quite a bit because of sizes and quality. Hard to generalize and come up with an excel spreadsheet. Maybe compare to what prices you would need to pay for similar products back home (with currencies converted in your head). You buy, or pass. There are so many shops within close proximity. Just walk around and see what may strike your interest. Try to have a specific grade/type to buy when you walk into a shop, and not let the shop-keepers up-sell you. Look for those shops that are crowded with local senior women. They always know good deals.

subject: The Mira or Gateway Hotel or Holiday Inn Golden?
usertext: Can anyone suggest which is the better hotel amongst the 3 I mentioned? I will be traveling with my family which consists of 3 adults, the last time we've been in Hong Kong was like 6 years ago. It's been awhile.Thanks in advance!

subject: 1. Re: The Mira or Gateway Hotel or Holiday Inn Golden?
usertext: The Mira is supposed to be the nicest. Holiday Inn GM is the best located because it's the closest to MTR stations, but Mira isn't too much further. Gateway is located at Harbour City on Canton Road. Harbour City is one of the more crowded shopping malls because lots of visitors shop there.

subject: 2. Re: The Mira or Gateway Hotel or Holiday Inn Golden?
usertext: Holiday Inn is... well it is a Holiday Inn. That's the oldest among them. I have seen it built in the 60's. Rooms have been renovated over the years, I am sure. But still may be dated. Gateway is a Marco Polo brand. More upscale. The Mira, more trendy. You can view the inside of the rooms and pick. Gateway is a little farther from the Tsim Sha Tsui MTR Station. But if you taxi around, wouldn't make a difference. Gateway can offer harbour view rooms I think. Mira can't.

subject: Opinion on One-Eight-One Hotel and suggestions
usertext: Hi, Please let me know whether staying at the 'One-Eight-One Hotel and Serviced apartments' is a good choice. In terms of location (close to MTR stations and to take the ferry to Lantau Island and Lamma Islands), value for money? We are looking for comfort, convenience and sea views from the room. We would prefer to stay on HK Island as we also have a family wedding and get together mid September. There seems to be a large number of hotels, I'm finding it difficult to decide. Also, since we'll stay for 4 days after the wedding and want to do trekking and other non-touristy sightseeing, maybe there are options other than on HK Island that may be less expensive and just as nice? Lantau Island for instance? Thanks in advance.

subject: 1. Re: Opinion on One-Eight-One Hotel and suggestions
usertext: "One-Eight-One Hotel and Serviced apartments' is a good choice. " Not familiar with this property but reviews here on TA and Google reviews look ok. Not as close to an MTR Station as I like but its a pretty good area around HKU and Kennedy Town with some decent promenade nearby if you are eager to be near the sea and Victoria Harbour. Another hotel option that I like is called East. They are on the other side of HK Island at Quarry Bay. Rooms are modern, nice and some have great views of the harbour. Importantly, they are right next to the entrance to Tai Koo MTR Station, allowing you to get around the city quickly. I'd give a look see of this property as well. You mention "good value" and about other options other than on HK Island that may be less expensive and just as nice? I might also suggest looking into Hyatt Regency at University. It is in a different part of Hong Kong, just outside University MTR Station near ShaTin. They have rooms with excellent views of Tolo Harbour and if trekking is a big interest, it is closer to some of the best hiking and country parks in HK. As this property is further away from HK Island and Kowloon, they usually offer noticeably lower room rates. Lastly, with the extension of the MTR East Rail Line last year, University Station is now connected all the way to Admiralty Station on HK Island - 35 min travel time from hotel door to Admiralty. By comparison 1-8-1 is 20 minutes away from the same location on HK Island. Anyway, just a couple of suggestions to think about. Good luck with your search and hope you find a place you are happy with.

subject: 2. Re: Opinion on One-Eight-One Hotel and suggestions
usertext: I don't know much about the hotel myself. I did see a YouTuber who stayed there for a weeks during the height of Covid quarantine requirement. They stayed in a large suite so it was quite nice. Location-wise, it's not bad as it's just a short walk to HKU station.

subject: 3. Re: Opinion on One-Eight-One Hotel and suggestions
usertext: As an alternative, have a look at The Connaught - a similar serviced apartment/hotel place on Connaught Road West. Excellent harbour views, especially from the higher floors (say floors 16-30). Very close to Sai Ying Pun MTR exit A2 (albeit that you then have to walk some distance underground to the platform); very close to the tram line and many buses; across the street from the Sun Yat Sen Park; and only 25 minutes walk along the waterfront promenade to the Central Ferry Piers.

subject: 4. Re: Opinion on One-Eight-One Hotel and suggestions
usertext: Thank you all very much for your suggestions.

subject: 15 Hour Layover in Hong Kong - Group of 23
usertext: Hi all! I know there are multiple posts regarding long layovers in Hong Kong but I think the current situation requires a post of its own. I will be travelling with a group of 26 people (including me) from New Zealand to Netherlands via Hong Kong both ways. On our return flight from Netherlands to New Zealand there will be a 15 hour layover in Hong Kong at the beginning of June. I think the first question would be are we allowed to leave the airport at all or would we require visa's to leave the airport? If no, then it makes the rest of the post obsolete. However if we don't need visa's, does anyone have any ideas/suggestions of what me and the group could do during this time? Ideally whatever we did during this 15 hour period would be under $100-150 NZD/per person. Things that I'm trying to keep in mind: - Easy activities that can accommodate our group - Easy access too and from the airport as we don't want anything to delay us catching our flight back to New Zealand - A decent experience of what Hong Kong has to offer - Cool sites to take great group photos at - We do have a few plus size people (not too sure how this might impact some activities) - If I've missed anything out that you think I should be looking into please let me know :) As this is the first time all of us will be going to Hong Kong or even long-haul international travel, I'd love to have a fair idea of what to do in Hong Kong that is relatively easy and smooth to follow. Or if this isn't something that can/should be planned over the internet, would I be better off going to a local travel agent? Looking forward to hearing all the great advice from you all! Very excited about this trip :) Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 1. Re: 15 Hour Layover in Hong Kong - Group of 23
usertext: Sorry forgot to mention flight details! Arrival into Hong Kong 6:00AM departing 9:10PM local time

subject: 3. Re: 15 Hour Layover in Hong Kong - Group of 23
usertext: Given your situation, I think you should consider a coach tour arranged by a private guide. I'm going to message you contact details of someone who conducts food tours/private tours in English. Really nice and fun gal who may be able to sort something out for you.

subject: 4. Re: 15 Hour Layover in Hong Kong - Group of 23
usertext: Does your group follow the leader, or is it like herding cats? If they follow the leader, I would DIY. Take the Airport Express Train to the HK Station (last station), (HKD$115, same day return fare). Stretch your legs by walking to the Peak Tram terminus (30 min). Take the Peak Tram up to the Peak (HKD $148 return fare). Walk around the Peak, take your iconic HK group photo. Lunch is going to be a problem with that many people. I personally like the Peak Cafe (Peak Lookout?), as it has historical interest for me (was there when I lived in HK, many many years ago.). But it's not cheap. Or you can wait till you get down from the Peak. Try to avoid the office lunch hours (12 to 2). There are many restaurants inside the IFC mall, where the Airport Express Train station is. If your group don't mind fast food, there is a Pret a Manger there. Or your group can break up for lunch. Then after lunch, take the Star Ferry over to Kowloon (another iconic HK photo op). Fare is HKD $5. Maybe have afternoon tea at the Peninsula, another iconic HK activity. I personally prefer another location, as the Peninsula is very touristy. And it'll be difficult witha group of 23. Next, more walking, maybe along the famous Nathan Road (photo op), but don't buy anything there. After an early dinner, back to the airport.

subject: 5. Re: 15 Hour Layover in Hong Kong - Group of 23
usertext: Sorry another edit (was writing original post at ungodly hours of the morning), we'll be in Hong Kong at the beginning of July NOT June.

subject: Recommendations for BBQ Pork Pastry
usertext: HI TA community, any recommendations where to get good BBQ Pork Pastry ()? Many many years (decades) ago, we tried our first ever BBQ Pork Pastry in HK and loved it! Tried to research but couldn't find any blogs/articles covering it. Thanks in advance.

subject: 1. Re: Recommendations for BBQ Pork Pastry
usertext: It's a common item at most dim sum places. It's one of my favorite dishes, and a must order whenever I go dim sum. But I don't know if it's special enough to have articles covering it. You can make your own. Plenty of recipes on YouTube. Just search for .

subject: 2. Re: Recommendations for BBQ Pork Pastry
usertext: I agree with what TSS said above regarding this item. I would say 80% of Cantonese restaurants offer it. On the other hand, it's not considered a notably special item. I have friends who like it, but nobody ever says "we will go to restaurant X because their "char siu so" is the best.

subject: 3. Re: Recommendations for BBQ Pork Pastry
usertext: In dim sum restaurants you usually get the steamed version; in bakeries you can find the baked version. Both are good. When you're at a bakery, make sure to add some egg tart as well, and maybe a pineapple bun. Two other typical Hong Kong bakery staples.

subject: 4. Re: Recommendations for BBQ Pork Pastry
usertext: Thank you everyone for all your replies. They're very helpful.

subject: 5. Re: Recommendations for BBQ Pork Pastry
usertext: I think "char siu so" is supposed to be baked. They have steam version ? Is it bbq pork bun? Don't know who has the best char siu so. But imo Ritz carlton has thr best bbq pork.

subject: 6. Re: Recommendations for BBQ Pork Pastry
usertext: I think @wvmarle mistakenly thought you were talking about "char siu chan bau", which is the Westernized version of the traditional "char siu bau" (bbq pork bun). The Westernized typically has a clear, sugary glaze on top of a slightly sweet bread. The contrast of the bun's sweetness and the char siu's salty flavor makes it an interesting and flavorful. There are also "char siu chan bau" with the pineapple bun's crust top at many Chinese restaurants now. But these are not "char siu so."

subject: 7. Re: Recommendations for BBQ Pork Pastry
usertext: Yes, I was referring to the baked ones. Something like this https://mission-food.com/dim-sum-and-then-some-char-siu-pastries/

subject: 8. Re: Recommendations for BBQ Pork Pastry
usertext: I don't think I've even ever heard the name "char siu chan bau". Neither have I ever seen the ones linked in #7 - though I've seen close varieties like the baked one linked below. Dim sum versions I'm thinking of: https://thewoksoflife.com/steamed-bbq-pork-buns-char-siu-bao/ (steamed) and https://thewoksoflife.com/chinese-bbq-pork-buns-cha-siu-bao/ (baked). Bakery is indeed more like a bbq pork filled pinapple bun. All of those are perfectly delicious in their own right, and highly recommended to try out. Chances are you'll love those varieties, too.

subject: 9. Re: Recommendations for BBQ Pork Pastry
usertext: Traditional Char Siu Bao  (bao = bun) is usually served at dim sum in restaurants. Sometimes you can buy them frozen in supermarkets. The dough is steamed and it should be fluffy and white in color. Char Siu Chan Bao is a variation. Instead of a steamed bun, the dough is baked and hence the name "chan bao = dinner roll'. So the top can be slightly browned due to an egg wash, or may have a sweet yellowish coating like pineapple buns. Char Siu Sou  is also baked. But instead of a bread dough, it uses a puff pastry so the sou is pastry-flaky. All three types will have bbq pork inside. But you can find Char Siu Chan Bao or Char Siu Sou on bakeries, because you can eat them "at room temperature'. Traditional Char Siu Bao is usually only served hot at dim sum, because the bao loses the fluffiness when cooled. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Tsim sha tsui star ferry pier to M+
usertext: Hi! Looking on google maps, the walk from the Star Ferry Pier at Tsim Sha Tsui to M+ is over one hour. Is there really no promenade along the water to reach it by walking? Tried to inspect street view photos and it looked like there was some construction in the works, but wondering what the current status is. We visit in early June and are very excited. Thank you!

subject: 1. Re: Tsim sha tsui star ferry pier to M+
usertext: One hour sounds about right. Maybe a little less. You have a 1.2 to 1.5 mile distance to cover. Even if there is a promenade to reach there in the newer landfill area, you still need to walk through the crowded Canton Road. It is the most crowded area in all of Tsim Sha Tsui during the day time. It won't be fast. If you want fast, take a short taxi ride.

subject: 2. Re: Tsim sha tsui star ferry pier to M+
usertext: Take a taxi. Most of Canton Road is quite interesting to walk albeit indeed very crowded, but the stretch along Austin Road is firmly in the "very much not nice" category for walking. On and off footbridges, lots of traffic, very noisy, smelly, polluted - you name it, everything that makes walking unpleasant is there.

subject: 3. Re: Tsim sha tsui star ferry pier to M+
usertext: Thanks @HappyFeet1234 and @wvmarle for your really quick responses! (Apparently quicker than one can walk between there, hehe.)

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Tsim sha tsui star ferry pier to M+
usertext: Google Maps quickest walking route shows a time of 1 hr 7 mins, distance of 5.3km and takes you right up to Tai Kok Tsui and then back down West Kowloon Waterfront Promenade which can't be right; https://goo.gl/maps/Fs6qxQWaqtcpssGy7 M+ on Museum Drive is accessible from Kowloon Station exits C1 & D1; https://webmedia.mplus.org.hk/documents/2023mplus-map-rgb-accessible-en.pdf Even if Austin Road is closed to pedestrians owing to construction work, Kowloon Station / ICC and its connection to M+ should be accessible from Canton Road (if necessary via West Kowloon Station). Museum Drive is also accessible on foot from the roundabout at the junction of Nga Cheung Road / Austin Road under the cross-harbour tunnel footbridge; https://www.mtr.com.hk/archive/ch/services/maps/kow.pdf It appears to me that Google Maps ignores various footbridges and passageways through buildings in the area. Apple Maps shows 1.7 miles and 37 mins which seems more like it.

subject: 5. Re: Tsim sha tsui star ferry pier to M+
usertext: I've walked from Star Ferry to West Kowloon, its around 30-35 minutes point to point if you can make use of the Austin MTR entrance (E) at Xiqu to go under Austin Road West. Come back up through exit (D2 - West Kowloon Station) on the other side of the road. Here you are on an elevated plaza area with no vehicle traffic. Walk west all the way to and through Elements Mall, making your way to the bridge crossing back over W. Austin Road into the Cultural District park. Inside Elements Mall just follow signs pointing to West Kowloon Culture District, past the ICC Sky100 Observation Deck attraction. You will shortly exit Elements Mall on an elevated bridge that puts you right into the park around 1-2 minute walk from the entrance to M+ This route above is a bit laborious and not an easiest to navigate but a heck of a lot shorter and quicker than what Google Maps suggests. You can also take a mini-bus (77M) to avoid the somewhat complicated walking route mentioned above. From Star Ferry, you will need to walk up to the China Ferry Terminal (China Hong Kong City). There is a light green bus pick up directly on Canton Road just in front of the entrance. It drops off along W. Austin Rd. just in front of M+ (next to last stop) after a 5-6 minute ride. This saves you the trouble of having to figure out the route provided above and saves you some walking/feet energy which can be better used in the museum instead. Some resources for the 77M bus below https://www.westkowloon.hk/en/transport https://www.16seats.net/chi/gmb/gk_77m.html Map of the 77M route https://moovitapp.com/index/zh-tw/%E5%85%AC%E5%85%B1%E4%BA%A4%E9%80%9A-line-77M-Hong_Kong-2741-2248609-59976806-0

subject: 6. Re: Tsim sha tsui star ferry pier to M+
usertext: What Hong Kong experts SolentTraveller and BradJill pointed out are very valid and interesting. The walking suggestion from Google Map is indeed not making any sense, sending readers to Tai Kwok Tsui (to the north) and back down south, making the walk 3 times longer. Maybe someone, under the direction of the big boss up north, stops feeding Google the latest details or worse yet starts feeding information that is wrong. (I have seen many cases using Google Map inside China.) The directions by Brad would work and be quicker, but it really needs that person to be a local to be able to take some of the shortcuts and methods. For someone as a foreign tourist who is not familiar with the environment, the disorientation factor, and the street crowd factor (no mapping software includes that) trust me you need to multiply any estimated walking time by 2. So 1 hour is about right. If you want fast, simply take a taxi. HKD ~$30 or so, up to 4 or 5 people.

subject: 7. Re: Tsim sha tsui star ferry pier to M+
usertext: Thank you, everyone, for all this feedback, especially the rule of thumb to double any walking time estimates. We'll try not to overplan our activities so we can enjoy the scenery and buzz along the way

subject: 8. Re: Tsim sha tsui star ferry pier to M+
usertext: Just to clarify. Perhaps you have a more peace of mind: My "double the time estimate" is not a general case for Hong Kong. It is just specific to the walk from Star Ferry Pier to M+. They are the extreme cases, where Canton Road is extra crowded during day time. And currently with all the construction projects, Austin Road must be extra confusing and not pedestrian friendly. I grew up at Haiphong Road crossing Canton Road in the early 60's. Back then it was not too bad. Life was simple. Until Kowloon Godown decided to sell their warehouse real estate and developers turned that land into the present day Marco Polo hotels, Harbour City, and later on China Hong Kong City. And the old Whitfield Barracks was turned over to HK Government, who later turned the barracks into the present day Kowloon Park. And the build-out of many hotels and commercial buildings around that corner... that spot became more and more crowded by the years.

subject: 1. Re: Free day
usertext: 250 Canadian dollar?

subject: 2. Re: Free day
usertext: HK is well served by public transportation. Find a hotel near an MTR (subway) station, and you are good to go. Use a search engine like Booking.com or Agoda, plug in your date and budget, look for hotels in the Tsim Sha Tsui or Causeway Bay area (plus several others).

subject: 3. Re: Free day
usertext: Us Dollars.

subject: 4. Re: Free day
usertext: As long as you choose a hotel near an MTR Station, you will have quick access to plenty of interesting tourist attractions. With that budget amount, I might first look at properties in TST or TST East (Kowloon) which allows you to be also be close to Victoria Harbour for a night walk along the promenade enjoying views of the Hong Kong Skyline.

subject: 8. Re: Hong kong Cityflyer Pre-paid Return Ticket Citybus
usertext: The Pre-Paid Return ticket can only be purchased from the Customer Service Centre at the Airport Ground Transportation Centre during its opening hours of 8am to 8pm and is no longer available online. The discrepancy in opening hours between the link in #1 and elsewhere on the website in your original post was pointed out to Citybus and they only just replied. The message about the e-Shop page only being a testing site wasn't there when I looked after your original post so was probably added in response to the query. The Pre-Paid Return Ticket can also be purchased at Admiralty (East) Bus Terminus Customer Service Centre 2-45pm to 6-45pm except Sundays, Wednesdays and public holidays but this wouldn't be of use to arrivals at the airport.

subject: Food Comments and Recommendations
usertext: Hi TA community, I've more or less assembled the list of food to consider for our trip. Would like to request for additional recommendations on those that are nice but do not have super long lines (i.e. hidden gems). Also preference (but not necessarily) around the Wan Chai area where we are staying...am thin on dimsum and dining suggestions around our area. Breakfast - Australian Dairy Company, Capital Cafe (Wan Chai) Dimsum - Tim Ho Wan, One Dim Sum, Chau Kee Dim Sum Lau Char Siu - Kam's Roast Goose (Wan Chai), Joy Hing (Wan Chai) Dining - Golden Zone Cafe, Very Good Seafood Restaurant Noodles - Tsim Chai Kee, Maks Noodle Dessert - Yee Shun Dairy Company, Kung Wo Tofu, Kai Kai Dessert Egg Tarts - Honolulu Cafe (Wan Chai), Bakehouse (Wan Chai) Egg Puffs - Lee Keung Kee, Mammy Pancake Others - Kam Wah Cafe (Pineapple Polo Bun), Cheung Hing Kee (Pan-fried buns, Wan Chai), Hang Heung (Wife's Biscuit) Many thanks. (As a side note while on my research, I find it sad that some recommended ones have since closed.)

subject: 1. Re: Food Comments and Recommendations
usertext: Golden Zone: I have never heard of it until now. Reviews don't seem to indicate it's anything special? Australia Dairy and Capital Cafe serve basically the same menu. I wouldn't make an effort to go to both. Also, Australia Dairy is closed on Thursdays so keep that in mind. AD does make very good egg custard and milk custard desserts. I actually like those better than their signature soup macaroni and eggs. They are also much better than Yee Shun. Maks is way overpriced with very small portions. I can't tell you where else to eat Cantonese style wontons though. I do recommend Kong Chai Kee at Canal Road East (just behind Times Square) for their Chiu Chau style fish ball, beef brisket, and fish dumpling noodles. Honolulu Cafe is way overrated. Don't bother. As to egg tarts, many tea cafes now make them. As long as you catch a fresh batch, most of them are pretty decent.

subject: 2. Re: Food Comments and Recommendations
