subject: 3. Re: Chinese herbs/spices
usertext: For cooking: supermarkets, wet markets (mostly dry good section but you find some also in the vegetables section), street stalls. In general: places where food is sold. If you're after the traditional stuff, you best bet will be the wet markets and shops around them.

subject: 4. Re: Chinese herbs/spices
usertext: Maybe check out the many dry goods stores in Sheung Wan, Wing Lok street.

subject: 5. Re: Chinese herbs/spices
usertext: For the "good" stuff, check out the Sheung Wan to Sai Ying Pun area from Wing Lok St as mentioned to Des Voeux Road West along the tram tracks. If you visit a wet market complex, there is usually a dry goods area where some shops sell such spices and various condiments. If the wet market is located at street level, you just have to walk around and look for a shop.

subject: 6. Re: Chinese herbs/spices
usertext: Check out the Yue Hwa Department Store on Nathan Road in Jordan. There's a supermarket in the basement that stocks all sorts of interesting foodstuffs from the Mainland. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: Chinese herbs/spices
usertext: Could you be more specific about what herbs you are looking for?

subject: 8. Re: Chinese herbs/spices
usertext: If you will be visiting the Mong Kok area, I happened to walk by 459 Reclamation Street yesterday. They are a dedicated spice store that some of my friends have patronized previously. You probably need to know Cantonese or use an online translator to let them know what you want. Use Google Map to find the store and Streetview to see what it looks like.

subject: Shuttle buses from Airport Express stations
usertext: We have noted here that the previous MTR-run shuttle buses from Hong Kong and Kowloon Airport Express stations no longer exist. However, I just noticed (and I don't think it's been mentioned here before) that a few hotels do run their own shuttle services as listed here: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/hotel-shuttle-service.html Currently these include: Hong Kong: Bishop Lei International House Cosmo Hotel Dorsett Wanchai Four Seasons Hotel Hong Kong Le Meridien Hong Kong, Cyberport Kowloon Alva Hotel by Royal It isn't clear to me whether these are scheduled or somehow on request - I guess you need to contact the individual hotels to find out.

subject: Cable Car / Tai O Village / Bus Timings
usertext: Hi, We will be in HK for 4 days with three kids, ages 3, 6, and 8 and really want to take the cable car to see the big buddha, then Tai O Village, and possibly a boat ride once there to try to spot the pink dolphins. Unfortunately, realistically we will only have time to do this on our first day in HK. We land at 10am. Will there be time to get to our hotel in TST, then go to Tung Chung to take the cable car, see the Big Buddha, take the bus to Tai-O, walk around and maybe do the boat ride if time permits, and then head back to TST in the evening? I guess most of this would depend on bus timings? Does anyone know when the last bus would be from Tai O, and what time the last cable car runs? Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Cable Car / Tai O Village / Bus Timings
usertext: Tung Chung is near the airport. If you have to go to TST first, you'll be backtracking back to the airport area for the Big Buddha. You may want to first store your luggage at the Citygate mall, visit Big Buddha and Tai O. Then pick up your luggage and go to your hotel.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Cable Car / Tai O Village / Bus Timings
usertext: The cable car runs until 6pm, except on some public holidays when it extends to 6-30pm. Bus 21 operates between Ngong Ping Village (location of the Big Buddha) and Tai O and the timetable is here; https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/detail/19 Bus 11 from Tai O to Tung Chung is frequent and operates until after midnight; https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/detail/14 However, as stated by TSS above, the Tung Chung cable car terminus is very close to the airport and if you propose travelling from the airport to Tsim Sha Tsui and then to Tung Chung this involves doubling back on yourselves and wasting a lot of travelling time which could be avoided if you are able to go straight from the airport to Tung Chung where luggage can be stored at the cable car terminus (until close of cable car service); https://www.np360.com.hk/en/visitors-information/faqs or in lockers at Citygate Outlets Mall (to 11pm); https://www.citygateoutlets.com.hk/-/media/Images/SwireCitygate/SitePdfs/Pdfs/locker_service.ashx?rev=6fb8ce723cd14ea09cb9b0db88387cd3

subject: 3. Re: Cable Car / Tai O Village / Bus Timings
usertext: Switch the activities with another day. Your timing is far less than ideal, with 3 young kids to attend to, all your luggage, and a hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui. Tung Chung (Cable Car Station) can be reached with MTR so it is not a big deal. You land at 10 am. In all likelihood, you won't reach your hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui until noon or 1 pm (unless you take a taxi there. But 5 passengers with luggage, you may need 2 taxi). When you get back to Tung Chung, it is likely 2 pm or later. Switch to do thing you have planned for around Tsim Sha Tsui on a different day. Then get an early start to visit cable car, Po Lin Big Buddha and Tai O that day.

subject: 4. Re: Cable Car / Tai O Village / Bus Timings
usertext: Thanks, our current plan is to take a taxi from the airport to the hotel. This is actually only a long weekend trip for us so we won't have much luggage at all. Then take the MTR to Tung Chung, ride the cable car and then take the bus to Tai O. After walking around Tai O, are there any options to get back to TST except for taking the bus to the cable car to get to Tung Chung? Can I take a taxi from Tai O to TST, or is there a bus, etc?

subject: 5. Re: Cable Car / Tai O Village / Bus Timings
usertext: There are other options than taking the cable car again. But you cannot take a taxi directly from Tai O to Tsim Sha Tsui because of taxi licensing regulations. You can take a Blue Taxi from Tai O back to Tung Chung - the taxi stand is outside the Tung Chung MTR Station. You can switch (at the same taxi stand, just maybe 40-50 meters away) to take a Red Taxi who is licensed to take you to Tsim Sha Tsui. Or you can also switch to take the MTR (subway/metro) to Tsim Sha Tsui. There is another way: to take a Lantau Bus #1 from Tai O to Mui Wo Pier: Link: https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/detail/2 Board the next ferry to Central Pier. Then walk to the nearby Star Ferry Pier (Central Pier #7) to cross the harbour to Tsim Sha Tsui. This route takes much longer, but it is a scenic tour route if you have extra time. Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Cable Car / Tai O Village / Bus Timings
usertext: You can also take frequent bus 11 directly from Tai O to Tung Chung without the need to return to the cable car at Ngong Ping. There are also ferries from Tai O to Tung Chung operated by Fortune Ferry with a scenic journey taking about 35 mins; https://www.td.gov.hk/en/transport_in_hong_kong/public_transport/ferries/service_details/index.html#o07

subject: 7. Re: Cable Car / Tai O Village / Bus Timings
usertext: Thank you all, super helpful. So provided that I am not restricted to getting on that last cable car at 6pm, the day actually seems quite doable given that I can take numerous other options to get back to TST? My fear was not being able to get back to the hotel that evening.

subject: 8. Re: Cable Car / Tai O Village / Bus Timings
usertext: RE: "My fear was not being able to get back to the hotel that evening." = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = No such worry. Transportation in Hong Kong is 24x7. Tai O may be an extreme case being at the most far-west corner of human settlement on an island in Hong Kong... still you should be able to catch a blue taxi. The small village may "shut down" way before the last bus departs. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Hong Kong Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: Hey ppl, I plan to go to HK in summer holiday this august. I confused to choose the themepark in HK, bevause disneyland is too pricey with the peak plus price and ppl said it is the smallest disneyland. What do you think if it is compared to Ocean Park? Would I regret to choose Ocean Park over Disneyland? I think to choose Tokyo disney next year. What do you think?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: I've never been to Disneyland, but I've been to Ocean Park several times and it's a fantastic day out. As well as all the rides, there are lots of other attractions, including pandas, penguins, an aquarium and eco trails to explore. If you have the chance to visit the bigger Disney site in Tokyo next year, I definitely wouldn't miss out on visiting Ocean Park this year.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: One vote for Ocean Park from me.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: I feel Disneyland HK is more suitable for young children. The rides would not excite older children and adults. Ocean Park has more diverse offerings.

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: I've been to both Disneyland and Ocean Park, on the same Hong Kong trip a few years ago, with a few friends - a mix of adults and three under 8 y.o. kids. If you're alone or with other adults and no young kids, you'll likely enjoy a day at Ocean Park much more than Disneyland. With some smaller kids along, they may have more fun at Disneyland, but as said above with a trip to Tokyo Disneyland planned and if you can only visit one, Ocean Park would be the better choice.

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: They are completely different type of Theme Parks. One is Disney which is self-explanatory and the other is an Ocean and education themed park with some fun rides. Have you spent time researching them by going through their websites, watching Youtube videos of the parks so you can see and understand the differences between the two? This is always the best way to learn about attractions like theme parks to determine if they are right for your and your family/group before making decision to purchase pricey entry tickets.

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: I have been to both of them, and other 2 Asian Disneylands. I guess HK will be very crowded this August(I plan to visit also). If you plan to visit Disney Tokyo next year, I would recommend you go to Ocean Park.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: October hotel prices
usertext: Coming mid October for 8 nights. We been fortunate to have visited Hong Kong few times but this time hotels are quite a bit dearer. Is it just too early and prices hopefully will drop or like everything else that's just way of life now. Thank you in advance

subject: 1. Re: October hotel prices
usertext: Your guess is probably as good as anyone else's. Do note that mid October is peak season (national day golden week is the first week of October & Canton Fair which also normally draws many people to Hong Kong). High prices are to be expected.

subject: 2. Re: October hotel prices
usertext: Mid-October is post Golden Week but it's the peak convention season for foreign visitors. If you want to go during those dates, book something that can be cancelled for now and then keep checking. Post Covid, who knows whether all these business related visitors will come back?

subject: 3. Re: October hotel prices
usertext: The pandemic has really brought out the worst from some businesses IMO, especially when it comes to service cuts and adding all sorts of junk fees. This is not unique to HK either.

subject: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: Hi, We're a family of four with two teenagers planning a vacation to Hong Kong in July for the very first time. The question we have is how long do we need in Hong Kong? Is 1 week enough or do we have to stretch it to 10days? We would like to visit both the island and Macau. Note: We're interested in all activities apart from hiking.

subject: 1. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: Depends on how much of Hong Kong you want to see. 1 week is good but since you are visiting Macau as well then 10 days would be more leisurely, not overly rushed. Many visitors do transit tours of Hong Kong from 2 to 4 days to view the highlights only.

subject: 2. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: Hong Kong doesn't really have all that many "check'em off a list" places to see. You mainly walk around, eat here and there, and absorb the vibe of the city. Some people love that kind of travel while others bore quickly, so it depends on you.

subject: 3. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: HK does have a number of check off list of attractions. Just check the HK Tourism website. For HK, even including Macau, 1 week is OK. But if you want to spend a couple of days touring Macau also, maybe 10 days.

subject: 4. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: I'd say a general rule of thumb would go something like Just the famous stops - 1 day (layover visits) HK Highlights only - 3 days (long weekend visitors) Highlights plus more of the good stuff - 5 days More in depth HK - 7 days (not difficult to keep busy for a week if you have the time, plus you may want to allow time for jet lag recovery and transportation/hotel check-ins that eat up a lot of time on Day 1 and 7) HK enthusiast - 8-10 days HK+Macau Just the famous stops (+1 day in Macau) - Day trip from HK Highlights (+2 days in Macau) Highlights plus more (+3 days in Macau) In Depth Macau (+4 days in Macau) Macau enthusiast (wouldn't be asking on a TA forum) :-)

subject: 5. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: Usually you can finish your trip in HK and Macau in one week, HK 5 + Macau 1 or 2(my first time), but the 2 cities worth 10 day's trip.

subject: 6. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: I suggest one week overall with a couple of days reserved for Macau. If you stay for a week in HK, you can see HK more in depth and also go hiking and take trips to the outlaying islands. However, July will be hot and humid so it's a bit tough to do these activities.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: We too are doing a first timer visit in 2024 - although I accept it's not a huge place, where is the best location to stay to make the most use of the time there (5 days?).

subject: 8. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: I'd suggest Causeway Bay or North Point. Lively convenient areas. Compact and easy to walk around (except for the crowds).

subject: 9. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: Also consider Tsim Sha Tsui or Mongkok.

subject: 10. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: #7 {where is the best location to stay to make the most use of the time there (5 days?).} If you use the Search Box at the top of this forum page and type in 'where to stay' you will be able to read endless past questions on this topic. Some depends on how many nights you are here, what your sightseeing focus will be but generally speaking as long as you are near an MTR in a generally centralised location on HK Island or the Kowloon Peninsula, you'll be fine location wise.

subject: 11. Re: First Ever visit to Hong Kong
usertext: With the more thorough MTR coverage nowadays, anywhere no Nathan Road between Mong Kok and Tsim Sha Tsui, then Hung Hom on the Kowloon side are very convenient. Even areas like To Kwa Wan and Kowloon City are good if you can find the right hotel. On the Island side, I suggest somewhere between Causeway Bay and Sai Ying Pun. North Point and Fortress Hill are serviceable, too but the MTR stations there are built way deep into the underground so you always have more walking to do.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Flying CX LHR - HKG, passport validity question
usertext: Hi all, I'm a British citizen flying from LHR to HKG on CX in two weeks (for 9 days). My passport expires end of September and thus I'm within the "6 month period". I know HK immigration won't have a problem, but has anyone experienced CX being difficult about this? Thanks, Anthony

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Flying CX LHR - HKG, passport validity question
usertext: Hong Kong Immigration passport validity requirement is for one month beyond your intended date of departure. Cathay Pacific has a six month passport validity requirement a a condition for online check -in. Since it appears your passport will have less than six months validity you will need to check in at the airport.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Flying CX LHR - HKG, passport validity question
usertext: Also, don't forget that if your current passport was renewed 10 years ago, at that time they were still adding on up to 9 months of unexpired time from your old passport. However, the present rules state that passports are only valid for 10 years after the date of issue, regardless of what the expiry date may say. So it's possible that even if your passport states an expiry date of September, it may already be invalid and if your current passport was a renewal of an old one, you need to check.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Flying CX LHR - HKG, passport validity question
usertext: Thanks for your reply. I called Cathay and they advised the ten year rule only applies to flights going to the EU, and Hong Kong Immigration/the airline doesn't enforce it. So I should be all good.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Flying CX LHR - HKG, passport validity question
usertext: Thanks for your reply, yes I'm aware I need to check in at the airport. I called Cathay and their helpline said there should be no issue, other than the fact HK immigration might ask to see my return ticket.

subject: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: Hello We are a family of 4 (with 2 grown kids), intend to be in HK for 1.5 days on August, landing on Sunday at 15:00, and leaving HK the night after, on Tuesday at 02:00 am. We would like to see the city as much as possible on Sunday, and visit Disneyland on Monday. We have 2 options for hotels: 1.Hong Kong Skycity Marriott Hotel- will be comfortable to leave the luggage and easy access to Disneyland (taxi?). At this opportunity we will probably take the airport express train to the city and back on Sunday. However, I don't know how much time will be left, since we need to first take the shuttle to the hotel, and we will have to go and come back from Hong Kong station in the city. 2. Holiday inn Golden Mile - this might be more comfortable for the first day (taxi?), but we will have to go with all our luggage. What do you reccommended for us? Which of these 2 option is better?

subject: 1. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: Questions first, to clarify: #1) Do you have any brand loyalty involved? Such as using Marriott points or Holiday Inn points? #2) It sounds like you are booking the hotel for 1 night only - Sunday night - correct? For Monday you won't be needing the room for another night before your flight? Since you planned to go to Disneyland on Monday and nowhere else, staying at Holiday Inn Golden Mile will not help you (actually will create a burden of going back there to retrieve your luggage and then to the Airport again, if you don't use the room for a second night. One suggestion is to stay at Hong Kong's one and only airport hotel: Regal Airport Hotel Hong Kong You can walk there with your luggage. It is connected indoor from the Arrival Hall. About ~1000 ft (300m). There you can drop off your luggage, get your room, walk back to the airport to take transportation. Airport Express Train is convenient, directly from the airport. But if you are going from the Airport to your hotel in the city, AE train may not necessarily be a good option any more since they are not running their connection shuttle. For example: if you are staying at Holiday Inn Golden Mile, I would take the Airport Bus A21 from the airport instead. It is a little slower but a good sight-seeing opportunity. The bus will drop you off at a bus stop within 1000 feet of walking to your hotel, along the street. It is better than needing a transfer.

subject: 2. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: Disney usually close at 21:30 after the fireworks. And your flight is 02:00 which means you could get to the airport at around 00:00. And disney and airport are both located on Lantau Island, it is not a good choice to get back to citycenter just for getting luggage. So it is a good choice to stay in Airport or Tung Chung. In between 2130 and 0000, maybe you could find a bar if you feel boring or want to get some snacks.

subject: 3. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: If you stay at Disney until it closes, you will need to find a hotel bar that is open or go to the airport. Some dining outlets will be open. Tung Chung will likely be quiet by then. In your specific case, staying at the airport makes more sense since you will spend most of your time at Lantau. On your arrival day, go to Tsim Sha Tsui area for your few open hours, see the skyline and eat dinner.

subject: 4. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: Thank you all for your response. It seems we will take the Marriott (better price than the Regal for the 4 of us, including breakfast). Which option is better (price and tome)- taking a taxi to the city or the express train for the 4 of us (considering its Sunday afternoon and returning aa night) ? And the same question for the day after to Disneyland? (taxi or MTR?) Where would you recommend we should focus on Sunday (I thought arriving to HK soho area, visiting Victoria peak and than take the ferry to TST - to the promenade area)?

subject: 5. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: Airport express is definitely not a good choice, especially you are 4 people. The train cost 100/110HKD to Kowloon station or Hong Kong station, which means 400hkd at least. But a taxi to TST should be around 270-300HKD

subject: 6. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: For 4 of you without bags, take a taxi. As to your Sunday plans, that's a very popular option though you need to see if you have enough time for all of those places. Arriving at 3pm, you might not get to the Peak until after 8pm or so. If you arrive late, consider dropping SoHo. SoHo has a good Sunday vibe during the day but by the evening, it's more like a restaurant/bar area. Head to the Lower Peak Tram Terminus to start and hope for a short line late in the day. Taxi back down to Star Ferry HK side and get across to the promenade area.

subject: 7. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: I saw there is an option for free return at the same day with the train. How much time is it by taxi from the airport to the city (on Sunday afternoon)? The advantage for taking a taxi might be different places for arriving and leaving the city (Where should we start - going to the peak and than the ferry and TST side, or the opposite?)

subject: 8. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: The Airport Express train is a good option in this case with the same day free return. Both for efficiency and economy. Buy the Same Day Return Tickets to Hong Kong Station. From there you can walk to Lower Peak Tram Terminus (about 15 to 20 minutes to walk). You can walk to SoHo area too if you still want that. After that, take the Star Ferry to Tsim Sha Tsui as Sammy suggested. Sight-see around the promenade. When time comes to return to your Marriott Hotel, 2 options: #1) Simply take a taxi from Tsim Sha Tsui Star Ferry Terminal taxi stand to Kowloon MTR Station to take the AE train back to the Airport. Since the fare from Kowloon Station is lower than from Hong Kong Station, you just use your tickets. No extra procedures involved. Taxi fare for this ride is about HKD $30 to $35 or so for all of you. Or: #2) Ride the Star Ferry from Tsim Sha Tsui back to Central Pier. Walk to Hong Kong MTR Station (5 minutes). Take AE Train from there back to the Airport. You pay for the ferry fare x 4 (HKD $6.5 per adult for upperdeck, Sunday). https://www.starferry.com.hk/en/service Price differences between 2 options are not too big. Want to cross the harbour to observe the night view one more time? Take Star Ferry. Or else taxi to Kowloon Station. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 9. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: Thanks for all your good advise and assistance

subject: 10. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: RE: "And the same question for the day after to Disneyland? (taxi or MTR?)" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = I forgot that you had asked this question in #4. For the journey from Marriott SkyCity Hotel to Disneyland, taxi would be better than MTR. Using MTR involves 3 legs: taxi from hotel to Tung Chung MTR Station (Airport Express train departing from the airport does not stop at Tung Chung nor Sunny Bay). Then MTR from Tung Chung to Sunny Bay. Then transfer to the Mickey Mouse Line from Sunny Bay to Disneyland Station. Too cumbersome. You won't save much money with 4 people. Simply ride a taxi to Disneyland from Marriott SkyCity directly. The fare is around HKD $130. Also take a taxi back to your hotel from Disneyland.

subject: 11. Re: Which of the hotels is better for us?
usertext: August, the heat and the humidity and tired... stay near airport, take taxi or uber. Airport Express only worth it if one person or two depending where you transporting to. But four of you, definitely taxi or uber.

subject: Ocean Park - Buy Tickets in Advance?
usertext: Hi, I am the type who usually likes to sort out tickets to attractions ahead of time when I go on holiday. I currently plan to take my 3 kids to Ocean Park at the end of June - but am conscious that it can rain quite a bit in June and the tickets are non-refundable. Does Ocean Park get so crowded that I need to buy the tickets in advance (planning on going on a weekend), or would it be ok to purchase just before arrival so I can check the weather forecast, etc? Thank you!

subject: 2. Re: Ocean Park - Buy Tickets in Advance?
usertext: General Admission tickets at Ocean Park are good for 180 days after the date of purchase. As such, you don't have to enter the park on a set date and can watch the weather to determine the best day to go while you are here in HK. Also, if you don't want to deal with crowds and longer queues, then best to enter the park as it opens first thing in the morning, that will give you a couple hours to get around and see higher priority attractions before the crowds set in for the day.

subject: 3. Re: Ocean Park - Buy Tickets in Advance?
usertext: You can buy a GA ticket and then look to reserve online a few days in advance. Go to Ocean Park's website for more information. Before you reserve, check the forecast for the upcoming days. As Brad said, go right when it opens. More importantly, take the cable car and go to the upper section right away. The cable car lines can be very long. I would hate to stand in the sun breathing the humid air with hundreds of other people later in the day.

subject: 4. Re: Ocean Park - Buy Tickets in Advance?
usertext: Thank you both. I was going to purchase the Ocean Park tickets via Klook, and saw that there is an associated reservation link where I have to select a date. I had initially thought that I had to select the date upon purchasing, but think this is incorrect. Thanks again.

subject: Itinerary with 3 Kids
usertext: Hi all, Can you please feedback on the itinerary below for a trip to Hong Kong end of June with 3 kids, flying from Singapore: Day 1: Arrive 10am. Check in at hotel in TST. Take crystal cable car on Ngong Ping 360 to see the Big Buddha, visit Tai O Village, take boat ride, head back to hotel in the early evening. Day 2: Ocean Park Day 3: Peak Tram, HK Park, HK Zoo and Botanical Gardens, Tai Yuen Street Day 4: Science Museum, Aqua Luna in the early evening, then 8pm light show in TST, walk around Temple Street Market Day 5: Lamma Island (is it worth a visit with kids??), and / or Ding Ding Tram and observation wheel in the evening Day 6: Depart back to Singapore after lunch I am wondering whether it would make more sense to take Ding Ding Tram after the Peak Tram / HK Park Excursion to Tai yuen Street Market, and if so, where would be best stop to get on? Any other must sees for kids? In addition, should I buy an Octopus card in advance and prefill with money, or can I purchase at the airport? Thank you!

subject: 1. Re: Itinerary with 3 Kids
usertext: Day 1 - Note that Ngong Ping 360 and Big Buddha are near the airport so if you go to TST to check-in to your hotel first, you are going to have to backtrack all the way back out to the western end of Lantau Island to visit these places including Tai O. If you want to visit these places on Day 1, consider going to Tung Chung (10 min from the airport) and leaving your luggage in storage at CityGate Mall. You are right outside the Ngong Ping 360 lower terminus from here and can begin your visit. Then head back to Tung Chung to get your luggage afterwards and make your way onward to TST to check-in to your hotel after that. It will save you two long journeys (45+ min) of travel around HK on the day. Day 3 - Your schedule is light. You can knock out these attractions together in 2-3 hours in the morning and have the rest of your day to do other sightseeing. Day 4 - Also a bit light. But good to think about attractions like the Science Museum which are good for the kids, easily a place you can spend 2-3 hours with the kiddos. We also have a LEGOLAND Discovery Centre at K11 Musea in TST that will be in the area you are visiting on the day. The Aqua Luna junk boat ride is ok for me personally. What I like better is the Star Ferry evening harbour cruise which also timed for the Symphony of Lights laser show https://starferry.hongkong-tickets.com/?gad=1&gclid=Cj0KCQjw4NujBhC5ARIsAF4Iv6e4J0MnGwRucQYkqa6vWFqh7875FhCGJ7v7X4JUFiAfAbgTtWrJcmgaAoqiEALw_wcB Day 5 - {Day 5: Lamma Island (is it worth a visit with kids??),} What are you looking for? Lamma is a chilled place with a backpacker(ish) seaside community, some quality km of easy hiking trails and a couple of clean nice beaches. But you can find pretty much all of that elsewhere in HK as well. The beaches around Stanley for example are pretty good as well and you are next to an even neater seaside community and street market. It all depends on what you are looking for.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Itinerary with 3 Kids
usertext: Hi BradJill Not trying to hijack this exchange but was interested to see what you were going to say about the Octopus card part! I'm visiting later this year and while I think I know everything about the cards, having been to HK a number of times before, I have not visited since Covid so I'm conscious things may have changed/websites may be out of date etc.

subject: 3. Re: Itinerary with 3 Kids
usertext: I agree with Brad's day 1 assessment. You either stay around the Tung Chung area and go visit NP360, Big Buddha and Tai O after landing, or choose another day. Backtracking almost all the way to the airport on that same day just seems exhausting. Throughout June, Ocean Park is closed on all Tuesdays. Also, you want to be flexible and plan a visit when the weather looks cooperative. Meanwhile, Science Museum is closed on Thursdays. I do like Lamma Island. However, it might be too hot to hike between the two bays at the end of June. Without the hiking, it's optional in my books.

subject: 4. Re: Itinerary with 3 Kids
usertext: Thanks, BradJill!! I kept the days a bit light as am aware that it will be very hot and schlepping along 3 kids seems to always take twice the amount than it normally should. What are your reasons for preferring the Star Ferry vs Aqua Luna? I thought I had read that Aqua Luna has an open deck, so a bit nicer? Stanley seems like a good idea, thank you. And would it be better to ride the ding ding after the peak excursion or do this on a separate day? I assume riding during the day will be less crowded than in the evenings?

subject: 5. Re: Itinerary with 3 Kids
usertext: {In addition, should I buy an Octopus card in advance and prefill with money, or can I purchase at the airport?} You can purchase a Sold Tourist Octopus Card ($39) when you arrive at the airport if you want to take it home as a souvenir. Otherwise, the most useful/practical option is to instead purchase the On Loan Octopus Card ($50) which you return at the end of your holiday. You will need to preload it with HK$150 as well. So the initial spend is higher but when you return the card at the HKIA counter and they will return to you your deposit ($50) + any outstanding balance less a HK$9 admin fee per card. https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/octopus-cards/products/on-loan/index.html

subject: 6. Re: Itinerary with 3 Kids
usertext: Post #4 {What are your reasons for preferring the Star Ferry vs Aqua Luna? I thought I had read that Aqua Luna has an open deck, so a bit nicer?} Just a personal preference. The Aqua Luna is a touristy junk boat ride. Nothing wrong with it but just not my cup of tea. The Star Ferry on the other had is a historic, classic, charming vessel that is a more authentic ride experience. It is a quintessential part of HK, something that everyone should do when visiting the city for the first time. If you don't want to do their 1 hour harbour cruise, you can take the short 8 minute ride across the harbour between TST and Central at anytime. {And would it be better to ride the ding ding after the peak excursion or do this on a separate day? I assume riding during the day will be less crowded than in the evenings?} I love the ding ding as well and enjoy riding it often. It is nearly as charming an experience as the Star Ferry. You will definitely have some free time on your hands if you do the Peak, HK Park, Zoo & Botanical Gardens in the morning. It is convenient to pick up and ride either direction from nearby Queensway if you do the HK Park last. Unfortunately, it is impossible to predict if one tram will be full up or have lots of seating/standing availability, especially at stops in the Central/Admiralty area where you will be sightseeing on the day. Just get on the platform and watch them as they approach. If one is full up, let it pass and wait for the next one or two. You shouldn't have to wait long for one that has some seats or standing room. Alternatively, just get on a busy tram and as those seated upstairs disembark, which happens regularly, make your way and have a seat. Alas, this also somewhat depends on how long you want to ride the Ding Ding. Believe it or not, taking a near full ride is a great way to see Hong Kong at a slow leisurely pace, you pass through a handful of uniquely different districts and see some amasing streetscapes and scenes. I personally love going through Sai Ying Pun/Sheung Wan area, seeing the endless Chinese medicine and dried seafood shops along Des Voeux Road. That is really neat, especially from the upstairs seats. To do this you can take MTR out to Kennedy Town and board in that area, riding east. Trams are not usually crowded in the K-Town area. Then just right east for as long as you want to go all the way to the end at Shau Kei Wan if you like. Alternatively, take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan and walk over the the Tram station, board and ride west toward K-Town.

subject: 9. Re: Itinerary with 3 Kids
usertext: On the trams, prams or pushchairs must be folded. Otherwise they won't fit through the doors to begin with.

subject: 10. Re: Itinerary with 3 Kids
usertext: I don't think anyone said it above, so just to be clear, children under the age of 3 travel free on public transport in HK. From age 3-11 they need their own Child Octopus cards. and from 12 up they need an adult card. In other words, every person aged 3 or over must have their own Octopus card - you can't use the same card for multiple people on the same journey.

I quote some of the headings and the main paragraphs: = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Can I Get a Visa on Arrival in Shenzhen? - See Who Are Eligible 1. Most European and developed countries are eligible for the five-day VOA, including US, UK, Canada, French, Australia, Germany, Korea, New Zealand, Poland, Romania, Spain, Sweden, and Switzerland. = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Where to Get the VOA? The five-day VOA is available at Luohu (Lo Wu) Port, Shenzhen Airport, Huanggang Port, Shekou Port and Fuyong Port. There is no office at Futian Port although it is only a few hundred meters from Huanggang Port. Ports VOA Office Opening Hours Phone Number Shenzhen Airport 10:00 - the arrival of the last flight (0755)82327700 Luohu Port 9:00 - 16:30 (0755)82324022 Huanggang Port 9:00 - 16:30 (0755)83391060 Shekou Port 9:00 - 13:00 & 14:30 - 16:30 (0755)26691202 Fuyong Port 10:00 - the arrival of the last carrier (0755)23459289 = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = From Hong Kong, when you take a MTR train to "Lo Wu" terminus, you are at the border of Hong Kong/Shenzhen. You walk across a bridge (it is an indoor connector now). You exit Hong Kong on the Hong Kong side, and enter Shenzhen on the other side of the Shenzhen River. On the Shenzhen side, it is called Luohu Port (same Chinese words as Lo Wu, but in Mandarin spelling instead of Cantonese spelling).

subject: 17. Re: Shenzhen day trip
usertext: Ok, second attempt at entry a success !!!! Left our hotel in Mongkok at 7.30, cab to Mongkok east, from where we took the train to Lo Wu. Got to the visa office before opening at 9. We were numbers 9 and 10. A very slow process . Firstly handed over our passports and paperwork and then paid the visa fee. Contrary to what I read online beforehand,, this can be paid with a card. Next another long wait whilst visas processed. Around 10.30, we were called up to the counter to collect and them proceeded through customs, another long painful wait. We got through around 11.15. A mother and daughter from our hotel, who we assisted , were numbers 11 and 12 and were not called for another hour, so it must be done in batches. We went straight to the commercial centre and started looking around. We made a rookie error by allowing a young boy to lead him to his shop. Couldn't get rid of him for hours, thus bypassing the first couple of floors. I found the prices not really cheap. I bargained aggressively and usually ended up with the goods, but it was a slog. Best buys for myself were prescription glasses ( I bought 6 pairs ) and some nice phone covers. The children's wear was disappointing and nice shoes for them practically non existent. In the past I got quality Disney costumes for my grand daughters, but these were nowhere to be seen. Quite a few of the stalls were closed. I would go again, but perhaps stay a night or two in Shenzhen at the start of the trip, flying into HongKong and then travel back to HongKong for the duration of my trip. Happy to answer any questions

subject: 1. Re: China visa issuance in Hong Kong
usertext: Its correct that its always been pretty easy for foreigners to obtain a China visa in HK and I've done it several times without any problem. Although I think the official advice is that visitors should apply in their home country I don't believe this has been enforced in practice. However, I don't haven't any experience since travel restrictions to the mainland were eased earlier in the year and haven't seen any anecdotal evidence regarding the current situation. You can apply at the China Visa Application Centre but need to make an appointment online first; https://www.visaforchina.cn/HKG2_EN/ or CTS (China Travel Service), affiliated to the mainland government, handles visa applications for visitors in HK; https://ww1.ctshk.com/en/chinavisa_2023/ Among other travel agents handling mainland visa applications Forever Bright has often been recommended by visitors as being reputable with good service; http://www.fbt-chinavisa.com.hk/

subject: Macau or Hong Kong to Disneyland
usertext: We are visiting Hong Kong and Macau in December, and trying to decide where to book our hotel. We want to visit Lantau Island for a couple of days to see Disney and the other attractions there. I'm having trouble finding information on how long it takes to get from Macau to Lantau island. Is the travel time to Lantau Island similar if you're staying in Macau or Hong Kong or does one take longer than the other? Thank you

subject: 1. Re: Macau or Hong Kong to Disneyland
usertext: Hong Kong and Macau are operating as two different countries for immigration matters. There is a border crossing (immigration formality) to go between them. Disneyland is in Hong Kong. Naturally accessing Disneyland will be faster from Hong Kong. Taking the MTR (Hong Kong's subway/metro), it can take 20 minutes to 1 hour to reach Disneyland's front gate depending on where you start. Taxi, maybe 30 minutes (but can be longer if you start from Hong Kong Island side). From Macau to reach Disneyland, it will likely be at least 2 hours each way because of border crossing and multiple transportation transfers.

subject: 2. Re: Macau or Hong Kong to Disneyland
usertext: {I'm having trouble finding information on how long it takes to get from Macau to Lantau island.} Macau hotel to the HZM Bridge Macau Port building by taxi (10-20 min) or by bus (30-60 min), Clearing Immigration in Macau and boarding Golden Shuttle Bus to HK (15 min), Golden Shuttle Bus ride to HZM Bridge HK Port building (45 min), Clearing immigration HK (5 min). From here you are on Lantau Island and simply need to budget travel time onward. {Is the travel time to Lantau Island similar if you're staying in Macau or Hong Kong or does one take longer than the other?} No and its not really that close either. Lantau is part of Hong Kong, much closer to everywhere in Hong Kong, serviced by a far greater number of transportation options and doesn't require border crossings in order to visit compared to travelling over from neighbouring Macau.

subject: 3. Re: Macau or Hong Kong to Disneyland
usertext: Got it...thank you very much!

subject: Hong Kong weather (Early December)
usertext: Hi everyone! We're travelling on the last week of November to first week of December this year. Just wondering what should be the clothing during this season? Travelling with my mom so I want to plan ahead. Will it be cold to need a coat or what type of jacket? Can we still wear sandals or only shoes/boots? I hope you can share your experience! Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong weather (Early December)
usertext: Clothing is a personal thing - depends on what you're used to - but generally it's nice at that time of year. This site is good for getting an idea of the weather to expect: https://weatherspark.com/y/127942/Average-Weather-in-Hong-Kong-Hong-Kong-SAR-China-Year-Round

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong weather (Early December)
usertext: Late Nov/Early Dec is technically our cool and dry season so much less chance of typhoon or heavy rains and the extreme heat that usually lingers deep in to October will have passed. Many of us consider this time of year as being when some of our best weather of the year - mostly pleasant days (21-25 C) and cooler but not cold nights (17-20 C). It is great hiking weather and good time for spending long days outside. Here is a look at our daily weather in Nov 2022 https://world-weather.info/forecast/china/hong_kong/november-2022/

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong weather (Early December)
usertext: Temperature and humidity are both comfortable during November and much of December. The only problem is sometimes the northern winds bring in haze. As to shoes, just make sure you wear a pair that's comfortable for walking. I wouldn't rely on sandals only though as they might not be the right shoes for all circumstances.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong weather (Early December)
usertext: Generally very good. Daily highs of around 25c. Nights will still feel quite warm because of the humidity which is around 70% at this time of year. It's one of the drier months of the year but still bring an umbrella. Long-sleeved garments for the evenings just in case the sea breezes pick up.

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong weather (Early December)
usertext: Thank you so much! Will check on this

subject: HKG airport CX business lounge
usertext: If you can use either HKG airport CX The Wing, Business or The Deck which one will you go for and why ?

subject: 1. Re: HKG airport CX business lounge
usertext: I'd think the Pier is your best bet, even if not the closest lounge to your departure gate, and especially if you want a shower. My understanding is that there are no showers in the Wing Biz now. I think the Deck has showers but in most other respects is inferior to both Wing and Pier - but YMMV. Pier has more food and drink options, the 'teahouse', is spacious and comfortable. I believe the Wing gets quite busy and crowded at times these days. Of course, if you have the time, do a lounge crawl and decide for yourself (though I sense your question implies that you only have time for one).

subject: 2. Re: HKG airport CX business lounge
usertext: Oh, also, you will almost certainly get more helpful replies by asking in one of the frequent flyer website forums (eg Flyer Talk) than here where posters tend to be expert in the destinations themselves, not so much the airports and even less so the lounges etc.

subject: 3. Re: HKG airport CX business lounge
usertext: Sound advice. Many of the DEs know the airport quite well - but not the lounges, as those are typically used by transit passengers. When departing they won't arrive too early, and when arriving they normally just get out of there asap. I for one also have never used HKG as transit point.

subject: 4. Re: HKG airport CX business lounge
usertext: I just travelled in and out of HK airport and used a few of the lounges. The Pier in my opinion is the best CX lounge, I like the space, and layout and the food variety. The seats and chairs, tables are kept in good condition. I also like the Wing, but the Wing seems more busy and crowded. The layout is more divided. I just used the Deck last night, it is rather smaller compared to the other two, Food selection was less and certainly didn't look as appetizing. Drinks were fine, not bad variety. Armchairs were getting old and lumpy. Noodle Bar area had no plugs for charging devices. I liked the size of the washroom stalls at the Deck. Large enough that when I am travelling alone, I can bring in my carry on bags and luggage inside, so didn't have to worry about security of my bags, when I often have to leave them outside the stalls. I personally choose the lounge that is closest to the departure gate. It's quite far to walk if you choose the choice of the lounge over the distance closest to the gate. All the showers, washrooms, food in general are similar. Just my opinion. In fact, I think CX lounge is better than Centurion Lounge! Wish you happy travel.

subject: 5. Re: HKG airport CX business lounge
usertext: Agree. Centurion lounge at HKG is not very good at all. It's small with no comfortable seating. Even the Priority Pass valid Chase lounge probably offers better food. Centurion lounges in the US are much better. >>>CX lounge is better than Centurion Lounge!

subject: 1. Re: Macau Fast Ferry in bad weather
usertext: It just looks like a normal rain storm, nothing particularly serious. Ferries should still be running as scheduled. Whether you want to change to the bus is a personal choice.

subject: 2. Re: Macau Fast Ferry in bad weather
usertext: The bus over HZMB is faster, cheaper and more frequent.... Worth considering.

subject: hk holiday
usertext: We 3 of us ( me, my girl 16y and my mom 75y) visit HK on early Aug Day 1 -(2pm arrived) : hotel Page 148 , light meals- temple Street/ladies market - victoria harbour -hotel Day 2 - big buddha / tai o/ 360 cable car (or any good idea like cheung chau /tai yu shan/lantau or Macau dauy trip) Day 3- Disney land Day 4 - ferry to tram/ victoria peak/causeway bay /Kowloon Day 5 - flights 2pm back to home *just want to bring my mum visit HK eat/shopping/enjoy, because she haven't visit before and eager to go.. thanks

subject: 2. Re: hk holiday
usertext: Your itinerary looks fine. August will be hot and humid.

subject: 3. Re: hk holiday
usertext: Macau is not recommended if you have so little time in total, as there's a lot of travel overhead just getting there and back (easily 4-5 hours total for the return trip, maybe more depending on where exactly).

subject: 4. Re: hk holiday
usertext: Otherwise, your itinerary seems sensible and balanced. Day 4 - you mention Kowloon. Kowloon is the name of the peninsula between Victoria Harbour and the New Territories and includes a handful of districts. It is where you are staying (TST district) and spending Day 1. Is there somewhere specific that you were thinking for that Kowloon mention? When thinking about Macau as a day trip option think a larger version of Malacca's World Heritage area with Portuguese style buildings in a Chinese city instead of Dutch in a Malaysian setting. It's different and unique but as pointed out, it is going to be very hot in August and a visit requires quite a bit of travel both ways from your hotel in TST. Could be a long and tiring day for a 75 yr old person. Cheung Chau is a place I think about for those who want a day out to enjoy fairly easily hiking/walking over a fair distance (takes a couple of hours but isn't particularly difficult) mixed in with some cultural & heritage attractions, a few beaches and connected by ferries to/from Central and Stanley on HK Island. I like 1/2 day trips to islands like Cheung Chau and Peng Chau but generally prefer the cooler months of the year. Again, might not be ideal with an elderly family member during August when it will be extremely hot and higher rain probability. As possible inclusions, there are some very nice gardens and parks you can think about visiting that won't be terribly far from where you staying at Page 148. Consider places like Nan Lian Garden & Chi Lin Nunnery, Kowloon Walled City Park & Wong Tai Sin Temple.... There are other park/temple combinations in Sha Tin as well.

subject: 5. Re: hk holiday
usertext: Day 2 - any good recommend ? tai o or lantau is very hard for elderly people ? big buddha got many stairs right? maybe just take photos from far

subject: 6. Re: hk holiday
usertext: Day 2 - If you take the Ngong Ping 360 Cable car and just walk around the village to see the Big Buddha and monastery, it doesn't have to be that hard. You don't have to walk up the steps to see the Big Buddha from right up front. It is actually most impressive from just in front of the steps when you can see its height just fine. Walk up the steps if you are up for it or just admire from the bottom of the staircase. Also, take a bus or taxi onward to Tai O and just walk around. It is a seaside village and flat so unless heat and possibly rain is a concern, it is no harder on elderly than anywhere else you can visit.

subject: Thoughts on Itinerary and Tourism in January
usertext: Hey me (28M) and my wife would want to travel to Hong Kong for tourism in January 2024. I can't see alot of opinions on how Hong Kong would he in the month of January. So wanted to ask. Also if you could help with itinerary and give me your thoughts 17th January : Arrive in Hong Kong. Visit Victoria Peak for panoramic views of the city, take a stroll along the Avenue of Stars, and explore the vibrant Tsim Sha Tsui district. 18th January : Visit Tian Tan Buddha on Lantau Island 19th January : Day trip to Macau 20th January : Ocean Park and shopping 21st January : Disneyland Hong Kong 22nd January : Visit Man Mo Temple and Star Ferry ride across Victoria Harbour to Hong Kong Island. 23rd January : Return Home to Mumbai Thanks again in Advance.

subject: 1. Re: Thoughts on Itinerary and Tourism in January
usertext: January will be cold and dry, with a couple days possibly dropping below 15 egree Celsius. It may be misty on some days.

subject: 2. Re: Thoughts on Itinerary and Tourism in January
usertext: Would you recommend the time and month for a Holiday?

subject: 3. Re: Thoughts on Itinerary and Tourism in January
usertext: January is fine to visit in general. Of course, weather is unpredictable so indeed, January could still see the occasional rainy day.

subject: 4. Re: Thoughts on Itinerary and Tourism in January
usertext: January is usually a good month to visit Hong Kong. We could get cold but we generally only have a handful of days under 12 Cel throughout the year. Plus, this is the dry season so much less chance for rain at this time of the year. There is no risk of extreme heat in January. Hazy skies can be an issue during winter, I think this is what minxbaby (post 1) was referring to and this affects visibility such as trips to The Peak or to the Big Buddha but there is little you can do to predict if this will happen or not. This is one of the best months of the year for hiking. As long as it is isn't too cold, which is rare, there are long days with pleasant temperatures, allowing full day hikes of 8-9 hours. This also means that it can be great for longer days, spending more time outside at Disneyland, Ocean Park and making a day trip to Macau. The only issue I see with your schedule is trying to visit Ocean Park, Disney and Macau on back-to-back-to-back days which may be very tiring. If you have enough days, perhaps do Macau, next day Ocean Park and then switch your last two days (21st and 22nd) so you can do some lighter and easier things before hitting Disney the next day. Another option is to simply choose between Disney and Ocean Park unless you are a theme park junkie in which case - do them both. Also, I would recommend doing these (Disney, Ocean Park & Macau Day Trip) on weekdays instead of weekends if possible... in order to avoid more intense weekend crowd pressure and make things less tiring. This isn't always possible but if so, its better to visit these crowded attractions on non-weekends. Have fun with your trip planning

subject: 5. Re: Thoughts on Itinerary and Tourism in January
usertext: You could also add Tai O to Lantau Island after the Buddha visit as well.

subject: November HK/Macau Trip Advice
usertext: Hi All Looking to visit for the first time in November. I am a really keen Horse Racing enthusiast, and would be looking visit both Sha Tin and Happy Valley to catch a meeting. The wife loves her Casinos, so I would like some advice as whether you would recommend staying in Macau or HK? Also any other advice or recommendations for our trip, hotel, restaurant or gambling venues. Many thanks Mark

subject: 1. Re: November HK/Macau Trip Advice

subject: 2. Re: November HK/Macau Trip Advice
usertext: Agreed. I think you need a few days at least in Macau, to soak in the experience - it's different from HK - not to mention the casinos for which it's famous. There are lots of fun ways of getting there. :)

subject: 13 hour layover at Hong Kong airport
usertext: Hi, I have a 13 hour layover. Landing at 6pm. Is there an internal transit hotel? And if not, would it be possible to exit immigration easily to stay at a nearby hotel? I am flying from Melbourne to London on Cathay Pacific (business class). Thanks in advance :)

subject: 1. Re: 13 hour layover at Hong Kong airport
usertext: With an Australian passport, you don't need a visa to enter HK.

subject: 2. Re: 13 hour layover at Hong Kong airport
usertext: There is no hotel inside the airside. Regal Airport Hotel Hong Kong is the only airport hotel that is connected to Terminal 1 Arrival Hall. You can walk there via indoor connectors with travelators (easy even with luggage). About 300 to 400 meters from the Arrival Hall. https://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Feature-g294217-d302173-zft1-Regal_Airport_Hotel.html You do need to go through Hong Kong's Immigration. It is quite efficient, so it should be fairly quick. Even quicker if your check-in bags are forwarded to your onward flight.

subject: transfer from Kai Tak to airport hotel
usertext: We will be arriving in HK by cruise ship. We will diembark and spend one full day touring and that night in an airport hotel. What is the best way to get from Kai Tak Cruise terminal to our airport hotel, with luggage, early in the morning? Is it easy to get a taxi? Or should I prebook a transfer service? How long does it take? We are hoping to get to the hotel early in the morning, so we can meet a guide there for a tour of Lantau Island. I was hoping to find a guide who would pick us up at the cruise ship and tour with us, then drop us at the hotel, but that hasn't worked out. I did do a search of the forum, but most queries are pre covid.....

subject: 1. Re: transfer from Kai Tak to airport hotel
usertext: Why are you staying at an airport hotel? You have a super-early flight the following day? Hong Kong is small and transportation is very efficient. From most places taking a taxi to the airport takes only 30 to 45 minutes depending on location, and is available 24x7. Arriving at Kai Tak Cruise Terminal, taking a taxi to the airport hotel just to drop off the luggage and then go back out to sight-see in the city is disadvantageous because one of the longest distance for a taxi ride in Hong Kong is to reach Hong Kong Airport. Taxi is the best solution. But I would advise you to select a hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui area where it is convenient for everything. Drop your luggage there and head out to sight-see. Next morning you can take your taxi ride (no matter how early, there will be taxi available) from there to the airport, just one time. Instead of "to airport", "back to city from airport", "back to airport (hotel) again at night). It will save you time and money. Hong Kong tour guides generally don't provide transportation. And especially for Lantau Island that is extra difficult. Except to/from airport, Tung Chung, Disneyland and Discovery Bay, the roads for rest of Lantau Island is restricted to island residents only.

subject: 2. Re: transfer from Kai Tak to airport hotel
usertext: Thanks for your reply. We do have a flight out the next day, although not early. I would like to tour Lantau Island and it seemed like staying near the airport would be convenient for both a Lantau tour and flying out the next day. I appreciate your advise and will do as you suggest. Thanks again!

subject: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: I'm going to Hong Kong and when i visit a city i always use google maps to mark the places i want to visit. I read somewhere that Google Maps doesn't work in Hong Kong (Because of the Chinese Firewall). Does anybody know if this is true? I'm also planning to use the Public Transport a lot. I downloaded a couple of them to test, but to be honest they all suck. HKeMobility and CityMapper. They are way too complicated. I'm not interested in departure times and fees. Just the fastest way to get somewhere. Does anyone have tips?

subject: 1. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: Google Maps can be less than helpful on the Mainland, but in Hong Kong it still works pretty much as it does in the rest of the world.

subject: 2. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: Google generally works just fine in Hong Kong. The only issue I've heard about from anyone is that signals can get a bit distorted (there's probably a more accurate word for that which I don't know) when trying to use the maps app in the downtown concrete canyons, when you're surrounded by skyscrapers.

subject: 3. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: Google Earth has a 3-D version of Hong Kong which can be a lot of fun to explore.

subject: 4. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: Google Map works fine in Hong Kong in general. But the map data is grossly inaccurate for regions that bordered with Shenzhen (China). You can clearly see it. The boundaries, roads, bridges don't match on both sides. Google Map cannot be trusted in China. The coordinates of things are off. That was somehow artificially achieved. But in Hong Kong - so far - the data are correct. The public transportation suggestions are roughly okay, but may or may not be the most efficient way(s). Transportation in Hong Kong is complicated. Many different options. There may be a harbour crossing involved. You can use those suggestions to get ideas, and maybe cross-check with others. For the most part, just home-in on Hong Kong's MTR System Map. MTR = Hong Kong's metro/subway/train. It provides the most efficient backbone of transportation and will cover about 80% to even 90% of points of interests from a casual tourist. Many tourbooks or even webpages would even suggest the closest MTR Station and Exit Number to use for a given point of interest. Hong Kong MTR System Map and Trip Planner: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/system_map.html There are 2 major bus companies. They have website for bus route searches: https://mobile.bravobus.com.hk/nwp3/index.php?golang=EN http://search.kmb.hk/kmbwebsite/index.aspx?lang=en

subject: 5. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: I use Google Map in HK all the time. It's not always accurate when it comes to driving directions (it does not consider certain restricted lanes that normal vehicles can't enter) but that should have no impact on the casual visitor. As mentioned, the public transport part is generally reliable.

subject: 6. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: Thank you all! Real helpfull! I thought maybe if you have a Hong Kong phone card GPS in Google Maps doesn't work. So you can't see where you're standing in Maps (hope i explain it good). I had found an alternative: maps.me But after hearing you all i think i'm going to try google maps. Thanks!

subject: 7. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: It doesn't have to be one or the other. Have ALL of them available at your disposal. When you see something that causes you in doubt, switch to another one and see what it does. While we are at it: Bing Map (works okay in China), Apple Map (works okay in China). But Apple Map is exclusive for iphones.

subject: 8. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: In China, Google (and I suppose all other maps) have a mandatory random offset on location. For some reason, knowing your actual location on a map is considered a national security risk or so. In Hong Kong, that's not an issue - though indeed signal reflections from the buildings can cause problems for the GPS. The hkemobility web site still offers transit suggestions, on all modes of transport. The app used to do this, then this function was removed and it went from great to useless. I don't know the current state. By the way, the fastest way to get around is almost always a taxi, except for harbour crossings during rush hour, then the MTR is the fastest. If your trip can be done easily by MTR, then that's a pretty good contender to taxis when it comes to travel time. Buses are almost always a slower option, albeit often more comfortable: you can usually sit, and there may be less changes.

subject: 9. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: I use google maps daily even for walking around the city and find it perfectly fine for the majority of the places that tourists are likely to visit with the big exception of the West Kowloon Cultural District which is understandable because of continued development and construction taking place there. Definitely let the forum know if this is where you are wanting to visit West Kowloon and we'll help sort out a walking route (or just suggest a taxi so you don't have to deal with figuring out how to get there on foot). Otherwise, for basic route planning around the city - google maps works just fine these days. And if you are thinking more about how to get around with public transportation/taxis, you can also use Citymapper as well. It is a good second reference to google maps and provides more updated and helpful means of transportation information and options.

subject: 10. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: +1 for Citymapper. I use it all over the world and it is extremely useful.

subject: 11. Re: Google Maps in Hong Kong
usertext: #10 - I really wish it existed for Macau.

Looking for the best area to stay in that is very close to the cruise port, but where we could still be in walking distance of a nice area to eat, walk around, explore etc. maybe an area with an outdoor market or something. thank you!!

subject: 1. Re: Less than 24 hours in HK- taking a cruise- where to stay?
usertext: I'd pick a place in the TST or TST East area so you can enjoy the promenade, views of the Hong Kong Skyline and have quick access to the MTR Station so you can get over to the island side if you want to spend a bit of time over there as well.

subject: 2. Re: Less than 24 hours in HK- taking a cruise- where to stay?

subject: Shopping
usertext: Hi Need suggestions on budget shopping for women clothing in Hongkong. Not interested in Ladies market or any such types as I'm not good at bargaining. Also, not into high end branded clothing. Please suggest places where I can pay tag price and also cheaper.

subject: 1. Re: Shopping
usertext: Just about anywhere in HK you'll be able to find tons of clothing shops, most of course targeting women. Generally no bargaining at shops. Shops cater for just about any budget, from cheap outlets to high-end fashion brands. You'll have to look at a few price tags and see whether they fall within your unspecified budget, and whether they're cheaper than your unspecified reference. Ladies' Market is for souvenirs, including souvenir t-shirts. Not for serious clothing.

subject: 2. Re: Shopping
usertext: Stay away from high end shopping malls in tourist areas, such as Element Mall or IFC Mall. There are plenty of mid priced shops at more local shopping malls.

subject: 3. Re: Shopping
usertext: In Mongkok you can try Argyle Centre, T.O.P Shopping Mall for traditional retail mall style shopping. A bit further north on Nathan Road, there are quite a few small, tiny boutique shops at Allied Plaza, probably 2/3 dealing in woman's clothing, shoes and accessories. In Causeway Bay, there is a boutique mall called Laforet In Sham Shui Po Sham Shui Po, you can just walk up and down Cheung Sha Wan Road and find hundreds of small, simple and boutique shops selling clothing and accessories. In Lai Chi Kok, if you want to see where the importers and exporters go to find clothing, walk through the Hong Kong Industrial Centre and clothing emporium area on the opposite side of Castle Peak Road from the MTR Station. There may be a thousand small shops there, many of which sell on a retail basis as well.

subject: 4. Re: Shopping
usertext: Take a look at Uniqlo brand: https://www.uniqlo.com.hk/en_GB/ stores location: https://faq-hk.uniqlo.com/pkb_Home_UQ_HK?id=kA32t000000TNQP&l=en_US&c=category_uq_sg_my%3AUQHK_C2_1&fs=Search&pn=1

subject: 6. Re: Shopping
usertext: A reminder to anyone shopping in Hong Kong that many many shops have an "All Sales Final -- No Returns" policy.

subject: 7. Re: Shopping
usertext: Agree with that stay away from Element Mall(BTW, what's the Chinese name?) or IFC Mall, even the cheaper brands in those malls. After travel around many Asian cities, the price in HK is not cheap. Go to the local malls is good idea. I have kept #3's post on my memo, thanks. :D

subject: 8. Re: Shopping
usertext: If you just walk around Mong Kok, Causeway Bay, Tsim Sha Tsui, or really, just any street in HK, check out the smaller shops. They can have what you need.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: Apologies in advance if this is a daft question! Is there anywhere in Kowloon or in the north of HK Island where one can still get a flavour of what HK was like, say 40 years ago - building style, small shops, crowded narrow streets , garish overhead signage and so on. I've read that Tai Hang is a bit like that in places, but are there other places you can suggest. Thanks

subject: 1. Re: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: Sheung Wan and the Western District.

subject: 2. Re: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: Sham Shui Po.

subject: 3. Re: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: You don't need to go far. Many are reachable using MTR (Hong Kong's subway/metro) with a short walk. For good reason. Aim to go to the older parts of Hong Kong/Kowloon, which usually also are highly populated and less organized. Kowloon: go to Sham Shui Po. e.g. walk along Fuk Wa Street at about Nam Cheung Street. Here is a look from Google StreetView: https://goo.gl/maps/gaFJjgm9SsVkroVK8 This is one of their street markets. Sham Shui Po is one of the places I lived when I was in elementary school. It has been over half a century. Not much have changed. You can walk from there to Tung Choi Street + Mong Kok Road. This is the venue for "Ladies Market". Look at buildings along the street you will see many of those overhead neon signs and business billboards. Along Nathan Road, north to south, many of them. On the other side of Nathan Road - along Shanghai Street. Businesses along Shanghai Street haven't changed that much over the past 60-70 years. Yau Ma Tei and Jordan are a few of those very old-school districts with no much new (real-estate) development. Temple Street - which has been a night street market for over half a century... what most tourists won't notice, along both sides of the street, upstairs are once (and still have some I am sure) red-light industry activities. Over on Hong Kong Island, the oldest districts are Sheung Wan, Sai Ying Pun, and such. Walk along Queen's Road Central and uphill from there (not as much down on the Des Voeux Road (ding ding tram tracks) because Hong Kong real-estate developers churned over the land for newer and taller buildings constantly. If you walk up the hills, along some small streets where it is hard to develop the land for bigger office buildings (or mega-millionaire residence) you will see more of old Hong Kong. Lots of history there. Look up some Hong Kong heritage walking trails that go through old Hong Kong buildings, you can get some info on good self-guided tour paths. These are more than 40 years old. You can be looking at >100 years old.

subject: 4. Re: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: Visit areas slated for demolition by the Urban Renewal Authority. https://www.pland.gov.hk/pland_en/p_study/comp_s/urss/images/ch6_5e.gif

subject: 5. Re: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: Thank you for your link to the picture of the government's plan. I am not surprised to see Sham Shui Po and Yau Ma Tei on the chopping board. I am, however, surprised to see Kwun Tong and Yau Tong on the list. There are the areas first developed in the 50's-60's. With Ngau Tau Kwok first, the Kwun Tong (building factories on the newly reclaimed land), Sau Mau Ping, Yau Tong and many public housing estates. (Basically anywhere east of Choi Hung was "new".) I spent most of my teenage years in Yau Tong while went to school in Kwun Tong. Sad to see these once-familiar places facing the wrecking balls (or maybe dynamites).

subject: 6. Re: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: A lot of places in Kwun Tong and Yau Tong have been redeveloped. By the way, which schools did you go to in Kwun Tong.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: Many thanks for all your responses. I will now do some detailed research on the places/areas suggested although Sheung Wan was already on my list as a possible. By way of background, my wife and I have been visiting Hong Kong regularly since the early 1980s and we are visiting again in a few months time - the first time since Covid. We want to visit some places we have not been to before, like the West Kowloon Cultural area. We also want to wallow in some nostalgia as we are now in our mid 70s (and creaking a bit) so cannot be sure how much longer we will be able to visit!

subject: 8. Re: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: Hi milanolarry: RE: "By the way, which schools did you go to in Kwun Tong."

subject: 9. Re: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: Not far away from mine. Hint: All boys must have ridiculously short haircut. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 10. Re: 1980s Hong Kong
usertext: I grew up in HK (way before the 80's) and lived in Sham Shui Po. In fact, on Nam Cheong st. as mentioned by HappyFeet, right above a clothing factory. I went back and saw that my building (3 stories) had been rebuilt into a multi story modern structure.

subject: Chungking Mansions
usertext: Many people say it is a very dangerous place and should never get close to it. Could anyone tell me what is so wrong with Chungking Mansions? Besides some fires many years ago, I cannot remember any major incidents that happened there.

subject: 1. Re: Chungking Mansions
usertext: Dangerous? In terms of potentially being a fire hazard and ill advised place to stay, the fact is the building does have a bit of a history there. However, it is not dangerous to visit, do a bit of shopping, forex exchange or to grab some cheap South Asian food at one of the many eateries inside. CK Mansions are teeming with people going in and out, much of the day, its perfectly fine in that regards.

subject: 2. Re: Chungking Mansions
usertext: Over the years, the main issue was fire hazard. And there had been a few times with significant burns. And occasional homicides. And small crimes. But on the fire risks, over the years they (the building owner? forced by government?) had cleaned up a bit - not have so many obstructions to fire exits kind of things.

subject: 3. Re: Chungking Mansions
usertext: Those were things of manyh years ago. In recent decades,I rarely heard of anything about it. When compared with Yuen Long and Wong Tai Sin districts, where human choppings are weekly occurrences, Chungking Mansions is quite a safe place.

subject: 4. Re: Chungking Mansions
usertext: If just there to eat and explore the interesting small shops, be viligant against petty crimes such as thefts. With a lot of strangers coming in and out of the many hostels, restaurants, money changers, and more, it's hard to trace and find the culprits. But I've tried their Indian restaurants many times before with no issues. I wouldn't recommend staying here to save a buck though - too many bad reviews but I guess you get what you pay for.

subject: 5. Re: Chungking Mansions
usertext: If you'll be meeting Hong Kong friends, you should at least be aware that whatever improvements have been made to CKM in recent years, its reputation among HK people remains dismal as ever. So better to avoid mentioning to them where you're staying! Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Chungking Mansions
usertext: When it comes to cheap and authentic curry, Chungking Mansions is second to none. By the way, the one in 7E is quite reputable and gets a lot of thumb-ups, you may give it a try next time.

subject: 7. Re: Chungking Mansions
usertext: I feel my life won't be truly complete until I've stayed a night at Chungking Mansions, AND the Peninsula. Preferably in that order. Not sure about burning the luggage in between, hmm... Gordon Matthews has a great book about CKM: Ghetto at the Center of the World.

subject: 8. Re: Chungking Mansions
usertext: I had walked around the building many times, but didn't dare to get in... Maybe next time.
