subject: August family trip: Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: Hi We arrive in HK in mid-August. The kids are 6,12,15. What would be better for us: Disneyland or Ocean Park? Thanks

subject: 1. Re: August family trip: Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: https://www.tripadvisor.com.sg/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14405806-Hong_Kong_Disneyland_or_Ocean_Park-Hong_Kong.html

subject: 2. Re: August family trip: Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: It mostly depends on your personal interests.

subject: 3. Re: August family trip: Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: Do you like Disney movies, characters and rides or sea animals, ocean education and related rides better? Watch a few Youtube videos posted for both and get a feel for what they have to offer, this will help you and your family decide which you are more interested in visiting while here in HK. In the end, they are both very popular theme parks so you'll likely have a good time whichever you pick.

subject: 4. Re: August family trip: Disneyland or Ocean Park?
usertext: Oh please, as a local, I would completely recommend Ocean Park over Disneyland, unless you are a fan of Disneyland and would like to visit every single one on the planet. The one in Hong Kong is miserably small. If you have visited other Disneylands, you might even find it boring and unworthy. Ocean park, on the other hand, is completely different. They have not only rides, but a lot of information of education on environmental protection. Of course, if you have enough time, why not both?

subject: First time in hong kong
usertext: Hello everyone we are a family of 4 and will be visiting hong kong for the first time for 4 days in july. We were interested in doing a day trip to Macau as looks interesting. Any advice on taking feries round trip on the 3rd july ? Any websites to book tickets in advance? Or do we just turn up and book? Any advice will be appreciated. We will be staying at hotel Royal Plaza kowloon and any advice about the hotel/surrounding interesting things to do/good chinese food around and commuting to see sites from our hotel would be much appreciated Thank you in advance

subject: 1. Re: First time in hong kong
usertext: July is also hot and humid like August so you can refer to the discussion here. https://www.tripadvisor.com.sg/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14420121-Hk_holiday-Hong_Kong.html

subject: 2. Re: First time in hong kong
usertext: Mind the long travel time to/from Macau of 2-3 hours one way. As you have only four days in Hong Kong, you may be better off spending it in Hong Kong which has more than enough to offer by itself.

subject: 3. Re: First time in hong kong
usertext: Thank you for your reply . I was under the impression the ferry only took about an hour each way? Maybe i am wrong?

subject: 4. Re: First time in hong kong
usertext: That's just the time sitting on the moving ferry. You have to go through immigration at each end -- four times on a round-trip -- and there's waiting involved and getting to/from the terminals. This is your first time too so it'll be a bit confusing. Doable certainly but it can be exhausting. Note that ferry service is often suspended in Summer when typhoons approach. Summer's also not a great time to be strolling around Macau. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: First time in hong kong
usertext: About the ferry journey over to Macau - Ferries to the Outer Harbour terminal on the Macau Peninsula are now around 70-75 minutes. They have to slow down now and ease into the terminal (no wake) because of major bridge constructions taking place in that area. Also bear in mind that it takes time to get to the ferry terminal and through immigration on both sides. Transportation in Macau is also very slow compared to moving around HK. All in all, you do need to allow 2-2.5 hours travel minimal each way and potentially longer depending on where your hotel is located in HK.

subject: 6. Re: First time in hong kong
usertext: Thank you for your replies everyone

subject: Best dumplings
usertext: Hi all I loved Ho lee fook and seeking a similar place to try with amazing dumplings - steamed with thin skins not the pan fried thick pastry! Please wow me with your recommendations - nothing Michelin star but great quality Thanks x

subject: 1. Re: Best dumplings
usertext: Staying at st Regis if this info helps

subject: 2. Re: Best dumplings
usertext: The Ho Lee Fook dumplings appear to be your typical dim sum dumplings: shrimp dumplings, leek dumplings, etc. Near your hotel, maybe Dragon King or Seventh Son? If you want higher end, may be Lung King Heen at the Four Seasons.

subject: 3. Re: Best dumplings
usertext: There are all kinds of "dumplings" in Hong Kong. It is easier if you get the actual name. I would have guessed (from thin skin, steamed, not pan-fried) that it is Xiaolongbao, which is a Shanghai specialty not Cantonese, though Cantonese dim sum restaurants may all sell it because it is a money maker. I don't know what Ho Lee Fook makes. They seem to blend Cantonese and Peking/Shanghai/Sichuan styles. For your class of consumption, look for the in-house restaurants in Four Seasons, Grand Hyatt (nearby), Regent Hong Kong, Ritz Carlton, The Peninsula. If you want to try Xiaolongbao, the one that makes it really good (Taiwanese brand) is Ding Tai Fung. There is one at Causeway Bay near your hotel. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Best dumplings
usertext: Ding Tai Fung is a bit "new wave" when it comes to what they offer. Their xiaolongbao is pretty good though. HK Old Restaurant at Prat Avenue, Tsim Sha Tsui, makes one of the better xiaolongbao's for a proper Shanghainese restaurant. The rest of their menu isn't bad either. They also have a central branch but I don't like that one as much. As to your original question, indeed, you need to specify the kind of dumpling.

subject: 5. Re: Best dumplings
usertext: Hi all Definitely not looking for DTF it's a chain found all over the place. I'm looking for great Asian dining - a place that also has dumplings - like gow gee style - basically a thin putter wrapping that is steamed - filling can be prawn, veg, mushroom, duck and mushroom, spinach I hope this helps

subject: 6. Re: Best dumplings
usertext: Thanks all I'll look into everything suggested

subject: 7. Re: Best dumplings
usertext: I am afraid nice dining dumplings don't come together. Most good dumpling stores are small or mid sizes stores. This article lists a few good dumpling places near Prince Edward mtr station. https://www.hk01.com/%E9%A3%9F%E7%8E%A9%E8%B2%B7/498638/%E5%A4%AA%E5%AD%90%E9%AB%98%E8%B3%AA%E9%A4%83%E5%AD%90%E5%BA%97top-4-%E5%BF%85%E9%A3%9F%E7%BE%8E%E5%91%B3%E9%A4%83%E5%AD%90%E5%BA%97%E5%B7%A8%E5%9E%8B%E7%85%8E%E9%A4%83-%E9%A4%83%E6%8E%82%E6%8B%9B%E7%89%8C%E6%9D%BE%E8%8C%B8%E9%A4%83 Hope you may use,google translate to view it.

subject: Location: InterContinental Grand Stanford
usertext: Hi How is this hotel location for families with kids (6, 12, 15)? Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Location: InterContinental Grand Stanford
usertext: Location is fine. A fairly quiet part of the city, especially after office hours.

subject: 2. Re: Location: InterContinental Grand Stanford
usertext: Thanks, Would you recommend Holiday Inn (better location, but less nice) or InterContinental Grand Stanford for a family with 6,12,15 kids? Thanks

subject: 3. Re: Location: InterContinental Grand Stanford
usertext: Recommend? It has a lot to with your budget and brand preference. I would recommend Regent Hong Kong (use to be InterContinental Salisbury) because of the location for the best view of the harbour. But prices are a notch higher. InterContinental Grand Stanford is fine. Holiday Inn is... Holiday Inn. I would not prefer that because it is at a busy corner with lots of foot traffic. And it is the oldest built in the 60's.

subject: 4. Re: Location: InterContinental Grand Stanford
usertext: Grand Stanford should offer a shuttle to the more central part of Tsim Sha Tsui. It's also a <10 minute walk to Hung Hom station. From Hung Hom, you can now easily cross the harbor to the Island side or go to many areas in Kowloon and New Territories. But the TST East neighborhood is mostly office. The nightclub business is still around but it pales in comparison vs the glory years. Holiday Inn Golden Miles sits at the most happening part of TST. If you don't mind the hustle and bustle, then it's a good spot. Read some hotel reviews to ensure you know about the rooms they offer. The Mira a few minutes up Nathan Road might be a tad nicer. However, their chic design isn't for everyone. Another choice might be Page 148. It's located on Austin Road so you can still walk to Tsim Sha Tsui. The closest MTR station is actually Jordan. The hotel looks quite decent and gets good reviews. Then if you prefer the bigger brands around Joran, look into Prudential or Nathan. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: How to see a panda in Hong Kong
usertext: Please note that pandas are native to Sichuan only. There are no local pandas elsewhere in China. The pandas that you're gonna see in Hong Kong will be essentially the same as any other pandas they you might have a chance to see in everywhere in the world.

subject: 6. Re: Does Airalo esim card work in HK?
usertext: @SammyFD I can only comment on the package we have which covers us for something like 13 countries in South East Asia. It will probably be cheaper to buy sim cards in each place you go but for ease we have found it definitely worth it. Had good signal and speeds everywhere we've gone. subject: Hong Kong Airport hotel recommendation
usertext: My husband and I are flying through Hong Kong on our way to Sydney in November. We arrive at HKG around 7:05pm and leave the following morning around 8:45am. Looking for suggestions on where to stay that has easy access to the airport and has good food close by. Not looking to get out and see the city - more to be able to walk around, shower, eat, and sleep.

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Airport hotel recommendation
usertext: Regal Airport Hotel is what you are looking for. It is connected to the arrivals area by way of a covered walkway. Then just walk back over in the morning before your flight.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Airport hotel recommendation
usertext: Regal Airport Hotel is the easiest indeed. Note that for food you'll be limited to what's available in the hotel and at the airport. If you're looking for other restaurants, take the Airport Express train one stop to Tsing Yi, the station is connected to the Maritime Square mall, or catch a bus to Tung Chung's Citygate mall. Both rides take about 10 minutes.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Alternative sites that avoid animal suffering
usertext: Hiya We have 11 days in Hong Kong this October and am looking for alternative things to do that avoid any sort of animal suffering or exploitation. For us this includes Ocean Park. I have no understanding why people would want to visit captive wild animals enduring a life time of suffering, unable to perform even the most basic of instinctive behaviours. But that's just me I guess judging by how popular this place seems to be :( The Geopark, bird watching, walking in nature and seeing traditional Hong Kong where possible is far more up my street so would be really grateful for some recommendations for off the beaten track places and experience . I'm also interested in industrial heritage, urban photography, history and street art We are staying at the Hotel Jen on HK Island. Love to hear everyone's thoughts on where to visit and also on any vegan restaurants worth a visit. Thanks in advance.

subject: 1. Re: Alternative sites that avoid animal suffering
usertext: In addition to Ocean Park, I would avoid visiting any wet markets where live animals are sold for food. Maybe also avoid the Goldfish market (do goldfish suffer in an aquarium?). Veganism is not a thing in HK, but vegetarianism is. There are some very good vegetarian restaurants. For example, Chi Lin Vegetarian, Kung Tak Lam Shanghai Vegetarian (2 locations), Veggie Kingdom for dim sum, etc.

subject: 2. Re: Alternative sites that avoid animal suffering
usertext: Vegetarian restaurants typically serve egg dishes. If you dine there and want to stay vegan, you need to ask about ingredients used.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Alternative sites that avoid animal suffering
usertext: Thanks. I've found a some good websites listing vegan stores and restaurants. What I was hoping to gather info on is more natural experience, walks, birdwatching, history etc.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Alternative sites that avoid animal suffering
usertext: Look up Hong Kong Wetland Park and Kadoorie Farm and Botanical Gardens. Both take a bit of getting to, but both focus on conservation and ecological issues and are well worth seeking out. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: Alternative sites that avoid animal suffering
usertext: Check if the Victoria City Boundary Stone hike interests you: http://www.hongkonghikes.com/2018/02/victoria-city-boundary-stones.html The view of the hike is good. Victoria City's history is available on Google. I like the colonial postboxes as well: http://thebeat.asia/hong-kong/nomads/explore/the-story-of-hong-kongs-colonial-postboxes If you like the history, check the postboxes on the map while you walk around the city. For street art, see if you can get Plumber King: http://zolimacitymag.com/meet-plumber-king-hong-kong-unexpected-graffiti-icon/ His works look like this: http://www.instagram.com/9226_3203/

You will need a knife to cut it https://youtu.be/p2Tladgs5cI For urban photos, you could check some housing estates: https://www.localiiz.com/post/culture-art-photogenic-housing-estates-hong-kong

subject: 8. Re: Alternative sites that avoid animal suffering
usertext: Love both of these, those housing estates! Thank you!

subject: 9. Re: Alternative sites that avoid animal suffering
usertext: Be aware that residents at those housing estates are not too happy about tourists taking photos.

subject: 10. Re: Alternative sites that avoid animal suffering
usertext: Many of the housing estates are open space. As long as one does not do too crazy things, the residents do not even notice or mind. Hong Kong Tourism Board advertises some housing estates, such as Choi Hung Estate, itself. Some housing estates are not (that) open and it is better not to disturbe the residents. Lai Tak Tsuen, the cylindrical shape one, are not open to outsiders. Monster Building is not closed, but when I was there a few years ago, there was a sign saying do not take photos.

subject: 11. Re: Alternative sites that avoid animal suffering
usertext: There is no problem taking photos at public grounds of estates. There are Facebook and IG pages where local people take pictures at such locations and post. Just make sure you don't really point the camera directly at someone.

subject: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: We are a early 30s couple traveling to HK for 6 nights and want to celebrate my partners birthday. We are looking for suggestions on how to improvise our itinerary and help plan our vacation. Now that our tickets are already booked, how bad is the weather going to be in mid-July? How should we be prepared? Hotel options : The Mira, Mira Moon or Novotel Century? Which do you recommend? 19th July : Victoria Harbor, Tsim Sha Tsui promenade (8 PM), Temple Street Night Market 20th : Tian Tan Buddha, Tai O village, Lan Kwai Fong (night life) 21st : Macau - St. Paul's Ruins, Senado Square, Macau Tower, A-Ma Temple 22nd : Disneyland (any tips on booking tickets?) 23rd : Man Mo Temple, Central District, Wong Tai Sin Temple, Peak Tram to Victoria Peak 24th : Day trip to Shenzhen for shopping (if we get visa on time) 25th : Reach airport by 5 PM We are fast paced travelers so let us know if we missing out anything or we need to adjust our itinerary. Visiting Shenzhen depends on visa if we dont get how can we utilize the day and how to spend 25th day time?

subject: 1. Re: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: Not much sightseeing planned round Wanchai/Causeway Bay area so not sure about staying at Novotel Century or Mira Moon. The Mira is in TST and near a useful MTR line and station which will work nicely in your favour for getting around the city. You are just a few minutes walk from the promenade and not far from the Star Ferry. I'd include that someone on your list of things to do, either day or night. Note 23rd - {23rd : Man Mo Temple, Central District, Wong Tai Sin Temple, Peak Tram to Victoria Peak} -= Everything in this list is on HK Island other than Wong Tai Sin which is in Kowloon. Just want to make sure you are aware of its location. The rest fit together and can combined conveniently.

subject: 2. Re: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: Novotel Century: traditional chain hotel, not as good as the other two on your list. Mira: Designer hotel but the elements might not be for everyone. As Brad said, the location is the best if you want hustle and bustle out the door. Mira Moon: Boutique hotel also with similar design elements but newer. Quieter in the area though you can walk to the happening parts of Causeway Bay and Wan Chai in 5 minutes. Check the hotel reviews and images here on Tripadvisor and see if you like these places. Just between these three, I would choose MIra Moon. Lan Kwai Fong nightlife is quite expensively overpriced. It might be better just to walk the streets a bit. For drinks, go up to SoHo (Staunton St, Elgin St) on a Friday or Saturday. Shopping at Shenzhen is a dying trend due to the rise of Taobao and similar websites. What do you intend to buy there? I wouldn't prioritize a Shenzhen trip for cheap shopping only. On your Wong Tai Sin day, also go to Chi Lin Nunnery. Also as Brad said, group things correctly geographically. Depending on your interest, consider museums like the HK Palace Museum and/or M+ over at Kowloon West. I would also spend some time walking the streets of Sai Ying Pun (seafood street) and Johnston Road (tram tracks). You get more of a local flavor without having to venture far.

subject: 3. Re: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: Thank you that is very helpful, I will move Wong Tai Sin and add Chi Lin Nunnery during my Kowloon visit. My only reason to visit Shenzhen was (I am ashamed to say this) to shop for replica's I heard that is the place. Taobao or most sites does not ship to India, so this might be the chance I thought. If I drop the plan to Shenzhen what would you suggest to fill it with?

subject: 4. Re: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: Shenzhen is a typical overdeveloped Chinese city. While it looks modern from outside, it lacks history and culture. And I don't think the shopping opportunity there is worth the trouble and money to get the visa. I see from your itinerary that you seem to be interested in historical site. You may consider visiting the Western District of Hong Kong Island to see a more traditional side of the city.

subject: 5. Re: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: Thank you Vincent, yes I have dropped my plans to visit Shenzhen does makes much sense. I will consider the western district, now that my whole day opened up what else can I add?

subject: 6. Re: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: {I will consider the western district, now that my whole day opened up what else can I add?} Really depends on how interested you are in historic sites, street markets, coffee shops. Western District feels disorganised if you don't know what to look for but armed with self-walk maps and knowledge of where to go, you can easily spend several hours exploring this district. Here are a link to several heritage trail (self-walk) routes including Central, Sheung Wan and Western District (see link below). These are poorly advertised or promoted but give you a feel for what is available to see in the area. https://www.amo.gov.hk/en/heritage-trails/cw-trails/index.html And for a real bit of fun, do take a ding-ding (HK double-decker street tram) through Western District, especially the area along Des Voeux Road between Sai Ying Pun and Sheung Wan where both sides of the street are lined with Chinese dried seafood shops.

subject: 7. Re: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: If you are into history. You may consider the Sun Yat Sen Historical Trail. You can easily Google the exact path. With a map, you won't get lost. It tells the history Sun Yat Sen, the father of Modern China.

subject: 8. Re: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: We would love to do hike but read July is not the best time due to extreme heat and rains. We would like to visit some street markets too. What would you suggest?

subject: 9. Re: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: Hiking in July is definitely a bad idea. Good to hear that you are not doing that. There is a very local street market in Fa Yuen Street, which is close to Mong Kok East MTR station. But the things sold there might not be the most interesting. But they are useful in daily lives. Another famous street market is also close by, which is located at Tung Choi Street and is close to Mong Kok MTR station. This market is often referred as "Ladies Market" as the stuff sold there are more interesting to ladies in general. If you have a map, it is very easy to walk between these two markets. You will wish to be there in the afternoon. Don't go too early or you will see no shops are opening.

subject: 10. Re: Critique my itinerary - 6 days mid July
usertext: Thank you! My wife is very excited to visit the ladies market and Mong Kok since we started planning for HK

subject: PAR inquiry
usertext: I got Hong Kong PAR but there is bit change in my plans, I entered 6 days as period of stay and added hotel name & hotel booking id but now my stay extended to 7 days and the hotel also changed, should I apply another PAR - or it will work?

subject: 1. Re: PAR inquiry
usertext: In short PAR is valid for six months and allows you multiple entries into HK for up to 14 days at a time. See Question 23 on the HK immigration FAQ page for PAR (see link) https://webapp.es2.immd.gov.hk/applies2-client/static/faq/i-par-reg/en-US/i-par-reg-faq.html Question 23 PAR is valid for six months. During the validity of PAR, you may use a valid notification slip together with the specific and valid Indian passport linked to the successful PAR to make multiple visits to the HKSAR visa-free. On each visit, you may stay in the HKSAR for up to 14 days, provided that you meet the normal immigration requirements. As for your hotel, I believe that is part of the non-mandatory entries you can fill in during PAR application (see Question 10). The mandatory information are {English name, sex, marital status, date of birth, place of birth, residential address, contact telephone number, India passport number, its place of issue, date of issue and date of expiry}. The line items above that are also found on your passport need to match entirely and perfectly. This is what is important when trying to register and enter HK with PAR, not your hotel or hotel(s) as far as I understand how PAR works.

subject: 2. Re: PAR inquiry
usertext: Thanks, actually I am going with family - so dont want any hassle if they ask me to redo PAR

usertext: {Mon, Jul 17 - Cover - Victoria Peak, Madame Tussads, IFC Mall, HK Observatory, Times Square and nearby} HK Observatory is our local weather provider. There is a historic building in Kowloon where they HQ but it isn't open to public visitation everyday of the year. Did you mean to include this on Mon 17 July or were you thinking of a different place on HK Island where the rest of your sightseeing interests are located? {Tue, Jul 18} - Nothing listed {Wed, Jul 19 (1) Ngong Ping 360 (Where to keep bags if checkup??} There are lockers at the CityGate shopping mall in Tung Chung next to the Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car lower terminal. subject: 5. Re: need expert advice
usertext: I would advice against going to Ngongping 360 on the day of departure. The crowd is unpredictable and you may end up missing your flight in the worst case. If you have not planned anything on the second last day, I would recommend visiting there that day. Then, you can take a bus from Ngongping to Tai O, a very preserved fishing village, From Tai O, you can take a bus back to Tung Chung and leave by MTR. On the last day, you can go to Mongkok and do some shopping, or go to the western district of Hong Kong Island to see the more traditional side of Hong Kong.

subject: 6. Re: need expert advice
usertext: Thank you so much for valuable advice - Also one of my friend from China told me hong kong gets too wet and there is much rain in July, so chances of me missing out many things are there in Hong Kong. I can only hope for best :)

subject: 7. Re: need expert advice
usertext: Im not sure about missing out on things because of the rain unless you are talking about hiking (indeed trails can get muddy), ferry rides or long days at theme parks. The bigger problem is the heat and humidity to be honest. The rains are only troublesome when they drop in buckets but these are usually short spells so you just duck under an awning, use covered bridges to walk from one point to another or duck into a mall, shopping centre or coffee shop for a break while the rain is coming down. If the rain is light and potentially ongoing for several hours, just use an umbrella and you'll should be fine moving around the city. HK is designed for rain and hot weather, you'll be surprised how much time you can spend underground, under covered walkways inside bridges or passing through MTR station passageways, keeping out of the rain or heat for the most part. As an extreme example, I can leave my house in the N.T. and get to most places on HK Island or the airport on Lantau Island and not step foot outside until I'm there if I want to avoid rain or summer heat.

subject: 8. Re: need expert advice
usertext: Frankly speaking, the drainage system of mainland China is bad that even the slightest rain may flood the city. So it is understandable that your friend in China may think that the rain in Hong Kong is going to cause much trouble. But as Brad Jill said, the whole city of Hong Kong is built around this weather and there will be no problems for most of the time. But yes, summer is the season for thunderstorm and tropical cyclone, getting trapped in one of those may disrupt your plan. But the chance is pretty much the same as the chance of getting trapped by weather in any other advanced economy in the world.

subject: 9. Re: need expert advice
usertext: Thanks guys! Brad, We have lived in India and Dubai and experienced 45C in the hottest days - So the hottest day for you is not a big problem for us but you know, spending lot of money on a good flight, good hotel and attractions tickets and all you get is heavy rain, it is something which I want to avoid but it is not in our control, so will wait few days and check weather reports for rough idea and book for exact shared schedule else will have to move plan to September end or something (which i dont want honestly and your replies regarding how rain doesn't much effect is more motivation to me to not reschedule) Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 10. Re: need expert advice
usertext: {So the hottest day for you is not a big problem for us but you know, spending lot of money on a good flight, good hotel and attractions tickets and all you get is heavy rain} My point is that heat and humidity is more of a problem than rains. We don't have the same kind of monsoon seasons that India deals with nor the prolonged downpours or flooding that can result from such rains. In my view, unlike other parts of the world, rain shouldn't be a reason to avoid Hong Kong. It just doesn't have that big of an impact here. However, if heat and humidity effect people, this is a real issue during the summer that should be considered. And to be honest, moving the trip to September doesn't really change much. It is still our rainy season so you might end up dealing with a few days with rain. We average 17 days with rain each July and 14 days with rain each Sept so it is not a great hedge. If you really want to avoid rain, you should come during our dry and cooler season - November to March. Temperatures are lower, rainy days drops dramatically (roughly 4-8 days per month) as does the chance for typhoons.

subject: 11. Re: need expert advice
usertext: The months with most rainfall and most hours of sunshine largely overlap. In summer: when it rains, it pours. It's quite common to go from bright sunshine to massive rain to bright sunshine in half an hour or so. A "day with rain" in July is usually better than "a day with rain" in say April when that's more likely to be a day of just rain...

subject: 12. Re: need expert advice
usertext: June is often the rainiest month. I feel it myself and it's also backed up by statistics. This year, it's probably been raining 3/4 of the days. July is usually a bit better. As mentioned, it might pour when it rains but I also feel there are more good weather days.

subject: 1. Re: where to find sealed & packed roast goose to bring back home
usertext: You can order roasted goose for take-away at many places around the city and vacuum sealing is fairly common so shouldn't be difficult to find a place that can do this for you, expect a small fee. I've not done the vacuum sealing myself but have heard from others over the years who have from places like Yat Lok and Yung Kee. Should be more that do that same but unfortunately, some odd things happened during the pandemic in regard to food preparation/service and delivery so it might help to call a few places that you've interest just to confirm that they can and will do this for you.

subject: 5. Re: where to find sealed & packed roast goose to bring back home
usertext: RE: "find sealed & packed roast goose to bring back home" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = DON'T do it. Good intention, but will have horrible results. No matter how good the package is, sealed (supposedly) or not... after the "fresh" roast goose go through handling - you, security checks, need to pack in some overhead bins... the guy sitting next to you is going to squeeze his hard carry-on case against your precious cargo in a plastic bag, and possibly squoosh it. The goose may deform to unrecognizable. After the plane ride, all the fat (and there are lots of them) from the roast goose will jell up. Super unappetizing. Maybe the grease will melt on your way home. Liquid and jell grease mix. Which will make it even more unappetizing. Good luck presenting it to your parents. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: I am visiting HK in December for a week. My favorite activity (ofcourse) is good eating. But because i'm muslim i can only eat halal food. I found quite a few places where they serve Halal food, but the majority are foreign cuisines like indian and indonesian. I would love to eat authentic Chinese food as much as possible. I found 'Islam Food' in Kowloon and 'Islamic Centre Canteen' in HK Island. Do any of you have more tips for me? I would love to hear it! Thanks in advance!

subject: 1. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: Monastery vegetarian restaurants and tea shops are a safe bet. Here are a couple sources highlighting Halal restaurants some of which are Chinese that you may want to consider. https://www.discoverhongkong.com/seasia/promotions/jelajahhongkong/12-best-halal-food-places-near-you-in-hong-kong/ https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/dining/top-yummy-halal-food-spots.html As a personal recommendation, have a look at Muslim Food Since 1950 (#7 on the list above), an old-school place in Kowloon City that is very popular with locals. They serve up Islamic food with heavy Chinese influence. Here is their website below. https://islamfood.com.hk/

subject: 2. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: Traditionally, Chinese people eat a lot of pork. We did not start consuming beef until the influence of the western world. Cattle has long been regarded as labour, instead of food. Even in Qing dynastic, it was illegal to slaughter cattle. So you can expect that it is not easy to fully avoid pork in our meal. That's why it is a bit difficult to find Halal traditional Chinese food. Halal food starts to grow in Hong Kong mainly because of the import of Indonesian domestic helpers and also the growing community of Pakistanis. Most halal food is specially targeted to them. So you may be a better bet with Indonesian and Pakistani cuisine.

subject: 3. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: I am pretty sure I saw 2 places in Kowloon City. Can't find them now though. On OpenRice there is only one: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/r-islamic-centre-canteen-wan-chai-xinjiang-dim-sum-r26571

subject: 4. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: why need to limited by halal or not halal ?

subject: 5. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: Because as a Muslim i'm not allowed to eat non-halal.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: There's a list of Halal Certified Food Premises in HK here; https://www.discoverhongkong.com/content/dam/dhk/intl/explore/muslim-travel/muslim-friendly-facilities/pdf/halal-list-en.pdf

subject: 7. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: Thanks Buddy!! Didn't know this!

subject: 8. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: Aside from the Islamic Cantre Canteen, I see this one: , Tak Ku Ling Rd, Kowloon (33-35) I think I have been there a couple of time, near the Kowloon Wall City Park.

subject: 9. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: Just as an aside, if you go to the Mainland you'll find halal restaurants serving Chinese dishes in even the smallest cities. You'll recognize them by the characters  Qing Zhen and by their green fronts. Not sure I've ever come across a Qing Zhen restaurant that wasn't decorated in green in front.

subject: 10. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong

subject: 11. Re: Halal Chinese Food in Hong Kong
usertext: Muslims have been living in Mainland China for hundreds of years. There is a big mosque in Beijing. Other cities have large populations of Muslims (Uyghurs). The relationship between Han Chinese and Uyghurs (and other minorities) is kind of complicated. I just read a book called "China Road", which laid out these issues from a foreigner's perspective.

subject: Reactive octopus card
usertext: Hi! Anyone know how much cost to reactive an octopus card after unused more than 1000 days? And is there any customer service to reactive it on arrival hall at HK airport? Thank you so much

subject: 1. Re: Reactive octopus card
usertext: After 1,000 days of inactivity, your Octopus will be deactivated. You can go to any customer service centre at MTR stations to have it reactivated free of charge.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Reactive octopus card
usertext: If your Octopus Card was issued on or after 1st October 2017 and has not had any transactions made or value added for three years there is an inactive Octopus administration fee of HK$15 after three years inactivity and HK$15 annually thereafter. The fee is deducted from the card deposit and any remaining credit balance. If these amounts are fully depleted by the fee the card cannot be reactivated. This only applies to the Adult On-Loan Octopus (not to Elder or Child Octopus); https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/octopus-cards/proper-use/inactive-octopus/index.html Depending on when it the card was issued it may in any event need replacing under the Card Replacement Programme and may be subject to an overdue replacement administrative fee; https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/card-replacement/about/index.html There are customer service centres at the airport in the arrival hall, also the "buffer hall" (after customs before the arrival hall) and at the airport station. No doubt if you present your card at any of the customer service centres the staff will be able to advise you the situation specific to your card.

subject: 3. Re: Reactive octopus card
usertext: Thank you so much for the explanation

subject: App for transportation
usertext: Hi, are there any apps or even just a website available where I can use to identify what transpo to take to get to one place to another? I'm trying to use google maps but bus and tram not showing up as an option even if I ticked it in the settings.

subject: 1. Re: App for transportation
usertext: Google maps definitely shows the bus, tram and ferries as part of public transportation routing around HK. After you click go for directions between two places, make sure you then click the little train icon up top next to the pedestrian that shows all public transportation except for ferries for routing around HK Island as well as between Kowloon, N.T. and Lantau. If you are not seeing tram or ferries it is could be because they are not efficient options between whatever locations you are trying to plot. Another very useful transportation app for HK is Citymapper. It is updated and on par with google maps for route planning by way of public transportation. Routes include MTR, buses, tram and ferries. It will also show walking, car (taxi) routes as well.

subject: 2. Re: App for transportation
usertext: Thanks so much! Will try citymapper and google maps again =)

subject: 3. Re: App for transportation
usertext: https://www.hkemobility.gov.hk/en/route-search/pt still seems to do the job really well. Don't know if the phone app version has been fixed (a few years ago the route planning part was dropped, making it just about useless).

subject: Central/WanChai to TST late night
usertext: Just wanna ask, if I miss the last MTR trip to TST from Central area, what will be my next option that is not too expensive? We are group of 7 adults, will there be taxis that will fit us and how much you think it will cost? If not taxi, what's our next option?

subject: 1. Re: Central/WanChai to TST late night
usertext: Though late night buses are available, your best option is really two taxis. The cost of each taxi should be $80-100? I haven't done this route for a while so I factored in the past few price hikes by guessing. Note that a taxi is required to use the meter. If you are leave from the Lan Kwai Fong area, don't board a taxi there. Head down to Pedder St and flag a moving taxi. If they shoot you a price before you board, close the door and get another cab.

subject: 2. Re: Central/WanChai to TST late night
usertext: Thanks SammyFd! 4 adults okay in one taxi? Also, is there an uber or something similar in HK?

subject: 3. Re: Central/WanChai to TST late night
usertext: Yes. 4 adults in a taxi is just fine. Yes, Uber is an option. Its a legal grey area but the app works and it gives you both private drivers and taxis as a slightly cheaper option. Note, there is also a HKTaxi app that is very useful as well. You can arrange taxi rides, notify that you are an English speaker and pay with with credit card through the app. https://hktaxiapp.com/

subject: 4. Re: Central/WanChai to TST late night
usertext: Oh great! Thanks so much!

subject: 5. Re: Central/WanChai to TST late night
usertext: Be aware that though it's illegal, many taxis on HK Island will refuse a fare to Kowloon. Also, know that except in the special case of a returning "Kowloon" taxi, you'll pay twice the tunnel charge as an add-on.

subject: 6. Re: Central/WanChai to TST late night
usertext: At present, the additional tunnel charge is only $10. In other words, if the running meter fare is $80, you pay $100 instead of $90. Uber does work in HK. You might get an Uber taxi in the process which works just fine. Again, the normal taxi rate should be $80 - $100. If you see an Uber rate that's inflated way beyond $100, I would just take a taxi and make sure it runs on the meter.

subject: Shenzhen electronic market products in Hong Kong
usertext: I am really impressed by the cheap electronics product videos I saw from Shenzhen but covering Macau, hong kong in 5 days and going to Shenzhen will be too much for me! is there any online website where I can get those products at a similar price or delivery from there directly?

subject: 1. Re: Shenzhen electronic market products in Hong Kong
usertext: What exactly do you want to buy though? Name a few things and see if we know.

subject: 2. Re: Shenzhen electronic market products in Hong Kong
usertext: If you're looking for consumer stuff head to Sham Shui Po and have fun looking around. If you're looking for electronics parts and supplies -- the sort of wholesale stuff you can find in Shenzhen markets -- not much of that in HK because HK doesn't have much of an electronics manufacturing industry to supply.

subject: 4. Re: Shenzhen electronic market products in Hong Kong

subject: 5. Re: Shenzhen electronic market products in Hong Kong

subject: 6. Re: Shenzhen electronic market products in Hong Kong

subject: 7. Re: Shenzhen electronic market products in Hong Kong
usertext: AliExpress gives you an idea of what's available and the prices, roughly. Then you can visit Ap Liu Street in Sham Shui Po where all the electronics shops are. It's a geek's paradise. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apliu_Street Crossing the border to Shenzhen is just too much hassle. Happy shopping. :) Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 8. Re: Shenzhen electronic market products in Hong Kong
usertext: Deliver where? Aliexpress delivers to Canada within a week on some products.

subject: 9. Re: Shenzhen electronic market products in Hong Kong
usertext: >>> My brother last year from Shenzhen bought drone for like 20 USD [...] A few things to keep in mind when you buy that stuff. Crap may be a better word. Quality is closely reflected in the price, especially at the bottom end as it gets harder and harder to shave off those last few cents. Warranty generally lasts until the door. Electrical safety. Standards in mainland - if they exist to begin with - are not followed well. Many products that connect to mains power are not safe, and may expose live mains at the low voltage output. Other products may be an outright fire hazard for the use of low quality materials and ignoring safety standards. That said, I've bought tons of stuff off Taobao (while living in HK) and Aliexpress (more recently). There's great stuff to be found at good prices, for me it's mostly electronic components, but also other equipment. Just keep in mind that going for dirt cheap means you're likely buying worthless crap that's often not even worth the rock bottom price. There's a lot of crap on sale on those sites.

subject: 10. Re: Shenzhen electronic market products in Hong Kong
usertext: Just about all locals buy a lot of Taobao stuff these days. As wvmarle said above, quality is reflected in the price to a certain extent. You probably don't have to buy the most expensive ones, but you definitely want to avoid the very cheap ones because they are mostly going to be low end. On the other hand, if you are willing to pay a reasonable price, you often get some great quality stuff for much less than HK retail.

subject: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: Is tap water safe to drink or should we rely on bottled water? If tap water is fine are there taps in public to refill the bottle?

subject: 1. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: https://www.tripadvisor.com.sg/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k3211988-Drinking_water_in_HK-Hong_Kong.html

subject: 2. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: 13 years old and still relevant today. I will stick with bottled water

subject: 3. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: I've always boiled tap water in the kettle, let it cool, then refilled the water bottle I bought on day one. That seemed to be the advice, and it's always served me well in HK.

subject: 4. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: I would not worry about using tap water to brush my teeth. I don't notice many drinking fountains out in the city (except at the airport, past security, for passengers to fill their empty bottles). HKers traditionally drink boiled water, probably habit from back when tap water was not safe to drink.

subject: 5. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: Most hotels will provide water bottles and will replenish daily as well.

subject: 6. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: If you are not an environmentalist, then using bottled water (free or purchased) is convenient and cheap. If you want to minimize that cost and also go easier on the environment, you can balance the two by buying a large bottle from a supermarket and then refill it into smaller and/or reusable containers daily.

subject: 7. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: As far as I know Hong Kong tap water fulfills all WHO requirements and is safe to drink. It does taste a lot better after boiling as you get rid of the chlorine that's been added to prevent microbial contamination.

subject: 8. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: We spent 4 days in Hong Kong and drank tap water each day without any issues. We are from the UK so I would imagine we'd have had a reaction if there was anything in it. Seems like locals generally steer clear but the data suggests it's safe.

subject: 9. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: Just about all locals boil their tap water out of habit. This practice might be slowly changing over the years as more families are now installing pricier filters.

subject: 10. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: in average, tap water in HK is usually clean, and the chance to get sick because of drinking tap water is relative low (comparing with other countries). Howver, you wont know what is the situation of the tube. So it is still advice to drink bottle water or boil it. Locals usually boil the water just for additional safety.

subject: 11. Re: Is tap water safe to drink?
usertext: I've tried filtered water - testers at shopping malls, selling the thing. Boiled water tastes better. I could still taste the chlorine in the filtered water.

subject: Best Area / Location To Stay Hong Kong & Macao
usertext: Hello everyone, We are planning our trip to Hong Kong and Macao in March/April 2024 and I am curious to know which is the best location stay. Hong Kong We would prefer to stay in the city centre or centrally located area (like say a Downtown in Dubai) which is close to the attractions like Disneyland, Shopping Malls, Local Food, etc. We plan to spend 05 nights here. Macao Not sure if this is a place to visit with a 07 year old and not sure on what to expect here. Is it worth the visit or is there some other place we should chose over this? How many nights here?

subject: 1. Re: Best Area / Location To Stay Hong Kong & Macao
usertext: Disneyland HK is far away from city center. So you can't be near both city center and Disneyland. HK has multiple city centers. You may want to check out hotels in Tsim Sha Tsui, Causeway Bay, Mongkok, etc. Try to find a place near an MTR (subway) station. Local food is everywhere.

subject: 2. Re: Best Area / Location To Stay Hong Kong & Macao
usertext: Disneyland is on Lantau Island in between the airport and the Kowloon Peninsula. You can travel there by way of MTR quite conveniently from any centralised location in Kowloon or HK Island which is where you will find the malls, food spots and other popular sightseeing. In addition to districts mentioned by TSS above, I'd look into properties from Causeway Bay to Sheung Wan as well if you have preference for being on HK Island instead of Kowloon. As for Macau, yes. it is fine to go there with children. They have Science museum, water parks, promenades full of children's play areas zones, pandas and all kinds of family-friendly entertainment on the Cotai Strip. See the Macau Government Tourist Office (MGTO) website to get a feel for what to do/see there. Also, make sure to use the TripAdvisor Macau forum for your research on our sister city.

subject: 3. Re: Best Area / Location To Stay Hong Kong & Macao
usertext: @BradJill @ThanksSocialSecurity Thank you for the quick recommendations. I think we will choose Tsim Sha Tsui for the location to stay in. However, what would be your recommended hotels? We are considering the following hoping that we would get a good view of the bay: 1. Intercontinental Grand Stanford Hong Kong 2. Kowloon Shangri-La Hong Kong 3. Holiday Inn Golden Mile Hong Kong 4. Hyatt Regency Hong Kong Tsim Sha Tsui 5. Sheraton Hong Kong Hotel and Towers 6. Regent Hong Kong The Regent and Intercontinental seem to be closest to the bay in terms of location but recommendations are welcome in terms of the guest experience.

subject: 4. Re: Best Area / Location To Stay Hong Kong & Macao
usertext: Regent has the best location on the view. Full frontal Victoria Harbour view if it suits your budget. Hyatt Regency is the newest, but need higher floors to have view (to clear the neighborhood buildings), Holiday Inn Golden Mile is dated (built in the 60's) and not have much to offer in anything in comparison. Sheraton's view of the harbour is somewhat blocked by Regent and the latest K11 Artus Hotel. No blockage for Kowloon Shangri-La. View from Intercontinental Grand Stanford view room is okay but not from a prime angle. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: Best Area / Location To Stay Hong Kong & Macao
usertext: I don't think HI Golden Mile hotel has rooms with harbour views. Although it is just a few minutes walk to the promenade area. Intercontinental Grand Stanford Hong Kong & Kowloon Shangri-La Hong Kong are both over in TST East. They are just just fine hotels but note the harbour views here are not the famous HK Skyline, its of the island further east. Still nice though. If rooms with a view of the famous part of HK Island are your priority, also consider Marco Polo harbour view rooms. Its right up there with the best of location and best of views. https://www.marcopolohotels.com/en/hotels/hongkong/kowloon/marco_polo_hongkong/rooms_and_suites/index.html and if you want something less expensive, look up the YMCA on Salisbury Rd. This is a decent property, right next to the famous Penninsula hotel and with some prime views of the the harbour and HK skyline as well. https://www.ymcahk.org.hk/thesalisbury/en/accommodation/harbour_view/index.html

subject: 6. Re: Best Area / Location To Stay Hong Kong & Macao
usertext: Note that the hotels you listed have varying budgets. They probably range from $1,500+ to $4,000+ for a random night. Actually, Regent should be considered the newest hotel. A multi-year renovation project just got finished within the last couple of months. If price is not an issue, Regent would be the top end hotel to stay. Location-wise, Regent is very good, so is Holiday Inn GM, Hyatt Regency and Sheraton. Kowloon Shangri-La and Intercontinental GS are at TST East slightly further away. Their harbor view angle is also less desirable. IGS is the worst located overall though they offer a shuttle service to central TST. If money is not an object, balancing hotel quality and location, I would pick in this order: Regent, Sheraton or Hyatt Regency (pretty much a tie), Kowloon Shangri-La, Holiday Inn Golden Mile, Intercontinental Grand Stanford.

subject: 7. Re: Best Area / Location To Stay Hong Kong & Macao

Holiday Inn - USD 150 (INR 12k) per night 5. Shangri-la - USD 365 (INR 30k) per night 6. subject: 8. Re: Best Area / Location To Stay Hong Kong & Macao

The prices you mention do not sound particularly high to me for harbour view rooms. Whether this price changes or not, and if so in which direction, I really can't predict. That's up to the hotels to decide. I'm actually more surprised you get pricing this far ahead to begin with.

subject: 11. Re: Best Area / Location To Stay Hong Kong & Macao

subject: 12:30 Pm HKIA to Macau
usertext: How to go to Macau when I land in Hong Kong airport after completing immigration by 12:30 PM (Yes, I will be completing immigration first)

subject: 1. Re: 12:30 Pm HKIA to Macau
usertext: RE: "(Yes, I will be completing immigration first)" The way to take the APM to SkyPier (to Macau) is before Hong Kong Immigration. If you intend to enter Hong Kong Immigration first (I don't know... maybe to meet a friend at HKIA or buy something at the airport's non-restricted area...) - you are no longer eligible to use HKIA's SkyPier to go to Macau. You need to seek for other routes. If you really want to take a ferry directly from HKIA to Macau, you buy the ferry tickets before HK Immigration, and hand over the baggage claim tags (if you have any check-in baggage). The ferry workers will retrieve your check-in baggage from the conveyor belt and forward them to your ferry. You claim your check-in bags after you go through Macau's Immigration at the pier/port in Macau. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: 12:30 Pm HKIA to Macau
usertext: Leo, The old SkyPier ferry to Macau has extremely limited service these days, just one sailing per day and only a few days a week. If your flight is delayed and you miss it, you will have to use alternative transportation. I would suggest looking into using the HZM Bridge which is right next to the HKIA airport. There is a regular circular bus (B4 - HK$8.3) between HKIA and HKMB and the ride is just 8 minutes. From there you can buy Golden Shuttle Bus ticket (HK$65). Bus leave every 3-5 minutes during the time you will be there and the ride to Macau is 45 minutes. It really is that simple to get to Macau these days without worrying about catching the limited ferry service from SkyPier.

subject: HK Sky Pier to Macau Help ( Can I Buy Tickets Online)
usertext: Hey Folks I land at 10 am at Hong Kong Airport, As I Understand I'm supposed to Not clear immigration and make my way to the Sky Pier Terminal and catch a ferry to Macau. I wanted to know if I can buy tickets and reserve seats online for a ferry at 11 am or so. And If you could Link me to a post with an explainer of how I'm supposed to get this done. I Hold an Indian Passport (with US Visa) , I also have a PAR to enter Hong Kong I will stay there for a Night and take the other ferry back to Hong Kong. Thanks, a lot Harsh

subject: 1. Re: HK Sky Pier to Macau Help ( Can I Buy Tickets Online)
usertext: Don't do it. The completion of the Zhuhai-Macau-HongKong Bridge, coupled with Covid-19, basically crippled the ferry service from HKIA to Macau. 2 operators: CotaiJet basically suspended that route: https://www.cotaiwaterjet.com/ferry-schedule/hongkong-macau-taipa.html Turbojet maintains 1 sailing departure a day, but only on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday: https://www.turbojet.com.hk/en/routing-sailing-schedule/hk-airport-macau/sailing-schedule-fares.aspx Unless you can match exactly that extremely limited time window.

subject: 2. Re: HK Sky Pier to Macau Help ( Can I Buy Tickets Online)
usertext: I am from India too and having same midnight flight btw but what is your PAR date? l am asking because i was bit confused if your PAR starts from lets say 1 July to 7 July but you dont do immigration on 1 July but go macau directly and do Macau immigration on 2 July - then will it work? because your PAR date is different?

subject: 3. Re: HK Sky Pier to Macau Help ( Can I Buy Tickets Online)
usertext: @HappyFeet1234 Okay, WHat do you suggest I do? To get from Hong Kong Aiport to Macau What are my best options? @Leo In the same boat about that, No Idea If its issued from 1st to 7th , Should be valid all through, Let me know i go Next month end

subject: 4. Re: HK Sky Pier to Macau Help ( Can I Buy Tickets Online)
usertext: @Harsh S: This question comes up every few weeks. Take a look at this thread. Check my replies (especially #1) and Macau Expert BradJill's replies. Use the bridge. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14356859-HongKong_airport_to_Macau-Macau.html

subject: 5. Re: HK Sky Pier to Macau Help ( Can I Buy Tickets Online)
usertext: I agree with HappyFeet. The fastest, cheapest option is to just use the HZM Bridge which is right next to HKIA airport. You can do this by taking circular bus route B4 (HK$8.3), the ride is 8 minutes to the HK Port Passenger Clearance building at HZM Bridge. From there you go through HK Immigration, buy Golden Shuttle Bus ticket (HK$65) and get in the queue to board outgoing buses which leave every 3-5 minutes during the majority of the day. The ride is 45 minutes and you are in Macau. It is that simple and straight forward. I would suggest going ahead and purchasing an Octopus Card while at HKIA and do pull out some HK$ from the ATM while you are at the airport. You can the Octopus to pay for the B4 bus as well as the Golden Shuttle Bus tickets across HZM Bridge on both sides. You can also use HK$ while you are in Macau. It is widely accepted currency there.

subject: 6. Re: HK Sky Pier to Macau Help ( Can I Buy Tickets Online)
usertext: (1) What are timings of B4 Bus and where to find it? (2) For Octopus card, can I add more balance at purchase site Thanks,

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: HK Sky Pier to Macau Help ( Can I Buy Tickets Online)
usertext: Bus B4 operates a 24-hour circular route between the passenger terminal and HZM Bridge Port, details here; https://nlb.com.hk/route/detail/87 Re Octopus Card, yes you can add value to it at point of purchase or from add-value machines in the airport arrival hall.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 8. Re: HK Sky Pier to Macau Help ( Can I Buy Tickets Online)
usertext: Note the B4 bus stop is on the service road adjacent to the airport bus terminus, marked as "Buses to Lantau Island" on the bus location map;. https://www.hongkongairport.com/iwov-resources/file/transport/to-from-airport/public-buses/bus_location_map.jpg From the arrival hall, follow the signs "Buses" which lead down a ramp at the bottom of which you reach the point marked "You are here" on the map. Then you just need to cross the road by the pedestrian crossing to the right to reach the bus stop. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 9. Re: HK Sky Pier to Macau Help ( Can I Buy Tickets Online)

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Last week of May
usertext: Hello, I'm planning on visiting Vietnam at the start of June next year. For certain reasons which are too boring to go into, my route from the UK involves flying BA in & out of HK. Will need to overnight in HK at least one night each side of my trip to Vietnam as it won't be a protected connection to/from Vietnam. So, I'm wondering since I'll be in HK regardless, is the weather going to be acceptable enough to stay 5 nights? This will be at the very end of May. Google tells me to expect rain. However, I cannot get confirmation about just how much rain there is likely to be each day and if there is a strong risk to any activities I may attempt. Like I say, I can simply overnight each side of my trip to Vietnam, but it would be a real shame not to take the opportunity to explore HK for 4 full days / 5 nights. This would be my first visit and I cannot change the dates unfortunately. Any thoughts greatly appreciated.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Last week of May
usertext: You can find detailed monthly weather reports including rainfall dating back to 1997 on the Hong Kong Observatory website. I doubt that anyone can accurately predict in any detail future weather but, for information, the last three years reports can be found these links; May 2023; https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/wxinfo/pastwx/mws2023/mws202305.htm May 2022; https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/wxinfo/pastwx/mws2022/mws202205.htm May 2021; https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/wxinfo/pastwx/mws2021/mws202105.htm Website; https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/index.html Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Last week of May
usertext: It is hot in late May and you can expect rains but this shouldn't prevent you from enjoying your time in Hong Kong. The city is designed for rain. There are many ways to avoid it by using Metro, underground and covered walkways and bridges. There is very little risk of major flooding and little risk of typhoon this early in the year.

subject: 3. Re: Last week of May
usertext: Usually, the end of May means high temperature starting to reach 30C on a daily basis so it will feel hot. Rain depends though it's usually nothing nearly as frequent as June. This year, it's been raining almost everyday in June.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Last week of May
usertext: Thanks for the replies. So it sounds like a 5 night stay may be worthwhile. I may be able to flex the arrival/departure dates by a week, which I guess can only help with avoiding rain.

subject: 5. Re: Last week of May
usertext: It is quite likely you experience at least some rain that time of the year; very unlikely to have day long rain (except if there's a cyclone, which is again extremely rare late May, then you may have a day of continuous rain). Rain comes mostly in bursts - heavy bursts. Note that by nature weather predictions tend to be unreliable; rain predictions even more so; and summer rain is very unpredictable as it's largely showers. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Last week of May
usertext: If you have some flexibility, coming a week earlier is better overall weather wise. You might see lower temperatures and lower chances of rain. I just need to stress the "might* part as you never know.

subject: 7. Re: Last week of May
usertext: As mentioned by others, even if it does rain it is not hard to avoid the rain in Hong Kong. There are plenty of indoor places to go such as big shopping centres and museums. Having been in Hong Kong in May, I have found it to be hot and humid. I have not experienced much rain in my visits at that time of year, but perhaps I was lucky or unlucky depending on how much you like the heat and humidity on sunny days. But since you are also going to Vietnam, you should have gotten used to those sort of conditions.

subject: uber apps
usertext: it's uber apps can book hong kong taxi ? e-taxi apps need register hk mobile number. taxi or uber better?

subject: 1. Re: uber apps
usertext: RE: "it's uber apps can book hong kong taxi ?" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = No. Taxi is still operating the old fashioned way: flag down, meter ticking. You are charged by distance and (if any) waiting time, plus if you have luggage - those are extras. Taxis in Hong Kong are plentiful. No need to do the Uber thing. Go to the taxi stands. Or flag one down passing by - if the taxi is empty ("For Hire" sign on), and there is no restriction on the street that prohibits taxi loading/unloading.

subject: 2. Re: uber apps
usertext: Actually, the Uber app in HK does allow you to see taxi fares and choose taxis to take journeys around the city. Here is a link to the Uber.hk webpage if helpful https://www.uber.com/hk/en/ride/ubertaxi/

subject: 4. Re: uber apps
usertext: If you use an app you can pay electronically but if you haul a taxi on the street be ready to pay with cash.

subject: 5. Re: uber apps

subject: 7. Re: uber apps
usertext: @Happyfeet {Thanks for the correction, Brad! Interesting to know.} I'm constantly having to learn and relearn how everything works here. Seems every week there is a new app that everyone must have or new way to use some other feature that is all the rage. I'm barely on the tech train as it is, especially as we move closer towards a cashless society, I may have to jump off. @KellyHYC {so i can choose either uber or hk taxi right? thanks} If you have access to a local phone number than you can download and use HKTaxi. Otherwise, use Uber and order a taxi through them. Note, Uber Tech Inc. (parent company) owns HKTaxi Limited (business) so either way you go... it fairly similar.

subject: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: Please answer my few queries (1) I was referring the map from here - https://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/eastbound-ding-ding.jpg My hotel is near 17E Queen street and if I want to take tram from same to 33E Murray Road - is its possible or I will need to go 21E western market terminus to board? I heard I need to push bell/button or something to notify driver to stop but to board like can I board from anywhere? (2) For distance like sheung Wan to causeway way - is MTR better or tram? what locals prefer and good?

subject: 1. Re: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: There are platforms in the street at each stop. You must board or alight at them. And the tram always stops at every platform, no need to signal the driver. Local people tend to take the tram for the distance of a couple of MTR stations. But for a tourist a longer trip is fine and a good chance to see HK, so long as you sit upstairs. (People in HK tend to speak of buildings, not numbered street addresses, by the way.) Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: {I heard I need to push bell/button or something to notify driver to stop but to board like can I board from anywhere?} Not to worry. The tram is slow, plodding down the street.... but in a good way. As mentioned above, it stops at every platform along the way and there are many stops so if you did miss one for some reason, just get off on the next. It won't be far up the street. {(2) For distance like sheung Wan to causeway way - is MTR better or tram? what locals prefer and good?} Completely depends on the purpose of traveling this route. If I'm in a hurry, I will use the MTR as it covers this distance in 9 minutes. The Tram takes around 20-25 minutes to cover this distance at street level. Also, during the summer, it can be rather hot and humid outside, trams have open windows to allow air to blow through but there is no A/C so it can be hot, especially on packed trams. The MTR has A/C and kept very cool during the summer. On the flip side, if I have time no my hands and am not in a rush, I will usually take the tram, especially during the cooler months of the year. The ride is nice, allows you to view several interesting districts each with their own unique characteristics. This versus zipping across the island in a tubular underground carriage is just more enjoyable.

subject: 4. Re: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: You don't need to go to Western Market Terminus to board the ding ding tram. Just walk from your hotel to the nearest tram stop (as you found - 17E Queen street). Any eastbound tram will take you to Murray Road (to ride the Peak Tram?). BTW: those numbers are tram stop codes. They are not street addresses. You may want to check the interactive tram map from the service provider instead of a third-party site with relayed information. Here is Hong Kong Tramways' interactive map: https://www.hktramways.com/en/interactive-map MTR is faster. Ding ding tram is more scenic because it runs on surface streets. For short distance such as this (2 to 3 km), the time difference is not much. Riding the MTR, you can't see anything. It is subterrain for that ride.

subject: 5. Re: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: Sheung Wan to Causeway Bay by tram is going to take you around 30+ minutes. Using the MTR, it takes around 10 minutes. So as Brad said, it depends on what you want to use the tram for. Also, it matters whether you get a seat (hopefully upstairs) and the weather.

subject: 6. Re: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: For long distance, MTR is faster. For short distance, I think the Ding Ding may have an advantage, as you don't have to walk underground to the MTR station. Some walks can be quite long.

subject: 7. Re: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: Thank you so much all of you :) I wont be in hurry as I am on vacation, and I am staying ibis central, so rather than walking to MTR, I would prefer Tram in front of my hotel even if takes few minutes extra "You don't need to go to Western Market Terminus to board the ding ding tram. Just walk from your hotel to the nearest tram stop (as you found - 17E Queen street). Any eastbound tram will take you to Murray Road (to ride the Peak Tram?)." - Yes, I am asking to go Peak Tram

subject: 8. Re: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: Just note that long rides on a crowded tram on a hot day isn't particularly enjoyable. I usually limit my tram rides to no more than the equivalent of two MTR stations. A good tool to use might be buses. Once off peak, they are usually not that crowded. They offer air conditioning and travel faster (traffic dependent). You also won't have to walk up and down vs MTR. Still, for a 3-4 stop journey, MTR is often quicker.

subject: 9. Re: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: Noted, SammyFD Thanks for advice, I will use MTR as per need! Actually I find buses bit confusing as those numbers, stops, different companies and all - as first timer, it becames easier to look tram or MTR with easy map and routes to understand over bus

subject: 10. Re: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: Buses are run by different companies (as do the trams and the MTR trains), but that's by and large irrelevant for travellers. Everything works the same on the different buses, and at least the KMB app also offers arrival time of buses run by the other companies (I never tried the NWST bus app). Also you won't see KMB route 1 and NWST route 1 at the same stop, for example. No possible confusion there, either. Finding bus stops and routes does tend to be a bit more confusing indeed. Google Maps, Citymapper and hketransport are some options to help out with this.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 11. Re: Novice Doubts about Trams
usertext: The KMB app shows its own and other bus operators routes and also Green Minibus Routes. The Citybus app shows its own and other operators routes but not minibus routes. NWFB no longer exists, all its routes were merged and rebranded as Citybus routes from 1st July.

subject: Where to eat for affordable dim sum & steamboat in Hong Kong
usertext: I'm in the midst of preparing my 4 days 3 nights itinerary in HK. Since I'm a Chinese therefore I would like to try authentic and affordable dim sum HK and also, steamboat is very popular in HK too. FYR, I will be staying at Mongkok area.

subject: 1. Re: Where to eat for affordable dim sum & steamboat in Hong Kong
usertext: Steamboat is what you'll be looking for in Singapore, here it's called "hot pot". Both are available at many affordability levels all across the territory Dim sum suggestions: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/restaurants?dishId=1036&districtId=2010 Hot pot suggestions: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/restaurants?dishId=1001&districtId=2010 And there are hundreds more restaurants in HK serving these type of dishes - over 1,000 listings for hot pot and over 1,500 for dim sum.

subject: 2. Re: Where to eat for affordable dim sum & steamboat in Hong Kong
usertext: In HK, there is no unauthentic dim sum. There is just good or bad dim sum. Anyway, there are so many places that it's impossible to give you much guidance. The one recommendation I have based on quality and price for dim sum s Reunion Garden at Hillwood Road (technically TST area but actually closer to Jordan MTR). I don't have their exact hours but dim sum is probably served some time between 11:30 to 3:30 (I did ask and know that 3:30 is the last order time). If you are going during peak lunch hour, book. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Where to eat for affordable dim sum & steamboat in Hong Kong
usertext: Try Lei garden dim sum, you may go to openrice.com for prices, comments and addresses.

subject: 4. Re: Where to eat for affordable dim sum & steamboat in Hong Kong
usertext: Lei Garden does have decent quality but for me, their dim sums's are too heavily seasoned. One more strike against them is the small portions for the price you pay.
