subject: Hi everyone
usertext: How much $ would one person need for one day trip in Hong Kong by bus or taxi+sightseeing+breakfast and lunch pls ?

subject: 1. Re: Hi everyone
usertext: Probably HKD 100 up to 500.

subject: 2. Re: Hi everyone
usertext: What is it that you want to do for your day trip in Hong Kong? Responses to generic question like this can go a whole lot of directions. You could do a day trip of visiting free actions, traveling around by bus and eating bakery/cheap food for no more than HK$50-100 or you could use taxi or sightseeing bus and pop into pricier attractions while enjoying a good brekky and nice lunch with drinks for a cool HK$1000+ a day per person.

subject: 3. Re: Hi everyone
usertext: It depends on what you want to eat and what you want to visit. From the visitor side... For traffic, if you only take metro or bus around the city, it could be cheaper, taxi is expensive... When I went to HK first time, my first traditional HK style breakfast cost me HKD200+, I was not full... For some good/traditional restaurants or hotels' dinner/afternoon tea, the meal/dinner is much more expensive, and looooong queue... If you only try street food or some small ones, HKD60 for a meal is enough.

subject: 4. Re: Hi everyone
usertext: Cost is relative to your home town. For visitors from the US, much of Europe, Australia and New Zealand, taxis should be quite affordable. My guess is visitors will spend roughly $50 a day on the MTR, Star Ferry, and local buses. For more expensive rides like the Peak Tram, check their website for pricing and budget accordingly. >>>if you only take metro or bus around the city, it could be cheaper, taxi is expensive.. If the "traditional" breakfast you ate cost over $200 for one person, you didn't go to any sort of "traditional place." Most HK tea cafes serve HK style breakfasts for roughly $35 to $45 nowadays. Lunch is about $60-$70. Dinner has a wider varience but at such cafes, the cost should be anywhere between $60-$100. Of course, the sky is the limit. >>>When I went to HK first time, my first traditional HK style breakfast cost me HKD200+, I was not full. I actually feel "street food" is overpriced for what you get. Egg waffles now cost $25 to 30. Bubble tea starts at $35 or so. Again, for good budget eating, go to an HK style cafe. If you want to go even cheaper, head to MX, Cafe de Coral or Fairwood though the quality won't be very good. >>>If you only try street food or some small ones, HKD60 for a meal is enough.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Hotel with pool
usertext: Hello, we are looking for a hotel with pool. We want a good location, very near to transport links with lots of food and bar options within walking distance. We also want an outdoor pool. Clean and comfy hotel. Views from hotel would be a bonus, but the location and pool are most important We have looked at the Wharney and Harbour Grand. Do either sound good or any other suggestions?

subject: 1. Re: Hotel with pool
usertext: If Harbour Grand suits your budget, take Harbour Grand. These two are not direct comparable. At least one grade higher. There are two Harbour Grand locations. Which one are you thinking? They both have views of Victoria Harbour (from their view rooms, which naturally have higher price tags). Harbour Grand Kowloon's pool is at the roof top. Great view of the harbour. Harbour Grand Hong Kong's pool is on about the 5/F, something like that. A closer-up view of the harbour, at a lower elevation. Both locations are good.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Hotel with pool
usertext: Thanks this is really helpful! We were thinking Hong Kong location. Is the location of either suggestions better for us who wish to be near public transport and near nightlife areas.

subject: 3. Re: Hotel with pool
usertext: They both have good access to public transportation (MTR - Hong Kong's metro, and buses). In Hong Kong, the backbone of fast and inexpensive transportation builds on MTR. Get familiar with it. Here is the system map of all the lines: Link: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/system_map.html Harbour Grand Kowloon is only about 400 meters to the Whampoa Station's entrance. Harbour Grand Hong Kong is even closer, about 300 meters to the Fortress Hill Station's entrance. Plus ding ding tram - which doesn't run on Kowloon side. "nightlife"... hmmm... you may need to be more specific on what that means. Different people have different ideas about that term. For bars, they are scattered. Quite many in Tsim Sha Tsui (not walking distance to Harbour Grand Kowloon, but a short taxi ride ~HKD $30). Bars - many in Causeway Bay (the pure drinking ones), and many in Wan Chai (people seek extra companies). Not walking distance from Harbour Grand Hong Kong. But similarly a short taxi ride ~HKD $30 or so).

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Hotel with pool
usertext: For nightlife we are a couple in our 30s so casual bars with live music are our thing really - where's best for that?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 5. Re: Hotel with pool
usertext: Hotel Jen part of the Shangri La group has a rooftop pool with harbour views. It's close to HKU for transport. Might be suitable. Whether its to your choice in terms of nightlife and the general location is a personal choice. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Hotel with pool
usertext: How warm do you like your pool water? Do note that after a few sunny days the water in a rooftop pool can get within a few degrees of body temperature (definitely >30 Celsius). Even sea temperature is often 28 - 29 degrees, which to me feels like swimming in soup.

subject: 7. Re: Hotel with pool
usertext: "many in Wan Chai (people seek extra companies)" That's unfair to many bars in Wanchai. Yes, there are some which can be places where gentlemen of a certain age go to meet ladies of about half that age, but that's only a few of them There are many, many "normal" bards in Wanchai, including, to the OP's point, The Wanch which is the place for live music. https://www.thewanch.hk/

subject: 8. Re: Hotel with pool
usertext: Harbour Grand Kowloon is the one I would pick over the Fortress Hill one. Even though the Fortress Hill location is not far from the MTR station, the platforms are built very, very deep underground so it's always a bit of a chore to go up and down. The Whampoa area has a decent mall and an Aeon supermarket/department store nearby. Close the Fortress Hill locations are mostly very local small shops and restaurants and a gas station so it's not as nice. Bars with live music can be found at Wan Chai, Lan Kwai Fong (expensive), Knutsford Terrace at TST, and TST East.

subject: Hotel accommodation.
usertext: We are going to Hong Kong in December for 2 nights before hopping on a cruise. I was thinking of staying around Victoria Harbour and the cruise terminal. Looking for any recommendations that aren't overly expensive as the first night we don't arrive until just after midnight.

subject: 1. Re: Hotel accommodation.
usertext: So your cruise departs from Ocean Terminal? (There is another cruise terminal. Make sure that's not the one.) There are plenty of hotels in Tsim Sha Tsui, near Ocean Terminal. Just do a hotel search in that area, depending on what you mean by "aren't overly expensive".

subject: 2. Re: Hotel accommodation.
usertext: Please clarify: Which cruise terminal? Ocean Terminal or Kai Tak Cruise Terminal? Either case: There are only a few hotels near the Kai Tak Cruise Terminal. I wouldn't recommend any of them. Your best bet is to pick a hotel in the Tsim Sha Tsui or Hung Hom area. They are along the Victoria Harbour waterfront. Not "overly expensive" is too subjective. State the actual budget amount (in HKD) then some concrete suggestions can be made.

subject: 3. Re: Hotel accommodation.
usertext: Even if your cruise departs from Kai Tak, as said above, I still suggest you stay at a more interesting area like Tsim Sha Tsui. On boarding date, just pay the extra HK$100 for a taxi to the port. You will probably get your money back with less /shorter MTR rides and save time by staying at TST.

subject: 3 days in Hong Kong in December - rough itinerary
usertext: Wd are taking a Celebrity cruise from Singapore to Hong Kong end Nov/early December. Have booked 3N stay at Ibis hotel Central & Sheung Wan @28 Des Voeux Road W. Doing my research now and would appreciate your answers to my thoughts. Some questions: Day 1: 1. Read that Celebrity cruise uses Kai Tak terminal. How much would taxi cost from terminal to hotel? 2.would probably reach hotel around 10+am. Plan to walk to Tai Ping San Street which Google map says is near the hotel. Explore n have lunch there. How long do you think it will take to explore the area? 3. Does it make sense to take the Ding Ding tram from a Western Market terminus after Tai Ping San Street? 4. For dinner, would like to eat roast goose at Yat Lok or Yung Kee. Which tram stop should we alight from ? Day 2: Plan to take the bus from Exchange Square to Stanley Village. Have researched and gotten the bus numbers. Day 3: At this moment - haven't made plans yet. We were last in Hong Kong in 2018 and have gone up to the Peak and also day trip to Macau. Any suggestions? Thank you

subject: 1. Re: 3 days in Hong Kong in December - rough itinerary
usertext: 1. My best guess is around $200. 2. With lunch, maybe a couple of hours. The area has some interesting restaurants and cafes, some galleries and what looks like smaller, independent shops. It's pretty easy to keep walking east to SoHo and then the pedestrian escalator area. 3. The tram runs on Des Voeux Road to Queen's Road Central, then Johnston Road to Wan Chai and to Causeway Bay. You can catch it from any stop in between. Tram stops are very frequent, usually within an easy walking distance. 4. There is a tram stop near World Wide House (on your left if going eastbound). Disembark at that stop, walk up Pedder Street to Yat Lok and Yung Kee. Day 3: It's hard to give you suggestions without you listing every major destination you visited previously. I am sure you went to TST and took Star Ferry though? Some other spots include: --Chi Lin Nunnyer/Nan Lian Garden/Kowloon City Walled Park --Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car, Big Buddha, Po Lin Monastery, Tai O --Lamma island --Cheung Chau --Hiking

subject: 3. Re: 3 days in Hong Kong in December - rough itinerary
usertext: Looks like my Ibis hotel is very central and convenient. Google map shows that Yat Lok and Yung Kee are about 15 mins away so I don't need to take the tram. Which is more scenic? If I don't get off, I will just take it to the terminus and then take the next tram on a reverse route to get back to Western Market? How long will one route take? A ride is Hk$2.60 and if I don't buy the Octopus Card, I can pay by tapping my credit/debit card when I exit? Thank you !

subject: 4. Re: 3 days in Hong Kong in December - rough itinerary
usertext: From Western Market, I suggest you go eastbound. The tram will take your through Central (financial district), Admiralty, then Johnston Road where you see a mix of old and new. By the time you reach Johnston Road, I think that should be enough for the tram unless you want to end up at Causeway Bay for shopping. Going beyond CWB is not going to yield anything that looks too interesting. A tram moves quite slowly so even if you have time to kill, it's just not worth spending more than 30-45 minutes on it. Note that going westbound from your hotel, Des Voeux West has a lot of dried seafood shops that still has some yeseteryear feel. Staying at Ibis, you can just walk there within minutes. In fact, if you don't mind walking a bit, turn left up the hill at Centre St. There is a pedestrian escalator as well. Between First Street and High Street, there are numerous cafes and restaurants with a good, relaxing feel. There is also a wet market en route which never looks too sanitary. I would still rate it as a local experience though. Going further west (MTR or tram as it's a bit far to walk), Kennedy Town Praya has a nice harbor view that is different from the usually happening view. Within Kennedy Town, there are also numerous cafes, bars and restaurants. It's less crowded overall so it might be a good area to go chill for lunch or one afternoon if you have time.

subject: 14. Re: 3 days in Hong Kong in December - rough itinerary
usertext: The Tourist Octopus card is a sold version. If you want to give it back then get a standard on-loan Octopus. Why would you use any site other than Octopus's to get information about Octopus cards - all the info you need is there? https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/index.html Note that you need one Octopus card per person. You cannot use the same card to pay for multiple people on the same journey. The fares (and timetable) for the Lamma ferries are here: https://hkkf.com.hk/en/timetables/ (they are different on Sundays & public holidays vs Mon-Sat) The fare for the #6 bus from Central to Stanley is $10.4 every day (each way). Use the Citybus app or website to find the timetable and next bus arrival times. https://www.citybus.com.hk/home/default.aspx?intLangID=1

subject: Help with Airport Express Train Tickets
usertext: Hey Folks So I want to take a Round Pass for the Airport Express Train. While Going from the Airport I would Get down at Kowloon. But After a week later, While Going to the Airport I would want to get on from Hong Kong Station. So Can I purchase Round tickets to Hong Kong Station and get down at Kowloon? Or Should I go for 2 Individual tickets? Thanks for the help

subject: 1. Re: Help with Airport Express Train Tickets
usertext: If you are set to use Airport Express train both ways to/from the Airport, you can purchase the round-trip tickets (instead of purchasing 2 different tickets at 2 different times). You will get a discount. The way to do it is to get the round-trip package for the Hong Kong Station (the fare to Hong Kong Station is higher). You can use such a ticket to exit Kowloon Station (lower fare). No problem. The machine will just know your ticket is valued at a higher fare than what you are due. Green light and you are good to go to walk through the turnstile. On the other hand, if you purchase the round-trip tickets for Kowloon Station but you board the AE train at Hong Kong Station, you will be stopped by the turnstile and you need to walk to the Customer Service counter to pay for the fare difference before you can use it. So either way, you would need to pay for fare for the KongKongStation-to-Airport journey.

subject: 2. Re: Help with Airport Express Train Tickets
usertext: Great Thank You. Also another Question From my Hotel in Jordan to Macau Do you recommend me to go the airport and Take a Bus across to Macau Via the Bridge or Is it better to take the Ferry? Time and Cost WIse ?

subject: 3. Re: Help with Airport Express Train Tickets
usertext: As your hotel is in Jordan, you should look at taking airport bus A21 instead (it runs along Nathan Road). Much cheaper, and overall just a little slower, than taking the Airport Express to Kowloon and taxi from there. Much better views along the way, too. To Macau, the bridge is definitely cheaper and likely faster overall than the ferry. In any case count on at least 2 1/2 hours one way for the whole trip (leaving your hotel to arriving at the historical centre or a casino in Macau).

subject: 4. Re: Help with Airport Express Train Tickets
usertext: @Harsh S, Where are you staying in Macau and for how many nights? There are a few ways to get to Macau from Jordan. If you have a lot of luggage and are staying at a major hotel on the Cotai Strip for 2-3 nights, the Cotai Water Jet ferry from the HK - Macau ferry terminal in Sheung Wan might be a good option for you. However, if you want cheapest and most convenient route, consider taking Airport Bus A21 (mentioned above) from Jordan to the HZM Bridge (see link) - journey time is just over 1 hour. Or depending on where your hotel is located in Jordan, you might be able to take Airport Bus A22 - journey time around 45-50 minutes to the HZM Bridge ( https://citymapper.com/hong-kong/bus/citybus-a21?lang=en https://citymapper.com/hong-kong/bus/citybus-a22?lang=en From HK Passenger Clearance Building (HK Port), take the Golden Shuttle Bus over to the Macau side as described in your question on this thread a couple weeks ago (see link and posts #3-5). Journey time is 45 minutes. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14443141-HK_Sky_Pier_to_Macau_Help_Can_I_Buy_Tickets_Online-Hong_Kong.html#118029267

subject: 6. Re: Help with Airport Express Train Tickets
usertext: It is a good option if you have four luggage bags between two people. You can take the Cotai Water Jet to the Taipa Ferry Terminal in Macau. There you can take the free Galaxy hotel bus from the ferry terminal to the hotel. You can also purchase the Cotai Water Jet tickets directly on their website and just use mobile barcode tickets to enter the platform area at the ferry terminal. No need for print out tickets.

subject: 8. Re: Time from Arrival at HKIA to Train Boarding at West Kowloon
usertext: The OP said in his other thread: "worse case i will book a car that night. not concerned about the cost as much as the convenience after such a long flight." You want "as much as convenience", and "not concerned about the cost". Why are you planning a James Bond operation. Just stay with the "SkyLimo" cross-board service, point-to-point, from the HKIA to your hotel in Guangzhou. Trying to catch a timed-departure train, you need to board the AE train from HKIA to Kowloon Station, walk for 10 minutes to West Kowloon Station, cross-bother again at the station, walk to the train platform, board the train to Guangzhou South or Guangzhou East, and still need to hail a taxi to take you to the hotel. Why, if "not concerned about the cost"? If you miss that departure, you may need to wait an hour or couple of hours for the next available one, lingering uncomfortably in a train station. subject: 14. Re: Time from Arrival at HKIA to Train Boarding at West Kowloon
usertext: Note that getting through the formalities at West Kowloon station can be a bit nightmarish. The problems start after leaving the HK side, as the mainland control points have multiple bottlenecks. The first check is your health code, with a line of computers where you scan but people bunch up and clog up there. Then immigration, and finally the X-ray security check. 45 minutes could be tight during peak hours.

subject: 15. Re: Time from Arrival at HKIA to Train Boarding at West Kowloon
usertext: If you download Wechat, you can fill in the health declaration form online in advance. I believe the code is only valid for 24 hours though so don't fill in the form too early. You will also need to fill out the code again to exit China. If you can't do so while in China, then you will have to mess with the computer terminals as described.

subject: December 2023 weather
usertext: Hi, thinking of going to HK early December. Will there be typhoon or monsoon? Thanks in advance!

subject: 1. Re: December 2023 weather
usertext: December is not typhoon season. It's usually dry and sunny. It can also be hazy though due to prevailing northerly winds bringing dust particles from mainland China. Temperatures should be comfortable for most visitors.

subject: 2. Re: December 2023 weather
usertext: December is winter in Hong Kong which is our cool and dry season. Typhoons occur during our warmer months, not something to think about with December trips. Winter monsoons do occur fairly regularly but mostly go unnoticed other than dropping temperatures a few degrees overnight. I believe we had 3 last December but these are nothing to worry about as temperatures never drop to truly cold levels in Hong Kong, especially in early December. Expect temps in early Dec around 17-21 C. It is a great time of the year to visit if you want to spend lots of time outside with minimal risk of rains and no chance of melting in the sun.

subject: 3. Re: December 2023 weather
usertext: There may be monsoons - they're cool and dry, sometimes very dry. You'll be extremely lucky if you get to experience a typhoon in December. Chance of snow may even be higher (also just about zero).

subject: 4. Re: December 2023 weather
usertext: It's funny you asked specifically for 2023 which is in the future. We have more info on the past. https://weatherspark.com/s/127942/3/Average-Winter-Weather-in-Hong-Kong-Hong-Kong-SAR-China#Figures-Temperature Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Buses on Lantau

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Buses on Lantau
usertext: The buses used on the Ngong Ping - Mui Wo service (Route 2) are single-deck with narrow entrance and steps although folded wheelchairs can be stored either on a luggage rack inside the bus or in the luggage hold under the passenger deck; https://flic.kr/p/2oPsnQ2 The bus operator on Lantau Island does have low floor wheelchair accessible double deck buses but unfortunately as far as I am aware they are still not allowed to operate on the Ngong Ping - Mui Wo route for safety reasons owing to the steep road leading to Ngong Ping and only operate on service 3M Mui Wo - Tung Chung). Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Buses on Lantau
usertext: The road up to Ngong Ping (about 1400 ft / 400 m elevation) has always been narrow and steep. I don't blame them not using the double-decker bus to serve that route. I wouldn't be comfortable riding on a double-decker bus to go up there either. Hong Kong's taxi fare is quite inexpensive compared to other first world countries. Can consider taking the Lantau taxi (blue taxi) to head up to Ngong Ping. e.g. From Tung Chung MTR Station to Ngong Ping village, about HKD $200. 22km mileage.

usertext: There are no ferries from Central to Tung Chung as far as I am aware. The only ferries from Tung Chung run between Tuen Mun and Tai O via Tung Chung. To get from Mui Wo to Central you either get the ferry, or back track to Tung Chung by bus or taxi and return from there.

These are two of the cleanest and nicest beaches in Hong Kong You can to this taking any buses from Tai O or Ngong Ping heading back to Tung Chung or Mui Wo along S. Lantao Road (inc. 1,2, 4, 11 and 23) and disembarking at Tung Fuk Village or the Upper Cheung Sha Wan Beach bus stop (best two spots in my opinion). Then afterwards, board buses heading back to Mui Wo which pass by regularly.

subject: 13. Re: Buses on Lantau
usertext: The suggestions in #8 and #11 won't work as the buses are not wheelchair accessible. However, the suggestion you made in #10 of taking round-trip on the cable car and then bus across the island to Mui Wo would work. The double-deck buses used on route 3M (Tung Chung - Mui Wo) are wheelchair accessible; https://flic.kr/p/2oPQge9 However, the route uses a mix of both single-deck (not wheelchair accessible) and double-deck buses so you may not be able to board the first bus if its single-deck but its a fairly frequent timetable; https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/detail/6 There are about 58 double-deck buses which operate locally around Tung Chung and across the island on route 3M. As far as I aware they don't operate on any other cross-island routes. Its quite a scenic route as the bus climbs up and over the mountains with panoramic views of the south coast of Lantau on the steep descent (with emergency escape lanes) although from the lower deck views may be restricted. usertext: The Water Taxi isn't really anything like a (land) taxi. It's just one (of several) harbour tours that run a couple of times per day on various routes. It's not generally useful as a point-to-point ferry service. I aslo can find no evidence on the service's website of any timetables showing that it currently serves Kai Tak Cruise Terminal (although it is mentioned once in the text). https://www.hongkongwatertaxi.com.hk/en/

subject: 18. Re: Buses on Lantau
usertext: To get away from Kai Tak Cruise terminal I think your options are either a taxi (all of which will carry a wheelchair in the trunk free of charge) if your partner is able to manoeuvre into one, or the bus routes 22, 22M, 22R which will essentially take you to Kai Tak MTR station. These buses are wheelchair accessible, as is the MTR station.

subject: 19. Re: Buses on Lantau
usertext: thanks heaps..I think that is why I was getting confused..I have noticed your other post and thanks for being so specific..it really is a great help..have a good day

subject: MTR/Ferry discounts for seniors and disabled tourists
usertext: Hi...I have looked at the thread available but the info appears to be over 10 years old. The reduced fares that are offered for both of the above, are they only for HK citizens or are tourists able to access. We are on a cruise with 36 hours in Hkg, so not sure that we would get value from a tourist 1 day pass...thanks in advance

subject: 1. Re: MTR/Ferry discounts for seniors and disabled tourists
usertext: Concessions for disabilities are only available for HK residents with the appropriate local paperwork. Concessions for senior (meaning age 65+) visitors are currently available on public transport through the use of Elder Octopus cards. The concession is generally that each trip is HK$2. Anyone can buy such cards - the age requirement is policed at the point of usage - anyone using such a card can be asked by MTR/bus/ferry staff to provide evidence of their age; the Octopus readers make a different noise and/or have a flashing light to indicate when such a card is used. Note though that the government has announced that this $2 concession fare will be restricted to people holding a so-called "JoyYou card" which is a personalised Octopus card bearing a photo available only to residents. On current plans this change might happen from late 2023 onwards. After the change, under the current system, seniors using an Elder Octopus card would get half fare. The tourist passes are not generally good value unless you intend to be a very intensive user of the MTR system. They are only valid on the MTR and don't apply to ferries or buses anyway.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: MTR/Ferry discounts for seniors and disabled tourists
usertext: You can benefit from age concessions on public transport if you are 65 or over by obtaining the anonymous On-Loan Elder Octopus Card. This is available to non-residents and no ID or proof of age is required to obtain. It costs HK$100 of which HK$50 is a deposit, refundable for a small admin fee if the card is returned at any MTR customer service desk before leaving HK. At the current time cardholders benefit from both the transport operators own voluntary concession (usually 50% of full adult fare) and the government subsidised maximum HK$2 fare where by the govt reimburses the operator the difference between HK$2 and 50% of full fare. The concession applies on most MTR, bus, green minibus, local ferry and tram services. However at some time (later this year I think) Elder Octopus Card holders will no longer benefit from the govt HK$2 concession but will still benefit from transport operator concession. The govt HK$2 max fare scheme will become restricted to HK residents only age 60 and over who hold the new JoyYou Card which is currently being rolled out. There are no concessions as far as I am aware for non-resident persons with disabilities. Edit - just seen HK GauYau beat me to it! Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: MTR/Ferry discounts for seniors and disabled tourists
usertext: Thank you for explaining...makes some sense now....

subject: 4. Re: MTR/Ferry discounts for seniors and disabled tourists
usertext: Thanks heaps...I understand it now

subject: 5. Re: MTR/Ferry discounts for seniors and disabled tourists
usertext: Soon the concession to senior on public transportation will be for Hong Kong Permanent Residents only. The current senior Octopus card has been on a rolling enrollment base to be replaced by Joyyou card which requires a HKID card issued after 2003 to apply, and would have the user's picture on the card, As of now, the last batch of eligible applicants, I.e. those born before 1938, has enrollment period between Sept 1 to Oct 31. After that, the government most likely will terminate the current non-registered senior Ootopus. The date of termination has not been announced yet. So you as a visitor would continue to enjoy this generous benefit thru end of 2023, most likely. By 2024, with the Joyyou card fully roll out completed, the non registered, no name, no picture senior Octopus probably will be removed permanently. Therefore, enjoy it as you can, for now. One thing to note, MTR and the government in recent weeks are frequently spot check to enforce the proper use of senior Octopus. Violator if caught will be fined by HKD$1000. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: MTR/Ferry discounts for seniors and disabled tourists
usertext: Can we assume the Elder Octopus won't actually *expire*, but eventually just function like a regular Octopus?

subject: 7. Re: MTR/Ferry discounts for seniors and disabled tourists
usertext: Elder Octopus is subject to the same expiry rules (due to inactivity etc) as other Octopi, Eventually they will get whatever elder concession the transport operators choose to offer. Currently that is around 50% discount on MTR, buses and ferries.

subject: 8. Re: MTR/Ferry discounts for seniors and disabled tourists
usertext: Re: #6 -- The MTR website states that when the government announces the withdrawal of Elder Octopus subsidies (and fully moves to JoyYou), the Elder Octopus cards will no longer benefit from the concessionary rates. The language seems carefully chosen to imply that the cards themselves will continue to function, and the individual will pay rates as determined by the various public transport operators. (As GaYau notes, that rate is currently around 50% in many instances.) So I am assuming I can go on using the same Elder Octopus card, even without the $2 government-subsidized fare. Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 9. Re: MTR/Ferry discounts for seniors and disabled tourists
usertext: That's my understanding too. Paragraph 4 at the link below indicates that the government has asked public transport operators to maintain their voluntary concessions for people age 65 and over; https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202307/12/P2023071200242.htm

subject: Buying Octopus Card at Airport
usertext: Are there places at the airport where I can buy Octopus cards? Thanks.

subject: 1. Re: Buying Octopus Card at Airport
usertext: Yes, Standard On-Loan Octopus can be obtained at any of the MTR/Airport Express customer service centres located in the "buffer hall" immediately after customs and before entering the arrival hall, or in the arrival hall itself or at the Airport Station. Sold Tourist Octopus can be obtained from some retail outlets at the airport and from MTR Ticket and Octopus Selling Machines at near the exits from the arrival hall to Airport Station; https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/tourist/channels/air/index.html

subject: 1. Re: HK Disneyland in September
usertext: {Is that a good time to go? } - Yes, no, maybe! Depends on how you define 'good'. {Will there be less crowds? } Historically speaking - yes, school will be back in session so there will be fewer locals and tourists compared to visitor numbers in August at least during midweek visits. However, HK is ramping up tourist visitor numbers in the post-pandemic era quite a lot each month so not as sure what Sept dip will look like this year. May not be that noticeable compared to Aug visitor numbers this year. {Will the weather be good.} Expect low to mid 30s and high chance or rains in first week of Sept. It will be hot and humid for certain. See 2022 Weather for September (link below) if helpful https://world-weather.info/forecast/china/hong_kong/september-2022/ https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/wxinfo/pastwx/mws2022/mws202209.htm Disney in Hong Kong is much smaller compared to the parks in Tokyo and Shanghai. Definitely manageable in one day only. Make sure you research each of the three theme parks using the available online resources available to you. This is the best way to determine if they are worth visiting for you personally.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: HK tourist numbers back to normal?
usertext: Hi, I'm returning in late November for a 12 day trip. Last time I was there was Nov 19 and it was unnaturally quiet due to the student protests. I'm curious as to whether tourist numbers have ramped back up to normal again, esp with mainland tourists? Not that it changes our plans! Separately, thinking about a visit to Cheung Chau and or Lamma Island. Is it possible to combine the 2 in one day? Thanks.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: HK tourist numbers back to normal?
usertext: Tourist numbers are increasing but still only about half of pre-covid levels in the first half of the year; https://hongkongfp.com/2023/07/14/hong-kong-records-almost-13-million-arrivals-in-first-6-months-of-2023-a-fraction-of-pre-covid-days/ I wouldn't suggest trying to visit both Cheung Chau and Lamma on the same day. There's no direct ferry service between these islands. You would need to return to Central to change ferries. The Cheung Chau - Aberdeen ferry which connected with Aberdeen to Lamma services ceased operating in 2020.

subject: 2. Re: HK tourist numbers back to normal?
usertext: Covering both Lamma and Cheung Chau on the same day is super-rushed. It won't be enjoyable, even though technically is possible, because of the multiple ferry rides (you will have 4) involved - ferry riding time and the waiting time.

subject: 3. Re: HK tourist numbers back to normal?
usertext: If you start early and finish late I think it's OK. You could get, say, the 09:00 ferry from Central Pier 5 to Cheung Chau, arriving around 09:55 (I prefer the slower ferry on that route because on a nice day you can sit on the open deck at the rear of Deluxe class). Wander around Cheung Chau for a couple of hours. Take lunch at some local eatery that takes your fancy at, say, 12:00. Get the 13:15 ferry back to Central Pier 5, arriving at 14:10. Get the 14:30 ferry from Central Pier 4 to Yung Shue Wan, arriving about 15:00. Wander around Yung Shue Wan and then set out on the Family Trail across to Sok Kwu Wan, which you should reach by 17:30. Have early dinner at one of the seafood restaurants in Sok Kwu Wan then get, say, the 19:35 ferry back to Central Pier 4 arriving just after 8pm. Those are the ferry times for Monday to Saturday - different on Sundays and Public Holidays. Details here: (Cheung Chau) https://www.sunferry.com.hk/en/route-and-fare/timetable (Lamma) https://hkkf.com.hk/en/timetables/ Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: HK tourist numbers back to normal?
usertext: Thank you! Sounds like one island per day is better, no need to cram it all in since we have a fair bit of time. And it may well be that after doing one we're happy not to do another. I'm ashamed to admit that having lived there as a child, as a family we never once went to either island. Several overnight trips to Lantau back in the 80s but that was it. Thought we'd explore somewhere new this time. Looking forward to coming back!

subject: 5. Re: HK tourist numbers back to normal?
usertext: There are more online resources making use of HK arrivals data these days. This page by Tradingeconomics.com shows line graph with pre-2019, pandemic years and current data. Sobering, viewing the graph at the 5yr, 10yr and 25yr ranges. https://tradingeconomics.com/hong-kong/tourist-arrivals

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: HK tourist numbers back to normal?
usertext: That's a very interesting link BradJill, thank you for including it. While I will enjoy it not being as crowded as it used to be pre-covid, I do feel for all the locals and their trade.

subject: 7. Re: HK tourist numbers back to normal?
usertext: I would not do both Cheung Chau and Lamma on the same day. You will be rushing both unnecessarily. Also, four of such ferry rides might feel a bit deja vu. These ferries are practical but don't offer the best comfort. Visitor numbers are definitely down vs pre-Covid. Popular attractions are seeing lines though.

subject: Overwhelming hotel options!
usertext: Hi everyone, would really appreciate some expert advice. So the Hk government is sponsoring flights/holiday packages from Australia. This has peaked my interest & with the amazing deals think I'll jump on board. I've researched the hotels, but not knowing the area, really am not sure where to choose. Couple ( 50 year old) love to explore, eat, drink & have fun hotel options are: The Silveri, Marco Polo, Grsnd Hyatt, Ovolo central or Southside & east Hong Kong. All similarly prided except the GH quite a bit more expensive. Any feedback greatfully welcomed.

subject: 1. Re: Overwhelming hotel options!
usertext: If Marco Polo suits your budget, take that one. The location is unbeatable. Have harbour view (if you get the view rooms), prime viewing angle. The Silveri is the newest. It is not too convenient, though situated right on top of the Tung Chung MTR Station, you can conveniently take MTR to other places (but will take extra time). Ovolo is a boutique hotel. The Southside&East location is not as convenient, but is close to the MTR Station. Again you can take MTR to other places. Ovolo Central is up on a hill if you are okay with walking back to the hotel. It is close to Central MTR Station. If you want to save money, Ovolo is not bad. You just need to trade off cost with convenience.

subject: 2. Re: Overwhelming hotel options!
usertext: Thank you so much for your info!! Marco is definitely in the budget. Was thinking April ( but now thinking possibly January) is January an ok time to travel? Google says great, but looks maybe a bit cold? Sorry for so many questions!

subject: 3. Re: Overwhelming hotel options!
usertext: You will like Marco Polo. It is a 5-star hotel, similar rank to Grand Hyatt. But Grand Hyatt askes for a much higher rate because they are right at the HKCEC (Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre), and is geared for traveling professionals and deal makers. Its location actually is not as convenient as Marco Polo. Businesspeople would like to be able to walk 5 minutes back to their rooms to take breaks and make phone calls and not stand in the exhibit hall all day. January is fine. It is one of the coldest months in Hong Kong. But Hong Kong is in the subtropical climate zone. Its "cold" is mild. Mean is about 15C, low 12C high 18C kind of days. But occasionally there may be a coldfront hit and the temperature can drastically drop to below 10C overnight. And it will last a couple of days then return to more of the norm. To me that is a great time to visit, as this "cold" doesn't bother me. The month of January is very dry. April - high chance being seasonally foggy and drizzle. If between January and April I will pick January.

subject: 4. Re: Overwhelming hotel options!
usertext: Happy Feet. Thanks so much. Appreciate your insight here. Sounds like a great option & think I'll lock in January Cheers Lea

subject: 5. Re: Overwhelming hotel options!
usertext: As long as the hotel you pick is near an MTR Station, it is easy to get out and explore, eat and drink pretty much as much as you like. But if room rates are similar, I agree with HPFT that Marco Polo in TST is difficult to beat for being centrally located, lots to do/see/eat and drink and access to an important MTR Station.

subject: 6. Re: Overwhelming hotel options!
usertext: Excellent. Thanks so much

subject: 7. Re: Overwhelming hotel options!
usertext: Grand Hyatt is a step above Maro Polo though. It's also reflected by various review sites. Of course, whether it's worth the premium is only something you can decide. The location is much better than it used to be with the new Exhibition Centre station nearby. Star Ferry is also available between Wan Chai and Tsim Sha Tsui to where Marco Polo sits. Of course, Marco Polo still has the much preferred location.

subject: Intercontinental Grand Stanford
usertext: We are returning to this hotel after some years. There used to be nearby cafes where breakfast was served. Is that still the case? We don't necessarily want the breakfast supplement at the hotel itself.

subject: 1. Re: Intercontinental Grand Stanford
usertext: Restaurants are still there - some have closed, some new have popped up. See https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong for listings.

subject: 2. Re: Intercontinental Grand Stanford
usertext: There are always places nearby. If there were you remember with names, let me know and I can tell you whether they are still around.

subject: 3. Re: Intercontinental Grand Stanford
usertext: If you are talking about 'western' style breakfast, there are options not far away. Le Pain Quotidien at TST Centre opens at 8am. Wide selection of western breakfasts and bread products. NOC coffee (8am) and Black Sugar (8am weekdays, 9am weekends) are two local and quite good coffee shops at Empire Centre just a 2 min walk from IGS. Both have breakfast and pastry items as well. If you can go a bit further, one of my favourite breakfast places in TST / TST East right now is at Reaction Coffee Roasters 8 min walk along Mody Road. They also open up at 8am and do really good, healthy breakfasts and coffee. If you want something simple, more low-key, a long standing favourite in the area is Crema Coffee on Granville Rd. Open around 7.45am and have simple, stright-forward brekky and good coffee as well. 3-4 min walk from IGS.

subject: 4. Re: Intercontinental Grand Stanford
usertext: Le Pain Quotidien just shut down very recently. NOC is above average but a bit expensive. Service is bad though. I have visited a few times and the staff were always stone faced and uncaring. Crema has been around for years. The food is ok and the coffee is good. It's affordable for sure. Just upstairs in the same building, Number 9 Coffee has a small shop with decent food. Reaction Coffee at Mody Road should be a good choice though it's a bit far from IGS. If you walk further to K11, Ninetys is on the expensive side but is quite popular. If you want a local HK style tea cafe, go to Fu Wah at Harbour Crystal Centre. I wouldn't call it very good but it's adequate and probably the best in the TST East area.

subject: Quick stay hotel options
usertext: Hi we, (family of 5 with 3 older teenage children) have an overnight stay in August. We fly in at 2 pm out again 11am next morning. Never been to HK before. Plan to go to hotel, freshen up then out to explore and eat then back to hotel late evening. We will need to be at the airport fairly early next morning so other than breakfast don't have any requirements other than to get to the airport that day. I'm thinking it may be sensible to stay nearer to the airport but suggestions are welcome please. Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Quick stay hotel options
usertext: Well it depends on your budget, but I agree with your plan to stay at/near the airport. By the time you are through immigration you should be past the check-in time for hotels. So if I were you I'd be looking at the Regal Airport hotel (which is the only one which you can walk to from the airport) or the other hotels either on Chek Lap Kok (Marriott Sky City, Regala Sky City) which are a very short cab ride away, or, if they are too expensive, then in Tung Chung (a slightly longer cab ride). Get to the hotel, drop your bags, freshen up, and go out for the late afternoon/evening. There's no problem getting back to the airport by MTR, bus or taxi late in the evening and then you're good to go next morning after breakfast. TLDR: Regal Airport Hotel.

subject: 2. Re: Quick stay hotel options
usertext: Thank you so much for your reply. I'll look at the Regal - sounds like a good option.

subject: 3. Re: Quick stay hotel options
usertext: If you opt for a stay at Regal HKG, then you can use the Airport Express Same Day Return Ticket where your return journey is free: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/complom_return.html Taxi roundtrip is also possible with a slight premium over the above offer. However, you need to make sure you find a taxi that can hold 5 passengers. On a taxi, the green plate at the front denotes how many passengers can ride in a cab. Only the older taxis can take 5 passengers. https://www.hongkongextras.com/resources/Taxi+Red.jpg

subject: 4. Re: Quick stay hotel options
usertext: But note that 5, essentially adult-sized, people in a cab is really very cramped for quite a long ride to the city centre, even if they are licensed for it. I'd go with the suggested Airport Express round-trip ticket which will be much more comfortable.

subject: 5. Re: Quick stay hotel options
usertext: Is your check-in luggage all forwarded to your onward flight the next day? Or you will have all your luggage with you that evening? If you still have all your luggage, then Regal is your best bet. But if all the luggage is forwarded, and all you have are carry-ons and backpacks, then staying at an airport hotel doesn't help you much because you want to spend some time exploring "out in the city". You have a round-trip journey to make between the airport and somewhere near the Victoria Harbour waterfront either on Kowloon side or Hong Kong side. If you only have carry-ons/backpacks, I would stay in a hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui. A few dozen hotels at various grades and price-levels to choose from. Be closer to the actions. You don't necessarily need to take a taxi (capacity 5). Just take Airport Bus A21 and it will take all of you to Tsim Sha Tsui area. These are double-decker buses. Sit on the upperdeck, front rows. It is a perfect sight-seeing journey others pay extra to do (e.g. Big Bus).

subject: 6. Re: Quick stay hotel options
usertext: Regardless of where you choose the hotel, the Airport Bus is indeed a good way to get into town, whether that be A21 to TST or A11/A12 to HK Island. You can buy round-trip tickets from the kiosk on entry to the bus station at the airport. These are somewhat cheaper than the Airport Express train, and the view is much better from the top deck than from the train.

subject: Chung yeung disneyland
usertext: We are looking at a disneyland stopover in hongkong 21-25th october. We have previously been to HK. We would have 3 full days and go to disneyland for two days out of the sunday, monday, tuesday. The chung yeung festival will be on the Monday 23rd. Is it going to be crazy busy in hongkong and Disney over the three days or do the locals usually go back to work the Tuesday? Just looking wether it will be worth the stopover or be too crowded?

subject: 1. Re: Chung yeung disneyland
usertext: {Is it going to be crazy busy in hongkong and Disney over the three days or do the locals usually go back to work the Tuesday?} Normal tourist attractions will see a rise in attendance when there are public holidays but Chung Yeung is not in the major holiday category like Chinese New Year (CNY), Xmas or Mid-Autumn Festival. It is a festival that involves climbing area hills to spend time and make offering to ancestors. Some locals will take the opportunity to go to Disneyland on the day but it won't be a 'crazy' amount. I'd expect that Monday (23 Oct 2023) to see attendance that is similar to normal Saturday and Sunday weekend level attendance for October but nothing like CNY level crowds.

subject: 2. Re: Chung yeung disneyland
usertext: BradJill it doesn't sound so bad then, thank you :-) !

subject: 3. Re: Chung yeung disneyland
usertext: Also just to clarify: the holiday is just that Monday, on Tuesday it's all back to work. Considering the size of Hong Kong Disneyland (very small compared to all others), one day is generally enough to visit the park, especially if you go on a weekday and start early in the day (be there when they open, or shortly after).

subject: 4. Re: Chung yeung disneyland
usertext: I suggest you visit Disneyland on that Tuesday only. It should be the least crowded day out of your stay. As mentioned, HK Disneyland is also not large so one full day should be enough. The mainland Chinese tourists are back so there are always more people at the popular attractions.

subject: HK august 26-31
usertext: Anyone planning on August 26-31?. Best cheapest hotels suggestions?.

subject: 1. Re: HK august 26-31
usertext: {Best cheapest hotels suggestions?.} You might want to spend some time researching on hotel booking websites like booking.com and others to see what room rates are presently being offered at our city hotels for the dates of your intended visit. This is a good way to get a feel for hotel costs at various category levels including our cheaper options. I'd do this first, come up with a short list of places that seem interesting. Then cross reference against Google Reviews, TripAdvisor property listing reviews and whatever other resources you find most useful to see if those properties meet your quality expectations and location needs. Generally speaking, most here recommend finding accommodations relatively close to MTR Stations that will allow you to move around the city conveniently to/from your hotel/hostel or guesthouse. Good luck with your research and hope you have a nice time here during your August stay.

subject: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: We're visiting HK from 22-28 Sept 2023 and would like your thoughts on some questions we have : 1. Arriving late on Sep 22, our Day 1 started on Saturday Sep 23. We plan to catch the Peak Tram and spend the day as suggested, bus to Wan Chai, Ding Ding to Central, Star Ferry to TST and watch Symphony of Lights. Is Saturday afternoon to Victoria Peak a decent or bad idea ? We know we will avoid the sunset up there as it might be too hectic 2. We plan to do a 6-7 hrs daytrip to Macau on Sunday. Is Sunday a good time to visit or way too hectic and better on weekday ? And if we want to catch ferry roundtrip, what's the best hour to visit ? We're planning to go around 10 AM, lunch there, sightseeing, and then come back during sunset hour 3. Are Harbourcity and Times Square the two best places for mid-range shopping in HK ? 4. We plan to visit Cheung Chau Island (daytrip) on weekday (maybe Tuesday). Is late September a good time to visit or it's still considered typhoon season ? We also haven't been to Sai Kung, out of these two, if we only have 1 day to go, which one is better in September ? 5. What is the recommended restaurant for Fried Pigeon / Squab in HK ? We're staying at Jordan, and I heard from friend that Tai Ping Koon (Yau Ma Tei) or Kam Shan (Jordan) is old restaurant that still good. Is it true ? 6. Is Yikcheong (Monster Building) still accessible for travelers to take pictures ? 7. What is the best route to spend a day on foot covering Man Mo, PMQ, SoHo in Central ? Thanks a lot for your answer

subject: 1. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: Peak Tram: best to go there on a weekday. The weekend lines can be horrendous. TST promenade is also best visited on a weeknight evening. On weekends, there are lots of tourists. Macau: maybe others like BradJill can give you more pointers. I would think Macau on Sundays might not be a good idea either. Shopping: Harbourcity and Canton Road area have just about everything from budget brands to luxury. The downside again is the crowd. Weekdays aren't too bad. Weekends are still ok if you aren't after certain luxry brands. That said, Times Square offers the more pleasant experience for sure if it has what you need. If you don't mind a quick subway trip, head to Cityplaza. Cheung Chau/Sai Kung: September is still typhoon season but you cannot predict when a storm might hit more than a couple of days out. It will still be quite warm (around 30C usually). Between the two, I would choose Cheung Chau unless you want to take the Sai Kung boat to the Geopark. Pigeon: The "Yau Ma Tei" Tai Ping Koon location is really at Jordan just to east of Nathan Road very close to the likes of Eaton Hotel. It's decent so give it a try. If you want to Cantonese style fried pigeon, it's served at many Chinese restaurants that also serve dim sum. Monster Building: I don't see why not. The path to these buildings should be accessible to the public. Maybe you can also visit Cityplaza on the same day. SoHo area: Just take the pedestrian escalator up from Queen's Road Central and work you way up. Visit a wet market at the lower section, see some murals, stop at Tai Kwun (old prison) and perhaps join a tour, walk to Man Mo Temple, continue to SoHo for lunch/drinks. Walk west on Staunton St to see a bit of Tai Ping Shan St. Come back and walk down the very steep Aberdeen St for PMQ. When you get all the way back to Queen's Road Central, visit the old Central Market which has been converted to shops, cafes and restaurants.

subject: 2. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: I only have one comment: RE: "2. We plan to do a 6-7 hrs daytrip to Macau on Sunday. Is Sunday a good time to visit or way too hectic and better on weekday ? " Don't. This will not work. There will be a 5-hour round-trip overhead with border crossing, sail or bus between Hong Kong and Macau, plus the connection times to your sight-seeing spot from the border to the place you want to be. You have under-estimated the time needed. Sundays will be worse than weekdays.

subject: 3. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: @SammyFD Thanks for the suggestions. We will alter the Victoria Peak to weekday but looks like the trip to Cheung Chau should be on Saturday. It's probably crowded too but I assume it's better to visit the island than Peak ? So far the itinerary is like this : Saturday - Cheung Chau Island Sunday - Times Square and Harbour City Monday - Victoria Peak and Central Tuesday - Macau Wednesday - Disneyland Thursday - departure I wonder if Cityplaza offer different experience than Times Square (tenant-wise) ? If it's quite similar, maybe Times Square is better ? We do consider to stay at Eaton (or Nathan in front of it), we'll try Tai Ping Koon, do you know any good restaurants nearby that we should try ? @HappyFeet234 Noted about the time needed. We do able to allow 1 full day for Macau daytrip and will plan it on weekday. We're thinking (assume from Eaton Jordan Hotel), to take the bus to Macau, sightseeing there, and return by ferry to HK. What's the best schedule for this ? Is 09.30 AM departure by bus, lunch around 12.00 - 13.00, and back by ferry around 17.00 feasible ? And if we're a family of 5, is it better to rent one way car to Macau (or much cheaper by bus) ? Thanks a lot

subject: 5. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: Though Cheung Chau might be somewhat crowded on weekends, it does have a more happening atmosphere as a result. On weekdays, most islands are very quiet. Times Square/Harbour City: choose one but not both. It's just not necessary. Even if Times Square doesn't have all the brands you need, you will almost certain find that particular shop in Causeway Bay somewhere. Sogo has a lot of brands, too but it's a much less pleasant experience since space is much tighter there. Times Square vs Cityplaza; Tenants are mostly similar though for mid-tier, you might actually find more at Cityplaza. You can always go on their respective websites to see a store list. Restaurants near Jordan: Reunion Garden at Hillwood Road: The dim sum quality is pretty good. It's not the cheapest but doesn't approach a 5* hotel restaurant price either. Chiu Mei Chong at Woosung St: Chiuchow style food. They have various items like goose, squid, tofu, etc soaked in a blend of traditional sauce which is good. They also serve many other traditional Chiuchow items. This place is a small local eatery so nothing fancy. Australia Dairy Company: I don't necessarily recommend going during breakfast or lunch when the line can get crazily long. Their best item is the steamed milk and steamed egg custard. Go in the later afternoon when the line is short. I believe they are now closed on Thursdays.

subject: 6. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: RE: "Is 09.30 AM departure by bus, lunch around 12.00 - 13.00, and back by ferry around 17.00 feasible ?" What have you included in your plan to sight-see in Macau within this timeframe?

subject: 7. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: 9:30 departure from your hotel means it'll be close to noon by the time you arrive at say Senado Square. Nicely in time to find a place to have lunch. To catch the 17:00 ferry back to Hong Kong you have to leave from that point no later than about 16:15, arriving at your hotel by 19:00. That schedule leaves you three hours for actual sight-seeing - out of a nearly 10-hour day out. For a day trip to Macau you'd better try to leave earlier than that, and stay into the evening - which is when the city transforms, and the casinos light up. Pretty spectacular and well worth seeing.

subject: 8. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: {Is 09.30 AM departure by bus, lunch around 12.00 - 13.00, and back by ferry around 17.00 feasible ?} A lot of useful information on the Macau forum that you can use to plan trips there. See link https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowForum-g664891-i12409-Macau.html And if we're a family of 5, is it better to rent one way car to Macau (or much cheaper by bus) ? Definitely cheaper to use buses but note they are not easy to use if you are unfamiliar with the streets of Macau and the bus routes, etc.... They are also usually very crowded so it might even be difficult to make use of for a group of 5 even when you know how/when and where to use them in Macau. Again... Try the Macau forum for this sort of advice and suggestions for your intended day trip to Macau. Also, with such a short day trip stay in Macau, I think it would be best to focus either on the Macau Peninsula to see World Heritage sites OR go all the way to Cotai where the casinos & entertainment properties are and perhaps nearby Taipa. If you do the Cotai/Taipa route, transportation to/from the ferry terminal(s) is much easier as you can use free hotel shuttle services to get there and won't have to worry about figuring our public transportation.

subject: 9. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: @SammyFD all suggestions noted, many thanks @HappyFeet123 at first, we're thinking to explore around Senado Square but looks like the suggested whole day trip into the evening is quite nice too @wvmarle @BradJill noted and thanks, maybe 1 full day at Macau is the best way to go instead of returning early will check on Macau Forum for more ideas

subject: 10. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: @Stephen: With your original time-frame, it will only be enough to tour Senado Square area that's about it. If you want to sight-seeing something/somewhere else, such as going to the Cotai area for hotels/casinos, you will definitely need more time than that.

subject: 11. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: @HappyFeet1234 Noted and thanks in your personal opinion, what's the best route for daytrip to see the essentials without taking too long in one place yet not too rush-y ? I'm thinking, spending 1 hour only around St Paul and Senado, maybe lunch there, spend the afternoon to Coloane (heard they have Lord Stow egg tart worth to try ?) and see the church, probably 2 hours and spend the rest of the evening at Cotai before heading back to HK ? Also, is taxi there hard to get in front of casino only ? Wonder if it's easier to catch one, say at Taipa or Coloane, or it's always best to learn about bus route ?

subject: 12. Re: 6 Days Itinerary Questions
usertext: {in your personal opinion, what's the best route for day trip to see the essentials without taking too long in one place yet not too rush-y ?} As mentioned before, loads of goodies on the Macau forum including posts that cover this very question you have (see link and look for #2 Macau Peninsula - Five Suggested Itineraries for the Macau World Heritage Area) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14466654-Sightseeing_Planning_for_Macau_2023-Macau.html {Also, is taxi there hard to get in front of casino only ? } Again, on the Macau forum, not here on the Hong Kong forum (see link - #4 recent article describing how difficult it is to hail taxi in Macau these days) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14466915-Transportation_within_Macau_2023-Macau.html

subject: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: Cathay Pacific changed my flight so I will be arriving at HKG @5 am (instead of mid-morning) this September on a Sunday. Airport Express doesn't start until 5:54 am. My hotel is on Nathan Road, according to MTR trip planner I can take Airport Express, change trains (twice) and get off at East Tsim Sha Tsui station. My friend told me that taxi doesn't like short ride as the fare will be ~$30 HKD from East Tsim Sha Tsui station to hotel. Looks like 1.8 km walk to the hotel. Is it safe to walk to the hotel at 6:30 am? I will probably be quite jet lagged after a 15-hr flight (total travel time is >34 hours including layovers). Traveling solo with one carry on luggage and a tote bag. Is the MTR ticket counter at the airport open @5:30 am?

subject: 1. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: The ticket counter at the airport should be open around 5:30 am, but in any case, you can simply board the airport express train (there are no barriers at the airport) and buy your ticket from the customer service desk at Kowloon Station before you exit the gates there. I'm really confused as to why you would mess around with the MTR. Just get a taxi from Kowloon Airport Express station to your hotel. Taxis don't get to choose which fares to accept - you get in close the door and then tell the taxi driver where you want to go. For taxis picking up at Kowloon Station a hotel on Nathan Road is a very common destination. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: Alternatively, take bus A21. Direct, much cheaper (about a third of the cost of the Airport Express), much better sight-seeing along the way, and it may even be faster overall at that time of day. By the way, if your hotel is 1.8 km from E-TST station, there just has to be a closer MTR station. That's a LONG distance to walk by Hong Kong measures. Also it doesn't make much- sense to go to E-TST station if your hotel is on Nathan Road, considering Tsim Sha Tsui, Jordan, and Yaumatei stations are smack on that very road. Bus A21 also serves that whole section of Nathan Road. Now if you would give us the name of your hotel, we could be more specific in suggestions.

subject: 3. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: Holiday Inn Golden Mile. I.8 km is 1.2 mile. My friend said cab driver in HK dislike short rides. The MTR trip planner website shows those routes rather than getting off at the Kowloon station.

subject: 4. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: The only problem with the A21 is that it appears first departure right now isn't until 7am according to Google Maps and CityMapper. That is a long wait to catch a bus. If you I would take Airport Express to Kowloon Station and then just grab a taxi onward to the HI Golden Mile. The ride is about 10 minutes and will cost around HK$45. Don't worry about the ride distance. As stated above, taxi drivers at Kowloon Station are very used to taking passengers to the hotels around TST so this isn't a problem at all. Note: If you have an Uber account you can also arrange a ride from Kowloon Station over to HI Golden Mile when you arrive there.

subject: 5. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: You also need to brush up your map-reading skills. The Holiday Inn Golden Mile is less than 100m from entrances to TST and TST East MTR stations. The 1.8km distance is from Kowloon Station on the Airport Express, and, as noted, taxis on the rank there will be happy to take you. Depending on traffic the fare would be ~HK$30-45. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: I've never had a short wait for a taxi at Kowloon station. The Airport Express pick-up area is simply too remote for many cabbies to drive all the way in to pick up, and it's not just a problem with the station's design, but the entire site with ICC and Elements shopping mall is just too out of the way to attract drivers in.

subject: 7. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: Whether there is a line for taxis depend on your arrival time. In the early morning, the line shouldn't be too long. I have taken taxis from there several times myself at that time frame. Late in the evening is when you might see a longer line.

subject: 8. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: And yes, it'll be safe walking around at 6:30 am. Mugging is almost unheard of Hong Kong. Some pickpocketing in crowded areas, but even that is rare.

subject: 9. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: For Holiday Inn Golden Mile, you don't need to change MTR train twice. Only once. Take the Airport Express to Hong Kong Station (not Kowloon Station). Exit the AE Platform. Walk a short distance (all underground, connected via pedestrian walkway, there are travelators along part of the way) to Central Station. Then take the MTR Tsuen Wan Line from Central Station to Tsim Sha Tsui Station (the second stop). Use Exit N5 at Tsim Sha Tsui Station. Once you go up to the street level, you are right across the single lane street from almost the front door of this hotel (~50 meters). Normally bus A21 works well for this hotel too, no transfer. But as Brad said it doesn't start until 7 am. You will have an hour to wait to use it.

subject: 10. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: The method described in #9 is possible but Airport Express to Kowloon + taxi is more efficient and comfortable.

subject: 11. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: Thanks for all the recommendations. I will have 15+ hour on the plane to contemplate about means to arrive at the hotel. Hotel check in time is 3 pm, doubt if I can check in early (7 am ish). Maybe I should hang around the airport (too bad Cathay's arrival lounge won't be open till next year), or, take the bus to go across the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge just for the ride. I believe the bus terminal is near the airport and I can ride the shuttle bus from the airport to the bus terminal. I read that it's a very scenic ride that takes 45 minutes. I wonder if I can just ride the bus round trip (sight seeing) and not go through Immigration to Macau? Just trying to kill some time before checking into hotel.

subject: 12. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: Why not just go to your hotel, leave your luggage with the concierge, then hang out around Tsim Sha Tsui till check in?

subject: 13. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: Indeed - I'm sure the Holiday Inn will allow you to store your luggae before check-in. Do that and then do a day's touristing. Note also that there are free showers available at HKG airport before you go through immigration, so you can freshen up there if you wish. https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/passenger-guide/airport-facilities-services/shower-facilities

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 14. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: You can't avoid Macau immigration if you take the bus across the HZM Bridge. The proposed sightseeing trip would involve passing through immigration four times (exit HK, enter Macau, exit Macau, enter HK). I wouldn't describe the journey as being particularly scenic. Its 55km in total on dual three-lane carriageway which includes about 25km of slip roads, a 6.7km subsea tunnel and a short land tunnel with the main bridge portion being about 23km. Unless you can get a seat on the upper deck of one of the double-deck buses the views aren't good as the seating on the single-deck buses or the lower deck of the double-deck buses is too low down to get good views. Its just sea, distant small islands, artificial islands built to accommodate some of the structure and occasional shipping. Sea mist can often also spoil the views.

subject: 15. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: Ok, scrap the idea of bus ride. Will go to Macau some other time (to see the pandas). I am kind of paranoid about public free showers, will wait till I check into my room. Not sure if anything in Tsim Sha Tsui area is open on Sunday @7 am.?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 16. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: I don't think you need to be wary of the free showers at HKIA. These are individual rooms, clean, well maintained and equipped with free soap, shower gel and hairdryer; https://flic.kr/p/2oS4nfG Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 17. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: You do need to bring your own towel. For Tsim Sha Tsui, dim sum or HK cafe for breakfast. Maybe ride the Star Ferry. Trip to the Peak? Ding ding tram?

subject: 18. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: Thanks for the free shower info. It sure will help with the jet lag. I read on the HKG airport info that one can buy towel from vending machine. Does the machine take credit card? Does anyone know the quality of the towels? I am not talking about fluffy 100% Turkish/Egyptian cotton, just not the sandpaper/scratchy towel, otherwise I will have to find a way to squeeze a bath towel in my 18" carry on luggage.

subject: 19. Re: Arriving at HKG @5 am
usertext: You could dry off with the shirt you wore on the plane, then put on a fresh one. That'll work in a pinch.

subject: Traveling for 3-4 days, Should I stay in Disney Land hotel?
usertext: Hello, I am planning to visit Hong Kong for 3-4 days and I want only to stay at 1 hotel. I am planning as well to visit Disney Land Hong Kong. Should I stay at their hotel or stay somewhere near Kowloon. Also is 1 day enough for Disney Land Hong Kong? thanks

subject: 1. Re: Traveling for 3-4 days, Should I stay in Disney Land hotel?
usertext: Yes, one day is enough to see HK Disneyland -- it is not very large, as theme parks go. Therefore, since you will have several days in the city and only one at Disneyland, IMHO it would make more sense to stay at a convenient place in Kowloon, and ride the MTR to Disneyland for your day-trip there. You will also have MUCH more choice, and a greater range of prices, if you look in Kowloon.

subject: 2. Re: Traveling for 3-4 days, Should I stay in Disney Land hotel?
usertext: Stay somewhere else - 1 full day is enough for Disneyland HK and it is easily accessible by public transport. As a general rule, look for hotels that are near to an MTR (subway) station wither in the Tsim Sha Tsui / Jordan / Ya Mau Tei areas of Kowloon, or on the north side of HK Island between Sai Ying Pung and North Point stations.

subject: 3. Re: Traveling for 3-4 days, Should I stay in Disney Land hotel?
usertext: Disneyland hotel is only a good option if you want to immerse yourself in Disney (you do pay a significant premium to stay at what is really a very inconvenient location for tourism).

subject: 4. Re: Traveling for 3-4 days, Should I stay in Disney Land hotel?
usertext: If you only want to stay at one hotel, then definitely don't choose a Disney one. You will be paying a premium for an inconvenient location. Disney Hotel is for those who want the entire experience. Even if that's the case, one night is enough.

subject: 5. Re: Traveling for 3-4 days, Should I stay in Disney Land hotel?
usertext: I agree with all the above. 1 day is enough. Stay at a convenient location close to where/what you will be visiting/doing for the other 2 to 3 days. Take MTR to Disneyland is convenient. Or take a taxi. Doesn't cost too much.

subject: Suggestions for a Free day in January (Island Options)
usertext: Hey, I have a free day during my trip Would you recommend me going to any of the islands, Considering it is late January (28th January) and Would be cold. Its a couples trip, Staying around the Jordan region in TST Day 1 : Arrive in the morning, Settle and Visit Victoria peak Day 2 : Disneyland Day 3 : Cable Car to Lantau Island (And Explore) Day 4 : Ocean Park Day 5 : Free day on Friday Day 6 : Weekend Hong Kong Island Exploration / Shopping Day 7 : Weekend - Leave

subject: 2. Re: Suggestions for a Free day in January (Island Options)
usertext: As mentioned above, Lamma and Cheung Chau are probably the two best options for first time visitors. If you want to consider another, have a look-see of Peng Chau, which is basically a smaller and more manageable island that is otherwise quite similar to Cheung Chau. https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/great-outdoor/wellness/peng-chau.html Any of these three will give you a good mix of seaside village life, temples for local heritage, small beaches and bit of outdoors hiking that is suitable for families and not terribly far from civilisation if it feels too cold for you. Loads of regular ferry service between these three islands and Central Ferry Pier as well.

subject: 3. Re: Suggestions for a Free day in January (Island Options)
usertext: There will be new Frozen movie themed opening up in Nov 2023 at Disneyland so just in time for you to see it in January, although yes I agree, it's best if you go with kids Regarding Cheung Chau Island, I like to know as well, from the pier, it seems there are two trails, left will take you to Observation Deck passing by Pak Tai Temple, and the right one will take you to Mini Great Wall, wonder which one's better (and easier if going with kids) considering the view up there probably similar ?

subject: 4. Re: Suggestions for a Free day in January (Island Options)
usertext: Actually the trail on Cheung Chau is a loop (circle) trail so you can follow it all the way around the island going either way. It is around 10.5 km if you want to do the entire trail.... or you can just focus on sections that are more interesting to you, because of the shape of the island, it is pretty easy to do northern section (shorter) or the southern (longer) section and just return back to the pier once you find yourself at Tung Wan Beach. If you look at a map of the island with the loop trail, it will make sense. https://www.alltrails.com/trail/hong-kong/islands/cheung-chau-loop Which section is better? I couldn't say, I sort of like them both. Here are some things to do/see at Cheung Chau that can help you decide. https://www.tripadvisor.com/Trips/97899048/Cheung%20Chau%20Island https://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g294217-d21353187-Reviews-Cheung_Chau_Loop_Trail-Hong_Kong.html

District: London Borough of Richmond upon Thames
