subject: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Has anybody had a recent experience on taking a taxi from Kai Tak cruise terminal to Tsim Sha Tsui? Can anybody recommend a transfer or taxi service? Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: If you have mobile phone and wifi access, you can arrange an Uber pickup at the cruise terminal for ride into TST. You will find plenty of taxis in TST for a ride back out to Kai Tak.

subject: 2. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: If you don't see a taxi available, you can call one via Uber.

subject: 3. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: We will also be arriving at Kai Tak cruise terminal. Are the normally taxis waiting when a ship is in port?

subject: 4. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Kai Tak Cruise Terminal taxi queue might be a bit deserted at times. There just aren't that many ships docking there. There is also nothing around it. Taxis don't pass by the dock area. Sometimes, if a taxi driver finds out there is a lot of business at a certain area, that information might be passed onto others. Again, you can easily use Uber to call one if necessary though I am not sure how long you need to wait.

subject: 5. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Depending on how much luggage you have, you can also get buses 22, 22R or 22M to nearby MTR (subway) stations. All these buses accept payment of the fare (about HK$7) by contactless credit card as well as Octopus card or HK$ cash.

subject: 6. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: For Uber, I will need to download the Uber App ? How far is the walk to the bus stop? We each have a 4 wheeler trolley luggage plus a hand luggage. Are the buses for passengers with luggages? What is the name of the MTR station? If we take the MTR, we will be going to Sheung Wan station. Thank you.

subject: 7. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Yes, Uber needs an app. The bus stop is basically outside the cruise terminal. No further than the taxi rank. I guess the buses from the cruise terminal expect luggage. The MTR (from Kai Tak station) maybe less so - if you can manage your luggae up and down escalators then you should be fine.

subject: 8. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Thank you. My 1st choice is the taxi. But glad to learn about the buses and mtr.

subject: 9. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: If you haven't used Uber before, assuming Singapore has it, you might want to download the app now and perhaps try a short ride so you know what to expect. You will be given a license plate number of the car so be sure to look for it at the designated meeting point. It's very important to wait at the correct place as they wouldn't know where you are otherwise. I have seen people wait at the wrong spot for 30 extra minutes and got charged extra.

subject: 10. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: We had Uber before then it was discontinued. We now have Grab and Gojek. Sometimes we have to select a pickup point. And if not familiar with Hong Kong - selecting may be slight problem. I see how the taxi Q goes. Thank you.

subject: 11. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: I also took a look at the MTR lines. From Kai Tai, it is the Tuen Ma line. To her to Sheung Wan, change to the East arail line at Hung Hom. The change to Island Line at Admiralty and get off at Sheung Wan. Takes 25 mins and on a single ticket would cost $15. Am I correct?

subject: 12. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: The MTR website should give you the cost of the ride. $15 sounds about right. There is a cost difference between using an Octopus and buying single tickets. The Hung Hom transfer is fairly easy as it just involves going down one floor to reach the next platform. The Admiralty transfer requires a couple minutes of walking in addition to changing floors. For a taxi to Sheung Wan, I imagine it will cost at least $200-$250? An Uber taxi usually costs slightly more when it's not at a peak demand period.

subject: 13. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Yes. I read that with Octopus card, fare would be HK$12.80. But at Kai Tak coming off the cruise, we would not have bought the Octopus Card yet. Incase we decide on taking the bus to MTR station, without the Octopus card, we can tap credit/debit card to pay for the bus fare when we get off the bus? Then at Kai Tak MTR station, we can purchase the Octopus card ? At both Hung Hom and Admiralty station when changing platforms, are there escalators or lifts, since we have luggages with us? I saw a taxi fare calculator. From Kai Tak cruise terminal to my hotel at Ibis hotel in Central & Sheung Wan it is about $145. I suppose this is before luggage charges. So your estimate of about $200 is fare estimate. My first choice is still the taxi. But it is good to know the alternative choices. Thank you.

subject: 14. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Hi CP9596, sorry if I tapped onto your thread on transportation coming out from Kai Tak terminal. There is a lot of information in Google you can search. For MTR route from Kai Tak to Tsim Sha Tsui, try this website. It even tells you the platform to board. https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/jp2/ For taxi fare calculation, try this. https://www.taxi-calculator.com/taxi-fare-hong-kong/360 I didn't check on Uber rates as my choice is taxi followed by MTR.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 15. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: The fares indicated in the taxi calculator are out of date. They don't include the July 2022 fare increase nor do the calculations appear to include tunnel surcharges or luggage fees. The Transport Department has published a leaflet with current estimated taxi fares to/from Kai Tak Cruise Terminal; https://www.td.gov.hk/filemanager/en/content_276/202207_kaitak.pdf

subject: 16. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: You're probably best off taking taxi instead of doing bus, MTR, another MTR, walk - all the while navigating an unknown city dragging around a lot of luggage. Do note that most taxis are still cash only.

subject: 17. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Thank you. Yes - take the taxi - that's my thought too. Hong Kong is still very much - cash or cash only! We recently returned from London in June where it was mostly contactless /Paywave. Hardly used cash ! Enjoyed the convenience.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 18. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal

subject: 19. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Thank you SolentTraveller. Your article is very recent, passengers had to wait 30-40 mins for taxi. That's unpleasant. We are arriving at Kai Tak cruise terminal in early December. Hope by then there is improvement. With luggages, taxi is still the best choice. I wonder if CP9596 has taken her cruise. Would CP9596 like to share with us her experience ? Thank you.

subject: 20. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: If you see a long line for taxis, again, consider paying a small premium to call a Uber car. If you have at least two large bags though, it's best (and usually cheaper) to opt for an Uber taxi. In that case, they will send you a taxi where the driver knows how to fit even 3-4 large bags into a cab. A regular Uber car (not the more expensive Uber XL) in HK is often quite small. I have taken trips in small Japanese cars and Tesla Model 3 a few times.

subject: 21. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Thank you. I downloaded the App Uber Hong Kong and keyed in pickup from Kai Tak cruise terminal going to Ibis Hotel Central & Sheung Wan. Yes, I saw Uber taxis. But I am not familiar with Kai Tak cruise terminal, and don't want to be standing at the wrong pickup point. I suppose standard taxis will have one pickup Q point. And Uber and private cars will likewise have a separate Q point, so that it is unlikely for me to stand in the wrong place and miss the Uber taxi ?

subject: 26. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: I've seen quite a few cases where the cruise company in fact did offer shuttle buses: to the airport and/or Kowloon Airport Express station, and to a number of hotels - the latter presumably hotels that can be booked as a package deal. These shuttles seem to have been organised by the cruise company themselves, and not all cruises had this option. The fares were generally pretty high (by Hong Kong standards at least), as can be expected from such a service, but then you're guaranteed of transport without any fuss. It would totally make sense to me indeed to have shuttle buses running between the cruise terminal and places like the airport, or indeed a major MTR station where if anything there are sufficient taxis available to take the passengers and their (often seriously bulky) luggage to all the different hotels. No need to pay from tax money. It can be payed from berthing fees, i.e. out of the profits the cruise terminal makes. Oh, wait, I think I just noticed a problem with that idea...

subject: 28. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Honestly I doubt the usefulness of this for cruise passengers. A typical embarking or disembarking cruise passenger has two large suitcases and a carry-on, even the vehicles used on airport routes can't handle this well. A major hurdle here. If that hurdle is overcome (or the passenger is an independent daytripper wanting to see the city - not very common in the typical cruise demographic) they end up at an MTR station which is, from a tourist perspective, pretty much in the middle of nowhere. They still have to find their way from there - dragging their suitcases on the train, probably followed by another train, and a significant walk, to their hotel. That's not something cruise passengers expect to do, they want convenience, and paying a bit extra for that is not an issue. It is of course possible that the cruise demographic has radically changed over the past few years. If so, that'd be a great surprise to me.

subject: 29. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: Agree. Shuttle buses for disembarking passengers with luggages do not solve the problem. We always travel with one 4-wheeler and a carry-on each. I saw pictures of the city buses Hong Kong, it is a standard double decker buses, not designed to store luggages. Certainly no way a passenger would bring the luggages and sit upstairs. In my view, Standard taxi or Uber taxi is still the best For disembarking passengers. I expect and would happily pay a KTCT surcharge. I can understand the reluctance of taxi drivers to wait for the cruise terminal since they cannot decline passengers travelling a short distance only. We cruised once using Ocean Terminal - had no problems. Just hope by the time of our travel in December, KTCT would have improved.

subject: 30. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: There are double deckers that look normal from the outside with luggage racks on both floors. Still, I agree it's not the most convenient solution. The buses with luggage compartments accessible from the outside are the best. Cross border buses to China use that configuration so travelers don't have to struggle with taking bags into the passenger compartment. My feeling is that for local economic policies, HK government is too reliant on the laissez-faire principle. Sometimes, market forces just can't solve a problem.

subject: 31. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal
usertext: >>> passengers travelling a short distance only. That won't happen, as the cruise terminal is a long way from any place any sane person would want to take a taxi to. A ride from the nearest MTR station (Kowloon Bay) to the cruise terminal is about $60. Most passengers will want a longer ride - e.g. to hotels in Kowloon, which would be something like $120-150. That is also key to the whole issue: taxis won't drive that far empty. They basically only drive to the cruise terminal when they have a passenger. There are plenty of fares to be picked up where-ever they happen to be. Likewise the airport, no taxi will go there unless they have a passenger - it's just that at the airport there's a constant and reasonably balanced stream of passengers in and out. Ocean Terminal doesn't seem to have a taxi problem. It is smack in the city centre, making it economical for a taxi to go there to pick up a fare.

subject: 32. Re: Transfer from Kai Tak cruise terminal

Hope the authorities will have time to put in more improvements having learnt from the last docking. They need to get their act together if cruises are going to be regular boost to the economy. We are arriving in Hong Kong on 10 Dec, disembarking on a much smaller ship - Celebrity Solstice - about 2800 passengers. But disembarking passengers with luggages will be a greater nightmare than daily trippers. I just hope by the time we arrive, the logistics would be smooth. Otherwise it would be a great discouragement to cruise to/through Hong Kong. Next time, I will check whether it is Ocean Terminal or Kai Tak terminal when choosing my cruise.

subject: 2. Re: Which hotel to book
usertext: I think you have got quite a bit of research work to do to help understand which of the 14 properties you have listed above is best for you and your family. Here are a few things you can do to drastically cut down on that list. {i don't know where all the metros are situated.} Do you have a travel guide book for Hong Kong with a map of the city? If not, you will probably need to print one and mark a handful of key stations along the Tsuen Wan (Red), East Rail (light blue) and Island (Blue) lines. No need to pen in every single station, just do those in the lower Kowloon Peninsula and between Kennedy Town and North Point (Hong Kong Island) on the Island line. This way you can see where the bulk of the most centrally located MTR Stations are in Kowloon and HK Island. Then use Google Maps to identify the location of the 14 hotels that you have listed to give you a better feel for how close they are to centrally located MTR Stations. When doing this, you will quickly be able to cross off places like Kowloon Harbourview which is a 10-12 minute walk to the Hung Hom MTR Station. This is too far on hot and/or rainy August days. You will also be able to cross off places like Rambler Oasis which is way out in Tsing Yi, very far away from pretty much everything and no where near an MTR Station of use. Then, just look at rating/rankings and reviews for the 14 hotels you mention above so that you can start to trim down your list. Places like Oasis Ave Hotel gets a 3.5 rating on Google Reviews while Royal Plaza comes in at 4.2. Do some comparisons, find out why some of these properties are considered much nicer than others you have listed. Also, it is going to be REALLY hot in August so you may want to give extra consideration to properties with swimming pools for afternoon cool downs for the kids. Some of the places you are considering including Park, Stanford Hillview and Dorsett in Wanchai don't have pools. Anyway, just something to consider. These are some basic research techniques you can use to create a much shorter list of properties that you are thinking about. If you can't pick from amongst those, let us know and forum regulars here can offer thoughts.

subject: 3. Re: Which hotel to book
usertext: You have a lot of hotels listed. As Brad said, they don't all belong to the same class. If they all cost similar, JW Marriott is the nicest one. If you want a Tsim Sha Tsui location, choose The Mira or the renovated YMCA Salisbury. The likes of Stanford Hillview, any of the Metro Park properties, and Park Hotel should be avoided. Dorsett depends on the location but why if you can stay at JW Marriott or The Mira?

subject: 6. Re: Which hotel to book
usertext: Royal Plaza is a popular hotel choice for families and is near the Mongkok East MTR Station. With the East Rail line now extending to Admiralty Station (HK Island), you can move between Kowloon and HK Island quite easily from that location. Very nice outdoor pool and a major reason many seem to choose this hotel. YMCA Salisbury has a good setup and is also very popular choice in TST. The location is right across the street from the promenade and views of Hong Kong Island skyline. Rooms are a bit on the simple, functional side... sort of the same with their pool. Mira is a nicer hotel in TST, better quality rooms. Loads of shopping and eateries around the hotel, Kowloon Park is just across Canton Road and easy access to TST MTR Station. But further away from the harbour and views you'll get from YMCA Salisbury. JW Marriott (5 star hotel) in Admiralty (HK Island). This is a fancy place that I doubt you will ever find comparable room rates to the three places mentioned above. If so, take JW Marriott every day of the week. It is one of the better hotels in HK, can run around US$500 per night per room If you are talking about Courtyard by Marriott. They have two properties in the city. One up in Shatin. It is too far away and not a great option compared to Mira, YMCA Salisbury or Royal Park. The other is a good property and room but no pool if memory serves correct. Its not too far from Sai Ying Pun MTR Station as well. Personally, if I were choosing I'd go with Royal Plaza if you want a large outdoor pool, Mira if you want nicer room and to be a quick walk to the harbour in TST or YMCA Salisbury if you want to be right on the harbour with a decent room and decent indoor pool.

subject: 7. Re: Which hotel to book
usertext: I am surprised that you have a mixed grades (quite a range) in your selection. You can't say "hotels are very expensive" when you picked some hotels that are known to be expensive! I will give you some 10-second run down on a few (the rest I would not consider). JW MARRIOTT HONG KONG by WAN CHAI - JW is not just a 5-star, it is the top-tier of the 5-stars. At least that's how Marriott considers it. If money is no object, take it. No need to go further. ROYAL PLAZA HOTEL - Good, higher-end compared to the rest, good location. If money is no object, take it. EATON HOTEL - mid-tier, great location, good hotel. If you want a balance, take this. Salisbury hotel ymca - this is also good. Great view of the harbour if you have a view room. Drawback is it is popular and you must book early. KOWLOON HARBOUR FRONT VIEW HOTEL - if you want view of Victoria Harbour from your room, this hotel has some rooms to offer (as does YMCA Salisbury). Location is not the best convenient. Crown plaza hotel causeway - this will be okay if you want a convenient location. A bit busy in the surrounding though. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 1. Re: Kowloon or the island

subject: 2. Re: Kowloon or the island
usertext: Really depends on what you're expecting and the specific location of the hotel. If you want to be right in the middle of the Hong Kong experience, then either Causeway Bay - North Point on HK Island or Jordan - Mongkok in Kowloon would do. subject: 3. Re: Kowloon or the island
usertext: While the political landscape has changed big time, the geography of Hong Kong has not while transit links have improved. Overall, the considerations of where to pick a hotel have remained pretty much the same over the past few decades, except that maybe the difference is less than it used to be thanks to the improved transit (especially the East Rail line now crossing the harbour).

subject: 4. Re: Kowloon or the island
usertext: { Hong Kong has changed in the last few years. } HK hasn't changed in ways that would alter preferences one might have for staying in Kowloon or HK Island more as a tourist. That is pretty much the same as it has been forever. Most importantly choose a hotel near an MTR Station on either side. If you have harbour view preferences, that can impact your decision to which side to stay. And as mentioned above, your itinerary and dining/shopping interests might have impact as well.

subject: 5. Re: Kowloon or the island
usertext: <> Has Tsim Sha Tsui recovered its economic mojo since the mainland border re-opened? When I visited in February, it was a dreary and depressing place, with all the shopfronts closed up bearing "for lease" signs. That district was heavily dependent on mainland tourists and it suffered terribly from the border closures.

subject: 7. Re: Kowloon or the island
usertext: One of the rare silver linings of the pandemic was that with no tourists around, the insufferable crowds of TST cleared out completely for a few years. We were taking evening walks along the promenade with sparsely spaced out locals. It was quiet, peaceful and something I'd not experienced in my years in Hong Kong. We knew this was a rare treat that wouldn't last and it didn't. As soon as the border reopened and the first groups of tourists started returning into HK. TST started to refill with tourists, many of those shops that remained empty started to reopen and the streets are becoming busier and busier by the day. Ave. of Stars feels is back to be crowded pretty much at all times of the day as well. TST East seems slower to catch up with the pre pandemic crowds but TST proper is getting there pretty fast.

subject: typhoon
usertext: Dear Hong Kong members, my flight to hk on 4--9/8 , just wanted to clarify it's typhoon during now in hk until 10 aug? any preparation during this time ? thanks

subject: 1. Re: typhoon
usertext: A typhoon (T8 or higher) never lasts longer than a day. Usually around 12 hours. At the moment the Observatory does not predict a cyclone to affect Hong Kong for the next few days. Cyclones can form quickly and are highly unpredictable, so not much can be said about a week from now other than general statistics. All info on cyclones (predicted and statistically) you can find on https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/index.html

subject: 2. Re: typhoon
usertext: Will probably rain next week and with typhoons there is always the chance for big winds (gusts). If the typhoon gets close we go into a T3 warning which means that we have to keep an eye out typhoon hitting HK. If we get to T8 signal, businesses will close and transportation suspended until the T8 signal is lowered. During T8 there is little you can do but hang out in your hotel and watch TV or walk around a bit if its not raining too bad or too windy. Also, no ferry service so forget trips over to Macau or outer islands during T8. Flight cancellations and delays into and out of HKIA is another thing to watch for when it comes to typhoons in HK. Best to watch the HK Observatory for local weather updates over the next few days so you know what to expect. Otherwise, not much you can do at the moment other than to keep up to date on local weather in HK.

subject: 3. Re: typhoon
usertext: The current typhoon is expected to hit Okinawa and then further west into China south of Shanghai. It won't come near HK. The long range forecast calls for some rain though.

subject: 4. Re: typhoon
usertext: There is no typhoon around now. Besides, even though typhoon signal no. 8 may have been hoisted, sometimes planes can still land. It all depends on how big the pilot's balls are. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Best time to visit HK in 2024
usertext: Hi All! I want to visit Hong Kong for one week in 2024 and I wonder what time regarding the weather could be the best? - 28 March to 06 April (Easter time) - first week of May - last week of May - first or second week of September Any suggestions will he highly appreciated! Thanks. Lukas

subject: 1. Re: Best time to visit HK in 2024
usertext: Solely from a weather point of view, for most people either late March or late September would be preferable. Between those times most people find HK too hot and humid for touristing.

subject: 2. Re: Best time to visit HK in 2024
usertext: Thanks! I also heard something like "the week commencing 2nd April is particularly busy"... but I am struggling to find why. Is the 2nd of April a special date in Hong Kong? I know HK is always busy but I would rather to avoid peak dates.

subject: 3. Re: Best time to visit HK in 2024
usertext: Climate info here: https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/index.html Pick the weather you like best out of the options, and hope that's what you're actually going to get.

subject: 4. Re: Best time to visit HK in 2024
usertext: What makes HK particularly busy is holidays in Mainland China. The primary ones are Lunar New Year (which falls around 10th February in 2024), the first week in May (labour day holiday) and the first week in October (Chinese national day holidays). As a secondary consideration, school holidays in HK would make theme parks (i.e. Disneyland and Ocean Park) a bit busier than normal, so yes, around Easter will not be the quietest time, but it will be far from the busiest.

subject: 5. Re: Best time to visit HK in 2024
usertext: Thank you guys. That gives me some good overall view for start. Can't wait to visit you next year :)

subject: 6. Re: Best time to visit HK in 2024
usertext: {Thanks! I also heard something like "the week commencing 2nd April is particularly busy"... but I am struggling to find why. Is the 2nd of April a special date in Hong Kong?} Easter holiday will be the end of March and early April 2024. April 4 is also Ching Ming Festival so there are several public holidays bunched up together. It will mean theme parks, shopping malls, restaurants and country parks will be busier than usual that week because of locals having several days off from work and school during that period of time. On the flip side, the weather can be really nice in early April. Very little chance of cold days and too early in the year for extreme heat or typhoons. Also, this is technically before the rainy season begins as well so while rain is possible, chances for big rains or long rainy days are still quite low. That all changes by the time May rolls around unfortunately. https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/wxinfo/pastwx/mws2023/mws202304.htm#:~:text=April%202023%20was%20warmer%20than,the%20normal%20of%20153.0%20millimetres.

subject: 7. Re: Best time to visit HK in 2024
usertext: Well, I am fine with bunch of local people all around. It's more like I would rather to avoid busy periods when hotel prices are skyrocketing. April sounds quite cool. But looking at the data from HK observatory website, seems like it is pretty cloudy. Would be nice to catch some sunshine and clear air.

subject: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: My wife and I will be in Hong Kong for a visit of several days. I have questions that aren't covered on travel sites. Are there any upsetting surprises waiting for us? I'm American, and my wife is an African who lives pretty much as Europeans and Americans do, so we are concerned about things like cleanliness. Are we going to have to deal with things like nasty public toilets or squat toilets? Should we take any precautions when going to restaurants? Are we going to have to watch our step because of public urination and defecation? I saw a Youtube video that said we would be expected to wash our own dishes and utensils in restaurants. That was unexpected. I also saw someone say restaurants don't provide napkins. We're preparing accordingly. We want to be ready for whatever happens, and we don't want to be so out of step we offend people.

subject: 1. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: I saw a Youtube video that said we would be expected to wash our own dishes and utensils in restaurants. That was unexpected. Wow, talk about faked news. HK is a first world modern city, probably cleaner, or at least on the same level, as European and North American cities. You won't encounter squat toilets unless you go to rural locations. The first time I encountered squat toilets was actually in Paris. You also won't encounter public urination, unlike NYC or SF or LA. One thing though, you may want to bring your own paper products. Sometimes public toilets may run out. Restaurants do provide paper napkins. But sometimes it's just a roll of paper. Also bring personal disinfectant fluid and wipes, as the concern for infectious disease is heightened in HK.

subject: 2. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: Thanks. I am relieved to read your remarks. I also see that the State Department is recommending Americans sign up for the STEP program. They say China is arresting Americans and holding them without bail, for breaking laws they don't know about.

subject: 3. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: While HK is part of China, it's not actually China. And I wouldn't put too much thought into whatever the US State Dept says. "for breaking laws they don't know about." Half the people in US jails will tell you they are innocent, so there.

subject: 4. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: Hong Kong restaurant faux pas? -- Ask for a glass of tap water. -- Expect fortune cookies at the end of the meal. -- If the waiter just hands you a slip of paper with an amount circled, tell him you want an itemized bill.

subject: 5. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: "Half the people in US jails will tell you they are innocent, so there." What do you mean "so there"?

subject: 6. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: The washing your bowl and chopsticks in lukewarm tea before your meal is a quaint custom that obviously does nothing for the actual cleanliness of said items. It only happens these days in very "local"/cheap places. Just think of it as a ritual like saying grace, or whatever you do where you come from. All restaurants provide napkins. At low-end very local places these may be in the form of a toilet roll in a dispenser on the table that you can take from as your need. But all medium to high-end places provide napkins just like anywhere else in the world. In my experience public toilets are at least as good on average in HK as in any European country - there was a major step up at the time of SARS (2003) and it has been maintained. The toilets in most higher end shopping malls are pretty good. And finally, please, please do not try to tip restaurant staff in the way that you would in the US. As local places where you pay in cash it is customary to leave any coins that you receive in change on the table. But this will be less than US$2. In places where you pay by card there will often be a 10% service charge added, and you should not add any more unless something really extraordinarily good has happened. Occasionally you will find places which make a point of saying that no service charge has been added. In these cases it is OK to leave nothing (if the service was mediocre) or up to 10% if the service was good. (Only go over 10% if something extraordinarily good happened) Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: Thank you for the help. I will pass this on to the wife.

subject: 8. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: The washing your bowl and chopsticks in lukewarm tea before your meal is a quaint custom... Ah, I see now. Yes this is more prevalent actually in higher end restaurants. They'll give you a pot of hot water and a bowl. You then dip your bowls and chopsticks in the hot water. It's a left over custom from the bad old days when hygiene was not nearly as good. In fact, you can still see this practice in Chinese restaurants in the US. You can immediately identify the customers as being from HK, as no one else do this. What do you mean "so there"? It means lots of people in jail claim innocence due to ignorance of the law. As it is said, ignorance is no excuse.

subject: 9. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: I wondered why you used the phrase "so there," because it is usually used during arguments.

subject: 10. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: You will probably find Hong Kong quite clean, tidy and well maintained compared to American cities. Some public toilet facilities in Hong Kong are modern and have attendants that keep them clean and tidy. Some even have free showers to use as well. The public toilets out in certain smaller villages may not be in the best shape in the world and those in the country parks can get overused and at times in poor shape especially towards the end of weekends with good weather when hikers flock to the countryside. However, in the main urban districts of the city around HK Island and Kowloon where most spend them time sightseeing, the public toilet facilities, as HK Gau Yau pointed out, are usually just fine and in better condition than what you find in European cities. Note that we have malls everywhere in city as well. They have bathrooms on numerous floors so you can always pop in and use them as well. Note: Interestingly, many MTR stations don't have public toilets. Again, they are usually near malls so you can just go there if the need arises. To add to HK Gau Yau's note on tipping. You can use wave pay features like Apple Pay (iPhone) to make payment at probably 90%+ of restaurants, bars and coffee shops in Hong Kong. If you do this, they never ask if you want to add tip like what you experience in the States. You wave, they offer you a receipt and you're done. When using the MTR, remember to stand to the right and walk to the left while using the escalators. Take business card of your hotel when going out. This way if you need a taxi and worry about communication barriers, just show them the hotel business card and off you go!

subject: 11. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: If you eat at mid priced restaurants or up, usually hygiene is ok. I recommend you take hepatitis A and B vaccinations before coming to Asia. 6% hk people have hepatitis B.

subject: 12. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: Actually, you can ask for tap water, particularly at smaller eateries like tea cafes. Most people don't drink it though. They use the water to "wash" their utensils. This practice is less prevalent when you go to higher end places. Anyway, it's optional so you definitely don't have to partake. For napkins, some give you free ones while others don't. Locals usually buy small packs of tissues. If you go to a local pharmacy/drug store, they sell it for roughly $1 a pack. Nasty toilets or squat toilets: At higher traffic places, the restrooms might not always look too clean. That said, I have seen some truly nasty toilets traveling in Western Europe. As to squat toilets, they are mostly gone. If you don't want an unpleasant surprise, it's always a good idea to look for facilities at larger shopping malls or hotels.

subject: 13. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: HK is certainly not the worst, but don't expect it to be very good.

subject: 14. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: In HK or the Mainland I've never seen people wash utensils in the cold tap water you'd drink. Always tea or hot water, usually a little ceremony where some tea is poured into a small bowl for swishing the chopstick ends. Which brings up another faux pas: using the wrong end of chopsticks.

subject: 15. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: It sounds like you are not intending to dine in fancy places? If you plan to eat local seafood consider typhoid shot. Ask your travel clinic. There may be squat toilets in some temples or sights outside the main city. No big deal. Your wife can practice at home. Bring own toilet paper just in case.

subject: 16. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: Well, I don't think my wife is going to build a squat toilet for practice, but it's an interesting suggestion. So I seem to be getting two kinds of responses: 1) Hong Kong is clean and modern in every way, and 2) it's so dirty you need two vaccines before you go.

subject: 17. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: Probably somewhere in between. HK is clean and modern in many ways, but it also has parts that are "backward". That's why we travel, to experience a new culture. I have all my vaccines up to date, not specifically for travel to any country, but just to be safe here at home.

subject: 18. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: I travel to experience new cultures, not to grow them in my cells. I'm amazed that I spent so much time planning and researching this trip, looking for problems, and never saw anything about hepatitis until today. They are certainly not going out of their way to warn tourists. The web says vaccination is recommended for those spending 6 months or more in endemic areas, so perhaps we will get out unscathed after 5 days. Is the seafood really a problem? Neither of us eats raw oysters, and it sounds like we should steer clear of sushi.

subject: 19. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: A Hong Kong government site says to avoid anything uncooked or undercooked, as well as ice and unpeeled fruit. These things can spread typhoid and hepatitis B, and it happens because people take dumps and don't wash their hands. So the comments about Hong Kong being a typical modern city with good hygiene standards were totally wrong. You can eat salad every day in a typical modern city without getting a disease. Looks like we'll be having hot or bottled beverages, no salad, and no fruit. The CDC says the tap water is safe, so there's that. The web says hepatitis B is not spread through food or water, so unless we play Twister with carriers, we should be okay. Bottom line: when I asked if I would get hygiene surprises in Hong Kong, the answer is YES in capital letters. There are two serious diseases spread by food and water contaminated by feces, and they are common enough to motivate the government to recommend shots.

subject: 20. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: Our medical office has a travel clinic. We usually check with it before travel to foreign countries. I get my medical advice from my doctor, not tripadvisor. As for seafood, there is a very interesting issue currently. Japan is getting ready to release radioactive water from the Fukushima Nuclear plant, damaged in the 2011 earthquake. Japan claims the water has been purified. But all the countries that get their seafood from the Pacific Ocean are up in arms. Japanese restaurants in China and HK are anticipating a huge decrease in business. So you may see much less seafood, not just sashimi, being eaten in HK.

subject: 21. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: I've lived in HK for 25 years. I eat sushi at least once most weeks. I eat salads several times each week. I've had the sh*ts from dodgy food less than 10 times in 25 years. I haven't caught hepatitis (and I'm not vaccinated against it). Don't believe all the scaremongering you read. You're no more likely to get sick from the food here than you are in America.

subject: 22. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: "all the countries that get their seafood from the Pacific Ocean are up in arms" This is factually incorrect. So far, China and its subsidiary SARs are the ones up in arms, according to this story in the SCMP: https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3227630/fukushima-discharge-row-hong-kongs-ban-japanese-seafood-imports-overreaction-or-one-grounded-science South Korea and Taiwan, specifically, are now said to be accepting of the wastewater disposal as long as carried out with due precautions. (Taiwan's attitude is described here: https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2023/06/05/2003800985 ) The hysteria seems to be very China-centric these days. (Also, it's not clear how much the ban will really affect most HKers, other than in the top-tier Japanese restaurants. Again, according to the SCMP, Japanese seafood makes up only 6.75 percent of HK seafood consumption: https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3229042/fukushima-row-japans-top-diplomat-hong-kong-accuses-city-officials-failing-show-scientific-proof ) Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 23. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: {So the comments about Hong Kong being a typical modern city with good hygiene standards were totally wrong. You can eat salad every day in a typical modern city without getting a disease.} Chris, relax, breathe and try to be calm. Unless you run into bad luck while here, there is a very high probability that you will be just fine in Hong Kong. If helpful, my wife is a physician and we take hygiene rather seriously. We don't eat in dingy back alley eateries but do dine throughout the city several times a week. We also eat salad that I prepare at home from produce picked up at local markets and supermarkets multiple times each week. Yes, we wash everything before preparing to ensure that it is clean, just like we do when we travel anywhere in the world when preparing our own food. We also eat fruit purchased in local markets and supermarkets nearly daily, every week, again washed at home before consuming simply because it is the smart thing to do. Have been eating locally in HK this way for nearly two decades and according to latest physical check ups and blood workups, we both remain disease free. Chris, you will be here for 5 days and if things go the way it does for the millions of other visitors that enter, stay, eat and use the toilets each month, you too can have a safe and healthy trip to Hong Kong. Just be smart, don't swap spit with strangers or eat foods that you feel unsure about and you will walk away without typhoid, hep B, cooties or whatever else is rattling your confidence. These are general rules of thumb for travel pretty much anywhere in the world and you should follow them while you are here in Hong Kong as well. If you do so, you should be just fine. Further, you won't have to seek refuge in McD or Pizza Hut for disease free hygiene and eating while here either. If you are not confident enough to ascertain and pick out places on your own, there are reputable eateries throughout the city that forum regulars here can recommend to you. Since you seem to have interest in salad, you will be happy to know that we have specialty restaurants which prepare salad, sandwiches, soups and wraps and the likes that have very high standards. I can recommend a few that I frequent in centrally located areas. TreeHouse (Central, HK Island) and Knead (Sheung Wan, HK Island) are very good places to start. Salfee (TST) is another pretty good option. You can also have packaged/prepared salads or custom salad bowls freshly prepared for you at our international supermarket chains like CitySuper or Marketplace by Jason's which have branches scattered around the city. Personally, I don't eat much fruit sold in restaurants in Hong Kong. Not because I'm worried about hygiene but feel less confident in freshness, prefering to pick out my own in markets instead. Feel free to purchase imported OZ/NZ/EU or NA fruit from CitySuper or Marketplace mentioned above. Local supermarket chains Park-N-Shop or Wellcome are ok as well. Hope this is helpful in alleviating your concerns and that you and your wife have a safe, healthy and happy visit to Hong Kong.

subject: 24. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: I think you are over worried. In HK, my suggestion is you simply avoid places that don't look right. Unless you have a very sensitive stomach, that should be good enough for most visitors. Again, for restrooms, large shopping malls and hotels have good facilities, so do larger restaurants. They are certainly nothing worse than where you are from. Occasionally, a small restaurant might not have very clean facilities so you might want to avoid those.

subject: 25. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: " I get my medical advice from my doctor, not tripadvisor." I've never had a doctor who knew how to prepare me for travel to every global destination. That's not what doctors study. Where I live, my best hope would be to be randomly assigned to one of the many Chinese immigrant doctors the US government has paid to serve rural areas. Also, hepatitis vaccinations take 6 months, and typical tourists don't plan 7 months in advance (one extra month for the time to get appointments). I contacted clinics and hospitals around here, and none of them routinely give shots specifically for travelers. Generally, they had no idea what I was talking about. Immunoglobulin is not available here. It has to be ordered. To get travel shots here, you would have to have a primary physician who is willing to let you tell him what you need. Tripadvisor is a much better source of information than local doctors, because it's full of people who have been through this. This is obvious. As it turns out, my wife has had all the vaccinations already.

subject: 26. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?

Practice accuracy. And pulling pants and underwear aside. Did it before and after knee replacement. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 28. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?

subject: 29. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: In case anyone else out there plans a trip to Hong Kong and then gets sandbagged by a bunch of weird alleged dangers right before getting on the plane, I will relay my experiences. We found Hong Kong to be a clean, modern city, just as someone in an earlier post said. As far as I know, neither of us got hepatitis. We didn't spend time rubbing ourselves against the locals, and we didn't borrow their toothbrushes, so I guess we didn't get much exposure. I don't have typhoid. I didn't get any diseases from the water, which is apparently treated by highly competent local authorities. I was told people might be rude, but we didn't have that experience anywhere. Just about everyone was friendly and helpful. Of course, I was raised in Miami, the rudest city on Earth, so maybe the people in Hong Kong were rude, and I just didn't notice. We were not arrested or waterboarded. I think those risks apply mainly to foreigners of Chinese descent, who go to Hong Kong to fight with the government. While we were there, we learned that the locals are terrified of the CCP, which is probably going to do a complete takeover before long and ruin everything, as it has ruined everything on the mainland. The subways and buses were clean and in good shape, much unlike their stinking, dangerous equivalents in New York City. The city appears to be free of violent street criminals, so that also distinguishes it from New York. Two sleazy guys did try to sell us dope, however. The food was good nearly everywhere. Much better than Singapore, which has an undeserved reputation as the food capital of the East. The roasted goose was particularly outstanding. We got lucky and met Mr. Ki, the roasted goose king. Very funny guy. It seems to me that Hong Kong is a place where you can get truly impressive food at just about every price level. You don't really need to go to expensive restaurants to get food you will remember all your life. There was one terrible food experience: high tea at the Peninsula Hotel. We knew we were going to a tourist trap, but we did it just for the experience. The food was garbage, pretty much, except for the scones, which were somewhat better than garbage. I would describe the meal as Barbie food. Two people could stuff themselves at a top steakhouse in the States for what we paid. At least our lunch photos looked good. The weather was unbelievably humid, and everywhere we walked, water from air conditioners dripped on our heads. It seemed like all of the buildings had a good coating of mildew. The buildings are very close together, so there isn't much hope of catching a breeze. We stayed at the Jervois, and there was nothing to complain about except the unavailability of the on-site laundry machines. The staff kept them running all the time, so they were not very useful to us. The suite we stayed in was very clean and quiet, and the people who worked at the hotel provided exemplary service. The neighborhood--Sheung Wan--was a good choice. It wasn't nearly as crowded as other areas of town, and there were plenty of stores and places to eat. Shopping was good in that absolutely anything we wanted was available, but the prices were about like they are in the US, so there wasn't much point in buying things. The selection of electronics was incredible. All in all, a very pleasant place to visit.

subject: 31. Re: Hygiene Surprises in Hong Kong?
usertext: Glad you enjoyed your visit.

subject: Non-Noisy Hotel Near Food, Stores, Etc.?
usertext: I'm pulling my hair out trying to find a good hotel for my upcoming visit. I finally decided to stick with Hong Kong Island in order to avoid sifting through an enormous number of places. I am looking for a clean, comfortable, safe place. I think it's best to be in an area where we can walk outside and find good restaurants and whatever stores we may need. I thought the Ovolo looked good, and then I saw a review saying they play thumping dance music until 4 a.m., which kept a guest awake all the way up on the 18th floor. Then I saw the Madera Hollywood, which looked very spacious but weird, and there was something about having to turn the AC on and off manually. Any recommendations? I want to stay under $300/night.

subject: 1. Re: Non-Noisy Hotel Near Food, Stores, Etc.?
usertext: I've been quite happy with 99 Bonham in Sheung Wan which is quieter neighbour at night once businesses close. No loud bars there, walking distance to loads of restaurants, bars and good coffee shops. 3 minutes from MTR Station. Rooms are much larger than usual, floor to ceiling windows so views can be great if you get a higher floor unit. Each room has a glass table that you can use as work desk or to enjoy take away meals if you are tired and want to dine in. They property also has an outstanding rooftop, usually with a few tables setup if you want to enjoy a bottle of wine or pizza while enjoy the views. https://www.99bonham.com/

subject: 2. Re: Non-Noisy Hotel Near Food, Stores, Etc.?
usertext: Thank you. I will take a look.

subject: 3. Re: Non-Noisy Hotel Near Food, Stores, Etc.?
usertext: It looks very nice. I also noticed the Jervois. Seems like you get a whole lot of space for not much money in this area.

subject: Sightseeing Planning for Hong Kong (2023)
usertext: This thread is for those researching and planning trips to Hong Kong in need of online resources to help arrange your sightseeing schedules. Resource URLs mentioned below are updated as of July 2023. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Must See-do attractions and sightseeing in HK 1) Hong Kong Tourism Board (Discovery Hong Kong) https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/index.html Managed by the Hong Kong Tourism Board, this if the first and foremost online website for learning about must see/do/tastes in HK. You can also pick up loads of good information on upcoming events, exhibitions, seasonable activities potentially taking place at the time of your visit to HK. 2) Hong Kong Extras http://www.hongkongextras.com/ This is a very useful supplemental resource - a real 'How To' guide for those needing more details than are provided in the website above. 3) Next Stop Hong Kong https://www.nextstophongkong.com/ A website that has good overview of sightseeing opportunities around the city as well as reviews of highlight attractions. 4) Time Out Hong Kong (online magazine) https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/things-to-do/the-best-hong-kong-attractions Time Out in Hong Kong is a bit too commercially driven at times and dining recommendations can be a hit or miss but they are current on new openings, events, exhibitions and do write ups on popular sightseeing and attractions that are worth a read ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Hong Kong Museums 1) LCSD Museums https://www.museums.gov.hk/en_US/web/portal/about-us.html A good place to start if you are interested in museum visits in Hong Kong 2) West Kowloon Cultural District https://www.westkowloon.hk/en/ Information related to recently opened M+ Museum, Hong Kong Palace Museum and other attractions around the West Kowloon Cultural District ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Zoos, Gardens and City Parks in Hong Kong 1) LCSD outdoor parks and facilities https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/en/facilities/facilitieslist/parks.html Government sponsored online resource with general information related to parks and leisure areas around Hong Kong. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Country Parks & Hiking Trails 1) AFCD (Country Parks) https://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/country/cou_vis/cou_vis_cou/cou_vis_cou.html Government sponsored online resource with general information related to country parks around Hong Kong. 2) Hong Kong UNESCO Global Geopark https://www.geopark.gov.hk/en UNESCO and HK Gov sponsored online resource with general information related to major attractions of Hong Kong Geopark 3) ALLTrails (Popular Trails) https://www.alltrails.com/hong-kong 4) DRONE & DSLR (Popular Trails and reviews) https://droneandslr.com/travel-blog/tag/hong-kong-hikes/ These two are good resources if you are thinking about doing a hike or two during your visit to HK ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Hong Kong Beaches 1) LCSD - Public Beaches https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/en/beach/index/beach-location.html Government sponsored online resource with general information related to parks and leisure areas around Hong Kong. 2) HK Best Beaches (TimeOut) https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/attractions/best-hong-kong-beaches A good place to start to learn about popular beaches in the city ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

subject: 1. Re: Sightseeing Planning for Hong Kong (2023)
usertext: Some information about temples in Hong Kong HK Best Temples to visit (HKTB) https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/culture/find-your-zen-in-the-best-temples-in-hong-kong.html Ultimate Guide to temple visits in HK (TimeOutHK) https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/attractions/guide-to-hong-kong-temples Chinese Temples Committee https://www.ctc.org.hk/en/direct_control_temple.asp List of temples under their administration and management as well as general information about temples (history, architecture, protected status, etc)

usertext: @BradJill. Thank you for the detailed information you provide. We will be in Hong Kong from Sept 12th to 21st. I had a quick question that I hope you can help with. The link http://nextstophongkong.com mentions about Ngong Ping cable car 360 tickets booked through Klook with a discount. They also mention about there being separate queues for these tickets. What do you suggest? Even if we book tickets online from the cable car site, we need to be in a queue to redeem the vouchers for the ticket? Thanks.

subject: 3. Re: Sightseeing Planning for Hong Kong (2023)
usertext: {The link http://nextstophongkong.com mentions about Ngong Ping cable car 360 tickets booked through Klook with a discount. They also mention about there being separate queues for these tickets.} Did you go to the Klook website to see what discount option is relevant to you? These are usually for particular holiday periods or for specific methods of payment like using mPay app. What they mean by separate queue is that there is a queue for purchasing tickets at the Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car terminus and a second queue for those who already have tickets. If you purchase online and advance, you don't need to get into the ticket purchase queue. You skip that line and go to the queue for those entering the platform area where the cable cars are located.

subject: Free Things to Do in Hong Kong (2023)
usertext: New thread with updated resources mentioning popular 'FREE' activities and sightseeing you can do around Hong Kong 60 Free Things in HK (SassyHK) https://www.sassyhongkong.com/free-things-to-do-in-hong-kong-whatsonhk/ 30+ Free Things to do in HK (TimeoutHK) https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/things-to-do/free-things-to-do-in-hong-kong Top 22 Free (or nearly Free) attractions (NextStopHK) https://www.nextstophongkong.com/hong-kong-for-free/ --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Note: HK city parks, country parks, beaches and the UNESCO Global Geopark are all free to enter and enjoy. A majority of the city museums and heritage buildings that are open to the public are free entry as well. --------------------------------------------------------------------------- Previous thread and discussion on free things to do in HK (2019) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k12111262-o10-Free_Things_to_Do_in_Hong_Kong_2019-Hong_Kong.html

subject: 1. Re: Free Things to Do in Hong Kong (2023)
usertext: There are hundreds of temples, monasteries and shrines around HK, most are open to the public and free to visit. Here are some resources on popular temples that are convenient for tourists to visit and see. HK Best Temples to visit (HKTB) https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/culture/find-your-zen-in-the-best-temples-in-hong-kong.html Ultimate Guide to temple visits in HK (TimeOutHK) https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/attractions/guide-to-hong-kong-temples Chinese Temples Committee https://www.ctc.org.hk/en/direct_control_temple.asp List of temples under their administration and management as well as general information about temples (history, architecture, protected status, etc)

subject: Revised itinerary - appreciate any comments
usertext: Our airline last minute change our flight timing and we will reach in the late afternoon in HK instead of early morning. Will appreciate any comments on our finalised itinerary: Day 1 Check in Dorsett Mongkok late afternoon. Shopping Day 2 Leave Dorsett Mongkok at 8.30am. Olympic MTR to Tung Chung Federal Palace for dimsum. Take cable car up to Ngong Ping Village and Poh Lin Monastery and Tian Tian Buddha. Take bus #21 to Tai O from Ngong Ping. Lunch then take boat ride and then go Tai O market. Take ferry from Tai O Public Pier to go back to Tung Chung departing at 14 16 18. Also buy prawn paste & husband roll from Cheung Choi Kee and egg tarts from Tai O Bakery. Dinner and Shopping at Citygate outlets Day 3 Olympic to Sunny Bay station. From there connects to Disneyland Resort line (about 1 hr) Disneyland Day 4 Breakfast nearby hotel Olympic MTR station to Kowloon Station Palace Museum (open 10am, Tues closed) and M+ Museum (open 10am, Mon closed) Lunch at Caf Bohme Dinner back at Mongkok Day 5 Breakfast nearby hotel Ocean Park Day 6 Breakfast nearby hotel Water World Ocean Park Day 7 Take bus #70 opposite across the road Tai Tsun St to One Dim Sum for breakfast Take bus #35A at Prince Edward station, Nathan Road to Tsim Sha Tsui East HK Science Museum Museum of History Dinner at Mongkok Day 8 Olympic Station MTR to Central then take ferry at Central Pier 5 to Cheung Chau Island (40 mins) Pier along Pak She Praya Road Tung Wan Beach - kayaking (any recommendations?) Lunch at Hing Lok Restaurant or Yu Lok CC Cheung Chau Island Trail - Cheung Po Tsai Cave (2km away, 30-40 mins walk) Dinner at Lei Garden in IFC mall or eat back at Mongkok Day 9 Olympic MTR to Hong Kong Island station, change Central station to Wan Chai station for lunch at Kam's Roast Goose [Take Ding Ding Tram to Des Voeux Road West at Sai Ying Pun (alight where?) Starstreet Precinct, Hong Kong Admiralty MTR to Mongkok MTR then walk 1km back to Dorsett Mongkok Check out by 4.30pm. Fly back to Singapore.

subject: 2. Re: Revised itinerary - appreciate any comments
usertext: A couple of observations... Route #21 only runs once per hour on weekdays (generally at :20 from Ngong Ping). https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/routemap/19 Note also that Tai O tends to wind down from mid-afternoon. The Tai O to Tung Chung ferry has more sailings on Saturday and Sunday. Olympic to Sunny Bay is only 25 minutes on the MTR. Two whole days for Ocean Park is quite a lot. On day 8, Olympic to Hong Kong station then through IFC mall to the ferry piers. Don't walk underground from then HK Station to Central station then to the piers - that's a very roundabout route. Also, although the fast ferry to Cheung Chau is 40 minutes, if the weather is nice I personally would take the ordinary ferry in deluxe class and sit on the open deck at the rear to take in the views. This takes about 55 minutes. Day 9. There's some backtracking here - I would walk from HK Island Station to the ding-ding tram on Des Voeux Road Central and take it west to the Central Street stop (assuming you're after dried seafood shops). Walk generally back the way you came via said shops (if this is in summer then follow your nose to find them!) then pick up the tram at Sutherland Street and take it to Wan Chai (Fleming Road stop) for Kam's Roast Goose. I'm not sure Starstreet Precinct is worth a stop, but if you have time then OK. 4:30pm checkout would require a special arrangement and maybe charge from the hotel. You might have to check-out in the morning and leave your bags with the concierge. Alternatively, if you are flying with Cathay Pacific you could do an in-town check-in at Hong Kong Airport express station as you start your day. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Revised itinerary - appreciate any comments
usertext: Is this your first time in HK? You are missing some of the typical destinations like the Peak via Peak Tram, TST Promenade, Star Ferry, etc. Near your hotel at New Kowloon Plaza, perhaps try this restaurant instead of Federal Palace: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/r-royal-ming-garden-restaurant-tai-kok-tsui-hong-kong-style-dim-sum-r683520 I have not eaten there, and Openrice isn't necessarily the most accurate when it comes to reviews, but it looks fine in general. After your dim sum breakfast, proceed to Tung Chung. HK Museum of History is currently being renovated so there isn't much to see. Also, even when it's not being renovated, the two museums together won't take you more than 2-3 hours. You can spend the afternoon roaming the TST promenade and maybe take the Star Ferry across. Assuming you have most of the afternoon, this can be a good day to bus up to the Peak and then take the Peak Tram back down. If you have visited the Peak before, then perhaps walk to the pedestrian escalator area. You will be able to visit the restored Central Market, Tai Kwun and SoHo area.

usertext: Also for day 9, the left luggage facility at HK Station is now open again (08:00-18:00). Currently you effectively plan to use an hour of your day just going back to your hotel to get your luggage. usertext: Looks good. Obviously you need to be ready to shuffle the plan around depending on the weather - days 4 & 7 are good for wet days.

subject: 16. Re: Revised itinerary - appreciate any comments
usertext: D9 {Lee Tung Avenue and Starstreet Precinct (if time avails)} What are you wanting to experience at Starstreet Precinct? It is basically a cluster of restaurants with a couple bars, bubble tea shops and handful of boutique clothing shops sprinkled in between. If you are not planning on seeking a meal there, I'm not sure there is much to see specifically at that location that will be of much interest. However, if you are wanting to spend time exploring Wan Chai, I might suggest doing the self-walk Wan Chai Heritage Trail* instead (see link) which includes some very interesting old buildings, some having been repurposed as art incubators and exhibition space. Others just view from the outside and move along. https://www.ura.org.hk/f/project/308/eng_final.pdf Just note that location #10 on the trail which is interestingly in Starstreet Precinct is the site of an old heritage building that was demolished and replaced with a new residential tower and ground floor Italian restaurant. #6 on the map is the southern end of Lee Tung Street so you can easily taken in the Lee Tung Avenue there as part of this self-walk through Wanchai.

subject: 20. Re: Revised itinerary - appreciate any comments
usertext: Yes 2 hours are enough. Note that the so called "Ngong Ping Village" really is a modern structure, a big commercial outfit selling this and that, along with food. I would not place too high a priority on them. But that is the first thing you go through (by design) when you walk out of the cable car. I would advice to skip them first. Go visit the Big Buddha Statue, and Po Lin Monastery first. Then come back to Ngong Ping Village to spend the rest of your time before you take your bus ride.

subject: 21. Re: Revised itinerary - appreciate any comments

subject: 22. Re: Revised itinerary - appreciate any comments
usertext: #21: It is not just a bus stop. It is a bus terminus where many Lantau bus routes originate and end. This 3D picture will help you. It is 3-D. You can use your mouse to pan around. To your right, that's the bus terminus serving multiple routes. Far at the distance is the Big Buddha Statue up on the small hill. Panning to the left, behind that white wall is the "Ngong Ping Village". They generally direct visitors to walk through the stores/shops inside the Ngong Ping Village (though you can bypass them by just coming out this way to walk by the parking lot and bus terminus towards the Big Buddha. Po Lin Monastery is somewhere in the center of this picture at a distance. You can't quite see it. But it will be obvious when you approach the piazza at the bottom of the steps from the Big Buddha Statue. Link (3D picture): https://maps.app.goo.gl/NqKbXKX8aEvPcU7e8 Link to pictures of Ngong Ping Piazza: https://www.alamy.com/stock-photo/ngong-ping-piazza.html?sortBy=relevant

You can pan around it at any angle left, right, up, down. It shows you the entire area from on top of the Ngong Ping Piazza. You can see the Big Buddha Statue, Ngong Ping Village, the bus terminus, Po Lin Monastery, everything from ~500 feet up in the air. Link: https://www.alamy.com/360-degree-panoramic-view-of-ngong-ping-piazza-big-buddha-lantau-island-hk-image332633374.html?imageid=667CCF5D-E0AF-4698-B03A-9CAAFCFBBED5&p=733678&pn=1&searchId=0cf50e4095c63696fd385b3f1bdbcfbe&searchtype=0

subject: 26. Re: Revised itinerary - appreciate any comments
usertext: Interesting family. Don't visit some of the best museums Hong Kong has to offer, while by visiting such places you will soon enough learn how to appreciate them. Calling places boring before even going there. Kowloon Park is interesting, lots to see. K11 well that's yet another mall, a fancy one at that, but in all yet another mall, so I understand they're not interested, who would want to visit malls, if you don't have a very specific reason to go there? I'd never even heard of this "cup noodle museum". Certainly not my cup of tea :-) If you're looking for museums: there's the art museum at the TST waterfront, and the science museum and history museum in TST-East. Though I don't know how good the last one is since the political cleansing operations; notably it had never been updated to the post-handover area to begin with.

subject: Hong Kong Weather & Climate (2023)
usertext: This thread includes updated online resources you can use to learn about Hong Kong's weather and climate throughout the year. Hong Kong Observatory https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/index.html This is the local weather resource that pretty much everyone in HK uses for current weather conditions as well as 10 day forecasts. If you are visiting HK, best to check this website starting around one week before your trip so that know exactly what to expect of weather conditions when you arrive. Monthly Climate in Hong Kong https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/cis/climahk.htm This HK Observatory webpage breaks down and summaries weather patterns and conditions (ie temperatures, rainfall, sunny days and typhoon likelihood) on a monthly basis. Using this resource, you can get a general feel for what the weather and climate will be like each month of the year. Historical Weather https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/wxinfo/pastwx/mws/mws.htm Use this HK Observatory resource if you want to view past weather conditions recorded during each month of the year going back to 1997. The information is data heavy so be ready to read a bit to get a feel for where to find the important information. World Weather - Hong Kong https://world-weather.info/forecast/china/hong_kong/april-2023/ Use this resource for more user friendly calendar style layout of daily and monthly temperatures and rain conditions. Just select the month and year you want to view. This site offers a nice perspective of what weather has been like in the past, allowing to you think about which times of the year offers conditions that you prefer for travel to Hong Kong.

subject: Getting Cash to Get to Hotel, Etc.
usertext: My wife and I will arrive in HK with exactly 0 HK dollars. I need some info. My understanding is that cab drivers will not take plastic. Is that true? Will we have decent opportunities to get cash at the airport? Each of us will have a big rolling bag and a backpack, so I assume mass transit is not a good move. I'm thinking each of us should bring a thousand USD because we have had some issues with foreign ATM's. Can anyone recommend a good source of currency in the Sheung Wan area? We will be at the Jervois, which, fittingly, is on Jervois Street. Not really sure how to make a cab driver understand our destination, but maybe there's an app.

subject: 1. Re: Getting Cash to Get to Hotel, Etc.
usertext: Don't know what your issue is with foreign ATM's, but that's my go to source for local currencies. Changing currency at the airport usually gives you a bad exchange rate, plus fees. But if you need local cash, and you don't want to use ATM, then I guess that's your only source. The name of the street your hotel is on is this in Chinese: . Copy the name and show it to your driver. Also have the phone number in case your driver needs to call the hotel for direction. There is a currency exchange shop on Cleverly St, couple of blocks from your hotel. I have never used them, so can't recommend. But in general, currency exchange shops in HK are honest, rates are shown before you exchange.

subject: 2. Re: Getting Cash to Get to Hotel, Etc.
usertext: Thanks for the help. I have had problems with foreign ATM's refusing to work with BoA debit cards. Not something I want to go through in an airport after 35 hours of travel. I also got skimmed in Turkey. Over a year after my trip, a couple of funny charges popped up, and I had to replace the card. Another strange thing: card readers in Ireland would not accept my American credit card chips. Waiters always acted surprised, like it had never happened before, but they must have seen it before I showed up.

subject: 3. Re: Getting Cash to Get to Hotel, Etc.
usertext: Maybe it's you, haha. I have Schwab bank. Their debit card is great for international travels, no ATM fees, no foreign exchange fees. And they'll refund ATM fees charged by local banks. There are other banks that offer no fee debit cards. I have BofA too, but never used their debit card for international travels.

subject: 4. Re: Getting Cash to Get to Hotel, Etc.
usertext: Sounds like the smart thing is to change a little money for the cab ride and then use cash to get money at a better rate the next day. Hard to believe Hong Kong is so behind the times with cab fares. New York cabs were taking cards 23 years ago.

subject: 5. Re: Getting Cash to Get to Hotel, Etc.
usertext: I think HK cabs do take credit cards, although I don't think all of them do. You can always do Uber.

subject: 6. Re: Getting Cash to Get to Hotel, Etc.
usertext: Public transport in HK is brilliant, and anything leaving the airport has ample room for big luggage. Airport Express looks convenient to your hotel, it's quick, and I'm pretty sure they take plastic. Chungking Mansions, just up from the harbour on the Kowloon side, is a highly competitive place to change money.

subject: 7. Re: Getting Cash to Get to Hotel, Etc.
usertext: "Don't know what your issue is with foreign ATM's, but that's my go to source for local currencies" Are the currency conversion rates used by HK ATMs are in par with the rates given at money exchanges in the town? My experience in some Asian countries is that ATM conversion rates are about 5% less (for both Visa and Mastercard) than what you get from the money exchanges.

subject: 8. Re: Getting Cash to Get to Hotel, Etc.
usertext: The currency conversion rates come from the underlying payment provider (Matercard/Cirrus or Visa/Plus). Banks in Hong Kong don't add any fees for ATM withdrawals by foreign cards. There are some other ATMs which do, but simply avoid them. Stick to ATMs associated with major banks (HSBC, Bank of China, Hang Seng, Standard Chartered, etc) and you'd get the standard rate. Whether your bank then adds any surcharges is something you need to check with them.

subject: 9. Re: Getting Cash to Get to Hotel, Etc.
usertext: HKD is pegged to USD. So if you are changing USD, the rate don't vary much day to day. Money changers probably charge a bit more than banks. I also heard that money changing kiosk on the corners of streets charge more than those in the middle of a block. But frankly, unless you are changing huge amounts of money, it does not make a whole lot of difference.

subject: HK Island vs Kowloon - Where to Stay (2023)
usertext: Little has changed to this conversation over the past couple of decades but it remains a regular question visitors are faced with when deciding what area of the city to stay during trips to Hong Kong. While there are other places around the New Territories, Lantau Island and outlying islands as well as near the airport most visitors choose hotels in the centrally located districts of Hong Kong Island or Kowloon. But which is better? There is no correct answer to this question and generally speaking as long as you are staying near an MTR Station, you will be able to move around the city with ease and convenience. Note that transportation between the two are plentiful, frequent and don't take much time. A lot will simply come down to what your sightseeing and dining itinerary looks like, what side of the harbour you prefer to see from your hotel and what property, room and room rates you are happy with when doing your accommodation research. With that in mind, here are a couple write-ups that go into benefits of staying on HK Island and Kowloon that might help with your decision. Where to Stay (Kowloon or HK Island)? https://www.nextstophongkong.com/where-to-stay-kowloon-or-hong-kong-island/ Kowloon vs. HK Island https://www.travellerselixir.com/kowloon-vs-hong-kong-island/ You can also use the Search Box on this forum and type in the same question HK Island or Kowloon? You will find numerous past discussions over the years with shared thoughts that are similar to what you will read in the write-ups above.

subject: 1. Re: HK Island vs Kowloon - Where to Stay (2023)
usertext: Searching for hotels in Hong Kong: There are quite a few hotel search engines that have good coverage of hotels throughout Hong Kong. Here are a few that you can use to start your research. You can also make reservations on most of these platforms if you find rates being offered there lower than booking directly with the properties. Here are a few popular hotel search engines for HK. http://Booking.com http://Agoda.com http://Trip.com http://hotels.com http://expedia.com.hk --------------------------------------------------------------------------- What about Cheap Accommodations? https://www.nextstophongkong.com/how-to-find-a-cheap-hotel-in-hong-kong/ NextStopHongKong has a good write-up and tool for budget accommodation research with the list of hostel and guesthouse search engines and techniques for finding budget friendly accommodations around the city. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- Hotel Deals and Promotions Discover Hong Kong https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/deals/in-town-offers/hotels.html Hotel deals and promotions are regularly being offered directly on the HKTB - Discover Hong Kong website. You will also find respective hotels offering promotions directly on their websites. This is always worth checking out before making final bookings. --------------------------------------------------------------------------- What about Airbnb in Hong Kong? https://www.airbnb.com/a/stays/Hong-Kong Yes, AirB2B is legal in Hong Kong but there can be problems with unlicensed guesthouses offering rooms on that website. Here is a recent article (Jan 2023) with HKFP that sort of dives into that situation. https://hongkongfp.com/2023/01/24/govt-staff-staying-overnight-at-hong-kong-airbnbs-as-part-of-guesthouse-licence-investigations/
