subject: Best way to get to Macau from Kowloon?
usertext: I'm currently staying in Kowloon, and I want to go to Macau for a day trip. I've read several websites about traveling to Macau, but they seem overly complicated. One method said to go back to Hong Kong Airport, and take a bus from there to Macau, which doesn't make sense. I also saw tickets for a bus going to Macau, but it said that the journey will take 4 hours, which seems a little silly considering that the ferry takes less than one hour. So what are some quick and cheap ways to get to Macau from Kowloon? Which bus or ferry could be best?

subject: 1. Re: Best way to get to Macau from Kowloon?
usertext: If you open Google Map and search where Macau locates, you will know why the bus needs to pass HK Airport. Go to HK Airport and take the bus there is the cheapest way. Plus there are multiple buses during the day. If you are looking for a so-called direct bus from Kowloon, a few companies provide the service https://www.tilchinalink.com/stations.php?lang=en https://www.hkmoexpress.com/#/pages/index/index

subject: 2. Re: Best way to get to Macau from Kowloon?
usertext: The bus is a smooth but boring trip across the Pearl River Delta. The ferry is a hydrofoil and even in good weather it's not a pleasant journey. You really can't see anything out of the windows because of the spray. But your choice.

subject: 3. Re: Best way to get to Macau from Kowloon?
usertext: i don't hink the Kowloon-Macau ferries have resumed yet. The cheapest way is to take the MTR to Sunny Bay, then transfer to B5 (15 minutes) to the bridge immigration building. Exit Hong Kong, and board one of the golden buses that run across the bridge (40 minutes). Enter Macau, then take the casino or local buses into town. It's a lot more moving around than the ferry, but is significantly cheaper. I recall the bridge bus is only about $65 in each direction, but is not a time saver since the immigration building is far from the city centre on both sides.

subject: 5. Re: Best way to get to Macau from Kowloon?
usertext: {So what are some quick and cheap ways to get to Macau from Kowloon? Which bus or ferry could be best?} This thread on the Macau forum describes main forms of transportation between Hong Kong and Macau (see link) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html Depending on where you are staying in Kowloon, airport bus to the HZM bridge is crossing over there is a good option. However, if you just want to spend time on the Cotai Strip to see the huge casino properties and entertainment complexes, you can do well to take the Cotai Water Jet from the HK Macau ferry terminal in Sheung Wan. It arrives at the Taipa Ferry Terminal where you can use free shuttle buses to the big casinos or try the new LRT. Remember that ferries require sticking to specific travel times where as crossing over by bus, you can just go and return whenever you like as the bridge and Golden Shuttles operate continuously 24 hours a day.

subject: 6. Re: Best way to get to Macau from Kowloon?
usertext: >>> I also saw tickets for a bus going to Macau, but it said that the journey will take 4 hours, which seems a little silly considering that the ferry takes less than one hour. That's pier to pier. By that same measure the bus would be even faster: it takes a little over half an hour or so for the trek from one end of the bridge to the other. That four hours is a bit much, it's more like 2 1/2-3 hours to make the one way trip - that's the time it takes from leaving your hotel to arriving at the interesting parts of Macau. An hour for the ferry (or the bus across the bridge), plus overhead: transport to/from piers/bridgeheads, immigration, ticketing, waiting. By the way, those hydrofoils did just fine for me. The cats were better: newer, better seats, and far larger thus by nature more stable. Buses tend to be at least as shaky if not more than those boats. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: Best way to get to Macau from Kowloon?
usertext: (As the name implies, Turbojet's "Foilcat" is a catamaran equipped with hydrofoils.)

subject: 8. Re: Best way to get to Macau from Kowloon?
usertext: Thanks for the replies. I ended up taking the metro from Jordan Station to Central Station, and hopping on a Turbojet ferry at Hong Kong Seaport (Sheung Wan). It seems to be the fastest and cheapest way to get to Macau quickly. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Revisions to Taxi surcharges when crossing the harbour
usertext: The tunnel tolls and surcharges for taxis between Hong Kong Island and Kowloon have just changed. The new toll for a taxi taking any of the 3 tunnels is HK$25. Unless the passenger boarded the taxi at a "cross-harbour taxi rank" then they must also pay the return tunnel toll. Thus, in most cases, when taking a taxi through any of the 3 tunnels under the harbour (for example from the airport to HK Island) the passenger will need to pay a total of HK$50 in tunnel surcharges. The surcharge of HK$6 for each item of luggage carried in the boot/trunk remains. The locations of taxi stands (showing which are cross-harbour stands) are listed in this XLS file: https://www.td.gov.hk/filemanager/en/content_276/taxi_stand_20230406.xls

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Hong Kong itinerary
usertext: In late September and early October, my partner and I will be spending 8 days in Hong Kong Our accommodation plan involves staying at both Kerry Hotel and The Hari. We are eager to sightsee, enjoy the food and drink, and try new experiences, especially if they are specific to Hong Kong. We are also wondering if it would be worth doing a day trip to Macau during our stay. We would appreciate recommendations on must-see attractions for our itinerary that align with our interests. Additionally, we are considering whether switching hotels is necessary, as it could offer a chance to experience both sides of the city. Any opinions on this would be welcomed. Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong itinerary
usertext: You can start here for researching attractions and sightseeing in Hong Kong (see link) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14480758-Sightseeing_Planning_for_Hong_Kong_2023-Hong_Kong.html {We are also wondering if it would be worth doing a day trip to Macau during our stay.} Depends on your interests. Some enjoy day trips to Macau, others prefer to spend a couple nights there, while others don't enjoy the 4-4.5 hours of transportation required to go to Macau and back during a single day. Here is a thread with information on how to travel to Macau to/from Hong Kong (see link) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html {Additionally, we are considering whether switching hotels is necessary, as it could offer a chance to experience both sides of the city. Any opinions on this would be welcomed.} Most prefer to just choose a single hotel near an MTR Station which allows you to travel around the city with convenience and avoiding have to pack up and move to another property somewhere else at the expense of valuable and limited sightseeing time. Others just like staying in multiple hotels and this is ok as well if this is what you enjoy doing during your travels.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong itinerary
usertext: Moving between those hotels would take less than 20 minutes. I don't see the point. Pick the one you prefer and stick with it. Personally I'd go with The Hari between those two just because it's marginally closer to MTR stations (although neither of them is that close by HK standards),

subject: Food markets and stalls near Wanchai?
usertext: Having visited all the ASEAN countries, we like to eat at small local restaurants, food stalls, or food courts. We have not had problems eating local food if it is cooked. Can members recommend suitable places to visit near Wanchai / HK Arts Centre? We only have a few days in the City and will probably be jet lagged, so would prefer not to have to travel too far, although if it is easily accessible on the tram or MRT that would be fine. Wan Chai and Exhibition will be our nearest MRT stations. Thanks for your help, Arthur

subject: 1. Re: Food markets and stalls near Wanchai?
usertext: HK is one of the great restaurant cities in the world. There are so many local small restaurants, you won't run out of options. However, HK is not good at street food, but there are food courts in shopping malls.

subject: 2. Re: Food markets and stalls near Wanchai?
usertext: Well the nearest place is Lockhart Road Market, which has a cooked food centre on the second floor. But you'll really struggle there unless you can read or speak Chinese.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Food markets and stalls near Wanchai?
usertext: Thanks for that. So not like Japan where there are pictures to point at? We had to survive in Japan not speaking a word of the language, so we looked at what other people were buying and pointed at someone's plate if it looked nice. Seemed to work, although we often had no idea what we had just eaten :-)

subject: 4. Re: Food markets and stalls near Wanchai?
usertext: It isn't difficult to get around the language barrier at many local eateries on the streets of Wanchai as they will have pictures in the window or menus with pictures. Quite a few restaurants will have dual language menus or at least one English menu on hand. Cooked food centres like the one on Lockhart Road don't really bother as they just don't see many foreigners. So it is a real challenge to try to dine at these places if you can't read/speak Cantonese. However, a few around the city have small eateries that make a better effort and do attract some foreigners/tourists who want to try. Here is a list of better cooked food centre options for tourists around the city. The Shueng Wan Market and Queen's Road Market are the closest to Wanchai that are reasonably easy enough to try. https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/restaurants/best-cooked-food-markets-in-hong-kong Sort of a cross over is the dai pai dong scene or at least the extent of which this famous street food scene remains in Hong Kong. Again, another decent list of places that have survived in Hong Kong. There are dai pai dong setups referenced in Tai Hang, a neighbourhood in the Causeway Bay area just east of Wanchai as well as others in Central and Sheung Wan to the west. https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/restaurants/best-cooked-food-markets-in-hong-kong

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 5. Re: Food markets and stalls near Wanchai?
usertext: That's great - just what we needed. Thanks for the info. Arthur

subject: Two days in Hong Kong
usertext: I will arrive in the evening and then have the next two full days. I'm staying in TST. Hopefully jet lag won't be too bad, but I may need to return to the hotel to nap. I was thinking I would take the Star Ferry and do the Victoria Peak Tram the first morning, weather permitting. Will I need a bus to get to the tram? Should I buy a ticket in advance? Is it worth going to/helpful to use the escalators? Is there anything else I should see before taking the ferry back? I am also interested in the Ngong Ping Skyrail to see Tian Tan Buddha - do I need to go back to TST to get to Lantau Island? Is this a big day? Should I do this the next day? Do you recommend buying the skyrail ticket in advance? I love gardens, so thought of Nan Lian, maybe better to do this in the afternoon and save Lantau Island for my second day? Thanks for any advice!

subject: 1. Re: Two days in Hong Kong
usertext: Star Ferry & Peak Questions Star Ferry TST to Central route begins at 6.30am in the morning. https://www.starferry.com.hk/en/service You can walk to the Peak Tram Lower Terminus. It is around 1.5km (20-25 min walk) from the Central Ferry Pier where you will arrive on the Star Ferry. Use google maps which plots good walking routes you can take. It is a generally flat walk until you reach Garden Road then the last you walk uphill for 300 metres or so until you reach the Peak Tram Lower Terminus. The Peak website states operating hours are now 7.30am. Used to be 7am if memory serves correct but right now it says 7.30am. https://www.thepeak.com.hk/en/getting-to-the-peak/location No need to purchase a ticket first thing in the morning even if visiting on weekend. If you have an Octopus Card, just walk to the till, tap it and enter the platform area, just like when using the MTR. {Is it worth going to/helpful to use the escalators?} What escalators are you referring to? The Mid-Level escalators? These are on the other side of Central District and not something easily combined with visits to The Peak. {Is there anything else I should see before taking the ferry back?} Really depends on your interests and time available. There is quite a bit to do/see/eat in the Admiralty/Central/Sheung Wan area of the city and a great flat hike around The Peak along Lugard Road. It is called the Peak Circle Walk (see link) I consider this the very best, family-friendly, easy hike in Hong Kong. To the west in particular there are several open viewpoints that have outstanding landscape views of the harbour and Kowloon in the distance and the towering skyscrapers of HK Island just below. When sky conditions are good, the scenery is incredible. https://en.tripadvisor.com.hk/Attraction_Review-g294217-d17450219-Reviews-Peak_Circle_Walk-Hong_Kong.html As mentioned as well, plenty of things to do down below The Peak including outdoor recreation (HK Park, Zoological & Botanical Gardens), Museums and art galleries, historic sites and heritage buildings, Central Waterfront, harbour promenades, some good breakfast options, plenty of coffee shops.... It just depends on your interests.

subject: 2. Re: Two days in Hong Kong
usertext: Lantau Island, Ngong Ping and Big Buddha Questions. You can travel over to Lantau Island from Central but doing so really depends on how much time you want to spend around The Peak and HK Island districts as well as how much time you want to invest doing the Ngong Ping / Big Buddha experience. Personally, during the hot months of the year, I would do this first thing in the morning which won't be possible if you are first visiting the Peak on the day. As such, I would personally do this on a different day but yes it is possible to combine and do both on the same day. If you have finished your visit at The Peak, you can return to the Central Ferry Piers from which you arrived on the Star Ferry. Go to Pier 6 and take the ferry from Central to Mui Wo (Lantau Island) https://www.sunferry.com.hk/en/route-and-fare/timetable?route=central-to-mui-wo From Mui Wo, you can take public bus #3M to Tung Chung Town Centre https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/detail/7 From the Tung Chung bus terminus, you are just a few minutes walk to the Ngong Ping Lower Terminus Station. Unfortunately, arriving here later in the day you will likely encounter queues at the ticketing booth as well as waiting to board cable car. This is why I prefer to come here first thing in the morning when they open at 10am to avoid the queues and get an early start on the journey up to the Ngong Ping Village. The ride is 25 minutes. {I love gardens, so thought of Nan Lian, maybe better to do this in the afternoon and save Lantau Island for my second day?} This is a very good alternative and one I would personally choose to do. Nan Lian and the adjacent Chi Lin Nunnery are easily one of HK's most beautiful combined locations and it is never busy so making your way there after spending time at Central works just fine. You might also want to checkout the nearby Wong Tai Sin Temple if you enjoy temple/monastery visits or the Kowloon Walled City Park which combines a nice garden laid out around old heritage attractions. It is a neat, peaceful garden/park with very interesting historic sites to see during your visit.

subject: Dim Sum Guide (2023)
usertext: This post provides some basic research for those wanting to learn about the dim sum scene in Hong Kong. The resources below provide an overview of dim sum here in the city as well as some suggestions for how to pick a place and what you might want to try during your dim sum experiences in HK. ------------------------------------------------------ 1) What is Dim Sum? The Basics (Asia Society) https://asiasociety.org/reference/what-dim-sum-beginners-guide-south-chinas-traditional-brunch-meal A really good summary of the origins and history of dim sum along with ordering, dining etiquette as well as popular dim sum choices that are worth trying. How to Enjoy Dim Sum (HKTB) https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/dining/dim-sum-culture.html Discover HK offers more on the topic with an expected lean toward the local scene with a few recommended places and dishes to sample during visits to the city. ------------------------------------------------------ 2) Why do Dim Sum in Hong Kong? The short answer, Dim Sum didn't originate in Hong Kong but it certainly made its mark on world cuisine here. Generally speaking, Hong Kong is the undisputed Dim Sum capital of the world. If you are going to try it anywhere, do dim sum in HK. ---------------------------------------------------- 3) Where to try Dim Sum in Hong Kong? The good news is that finding good dim sum in Hong Kong is like finding leaves in a forest. It is not difficult at all. In fact as long as you stay away from your Western hotel buffet line, you should be able to easily find very dim sum or yum cha (dim sum & tea) restaurants on your very own, A) How to search for dim sum restaurants? If you want to find places on your own, you can start with our local food review website called OpenRice (see link) https://www.openrice.com/zh/hongkong Just type dim sum and the area of the city where you want to find a place in the search box near the top of the Openrice homepage. You can then scan the search results to see if there is a place that interests you. B) What if I want to try more popular, famous and tourist-friendly dim sum specialists? Start with these publications which provide lists of popular places for tourists to try dim sum in Hong Kong Best Dim Sum in Hong Kong (TimeOutHK) https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/restaurants/hong-kong-best-dim-sum Best Dim Sum & Yum Cha in HK (SassyHK) https://www.sassyhongkong.com/eat-drink-dim-restaurants-dumplings-best-for-every-occassion/ Best Dim Sum in HK (LifestyleAsia) https://www.lifestyleasia.com/hk/dining/best-dim-sum-restaurants-in-hong-kong/ You'll find good options in the published write-ups above however there are others that you might have heard of or read about elsewhere that are likely just fine. I tend think smart to pick places close to your hotel or near to intended sightseeing that you have planned. You won't need to go far out of the way for good dim sum. ---------------------------------------------------- 4) What Dim Sum should I order in HK? The first couple of resources provided above touch on the basic and most popular dim sum baskets and orders. However, the internet if full of other publications on this topic as well. Here are a few such write-ups which include popular dish sum in HK as well as a sample menu page from tourist friendly Dim Sum One so you know what to expect when trying to mark your dim sum card. 10 Dim Sum to try in HK (Dash Blog) https://www.dash.co/en/blog/10-most-delicious-dim-sum-to-try/ Best Dim Sum Dishes (Thrillest) https://www.thrillist.com/eat/nation/best-dim-sum-dishes-food 22 Tasty Dim Sum (LuckyPeach) https://tasty.co/article/luckypeach/the-essential-guide-to-dim-sum This LuckyPeach writeup is fairly old at this time but remains relevant with dim sum that you can commonly find in Hong Kong. Sample Dim Sum Menu Card (One Dim Sum) https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/p-one-dim-sum-p17000733 ---------------------------------------------------- 5) What If I Just want to do s Dim Sum Food Tour? No problem, there are food tour specialists that offer Dim Sum experiences that you can register for as an individual or groups. You can find dim sum tour providers here in TripAdvisor or through Google during normal times. Note: Since the pandemic ended and the city has reopened, food tour specialists have been a bit slow to restart their tours. So definitely contact the providers directly through their websites or other social media to find out if they are still open for business and offering their tours again if this is of interest. One outfit that had become fairly popular before the pandemic that I has already restarted their food tours is Humid with a Chance for Fishballs (see link to company and dim sum tour) Humid with a Chance for Fishballs https://humidwithachanceoffishballs.com/hong-kong-tours/food-tours/#DIMSUM-LUNCH ---------------------------------------------------- *This should be enough to get you started on your dim sum research. If you have other questions, feel free read up on the many past questions posted over the years. You can find them using the Search Box at the top of this forum. If you still can't find what you are looking for, just post the question and someone will answer it for you. ----------------------------------------------------

subject: Get a decent 6 hour rest in Hong Kong Airport Landside.
usertext: Hi everyone, Are there any comfortable resting areas in Hong Kong landside to rest for the night? I will arrive in HKG around 10 PM and my next self-connecting flight is not until 7 AM the next day. I do not think that staying at a hotel would be worth it since I would only probably get only less than 5 hours of stay at a hotel as I would need to go through the whole check-in process again. Given this, I would rather stay at the airport. Unfortunately, I read that lounges are only in the airside so I would want to know what my options are if I stay on the landside. Thanks in advance!

subject: 1. Re: Get a decent 6 hour rest in Hong Kong Airport Landside.
usertext: I think this is going to be hard. Literally. There are some lounge chairs in the "relaxation" center on the airside. But you can't get in until you get the boarding pass on your next flight. There are up-right seats in the non-secure, departure area. Or sleep on the floor if you can find a more quiet corner. Maybe bring a roll-up inflatable mattress and have a coat or small blanket to help you nap.

subject: 2. Re: Get a decent 6 hour rest in Hong Kong Airport Landside.
usertext: I assume by "self-connecting" flight that you have check-in bags which can't be checked through, and hence need to come landside to collect them and recheck them?

subject: 3. Re: Get a decent 6 hour rest in Hong Kong Airport Landside.
usertext: The open seating in the departure level is often pretty full with others resting/sleeping/waiting for their early morning departures. There is a regular flow of people passing by as well, making way to check-in counters. Seems like a challenging place to get quality rest if you can find a seat. But I see people doing it every time we have to check-in for late night departures. If these seats are filled up in this departure level in front of the check-in rows, there is also some space to the far left in the downstairs Arrival Hall, near and entrance to the Regal Hotel footbridge and beside a tall LED screen that is often showing some sort of garden / rainforest scene. As soon as you exit customs and baggage collection into the Arrival Hall, you can make a hard left, walk to the far end. You can't miss the big screen mentioned above. You can look for some open seating in that area as well. Not particularly comfortable for long hours of sitting but at least they may be available if the mentioned rows of seats in the Departure Level are all filled up. Note: There is free wifi at the airport so if you have a Netflix account, you can watch a movie to two to kill time while hanging out overnight.

subject: 4. Re: Get a decent 6 hour rest in Hong Kong Airport Landside.
usertext: Yes, that's correct. I have to collect my bags when I arrive and then recheck-in again for another flight.

subject: 5. Re: Get a decent 6 hour rest in Hong Kong Airport Landside.
usertext: Thank you for all the replies. I guess I really don't have any options but to sleep on benches since there are no sleeping pods. My best option is to find a quiet corner within the airport.

subject: Hotel recommendation with 8 month old baby.
usertext: I wanted to ask if anyone had a great hotel recommendation if they have or know someone stayed with a very young child. Ideally with a crib as an option. Did search but couldn't see a post. Location fairly flexible

subject: 1. Re: Hotel recommendation with 8 month old baby.
usertext: I might suggest starting your research with Booking.com. Input 2 adults, 1 child (age 0) for the dates of your intended stay. Search results will be limited to hotel properties that offer rooms with cot availability (usually on request) and you should find several hundred from which to consider, including quite few of our better hotel properties around the city.

subject: Cordis or InterContinental Grand Stanford
usertext: Family (a couple + 6, 12, 15) traveling for 5 days. Which one would be better for us, Cordis or InterContinental Grand Stanford? Thanks Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 1. Re: Cordis or InterContinental Grand Stanford
usertext: There is no right or wrong answer to this question. Both properties have their benefits depending on your sightseeing plans, what part of the Kowloon Peninsula you prefer to stay, what calibre of room you able to reserve and room rates that you are finding. I would simply recommend to reading up on reviews for both properties here, Google Reviews and other hotel review platforms that you might be using and then make your selection. Note that Cordis is located in a very busy area of Mongkok with more street markets, focused shopping centres and buildings and more dense crowds. There is immediate access to the Mongkok MTR Station allowing you to travel around the city with convenience. Some Western food and drink options nearby but much in the form of simple local eateries InterCon GS is near more open space and directly on the TST Promenade where you can enjoy walks on the harbour and views of the HK Skyline. It is a short walk to the Hung Hom and TST East MTR Stations. More international mix of food, drink and coffee shops nearby. Still plenty of local food options nearby as well.

subject: 2. Re: Cordis or InterContinental Grand Stanford
usertext: If you don't mind the crowds, Cordis is much more conveniently located with much more vibe. On the other hand, while Intercontinental GS is located right across a main road from the water, it's actually at a rather quiet corner of TST East which is mostly a commercial district. The walk to the closest MTR station is going to take around 10 minutes when you are walking with children. I do believe they have a shuttle bus that goes to TST proper.

subject: 3. Re: Cordis or InterContinental Grand Stanford
usertext: I've stayed at both but walking through Mong kok yesterday, I would rather stay at Intercon. It is unbelievably busy in that part of MK where Cordis is. And MK is like that every single day at all hours

subject: Hong Kong Bar Scene (2023)
usertext: Hong Kong has long had a thriving bar scene. Now that the pandemic is over, visitors are returning to find some old favourites having bit farewell but a wave of new places having opened around the city, especially over the past few months. Here are some publications highlighting recommended places you might want to try while visiting Hong Kong ------------------------------------------------------------ Best Overall Bars in Hong Kong - Whats Popular Now Best Bars in Hong Kong (Vogue) https://www.voguehk.com/en/article/art-lifestyle/best-bars-hong-kong/ HK scores 8 of Asia's 50 Best Bars for 2023 (HKTB) https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/nightlife/asia-50-best-bars-in-hong-kong.html 50 Best Bars in Hong Kong (TimeOutHK) https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/bars-and-pubs/best-bars-hong-kong These lists are quite heavy in the fancy cocktail bars, whisky bars and speak-easy style hidden bars that all on the up and up these days. They are less representative of other bar categories of potential interest. ------------------------------------------------------------ Rooftop and Sky Bars - Steady and Thriving 12 Best Rooftop Bars in HK (TimeOutHK) https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/bars-and-pubs/best-rooftop-bars-hong-kong 23 Best Rooftop Bars in HK (RoofTopGuide) https://www.therooftopguide.com/rooftop-bars-in-hong-kong.html Rooftop bars in Hong Kong can be touch and go with food and drink quality rather iffy at times. But those views... will always ensure this category of bars continues to thrive in Hong Kong. ------------------------------------------------------------ Wine Bars - Steady as She Goes Best Wine Bars in HK (http://LanKwaiFong.com) https://lankwaifong.com/blogs/beverages/the-best-wine-bars-in-hong-kong 13 Best Wine Bars in HK (TimeOutHK) https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/bars-and-pubs/the-best-wine-bars-in-hong-kong A niche bar segment that struggled in recent years but with sizeable enough popular of wine drinkers and steady local appetite for good venues, there will always be a few good places to try around the city. ----------------------------------------------------------- Traditional Pubs and Gastropubs - On the Wane All publications I've reviewed from the past few years are outdated with too many amendments needed. While there remain a fair number of old favourites, this is a category that has seen far greater number of closings compared to new openings in recent years. Standouts that remain include: The Globe, The Chinnery, Captain's Bar, The China Bar, Shoreditch, Churchills, Queen Victoria, Trafalgar, Delaneys Irish Pub, Ned Kelly's Last Stand, Chin Chin Bar ------------------------------------------------------------ Craft Beer Taprooms - Major Strides in Recent Years Best Beer Bars (TimeOutHK) https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/bars-and-pubs/best-craft-beer-hong-kong Craft Beer in HK (LifestyleAsia) https://www.lifestyleasia.com/hk/dining/drinks/craft-beer-best-drinking-spots-hong-kong/ Taprooms didn't exist in Hong Kong a decade ago, now there are a handful of really good places to try local and international handcraft beer on tap. Will likely remain a fairly small niche market in HK, the craft beer scene has at least established a steady enough footing to ensure it viability and long-term survival, allowing top performers to hopefully stick around for a while. ------------------------------------------------------------

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Bar Scene (2023)
usertext: First of all a huge thanks to BradJill for all the useful information in so many topics! I do like some bar hopping, but I'm not into fancy, expensive hotel bars or similar, I prefer smaller and cheaper places where the local goes. A little bit of "decadence" is charming as long as it isn't dangerous. I'm staying in Kowloon this time, close to Jordan MTR. Is there places like this to be found in the neighborhood? As an example, I've been to Ned Kellys long time ago, and I love that place and will return, although It's not my kind of music. But it has my kind of vibe! TIA

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Bar Scene (2023)
usertext: If you want places where you will hear English spoken and you will be readily understood in English then they are never going to be really cheap. But for live music definitely get to The Wanch (in Wanchai, but easy to reach from Jordan by MTR). https://www.thewanch.hk/ In Kowloon also look at Delaneys (which is also good for live sports) http://delaneys.com.hk/ Also maybe try Trafalgar in Wanchai https://trafalgar.com.hk/ For more of a gastro pub with a great range of beers then The Globe. https://www.theglobe.com.hk Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong Bar Scene (2023)
usertext: #1 {I'm staying in Kowloon this time, close to Jordan MTR. Is there places like this (Ned Kelley's) to be found in the neighborhood? If you are wanting to do a bit of bar hopping, TST is just one neighbourhood south of Jordan and where you will find the highest concentration of Western bars like Ned Kelly's Last Stand (Ashley Rd.). Near Ned's you can also try Ashley Road Trading Co. and Kowloon Taproom which are both pretty good. On the other side of Canton Road, there is a slew of bars/restaurants along Knutsford Terrace. These have a bit more local vibe and due to higher concentration of places, you might be able to find cheaper happy hour deals. Im not sure how things are faring there since the pandemic ended but this was a busy area on weekends in the past. You'll find more bars in the area around Prat Ave. Hart Ave. and Hanoi Rd in between K11 Art Concept Road and Chatham Road. There are plenty of drinking holes on those three streets.

subject: Vegan, Vegetarian & Halal in Hong Kong (2023)
usertext: Updating the forum with helpful resources pointing out vegan, vegetarian and plant-based as well as Halal recognised eateries around the city. --------------------------------------------------------------- Vegan/Vegetarian eateries in Hong Kong (HappyCow) https://www.happycow.net/asia/china/hong_kong/ Best Vegetarian & Vegan Restaurants in HK (Tatler) https://www.tatlerasia.com/dining/food/vegetarian-vegan-restaurants-hong-kong Guide to Vegan/Veg Eating in HK (SassyHK) https://www.sassyhongkong.com/eat-drink-vegan-restaurants-veggie-friendly-health/ --------------------------------------------------------------- Halal Restaurants List for Hong Kong (HKTB) https://www.discoverhongkong.com/content/dam/dhk/intl/explore/muslim-travel/muslim-friendly-facilities/pdf/halal-list-en.pdf Best Halal Eating in HK (http://LifestyleAsia.com) https://www.lifestyleasia.com/hk/dining/food/best-halal-food-restaurants-hong-kong/ Halal Restaurants in HK (SassyHK) https://www.sassyhongkong.com/halal-restaurants-in-hong-kong-eat-drink/ ---------------------------------------------------------------

subject: 1. Re: Vegan, Vegetarian & Halal in Hong Kong (2023)
usertext: A note particularly for visitors from South Asia: the term "vegetarian" as used in Hong Kong generally allows for eggs and dairy products in the food. The concept of "pure vegetarian" as used in India (meaning that dairy products are OK, but eggs are not) is not generally understood in Hong Kong except in Indian/Nepalese restaurants, so you will need to be explicit about what you will or will not eat. Of course vegan food (meaning only plant-based, no dairy, no eggs) is acceptable to pure vegetarians.

subject: 2. Re: Vegan, Vegetarian & Halal in Hong Kong (2023)
usertext: Thank you for posting this resource! This is my single biggest concern about my prospective trip to HK next year as a 30+ year strict vegetarian.

subject: Restaurants recommendation

My girlfriend has a birthday in October, during our stay, so i want to take her to some nice place to have a dinner. The location is not really important, but we will be staying in the Mong Kok area. JFYI - we've been to Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam and we always enjoy the local food. Thanks in advance. subject: 1. Re: Restaurants recommendation
usertext: Ming Court at Cordis Hotel fits the bill for what you seem to be looking for. It is a place you can dress up a bit if you like, service is great and the food is outstanding. Prices are very reasonable for the dining experience as well. This is a place we take guests when visiting HK and occasionally dine at for holiday and special occasions. Do make reservations in advance for Ming Court.

subject: 3. Re: Restaurants recommendation
usertext: One easy way is to seek the Cantonese (that's "local" in Hong Kong) restaurants in top 5-star hotels. Often times there are some views to go with the food. Examples: Four Seasons Hotel - Lung King Heen The Peninsula Hong Kong - Spring Moon Mandarin Oriental Hotel - Man Wah The Ritz-Carlton Hotel - Tin Lung Heen Regent Hotel Hong Kong - Lai Ching Heen (Yan Toh Heen) Cordis Hotel Hong Kong - Ming Court (Mong Kok) Grand Hyatt Hong Kong - One Harbour Road JW Marriott Hotel Hong Kong - Man Ho Chinese Restaurant But note that these "nice" and "decent" offers will have proportionate price tags.

subject: 4. Re: Restaurants recommendation
usertext: Thank you guys for the suggestions.

subject: 5. Re: Restaurants recommendation
usertext: Ming Court also has a location at Wan Chai North. That one would be more convenient if you are staying at the Island side. It's a pretty short walk from the Exhibition Centre station of the East Rail Line. You can take East Rail for one stop to Admiralty and then use the Island Line to the north (populated) side of HK Island.

subject: 6. Re: Restaurants recommendation
usertext: Celestial court at Sheraton is not as expensive as other 5 or 6 star hotel restaurants but the Chinese food is very decent. The only con is that it has no view.

subject: 7. Re: Restaurants recommendation
usertext: TST Sheraton Chinese food menu https://www.celestialcourt.hk/our-menus

subject: 8. Re: Restaurants recommendation
usertext: If you want a great view and a very high ceiling dining hall, Dyansty at Renaissance Harbourview (Wan Chai North) fits the bill. Again, prices correlate to the above 5* hotel restaurant places.

subject: 1. Re: How to get to Guangzhou from HK past 11 PM
usertext: Other options, there are: book your own private transfer from the airport - Cross border limo service. It will be costly. But money talks. Link: https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/mainland-connection/skylimo.page "Service Hour: 24 hours" Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: How to get to Guangzhou from HK past 11 PM

subject: Day Trips
usertext: Hi, I'm visiting Hong Kong next March for a week. This is our second visit. On this trip I'd like to spend a day in Macau and also visit Cheung Chau, Lantau and Lamma islands. I know everywhere is busier on a weekend but realistically we're going to have to do at least one of these on a Saturday or Sunday. Any advise on which one would be best? Or are they all as busy as each other so difference? Also for the Macau Ferry - do you have to tie yourself down to a time by booking return journey tickets in advance? It's hard to know how long we'll be there. However, don't want to land up stranded either if the ferries are full and we have no ticket back. Thanks All!!

subject: 1. Re: Day Trips
usertext: I'd say Lamma -- a walk from one end of the island to the other with a meal at the end -- works best. If it's a weekend and the weather's nice you'll have lots of company but that's part of Hong Kong's atmosphere. (It's more just an afternoon than an all-day trip.)

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Day Trips
usertext: Thanks for the advice. Was definitely planning on walking from one end of Lamma to the other. I did consider trying to do Lamma early morning and Cheung Chau afternoon even though I know we'd need to go back to central pier. Don't want to rush anything either though and we have a whole week so plenty time.

subject: 3. Re: Day Trips
usertext: {don't want to land up stranded (In Macau) either if the ferries are full and we have no ticket back.} Not sure if you are aware that the HZM Bridge opened in 2018 providing around the clock means for travel between HK & Macau. Shuttle buses run 24 hours a day between the two sister cities and are less than half the price of ferry tickets. This makes returning to HK at you leisure much more convenient these days. See this thread on How to Visit Macau from Hong Kong to learn more about how to use the HZM Bridge if interested. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html

subject: 4. Re: Day Trips
usertext: The way Macau ferry tickets work is that they have a specific ferry on them, and that is the last ferry that you can catch. But you can turn up for an earlier ferry on a standby basis and take the first one with space. At busy times there can be a queue for standby, but you probably wouldn't have to wait more than one or two ferries. The ticket is void after the departure of the ferry that it's booked for.

Will look into the bus also thank you very much!! HK Ga Yau..thanks for the ferry ticket info. That's perfect if we can turn up for an earlier ferry on a stand by basis. Thanks All!!!

subject: April spring break or June?
usertext: I would like to take my kids to visit where I was born. I am thinking of late March to April during spring break or first week of June. We would only have 8 days if we go late March and the kids will deal with jet lag before school starts. If we go in June 1st, we could go longer and kids don't have to deal with adjusting time zones since it will be summer, I was told that June is too hot and humid. I was there 20 years ago so I can't remember. Would you agree March/ April would be better?

subject: 1. Re: April spring break or June?
usertext: You can see here the long-run (1991-2020) average, max/mean/min temperatures and rainfall for 10-day periods through the year. https://www.weather.gov.hk/en/cis/normal/1991_2020/10day_normal.htm From which, yes, March/April is about 6 degrees (10F) less hot and has less than a third as much rain as the first 10 days of June. By June the weather is seriously hot. I realise that SF gets quite hot occasionally, but the key difference is that in HK the heat is consistent day to day, and it doesn't cool down much at night, so it will generally not get below 26-27 degrees (~80F) and still with high humidity. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: April spring break or June?
usertext: End of March to early April is much better temperature wise. Occasionally, it does get humid and foggy but not uncomfortable. By late May, the temperature will feel summer-like with humidity to match. Also, once June rolls around, HK is more likely to get rain. Kids can usually get over jet lag a bit quicker.

subject: 3. Re: April spring break or June?
usertext: Unless you like hot, humid and constant rain, go in April. Hot and humid is already a terrible combo, but the constant unending Waterworld rain is not fun especially when trying to get from place to place People will still look at you like a freak for wearing shorts and a T-shirt while old ladies will be wear fur coats.

subject: 4. Re: April spring break or June?
usertext: I don't understand this bit. Many people wear shorts and a t-shirt on warmer winter days. Hardly anyone wears fur nowadays, including elderly women. >>>People will still look at you like a freak for wearing shorts and a T-shirt while old ladies will be wear fur coats.

subject: 5. Re: April spring break or June?
usertext: I think there's more risk of that unending rain in April than in June - while a spring shower can last the better part of a day if not longer, a summer shower rarely lasts longer than 20 minutes, and then the sun breaks through again. Except for the days following a typhoon, those can be total washouts. Of course the total rainfall in that 20 minutes can be more than in a spring day.

subject: 6. Re: April spring break or June?
usertext: {I think there's more risk of that unending rain in April than in June} Late April, I might agree with you wvmarle.... but OP is asking about Late March to April for 8 days only. We only average around 11 rainy days during April and they lean considerably towards the second half of the month. Yes it can rain during first week of April I'd put my bet on that week over any week in June for avoiding rains in HK.

subject: W, Ritz, JW Marriott? First time with Fam
usertext: This is my first time brining my kids along. I haven't been back in ages so I am not too sure about the W or Ritz area. Is it easy to get around if we were to stay at Ritz or W? I was looking at JW Marriott because it is right on top of the admiralty station. I have status with Marriott that's why I was looking at their hotels. My cousin recommended the Fullerton but it is very far right? Not Marriott but it does look beautiful. Thank you for all the advice in advance!

subject: 1. Re: W, Ritz, JW Marriott? First time with Fam
usertext: Im not a huge fan of the location of Ritz or W when it comes to hotel stays. There is a mall called Elements downstairs and quick access to the West Kowloon Cultural District but these hotels are otherwise, quite isolated. The Kowloon Station is for Airport Express line and Tung Chung line which can get you to Central rather quickly but not TST area or other popular places in Kowloon. You can see TST from the hotels and it looks close but requires a near 30 minute walk, past construction and through convoluted routes because of the construction. If you plan to use taxis this isn't really an issue but overall, the two hotels are not great for those who want to make use of public transportation to get around the city. JW Marriott on the other hand is directly connected to Admiralty Station which is a major hub and MTR interchange with access to numerous MTR lines that can get you pretty much anywhere in the city relatively quickly. It is also next to one of our largest and best city parks (Hong Kong Park) and a short walk to the Peak Tram, Ding Ding rides. Some very good local dining at nearby Starstreet Precinct, Wanchai neighbourhood as well.

subject: 2. Re: W, Ritz, JW Marriott? First time with Fam
usertext: The main thing the Fullerton has going for it is that it's at Ocean Park, so if a significant part of your trip were to be at Ocean Park / Waterworld with your kids then that might make sense. And there's also the Hong Kong Ocean Park Marriott which would work in that case and has the advantage that it is adjacent to the Ocean Park MTR station which overall is certainly no worse that the Ritz/W location for connectivity elsewhere, (The Fullerton is on the far side of Ocean Park as far from the MTR so getting elsewhere is a bit of a faff.) But if Ocean Park isn't the major part of your plans then I agree with BradJill - go with the JW Marriott at Admiralty - you can't beat that location for connectivity.

subject: 3. Re: W, Ritz, JW Marriott? First time with Fam
usertext: In terms of hotel quality, Ritz Carlton wins, hands down. However, when it comes to location, there is no question that JW wins. JW isn't exactly a shabby hotel. Perhaps read the hotel reviews here on Tripadvisor before you decide. W should not be considered. Service isn't up to par. Their boutique style design isn't for everyone. Food at most of their outlets are below average. Fullerton is nice and new but not in the league of Ritz Carlton. I would rate their location overall as equal (not so desirable).

subject: 4. Re: W, Ritz, JW Marriott? First time with Fam
usertext: My opinion: if you like the Ritz or JW grade of hotel, the location seems secondary. You pick the hotel for what that hotel offers: nice room/deco/furniture, great service, pool, view, etc.. Being close to a MTR Station (or bus stop?) is less important. Hong Kong taxis are so plentiful. Literally, with the click of your fingers you can hail one. (Okay... relax, just an exaggerated figure of speech, no need to rebut me on that.) Going out from your hotel, your bell captain will click the fingers for you... Taxi around. Or bridge it to the closest MTR Station. And the Ritz is right on top of MTR Kowloon Station. It is not entirely inconvenient. With The Fullerton, it is a new, nice hotel facing the Pacific Ocean. Many hotels in Hong Kong have views of Victoria Harbour. Very few hotels have views of islands in the open ocean. The Fullerton, and I think Le Meridien at Cyberport. I think that's it. Thus if you like view of open ocean, less "crowded city" feel, take that one.

subject: 5. Re: W, Ritz, JW Marriott? First time with Fam
usertext: The problem with Ritz Carlton's location is a bit more complex. MTR access is limited. Going to the Island side, you will always have to walk 7-8 minutes from HK station to Central station to reach the Island Line. As to most of Kowloon, there is just no simple way to go to most places that interest the casual visitor. For those thinking of relying on taxis, while they might be readily available (but not necessarily on weekday mornings during rush hour), traffic to/fromTsim Sha Tsui and Jordan are often quite bad for much of the day. subject: Budget Gyms in Hong Kong
usertext: Hi guys, im in hong kong for a month, whats the cheapest gym that i can sign up for? Expecting prices to be around $600hkd a month.

subject: 1. Re: Budget Gyms in Hong Kong
usertext: Cheapest would probably be the LCSD Fitness Centres run by the local government. They offer a Monthly Ticket Scheme (HK$180 per month). https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/en/fitness/ticket.html See LCSD Introduction to how to register https://www.lcsd.gov.hk/en/fitness/index.html

subject: 2. Re: Budget Gyms in Hong Kong
usertext: I believe it is not possible for a foreigner to be eligible for the LCSD gyms if he is only coming for 1 month. IMO the best option is to find a hotel with a gym.

subject: 3. Re: Budget Gyms in Hong Kong
usertext: Note that the gov't wants you to undergo some kind of assessment before you're allowed to use the fitness rooms. That's possibly a major obstacle for short term users. I don't see a mention of HKID card requirement on the website, or otherwise a restriction to HK residents.

subject: 4. Re: Budget Gyms in Hong Kong
usertext: HK is a lousy city for gym-seeking visitors. (Accustomed to the HK situation, I was quite surprised at how easy and cheap it was to get a one-month membership when I visited London.) Hotel gyms are very expensive. Mostly HK gyms operate on a long-term subscription business, and they don't advertise short-term packages. However, from time to time there are "promotions" which might suit you. I note, for example, that Anytime Fitness has an ad for a student special summer offer -- but this is Hong Kong and as far as I can see the offer is only described in Chinese on their website https://www.anytimefitness.hk/ . Last time I was in HK, I managed to get a three-week offer from Pure Fitness, but the price was above your desired price point. I think the only way to get current, useful information on the existence of any useful promotions will be to call or visit the relevant gyms.

subject: Layovers in Hong Kong (2023)
usertext: This thread contains resources and tips for planning layovers at Hong Kong International Airport. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- Where to Start with Layover Planning? All layover considerations should first address the length of your layover at HKIA and what time of day or night you awaiting your outbound flight. If you have a 3 hour layover from midnight to 3am, forget about leaving the airport in between flights. On the other hand, if you have a 12 hour stop from 10am to 10pm, forget about staying in the airport. There are quite a few online resources addressing layovers in Hong Kong. These two combined cover most of the important points to consider and plan layover visits into the city 1) How to Plan Your Layover in HK (NextStopHK) https://www.nextstophongkong.com/stop-over/#minimum_time This is a pretty good guide to use to kick-start your research. There is a good breakdown of time allotments for getting into/out of the airport and the city as well as a generic suggestions for what you can do during 4+, 6-7, 8+, 12+ hr layovers. 2) Layover What To Do (http://DroneandDSLR.com) https://droneandslr.com/travel-blog/hong-kong/layover-what-to-do/ This guide covers practical matters including visa needs, locker storage at HKIA, wifi at the airport, currency exchange and Octopus, offers a few detailed descriptions for 6hr, 6-9+hr and overnight layovers and introduces some hotel options for those who just prefer to grab a room and rest while they are in HK. --------------------------------------------------------------------- What Else Do I Need to Know? Do I need a visa to enter Hong Kong? https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14479683-Hong_Kong_Visa_Requirements_2023-Hong_Kong.html#118350396 Start here to check on your visa requirement conditions for entering Hong Kong during flight layovers. Hong Kong Weather https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/index.html Obviously weather can impact your layover options so best to watch our local conditions a few days ahead of time. Getting into the city from HKIA https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14482016-Hong_Kong_Airport_to_the_City_2023-Hong_Kong.html Start here for resources related to planning your route into the city and back to the airport. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Staying at the Airport Airport Lounges (HKIA) https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/passenger-guide/airport-facilities-services/airline-lounges Resting Lounge Guide (HKIA) https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/passenger-guide/airport-facilities-services/resting-lounges Complimentary Shower Facilities (HKIA) https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/passenger-guide/airport-facilities-services/shower-facilities Free Wifi Internet Access (HKIA) https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/passenger-guide/airport-facilities-services/wifi-and-internet-access Entertainment & Shopping (HKIA) https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/relax-fun/ Food and Dining Options (HKIA) https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/shop-dine/dining/ -------------------------------------------------------------------

subject: Airport taxi
usertext: Hello, In Philippines you can book online a taxi that is a bit cheaper than a regular taxi. It's called grab. In U.K. it's called Uber. Is there a similar thing here in Hong Kong? We be first time in HK on Monday 4th September. For a couple of days as we going to Disneyland. We be staying at the Disneyland and our flight lands about 6pm so we just want to get to our hotel quickly. Can you download the taxi app from the Philippines?

subject: 1. Re: Airport taxi
usertext: From the airport, just take a blue taxi from the taxi stand to Disney. Uber is available but it's not exactly legal. You will have to arrange a meeting point which might be a pain at an airport you don't know. Also, Uber HK's pricing is usually slightly more expensive than taking a taxi.

subject: 2. Re: Airport taxi
usertext: I agree with just taking a taxi from the rank at the airport. Interestingly, the Airport's page which lists taxi fares to different destinations reminds me that Green taxis can also go to Disneyland, and the estimated fare is HK$130 (compared to $145 for red or blue taxis). https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/to-from-airport/taxis.page (Note that there is an additional charge of HK$6 for each item of luggage that you put in the boot/trunk.) Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Airport taxi
usertext: And to the question {Can you download the taxi app from the Philippines?} There is no Grab or Lyft in Hong Kong but there is Uber as mentioned above. We also have a useful HKTaxi app but you do have to have a local phone number to register in order to make use of HKTaxi app here. As for Uber, you can definitely download on your phone in the Philippines and use it here. If you are not comfortable arranging ride with an UberX vehicle, you can also use the app to book taxis as well.

subject: Kowloon parks?
usertext: I love to spend a few hours in city parks relax to enjoy the stillness, go for a walk and to enjoy the greenery. Are there any parks similar to Lumpini Park in Bangkok or Central Park in NYC to be found in Kowloon? TIA

subject: 1. Re: Kowloon parks?
usertext: Hong Kong is Hong Kong with its own character. But try Kowloon Park in Kowloon. Or for a SE Asia vibe, Victoria Park in Causeway Bay on a Sunday.

subject: 2. Re: Kowloon parks?
usertext: There's Kowloon Park, the largest of Kowloon (yet not exactly large). Busy most of the time. Signal Hill Garden (Blackhead Point). King's Park Recreation Ground & Yau Ma Tei Service Reservoir Rest Garden Nam Cheong Park Kowloon Tsai Park, Kowloon Walled City Park, Morse Park, Lok Fu Park, Checkerboard Hill That's about it. There are more but the above are I think the most interesting parks. Note that they're all rather small.

subject: 3. Re: Kowloon parks?
usertext: We do have fair-sized city parks which surprises me at times but simply lack urban space for parks the size of Central Park (NYC). However, what we have that is much better are designated country parks with proper forests, lakes, hiking trails as well as macaques & wild pigs right in the city. These protected areas become very rural, very quickly so you can get fairly deep in nature in little time at all. Quite the contrast to the busy and chaotic city streets nearby. Some of the Hong Kong Country Parks are easily accessible to where most tourists stay in Kowloon. Lion Rock Country Park is worth looking into if this is of potential interest. You can hike up to some outstanding viewpoints over Kowloon, follow a War Relics trail, Go all the way up to the landmark Lion Rock as well if you like. LIon Rock Country Park https://www.discoverhongkong.com/uk/interactive-map/lion-rock-country-park.html War Relic Trail through Lion Rock https://hikingtrailhk.appspot.com/en/w/war_relics_trail Lion Rock Trail & Hike https://droneandslr.com/travel-blog/hong-kong/lion-rock-hike/ Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Kowloon parks?
usertext: But if all you want is an easy to get to urban oasis, you would be disappointed. HK is one of the most densely populated cities of the world. Unless you are willing to do some hiking (see post #3) or travel outside the city (still in HK, but outside the core urban center), you won't find anywhere to enjoy "the stillness".

subject: 5. Re: Kowloon parks?
usertext: Hiking in Hong Kong isn't something you should suddenly do on a whim! You need to be well prepared with water, maps, cell, proper clothes etc. and be aware of the weather. Usually best too to avoid the trails till October because of the heat. Before October on a nice hot and sunny day, head to Shek O on Hong Kong Island. As beautiful a beach as can be.

subject: 6. Re: Kowloon parks?
usertext: I would respectfully disagree (in part) with the previous post. Yes, that post is right if you are talking about long treks in the Sai Kung country parks. But there are also plenty of hikes in HK that are closer to the urban area and much easier to undertake "on a whim." Think Bowen Road or Black's Link, or Lugard Road or Sir Cecil's Ride, for example. Or the walks around the Tai Tam Waterworks or the Aberdeen reservoir. Of course, it is always wise to be aware of the weather. Whether or not the summer months are too hot for hiking depends on the individual's body situation, which we cannot know. (I would normally advise a person from Stockholm to err on the cautious side, but a person with the nickname Malabar Man may be better adjusted to the heat and humidity.)

subject: 7. Re: Kowloon parks?
usertext: Sir Cecil's Ride in particular, it's easy to take a wrong turn without a map. (I have.) And hard to find the starting/ending points unless you know what you're doing. Same for hiking around Tai Tam. Gotta put yourself in the position of someone completely green to exploring the HK countryside. Myself I'd be very cautious about sending someone who's only spent a couple days in HK off solo hiking even on the Island. Quite a few boars around Tai Tam and Mt Parker country parks, too. They're big. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 8. Re: Kowloon parks?
usertext: @Alamigo {Hiking in Hong Kong isn't something you should suddenly do on a whim!} I appreciate your reference to not approaching hiking in Hong Kong blindly with no knowledge of trail challenge level or logistics, without proper shoes, water and understanding of our weather...... All very fine to mention and point out...... But we do have beginner level hiking & trail opportunities for the most inexperienced of hikers/walkers and even those with families, some of which can very much be done on the whim and by completed by pretty much anyone. As a couple of examples of this point - I've encountered tourists with a 2 and 4 yr old little ones at the top of Tai Mo Shan. It is fairly easy road trail to follow to the peak, hence why you always see families there, not just long distance hikers taking in the MacLehose Trail. And how many families and tourists do we see walking along the Peak Circle Loop Trail every single day of the year? https://www.alltrails.com/trail/hong-kong/central-and-western/victoria-peak-loop#:~:text=Head%20out%20on%20this%202.2,encounter%20other%20people%20while%20exploring. I offer these two examples not to challenge your warnings about hiking in Hong kong 'on the whim' but to instead offer the perspective that you actually can look into our trails and country parks and find opportunities that suit your experience level and interest, even if you rarely hike and/or are in the city for short stays. If being in the countryside and/or hiking is something tourists have interest, there is probably a trail somewhere that will fit their situation just fine.

subject: 9. Re: Kowloon parks?
usertext: Well, I didn't mention the snakes. Or the expat who died last month hiking one evening not far from his home in Mid-Levels right on HK Island. Nothing unusual about that: hikers die pretty regularly in Hong Kong. Similar to the number who die trying to climb Mt Everest actually. And those of us who know the risks know them because we've made plenty of mistakes ourselves over the years.

subject: 10. Re: Kowloon parks?
usertext: Well, people tend to die all the time. Part of life. For most it happens at home or in hospital, for others when they're having fun doing other things. No reason not to go on a hike. It's also outright ridiculous to even suggest that a hike in Hong Kong is at all comparable to doing the Mount Everest - even if you're looking at rather tough ones like the Hunchbacks. Of course there are snakes in Hong Kong, there are even venomous ones, however snake bites are extremely rare - and those that get bitten are far more likely to be gardeners or farmers (especially the latter we have very few of in Hong Kong), than one of the many many hikers. Likewise wild boar are by and large harmless - if treated with respect, which starts with keeping your distance. In my opinion the nastiest (by far!) wildlife in Hong Kong are the hornets. I've encountered them a few times, one time they targeted me as well, and in all cases the result was at least one seriously sick person - and no, they were not allergic or so. Just had a few too many stings. Oh, and the monkeys of course. Cute as they are, they're ruthless thieves and robbers.

subject: Bus or Ferry to Guangzhou from HKG?
usertext: US passport holder will land on 5 am in HKG. Which is most convenient way to Guangzhou from HKG airport? Understand ferry is faster, fewer schedule and more $, bus is slower, more schedule, and less $. Other than that what else I need consider? Custom procedure are same? Thank you

subject: 1. Re: Bus or Ferry to Guangzhou from HKG?
usertext: The fastest is the high-speed train, but a lot depends on exactly where in GZ you are aiming for. It is an absolutely enormous city, so if you are going somewhere a long way from either an XRL station or ferry pier but a bus goes close to your destination, the latter might be more ocnvenient than taking "faster" transport from Hong Kong and then a 90 minute taxi/ Didi ride (specially if you have luggage).

subject: 2. Re: Bus or Ferry to Guangzhou from HKG?
usertext: Cathay also flies to Guangzhou at 07:55, precisely to target those coming in on overnight longhauls, which would save you having to enter HK and deal with your luggage etc. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Bus or Ferry to Guangzhou from HKG?
usertext: Where is your destination in Guangzhou? I never take the ferry as I consider the bus is more convenient. There are various drop off locations for the bus. However, some say the ferry is more comfortable. I also understand that for those new to the city/country, some don't feel comfortable to be dropped at an unknown place by a bus. In a train station or ferry pier, they have more time to collect themselves.

subject: 4. Re: Bus or Ferry to Guangzhou from HKG?
usertext: Forget about bus. It is not a direct bus ride. You ride a bus on Hong Kong side to a border (typically Shenzhen Bay Border), walk across (immigration procedures both sides), then you board a Mainland bus from that border to a Guangzhou destination. Depending on the bus company and their routes, typically that's a hotel in Guangzhou. Border crossing and boarding the Mainland bus can be confusing. Take the ferry. You arrive early enough for their earliest departure (only 3 departures a day) to Pazhou, Guangzhou. It is convenient and comfortable. You don't enter Hong Kong Immigration. You go directly to the ferry via SkyPier (the workers will retrieve your check-in bags and forward them to the ferry). You only do Immigration Custom once (instead of twice) at Guangzhou. Price difference? That's peanuts. Ferry HKD $300. Bus HKD $250. Only HKD $50 to buy comfort and saving time (only 1 time border crossing). It is worth it.

subject: 5. Re: Bus or Ferry to Guangzhou from HKG?
usertext: For Ferry to Pazhou, Guangzhou, it departure at 0815,1200,1445, from HK airport Skypier. https://www.cksp.com.hk/#/main/shipline/ship2 And here is the detail for ferry. https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/mainland-connection/ferry-transfer.page#1 Landing at 5am could get on the ferry that departure at 0815

subject: 6. Re: Bus or Ferry to Guangzhou from HKG?
usertext: Thank you @Cyrus Wong @HappyFeet1234, I will take ferry then. Do I buy ferry tix before arriving HKG or after arriving at Ferry station?

subject: 7. Re: Bus or Ferry to Guangzhou from HKG?
usertext: RE: "Do I buy ferry tix before arriving HKG or after arriving at Ferry station?" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = No need to buy the ferry ticket until you land at the HKG Airport, to keep things flexible (in the event of flight delay or cancellation). Unless you are travelling during the Canton Fair. Once you deplane, DO NOT enter Hong Kong Immigration. The ferry ticket counter is in the Arrival Concourse to the right side of the Hong Kong Immigration. Once you purchase the ferry tickets, if you have any check-in bags you turn over the claim tags to the ferry workers. They will have staff to retrieve your check-in bags based on the Tag IDs. It will take a few minutes (hopefully under 30 minutes). Once all your bags are retrieved, your ticket number will show a green light. You keep checking the status on their status computer screens. You will then be cleared to ride the APM (go underground) to SkyPier to take the ferry without going through Hong Kong Immigration. You will retrieve your check-in bags in Guangzhou (Pazhou port).

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

subject: Peak tram or big buddha
usertext: Morning I am just finalising a layover trip. We will arrive in Hong Kong and have booked Skycity Regal hotel. Landing at 2.30 pm. Plan to go to hotel then either big Buddha or Peak tram then ferry and symphony of lights. I would like to know whether it is better to go to big Buddha or peak tram? I would like to go to whichever suits my itinerary better by public transport and is the easier journey please? After symphony of light we will grab some food. We like street food/ markets. Where is best for this please and easily accessible from Avenue of Stars where we will watch the light show? Any other suggestions you have? We will then go to the hotel ready for a flight out the next morning. Thank you.

subject: 2. Re: Peak tram or big buddha
usertext: Regal is Regal: "Regal Airport Hotel Hong Kong". Skycity is "Hong Kong SkyCity Marriott Hotel", a Marriott, not Regal. Make sure you know which is the one you have booked. Regal, you can walk to it from the airport terminal. Maybe 5 minutes. Skycity you need to take their hotel shuttle. Do you need to claim your check-in bags at Hong Kong Airport? If not that is better. Do you plan to drop off your carry-ons and backpacks at your hotel first before you go for your afternoon/night sight-seeing? If you do, it will take extra time. If needed to take a shuttle to Marriott that will take a longer time. Time is a bit tight for Big Buddha. Landing at 2:30 pm, you need at least 30 minutes to deplane and go through Immigration Check. If you need to claim your check-in bags, that will be another 20 minutes or so. You need to take transportation (bus or taxi) to Tung Chung first. That's another 30 minutes. At the earliest you may be at the Cable Car Station at 3:30 pm. With (if) picking up check-in bags, or need to drop off carry-ons at the hotel, it will likely take another hour. (4:30 pm). The Buddha Statue closes at 5:30 pm, and cable car closes at 6:00 pm. The ride up (or down) takes ~30 minutes. You will just barely have enough time to tour the Big Buddha if you can be at Tung Chung Cable Car Station at 3:30 pm. Time-wise, Peak Tram, The Peak (with a viewing platform on the roof (fee admission)), will be easier. Forget about your idea of "street food". It has mostly gone on extinction in Hong Kong, not like cities in Mainland China or Southeast Asian countries. People can still buy/eat on the street. They need to buy those freshly cooked snack-like hot food from some tiny store-fronts, not from a hawker pushing a 4-wheel mobile food cart like we had in the 60's to 80's. Avenue of the Star in at the prime $$$$$ real-estate in Tsim Sha Tsui by the harbour front. Not easy to find those hot-food shops. One place that is closest to Avenue of the Star you can try is: Between East Ocean Centre and New Mandarin Plaza Block A and B. I am showing it on a Google Map here (Centered): Link: https://goo.gl/maps/6ZedLNtSgYSSpD9L9 From Avenue of the Star, about a 10 to 15-minute walk, the path on a map here: Link: https://goo.gl/maps/51Uf9siQYKAQRL7N8 This is a Streetview picture of what it looks like on the ground. The picture was taken early in the morning. Doesn't look like much because most of the shops are not opened yet. Pan around and "walk" around, you will see many tiny stores. You can buy those street-eats from these shops. They are mostly "packaged to go" (skewered, paperbag, plastic boxes, styrofoam containers, etc) for you to eat on the street. Some shops don't even have their own dining room. It is a pedestrian-only walkpath connected to a plaza (you may be able to find some benches. Around lunch time, or late afternoon and evening dinner time this area will be populated with pedestrians. Streetview Link: https://goo.gl/maps/Gkb7UZLUB2AQE7DB7 This is a picture of what one of those shops/stalls look like at night: Link: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/37/HK_TST_East_New_Mandarin_Plaza_Bar_Street_food_shop.JPG

subject: 3. Re: Peak tram or big buddha
usertext: Thank you. It's the Regal not the Marriott I have booked. I will take hand luggage only so no luggage to collect. Peak Gondola seems easier and I will look at the food suggestions. Thank you for your help on this.

subject: 4. Re: Peak tram or big buddha
usertext: If you go to the Peak, there are some tips: #) Get some HKD cash for your layover. Credit Cards are not accepted for taxi or most transportation and small-amount transactions (such as buying street food). There are ATM machines dispensing HKD notes right at the Luggage Claim area, if you have an ATM card that you can use in Hong Kong. #) Airport Express Train offers the Same Day Return Ticket package for the same price as single-journey. Basically the return journey is free. Buy that package to take the Airport Express Train from the Airport to Hong Kong Station is the quickest way to get there. #) Outside Hong Kong Station is Central Pier. There is also a bus terminus. You can take bus 15C for a short ride to the Lower Peak Tram Terminus to take the Peak Tram. Or else you can walk there, a little uphill, in about 20 to 30 minutes. #) From Central Pier #7, you can take the Star Ferry to cross the harbour to Tsim Sha Tsui. Avenue of the Stars is only a short walk from the Tsim Sha Tsui Star Ferry Pier. And the street food area is about a 10-15 minute walk from Avenue of the Stars. There are elevated pedestrian walkpaths to cross Salisbury Road. #) To return to the Airport, take the Star Ferry once again back to Central Pier #7 and walk back to the Hong Kong Station to take the Airport Express train. Or else you can hail a taxi to take you to Kowloon Station to take the Airport Express train. You AE return ticket (good for Hong Kong Station) is also good for Kowloon Station because it is a lower-cost ride from Kowloon Station. No need to buy a different ticket. But taxi fare will be about HKD $40 I think from Tsim Sha Tsui to Kowloon Station, compared to just ~ HKD $5 taking the Star Ferry.
