subject: 1. Re: Travelling to Hong Kong (Unemployed)
usertext: If you are a Philippine passport holder you are allowed to stay in Hong Kong for up to 14 days without a visa. You may be asked to show that you have a return ticket and the means to support yourself during your stay, but it sounds as though have both of those, so I don't understand what you are worried about.

subject: 2. Re: Travelling to Hong Kong (Unemployed)
usertext: Immigration will probably not be bothered to even ask you questions unless there is something suspicious with your passport or travel history. If you have evidence of return flights back to Manila and evidence of funds to support you while you are here you will be fine. HK immigration isn't concerned of your employment status in the Philippines, only that you have sufficient funds to to cover being in HK while you are here.

subject: Early HKG stopover ...
usertext: Hi, possibly an odd question ... We arrive into HK around 6AM and have a stopover of 7 hours. We are looking for some sort of early morning activity as we want to be back at the airport around 11AM. We have access to the lounges so could stay there. We have been to HK a few times ... seen quite a lot of it. Been to the peak ... seen the giant Bhudda ... walked the foreshores many times. Obviously too early for a bit of shopping. Any ideas? Thanks.

subject: 1. Re: Early HKG stopover ...
usertext: Hong Kong is a late-rising city. Nothing much going on early in the morning. You want to go watch people practice Tai Chi? Or go to Tung Chung and have some dim sum breakfast? Or take a taxi to the nearby Discovery Bay and walk around. Or one of the Disney Hotels to wonder around. You can take the Airport Express train to Hong Kong Station, and walk around the harbour-front promenade from Central Piers all the way to the Hong Kong Cenvention and Exhibition Centre, including the Golden Bauhinia Square. It is quite a bit to see, with backdrop of Victoria Harbour. Same way back. (AE offers the Same Day Return Ticket package for the same price as single-journey. Basically the return journey is free.) Or... pick one of the Airport Bus routes: A21 (Kowloon), or A11, A12 (Hong Kong Island). Ride to the end as a sight-seeing bus (Double Decker, very comfortable). Ride back to the airport. The bus ride is about 90 minutes each way.

subject: 2. Re: Early HKG stopover ...
usertext: Good advice above. Those buses follow roughly the same route as the Airport Express train, but the buses get some magnificent views that are hidden from the train.

subject: 3. Re: Early HKG stopover ...
usertext: We've caught that bus before ... and yes, the views are much better than the train. Thanks for the suggestions ... we'll see what we feel like on the day.

subject: 4. Re: Early HKG stopover ...
usertext: The amount of time you have available isn't bad but the timing isn't good. Very little is open in HK before 9-10am but there are some things you can try thqt might be different than what you have experienced in past visits. Another consideration to HPFT's suggestions above - West Kowloon Cultural District which you can walk to from Kowloon Station (20 minute ride on Airport Express) has really grown up during the pandemic. M+ and HK Palace Museums are both very impressive museums that have opened in the past couple of years. Unfortunately, they don't open until 10am each day so wouldn't have time for much of a visit before needing to turn around and return back to the airport. However, you can still walk into the main ground floor lobby of M+ and walk around to see the interior architecture of the building once they open the doors at 10am. You can also walk around Art Park and enjoy the promenade at any hour of the morning. Walk over and have a look at the Palace Museum exterior architecture which is impressive can be done at any hour as well. https://www.westkowloon.hk/en/ HPFT also mentioned Tung Chung for dim sum. To add to that suggestion, there are actually some interesting historic attractions scattered around Tung Chung that might be interesting to find given your layover situation. They are found on this informal Relics of Tung Chung self-walking tour (see link) https://www.amo.gov.hk/filemanager/amo/common/form/TungChungpanels.pdf There are a couple of temples as well as an old lime kiln and Qing Dynasty battery, the last two which you can see at any hour of the morning. Most interesting of the lot is the restored Tung Chung Fort. The information centre inside opens at 10am (Wed-Mon) but I think you can actually enter the fort earlier, have a look at the wall, cannons and walk around the fort on top of the restored wall. Worth a visit to the info centre as well to help understand what you are looking at while there. https://www.amo.gov.hk/en/historic-buildings/monuments/outlying-islands/monuments_07/index.html

subject: 5. Re: Early HKG stopover ...
usertext: One of the interesting things of Tung Chung fort is that there's a (now closed) school built smack in the middle of it. Way to reuse a historical relic :-) Must have made for an interesting playground for the kids. Now the school building is used as visitor centre (probably closed in the early morning).

subject: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: Currently scheduled for a United Airlines flight to San Francisco departing at 11:00 am on a Monday morning in February. What time do I need to arrive at the airport to make my flight? Thanks for any advice.

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: Hong Kong workers are highly efficient. Generally arriving 2 hours before your flight should be plenty of time.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: Thank you!

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: Last time I did this, the US had a heightened security screening process. Essentially we were questioned at the check in counter. Then there was an added security check at the gate. So if those procedures remain in place, I would say 3 hrs. If not, then 2 hrs should be enough. HK does have an exit immigration check.

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: Wow, that would definitely make a difference. We're disembarking from a cruise ship at 7 am so it may be difficult to make a 11:00 departure. Thank you so much for the update. I appreciate your help.

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: I too am familiar with the recommendation of always being at the airport 3 hours prior to any flights to the US but having regularly departed to the States from HK over the years, we have never come close to needing that much time. Last experience was this past April, flew with United to SFO similar to what you are doing, arrived at the airport just over 2 hours prior to our scheduled departure. Check-in was slower than usual, around 30 minutes. We then cleared immigration and security in around 10 minutes and had plenty of time to walk over to the departure gate, have a coffee while we waited. Which cruise terminal are you arriving at? If Ocean Terminal in TST, you should have plenty of time to make it to the airport with time to spare. If Kai Tak Cruise Terminal (KTCT), transportation services there is iffy with many reporting very long waits for taxi. The ride to the airport from here is 40-45 minutes as well. You would be hard pressed to make it to HKIA by 8am if you wanted to check in that early. I would definitely recommend downloading Uber app on your mobile phone so that you can arrange an UberX or taxi (can do both through the Uber ap) and allow you to avoid waiting around for free taxi to become available at KTCT.

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: This information is really helpful. Thank you. I'm not sure which port Oceania Riviera uses but I'm now thinking it might be better to just take the 10:30pm non stop to SFO rathe than risk the 11:00am flight unless the cruise line will allow us to depart earlier than 7:00am Thanks again!

subject: 7. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: I think that is a good idea. 7:00 am to 11:00 am is only 4 hours. You need to factor in the time to reach the taxi stand and get a taxi, and the travel time from there to the Airport. Riviera docks at Ocean Terminal. You can verify it on this website: http://www.oceanterminal.com.hk/en/schedule.php?f=t Enter the Year "2024", Month "February", and Ship "Riviera". It looks like 7:00 am is only the ETA. It may take a while for passengers to get off the ship. (And you need to do Immigration procedure?) I don't think you have enough time to catch the 11:00 am flight.

subject: 8. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: Thank you. This is really helpful.

subject: 9. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: Nice call Happyfeet. It does feel like 4 hrs would be cutting it too close reading your response, I agree it seems best to defer flight until later, much more relaxing and stress free to play it safe.

subject: 10. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: 11:00 is tight indeed, very tight. You better stay one more day in Hong Kong (consider e.g. one of the Marco Polo hotels, they're connected to Ocean Terminal via Harbour City mall), or another hotel nearby. Then the next morning 8ish take a taxi (or bus A21 - a little slower but cheaper and better views) to airport.

subject: 11. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: Thank you!

subject: 12. Re: Hong Kong Airport Departure Process
usertext: Thank you!

subject: Taxi service from HK airport to Kai Tak Cruise terminal
usertext: I have not found any posts on this subject. Has anyone used taxi service from Hong Kong airport to Kai Tak Cruise terminal ? Do taxis except credit card or only $HK ?

subject: 1. Re: Taxi service from HK airport to Kai Tak Cruise terminal
usertext: {I have not found any posts on this subject. } See link below to Hong Kong International Airport - Taxi Transportation - Kowloon -> Kwun Tong/ Kai Tak Cruise Terminal $310 https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/to-from-airport/taxis.page { Do taxis except credit card or only $HK ?} Some taxis accept electronic payments, such as Octopus, credit cards but you can't on this. Be ready to make payment with cash. If you want/need to to make credit card payment, you can download the Uber HK app and arrange a taxi to meet/pickup at that airport and drive you to the Kai Tak Cruise Terminal (KTCT)

subject: 2. Re: Taxi service from HK airport to Kai Tak Cruise terminal
usertext: Of all my years using a taxi here in HK, I have seen a grand total of ONE that takes Octopus. You should get some HKD cash. If this is the only time you will need HKD, then I suggest you go to the ATM and pull HKD400. from a bank machine at the airport. Do not use a Travelex.

subject: 3. Re: Taxi service from HK airport to Kai Tak Cruise terminal
usertext: To supplement Sammy's remark: the bank-owned ATM machines (which have better rates than Travelex) are located outside the customs and immigration controls.

subject: 4. Re: Taxi service from HK airport to Kai Tak Cruise terminal

subject: Useful Mobile Apps for visiting Hong Kong (2023)
usertext: Here are some resources highlighting useful mobile apps for those traveling to Hong Kong. Recommended HK Apps (HKTB) https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/plan/traveller-info/travel-apps.html Discover Hong Kong's list of recommended apps for visiting HK. It is a fair place to start but there are more, different and some better app recommendations in the two following write-ups worth considering. 14 Apps for trips to HK (http://Saporedcina.com) https://www.saporedicina.com/english/apps-traveling-hong-kong/ Some overlap with HKTB but a few more app suggestions that might be useful. 42 Apps used by Hongkongers (HKHub) https://thehkhub.com/the-best-smartphoneapps-for-hong-kong/ This one is overkill for tourists but shows a fairly extensive list of what is out there and frequently used by those who live in the city. If I were visiting Hong Kong today, these are the apps I'd download (or at least consider downloading) below. Note that others will have their own preferences which will differ to mine. ----------------------------------------------- Transportation - Best apps for getting around the city Google Maps https://apps.apple.com/us/app/google-maps/id585027354 CityMapper https://citymapper.com/?lang=en HKTaxi* https://hktaxiapp.com/ *HKTaxi only works if you have a local phone number Uber HK** https://www.uber.com/hk/en/ **You can arrange UberX and local taxis through Uber HK app. ----------------------------------------------- Food and Dining - Best apps for looking up restaurants/eateries Openrice https://apps.apple.com/hk/app/openrice-%E9%96%8B%E9%A3%AF%E5%96%87/id310663323 You can find pretty much every eatery on Openrice. Great resource for locating a specific type of food or restaurant you are looking for no matter where you are in Hong Kong. Deliveroo https://apps.apple.com/hk/app/deliveroo-food-delivery-app/id1001501844?l=en Foodpanda https://apps.apple.com/hk/app/foodpanda-food-delivery/id758103884?l=en Hopefully not necessary but if you find yourself exhausted or just don't feel like going out, here are our two best food delivery apps in HK. ------------------------------------------------ Other Essentials Weather (MyObservatory() https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/myobservatory.htm Octopus App for Tourists https://www.mtr.com.hk/mtrmobile/en/ Brand new Octopus feature that will probably become an essential app in the future. HKTrails (for hikers) https://apps.apple.com/hk/app/hiking-trail-hk/id1403380232?l=en ------------------------------------------------ Might Be Useful Free Wifi (http://Wi-Fi.HK) https://apps.apple.com/hk/app/wi-fi-hk/id899066359 Water for Free in HK https://apps.apple.com/us/app/water-for-free-2-0/id1252258619?ls=1 Ex (Forex currency exchange rates) https://www.xe.com/apps/ ------------------------------------------------

subject: 1. Re: Is Disneyland quiet in April and May?
usertext: Avoid the beginning of May (mainland Chinese holidays) and HK public holidays like Easter in April. Avoid weekends if you can. On other days, it should not be especially crowded.

subject: 2. Re: Is Disneyland quiet in April and May?
usertext: We went mid May this year, didn't do all of the rides (none of the thrill ones) but only waited 20-30 minutes for the most popular things. It didn't feel over crowded.

subject: High speed train from Hong Kong to Shanghai
usertext: Hi, Travelling to Hong Kong in mid November and thinking of taking high speed train to Shanghai, 1st class tickets are $208 US and 2nd class tickets are $128 US. If I buy a 2nd class ticket because it's cheaper, are the toilets squat toilets or do they have normal toilets on these high speed trains. subject: 1. Re: High speed train from Hong Kong to Shanghai
usertext: it will be normal toilets. However, it will not be so clean, especially after a few hours since departure. Why don't consider taking a plane ? Taking trains more than 4 hours is quite a suffering.

subject: 2. Re: High speed train from Hong Kong to Shanghai
usertext: High speed trains have normal toilets. I find them to be rather clean, even on long distances.

subject: 3. Re: High speed train from Hong Kong to Shanghai
usertext: I don't think you need to worry too much about the toliet. It will be clean and neat. Otherwise you can also ask the attendant to do the clean work if it is dirty. Moreover, The HSR train from HK to SH is CR400(Fu Xing Hao), which is the most updated one. The toliet is slightly different from the previous CRH1CRH2CRH5CRH3 model. It's better for you to copy and paste those Chinese characters() in Google search and review the images available. Happy riding!

subject: HK/Macau which order?
usertext: Hi I've 7 nights in January and thinking about 2 in Macau and 5 in HK. Was going to do Macau first as our flight arrives in HK around 2pm, though I'm not sure which is the best way round to do it. Wanted to book Wynn in Macau but there's no availability as it's the weekend, so didn't know whether to do HK first? Wynn not a deal breaker but normally stay there in vegas. Also is 2 there and 5 in HK a good split? TIA :-)

subject: 1. Re: HK/Macau which order?
usertext: I think your split is about right. Macau hotel availability is always better (and cheaper) on midweek days. It is a very weekend-driven tourist economy. If it were me, I would try to schedule to be in Macau on weekdays. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: HK/Macau which order?
usertext: Travel to Macau from HKIA is quite convenient using the HMZ Bridge which is next to the airport if you decide to go that route. Related, departing Macau by way of the bridge to HK for outbound flights is also convenient logistics wise. See thread with details about typical travel options between HK <> Macau https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html Another thing to consider is your outbound flight out of Hong Kong. If you have an early flight out of HKIA then probably best to be in HK the night before as travel to the airport from hotels in the city are just much smoother, quicker and stress-free compared to coming over from Macau. If hotel room cost is an important factor, definitely consider HK_Observers mention above about room rates midweek vs Friday & Sat nights in Macau when they spike significantly compared to what you spend for weekday stays.

subject: 3. Re: HK/Macau which order?
usertext: Thank you HK_Observer and BradJill. We land on the Friday and fly out Friday night at 11pm so an early flight isn't an issue. Based on what you've both said, Friday and Saturday nights in Macau has a lot less availability. Cost isn't the primary concern but no point in paying double if we don't need to I guess. If we did Macau on the Wednesday and Thursday how long would it take to get there from HK and what time would we need to leave Macau on the Friday for an 11pm flight?

subject: 4. Re: HK/Macau which order?
usertext: {how long would it take to get there from HK } Depends on where you are staying in Hong Kong. Review the transportation options provided in the link provided in my post above to get a feel for how much time it will take you go over to Macau and then onward to the hotel you choose there. {would we need to leave Macau on the Friday for an 11pm flight?} Similarly, depends on where you are staying in Macau. Otherwise, read some of the posts on this thread from the Macau forum which discusses travel and time allotments between HKIA and Macau. It is a good place to start for understanding how much time you should allow for travel over the airport. Having an 11pm flight, you'll have plenty of time to do so comfortably. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14356859-HongKong_airport_to_Macau-Macau.html

subject: 5. Re: HK/Macau which order?
usertext: Thank you again BradJill, very helpful :-)

subject: Cathay pacific layoverHK 21 hr.. from Manila to US.S.
usertext: Hi...I have US passport , can I venture out easily in HK and eat yummy HK food , stay in a hotel overnight ? pls advice ...do I need visa? Is it easy to go out in HK just to eat ?! Do taxi Uber accept credit cards? Are there authentic HK restaurants near the airport that locals eat? I have 21 hr overnight layover in oct. Thx... Kris

subject: 1. Re: Cathay pacific layoverHK 21 hr.. from Manila to US.S.
usertext: Some resources on this forum where you will quickly find out US passport holders don't require visa to enter Hong Kong and some help planning layovers in HK. Visa Requirements for Hong Kong https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14479683-Hong_Kong_Visa_Requirements_2023-Hong_Kong.html#118350396 Layovers in Hong Kong https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14493334-Layovers_in_Hong_Kong_2023-Hong_Kong.html {Do taxi Uber accept credit cards?} There are some taxi that accept credit card but they are rare so best to be ready to pay with cash. Or download the Uber app and link to credit card you have in your iPhone wallet. They you can choose either a UberX or taxi through the app. Note that a lot depends on how you end up deciding to go into the city. With 21 hours, you are probably going to want to have some spending cash anyway so using an ATM to pull out enough to cover taxi ride will make sense. You may decide to use other modes of transportations as well.

subject: 2. Re: Cathay pacific layoverHK 21 hr.. from Manila to US.S.
usertext: What is your arrival time and departure time?

subject: 3. Re: Cathay pacific layoverHK 21 hr.. from Manila to US.S.
usertext: No visa needed for US passport holder. Easy to go out and eat, sightsee, whatever. Uber accepts credit cards; taxis do not. Area around the airport is pretty sterile. There are some locally - oriented restaurants in the CityGate shopping mall, not too far (by bus) from the airport terminal. But by far the best way to do this type of stopover is to take the Airport Express train from the airport to Hong Kong station, which is right in the middle of "downtown" HK. There you can walk around, see some sights, eat, drink and generally have a good time. A same-day round-trip ticket on the train costs $115 HK dollars. Credit card can be used to purchase ticket. Customer service booths are located in the airport arrival hall.

subject: 4. Re: Cathay pacific layoverHK 21 hr.. from Manila to US.S.
usertext: Does Cathay provide a hotel room on long stopovers?

subject: 5. Re: Cathay pacific layoverHK 21 hr.. from Manila to US.S.
usertext: That would be a surprise!!

subject: 6. Re: Cathay pacific layoverHK 21 hr.. from Manila to US.S.
usertext: No. I don't even think they give you a hotel room for an overnight layover. >>>Does Cathay provide a hotel room on long stopovers?

subject: 11. Re: Cathay pacific layoverHK 21 hr.. from Manila to US.S.
usertext: No too high risk of random detention there indeed. Police will probably just kill you. Easier.

subject: 12. Re: Cathay pacific layoverHK 21 hr.. from Manila to US.S.
usertext: StormKing, I've offered some context to help with your misunderstanding of safety and security in Hong Kong and Macau for American citizens in the separate thread that you started (see post #8 in your thread linked below). https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14507351-USA_to_Hong_Kong_Safe-Hong_Kong.html

subject: 2. Re: Cafes near HK Disneyland
usertext: How "near" is near? Within walking distance - no. You need to take taxi out there or take the hotel shuttle to take MTR via at least 1 transfer at Sunny Bay Station. You can go to Tsing Yi Station, Maritime Square (it's a mall) is right on top of the MTR Station. Or go to Tung Chung Station, Citigate Outlet Mall is right on top of the MTR Station. Opposite directions, both are 1-stop away from Sunny Bay. About same distance. There are lots of local eateries at these malls. Big restaurants or small eats. Do some research ahead of time (http://openrice.com), or browse around and follow your eyes/nose. Citigate Outlet Mall may suit you better. They have a food court - which is about as close to a "hawker centre" as you can find. Link: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/r-food-opera-tung-chung-international-r631030 You want to save money? The best advice is not to stay at the hotels at Disneyland. You need to know they are in the business of making as much money as they can from their loyal fans. So you can have a "whole experience". Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Cafes near HK Disneyland
usertext: Nearest non-Disney food options are at 30-45 mins travel from those hotels. Most relevant non-Disney tourist sites are well further than that. Indeed I also strongly suggest you to look into down town hotels for the second and third night. One night for the Disney experience, one day for the park (it's small, one day is really enough), and then move to Hong Kong proper.

subject: Possible to do Lantau island in half day
usertext: Hi folks, Is it possible to cover Lantau island - Big Buddha, Tai O, and other touristic points on Wednesday (19th Sep,23) and also catch an international flight at 6 PM from HK? If yes, any tips will be helpful. We are open to take priority line for cable-car. This needs budgeting of time to collect our baggage from hotel for the flight as well. Another alternate we are exploring is that we cover it in the 2nd half from 2 PM onwards (and then return as late as possible, believe it is 6 PM). Wanted to check if we can check-in our luggage (1 bag) somewhere before cable-car and is it too hot (mid-sep) with a 4 year old kid? Thanks in advance :)

subject: 1. Re: Possible to do Lantau island in half day
usertext: Where is your hotel? So you want to "do" Lantau Island, then go back to your hotel, then return to the airport (which is on Lantau Island)? On option, since in-town check-in is now open (depending on your airline), you may want to check your luggage at the Airport Express in town station, then go to Lantau, then go to the airport. This saves you a trip returning to your hotel.

subject: 2. Re: Possible to do Lantau island in half day
usertext: Two main options for this day. 1) check in your luggage at Hong Kong or Kowloon Airport Express station (you have to buy a ticket - call it a service fee) early morning. Ferry to Mui Wo (the slow ferry has far better views than the fast ferry); bus to Tai O (connects to the ferries); visit Tai O; bus to Ngong Ping; visit the monastery; 3ish cable car down and taxi or bus to the airport. Very doable if you can start off early. 2) MTR to Tung Chung; drop your luggage at the left luggage facility of the cable car; cable car to Ngong Ping; visit monastery; bus to Tai O; enjoy the village; and then either bus to Tung Chung or bus back to Ngong Ping and cable car down. Collect bags, head out to the airport, check in etc. A bit faster solution. Unless things changed I'm not aware of a priority line for the cable car. Booking tickets in advance online does tend to make it a bit faster as you can skip (most of) the ticketing line.

subject: 3. Re: Possible to do Lantau island in half day
usertext: Be aware that on weekdays the bus between Ngong Ping and Tai O only goes once an hour, so you'd need to build your schedule around that. Details of all the buses on Lantau here: https://nlb.com.hk/route

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Possible to do Lantau island in half day
usertext: Note that at the current time the Airport Express In-town luggage check in facility is only available for passengers taking Cathay Pacific flights and only at Hong Kong Station (6am to 3pm daily). In-town check is not available for passengers taking flights with other airlines or at Kowloon Station where the check-in service closed in April 2020 during the pandemic and has not yet reopened.

subject: 5. Re: Possible to do Lantau island in half day
usertext: Given that is will be quite hot and fairly good chance for rain in mid-September, I think it is a lot to ask to coordinate doing Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car/Village as well as Tai O on a travel day where you need to be at the airport around 4pm for flight back home. It is doable but would be a bit too stressful for my comfort, even being fairly familiar with how transportation works on Lantau Island. Tai O is a neat place to visit but I wouldn't consider it worth stressing yourself in order to cram in an additional place to see before flying out of HK. To be honest, I'd give it a pass and add to your bucket list for next trip to Hong Kong. There are other things you can do near Tung Chung if you end up with some extra time on your hands. Definitely there will be time to go up Ngong Ping Village. Cable Car starts running at 10am. Luggage storage is available at the Lower Terminus as well as the Tung Chung shopping mall. You can do casual/leisurely visit at the village, see the Big Buddha and monastery. The cable car back down is fun but I enjoy the bus trip back to Tung Chung as well. It is longer but you get to view some nice countryside areas of Lantau. If time is on your side on the day, you can sider doing this as an activity on the day. Have a late lunch at Citygate Outlet Mall back Tung Chung afterwards. Then make your way to the airport when you are ready. If you find you've a couple free hours after lunch, there are a few historic attractions around Tung Chung like the Tung Chung Fort that are interesting enough to use 30-45 minutes time. Taxi or public bus from Tung Chung will have you back at the airport in 15 minutes. Good luck with your planning and have a nice trip to Hong Kong.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Transport
usertext: Hi is Uber reliable in HK or is there another alternative, other than MTR? Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Transport
usertext: The alternative is taxi.

subject: 2. Re: Transport
usertext: Other than that, there are also buses, minibuses, trams, ferries - lots of transport options available! Taxis are reliable and easily available. Note that most are still cash only.

subject: 3. Re: Transport
usertext: Hong Kong has a comprehensive public transportation system that is reliable, relatively low cost and with fairy rare system disruptions. Here is some general information from our local tourist department if useful. https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/plan/traveller-info/getting-around.html Since you are asking about Uber, I would also mention that is is useful to download the Google Maps and CityMapper apps on your mobile phone as well. They are very good for planning routes and seeing what transportation options are most suitable for journeys around the city.

subject: 4. Re: Transport
usertext: Uber is reliable. In HK, within Uber, you also have the option of calling taxis. In that case, a regular taxi will come and pick you up. In most cases, taxis are readily available except at places like Lan Kwai Fong late at night.

You can use trip.com to look at the train schedule and book train tickets from Hong Kong to Guangzhou: Link: https://www.trip.com/trains/china/route/Hongkong-to-Guangzhou/

subject: Contactless vs octopus card
usertext: Can we use Apple Pay or a contactless credit card instead of an octopus card?

subject: 1. Re: Contactless vs octopus card
usertext: The answer is "may be". Your question is too general. Apply Pay, Contactless Credit Card, Octopus Card are different methods of payment. Which method(s) are accepted by the merchant/service-provider/transportation-operator depend on the merchant/service-provider/transportation-operator! One cannot say "yes you can use XXXXXX method to pay for everything". The merchant/service-provider/transportation-operator has to have special machines to support each of those technologies. Not a one-size-fits-all thing. You may want to ask with more specifics. Such as to pay for what?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Contactless vs octopus card
usertext: The main bus operators Citybus and KMB both accept contactless payment by Mastercard, Visa, Union Pay, Apple Pay, Google Pay and Samsung Pay. Hong Kong Tramways accepts contactless payment by all the above methods plus JCB card and Huawei Pay. MTR doesn't currently accept contactless card fare payment but is the course of replacing all its entry and exit gates and installing software to enable contactless card payment. However, the system is not likely to be in operation before the end of this year; https://www.mtr.com.hk/archive/corporate/en/press_release/PR-23-017-E.pdf I don't think cross-harbour (including Star Ferry) and outlying islands ferries accept contactless payment yet. Some green minibuses trialled Alipay contactless payment but I'm not sure how that progressed.

subject: 3. Re: Contactless vs octopus card
usertext: Thank you. That's really helpful.

subject: Entering hongkong after being absent for over 3 years
usertext: Hello, It will have been 4 years since i entered HK with my right to abode 3* HK ID card I was wondering will i still be able to enter HK with this as i know it changes to right to land after 3 years? Will i need to get it changed to right to land whilst over there? Thank you

subject: 1. Re: Entering hongkong after being absent for over 3 years
usertext: You have your "right to abode", you can always land in and enter Hong Kong with your HKID card. Your ID card may not always match with the latest technology that the HK government is using to automatically process your entry (e.g. chip sensing, fingerprint scan, and whatever biometric technologies they may have deployed), you can always queue (if there is a queue) through the counters for Hong Kong residents (vs foreign visitors) to process your entry. They can manually look up your information. Do have your current passport with you in the event someone wants to have a second piece of identification. A passport is still the valid document for international travel anyway.

subject: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: Hi will UK banking apps and normal apps such as ebay, amazon etc work in hong kong or will i need to use a VPN?

subject: 1. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: I guess you're going to need to be specific about which banking apps and what exactly you want to do with Amazon. eBay and Amazon attempt to geolocate you from your IP address. I certainly use the Amazon UK website often in HK so I would expect the app to work too in the sense of ordering goods, which they wuill happily deliver to HK, But note that Prime video will not due to geographic rights issues. And Amazon Prime is quite good at spotting VPN usage, so I have had very limited success trying to watch Amazon Prime UK videos from Hong Kong, even with VPNs. I can't comment oneBay except to say that eBay HK is not useable in English.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: Like halifax, revolut

subject: 3. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: I know friends who use Revolut here, so I'm confident that will work. No idea on Halifax. But in general banking apps need to work worldwide - people travel. All my HK ones work fine in the UK, for example.

subject: 4. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: HK does not have the Great Fire Wall. So my thinking is that most apps should work. Even Face Book (Meta) worked for me. And if Face Book works, I can't think of an app that won't work.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 5. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: My RBS and Halifax apps both work fine in HK.

subject: 6. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: Would recommend using a banking app in HK on device(s) with a VPN. Using a VPN connected to a UK server increases the likelihood of apps working, besides encrypting your data between your device and the UK server. I had no issues streaming Amazon Prime videos when using Express VPN when in mainland China. Also, do your banking apps require 2 factor authentication to log in, such as a code texted to your smart phone UK number? And if so, you need to confirm you can receive the code when in Hong Kong or turn 2FA off before you travel, or look into getting a hardware authentication device such as a YubiKey. A list of these devices can be found here: https://www.pcmag.com/picks/the-best-security-keys-for-multi-factor-authentication Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: I've actually found some banking apps DON'T work with a VPN. The app somehow checks if a VPN is being used and flags it as a security issue. Same way some banking apps don't work if you've rooted your phone.

subject: 8. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: @7 - Which VPN? Not all VPNs are created equal. Here is what NordVPN says about VPN use for online banking: "VPN for online banking: Is it really safe?" https://nordvpn.com/blog/online-banking/

subject: 9. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: Mind: NordVPN is in the business of selling you VPNs. What they state there may very well be true, yet it's probably just part of the picture. From the pov of the bank: someone using a VPN may just as well be an imposter, trying to pretend they're you by pretending they're in your home country and not in say Nigeria or Russia. Thus you connecting to the bank over a VPN may very well be a major red flag for the bank. Actually this is the exact argument NordVPN uses to recommend you using a VPN while you travel - basically hiding from your bank that you're travelling. Whether that's a good idea to begin with I doubt: you can't hide your location when trying to get money from an ATM. So when the bank detects you connect from your home country (faked - using a VPN), and an hour later you attempt to withdraw money from an ATM in Hong Kong, 12 or so hours flight away, don't blame them for instantly blocking your ATM card as if that's not a red flag indicating stolen credentials, I don't know what is!.

subject: 10. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: It doesn't matter what VPN you're using: on Android an app can check the network connection and find out if a VPN is in use on your phone.

subject: 11. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: So, don't use a VPN. Your choice. I'd rather keep my data, especially my bank information, as secure as possible.

subject: 12. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: Any bank app will use end-to-end encryption. That a VPN is "more secure" for bank apps is just the scare tactic VPNs use to sell their service.

subject: 13. Re: UK banking iphone apps work in Hong Kong?
usertext: For people who are really worried about security, they just shouldn't use a cell/mobile phone, let alone use any banking apps. As to websites access here, HK itself doesn't block anything that I know of. However, some foreign governments sites and private sites block access to HK'ers for "security" reasons. Some sites I can't access without a VPN are several of the "people look-up" sites in the States, some of the .gov or related sites also in the States, and also some European government sites. I was trying to look up Italian transport once and got blocked. Another time, I had to help my friend pay his Madrid driving ticket with a VPN because the payment site wouldn't grant him access. Amazon: I regularly browse and buy things from various Amazon sites all the time. Some items that are cheaper buying from US Amazon than locally offer free shipping if you buy more than $49. For things like Whatsapp, Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Google related services, etc, they all work. In fact, for HK'ers who use their home plan roaming to access the internet in China, these sites even work in the mainland.

subject: 6. Re: General prices
usertext: Cheung Chau is okay for a 2-night stay if you want to experience it. Warwick Hotel Cheung Chau Or you can move to Discovery Bay for a quiet corner: Auberge Discovery Bay Hotel Hong Kong Personally I kind of like (not on an island but you can walk out to a beach): Hong Kong Gold Coast Hotel The latest: Good view of the Pacific Ocean with some islands out there: The Fullerton Ocean Park Hotel Hong Kong (This one is more expensive because it is built for the Ocean Park waterpark.)

subject: 7. Re: General prices
usertext: {I'm not keen on Macau as a side trip, casino culture doesn't appeal.} I wouldn't write off Macau without doing a bit more research. There is much more to our sister city than just Vegas style casinos. It was the oldest and last European colony in Asia with nearly 500 years of Portuguese history, really unique fusion culture, heritage and cuisine that is significantly different than what you will experience here in HK. The entire city centre of Macau a UNESCO World Heritage area with over 25 historic attractions and places to visit. Only a couple require entry to visit as well. https://www.wh.mo/en/site/ There are affordable mid-range accommodations in Macau during midweek but not so much on weekends. Lots of quaint squares and city parks, promenades and green space, neat places to chill and enjoy more relaxing environs that what we have in Hong Kong. Anyway, Macau is a nice change of pace to bustling Hong Kong, especially if you are here for 12 nights which is quite a lot for most visitors. There is convenient transportation between the two cities as well if interested.

subject: 8. Re: General prices
usertext: Thank you! I'll do a bit more research and have a look through all your other recommendations as well:-)

subject: 9. Re: General prices
usertext: +1 for Macau indeed. No need to visit the casinos, the heritage sites have so much on offer. Lots of museums as well, ranging from arts to history and many other topics. Very interesting food options as well - the best ones are not in the casinos. For an island stay, I've always liked Silvermine Bay Resort. A rather basic but decent hotel, at a great location (at the beach) and quite conveniently located for several trips: ferries to Cheung Chau and Peng Chau, bus to Tai O and Ngong Ping (both on Lantau), a decent choice of restaurants in Mui Wo, and many options for hikes or just a walk in the rural surroundings (and see a very different side of Hong Kong).

subject: 10. Re: General prices
usertext: Thank you! Love the idea of splitting our stay like this! Just what I was looking for:)

subject: 11. Re: General prices
usertext: Lunch, dinner, transport, 7-11 snacks - would HK $500 per person per day suffice? ~~~It is a very good budget, unless you eat in Disneyland or Peninsula everyday and take taxi not metro... :D I agreed with #1, you can save some money and get a good dish at 5-stars. Snacks are cheap in HK, street food is not expensive, the price of good restaurant is ok. But if you want to experience a traditional breakfast or Peninsula afternoon tea, it costs money... and time...

subject: 12. Re: General prices

subject: Tips for solo traveler as a female?
usertext: I am a single middle-aged female and like to travel to S.E. Asia. Have never travelled alone before. Is it scary to travel along? Is it possible to find a travel partner? Wondered if anyone has any experience or advice to share? Thanks in advance.

subject: 1. Re: Tips for solo traveler as a female?
usertext: Hong Kong is very safe, it's perfectly normal for women to be out and about alone even late at night. Scary? That's mostly on you. No need to find it scary. Normal precautions of course apply - use common sense. Finding a travel partner? If it's just for a destination, try Meetup.com for social events or apps such as tinder for one on one meetings - tinder dates are said to be great local guides, as I've read about by travel writers a few times, just be honest to your dates of what you expect. If you want someone to travel with you between places, no ideas. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Tips for solo traveler as a female?
usertext: The only advice I would give someone (male or female) is never to get stupid drunk. Most problems occur when you are drunk and not in possession of all your senses.

subject: 3. Re: Tips for solo traveler as a female?
usertext: There is an entire forum here on TripAdvisor dedicated to solo travel. You can pick up some good tips and advice that will apply to traveling on your own in general from the experts and regular contributors there (see link)

subject: 4. Re: Tips for solo traveler as a female?
usertext: As a now officially "senior" single woman who has called Hong Kong home for more than 30 years, I can assure you that this region is really, really safe. At all hours. In any neighbourhood. I can honestly say that the greatest safety issues I have encountered here have been either overspending my budget and tripping over a kerb (because I wasn't looking where I was going). And, if getting really off the beaten track, there are some villages in rural areas where residents let unfriendly dogs off-leash after dark. So, as others have written, don't get stupid drunk, and I'll add don't go hiking alone, and you'll be absolutely fine.

subject: 5. Re: Tips for solo traveler as a female?
usertext: I have done plenty of solo travel in South East Asia and Hong Kong and elsewhere. I am male, but you will find that there are plenty of female solo travellers as well. As mentioned the Solo Travel forum here on Tripadvisor is a good place to ask questions about solo travel. Personally I do not find solo travel scary. In fact I find it exciting, and it is liberating to not have to make compromises with travel companions about what you want to do or see. Occasionally you can feel lonely. But even that is often temporary. One way to get around that could be to join a tour. By that I mean a day tour. That is a quick and easy way to have some company, and for me it also means that once that is over I can go back to doing my own thing, which is just as important to me. I have never tried to look for a travel companion for an entire trip, and to be honest I would not choose a stranger to be a long term travel companion. Lastly I would add that solo travel is not for everyone. But the only way to discover if it is for you is to do it.

subject: Which hotel for the first time in Hkg as a tourist in Sept23
usertext: Hello, My wife and I are mid 30s and planning to visit Hkg (3N/4D) and Macau (2N/3D). While we are not ultra-rich to afford a Four seasons or a St Regis, we do believe in splurging on travel within reasonable limits. We are utterly confused on the 4/5 star hotel to stay in Hkg with reviews all over the place and prices . Our key considerations are - 1. Walkable access to MTR/Subway 2. Outdoor (Rooftop) Pool 3. Rooftop Lounge (added advantage) 4. Harbour View or City Skyline (which is better?) 5. Preferably Marriott/HH/Hyatt/Shangri-La chain (offering great bfast beyond Asian spread). 6. 1D would be in Disneyland and other 2 days for top attractions. We intend to spend less time at the hotel. 7. Budget Approx $2000HKD/Night We have shortlisted The Kerry Hotel, Shangri-La basis an analysis of above requirement + % of total TA reviews at 3 or below (% of bad review/total reviews) - low % is better: Kerry Hotel has 7.4% Hyatt Centric (tempting price points and great view) has 12.3% Hyatt regency TST has 12.2% Conrad - 9.8% Intercontinental stanford -9.9% Park lane, pullman - 10.3% Hari hong kong - 5.3% (however, only 418 reviews as on date) Harbour grand hk - 13.5% Renaissance Marriott hk- 11.6% Holiday inn golden mile - 20.3% Sheraton Hotels and Towers HK -19.7% Still wanted to hear from someone who has been to Hkg recently. Is it also worth splurging on hotels in Hkng when one would be spending most of the time sight seeing, eating outside?

subject: 1. Re: Which hotel for the first time in Hkg as a tourist in Sept23
usertext: Your list of hotels are not close comparables. I will give you my opinion. = = = = = First, the "shake out": Park lane, pullman - 10.3%: Been around a long time. On one side it's the "skyline" (if you can call it that) over Victoria Park. But I don't believe they have a pool. Hari hong kong - 5.3% (however, only 418 reviews as on date): I don't think this hotel has a pool either. I have not seen a hotel which has a pool does not feature it in their website. Holiday inn golden mile - 20.3%: No view. The rooftop pool is a bit forgettable. Conrad - 9.8%: This is a high-end hotel. (Or maybe just high-price). It is a notch higher than the other ones that you put together. = = = = = Second, the "missing something" views: Hyatt regency TST has 12.2%: Surrounded by older tall buildings. You need to be above certain floors to have a view of Victoria Harbour. Or else you will be seeing the tinted windows of your neighbouring building. Intercontinental stanford -9.9%: their view to Victoria Harbour is from the side, not straight on. Sheraton Hotels and Towers HK -19.7%: They have a very narrow view of the Victoria Harbour (to clear the Regent Hotel which is blocking most of their view, and the Peninsula Hotel which is also blocking their view). = = = = = Third, the "finalists" from your criteria: Kerry Hotel has 7.4% Hyatt Centric (tempting price points and great view) has 12.3% Harbour grand hk - 13.5% Renaissance Marriott hk- 11.6% And Kowloon Shangri-La too Have good, unblocked view of the Victoria Harbour. I have stayed at Harbour Grand Kowloon before (the sister property to Harbour Grand Hong Kong) and would not hesitate to take it. Kowloon Shang would probably give you good value. Renaissance is more positioned as a business hotel (it is next to the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre) than a vacationer hotel. Hyatt Centric is fairly new. I have no experience. If the price is good, it may be a gem. Kerry Hotel too perhaps. Too new for me. Last time I passed that way it was just an empty land.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Which hotel for the first time in Hkg as a tourist in Sept23
usertext: We stay at the Renaissance Harbour View on HK island - we have booked to stay again next year. The hotel is situated immediately adjacent to the Exhibition Centre and is within a few minutes of the MTR. The Star Ferry is approximately 5 minutes walk. The rooms aren't huge but the view of the harbour is nice. The pool (shared with the next door Grand Hyatt) is an outdoor pool and is on the 11th floor - again with great views of the harbour. We would recommend.

subject: Good boutique hotels to stay
usertext: Hi travellers Planning to stay for a week in Hongkong . Ideally we prefer to stay in newish boutique hotels that's mid range to high end and have easy access to transportation and eateries/ Shopping . Zeroed in on two hotels - Hyatt centric and East because of the harbour views However I'm confused which one to go for as both look equally appealing and cost almost the same . Anyone who have stayed in these hotels can share their experiences would really help Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Good boutique hotels to stay
usertext: RE: "Zeroed in on two hotels - Hyatt centric and East because of the harbour views" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Strictly my opinion based on the 2 locations of these hotels. Hyatt Centric is right there near North Point Pier by the Victoria Harbour. If you select a harbourview roomtype, you are almost guaranteed to have a good, unobstructed view of the harbour (except for the lowest few floors perhaps). There is no other building between this hotel and the harbour. Not the same for Hotel East. It is located at Kornhill and is surrounded by the earlier-built residential high-rises. My eyeball-estimate: to have an unblocked view of the harbour you need to be above 20/F at least at this hotel. Have you checked with the hotel? Sometimes hotels advertise for "harbour side" but does not necessarily mean unblocked views. Maybe only a few guests can get the good view from the building. Hotel Management knows good view can demand higher rates. They generally will price the rooms/roomtypes proportionally. For both of these properties, the access to MTR (Hong Kong's subway) are about the same. Both, just a short walk. Hyatt Centric - about 1000 feet (~350 meters) to an entrance to North Point MTR Station, which is closer to Causeway Bay (the shopping/eatery area). Hotel East is about 500 feet (~200 meters) from an entrance to Tai Koo MTR Station. But they are 2 stations farther from Causeway Bay. If view is a priority for you, I would take Hyatt Centric which seems to be a safer bet. And you are up-close to the waterfront.

subject: 2. Re: Good boutique hotels to stay
usertext: Thanks a lot that was helpful !

subject: 3. Re: Good boutique hotels to stay
usertext: Definitely nothing wrong with Hyatt Centric but I'm actually a bigger fan of Hong Kong East Hotel in Tai Koo. We've stayed there a couple times including a Xmas holiday, much to do with the modern, boutique and really nice rooms. Note HPFT is right, the harbourview rooms are on the higher floors and facing north. Do ask for these or select when making reservation. If you don't get one, not to worry, the rooftop bar called sugar here is really nice with excellent views. Food isn't bad, drinks are fine. It is a great place to unwind after a day of sightseeing and before heading out to dinner. The entrance is right outside the Kai Koo MTR Station (exit D1), right on the Island line as well so you are pretty well connected for sightseeing around the city. You are also right next to a good shopping mall called Cityplaza. There is a nice modern urban park called Taikoo Park nearby and a surprising number of western restaurants and coffee shops in the area. It is it a good place for a few nights if you want boutique, a bit off the beaten path area but still very well connected for MTR transportation.

subject: 4. Re: Good boutique hotels to stay
usertext: So true ! I really liked the modern feel to the rooms compared to Hyatt and the in room drinking tap is a huge plus from the sustainability factor . But wasn't sure on the housekeeping and customer service so was unsure . Thanks a ton !

subject: 5. Re: Good boutique hotels to stay
usertext: have you been to this trip? If yes which hotel did you end up with? I just saw this thread today. I stayed at Hyatt Centric (then called Hotel Vic) in 2019 for 7 days. I have to say I don't like it as it doesn't have a single drawer so every day I had to pull something from my suitcase. We are going to HK next week and will at East

subject: 6. Re: Good boutique hotels to stay
usertext: It's not an overriding concern since Hong Kong is relatively compact and transport's good. But North Point is a livelier more traditional neighborhood than Taikoo, which is a huge modernish housing estate anchored by a shopping centre.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: entry requirements to visit china with hong kong id card
usertext: With effect from 30th August covid tests are no longer required to enter China; http://english.www.gov.cn/news/202308/28/content_WS64ec61b0c6d0868f4e8dee2c.html

subject: 2. Re: entry requirements to visit china with hong kong id card
usertext: You can't enter Mainland China with a HK permanent ID card. You need a Home Return Permit.

subject: 3. Re: entry requirements to visit china with hong kong id card
usertext: i think i have a china resident card but it has expired

subject: 4. Re: entry requirements to visit china with hong kong id card
usertext: For travel to China you normally need a home return permit (which is only available for Hong Kong residents with 3-star HKID), or your passport with China visa. To get a new home return permit (if you're eligible) I recall you have to contact CTS (China Travel Service) which has offices all over Hong Kong. To get a visa, you may contact one of many visa agents. Prices for visa vary depending on your passport and between the various agents.

subject: 9. Re: entry requirements to visit china with hong kong id card
usertext: No testing or vaccine requirement to enter HK or China anymore. At present, you do have to fill out a health declaration. If you have Wechat on your phone, you can fill one out online within 24 hours of arrival into China (filling it out too early voids the resulting QR code). Without Wechat, you have to stop at the computer terminals at the border to fill one out which will take some extra time.. Leaving China, you will also have to fill out the health declaration. The same process applies. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Experience using Revolut in Hong Kong?
usertext: No bank ATMs in Hong Kong charge fees for cash withdrawal. Any fees are imposed by your card issuer.

subject: 3. Re: Experience using Revolut in Hong Kong?

subject: 4. Re: Experience using Revolut in Hong Kong?
usertext: Please read the previous post. There are no fees so of course it is easy to find an ATM with no fees. Can be found everywhere including the airport.

subject: 5. Re: Experience using Revolut in Hong Kong?
usertext: HSBC, Bank of China and Citibank all have multiple ATMs at the airport

subject: 6. Re: Experience using Revolut in Hong Kong?
usertext: ATMs are all over the place, and indeed do not charge you. Be aware of any charges your home bank may levy, and you may need to inform your bank of your travel so they don't block the card for unusual/unexpected transactions. If the ATM asks you to charge you in your home currency (some actually do this!), don't take that offer. Let your bank to the conversion, that are always better rates.

Or you can now simply use contactless credit cards on buses, MTRs (Visa only) and ding-ding trams. Edited: 1 year ago

usertext: How to get from the HKIA to Macau old city?I reach HKIA at 7 am . Would ferries be cheaper or should I take a bus. Also how to return from macao to Hong Kong near Chungking Mansions Do the trains/buses in Hong Kong accept PIN based credit cards or is cash needed? Do we need cash in Hong Kong ? Where to change cash in Hong Kong and can we change it back at the airport to USD ? If we use an ATM does it show English instructions and will it have a local ATM withdrawal fee (in addition to my bank charges)

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: {How to get from the HKIA to Macau old city?I reach HKIA at 7 am . Would ferries be cheaper or should I take a bus......Also how to return from macao to Hong Kong near Chungking Mansions} See these two threads for everything you need to know about transportation to Macau from Hong Kong and HKIA https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14356859-HongKong_airport_to_Macau-Macau.html {Do the trains/buses in Hong Kong accept PIN based credit cards or is cash needed?...} See - Octopus Card thread below. This is a smart card that you can pick up at HKIA airport when you arrive and use for bus and MTR train transportation around the city. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14482045-Octopus_Card_2023-Hong_Kong.html Do we need cash in Hong Kong ?} Yes... best to have some cash. You can use Octopus mentioned above for many of your small purchases in convenient stores, coffee shops and casual restaurants but there are some places where its just best to have some cash. Taxi for example, is mostly a cash only arrangement here in HK. {Where to change cash in Hong Kong and can we change it back at the airport to USD ?} You can get cash at ATMs throughout the city. Since you are staying at Chungking Mansions, you can also use the forex dealers on the ground floor there. They offer some of the most competitive rates in the city. Yes, you can change your remaining HKD at the forex dealers at the airport when you leave. {If we use an ATM does it show English instructions and will it have a local ATM withdrawal fee (in addition to my bank charges) Language is in English. Also, there are no ATM fees in Hong Kong but your local bank may impose charges. That is something you will have to confirm with them.

Also fro Macao not clear which route I should ake to be near Chung King mansions in the night. REquest guidance on this? Is September -end October Typhoon season?

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: Hi Do we need to tap in and tap out contactless credit cards at Buses and trams? Does the A21 (and other Airport buses like t0macao border etc ) accept contactless credit cards too? Also if I buy octopus , where can I get a refund early morning 5.30 am? I will be using the A21 bus to reach airport at 5.30 am. AT airport at that time will refund for octopus be available?

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: On buses you tap in only. On the tram you tap out only. Yes, the A21 accepts contactless credit cards. The MTR customer service desk at the Airport opens around 05:30; you can refund Octopus there. Be aware that HK is a very efficient airport, You need to be there at most 2 hours before departure, and if you have cabin baggage only and have checked-in online then 90 minutes is plenty. One question in my mind is whether you can use a single contactless credit card to pay for multiple people on the bus/trams. I'm not at all sure about this (you certainly need one Octopus card per person, including children over the age of 3); maybe others can advise.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: KMB has a five minute delay between contactless payment transactions on its buses; https://www1.kmb.hk/en/news/press/archives/news202102063775.html I expect, as is the case with Octopus, other transport operators will operate a similar system which I believe is in place to prevent accidental multiple charging although I can't find confirmation of this.

subject: 7. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: MTR for octopus do we have to tap n and tap out? Do tourists get the disablity discount on octopus?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 8. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: For MTR journeys you tap in and tap out with Octopus Card. Only HK residents receiving Comprehensive Social Security Assistance or Disability Allowance are eligible for concessionary fares for disabled persons.

subject: 9. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: For MTR rides you need to tap in and tap out. Because the MTR ride is not a fixed fare. The fare is roughly proportional to distance traveled. The longer the ride, the higher the fare. They need to know where you got in and where you exit to access the right fare for your ride, and to deduct it from your card's balance.

subject: 10. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: I am grateful fo all for their immense help

subject: 11. Re: Hong Kong Queries

subject: 12. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: Everything you need to know about Octopus Cards can be found here (see link) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14482045-Octopus_Card_2023-Hong_Kong.html 1) On loan Octopus can only be acquired with cash payment. 2) Initial Stored value (HK$50 per child, HK$150 per adult). There is no minimum stored value, you keep the card balance what you like and top up when you necessary. https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/octopus-cards/products/on-loan/standard.html 3) Refund - Administration fee of HK$11 or 1% or remaining value per card - you will pay whichever is higher. https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/customer-service/refund/index.html Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 14. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: The Queens portrait coins were replaced by bauhinia coins during 1993/94. They remain legal tender but traders are not under any legal obligation to accept them and the decision is down to each individual trader to decide; https://www.hkma.gov.hk/eng/key-functions/money/hong-kong-currency/coins/ I don't think I've used any of the old coins since about 1998 so I'm not sure whether they are readily accepted nowadays.

subject: 28. Re: Hong Kong Queries

subject: 29. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: ATMs at Hong Kong banks do not charge any fees for cash withdrawal. Note that, like most countries in the world, there are other ATMs which serve solely to rip off tourists. Stick to ATMs from HSBC Bank of China, Hang Seng, Standard Chartered, Citibank, Bank of East Asia, and you'll be fine. HK bank ATM cards do generally have 6-digit PINs. I have no idea how overseas cards with 4-digit PINs work, but I guess they must do otherwise we'd be hearing lots of fuss about it here. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 30. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: Cards with four digit PIN codes works just fine. Simply press enter after keying in the number, as usual. I have always used a 6-digit pin for my HK ATM card, but I do recall that it is possible to set a 4 or 5 digit PIN as well.

subject: 31. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: I recently used Australian debit card with 4 digit pin at HSBC ATM at the airport and it worked well. So I believe there will not be any issue using a credit cards with 4 digit pin. HSBC HK ATM charged me 3% currency conversion fee. However overall conversion rate (including conversion fee) was not bad bad compared to what I got from the money changers in Kowloon.

subject: 32. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: "HSBC HK ATM charged me 3% currency conversion fee." No it didn't. Your issuing bank may have done (or the Visa/Cirrus intermediary) but HK banks do not add any charges - they just send a bill for however many HKD you withdrew to your bank. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 33. Re: Hong Kong Queries

subject: 34. Re: Hong Kong Queries

subject: 38. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: HK banks do not levy withdrawal charges. It's your own bank that does it. Any HK bank ATM is fine to use. I would not use a credit card to withdraw cash. It is considered a cash advance, and credit card companies charge crazy interest rates.

subject: 39. Re: Hong Kong Queries
usertext: All banks are safe from ATM withdrawal charges. HK banks include: HSBC, Bank of China, Hang Seng Bank, Bank of East Asia, Standard Chrtered Bank, Citibank. But absolutely do NOT withdraw cash on a credit card unless it is your last resort. Use your normal bank ATM card (assuming it has a Plus/Cirrus (i.e. Vis/Mastercard) symbol on it). You may need to tell your bank that you will be travelling and set an overseas withdrawal limit.

subject: 1. Re: Should I rebook or cancel my trip to HK
usertext: {Should we just postpone our trip for next year? } Your choice. Saola is past us now and moving away from HK but the weather folks at the HK Observatory are suggesting the possibility of a lot of rain early next week and there is still another typhoon Haikui that is sort of in our region that could affect weather as well. None of this is life threatening for early next week but it isn't ideal for travel either. If you decide to postpone in favour of visiting during the dry and cool season, that means coming here from November to end of March. From April through October is when we have wet (rainy) months. You can learn all on this thread with resources about Hong Kong weather and climate https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14480965-Hong_Kong_Weather_Climate_2023-Hong_Kong.html As for low crowds at Disneyland? Don't visit the Park during public holidays or weekends for starters. There is rarely a time when there are actual low crowds but these are peak days where it is busier and more crowded than usual. If you can go during midweek during the cooler and dryer months of the year, that is what I would do.

subject: 2. Re: Should I rebook or cancel my trip to HK
usertext: Weather won't be entirely stable but it doesn't look too bad per the forecast. The effects of typhoon will mainly be over by the time of your arrival. March and April could be a more comfortable time to visit assuming you don't catch the extremely humid days when everything goes foggy. November is a great time with the only downside being the hazy skies.

subject: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: This is just an academic question. Assume that I had passports of two different countires. I used one of time to enter HK. When I left, would there be any problems if I used another passport to do the clearance? Just courious.

subject: 1. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: I don't think I would do that. Unless you have a very good reason. These days, we all leave our digital footprints whether we realize or not. You enter a country, passport scanned, ding you are in. If you use passport 2 to get out, your identity 1 has never left. meanwhile Identity 2 is leaving Hong Kong (but you have never "entered" Hong Kong in their system). You just created 2 problems: Identity 1 may have overstayed the 90 days or whatever duration he is allowed to, and will be flagged for future alerts. And Identity 2 had never entered Hong Kong properly (smuggled in?) and now is leaving. You just risk the chance of being invited to the "back room" for further questioning.

subject: 2. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: I just did my "thought experiment" a little further. With my example in reply #1: Upon you exiting Hong Kong using Identity 2... Hong Kong Immigration would not know what happened to Identity 1 (yet). So it will just be in their database with a possible violation of the terms/conditions for a visa-free-entry. But you, standing in front of an Immigration Officer, as Identity 2... they know this passport holder has not properly entered Hong Kong (no such a record). Maybe it's their machine malfunctioned, maybe the other Immigration workers entered the passport information incorrectly (but these days with digital scanning the chance of that is very low). So the third good possibility is that this individual, YOU who is standing in front of them, some how (they don't know how yet), has entered Hong Kong with an unknown entry date and now wants to exit. I think that very likely they will invite you to the back room and at least discuss about it and try to understand what may have happened. When did you get in, where did you get in, how did you get in, etc... If they are going to let you go, it may delay your plan of getting on your flight. And if during the conversation something slipped and you spilled the beans that you used Identity 1 to enter Hong Kong. Now they have the 2 ID's that they will link together. Maybe they won't legally pursue you. But they will for sure make notes of these kind of cases. Individuals have multiple identities (and then switching while they are travelling) are more likely regarded as No-Good than Good. Smugglers, drug-dealers, spies. I think you will really create a cloud over your eligibility for future visits. If you want to enter Hong Kong without using your real identity, do it right. Get a good fake passport and stick to using the same one for entry and exit. LOL

subject: 3. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: If they invited me into a black room for questioning, well, just tell them frankly my name was Bond, J. Bond. :-)

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: In addition to HappyFeet's advice, if you use a different passport to depart HK you won't be able to use the Smart Departure channel to pass through immigration on exit. Based on information collected on entry passport holders of 102 countries can use automatic gates to exit, avoiding the need to attend the manned immigration counters; https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/echannel_visitors.html#:~:text=%22Smart%20Departure%22%20for%20Departing%20Visitors,-Eligibility%20Criteria&text=A%20departing%20visitor%20is%20eligible,Aviation%20Organization%20(ICAO)%3B%20and Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: I wonder what will Larry experience if he uses Passport #2 go to through Smart Departure channel. Maybe it will immediately lock the turnstile and trigger a flashing orange light on top and sound the siren... or maybe nothing. Hey that maybe your chance.

subject: 6. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: {This is just an academic question.Assume that I had passports of two different countires. I used one of time to enter HK. When I left, would there be any problems if I used another passport to do the clearance? Just courious.} Short answer is a big 'Yes'. In fact, it simply won't work. Let's say you have a U.S.A. passport and Israel passport. You enter Hong Kong with your U.S.A. passport which is fine and dandy but then try to exit with your Israel passport, which will not show up on the system as having ever entered HK in the first place, it is going to trip the system and be flagged by Immigration. This could be an honest mistake that requires quick straightening out. There are plenty of dual citizens so perhaps an error on your part, simply provide your U.S.A. passport which you used to enter Hong Kong instead of your Israel passport. If immigration officer is nice and believes you just made a mistake, there is probably nothing to worry about and they will process your official exit out of Hong Kong. However, if they believe what you are doing is somehow nefarious or that you were trying to deceive immigration, like what HPFT described, you could be pulled aside and questioned as to why you tried to use a different national passport to exit HK compared to the one used to enter. Not something anyone in their right mind would want to experience for the sake of curiosity. In short, just don't do it! No benefit whatever, definitely some serious risks.

subject: 7. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: Thank you guys. Never though there would be such long replies. Please, don't take my question too seriously. I have no intention of trying it out. Perhaps, it may work in some banana republics.

subject: 8. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: Always use the same document to enter and exit a country. This is true of HK and elsewhere.

subject: 9. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: You should use the same passport to enter/exit HK. If you have a second passport, you can use it to leave your country of origin or enter your next destination as you see fit.

subject: 12. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: To me the question is not academic. I've asked the question to people in the know, i.e. immigration officials. The answer is simple: you must use the same passport entering and exiting Hong Kong. I didn't ask about consequences of trying to do differently but I'm guessing it'd have odd results. So use one passport for one border, another passport for another. Or, as I've routinely done, use my HKID card to exit Hong Kong, and my (foreign) passport with visa to enter mainland. That's how it's supposed to be done.

subject: 16. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: You would probably have used Smart Departure which has been in place since October 2017 for most nationalities including Philippines where you don't need to present yourself at a staffed immigration counter to depart. Instead, you simply scan your passport at immigration e-channel exit gates which automatically open, record your departure and allow you to exit into the secure areas and departure gates; https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/echannel_visitors.html#:~:text=%22Smart%20Departure%22%20for%20Departing%20Visitors,-Eligibility%20Criteria&text=A%20departing%20visitor%20is%20eligible,Aviation%20Organization%20(ICAO)%3B%20and

subject: 24. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: #22: From what you described, it seems you used Terminal 2 to check in your with your airline, and waited on the Terminal 2 side. I think that's why the security staff told you to "go the other way" (meaning to go through Immigration back in Terminal 1.) There was an immigration check too on the Terminal 2 side, just smaller. After immigration, you go to take the APM (Automated People Mover) to the gate to board your flight. But when you said: "after I checked in my luggage and returned my octopus card, I sat at the coffee shop and waited for boarding." That is really not possible. Checking in the luggage, and returning the Octopus Card are all done in the non-restricted area. You haven't gone through airport security and immigration check (departure) yet. You couldn't be possibly waiting to board the plane (not at the gate anyway), but maybe in some kind of seats in the non-restricted area. You still need to go through airport security check, and immigration (departure) before you can "board" the APM to reach your gate. Maybe it happened so fast that it was a blurr?

subject: 25. Re: Enter and exit HK using different passports
usertext: Yes, you are correct. It was done in the non-restricted area hence I was able to return my Octopus card. I was supposed to go to the immigration booth after I finished my coffee. I was waiting to board my plane at the coffee shop. That's when I realized that it was boarding time and we were rushing straight to the train and not the immigration counter. That's when the security personnel told me that we had to go to the other side, however, the security did not insist that we go that way hence we were able to get on the train straight to our gate. I don't remember going through immigration after we got off the train as well. I already requested a Statement of Travel Records but until I receive the copy, I will not dare to enter HK.

subject: 4. Re: hong kong trip in christmas day - 2 adults 1 kid
usertext: Ocean Park and the Big Buddha are in completely different areas of the city and not convenient to see both on the same day. Best to do Ocean Park (southern side of Hong Kong Island) one day and Big Buddha and Ngong Ping Cable Car (Lantau Island) on a separate day. Both will be open through the Christmas holiday. There will probably not be fireworks displays on Christmas day in the city. However, Disneyland usually holds nightly fireworks. There is a good chance they will do so on Christmas Day as well.

Do go for a stroll along the harbourfront in the evening, to see the decorations on the buildings along the harbour. That's usually pretty good. For places to eat, have a look at https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong Note that Western restaurants will be offering overpriced set meals in a crowded setting under strict time limits on Christmas. Chinese style restaurants are generally offering their normal fare.
