subject: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: Dear experts, Fully aware that my question has been many times asked and answered, but there few caveats that make me ask again. So appreciate your patience and knowledge! We're going to HK and trying to pack light of course. Which is tricky for a few reasons. First - end of October/ beginning of November HK weather may vary. Second - we're traveling for two weeks, so need enough clothes for whole period. Also - we're going to do sightseeing, park walks and evening restaurants meeting people (although not formal, but nice). So - need as many tips on what to pack - weather wise, time frame wise, and occasion/propriety wise. Would greatly appreciate any thoughts and recommendations. We are of 'elegant age' :) so term 'appropriate' is important for clothes and footwear.

subject: 1. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: I won't venture to tell you what exactly to pack. That is personal to how one feels and likes to dress based on temperatures and general weather. What I would say is to not worry too much about temperature range or weather differences. We don't have wild variances (cold in the morning, hot in the afternoon) like other places around the world. It can still a bit hot at the end of October during the middle of the day but leaning into November we start to have some of the best weather of the year with comfortable temperatures throughout the day and reduced chances of rain. When you research our local weather and climate resources, you will find that there is very little chance of cold days (we call cold anything under 12 C (53 F) until December. Also the extreme high temps 30C+ (86 F) will have passed by November. Basically you are looking at a temp likely to range between 17 to 27 (63-80 F). It is similar to weather in NYC around mid September. The rainy season will be coming to an end as well. Still ok chance for light rains the first couple weeks of November but not like what we have during the summer months at all. Typhoon season has basically passed as well. While theoretically it can happen, it is very rare by November. November is a big hiking month for us in Hong Kong for these reasons. The weather is pleasant, you can start early and enjoy cool temperatures and it doesn't really get proper hot anymore during the day so we are able to start doing the longer distance trails 6-10 hour hikes across our country parks. This might also help you to think about what sort of clothes you might want to bring at this time of year.

subject: 2. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: I would bring clothes that serves more than one purpose. For example, a shawl can serve many purposes, from a windbreaker to a light jacket. Also dress in layers, such as a short sleeve, a long sleeve, and a light jacket. You may be warm outside in the day time, but HK shopping malls and some restaurants notoriously turn their air conditioning very high, so you'll need a light jacket.

subject: 3. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: {but HK shopping malls and some restaurants notoriously turn their air conditioning very high, so you'll need a light jacket.} This is definitely a common practice during the hot summer months. I'm not sure how many malls, restaurants will still be running the A/C like this by the end of Oct and early November though.

subject: 4. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: Thank you all for a great points! To be a bit more specific - is it appropriate to wear capris and t-shirts to visit a temple? Do I need to pack a cocktail dress to go to dinner with friends, or light trousers and summer blouse should be ok? Again - not a formal event, but daily evening meal at some casual places. Day-to-evening clothes - does it work in HK? Or we shall be more particular? I definitely appreciate shawls advice - nice shawl may dress up a simple dress, and make a t-shirt look appropriate at the temple - am I wrong? How formal is HK?

subject: 5. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: HK is very informal. Unless you are invited to some high end functions, such as some movie star's birthday bash, you can pretty much wear anything (and people do). There is no dress code for temples.

subject: 6. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: Thank you very much!! It's really nice to know!

subject: 7. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: If you are from NY, you will likely find the weather at the end of October to the beginning of November very comfortable. You can probably go in shorts during the day if you want to stay comfortable. As to meeting others for drinks and dinners, it depends on who you are meeting and the places you will be visiting. Very few places have dress codes. In all likelihood, you can leave your cocktail dress at home unless you are going to a specific function that requires it. Do heed the suggestion to bring a windbreaker or something similar for indoors. MTR trains and stations aren't too cold though. I always wish there is a bit more air.

subject: 8. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: Thank you, Sammy - this is very helpful! New Yorkers are very tolerant and accepting of tourists, it's totally normal to see people in sporty attire in a theatre. But we also have tendency to assume that people in other countries have the same views. Thought I better check. So thank you for sharing! Now I'm getting an idea where to start with my packing.

subject: 9. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: Another thing, to reduce the quantity of clothing you need to bring: there are lots of inexpensive drop&pick type laundry services around town. Drop in the morning, pick up late afternoon or latest next day morning. Also do check the weather forecasts shortly before you leave at https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/index.html At the same site you can find climate information, to have an idea of what typical weather in that period would look like.

subject: 10. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: Oh, that's a great advice! Thank you - I had no idea about laundry optiongood to knowhow would I find such places?

subject: 11. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: Google maps shows the location of quite a few local laundry shops. Hotel front desks will be able to point them out to you as well.

subject: 12. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: Make sure your hotel isn't pointing you to a self-service laundry place. In all likelihood, you want a wash and fold type of place. In HK, a load shouldn't be too expensive relatively speaking.

subject: 13. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: Great advice, great people, thank you! Looking forward to my first Asia trip!

subject: 14. Re: Packing question with some caveat
usertext: When you know where exactly you're going to stay, you may also post the question here. Good chance one of the regulars knows some place in that area. Though hotel concierges should be able to help you, too. Part of their job.

subject: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: Will be staying in Royal Pacific Hotel for my coming trip to Hong Kong. Understand the hotel is near to Austin MTR station and Tsim Sha Tsui station. Would appreciate some advice which will be the most convenient way to travel to airport? Direct by taxi from hotel to airport? Or from Austin station to airport by Mtr & Airport express. Solo traveller with luggage. Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: Don't even think about using Austin MTR and the airport express! Just get the Airport Express to Kowloon Station and get a taxi (and vice versa), With easily manageable luggage, I would suggest the more scenic (and cheaper) option of the A21 CityFlyer bus to stop 13 (Kimberley Road, Nathan Road) and then a walk of about 400m through Kowloon Park. https://mobile.citybus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=A21&dsmode=1&l=1 Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: Most convenient would be to simply take a taxi (HK$230-240) all the way to the airport. A cheaper yet still fairly convenient alternative route unless you have multiple heavy luggage would be to take a taxi from the hotel to Kowloon Station (est HK$40) and to take Airport Express (HK$100) for the short 22 minute ride to the airport. Cheapest route still is to just take A21 airport bus (HK$34.60) to/trom the airport and Nathan Road about a 10 minute walk to/from the hotel.

subject: 3. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: Taking Airport Express to Kowloon Station and then a taxi to this hotel is a good balance for speed and price. For this hotel I would advise against take airport bus A21. The reason is you have a relatively long walk with luggage, along the often very crowded Haiphong Road and Canton Road (but it depends on the time of day). Though the distance is not too far, about 700m to 800m, if you walk through this during late afternoon early evening, it will feel like a salmon swimming up-river with your luggage. And you are just off the plane perhaps from a long flight, with jet lag, and may easily lose orientation in a foreign city. Taxi (from the Kowloon Station) will take you straight to the hotel front door. Only if you want the most economical way as priority would I advise this route.

subject: 4. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: "The reason is you have a relatively long walk with luggage, along the often very crowded Haiphong Road and Canton Road (but it depends on the time of day). Though the distance is not too far, about 700m to 800m" Sorry, but this is just a daft route - you can walk almost directly across Kowloon Park from the bus stop (#13) to the hotel: about 400m.

subject: 5. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: "Daft": adjective, INFORMALBRITISH, silly; foolish. We can all agree or disagree on forum discussions. But you should give other posters some respects. 400 meters. 1312 feet. You conveniently omitted that it is a straight-line distance between the #13 bus stop "Kimberley Road" and the Royal Pacific Hotel. Just measure it on Google Map. When we walk on streets, we don't have a jetpack on our back to fly in the air along a straight line. You need to cross the busy Nathan Road at specific junctions, walk up the steps (oh yeah, with your 4-wheel suitcase, may be two) and meander through the criss-crossing walkpaths inside the park, (hopefully you can use your cell phone's GPS and map to guide you right?), avoiding the all the manmade short walls and obstacles and what have you. Oh, don't miss the walkpath that takes you to the one and only elevated pedestrian walkway to go above Canton Road to the Royal Pacific Hotel Tower. Or else you will need to circle back. Oh yeah, once you get to the Royal Pacific Hotel building, find the way down to the hotel main lobby, that's right. That kind of 400 meters. All just off the plane perhaps from a long flight, with jet lag, and may easily lose orientation in a foreign city.

subject: 6. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: The OP is asking about transportation to the airport from the hotel not the other way around. If they have stayed in HK at least a couple days, they will have opportunity to walk through the park during that time and familiarise themselves with the route over to Nathan Road where they will find the A21 pick-up point. However, for arriving in HK and travel down to the hotel, if this is the OP's first trip to HK, walking through Kowloon Park to get to the Royal Pacific may not be a great idea. Really depends on how experienced the traveller is and how comfortable they generally are navigating their way around city streets (and parks). Can you imagine them getting stuck in the maze near Nathan Park and with luggage? Aiya! Flight time and travel fatigue can play a big factor as well. For most convenient transport from the airport to the hotel for someone not familiar with TST, I would just stick with taxi all the way to the hotel or take AE to Kowloon Station & taxi over to the hotel from there. Get your bearings for the TST area first, then consider walking through Kowloon Park and using the A21 on Nathan Road for lower cost transportation back out to the airport. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: For a party of two, a good solution on balance is to use a taxi to Kowloon station + Airport Express. AE offers a group discount so you pay $150 for two. That means the total trip cost with the taxi fare should be roughly $200. For a party of 3-4, just take a taxi all the way to the airport. It probably costs around $300. Staying at Royal Pacific with large bags, I don't recommend using the A buses at Nathan Road. Canton Road and Haiphong Road are always crowded. It will feel tortuous to navigate with big bags for that sort of distance. I also don't recommend going through Kowloon Park. There are a few steps to cross the bridge to the park to start. Then as far as I know, any exit facing Nathan Road has quite a few steps as well. It's not a good idea with luggage. You might also get lost easily.

subject: 8. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: In the days of Google maps, I find it really inconceivable that people can get lost in urban areas (except in very dense high-rise buildings where GPS because erratic).

subject: 9. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: Thank you so much for all your kind advice and helpful information. I will either take a taxi direct from hotel to airport or taxi+airport express on day of departure. Looking forward to visit HK tomorrow.

subject: 10. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: This doesn't change the fact that this "400 meters" distance is "looking good on paper" and not a reality, and that it is much more efforts to navigate for a first time visitor to Hong Kong (i.e. not a local resident). Not to mention that the assumption of all travelers will buy a local SIM card first thing stepping out of a plane, or are willing to pay for cell phone roaming charges when touring in a foreign country, or have prepared in advance to download offline maps on a cell phone is just too much. In addition to the possibility that this traveler's arriving time could be in the evening where the park is so dark to walk through. Just a broad stroke attack on other posters' ideas as silly and foolish shows how much considerations you have put in when composing an advice to visitors.

subject: 11. Re: From Royal Pacific Hotel & Tower to Airport
usertext: While I don't disagree overall for walking on the streets, trying to follow directions walking through Kowloon Park is another matter. Again, entering and exiting Kowloon Park and even just navigating through it, one will most likely run into steps at some point so it's not for anyone with luggage. >>>In the days of Google maps, I find it really inconceivable that people can get lost in urban areas (except in very dense high-rise buildings where GPS because erratic).

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 36hrs before cruise
usertext: Hi. I have 36hours before taking a cruise from kai kak terminal. Can anyone recommend a hotel which is a good location for transport from airport to hotel and hotel to terminal using public transport? I'm looking at kerry, millenium, harbour grand kowloon, icon etc. Budget for one night 3500hk preferably with club lounge Tia

subject: 1. Re: 36hrs before cruise
usertext: Hotels in TST area would seem best for your one night stay. Harbour Grand View and Kerry are both near Hung Hom, too far away for useful MTR Stations and sightseeing in the TST district for my liking. Millenium and ICON are nearer to the TST promenade & TST East MTR entrances so they aren't bad. ICON is a chic property and I like their rooms. They nice high floor club lounge as well. There outdoor pool is really nice, great views of the harbour as well. You will find public airport bus A21 that has drop off at Granville Road & Chatham Road around 500 metre walk over to Millenium and ICON properties. It is fairly straightforward and easy to navigate using Google Maps. However, if you have sizeable luggage, I might suggest instead taking Airport Express from the airport to Kowloon Station and from there taking a taxi over to the hotel. This would be most convenient way to the hotel if you don't want to take a taxi directly from the airport all the way to the hotel. Unfortunately, public transportation over to Kai Tak Cruise Terminal (KTCT) isn't convenient and requires MTR and/or bus changes. It can be a challenge with luggage as well. Best to just grab a taxi from the hotel. It is around 15 minute ride.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

subject: singapore to Hong Kong/Macau
usertext: Hi.. planing my trip to hongkong and Macau. anyone can advise: 1. SIN - Hong Kong then to Macau - SIN? 2. SIN - Macau - Hong kong-SIN? 3. SIN - Hong Kong - Macau back to HK -SIN?

subject: 2. Re: singapore to Hong Kong/Macau
usertext: You may want to familiarise yourself with transportation between Hong Kong and Macau as well. This might influence how you want to organise your flights from Singapore. Here is a resource thread with that information. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html In particular look at the HZM Bridge that provides land crossing between HK <> Macau. The Hong Kong end of the bridge is right next to HKG Airport which makes it convenient for people to fly to HK and go directly to Macau as well as those staying in Macau to go straight to HKG airport for outbound flights back home.

subject: 3. Re: singapore to Hong Kong/Macau
usertext: In general it'll be easiest and cheapest to have a return ticket - i.e. SIN - Hong Kong - SIN or SIN - Macau - SIN. Whatever works best for you. Transport between the cities is easy, albeit a bit time consuming.

subject: 4. Re: singapore to Hong Kong/Macau
usertext: Agree. Nevertheless, you can always take a coach crossing over in every 30 mins intervals

subject: 5. Re: singapore to Hong Kong/Macau
usertext: Jimi L, The Golden Shuttle that crosses the HZM Bridge departs every 15-30 minutes during the middle of the night. During the rest of the day, minimum departure time is every 15 minutes or as soon as a shuttle can be filled with passengers, which is usually every 3-5 minutes during much of the day.

subject: Octopus card app for tourist
usertext: Anyone use this app before? How is the exchange rate for the reload? Any hidden charges upon asking for refund?

subject: 1. Re: Octopus card app for tourist
usertext: See the Octopus 'Set up your Octopus in just a few steps' section of the webpage for the Octopus Tourist App. It will help explain how the mobile app works. https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/tourist/apple-pay/index.html {How is the exchange rate for the reload?} Determined by your bank. Reload is just like making a local purchase in HKD using your foreign credit card. The exchange rate is set and applied by your bank back home. {Any hidden charges upon asking for refund?} Review the how to seek refund part of the shared link above. It is a simple two step process and any unused balance is fully refunded back to the credit or debit card selected from your iPhone or Applewatch to top up your Octopus.

subject: One day in Hongkong

usertext: Just to clarify some points made by reply #2: "Our cruise company arranged shuttle buses from the port into the city area. From here we walked to the ferry terminal and bought HoHo tickets to use on the other island.., Kowloon ???" You probably took the shuttle to Tsim Sha Tsui (part of Kowloon, a peninsula). the island would be Hong Kong Island. "One of the stops was the cable car? Funicular ? Which would have been good if it hadn't been foggy" That would be the Peak Tram. Sorry it was foggy, but if not, you get an iconic view of HK Island. For roast goose, Kam's, Yat Lok, or Yung Kee.

subject: 5. Re: One day in Hongkong
usertext: >>> Our cruise company arranged shuttle buses Don't miss the subtlety here! Those shuttles are indeed often arranged by the cruise company, so whether they're available or not depends on the cruise company. If available, great. There are also public buses running from the cruise terminal to get you to other parts in town. Another good option. Buses I believe nowadays accept contactless credit cards for payment, that saves the hassle of getting exact cash to pay (no change given for cash payments). Taxis are generally in seriously short supply at Kai Tak. A long standing (since opening) and as yet unsolved problem. Taxis are cash only in Hong Kong, no credit cards.

subject: 6. Re: One day in Hongkong

subject: 14. Re: hong kong or singapore cheaper
usertext: Thanks to all those mainland shoppers, luxury brand items in Hong Kong actually tend to be significantly more expensive than in Europe. The idea that Hong Kong is a shopper's paradise is very outdated, by a few decades or so.

subject: 15. Re: hong kong or singapore cheaper
usertext: As far as I know, European luxury brands have always been more expensive in HK vs Europe. That was true even 20 years ago before the mainland folks flooded the HK shops. Of course, their presence probably helped drive up prices in the long run. We (local HK'ers) make up only a small percentage of their purchases these days. Now that Covid is over, another interesting phenomenon is the resurrection of the various pharmacies catering to mainlanders. During the peak of Covid, most of them went out of business. The few remaining ones barely had any customers. Once the border opened, the pharmacies are opening everywhere again. There are probably 15 new shops within a 5-minute walking radius of my office. For the more legitimate ones, even their product mix changed. During Covid, they sold more day-to-day items catering more to locals. Now, a lot of those products are no longer available. The shelf space is now stocked with what the mainland Chinese want to buy.

subject: Hongkong travel between sep 30- oct 6
usertext: Hi I will be visiting hongkong with family (4 adults 2 kids). Our main purpose is Disneyland and Ocean park for the kids. And a bit of shopping too. Is it the right time to travel considering we have already booked the flight and hotels and there is no better time for us to travel . We are worried about the crowd since it's the golden week

subject: 1. Re: Hongkong travel between sep 30- oct 6
usertext: Golden Weeks have been less and less of an issue before covid already, and tourism still hasn't recovered (if the number of posts on this forum is anything to go by, it's very far from full recovery, as the volume of posts is maybe a third of what it was a few years ago). So I wouldn't be too worried. Of course do avoid the holidays (30/9, 1/10 and 2/10) for visits to those theme parks. Those days will be extra crowded. 3-6 Oct shouldn't be too bad.

subject: 2. Re: Hongkong travel between sep 30- oct 6
usertext: Historically Golden Week has been a Peak travel time for Hong Kong. This has particularly been felt in the form of much higher than usual hotel rates, longer queues for crossing the border to mainland and travel to Macau as well as more crowds at Disneyland, Ocean Park, Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car and Big Buddha, The Peak Tram, Star Ferry and handful of other main attractions. How bad will be the crowds be? It is a bit difficult to judge as the city has been on lockdown or dealing with other matters (2019) for several years in a row so this is the first normal 'Golden Week' we've had in 5 years. Could be pent up demand from mainland visitors that will result in serious crowds this year. For sightseeing venues mentioned above during our Peak travel times, the key is to get there early. Mainland Chinese tourists usually come in the form of tour groups. They can only travel as fast as their slowest participate. So, if you get to the Parks before opening time, you can usually go straight in when they open the gates and enjoy yourself nearly crowd free for an hour or so and with not so bad crowds for another couple of hours. This gives you a few hours of good sightseeing conditions before crowds get bad. Try to show up at noon to enter Disney or Ocean Park, you may face a long queue to get in and very crowded conditions once inside. Similarly, show up at the Lower Peak Tram station or Ngong Ping 360 cable car station first thing in the morning, and you won't likely wait in queue at all or just a short minimum wait. Try to go around midday, expect a long queue and bring a hat or umbrella to block the sun while you wait.

subject: 3. Re: Hongkong travel between sep 30- oct 6
usertext: Since everything is booked, it may be too much to lose to cancel. I would say not worry too much. While the Golden Week has been the busiest time people travel in China and some go to Hong Kong. But that was the Golden Week in the "Golden Days (or Golden Weeks)". With Covid, a lot of things in China came to a halt. And things are just trying to recover. Right now what's facing that nation is to get a job (again) for the younger generation, and the real rea-estate crisis which had been brewing for some time. People are facing the probable possibility that they will lose most of their savings, having bought their future home on a piece of paper with all their savings but the bubble has burst. That affects their travel and spending habits. At least the degree of "crowdedness" would be less than what it has been.

subject: 4. Re: Hongkong travel between sep 30- oct 6
usertext: For the popular places Brad mentioned in #2, show up *before* it officially opens. By lining up 15 minutes early, you might end up saving an hour. For Ocean Park, once you get in, take the cable car to the upper section to start. The line forms in a hurry and the wait could be brutal on the wrong day.

subject: 5. Re: Hongkong travel between sep 30- oct 6
usertext: Thank you . Feeling a bit relieved .

subject: Side trip to Yangshuo
usertext: Hi all Considering breaking up our HK stay with a 3/4 night trip to Yangshuo. I see that it's now possible to take a high speed train from Kowloon to Guilin. Has anyone done this recently, and if so, what was the experience like? Any pointers? Hope to be travelling end March/ early April 2024. Thanks in advance :-)

subject: 1. Re: Side trip to Yangshuo
usertext: Make sure you have your China visa arranged before taking that trip. For the trip itself, I've never gotten a chance (or a reason) to use the high speed train but I'm expecting it to be as simple as going to the station, buying a ticket (or booking in advance of course), clearing immigration (HK and mainland immigration are both in West Kowloon station), and getting on the train.

subject: 2. Re: Side trip to Yangshuo
usertext: Sorry, forgot to ask which online ticketing platform is the best to use to purchase tickets in advance?

subject: 3. Re: Side trip to Yangshuo
usertext: The official 12306.cn site is workable for foreigners now but trip.com is a little more user friendly.

subject: 4. Re: Side trip to Yangshuo
usertext: With this kind of long-distance journey, I would not just show up at the train station without booking the tickets in advance. Too much effort at stake that you may not be able to board the train at the time you want to. http://www.trip.com is my go-to site for bookings of hotels and train tickets in China. I like their interface, easy to use, and is designed well as an "English" site. This is a sample train ticket schedule-check and price quotes, Hong Kong to Yangshou: Link (original URL): https://us.trip.com/trains/china/list?departureStation=%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E8%A5%BF%E4%B9%9D%E9%BE%99&arrivalStation=%E9%98%B3%E6%9C%94&displayDepartureStation=Hong%20Kong%20West%20Kowloon%20(%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF%E8%A5%BF%E4%B9%9D%E9%BE%99)&displayArrivalStation=Yangshuo%20(%E9%98%B3%E6%9C%94)&departDate=2023-09-18&returnDate=&curr=USD Link (same URL, shortened, clickable): https://tinyurl.com/u9u6vb9t I don't believe they offer a direct route from Hong Kong (West Kowloon) to Yangshou. I don't think they have enough demand. All the train connection arrangements are via Guangzhou South, and with a few hours to wait in between. Thus it makes almost a full day's activity just to take transportation there. Keep that in mind.

subject: 5. Re: Side trip to Yangshuo
usertext: Thanks so much. I've read that there's a direct train Kowloon to Guilin and see it on the Trip.com site. Do tickets only go on sale 15 days before the time?

subject: 6. Re: Side trip to Yangshuo
usertext: RE: "Do tickets only go on sale 15 days before the time?" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = It sounds about right. I am not sure if each route-pair (departure/destination) has the same booking time window. When you use trip.com to examine the train schedule/price, when you pick the Departure date on a calendar for that route they will tell you. Dates with the little clock icon below the date means you need to wait (not available yet). They will rotate on a daily basis.

subject: 7. Re: Side trip to Yangshuo
usertext: Thanks so much!

subject: 8. Re: Side trip to Yangshuo
usertext: There are direct high speed trains direct to Guilin West Station from Hong Kong; and from there you could take a high speed train to Yangshuo (about 30 minutes). However, the Yangshuo train station is not in Yangshuo, but closer to Xingping, about 25 km from Yangshuo, an interesting village and from it a short walk to see the inspiration for the scene on the 20 yuan bill. You might though see about spending one night in Guilin then taking one of the Li River morning boats to Yangshuo (about a 5 hour trip). While in Yangshuo do take a bamboo (man powered) raft down the Yulong River and if looking for some night entertainment, go to the Impression Sanjie Liu sound and light show played on and around where the Li and Yulong rivers meet.

subject: 9. Re: Side trip to Yangshuo
usertext: Thanks John!

subject: Hong Kong in late February: tips on climate and length of st
usertext: Good morning everyone, I am tickled by the idea of taking a trip to Hong kong in late february, I have a few questions: is the season good? from what I see it should not rain much and the daytime temperatures seem to be pleasant even in pants and short sleeves. How many days to stay? I was thinking of 3 full days to see: Central area, Victoria Peak, go up to Sky 100 platform, go up to Tian Tan by cable car and Po Lin monastery, Quarry bay area, a typical fishing village, I was thinking of Aberdeen because much more convenient than the more famous Tai O then if time remains go to the 10,000 buddah monastery. Many people tell me that especially for Victoria Peak and Tian Tan you have to budget for long waits in line. I am undecided whether to do the day tour in Macau, in which case I would add a fourth day. Thanks to all

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong in late February: tips on climate and length of st
usertext: Aberdeen is a high rise residential area like most of HK. There are of course lots of boats in the harbour, and especially across the water in Ap Lei Chau quite a few shops catering to boats, selling things like anchors, ropes, bouys, etc. Also still a number of shipwharfs. But all in all not exactly a fishing village, like e.g. Tap Mun or Ko Lau Wan. That kind of places still see at least some traditional fishing.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong in late February: tips on climate and length of st
usertext: {is the season good? } Personally, I love the weather here in Feb. This is the time of year where locals can spend many, many hours outside without having to deal with the heat, humidity and rains that frequent the city in the warm summer months. Temps can dip below 12 but it isn't common, avg around 15-18 (low - high) for the month. There is zero risk of typhoons in Feb also. https://www.hko.gov.hk/en/cis/climahk.htm {How many days to stay?} Somewhat depends on where you are flying from and how much time it will take you to recover from jetlag. Given the list of things you've mentioned being interested in seeing, I'd say you are looking at a busy and full 3 days or a bit more relaxed 4 days when you build in meals and transportation with this list of interests. {I am undecided whether to do the day tour in Macau, in which case I would add a fourth day.} I don't usually recommend Macau day trips until people have been here at least 4 days. There is quality sightseeing that can quickly fill up a week in HK without having to deal with the quite a bit of travel time to/from Macau when you add it up. However, Macau is a very interesting and fun place to spend time having a bridge with 24 hour shuttle service between the two cities, makes it pretty easy and convenient to do so for those interested.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong in late February: tips on climate and length of st
usertext: Late February is one of the best times to come. The weather is usually cool (relatively speaking) and dry. Chinese New Year crowds will be gone so for most destinations, you shouldn't see any crazy waits.

subject: Hongkong Airport to Macau
usertext: My Hong Kong visa hasn't been approved yet. I am an Indian citizen. I am planning to visit Macau. Can I go through skypier terminal to macau and get back to airport through same terminal without immigration. While departing from Macau do they check for Hong Kong visa.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Hongkong Airport to Macau
usertext: I don't believe this is a viable option. The HK Immigration Dept FAQ2 appears to indicate that you require Pre-Arrival Registration (PAR) since PAR exemption is only for travellers in direct transit by air (see FAQ2) whereas this a sea transit although you could always ask the Immigration for confirmation; https://webapp.es2.immd.gov.hk/applies2-client/static/faq/i-par-reg/en-US/i-par-reg-faq.html Re your query as to whether you can get back from Macau to the airport via SkyPier, you cannot enter HK via this route which is for transit passengers only, regardless of whether you have a visa. However, in any event, there are currently only two each way sailings per week between HKIA and Macau, on Friday and Sunday with TurboJET; https://www.turbojet.com.hk/en/whats-new/airport-route-resumption.aspx Cotai Water Jet services between HKIA and Macau remain suspended.; https://www.cotaiwaterjet.com/ferry-schedule/hongkong-macau-taipa.html Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Hongkong Airport to Macau
usertext: You can use Skypier - then you bypass Hong Kong immigration - to go to Macau and from Macau back to HKIA. Note that there is currently only three departures weekly, at 12:45 on Tuesday Wednesday and Friday to Macau (Taipa). Details: https://www.turbojet.com.hk/en/routing-sailing-schedule/hk-airport-macau/sailing-schedule-fares.aspx From Macau you can do the same, the ferry departs at 11:00 (same three days a week). There used to be a list of participating airlines for travelling to HKIA, but I can't find this any more. Macau immigration will not check whether you have the paperwork to enter Hong Kong when you exit Macau. Your airline however may not allow you to board your plane if you can not show a Hong Kong visa or PAR, or onward ticket (though I expect that having a hotel booking in Macau and reasonable connection to that ferry would be enough - ask your airline about this).

subject: 3. Re: Hongkong Airport to Macau
usertext: >>> However, in any event, there are currently only two each way sailings per week between HKIA and Macau, on Friday and Sunday with TurboJET; Apparently that changed, as the schedule page on their web site lists three sailings weekly. Still very few.

subject: 4. Re: Hongkong Airport to Macau
usertext: SkyPier ferry from HKG to Macau without PAR. There is an old discussion on the Macau forum back when there was regular ferry service between Macau and SkyPier where several Indian Nationals confirmed being able to use the ferry from HKG SkyPier to go direct to Macau without having PAR as long passenger was using participating airline for this service. https://www.tripadvisor.in/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k10130203-o10-Immigration_rules_for_Indian_Nationals_Jan_2017-Macau.html https://www.tripadvisor.in/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k10060549-o610-Pre_arrival_Registration_for_Indian_Nationals-Hong_Kong.html#83049315 The problem is that they have all but abandoned the ferry service from SkyPier to/from Macau and the old list of participating airlines has been missing from the HKG website for at least a couple years now. In short, too many unknowns to consider this a viable form of transportation any longer. Naveen, Very little in the form of encouraging suggestions for you unfortunately. Did you book cancellable flights for your October trip to Hong Kong? If you need to travel in the near future, rebooking flights directly to Macau may be your best option. This is what another Indian National poster has had to do just earlier this week (see discussion). https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14523363-Macao_to_HK_Airport_Terminal_via_Direct_Bus-Macau.html

subject: 6. Re: Hongkong Airport to Macau
usertext: My HongKong visa is rejected and I had mailed them with additional documents for reconsideration. I am not very hopeful of getting my visa approved with Oct 19 where my travel dates fall. The only best thing is I have turbojet sailing on both days of arrival and departure. I had mailed immigration department for transiting to macau hoping for a positive reply. Thanks all for your time in responding my query. Will let you know if I get reply.

usertext: Hye Naveen, could you do it ? I also want to do the same . Please let me know if you faced any Problem at Delhi airport.

subject: Ngong Ping in January
usertext: Dear All, I'm currently planning my trip to Asia and were thinking of going to Ngong Ping. 1. Will it be ok in January? Not cold and foggy? 2. Should I purchase tickets beforehand? 3. I'm overweight but used to walk on plain ground, but I'm a little bit concerned if the steps to Big Buddha will be to much for me? TIA

subject: 1. Re: Ngong Ping in January
usertext: 1. Could be cold, could be foggy, but not too likely. Most of the time it's around 15-20 C and good chance of sunny weather in that time of the year. 2. Generally not needed to buy tickets in advance. Do avoid weekends and holidays, as then it's extra busy. 3. If so, just don't go up the steps. I can't say if it'll be too much for you or not.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Ngong Ping in January
usertext: Re question 3, there are places on the way up where you can pause, without getting in other people's way. to see how you feel. But it is a long haul. So if you have any doubts better to give it a miss methinks.

subject: 3. Re: Ngong Ping in January
usertext: The stairs aren't narrow so you can easily rest when you go up to the Buddha. Obviously, we don't know you so we can't judge your physical condition. Just go up slowly at your own pace if necessary.

subject: 4. Re: Ngong Ping in January
usertext: The stairs going up to the Big Buddha Statue looks like this: Link: https://www.alamy.com/hong-kong-china-04-may-2018-staircase-pathway-to-tian-tan-buddha-statue-in-ngong-ping-hong-kong-china-image447954179.html It is not straight up, but a bit of a Serpentine pattern like a snake. After every 12 steps or so there is a flat landing where one can rest. Maybe you can climb up along the side and hold on to the handrail while resting. Go up at your own pace.

subject: Walking distance to Dim Sum
usertext: Hi, we have a 4 day stopover to revisit , this time staying on the island near Kennedy town at 181 hotel connaught road, On our last trip we discovered a very authentic place in Kowloon called the London restaurant on Nathan road Mong Kok. Am I likely to find something similar close to our hotel ? hopefully just a walk away . Otherwise we can jump on the MTR. Anything except high end , we do have a budget limit. Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Walking distance to Dim Sum
usertext: You can't help but bum into a dim sum restaurant in HK, just about everywhere. In Kennedy Town, there are at least 5 or 6 dim sum restaurants, all of them authentic. Victoria Harbour seems like one that's similar to the London.

subject: 2. Re: Walking distance to Dim Sum
usertext: You can try the Openrice website. Just enter Dim Sum, Kennedy Town and the search results will reveal more than a few options. https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/restaurants?whatwhere=dim%20sum,%20kennedy%20town&tabIndex=0

subject: 3. Re: Walking distance to Dim Sum
usertext: The likes of London Restaurant are considered proper Chinese restaurants. You find these everywhere. You will find similar places everywhere in HK. These days, there are many smaller eateries that focus on dim sum only from morning to night. These are very easy to find as well. Note that in HK, just about all dim sum places are "authentic." There are of course good dim sum and bad dim sum but that's subject to personal tastes. The newer style small dim sum eateries don't have the same traditional feel but their food can still be good.

subject: 4. Re: Walking distance to Dim Sum
usertext: Kennedy Town couldn't be more old-school Hong Kong. You can't find more "authentic" Hong Kong dim sum than that. In general just about anywhere you eat in Hong Kong, food is authentic. Local restaurants don't rely on tourist patrons. It's more a matter of not-so-good ones, good ones (generally), and really-good ones. Out of the list that Hong Kong Destination Expert Brad provided, it looks to me that: Sun Hing Restaurant  seems to be a hole-in-the wall dim-sum specialty shop. Their dim sum pictures look pretty good to me. Link1: https://maps.app.goo.gl/QhtVWAaUkWt39Fgr6 Link2: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/r-sun-hing-restaurant-western-district-guangdong-dim-sum-r125594 It is about half a mile from your hotel. Not sure if you consider it too far to walk. Don't need subway (MTR). If you don't want to walk, hop on a ding-ding tram west-bound (to Kennedy Town) for just a couple of stops.

subject: Firework in NYE Hongkong 2024
usertext: Hi, anyone experience firework for NYE in HK before? I'm planning to watch firework for NYE in HK this year but still have some confusion 1/ Where is the best place to watch firework because no any articles mention about this one (maybe it's too soon?) 2/ Is it difficult to take train/bus to hotel in NYE night? Or should I book hotel near harbour (incase firework will be watched at the harbour) 3/ Anyone travel to in NYE this year and join watching together? 4/ Everything will still be opened on 1st 2nd after NYE? Thank you so much!

subject: 1. Re: Firework in NYE Hongkong 2024
usertext: Fireworks are best watched from either side of the harbour - Tsim Sha Tsui on the Kowloon side, and Tamar and Central waterfront at the Hong Kong side. The MTR is likely to run longer than usual hours, and there are always night bus services. Those are likely enhanced, too. Note that bus routes may be truncated, as places like the Star Ferry Pier bus terminus are often closed for vehicles. So a little more walk. There are tens of thousands of others that want to go home in the middle of the night so there will be plenty of transport available. If your hotel is more than walking distance from where you go watch the fireworks, you best ask the concierge for details on transport arrangements and how to get back to your hotel late at night. They'll be able to give you detailed and up to date information. 1 Jan is just a normal holiday, not much special about it. Everything is open. This in stark contrast with the first day of the Chinese New Year! Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Firework in NYE Hongkong 2024
usertext: The NYE fireworks have improved over the years, but indeed, it's nowhere near the National Day or CNY ones.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Entering procedure at Hong Kong Airport
usertext: What is the procedure now for entering Hong Kong for a few days as a British tourist. I have a UK passport. Is a Visa required? Is a Covid test done? Immigration and customs procedure. Not been long hall for a while so a bit out of touch. Thank you

subject: 1. Re: Entering procedure at Hong Kong Airport
usertext: British passport with at least 6 month validity can enter HK without visa, stay up to 90 days. COVID test no longer needed. Immigration and customs procedure, pretty much like most other airports. Get off plane, follow sign to immigration, line up and present your passport to an immigration officer. Then get your luggage, walk through the green cusoms line (nothing to declare), and out to the arrival hall.

subject: 2. Re: Entering procedure at Hong Kong Airport
usertext: Actually, UK citizens normally get a visa-free stay of 180 days.

subject: 3. Re: Entering procedure at Hong Kong Airport
usertext: "British passport with at least 6 month validity can enter HK without visa, stay up to 90 days." Not correct - British Citizens may visit for up to 180 days visa-free. The passport must be valid for at least one month beyond the intended period of stay. https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/visas/visit-transit/visit-visa-entry-permit.html https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/plan/traveller-info/immigrations-and-customs.html

subject: 4. Re: Entering procedure at Hong Kong Airport
usertext: It is a very smooth process arriving into HKG airport as well. Everything works quite efficiently, calmly, good signage everywhere, clearing immigration & customs usually takes but a handful of minutes. Good transport to the city as well. Let the forum know i you need suggestions for how to go from the airport to your hotel.

subject: Using buses and trams
usertext: Going to be in HK and then Singapore and getting a little confused about different arrangements for buses and trams. Re HK, can you confirm please that: 1. you get on a bus at the front and tap in with Octopus Card but don't tap off when getting off at the back of the bus 2. you get on a tram at the back and don't tap in and get off the tram at the front and do tap 'out' Thanks in advance for your help

subject: 1. Re: Using buses and trams
usertext: Yes, your summary is correct. The exit door on buses is in the middle, not at the back. In both case you may also tap a contactless credit-card instead of an Octopus card. Currently, as a promotion, if you do that on the tram with a Visa card (only) you pay $2 instead the normal $3. (Note for pedants/completeness: yes, there are also a very few bus routes with "section fares" where you may get a refund of part of the fare when alighting at certain stops by tapping out as well, but tourists should not concern themselves about this.)

subject: 2. Re: Using buses and trams
usertext: Yes you are correct :) just follow what other locals do and you will be fine. And when you don't have to pay (on your way out or in), we don't usually put a machine there. So you will be fine :)

subject: 9. Re: Using buses and trams
usertext: >> Logically, I don't see how the MTR can accept credit card payments. It's not a one time charge. They can try the same way the Dutch public transport services currently accept regular ATM cards and I believe even credit cards (though not many people have a credit card, and even fewer actually use them). You simply use the same card to check in and out of buses, trams, trains, or metros. Works wonders. So it's perfectly possible. One problem remains: travellers with children will need a sufficient number of credit and debit cards... as it's still one person per card.

subject: 10. Re: Using buses and trams
usertext: There's absolutely no problem using credit cards with a turnstyle in-and-out transit system. London among many other places uses this system. You simply have to make sure you swipe in and out with the same card, or you'll be charged for two maximum-value trips.

Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 16. Re: Using buses and trams
usertext: It does get a bit more complicated when you have both an Octopus and a contactless credit card in your wallet. Which one gets read and charged?

subject: 17. Re: Using buses and trams
usertext: RE: "when you have both an Octopus and a contactless credit card in your wallet. Which one gets read and charged?" They will charge both!!! LOL @TSS: #7 "The charge depends on distance traveled, thus tagging on both entry and exit. I don't see how it would work with a credit card." I think the programming can support it (using credit card). Restaurants do it all the time. When you have a meal, they ring your credit card with the "service rendered" amount (bill total plus tax but before tips) initially. The amount is marked as tentative. Depending on the restaurant, they may buffer it with 20% to 30% as the amount charged. Then you sign the bill, and add the tips. The restaurant will revise it accordingly as the finalized amount before settling with the credit card company. MTR can access a maximum fare initially on your credit card (e.g. treat it as if you are riding to Lo Wu, maximum fare). This amount is tentative. When you exit your MTR ride with your credit card, then the fare amount is finalized and settled with the credit card company. If there is a "no show" (no exit record from that credit card for that day), then the maximum fare will be accessed. Of course the actual programming is probably more sophisticated than that, like how to deal with cases where the same rider Enter, but the Exit was not sensed (while he did wave his CC), and then he rides again with the same CC to Enter. Do you deny him? Or close the last one with Max and let him ride the second time? And then, of course, we will have some family who have 6 kids riding together with the parents... How can MTR expect us to have 8 different credit cards to ride, one card per individual??? They are just kids!!! Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 18. Re: Using buses and trams
usertext: HappyFeet, what you said confirms what I think. This whole scheme is just overly complicated. Since 100% of HK residents have at least one Octopus card, why would anyone use a credit card? Now, if they allow the use of credit cards to top up my Octopus card, that's a different issue.

subject: 19. Re: Using buses and trams
usertext: Nothing complicated about it. They have these things called computers that do the calculations. But you do have to make sure there's no card clash if you have different cards in your wallet, usually by taking out the one you're going to use. MTR may reduce this problem somewhat by using different readers for Octopus and credit cards. Will have to see. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 20. Re: Using buses and trams
usertext: The card readers on the buses and the tram for Octopus and for credit cards are separate (with a third reader on buses for QR codes on mobile screens); I'm pretty sure they will be on the MTR too.

subject: 21. Re: Using buses and trams
usertext: But if you've got more than one credit card in your wallet you still have to take it out to avoid card clash.

usertext: Hello, Is it only at Lo Wu Control Point you can get Shenzhen 5 day visa on arrival? Can you get it at Lok Ma Chau Control Point? We'll be travelling from Yuen Long and there'll be 4 of us altogether, is it possible to get a taxi to Lo Wu Control Point? Thank you!

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: HK-Shenzhen
usertext: As far as I am aware, in addition to Luohu control point ( connected to Lo Wu MTR station on the HK side of the border), the visa on arrival is available at Huanggang control point, connected to Lok Ma Chau control point* on HK side). Taxis are not allowed access to Lo Wu, which is inside the frontier closed area. You can reach the control point by MTR East Rail Line from Sheung Shui station. Opening hours of the visa office are 9-00 to 16-30. Lok Ma Chau control point* is only accessible by taxi during the hours of 23-00 to 06-30. At other times it is accessible by the 24-hour cross-boundary shuttle bus ("yellow bus") from the nearby San Tin Public Transport Interchange which is accessible by taxi. * not to be confused with Lok Ma Chau Spur Line control point which connects Lok Ma Chau MTR Station with Futian Port which I believe does not have a voa facility. Note - Huanggang control point is undergoing a major renovation at the moment. I'm not certain that all services such as voa are available at the current time. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: How do i renew china id card in hong kong?

subject: 1. Re: How do i renew china id card in hong kong?
usertext: A home return permit can be renewed through CTS. Other kinds of Chinese ID cards I don't know. Generally you will not be allowed to travel with an expired document, but it may depend on your specific situation.

subject: 2. Re: How do i renew china id card in hong kong?
usertext: Chinese ID card, wouldn't you treat it as renewing a Chinese passport - at the Chinese Consulate in the country where you are at? Why go to Hong Kong to renew a China ID? The Chinese Consulate in your current location should have the same access to the information they need as the one in Hong Kong. Have you contact them? These things take time. By the time you get an appointment (in Hong Kong), it may be beyond the date that you planned to stay in Hong Kong. And no I don't think you can travel with an expired ID.

subject: 1. Re: Hotel choice!

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Hotel choice!
usertext: Hi no I have not, but will do now! Any other recommendations?

subject: 3. Re: Hotel choice!
usertext: Ive not stayed at Hari but have done a couple stays at both Cordis (Mongkok) and Langham (TST). The area around Hari in Wanchai is fine but not interesting to everyone so worth researching the area as well if you want to give consideration to this property. Cordis is a nice property well located above the Mongkok MTR Station. However, to be honest, these days I prefer to take Mongkok in small doses. Crowds are nuts there the majority of the day and late into the evenings. Langham is a charming property with very comfortable rooms. It is pretty close to the TST promenade where you find world famous views of the Hong Kong Skyline. Star Ferry Pier is nearby and loads of shopping malls, a handful of bars, coffee shops and plenty of casual eats. Still can be rather crowded in this area but more manageable and easier to get away compared to Cordis in Mongkok. TST MTR is near although the station is huge so a bit of underground walking to get to the platforms. Good luck with your property search.

The location is further down the promenade and a bit of a walk to both the Hung Hum and TST East MTR Stations, that is probably the only real complaint I have with them.

subject: Trip Done Report - 9 Enjoyable Days in Hong Kong
usertext: We visited for a family wedding (big Indian wedding:)). We certainly were not prepared for the wonderful, interesting and unique city that Hong Kong is. We enjoyed our 9 days stay in this clean, convenient and orderly city with lots to do and such diversity in food and experiences. We stayed at Midlevels at 2 Macdonnell Road - clean, well serviced and comfortable with a small kitchenette. The stay included a very good breakfast. The staff were very courteous as we realised most people in Hong Kong are. In addition, they offer a complementary shuttle to Central MTR which was a boon. From the bay window in our room on the 24th floor we had a gorgeous view of the iconic Hong Kong skyline that was lit up at night, the botanical garden just opposite and the sea, just about visible between the buildings. Hong Kong is a city that is built on slopes and since we usually walk whenever possible, we got in our share of exercise during our stay. Pedestrians are well catered to and interesting staircases connect streets and localities bypassing the streets that wind around. We cut through the botanical gardens regularly, to walk to our destinations (they are beautiful). We were fascinated by the escalator that runs from Central to Midlevels through some very interesting localities. We used the MTR extensively, paying with the Octopus cards that we picked up at the airport. (My husband was entitled to the elders card giving discounted fares for everything). The MTR is easy to use and connects Hong Kong along with the public buses, really well. This, together with the taxis, that are omnipresent, comfortable, spacious and reasonably priced (only cash) took care of our transport needs. We only used Uber when we needed a large vehicle to attend the wedding functions. We also went on the city tram one evening (upper deck), getting on at Kennedy Town and enjoying the city sights until our destination at Wan Chai. A great way to see the city. We wanted to eat at Joy Hing Roasted Meats having read some good reviews. It was a very small place and packed so we took out the roasted goose. However, we didn't enjoy it - way too fatty for us. Star Ferry is another mode of transport to experience - we took it from Victoria Harbour to Central on HK island. Easy to pay for with the Octopus card or by getting tokens for cash payment. At the Victoria Harbour we had dinner at Nha Trang - a Vietnamese restaurant in Ocean Terminal. We had a table by the window and enjoyed the view of the ferries and junks lit up, sailing by. The food was delicious (spring rolls, crab meat in a coconut curry). We even went on the Ferris wheel at the Harbour in Central. One day was kept for Lantau Island, getting there by MTR to Tung Chung station. There we took the Ngong Ping 360 cable car - the Crystal car with the glass bottom. The wait in the queue for tickets wasn't too long and it was a lovely experience across the water, and the forested slopes to the top. We then walked up to the Tian Tan Buddha. Beautiful access and walk up. After a break for drinks we took the bus to Tai O fishing village. Such an interesting place! Super clean especially unexpected for a fishing village, narrow paved streets lined with interesting food stalls. We tried the salted dried squid and pork at one of these. Pretty good! Lunch was at Solo - a quaint restaurant that is located on a decking that overlooks the water. Small tour boats passed by. We walked to the Pier at the Tai O Public Pier, where the Tai O Heritage hotel is located, hoping to get the ferry back. The walk was through the village, which we enjoyed, so we weren't too upset to find out that the ferry didn't leave from there. Enjoyed some cuttlefish at another stall just before we left. Another island we visited was Cheung Chau. We reached it using the Sun Ferry from Central Pier 5. We went on the fast ferry and returned on the standard ferry on the Deluxe deck. Both ways it was very efficient and comfortable. We used our Octopus card to pay. I needed to top up my card for which there was a counter at the entrance. The Island is quaint with some great places to eat. We ate at a place called Ding Ding Restaurant. It had opened just days earlier. In addition, it was airconditioned which was a boon! We were delighted with the ambience and especially the food - the pork khimchi and the ice cold lemon tea was delicious! We did the short trail the 'Mini Great Wall trail'. Only 850 metres - a paved trail with good views of the sea and unique rock formations along the way. Also on the trail, is the Kwun Yam temple. The Kwun Yam beach is pristine with designated swimming areas, clean changing rooms and toilets. However there was a sign up restricting swimming, as life guard services had been suspended. We even managed to get an ATM on the island to replenish our cash that was running low. Another day, we visited Sai Kung town. We took the A1 bus from the Choi Hung MTR station. We walked along the interesting waterfront where a busy floating seafood market supplies the waterfront eateries, ate at Chuen Kee Seafood restaurant - the set menu of 4 sea food items (lobster, crab, shrimp, fish) and a vegetable dish - all really delicious. We then went to the Sai Kung Cafe and Bakery and had the special buttered pineapple bun and tea. Highly recommended! Street Food Central on Hong Kong Island is a bustling area that has multiple food stalls. While we were there, we happened upon a live TV music show being performed. Wonderful happening place. Walking back we found ourselves at Tai Kwun - the restored Central Police station and prison building complex. The next day we took the funicular train to the Victoria Peak. Interesting experience! After strolling through the Peak Galleria we did the trail along the Circle walk and through Lugard Road - some good lookouts and onto the Pok Fu Lam Reservoir. It was a long hot and humid walk to the reservoir, though upto Lugard Road it was tree covered and cool. From there we made our way to the road and took a bus back. Kowloon Walled City is a beautiful garden with parts of the old city beautifully restored - worth experiencing. We reached it from Lok Fu Place MTR station. Dim dim sum Mong Kok is a great place for dim sum. We over ate there trying out quite a few items on the menu. Throughout, the weather was hot and terribly humid. Loose cotton clothes, sunscreen, peak caps, and lots of water kept us going through the day. We were fortunate to have great weather throughout. All transport is clean, orderly, and really easy to use. By using public transport so much, we experienced different areas of the city and managed to get quite a good flavour of the city - not just the gleaming high rise areas. To return home, we took the Airport Express from Hong kong station. We surrendered our Octopus cards using the refund to partly pay for the tickets. It's a really convenient way to reach the airport that takes you upto the departure hall itself.

subject: 2. Re: Trip Done Report - 9 Enjoyable Days in Hong Kong

subject: 7. Re: Trip Done Report - 9 Enjoyable Days in Hong Kong
usertext: There's something that we noticed that maybe someone from Hongkong might be able to tell us about. On Sunday evening we noticed many groups of young women sitting under the bridges and near the MTR station and bus station t Central area. They seemed to be having a picnic, some were playing cards, some singing. Around 8.30 pm they seemed to be breaking up and saying their good-byes. We were told by someone that they are househelp and they have the evening free on Sundays. If so, we wondered why they wouldn't meet in one of the many parks instead?

subject: 8. Re: Trip Done Report - 9 Enjoyable Days in Hong Kong
usertext: Yes they are domestic helpers, from the Philippines, Indonesia, or Thailand. They have the whole day off, that's when they meet with friends.

subject: Food on flights from US
usertext: I don't know if this is the best place to ask this, but am hoping someone can answer! My flying time is 16 hours and United says the meal service is dinner. Does this mean they give me one meal in 16 hours?? I'll obviously try to sleep part of the flight, but I need more than one meal! On the much shorter flight to Europe we'd get a very small breakfast before landing. It's hard to take food along because of course you can't keep it cold/safe to eat hours later.

subject: 1. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: These long-haul flights (12 to 16 hours) will serve 2 meals at least. Whatever it is called (dinner, lunch, breakfast). I last flew UA from SFO to HKG in 2019, 2 meals. When they serve these meals depends on your departure time. Some other carriers may include a third light meal too or "light meal on request". Like... they don't want to push the carts down the whole isle to serve but if any passengers feel extra hungry they can request it.

subject: 2. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: One meal (dinner?) about 2-3 hrs into your flight. Second meal (breakfast) couple of hours before landing. You can go to the galley to pick up some snacks in between (chips, cookies, nuts). You may even request a cup of noodles. I have had no problem bringing my own food on board. Usually I take a sandwich, snacks such as nuts, crackers, protein bars, etc.

subject: 3. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: Thanks for your replies. I've never flown this far - Europe is a piece of cake compared to this! United is no help. I am a bit of a grazer and am used to eating every few hours. I think I may pack some nuts, or look into some bars. Not something I've had - any brand you'd recommend?

subject: 4. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: Well now I'm concerned - saw your date of flight, so I just tried a "chat" with United and they say only one meal! Hoping someone has flown recently and can answer. I'm in coach; certain the business class gets more food.

subject: 5. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: 100% pack some of your own food! You just can never be sure how United is going to cut corners.

subject: 6. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: Kind Bars are good. There are so many different brands of protein bars you may have to try some yourself. Costco sells a number of different ones. Those chat people may or may not know their stuff. Here is what United says: "If you're flying in United Economy on an international flight that is 800 miles or more, you'll receive an entre, a salad and salad dressing, a snack, and (on select flights) ice cream and a hot pre-arrival meal." So you'll have a meal (an entree), and then a pre-arrival meal. So a dinner and a breakfast. That's been my experience.

subject: 7. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: Yeah. Looks like it is a terminology thing. Or expectation painting. You have 1 full meal and 1 less than full meal. 1.5 meals? Typically they arrange it so that after the first full meal, most passengers would read a book or watch a movie and dose off and sleep most of their 16 hours (or whatever remaining of it). Then before arrival, will have something to warm them back up.

subject: 9. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: RE: "@chewpei - 16 hours with one meal - do you have a medical reason for needing to eat often? If not, isn't this a first world problem?" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = #8: @LoloD: I don't think your assessment is fair. We, the population at large, have a "between meal" time of about 5 to 6 hours. That's from Breakfast to Lunch, Lunch to Dinner. Unless one totally sleeps the whole way through 16 hours, it is not unreasonable to want 2 meals within these 16 hours. Your first world versus (whatever) world statement is a bit out of line. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 10. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: Thank you for your statement. Seems to me that all social media has become less kind in the last few years. First World problem? On a 16 hour flight, even if I slept 8 hours (extremely unlikely) that means 8 hours awake. Yes, I eat more than once in 8 hours. I'm amazed at how a request for information on what anyone has experienced on a recent long haul flight to Asia has turned into such a difficult request. Has anyone gotten a second meal? If not I need to pack food, which I'd prefer not to do. I fly to Newark from another city, so keeping something cold is impossible. Airlines are cutting costs and I want to be prepared - sorry!

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 11. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: British Airways cut their service to just one meal on long haul flights but reverted back to two meals after a backlash.

subject: 12. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: For 16 hours, UA will give you two meals. The second meal might be the "light" one depending on your arrival time. There will also be snacks or something very light available in-flight. Still, bringing some of your own food isn't a bad idea. Airplane food, especially on airlines like UA, just isn't something very appetizing. Also, per my experience, most airlines give you the first meal within 90 minutes to 2 hours once the plane takes off. 3 hours are probably too far into the flight. It's not something important normally but it might give you a reference for when to eat before you board. As to the "first world problem" comment, I agree that's just non-sense. Most humans probably get hungry no longer than 6 to 8 hours after their previous meal. Also, the "first world problem" comment does not add any value to the discussion. Why criticize when you have nothing useful to offer?

subject: 13. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: It's really not necessary to waste more time on this discussion. Bring your own food. I always do. Even when I fly business class. God knows what they feed you, and when. It what they put in front of you is sometimes not even dit for human consumption. A few homemade sandwiches, a banana or two and an energy bar go a long way.

subject: 15. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: First world or not, most people flying on a long haul flight that is 16 hours long should know to expect two meals. It has nothing to do with where you are from. Remember that on this forum, we are discussing travel matters. Traveling, especially for pleasure, is already a first world problem in every aspect. If one has to apply the "first world problem" rule, then every question, every thread that ever gets posted should get the same treatment. What to see and do in HK? That's a first world problem. What 5* hotel to stay in HK? That's a first world problem. The existence of Tripadvisor? That's a first world problem.

subject: 16. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: You may have your opinions on many things, climate issues, politics, racial inequalities, whatever. This forum is not the place to unload them. The focus is on travel related questions/answers/information-sharing. One of the key forum rules is prohibiting harassment. One should not post something that makes another poster feels bad. Some kind of shaming. Re-read your post.

subject: 17. Re: Food on flights from US
usertext: For business reasons, I used to have to fly BA a lot. I have flown their various classes and I never liked them. They were always the industry leader in making the experience worse for the traveler. They were one of the first legacy airlines to charge a seat reservation fee for just about everyone. They were also one of the first, if not the first airline, to put 10 seats across on 777 instead of 9. Now, many airlines are following suit. I am just so glad that I don't have a need to fly them (much) anymore. >>>British Airways cut their service to just one meal on long haul flights but reverted back to two meals after a backlash.

subject: Hong Kong public transport
usertext: Hello, I'm staying near the Lan Kwai Fong district near soho in Hong Kong. Just curious to know the best methods of transportation from the airport to and from this area. Is there 24 hours services etc? Thank you

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong public transport
usertext: Just you? Lots of luggage? The best, IMO, is taxi.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong public transport
usertext: I would take the Airport Express train to Hong Kong Station. Then take a taxi from there to your accommodation. It is fast, and less costly than taking taxi from the airport. AE train runs until shortly before 1 am and start at about 6 am. Taxi is 24-hour.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong public transport
usertext: Taxi door to door is always the best. Airport Express train + taxi is fast and cost about 50-60% of a straight taxi ride. Airport Bus to Central plus a taxi is the most economical but around 30-40 minutes slower depending on traffic. Note that staying at LKF, you should get a taxi for the last leg of the journey since it's located up a somewhat steep hill. If you have any luggage, it's pretty hard to drag them up the street since there are often steps involved. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong public transport
usertext: Here is a starter thread with links to airport and transportation resources if you want to learn more about how to travel between the airport and the city https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14482016-Hong_Kong_Airport_to_the_City_2023-Hong_Kong.html

subject: Roast goose/hop on hop off
usertext: If I take the hop on and hop off will it take me to Wellington Street to Yung Kee roast goose restaurant?

subject: 1. Re: Roast goose/hop on hop off
usertext: The "hop on hop off" type of buses will not take you directly to the restaurant. You need to map out which hoho bus stop to use and walk the rest. Which bus company are you using? If it is Big Bus Hong Kong, ironically it is just the second stop (Mid-Levels Escalator), pretty much right after it departs the terminus. Link: https://www.bigbustours.com/en/hong-kong/red-hong-kong-island-route Be honest, don't use these hoho buses as transportation means. Hong Kong is compact and small. The waiting time overhead for each bus run (like 1 hour), a long time to wait. Riding the entire route and kick-back and sight-see may be all right. The other hoho bus is Rickshaw: Link: https://www.rickshawbus.com/en/routes/index.html Use "Lan Kwai Fong". Yung Kee is right there at the heart of Lan Kwai Fong. I think I am forgetting a third hoho bus company. Not sure if it is still in business.

subject: 2. Re: Roast goose/hop on hop off
usertext: As HappyFeet says, I don't see the point of these buses, except perhaps as a lazy way to get an overall feel for the place on your first day when you are jetlagged, when you could just take the whole route. After that the MTR and normal buses are extremely easy to use in these days of apps and Google maps. They all have announcements and route information in English as well as Chinese. Edited: 1 year ago
