subject: RE: China to Hong Kong and back to China
usertext: Understand we (Malaysian) need visa to travel to China and no need for Hong Kong. However, my question is if I travel to China GuangZhou from Malaysia by air, then will take the train to Hong Kong, and after that, from Hong Kong back to GuangZhou to Malaysia. Do I need to have a separate visa to re-enter China from Hong Kong? Thanks

subject: 1. Re: RE: China to Hong Kong and back to China
usertext: Does your China visa cover you multiple entries?

subject: 2. Re: RE: China to Hong Kong and back to China
usertext: I am in the middle of applying for the visa and need to decide on single entry or double entry. If re-visit back to China from Hong Kong and need to have a separate visit then I need to apply for double entry.

subject: 3. Re: RE: China to Hong Kong and back to China
usertext: RE: "If re-visit back to China from Hong Kong and need to have a separate visit then I need to apply for double entry." = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = That is definitely the case. Hong Kong SAR is treated AS IF it is a different country as far as immigration matters are concerned. You will need a multiple-entry visa to cover your return from Hong Kong back to Guangzhou.

subject: 4. Re: RE: China to Hong Kong and back to China
usertext: You may be able to get 144 hr visa free entry to Guangzhou for your one or both entries at Guangzhou. Have you checked?

subject: 5. Re: RE: China to Hong Kong and back to China
usertext: @4 - The OP is just applying for a visa now and it is best to apply for a double entry visa (required to return to mainland China) using an application itinerary that shows Guangzhou arrival, travel to Hong Kong, followed by travel back to Guangzhou; and not have to worry about meeting the 144 hour TWOV requirements including finding an approved port of exit from Guangdong province to Hong Kong.

subject: 6. Re: RE: China to Hong Kong and back to China
usertext: As far as I know those TWOV visa require you to use the same exit port (i.e. Guangzhou airport) as you used to enter the country. Also to qualify you need a connecting flight to a third country to qualify for that visa, and it seems OP is just trying to do Malaysia - Guangzhou - Malaysia. It's really a transit/layover visa.

subject: 7. Re: RE: China to Hong Kong and back to China
usertext: @6 - From the China Southern Website on 144 hour requirements: "The transit passengers must leave China from one of the 32 open ports in Guangdong province. " You can find the 32 ports here (BTW, Kowloon West is not one of them): https://www.csair.com/en/tourguide/transit_flow/flightsTwo_hub/72_hour_stay/

subject: 8. Re: RE: China to Hong Kong and back to China
usertext: Interesting. Those railway ports mentioned, aren't those the places where you would catch the now defunct intercity through train to Hong Kong? In any case Malaysians do not qualify, so it's not an option for the OP.

subject: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: Hi All, We are planning a family trip from Sydney Australia to Hong Kong and Macau. 3 adults and 2 children ages 4 and 7. Plan is to arrive at Hong Kong on 26th of December, stay till 1st or 2nd of January and then travel to Macau and stay till 7th of January. We also need to be mindful that given we are 3 adults and 2 children we will either need 2 rooms nearby each other or one big room which makes it tricky to book. Hong Kong is mostly going to be for children. I am tossing between staying at Disney Hotel where it will be easier to access Disney and allows one of the adults to stay with the children at Disney while the other two explore the city OR staying at a 5 star accommodation which sits between Hong Kong city and Disney. The first option, I would imagine, provides better access, and second option allows to stay at a 5 star up market hotel without having to spend as much for accommodation. Given the above, and the fact that I have heard disney in hong kong is not very big, which option is the better option in your opinion? Is there much to do for children of that age in Macau? If so what are they and do they need to be prebooked? are we better off staying in Hong Kong and just catch the ferry to Macau or move to a hotel in Macau instead? What 5 star hotels both in Hong Kong and Macau are recommended given our situation? Is it easy and cost effective to go around with a taxi in Hong Kong and Macau?

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: For a Disney hotel stay, 1 to 2 nights maximum are enough. The location is too inconvenient for a longer stay. Move to a proper centrally located hotel for the remaining days. As to cost, I have no idea but I don't think Disney hotels would be cheap between Christmas and New Year's? Since you have enough days, staying at Macau for 2-3 days makes sense. Macau is normally not a destination where you needs to spend 5 days though. As to hotel recommendation, what is your budget? It's much better to post a figure than recommending based on star levels. There are quite a few 5* hotels in HK. Their prices vary significantly. Taxis are affordable overall. Always pay based on the metered rate.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: Great thanks, based on what I have checked Disney Hotel is slightly more expensive than equivalents. Budget is between $1000 to $1500 AUD per night give or take, Will we be ok to stay at a hotel in between Disney and Kowloon? Is there a hotel / type of room recommended to watch NYE fireworks? Is it worthwhile to visit Taipei while we are there, is it within Ferry Distance to visit from Hong Kong? if so whats there to do and will it possibly need a visa?

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: Considering it's just about 40 mins on the MTR to get from Kowloon or Hong Kong Island to Disneyland, it makes no sense whatsoever to try and find a hotel halfway (that's before considering the relative lack of hotels halfway). Also indeed 1-2 days is enough for Macau. Especially with children, as it stops you from spending the rest of your time in the casinos (as you'll be done seeing what's worth seeing outside of that after two full days).

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: {Is there much to do for children of that age in Macau? If so what are they and do they need to be prebooked?} Macau has done a pretty good job building up their child and family-friendly attractions over the years. There are some helpful threads and information for researching our sister city on the Macau forum (see link) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowForum-g664891-i12409-Macau.html

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: RE: "Budget is between $1000 to $1500 AUD per night give or take," = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Is this budget per night for 2 rooms as you stated you may need? Or just for one room? It is a big difference. Also, the 3 adults - are they all in the same family? Or one of them a nanny for your 2 kids and thus would require a separate room/space? That may steer whether you need 2 rooms, or you may be able to do a suite with foldable beds or sofa dub'bing as a bed at night. The rate of a suite is typically less than 2 rooms. You asked about 5-star hotels between Hong Kong Disneyland and Kowloon. Well, in between, there is Ma Wan (a tiny island), Tsing Yi (a bigger island), and a stretch of land which had been developed into a huge container port, many of the earlier-built residential high-rise real-estates, then the older part of the earlier Kowloon's land development. While there are a few hotels here and there, there is no 5-star hotel, let alone top/nice 5-star hotels. Most 5-star hotels (and there are many of them in Hong Kong) are located in the tip of Kowloon adjacent to or very close to Victoria Harbour. I think given your situation, you want to stay at a Disney Hotel for 2 nights, and then the rest of the time in a different 5-star hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui. Instead of picking something "in the middle", then play ping-pong commuting to Disneyland or other parts of your interests in Hong Kong / Kowloon for sight-seeing everyday, which doesn't make sense. For Macau, it is a tad too long especially with 2 young kids. I was going to suggest JW Marriott in Macau's Cotai area because they have an awesome pool and a great lazy river (one of the only few hotels - well it is a shared facility in the Galaxy complex - that has it in Macau). But reviewing the dates of your trip, being in late December/January, unfortunately I think their lazy river would be shutdown for the season. At any rate, I would trim down the time in Macau. Tapei is not "ferry distance". It is 500 miles away from Hong Kong, an 1-hour flight time.

subject: 8. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: It's best to post in HKD though with your type of budget, you should be able to afford most hotels. Note that even for 5* hotels, there are really great ones to more "normal" ones. From the list you posted, Ritz Carlton is obviously the best but its location is less convenient if you want to visit HK for multiple days. Kerry isn't as good. Corids is very convenient but Mong Kok is very crowded. Cordis is also not as nice as Kerry. In your specific case, look into Upper House at Admiralty. With the relatively new East Rail extension, Admiralty is now a very convenient area to get to just about everywhere.

subject: 10. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: If you want a good harbour view from the Hong Kong Island side, I think Four Seasons is a better location because it is more close up to the waterfront with no blockage. On Kowloon side: Rosewood and Regent have the best full-frontal view of the harbour. Shangri-La Kowloon - the view is good and unblocked, but it is not in the same grade as Rosewood/Regent. Marco Polo's view is good. It is the oldest among these hotels. I think it is not at the notch as Ritz/Four-Seasons/Regent/Rosewood. One of the oldest hotels in Hong Kong - The Peninsula, also has a respectable view of the harbour. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 11. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: Carrying a small amount of cash is still useful in HK. Most taxis, for example, still do not accept cards. Amex cards are less widely accepted here than Visa, Mastercard and UnionPay. Have one of those, just in case. Also, it is useful to get Octopus Cards, which are the local cash card. They are used to pay public transport fares (tap on and tap off) and are also accepted in convenience stores and many shopping and tourism destinations. The standard "on loan" Octopus car can be procured at any MTR ticket office, including at HK Airport. The cost is minimal (there is a deposit on the card which is refunded when you turn the card in before departure, with the exception of a small admin fee.)

subject: 12. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: For the classic HK harbour view you need to be on the TST side, so the Rosewood/Regent/Peninsula (high floor) are the places to be if money is not a big issue.

subject: 13. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children

The hotels also vary significantly from each other. We have stayed at some of New York best hotels for less per night that they charge at hong kong, its just amazing. subject: 14. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: "Also, it is useful to get Octopus Cards, which are the local cash card. They are used to pay public transport fares (tap on and tap off)" Just to elaborate - on the MTR (subway) you tap at the entrance gate and the exit gate (the fare is specific to each set of station pairs). On buses and minibuses you simply tap when you get on (the fare is set solely by the route and where you get on, whether travelling one stop or many). On the ding-ding tram you tap when you get off (the fare is the same for any length of journey).

subject: 15. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children

subject: 16. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: #15: Hong Kong taxi fare calculations here, from the official source (Hong Kong Transport Department): Link: https://www.td.gov.hk/en/transport_in_hong_kong/public_transport/taxi/taxi_fare_of_hong_kong/index.html Very roughly (all amounts in HKD): Flagdrop: $27, up to 2km covered by this flat rate From 2km to 9km: About $9.5 per km (the taxi meter jumps every 200m) From 9km onward: About $6.5 per km (the taxi meter jumps every 200m) But Luggage is HKD $6 per piece. And there can be toll fees (tunnels and bridges), depending on where from/to. Can be very complicated. But generally Hong Kong taxi fare is not considered expensive.

subject: 17. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: {Are there any other places worth visiting for children that are in 4 to 7 age bracket?} You seem to be well versed on how to research these things independently based on your past posts. There are are quite a few online write-ups about the things to do in Hong Kong for those with little ones beyond the major Theme Parks. We have many urban and rural parks, wetlands, aviaries, small zoo, animal rescue park, light hiking/walking opportunities, malls with designated children's play zone areas, promenade play areas, ice-rinks, cinemas, ferry boat trips, islands, beaches, a Legoland Discovery Centre, Snoopy Land and related child friendly places that some find interesting for their little ones. If you look up on the available online articles that can quickly referenced through google search, you will also recommended things to do with children for residents who live here year round, perhaps something you come across strikes interest for your little ones as well.

subject: 18. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children
usertext: Hi Nav S On HK Disneyland - yes, book your park tickets and reserve your park visit date as soon as possible. They're introducing a new theme land this November, Frozen, and given that you will be visiting during the holidays, there is a possibility you might run out of slots. A few years ago, they did not require reserving the park visit date so this is something that needs to be kept in mind. I use Klook to buy tickets and then make the reservation directly in HK DL's official website. On HK Hotels - just be mindful that some hotels count children/infants as one occupant regardless of age. If you book a triple room for example, it may limit the occupant number to exactly three - I.E. two adults + 2 kids will not be allowed. So just make sure to familiarize yourself with the hotel policies. With your budget, I would look into two-bedroom suites for your group. On Macau - whether you are planning to do this at the beginning, middle or the end of your trip, just keep in mind that having kids plus luggage in tow might pose some challenges to your travel. The best option is to arrive in HK and depart from Macau or vice versa so you only travel once. If this is not an option, the most practical way is to travel to Macau directly from HKIA (via bus) if you can manage it and if it fits your schedule. Otherwise, you might need to consider leaving some pieces of your luggage at your HK hotel prior to checking in. We'll also be travelling with kids and a senior this year and so far it is likely that we'll just opt for a day trip to avoid the hassle. If your budget allows it - you can also opt to stay one night without checking out of your HK hotel. 1-3 days for me is enough to see the highlights in Macau. Just in case you haven't checked out the travel options - there is the ferry, HZMB bus and there is also a point to point bus from HK city centers that drops off directly at certain Macau hotels. Take note of the luggage allowance especially on the bus options. Teamlab is now available in Macau - your family might enjoy that. Good luck!

subject: 19. Re: Hong Kong and Macau Visit Over Christmas with Children

subject: 1. Re: How (un)common are connecting rooms at Hong Kong hotels?
usertext: Not as common in Hong Kong to find connecting rooms but there are places that offer them. If you goggle hotels with connecting rooms hong kong, you should see in the search results a handful that do. One particular property that has been quite popular for those with families that offers connecting room is Royal Plaza in Mongkok. They are worth a look-see even if you decide to go a different direction with your hotel search. https://www.royalplaza.com.hk/en/family-1-1-combo-room-package/ If you are looking for something more upscale, consider JD Marriott (see link) https://www.marriott.com/offers/be-2-gather-at-jw-connecting-rooms-OFF-66947/hkgdt-jw-marriott-hotel-hong-kong or the deluxe connecting rooms at The Penninsula https://www.peninsula.com/en/hong-kong/luxury-hotel-room-suite-types/connecting-deluxe-rooms

subject: Help with itinerary, please.
usertext: Hi! Me and my friends are heading to HK next week, and we could really use your expert advice on our itinerary. Here's what we've come up with so far: Day 1 Arrival at HK Airport (9:00AM) Citygate Outlets (lockers available) Hotel TST Peak Tram. Victoria Peak TST Avenue of Stars, Symphony of Lights, Harbour City (Fixed schedule. We need to meet someone in Citygate Outlets, and we already have fixed date Peak Tram ticket) Day 2 Disneyland Day 3 - Option 1 Ngong Ping cable car + Ngong Ping Village Tai O Village Bus + MTR to Mong Kok Mong Kok Night Market and Sneaker Street (We only booked one way ticket Ngong Ping cable car. Is Tai O Village worth it? Or better to just explore SSP?) Day 3 - Option 2 Ngong Ping cable car + Ngong Ping Village Bus + MTR to Sham Shui Po. Explore SSP (Golden Computer Center, Market) Mong Kok Day 4 Fast Ferry from Central to Cheung Chau Explore Cheung Chau Fast Ferry from Cheung Chau to Central Explore Central (we just want to eat at Yat Lok) Central to Causeway Bay. Explore Causeway Bay (Times Square) (Is it worth it to go to Cheung Chau or just stay and explore in the city?) Day 5 Flight back home So, what do you guys think? We're looking forward to your suggestions. Thank you so much in advance!

subject: 1. Re: Help with itinerary, please.
usertext: Tai O is a pretty nice old fishing village; Shamshuipo is a crowded fairly old neighbourhood of Kowloon. Both are worth visiting. If you go to Shamshuipo, do go visit the exhibition in Mei Ho House (about the first public housing of Hong Kong), and the wet market at Shek Kip Mei Estate. Cheung Chau is a nice island, lots to see there, both in the village itself and the natural areas next to it. Ordinary ferry makes for a more interesting ride than the fast ferry as you have much better views, and most even have an open air viewing deck.

subject: 2. Re: Help with itinerary, please.
usertext: Next week will be China's long National Day holiday. Be prepared that popular sites could get crowed.

subject: 3. Re: Help with itinerary, please.
usertext: Day 4 {(Is it worth it to go to Cheung Chau or just stay and explore in the city?)} Some consider it a fine place to visit. Others could care less. When you researched Cheung Chau, what did you learn/see that was interesting to you? If you haven't researched Cheung Chau yet, here are a couple resources to help. https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/great-outdoor/wellness/cheung-chau.html https://www.tripadvisor.com/Trips/97899048 Good luck with your research and trip planning.

subject: The Mira - breakfast options
usertext: Hi all, Considering booking at the Mira in TST for a 10 night stay WITHOUT breakfast. The price difference between breakfast inclusive and without is quite substantial, and after day 3 of hotel breakfasts we're usually over it. Are there many reasonably priced breakfast restaurants in the area? I've had a look at tenants in the Mira mall, but couldn't see any. Dim sum would be a bonus! Thanks in advance:-)

subject: 1. Re: The Mira - breakfast options
usertext: Mira Hotel's location is fairly central in Tsim Sha Tsui. There would be hundreds of eateries offering Western style, Chinese style and all kinds of food options. I wouldn't worry too much about it. You walk around the places near your hotel when you arrive, you can scout out many places you would want to try during your stay.

subject: 2. Re: The Mira - breakfast options
usertext: That's great, thank you!

subject: 3. Re: The Mira - breakfast options
usertext: Local eateries with local/Chinese food - won't be a problem finding places open and some very early. Do note however that outside of HK Island, it is not that easy to find 'western' breakfast before 10am beyond your typical McD and Starbucks like franchises There are some around TST but best to do a bit of research ahead of time to have places picked out before hitting the streets at 8.30 or 9am to find on your own.

subject: 4. Re: The Mira - breakfast options
usertext: Very Good restaurant at Nathan Road has been around for decades. It should be a good spot for traditional dim sum. Also, there are now numerous dim sum specific eateries (not large restaurants) everywhere. For example, not too far from your hotel, you will find them at the Jordan area and also at Cameron Road at TST.. For tea cafes, Australia Dairy Company isn't too far away either. Go on weekday mornings (closed Thursdays and most public holidays I believe) to avoid crowds. Note that the tea cafes closest to your hotel on Kimberly Road are mostly terrible otherwise. The ones at Cameron Road at least meet the par. And if you get sick of such larger eats, the Mira Mall has a onigiri (Japanese rice ball) place next to Starbucks.

subject: HK Express (island check-in) and Lantau Island daytrip
usertext: I will be flying out of HK on a midnight flight. Staying in Wan Chai. At first I was thinking that after check-out we could get rid of the luggage at the HK Station airport express and then go to Lantau for the day before heading to airport after dinner. But then I realised the Airport Express doesn't go to Lantau. Does anyone have a good suggestion? Or best to forget it and just go to Lantau as a separate daytrip?

subject: 1. Re: HK Express (island check-in) and Lantau Island daytrip
usertext: The in-town check-in is not back to usual, and appears to be available to CX passengers only at this moment: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/complom_checkin.html Of course things may have changed by the time you fly (hopefully, it was a fantastic service). Otherwise: just forego your AE ticket - call it a service fee (it's actually cheaper than storing your luggage in the airport for a day), and take the regular MTR Tung Chung Line trains from Hong Kong to Tung Chung and proceed from there. Alternatively you may use the lockers at the basement of Citygate Mall in Tung Chung, or the left luggage service at the cable car station (opens until the last cable car passengers have made it back to Tung Chung). https://www.np360.com.hk/en/visitors-information/tourist-guide

subject: 2. Re: HK Express (island check-in) and Lantau Island daytrip
usertext: But then I realised the Airport Express doesn't go to Lantau. Sure it does. The airport is located on Lantau Island, so the Airport Express does go to Lantau Island. So if you can do island check in, you can ride the Airport Express to the airport, then take a bus to Tung Chung. Both are on Lantau Island. If the check in is not available to you, then I would take MTR to Tung Chung, store your luggage at the mall. Then when you are ready to go to the airport, take a bus or taxi.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: HK Express (island check-in) and Lantau Island daytrip
usertext: To be more accurate (or pedantic perhaps!) the airport is located on Chek Lap Kok, a separate island connected to Lantau by bridges and HK's third largest island after Lantau and HK Island, but you can still do as TSS suggests.

subject: 4. Re: HK Express (island check-in) and Lantau Island daytrip
usertext: Thank you everyone for your very helpful replies!!! Much appreciated. I did not realise that there are those left luggage services, so I will look into that. I am flying CX so the HKS check-in option would mean we can get rid of the big pieces early and can just leave the hand luggage at Lantau.

subject: 5. Re: HK Express (island check-in) and Lantau Island daytrip
usertext: At Tung Chung MTR, exit right (from direction of travel, follow everyone), and find the underground parking under the mall. There are lockers on two levels next to the elevators, with an attendant in case of questions. Different sizes, and payment is by Octopus, possibly other means. Or walk just past the mall and find the cable car station (eyeball the cables) and use their luggage storage, as mentioned above. MTR, mall, cable car, Lantau buses, other buses (eg Airport) and blue taxis for Lantau are all found close together. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: HK Express (island check-in) and Lantau Island daytrip
usertext: Wow Ngong Ping left luggage is HKD100 per piece!! Definitely cheaper to use Airport Express then. Citygate is HKD 60 day pass for a locker, will be good for the hand luggage.

subject: 7. Re: HK Express (island check-in) and Lantau Island daytrip
usertext: Personal opinion: try the Lantau buses. They have their own lot, adjacent to the cable car station the last I looked, but some things were moving around at the time. Queues are sometimes big, but they move well. The buses take you to Ngong Ping (Buddha etc.), Tai O, and a few other places. Good views from the bus (you go over a big hill), worthwhile sightseeing if you have the time. The cable car is a wee bit pricey, and it has its own queues. But it probably does have the best views, I'll grant that. (I've never taken it; I'm always on the bus.)

subject: Trip planned for first week of January 2024 _ please advise
usertext: Hello members. We are planning to stay in The park hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui. Where can we find Indian food breakfast option in vicinity... nearby location has McDonald's or grocery store. Any food delivery app which provide and deliver Indian breakfast Disneyland n ocean park... is packed chip's and biscuit and water bottle allowed to take

subject: 1. Re: Trip planned for first week of January 2024 _ please advise
usertext: {Where can we find Indian food breakfast option in vicinity.} You can use our local food review website called openrice to identify Indian restaurants in TST. There are plenty of options. However, I'm not familiar with those that open before 10.30am. Sangeetha Vegetarian Restaurant at nearby Wing On Plaza (10.30 openign) is a good option. There may be arcade/canteen style places in the Chungking Mansions that will be open early. That is where you find a fair number of simple, casual and cheap South Indian eateries and food shops. https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/restaurants/cuisine/indian?districtId=2008&tabIndex=0 {nearby location has McDonald's or grocery store. } Seriously, learn how to use google maps as quickly as you can. It will help so much with finding what you are looking for throughout Hong Kong. Input 'Mcdonalds TST' and you will quickly see the location of every branch in the area. You can also use google maps. Input 'Indian shop TST' and you will see the location of several market shops in the area that sell Indian foods that are not far to walk from Park Hotel. {Any food delivery app which provide and deliver Indian breakfast} Two most popular food delivery apps are Foodpanda and Deliveroo. Both have Indian food delivery but again, not a lot of breakfast options available. It is evening time now. I might suggest playing around with these two sites online when its morning time in Hong Kong to see if there are Indian restaurant/delivery options showing available in the morning that will deliver to Park Hotel. {Disneyland n ocean park... is packed chip's and biscuit and water bottle allowed to take} https://www.hongkongdisneyland.com/park-rules/ SEE -> Guests are allowed to bring outside food and beverage items into the Park for self-consumption, provided that they do not require heating, reheating, processing, refrigeration or temperature control and do not have pungent odors. Examples of food items not permitted in the Park include, without limitation, instant noodles that require hot water, food kept in containers with reheating capabilities and durian fruit. https://www.oceanpark.com.hk/en/park-rules-and-regulations SEE -> FOOD AND DRINK - Guests may bring in baby food and a reasonable quantity of food and beverages for personal consumption. For the safety and comfort of other guests, alcoholic beverages cannot be brought into the Park; food or beverage items with heavy or pungent smell are not allowed either. Guests are also reminded that they may not light any fire, barbecue or otherwise cook food in the Park.

subject: Transit in Hong Kong airport
usertext: I am travelling from singapore to Japan. Planning to take 2 different flight (different airlines) My first flight (singapore airlines) reaches at 10:45 PM Next flight (tway air) departure time 2:30 AM I have around 3:30 hrs between the flight. Because of different airlines I have to re checkin but same terminal My question is 3:30 hrs enough for immigration and customs clearence on arrival + airline checkin + security check and immigration?

subject: 1. Re: Transit in Hong Kong airport
usertext: 3:30 hours are enough. No problem there. However, be reminded that Indian nationals are required to complete pre-arrival registration online successfully before visiting or transiting the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) visa-free. Per Hong Kong Immigration Website: Link: https://webapp.es2.immd.gov.hk/applies2-client/static/faq/i-par-reg/en-US/i-par-reg-faq.html quote: Q: Do I need to apply for PAR if I am transiting the HKSAR? You do not need to apply for PAR if you are in direct transit by air and will not leave the airport transit area. However, if you are seeking to enter the HKSAR during transit, you need to apply for PAR. End-quote

subject: 2. Re: Transit in Hong Kong airport
usertext: I have PAR. 3:30 hrs enough for custom clearence and ckeckin and security check? Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Transit in Hong Kong airport
usertext: Thank you

subject: 4. Re: Transit in Hong Kong airport
usertext: You shouldn't need to go through customs & immigration at HKG at all. There are "transfer desks" within the secure area, where you should be able to check in for your second flight and get your boarding pass. https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/passenger-guide/transfer-transit/#2

subject: 5. Re: Transit in Hong Kong airport
usertext: Except that T'way Air (which only flies from HK to Korea, BTW, not direct to Japan) is a low cost airline. So if you have any checked bags then you will need to go landside to collect them and recheck them for the second flight. But still, 3h30 should be plenty of time.

subject: 6. Re: Transit in Hong Kong airport
usertext: "You shouldn't need to go through customs & immigration at HKG at all" Then how can OP check his/her luggage in to T'Way airline? Post #5 has explained the process correctly.

subject: 7. Re: Transit in Hong Kong airport
usertext: If you have baggage, you definitely need to clear inbound immigration and customs and then recheck. Normally, 3:30 gives you more than enough time though one can never predict flight delays. If you have no baggage, then you should be able to use transit security only without going through inbound immigration or customs. For your onward flight, I assume you can get a boarding pass via online check-in?

subject: Stopover at Hongkong
usertext: Hi we shall be flying to Mumbai to Tokyo via Hongkong with seven hours between flights.Is it practically possible to go out , have a quick look at the city ( 2 hrs ) and come back ? We understand Hongkong visa is on arrival for Indians .Thanks for any response

subject: 1. Re: Stopover at Hongkong
usertext: Sorry , read " to Mumbai from Tokyo" .

subject: 2. Re: Stopover at Hongkong
usertext: It is not "visa on arrival" (you don't actually get a visa or pay anything for it like in China). It is considered a "visa free" visit or transit. However, you need to go through the PAR (pre-arrival registration) to see if you are successful in getting approval first. See this: = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Indian nationals are required to complete pre-arrival registration online successfully before visiting or transiting the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) visa-free. Per Hong Kong Immigration Website: Link: https://webapp.es2.immd.gov.hk/applies2-client/static/faq/i-par-reg/en-US/i-par-reg-faq.html quote: Q: Do I need to apply for PAR if I am transiting the HKSAR? You do not need to apply for PAR if you are in direct transit by air and will not leave the airport transit area. However, if you are seeking to enter the HKSAR during transit, you need to apply for PAR. End-quote = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = If you are successful in PAR, what actual time is your 7-hour layover? If those are in the middle of the night (e.g. between 00:00 am and 7:00 am), there is not much you can do. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Stopover at Hongkong
usertext: Thanks a lot .Our Cathay Pacific flight is reaching Hongkong at 13.05 hrs and flight to Mumbai is at 20.20 hrs . Does it look alright ? When you say Visa free , we still have to go through some kind of checking process before entering the city, is it not ? Will there be a longish queue ?How long it will take ( typically )from arrival - exit - re-entry - departure ? Based on your advice, we will decide . Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Stopover at Hongkong
usertext: That is enough time to go out and have a look at the city for a couple of hours, yes. You can take the Airport Express train from the airport to downtown (Hong Kong Station) in 25 minutes, and then walk around the harborfront and take a ride on the Star Ferry to Kowloon (and back, to get your train to return to the airport). Buy a one-day return ticket and your return train ride is essentially free. Hong Kong immigration checks are usually fast -- from getting off your plane to exiting the customs area count half an hour. On return, you have to wait in a security check line but assuming you have your HKG-BOM boarding passes in hand already, arrival at the airport 90 minutes before flight time should be more than sufficient. Don't delay -- apply online for your PAR entry permission now, so you can be sure of your entry to Hong Kong. (If the PAR is refused, you still have the option of changing planes in Hong Kong, but you will not be allowed to leave the airport transit area.)

subject: 5. Re: Stopover at Hongkong
usertext: @H_K Observer, we have applied for PAR and got back a PDF file online. Is this the approval or we should get something else too? Also couple of more queries... a) Where is the Airport express station? Do we have to go out of the terminal? b) Can I use US dollar for the tickets and restaurants in the city? Or do we need to convert the money before leaving the airport? Or can we manage with our credit cards? Many thanks for your support.

subject: 6. Re: Stopover at Hongkong
usertext: RE: "a) Where is the Airport express station? Do we have to go out of the terminal?" The Airport Express Train was designed very well. The train station is integrated into the HKIA terminal structure. From the Arrival Hall when you walk out, you walk straight on and within 2 minutes you will be at the train platform. Follow the signs. You can buy your tickets at the Arrival Hall (Airport Express Customer Service Counter), or you can even just hop on to a train to Hong Kong Station or Kowloon Station (same line), and buy the tickets when you arrive those stations. For your layover, buy the "Same Day Return" ticket package for the same price as a single-journey ticket. Basically the return trip (Same Day) is free. = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = RE: "b) Can I use US dollar for the tickets and restaurants in the city? Or do we need to convert the money before leaving the airport? Or can we manage with our credit cards?" Can't use USD directly in Hong Kong. You need HKD currencies. I think you can use your credit card to buy the Airport Express train tickets these days. (I am not 100% sure.) Big, established restaurants would usually take credit cards. Small mom-and-pop or hole-in-the-wall outfits probably won't. There are ATM machines at the airport, right there at the luggage carousels. If you can use your ATM card internationally, you can withdraw HKD cash from those machines. I think the minimum is HKD $100 and then the multiple of HKD $100. Get the $100 and no higher. Makes it easier to use for payments. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: Stopover at Hongkong
usertext: @HappyFeet1234 Thanks a bunch for your detailed explanation and guidance. We have received a PDF online with this heading( Notification slip for Pre- Arrival Registration) ..is the printout of the same good enough or there is something else we can expect from the PAR authority? Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 8. Re: Stopover at Hongkong
usertext: RE: "We have received a PDF online with this heading( Notification slip for Pre- Arrival Registration) ..is the printout of the same good enough or there is something else we can expect from the PAR authority?" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Kasturi: I was born in Hong Kong so I only use my Hong Kong ID when I return to my homeland. Thus I have no first-hand experience with the HK immigration procedures for other nationals. From what you described, I think that is probably all you need. What's important, I think, is on that PDF document, did it give you some kind of reference number (that is uniquely assigned to you)? Any mentioning of your passport numbers or anything like that? The reference number is the most important. If the printout is lost, and you have taken a picture of that PDF file with the reference number on it with your smart phone and bring that with you, the Immigration Officer can look that up by the reference number, even if you don't have the print out with you. (Or they might be able to look that up by your passport number, I don't know. It is better to have abundance of supporting evidence than not enough. ) RE: my reply #6. I don't think I was very clear on the following paragraph: "If you can use your ATM card internationally, you can withdraw HKD cash from those machines. I think the minimum is HKD $100 and then the multiple of HKD $100. Get the $100 and no higher. Makes it easier to use for payments." What I meant was these ATM machines are configured to dispense HKD $100 bills (but they may disperse some higher denominations as well, such as HKD $500 and HKD $1000 bills.). You can withdraw a minimum of HKD $100, or a multiple units of $100 (such as withdrawing $200 total, $300 total, and so on). My advice was on not to opt to take the $500 or $1000 bills for your short stay. Sometimes it may be difficult to "break" them if you are buying items that don't cost much. Some merchants may not be willing to take the bigger bills ($500, $1000) fearing of counterfeits. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 9. Re: Stopover at Hongkong
usertext: #6 {I think you can use your credit card to buy the Airport Express train tickets these days. (I am not 100% sure.)} That is right. You can use cc: to purchase AE tickets at the Customer Services desk and I believe at the self-service ticket machines as well. These are both encountered prior to walking onto the train platform at the airport station. You can't miss them. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 10. Re: Stopover at Hongkong

subject: most up to date travel book Hong Kong 2023
usertext: I know so much of my information will be coming from this forum, but I still somehow like to carry a travel book with me. Not too heavy! Easy to read! I guess I am considered a senior female traveler.

subject: 1. Re: most up to date travel book Hong Kong 2023
usertext: It's a good question, because many of the things that travel books recommend (particularly restaurants etc) are very different after the 3 years of hysteria, and several things opened during that period (e.g. in the West Kowloon Cultural District). So you'd probably be better off relying on online sources (again checking carefully for when they were written/updated) unless you can find a guide book that has been written or (extensively) revised since March 2023.

subject: 2. Re: most up to date travel book Hong Kong 2023
usertext: I don't have a specific recommendation. But suggest that when you are in HK, go to the HK Tourism Board's store at the Kowloon Tsim Sha Tsui Star Ferry pier. They have all kinds of brochures about HK, and maybe a guide book or two. Most information are free, some are for sale. Staff is very helpful.

subject: vinyl record shops
usertext: hello anyone knows where can i find vinyl record shops around hong kong? thanks

subject: 1. Re: vinyl record shops
usertext: Are you looking for stores sell vinyl records on new music, new album, new titles? Or are you looking for vintage old music/album/titles that were originally recorded and sold on vinyl records? Those are more collectors items as the industry had not made vinyl records since the 80's when digital CD came to the market. I think finding this kind of stores is hard as the rents and costs of operating a store front are high. I think a lot of collectors trade their collections online these days. And are you looking for western music (e.g. from the USA) on vinyl records? Or the local Chinese artists selling new Cantonese song titles in vinyl record media?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Itinerary - sort of!
usertext: Hi all. I'm not one for doing an hour by hour itinerary but I do like to have a bit of a list of places to see and things to do. We will be in Hong Kong next week and this is on our shortlist, so far. Would appreciate any thoughts and advice. We will be there for 11 days. Places under consideration, I've tried to group them and I know we won't need to see all the outdoor places for example so looking for opinion on which ones to knock off the list! Outdoor Hong Kong wetland Park Nam sang wai Kadoorie Farm and Botanic Garden Botanic Garden Hong Kong geopark Walks Dragons back + Shek o Lion rock Ping Shan Heritage trail Neon signs audio walk The busy part of Kowloon, Nathan Road and surrounds Temple Street nightmarket Stanley market Man mo temple Chi lin nunnery Tian tan buddha Star ferry Day trips to Macau Shenzhen Cheung Chau island So what have I missed? What should I remove? Anything I should add? Would appreciate all feedback. Thanks all

subject: 1. Re: Itinerary - sort of!
usertext: Hong Kong Geopark is stretched out, has great sights, but many are not easily accessible. Your best option for this is to go to High Island Reservoir East Dam - but you'll need a taxi to get there. Count on about 2 hrs of travel one way from Kowloon or Hong Kong Island. Wetland Park and Kadoorie Farm are very nice places to visit. Nam Shang Wai is nice as well, close to Wetland Park so can quite easily be combined. Neon signs: not many of those left these days. Could be an interesting tour nonetheless, I don't know it. Temple Street: reportedly still very dead, few visitors. Stanley Market I never really liked, and for the lack of tourists probably the same problems as Temple Street has. Lion Rock: great views, strenuous hike. It's very steep up. If you do, make sure to walk down via A-ma Rock. Dragons Back: nice views, easy hike, I'd put it on the backburner considering your other plans. Shenzhen: needs visa! making this not generally suitable for a day trip. Macau: travel time easily 3 hours one way. Can reasonably be done as a day trip but better stay for a day or two. Man Mo Temple, Chi Lin Nunnery, Star Ferry, Big Buddha - all nice things to do.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Itinerary - sort of!
usertext: Note that the Ngong Ping 360 cable car is closed for maintenance from 9th to 14th October inclusive so if you intend to visit the "Big Buddha" during that time, alternative transport from Tung Chung is bus 23 or blue taxi or an alternative route is via ferry from Central Pier 6 to Mui Wo then bus 2 from Mui Wo to Ngong Ping. You could also take the opportunity to combine the visit to the Buddha/Po Lin Monastery with the nearby fishing village of Tai O; https://www.discoverhongkong.com/uk/explore/great-outdoor/tai-o-fishing-village.html Tai O can be reached by bus 21 from Ngong Ping, bus 1 from Mui Wo and bus 11 from Tung Chung or a ferry service from Tung Chung Development Pier, a scenic ride alongside the airport island and the northern coast of Lantau Island, although it's not a frequent service; https://www.td.gov.hk/en/transport_in_hong_kong/public_transport/ferries/service_details/index.html#o07

subject: 3. Re: Itinerary - sort of!
usertext: You are visiting this month? Be mindful of our weather for your outdoor days. Supposed to be 34 degrees today which is dreadfully hot for hiking up to places like Lion Rock

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Itinerary - sort of!
usertext: Thanks all. Will take on board the things suggested and advice given. The weather isn't looking great for our first few days, warm but rainy so we may end up looking for indoor things to do!

subject: 5. Re: Itinerary - sort of!
usertext: I'd also suggest skipping Shenzhen and even Macau. Save it for the next trip. If this is your first time hiking in Hong Kong you may be surprised it's real hiking, not a walk in the park. Good shoes, clothing appropriate for the weather and water are essential. And head out early. It may take longer than you think and you don't want to spend the night in the hills. (I wouldn't call Dragon's Back "easy," by the way.) I think Lamma makes a better island trip than Cheung Chau. Nice walks and restaurants. (Too bad about the power plant, of course.) Don't forget The Peak at dusk as the city lights up and the nearby trail around The Peak. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Itinerary - sort of!
usertext: >>> (I wouldn't call Dragon's Back "easy," by the way.) I was applying Hong Kong standards for hikes. It's easy compared to hikes like the Lion Rock.

subject: Cash or credit card?
usertext: We're visiting Hong Kong for 2 weeks. I'll be taking some hkd with me to use for taxi and buying small things. Is Visa and Master card widely accepted in most restaurants and shops? Thanks in advance,

subject: 1. Re: Cash or credit card?
usertext: {Is Visa and Master card widely accepted in most restaurants and shops?} For the most part 'yes' and we use a smart card called the Octopus which you can download into your iPhone digital wallet and use to make wave payments or you can obtain an on loan physical card which is handy for lower expenditure amounts. See this thread about the Octopus Card which you should go ahead and pick up given that you will be here for two weeks. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14482045-Octopus_Card_2023-Hong_Kong.html

subject: 2. Re: Cash or credit card?
usertext: The answer depends. Smaller eateries tend to accept cash, Octopus mostly. They might also accept other forms of electronic payment like Alipay and Wechat but not necessarily credit cards. The same goes for smaller shops. In short, you should have some cash and/or a way to get cash (such as at an ATM machine).

subject: 3. Re: Cash or credit card?
usertext: Thank you for your valuable info. My mom is 66, so she's qualified for the elder Octopus card? While I'm reading the info on the Octopus card, It seems like I can purchase the cards at any MTR station and they accept cash only. I'll definitely take some HKD with me for the trip. However, do you recommend that I should use the ATM machine or take some Canadian cash with me and exchange it at the bank if needed? I'll be using my Visa for most of the time if accepted. Thanks again for all your help!

subject: 4. Re: Cash or credit card?
usertext: Use the ATM machines. You don't want to hassle with banks. Moneychangers in town usually have fair rates for USD and EUR but don't know about CAN.

subject: 5. Re: Cash or credit card?
usertext: Sounds good! Thank you!

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Cash or credit card?
usertext: Do the ATMs (especially airport ones) charge a fee? Should I try and find a bank one rather than one of the non bank that can charge a large fee?

subject: 7. Re: Cash or credit card?
usertext: #6 No. Banks in Hong Kong don't charge fees for cash withdrawals.

subject: 8. Re: Cash or credit card?
usertext: No bank ATMs in HK charge fees for cash withdrawal. There are hundreds of bank ATMs throughout the territory (far exceeding the number of non-bank ones). Choose any of HSBC, Bank of China, Hang Seng Bank, Citibank, Standard Chartered, or several other smaller banks.

subject: 9. Re: Cash or credit card?
usertext: But your own bank in Canada may charge fees if you use their cards overseas. You need to check with them as well.

subject: Hong kong arrival after midnight
usertext: Hi all We will arrive after midnight maybe after 3 am . Please advise on where to buy our octopus cards as I understand Klook counters are already closed so we're not planning on booking in advance . Is the bank at the airport open for 24 hours ? . We plan to take the N21 bus to our hotel at TST after arrival

subject: 1. Re: Hong kong arrival after midnight
usertext: No bank is open at that hour. There are ATM machines you can withdraw HKD cash. You cannot get Octopus Card at that hour. Just use USD cash (no change given when you pay to board N21 bus). At the airport, buy a cup of coffee or something at the 24-hour McDonald's. Get some small HKD bills/coins in change, enough to pay for your ride.

subject: 2. Re: Hong kong arrival after midnight
usertext: Hello Happyfeet Thank you so much for such quick & witty reply ! Have a nice day !

subject: 3. Re: Hong kong arrival after midnight
usertext: Glad that helps a little. I made a typing mistake in #1. I typed: "You cannot get Octopus Card at that hour. Just use USD cash (no change given when you pay to board N21 bus). " Of course I meant use HKD cash (Hong Kong dollar) while in Hong Kong, not USD. Sorry.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Hong kong arrival after midnight
usertext: You no longer need cash to pay bus fare if you don't have Octopus Card. You can use contactless debit or credit card or mobile payment such as Apple Pay, Huawei Pay; https://www.citybus.com.hk/en/uploadedFiles/app_promote/eps/EPS-ENG-1.html You can't obtain a physical on-loan Octopus Card at that time of night. If you have an iPhone you can download the Octopus App for tourists anytime before you leave for HK. This is a digital version of the on-loan Octopus; https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/tourist/apple-pay/index.html The sold version of Octopus (Tourist Octopus) can be obtained at the airport 24/7 from the 7-11 convenience store in the arrival hall or from MTR Ticket and Octopus Selling machines located near the arrival hall exits leading to Airport Station; https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/octopus-cards/products/sold-tourist/index.html

subject: 5. Re: Hong kong arrival after midnight
usertext: Thank you ! Have a nice day !

subject: Three hours in Hongkong
usertext: Hi all We shall have six hours transit time in Hongkong't in an upcoming trip.My wife has not been to the city. What is the best way to let her have a quick feel of the city? I suppose we can spend around three hours from airport to city and back. We are from India and have got PAR done. Thanks for any response.

subject: 1. Re: Three hours in Hongkong
usertext: Take the Airport Express train directly from the airport arrival hall to Hong Kong Station. Buy the "Same Day Return" ticket package - same price as the single journey to the Hong Kong Station. Basically the return trip is free. The ride to Hong Kong Station is under 30 minutes. Very fast. Once you are at Hong Kong Station, walk outside towards "Central Pier #7" (Star Ferry). You can ride the Star Ferry to Kowloon (Tsim Sha Tsui) and back, for a short harbour crossing cruise. (The crossing takes only about 10 minutes). Or you can walk around the Central Promenade with the iconic view of the Victoria Harbour. You can do both - ride the Star Ferry round trip, then walk around the promenade. Have a soda drink or snack or something. That's about all the time you have, and then back to Hong Kong Station to ride the AE train back to the Airport. Very convenient. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Three hours in Hongkong
usertext: Solid suggestion by HappyFeet above. Some other resources for planning a layover in Hong Kong can be found and read here -> https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14493334-Layovers_in_Hong_Kong_2023-Hong_Kong.html

usertext: Just wondering if it's cheaper to take an Uber or taxi from the airport to Mongkok Hotels? Will they accept cash as I won't be able to get the Octopus card till I get to one of the MTR station. Thanks in advance!

subject: 1. Re: Uber or taxi from airport to Mongkok hotels?
usertext: Depending on the hotel, it may be a lot cheaper to take an airport bus. And you can get your Octopus card at the MTR service kiosk right at the airport. To answer your question, Uber is in a grey area, not officially legal or illegal. But I thought Uber only takes credit card? On the other hand, I think very few taxis take cards (credit card or Octopus). So cash is king.

subject: 2. Re: Uber or taxi from airport to Mongkok hotels?
usertext: Thanks for the quick reply! We'll be staying at the Holiday Express Hotel in Mongkok. However, our flight does not arrive till 11:30 pm. It's getting late and exhausting, so probably the best option is to take a taxi or Uber ( I do have an Uber app on my cell). Is it easy to get a taxi from the airport? Thanks again for all your help,

subject: 3. Re: Uber or taxi from airport to Mongkok hotels?
usertext: Yes it's easy to get a taxi. Just go to the taxi queue just outside the arrival hall. Get some HKD from a bank ATM machine at the airport first (maybe HKD 500 to 1,000?).

subject: 4. Re: Uber or taxi from airport to Mongkok hotels?
usertext: Taxis are always readily available and generally cheaper than Uber. Also you don't need to search for your taxi (very clearly signposted where to find them, a short walk from arrivals), like you have to search for your Uber (no signage; good luck navigating the car parks if you're not familiar with the place). Taxis are cash only; Mongkok should be around $250-280 I remember.

subject: 5. Re: Uber or taxi from airport to Mongkok hotels?
usertext: Thank you everyone!

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Uber or taxi from airport to Mongkok hotels?
usertext: I used Uber yesterday, payment options included cash, Google pay, credit or debit card, PayPal. (I'm travelling from the UK).

subject: thrift stores or deals on clothes, etc. in Hong Kong
usertext: Looking for thrift stores and/ or stores or markets that might have deals on mostly women's clothing. Going in a few weeks.

subject: 1. Re: thrift stores or deals on clothes, etc. in Hong Kong
usertext: There are some thrift store style places selling second hand clothes around the city (see link) https://www.sassyhongkong.com/thrift-stores-hong-kong-style/ Otherwise, if you are looking for lower cost women's clothing you can try places like Argyle Centre (low price), T.O.P. (leans trendy but some low price) in Mongkok. There are more options as well in this area of the city but these two are goo places to start. https://www.argylecentre.com.hk/?lang=en https://www.linkhk.com/en/shop/?scid=163 Allied Plaza isn't another place, arcade style w/ low price & trendy in Prince Edwards (see link). Similarly, quite a few more places like this around the city, especially in Kowloon. https://en.tripadvisor.com.hk/ShowUserReviews-g294217-d2617194-r818313284-Allied_Plaza_SHOPPING-Hong_Kong.html if you want to visit loads of small, boutique and retail style shops dealing in women's clothing you can head over to Cheung Sha Wan Road between Lai Chi Kok and Sham Shui Po (see link) https://www.discoverhongkong.com/us/interactive-map/cheung-sha-wan-road-fashion.html Some similar options on HK Island around Causeway Bay starting with Jardine's Crescent street market (see link) and LaForet (see link) https://www.discoverhongkong.com/in/interactive-map/jardine-s-crescent-street-market.html https://www.nextstophongkong.com/laforet/

subject: 3. Re: thrift stores or deals on clothes, etc. in Hong Kong
usertext: The various Salvation Army stores are the places that have the familiar thrift-store vibe.

subject: 4. Re: thrift stores or deals on clothes, etc. in Hong Kong
usertext: Also be aware that store clerks would not hesitate to publicly comment on your size and shape.

subject: Transport to hotel and mobile SIM
usertext: Hi, Looking forward to returning to HK after 5 years. I am staying this time at Eco tree hotel Causeway Bay (between Tin Hau and Fortress Hill I believe). I have always used the AirPort Express on previous visits and used the hotel shuttle bus service from HK station. I have not stayed at this particular hotel before and wonder what is the most convenient way to travel from the airport, arriving about 5.30pm. Well versed with the MTR but not so with bus service. I know the hotel shuttle bus service is very much reduced now from pre-Covid days and doesn't cover this hotel. Secondly, I have looked at the data package that my provider (EE) offer and it's about 74hkd per day (I will be there for 14 days). Any advice on a local sim? Don't use for streaming or anything just for google etc as will have Wi-Fi in hotel. Thank you in advance.

subject: 1. Re: Transport to hotel and mobile SIM
usertext: Here is a perfect solution for you: don't mess with MTR or Airport Express. Simply take Airport Bus A11. It departs from the bus terminus at the Airport (follow the signs for "Buses" to the bus terminus). Route information here (A11), click on direction "To North Point Ferry Pier": https://mobile.citybus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=A11&dsmode=1&l=1 Fare is HKD $41.9. You don't need any transfer. Alight at bus stop #18 "Gordon Road". From that bus stop, the Eco Tree Hotel is only 120 meters away on leveled streets. Even taxi can't get much closer than that. Link to Google Map from bus stop to hotel: https://maps.app.goo.gl/hdgikw3fCLHnAUTT9 = = = = = SIM card: check one of the recent threads. Prices are in HKD. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14384791-Best_sim_card_in_HK-Hong_Kong.html Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Transport to hotel and mobile SIM
usertext: You may want to take airport bus A11. Exit at Fortress Hill Station. It's about a 5 min walk to your hotel.

subject: 3. Re: Transport to hotel and mobile SIM
usertext: My esteemed colleague HappyFeet's direction is much better than mine. Gordon Street is much better than Fortress Hill Station. What do I know? I grew up in Kowloon. HK Island is like a foreign country to me.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Transport to hotel and mobile SIM
usertext: Thank you to both of you. I shall use the airport bus and then use the MTR and the tram for getting about. Will check the link re SIM.

subject: Itinerary help
usertext: I will be arriving at 6:45 a.m. and expect I will be tired and jet lagged my first day. I have 3 days; I'll board my cruise ship the last day in the afternoon. I plan to drop off my luggage at my hotel in TST upon arrival. I want to take the Star Ferry, and go to the Peak tram at some point, but wonder if this is a good idea for my first day? I also want to go to the Big Buddha on Lantau, but I'm not even sure of the best way to get there, and how much time to allow for this area. I also would like to see the Chi Lin Nunnery. I'm thinking a hop on, hop off bus tour might be a good way to get an overview of the city, and I can do this even if I'm tired. I'm hoping for some advice on a good way to spend my first day, before I can eventually check in and take a nap! any advice on other sights is much appreciated. I am not much of a shopper.

subject: 1. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: The Peak, the Big Buddha, and Chi Lin are pretty far apart. I would do the Star Ferry and Peak Tram on your first day. Have lunch (try to avoid the very busy workers' lunch hours). Then check in and do your nap.

subject: 2. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: {I also want to go to the Big Buddha on Lantau, but I'm not even sure of the best way to get there, and how much time to allow for this area.} You can use the MTR to make way from TST to Tung Chung for your visit to the Big Buddha. If you want to take the Ngong Ping Cable car, they usually begin running from the Lower Terminus at Tung Chung at 10am so you can start there and then and allow 2-2.5 hours for cable car rides up and down and time spend viewing the Big Buddha, Po Lin Monastery and Ngong Ping village or if you want to add on a side trip to Tai O Village budget another 2-3 hours time. I would suggest doing this the second morning and not trying to combine a visit here with the Star Ferry and Peak on your first arrival day.

subject: 3. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: Thank you for your advice. I will leave the Chi Lin Nunnery for the 3rd day then I think.

subject: 4. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: One more question - is there a bus I can take to the Peak tram from the Star Ferry? I have some old notes from a friend that mentions bus 15C, but I wonder if that's still the case. I know it's only about a 20-25 minute walk, but I do expect I'll be walking around once I'm at the Peak too. Thanks!

subject: 5. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: @chewpei, #4: Yes route 15C is still current: Link: https://mobile.citybus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=15c&dsmode=1&l=1 It has been around for at least 50 years. I had first taken it when I was small. :)

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 6. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: Bus 15C still operates to the Lower Peak Tram Terminus on Garden Road every 30 mins from 10am to 10pm; https://www.citybus.com.hk/en/uploadedFiles/cust_notice/TS-NWFB-15C-15C-D.pdf

subject: 7. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: Looking at the map from my travel book it appears I'm halfway there if I walk to Garden Road from the ferry pier - or am I incorrect? Or does the bus take Garden Road to get there and can I get on near the ferry? I don't mean to be dense, but I will be operating on whatever sleep I get in my economy seat on a very long flight, so I need specific directions or I will be wandering in a daze! And the Octopus card works on MTR and buses? But not the ferry?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 8. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: The Lower Peak Tram Terminus on Garden Road is where the Peak Tram begins its steep uphill journey to the Peak, the upper terminus of the Peak Tram being located inside the Peak Tower. Octopus works on ferries as well as buses and MTR. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 9. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: My question is where do I get on bus 15C? Near where I get off the ferry? Or farther up Garden Road?

subject: 10. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: As soon as you get off the Star Ferry and walk out of Pier 7 you will see bus stops to your immediate right. One of them is for bus 15C to the Peak. If you have a look at Star Ferry Pier 7 on google maps, it will be very clear.

subject: 11. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: Thank you so much!

subject: 13. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: @chewpei: If you are really really really tired that morning, keep the following idea in your backpocket: There is another bus, route #15 (not #15C) that runs from Central Pier to The Peak. Basically it has the same end-points compared to "Bus #15C plus Peak Tram" combination. It is one bus ride, from end-to-end. It will take you to The Peak. And you can take the Peak Tram down afterwards (though traveling backwards on the tram because of the steep tracks). Bus 15 starts from Central Pier 5 (2 piers over, a very short distance), but it stops outside of Central Pier 7 (Star Ferry) to pick up passengers before going on to the rest of the route. If you are really really really tired, you can take Bus 15 up to the peak instead of taking the 2-leg journey (15C + Peak Tram). Take a front row seat on the top of the double-decker bus. Enjoy the view along the way - pretty much the same way as your thought of taking the hop-on/hop-off bus. You may likely even take a nap during that journey. That's okay. The seats are comfortable. At the Peak, outside the Peak Tower, if you take the Mount Ausin Road going further uphill (the one and only road that allows automobile traffic), about 700 feet away, there is a small park "Mount Austin Playground". It is a community park. You can even sleep lying down! You are in a park! Recharge. But bring something to lie on. And perhaps a jacket. Link to Mount Austin Playground: https://maps.app.goo.gl/5scS8h3XFXWHNXdU9 Link to Bus 15 info: http://mobile.citybus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=15--The_Peak&l=1 Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 14. Re: Itinerary help
usertext: What HappyFeeet says works, but for me the Peak Tram uphill and the #15 bus downhill is the best combination.

subject: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Hey guys what are some of your favourite fast food eats in Hong Kong ? I've tried yoshinoya beef bowl, was ok. Cafe de coral was pretty terrible tbh. McDonald's is ok. I like eating pretty much anything so recommendations welcome.

subject: 1. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Anything from Cha chaan teng, or siu mei rice, this this rice

subject: 2. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Wake up!  You are in HONG KONG. One of the best places for food in the world. Don't go "fast food". McD??? Just go to any of the local "Cha chaan teng" types of restaurants, as mentioned. (The term in Cantonese means the hall for tea and meals.) Basically those are the everyday affairs, good eats, Hong Kong style. And it is in Hong Kong, everything is FAST.

subject: 3. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: I prefer fast food stores over Cha chaan teng. Most of the Cha chaan teng are crowded and below average, way overrated. Maybe Tai Hang is one of the ok one.

subject: 4. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: I mean Tai Hing

subject: 5. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: I mean Tai Hing tea restaurant.

subject: 6. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Yes have been to tai hing before and there noodles are very good. I do plan to go to the dairy milk company to try there ramen and toast

subject: 7. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: More of what I'd call street food but I like Wow Charsui, Hot Star Fried Chicken and King of Coconut.... and have to admit passing by Hana Musubi branches far too often. https://www.wowcharsiu.com/ https://www.timeout.com/hong-kong/restaurants/hot-star-large-fried-chicken https://www.discoverhongkong.com/uk/interactive-map/king-of-coconut.html https://www.h-musubi.com/en/

subject: 8. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: For wondon noodle, I recommend Tsim Chai Kee Noodle, which operates like fast food store. For Yunnan Noodles/Rice Noodles, I recommend Mixian Sense. Some like tamjai samgor mixian, but I think the soup is too salty.

subject: 9. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: A few more that have come to mind since posting earlier... Zanchee is a pretty decent place to pickup quick bibimbap & Korean style fried chicken. Bengal Bros for kathi rolls (basically wraps) and Salfee Bar (quick and healthy salad style orders).... None are classic western style fast food restaurants but I tend to treat them that way, pop in for quick, affordable pick-up orders that I can take home, eat there in some cases or on the go.

subject: 10. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: For Western taste, try MOS burger or Oliver's Super Sandwich.

subject: 11. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Been to a few wonton places but found them a little hit and miss. Sometimes the noodles aren't that good or the broth lacks flavour. Which congee places do you recommend?

subject: 12. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Congee: Tim Choi Kee at Kowloon City is pretty decent. They also serve some of the cha chann teng standards like ramen noodles. Chiu Chow Style fish balls, beef brisket, dumpling noodles: Kong Chai Kee (Causeway Bay near Times Square) Australia Dairy Company: their food is ok but the tables are tight. Go early on weekday mornings of later in the day to avoid lines. Closed Thursdays. The best items there are actually their steamed egg custard and steamed milk custard. Mixian (rice noodles): Tam Jai and Tam Jai Sam Gor are the most popular, generally more highly regarded than Mixian Sense (which is a Cafe de Coral restaurant). For cha chang teng, try Soul Kithcen ().. I am not saying they are the best but I regard them as above average. Note that it's very hard to get people to agree on which cha chann teng's are good due to the wide variety of dishes served and the varying taste buds. Overall, I suggest you avoid the mega chains like Cafe de Coral, Fairwood, Maxim's MX, and even Tai Hing (overpriced and very average in my books). Try Mu Taiwan Noodle if you are interested in Taiwanese style beef noodles.

subject: 13. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: For congee, I like Law Fu Kee in central. They also have good wonton noodle.

subject: 14. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Cafe de coral is good usually only for hotpot dinner, or for their takeout bbq menu.

subject: 15. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Did their used to be a tam jai in festival walk around 5 years ago? Because that was so salty and spicy.

subject: 16. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Yes, there is a Tam Jai noodle at Festivals walk. Shop L2-20, 2/F, Festival Walk

subject: 17. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: The Tami Jai is still there at Festival Walk. That one is open for breakfast, too. However, I do have a friend who goes there occasionally She says that one isn't as good as the other locations. Law Fu Kee has been around forever. I might have visited once years ago but I know it's pretty highly regarded by many.

subject: 18. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Actually surprisingly enjoyed some fried toast with peanut butter from cafe de coral yesterday. Although it came cold  the locals seem to order the fried noodles or the char siu rice

subject: 19. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: I think cafe de coral is OK for its price. I usually eat cafe de coral or Mixian Sense for lunch, use their app to order 15 minutes in advance and pickup the food.

subject: 20. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: The toast came out cold because fast food chains make stuff in batches. From that perspective, cha chann teng is always better.

subject: 21. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Some cha chann teng also make stuff in batches, some have lower hygiene and more crowded. cha chann teng is not always better.

subject: 22. Re: Favourite fast food eats
usertext: Fav eats around shatin

subject: Hotels with best harbor views
usertext: Hi, we are staying at 11.-13. February and looking for a hotel with the best Victoria harbor views. Especially, it would be great to see the fireworks from our room or the hotel terrace / lounge. I'm thinking of the below hotels, could you please advise on them or recommend another one which is not on my list? Four Seasons and Rosewood is out of my budget unfortunately and Regent has no availabilty :/ Thank you! Hyatt Regency TST Grand Hyatt Sheraton & Towers Intercontinental Grand Stanford Kowloon Shangri La Renaissance Harbor View

subject: 1. Re: Hotels with best harbor views
usertext: RE: "best Victoria harbor views." Kowloon Shangri La <=== THIS one. Take this one. Best harbour view unblocked (presuming you take the view side, of course). For the fireworks, this one will be the best. Hyatt Regency TST - only on higher floors. Something like >25/F or so? Because the lower floors are surrounded by neighboring buildings. Those rooms at higher floors are likely suites, club rooms or something like that - roomtypes that are at higher price than regular rooms. You can ask the hotel. Grand Hyatt - the harbour view room should be good. From the Hong Kong side. Sheraton & Towers - this one is tricky. To have good harbour view, you need to pick rooms that are at the south-west corner. Only a few per floor, and at a higher floor to clear the obstruction from the Space Museum. Or else the view is blocked by The Peninsular, or by Regent. Intercontinental Grand Stanford - the view is not that good. It is to the side of the hotel and not the prime angle. Renaissance Harbor View - this one is similar to Grand Hyatt. Harbour view room should be good. Check the hotel review page on photographs submitted by their customers to get some ideas. The real gem is YMCA Salisbury Hotel, harbourview rooms. If you can book it for your dates. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Hotels with best harbor views
usertext: And if you find the harbour view room rates more impressive than the fireworks display itself, just grab a normal city facing room and walk over to the TST promenade (Kowloon), Central Promenade or Tamar Park (HK Island) and enjoy the display from one of the harbour front locations with the rest of us for free. ;-)

subject: 3. Re: Hotels with best harbor views
usertext: Thanks @HappyFeet1234 for the detailed overview and advice, very useful! @BradJill, after checking the prices you must be right :)) In general all hotels have skyhigh prices for these dates, what I completely understand. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Hotels with best harbor views
usertext: I would be concerned with the Wan Chai North area (Renaissance Harbourview and Grand Hyatt). There is constant construction going on. Even though the harbor view itself can be excellent, the minute you look down, you might see a lot of construction vehicles and dirt. YMCA was renovated not too long ago so it might indeed be a good choice. Kowloon Shang: ever since the new K11 Musea/Rosewood complex got built, a lot of the views to Central is blocked. I have no idea how much of the fireworks view can still be seen as a result. For fireworks from a public setting, a view from Tamar Park might be ideal since it's usually much less crowded that TST promenade.

subject: transport from airport to East Hong Kong hotel in Taikoshing
usertext: We will arrive at about 8am on 23/10 and stay at East Hong Kong hotel. If we catch taxi roughly how much will the fares be? If we want to catch public transport, which route will be the best? Thanks ahead.

subject: 1. Re: transport from airport to East Hong Kong hotel in Taikoshing
usertext: From the HK Airport website (see link) - estimate fare $355 https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/to-from-airport/taxis.page If you want to take one of the Airport Bus lines go with A12 which has drop off at CityPlaza (King's Road) around 350 metres from East Hong Kong Hotel. If you have a look at Google Maps you can see the various public transportation options between HKIA and East Hong Kong Hotel, including using Airport Express to Hong Kong Station and MTR to Tai Koo MTR Station (exit D1) is right outside the hotel. This is another option you might want to consider for travelling to the hotel depending on how much luggage you have.

subject: Free Airport Express Train Ticket - HK Goodies
usertext: Hong Kong Tourism Board website mentions that as part of HK Goodies vouchers, it is possible to get free one way airport express train ticket to Hong Kong island. However it is impossible to understand how to redeem it. The information in its website is very vague and even the free drink option is not available at the moment. Has anyone recently claimed these vouchers and specifically got the free airport express ticket?

subject: 1. Re: Free Airport Express Train Ticket - HK Goodies
usertext: Really? It seems pretty straightforward to me. I am accessing their discoverhongkong.com website from USA. You just click on the link to go to one page for the instructions on how to redeem. Link: https://www.discoverhongkong.com/us/deals/hkgoodies.html#where-to-get-the-offer You just visit one of the 3 Hong Kong Tourism Board Visitor Centres. The one at Hong Kong International Airport is most convenient. Because you land at that airport (but will need to take a few minutes to do this before you leave the airport). Hong Kong International Airport Visitor Centre Address: Buffer Halls A and B, Arrivals Level, Terminal 1, Hong Kong International Airport, Lantau Island Distribution hours: 8am to 9pm daily Or else if you are too tired after landing or don't want to spend the time at that moment, you can visit their other 2 visitor centres: Kowloon Redemption Centre (this is most likely the most convenient one) Address: Star Ferry Concourse, Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon Distribution hours: 10am to 8pm daily Hong Kong West Kowloon Station Redemption Centre Address: GFM Level, Hong Kong West Kowloon Station, Kowloon Distribution hours: 9am to 6pm daily = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = What they want from you to show your eligibility: 1) You are staying in Hong Kong for 90 days or less (really mean visiting, not moving to Hong Kong long-term). 2) With a non-Hong Kong mobile number Visit one of the Hong Kong Tourism Board Visitor Centres on arrival to collect your visitor consumption voucher in person. Please bring a copy of your valid overseas travel document to prove your eligibility.

subject: 2. Re: Free Airport Express Train Ticket - HK Goodies
usertext: P.S. It looks like you have to choose from one of the 3 gifts. A drink, or a HKD $100 cash voucher for dining or shopping or attraction fee, or a free transportation ticket, (or a special gift). You don't get all 3. Just one of the 3. If you choose the transportation ticket voucher (Airport Express single-journey train ticket), once you get the voucher, you just walk to the Airport Express Customer Service center (at the airport) and redeem it as your AE train ticket to Hong Kong Station. (Recap: Visit the Hong Kong Tourism Board visitor center first, get the voucher, then to the Airport Express Customer Service counter at the airport, to redeem the voucher for the actual train ticket.) A 2-step process. Caveat: This is my interpretation of the process. Edited: 1 year ago
