subject: Regarding HK Disneyland operation
usertext: Is the HK Disneyland and Ocean park open completely for tourists?. I see some important information about outdoor operations not operational due to weather singnal no.3. What does this mean?. Our trip is planned from 20th-23rd Oct in HK and Macau. Should we reschedule?. How is the weather in HK and Macau now?. Kindly help.

subject: 1. Re: Regarding HK Disneyland operation
usertext: By the time of your arrival, the current typhoon (Koinu) will be long gone. On the other hand, we cannot predict storm formation more than a few days in advance. There is no reason to make any changes at this point.

subject: 2. Re: Regarding HK Disneyland operation
usertext: outdoor operations not operational due to weather singnal no.3. What does this mean? It means there is a typhoon (big storm) coming near HK. Storm signal can go up to no. 9. But in 2 weeks this storm will be long gone. But no one knows if there may be another storm. Keep your eyes on the weather.

subject: 3. Re: Regarding HK Disneyland operation
usertext: The Typhoon signal 3 has been lowered with typhoon Koinu being far enough away from Hong Kong so places like Disneyland and Ocean Park should be back to operating per usual today.

subject: 5. Re: Regarding HK Disneyland operation
usertext: Thank you very much

subject: Mtr
usertext: Hi I was planning on getting the airport express to Hong Kong / Central and then on the blue line to HKU, but have read this and am now worried about using the MTR with a larger than carry on suitcase. Can anyone advise please? Baggage MTR does not permit anything more than the airport carry-on luggage size. Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Mtr
usertext: It is theoretical. How many check-in size big suitcases do you have? Just 1 or 2+? How many people in your party? Just you or 2+? You can always take a short taxi ride from the Hong Kong Station up to HKU.

subject: 2. Re: Mtr
usertext: I'd go for the Airport Express and a cab as suggested. It won't be more than HK$60 to anywhere for which HKU is the nearest MTR. Or if money is an issue then look at the CityFlyer buses: A12 or A10 might work, depending on your exact destination and time of arrival. Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Mtr
usertext: Thanks. I've never heard of this on mass transit before to be honest. There are 2 of us and 2 big but not enormous suitcases, approx 20kg each. I'll look at the cab idea but I'm disappointed we can't use the MTR. I'd say for environmental reasons such as air quality but as we will just have flown to the other side of the world that doesn't really wash does it

subject: 4. Re: Mtr
usertext: You'd probably be OK, but remember that Central MTR is quite a long walk (underground) from HK Station where the Airport Express arrives. And no doubt there's a walk from HKU MTR to your destination. Really, just cab it - the cab will be sitting running its engine whether it's transporting you or not! Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 5. Re: Mtr
usertext: Good advice, thanks

subject: 6. Re: Mtr
usertext: I am with HK Ga Yau. A short taxi ride to bridge the gap is more practical. If you opt to proceed with riding the MTR Island Line: *) I don't think anyone will come up and challenge you about your suitcases. MTR doesn't hire staff to check at every gate in every station to police passengers lugging their belongings. (Maybe unless someone is trucking a ridiculous huge cargo that may catch the eyes of some monitoring the close circuit TV). *) I hope you are not arriving during the evening commuter rush hours. During those hours, the subway cars may be packed. *) Be courteous and don't lay your suitcases where they block other passengers getting through. One way is to move to the tail end of the train (the driver is in the front of the train), and ride in the last car. There will be no passengers walking through between cars. The tail end usually is less crowded than the middle of the train anyway. *) Don't compete with other passengers when you alight at your HKU station taking the escalator up from the train platform to the ticketing lobby. Usually that's where the congestion is. Wait for 2 minutes or so after your train has departed when most of the passengers have already gone up. Take your time to lug your suitcases. *) Use elevators (whenever available instead of escalators) Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: Mtr
usertext: We made it. Took the airport express train on our newly purchased Octopus card and then a taxi to our hotel. All very easy. Thanks all for the help

subject: Lunch for one
usertext: I'd love to hear where people would recommend for a nice weekday lunch for one (Australian female). Not keen a a set/degustation menu though. Happy to travel a bit out for a nice view or setting. Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Lunch for one
usertext: Majority of the seaside restaurants in Sai Kung or Lamma island would work. Great view, relatively quiet on weekdays. If you prefer something meatier, you could try Smoke & Barrel or Braza Churrasco, both smack dab in the middle of LKF, central.

subject: 2. Re: Lunch for one
usertext: Lunch at one of the harbour-side seafood restaurants in Sai Kung is tops for setting but at least be aware that some of the restaurants there have a reputation for taking liberties with pricing. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Lunch for one
usertext: I eat solo lunch around the city several days of the week, your options are limitless. Have a think of what cuisine type you are interested in and whereabouts you plan to be and then you can search via openrice, google reviews or here on TA for options.

subject: 4. Re: Lunch for one
usertext: If your budget can support it, a nice lunch at the Tosca di Angelo Restaurant on top of the Ritz-Carlton hotel would provide a spectacular view along with world-class Italian cuisine. If you prefer a sea-level view with more casual atmosphere, you could also check out the Lobby Lounge in the Regent hotel.

subject: 5. Re: Lunch for one
usertext: Be careful you don't run into the weekday office lunch time. Otherwise, the choice is indeed limitless. How about dim sum? Maxim's, City Hall.

subject: 6. Re: Lunch for one
usertext: The downside of eating dim sum by yourself is you probably won't be able to sample too many items unless you end up wasting a lot of food. As to seafood places, some that cater more to visitors (like the ones at Lamma and Sai Kung) might have set menus for one. More importantly, what kind of food do you want?

subject: 7. Re: Lunch for one
usertext: Thanks for the suggestions. I like lots of types of food but not so much red meat. My budget does stretch to somewhere nice but I'm just don't want a degustation/big set menu which many of the hotel restaurants seem to have. The seafood or the Italian seem to be the way to go. I'll save the dim sum until I have my husband to share with :)

subject: 8. Re: Lunch for one
usertext: Try one of the food courts in a shopping mall. Plenty of options for single diners. Again, avoid the office lunch rush.

subject: Airport to Royal Plaza Hotel
usertext: I know this has been asked many times before, but I am struggling to make a decision. In a few weeks, we (2 people) will be in HK for the first time. We'll be staying at the Royal Plaza Hotel near Mong Kok East. We arrive on a weekday at 3 pm, and we'll have luggage with us. I guess we'll be out of the airport by around 4 pm, so I assume the traffic will be particularly bad by the time we get into the center. As far as I can see, the older topics on this are out of date because the various hotel shuttles are no longer running. So the options now are: A21 bus: but the stop is about 15 mins walk away, which sounds like a hassle with a suitcase through busy streets. Airport Express train to Kowloon station, then a taxi (but how easy is it to figure out taxis when you get to the station?) This is possibly the fastest option. Airport Express and then multiple changes on the metro. This also sounds like a hassle, and there are few things more annoying than tourists and luggage on the metro when people are trying to get home from work. Red taxi from the airport. This is listed as costing around 300 HKD, which is OK for 2 people, but if (when) the traffic is bad, how much will that increase by? If the most we are likely to pay is, say, 400 HKD, then a taxi seems easiest. But if it could end up costing 600 or 700 HKD because of traffic, then maybe not. What's the best option?

subject: 1. Re: Airport to Royal Plaza Hotel
usertext: Since you have 2 in your party, just take taxi direct. Don't mess with taking Airport Express to Kowloon Station Plus something. 2 tickets would already be HKD $105 x 2 = $210. Plus taxi fare. That's just a wash. Changing to other MTR lines with luggage is a drag. Taking the A21 bus and walk to the hotel is okay. But you are walking among some of the busiest streets in Mong Kok area, plus the confusion of needing to use elevated walkpaths to cross streets. Not easy for a first-time arrival. Unless you want to pinch the pennies, I would take a taxi. Rush hours in Hong Kong doesn't come that early (4 pm). Unless it is crossing a tunnel under the harbour (you are not, you are going to Kowloon). No it wont be HKD 600 to 700, I can assure you. The "stuck in traffic" time-charge jumps HKD $1.3 per minute (after a long distance, and it will be coming from the airport). 1 hour stuck in traffic would cost you HKD $78 extra. You won't reach that high. My guess is a 30 minutes delay, max, going to Royal Plaza. Link to Hong Kong Taxi Fare calculator: https://www.td.gov.hk/en/transport_in_hong_kong/public_transport/taxi/taxi_fare_of_hong_kong/index.html P.S. Plus HKD $6 per luggage in the boot. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Airport to Royal Plaza Hotel
usertext: As HappyFeet says - take a taxi. It is extremely unlikely to go over HK$400.

subject: 3. Re: Airport to Royal Plaza Hotel
usertext: That's really helpful. Thanks for the fast response.

subject: Where do Hongkongers go for family break?
usertext: Hi all, Where do Hongkongers go to escape the city and relax with their family? Thailand? We have a young toddler who will be 1.5 years old. Looking for relaxing in/around hotel so decent pool is a must. Maybe somewhere with a beach but not essential. Thanks!

subject: 2. Re: Where do Hongkongers go for family break?
usertext: Kota Kinabulu has a couple of Shangri-La resorts that make for nice 2-3 night getaways.

subject: 3. Re: Where do Hongkongers go for family break?
usertext: For family vacation, Japan is the most popular for HKgers. For beach vacation, Phuket is the most popular.

subject: 5. Re: Where do Hongkongers go for family break?
usertext: Japan is the most popular spot overall but not necessarily with younger children. With a toddler, the best Japanese destination is likely Okinawa. If you visit there, you should plan on renting a car as public transport is not very efficient. Many Thai beaches and resort towns (not just Phuket) are popular and relatively affordable. Unlike Okinanwa, pool access will be all year round at various Thai properties.

subject: 6. Re: Where do Hongkongers go for family break?
usertext: Many Hongkongers go to Taiwan, Japan or Mainland China for short break. But if you looking for a decent pool for relax. Bettet to go Bali if you have enough time. Otherwise go to Thailand if your time is complex.

subject: 7. Re: Where do Hongkongers go for family break?
usertext: Locals on a tighter budget will simply head for outlying islands or New Territories. Outside of weekends and major public holidays there are plenty of both bargains and peace & quiet to be had.

subject: 8. Re: Where do Hongkongers go for family break?
usertext: If you count those 2-day break, the new trend is going to Shenzhen or Greater Bay Area.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 9. Re: Where do Hongkongers go for family break?

subject: 10. Re: Where do Hongkongers go for family break?

Thanks for the responses so far everyone. Lots of great ideas - at the moment we are thinking 1 night over in Macau at one of the hotels to enjoy the facilities and possibly 4-5 nights in Kota Kinabalu / Thailand / Indonesia, again to relax and enjoy the facilities at a resort / beach setting.

subject: 11. Re: Where do Hongkongers go for family break?

subject: Use of Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch for Children

subject: 1. Re: Use of Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch for Children
usertext: Child Octopus is not available for iPhone, only Adult and Elder versions are available; https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/mobile-payment/apple-pay/about/index.html

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Use of Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch for Children
usertext: Having read through the various FAQ's which I find a little confusing I'm still not quite sure but according to Q5 at the link below it appears you can link two cards to the wallet in the Octopus app; https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/customer-service/faq/wallet/link-card.html

subject: 4. Re: Use of Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch for Children
usertext: Frankly I find it counter productive to use the Octopus card on a phone. It's much easier and simpler to just use the card, you don't even need to take it out of your wallet or purse. You don't need to take your phone out, put in the security code, get to the app, then scan the app. After doing all that, 5 people have already walked past you just scanning their cards. And linking 2 cards on the same phone is even more troublesome. After scanning one card, you then have to go scan the second card for the second person. Don't be surprised when some impatient HKer (and there are lots of them) express some displeasure.

subject: 5. Re: Use of Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch for Children
usertext: "You don't even need to take it out of your purse"? If I have an Octopus card it scans it from my bag? When you purchase the card do you choose how much $ to load on it? What do you recommend for a 3 day visit? Thanks for any advice!

subject: 6. Re: Use of Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch for Children
usertext: "You don't need to take your phone out, put in the security code, get to the app, then scan the app" With Octopus set as Express Transit Card on an iPhone you don't need to turn the screen on or open the app to make payments, you just tap it on the reader in the same way as with a physical card; https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/customer-service/faq/tourist-apple-pay/use.html

usertext: I have an Android phone. Plan on buying a card.

subject: 8. Re: Use of Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch for Children
usertext: With Octopus set as Express Transit Card on an iPhone you don't need to turn the screen on or open the app to make payments, you just tap it on the reader in the same way as with a physical card; You do if you have to switch to a second card.

subject: 9. Re: Use of Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch for Children
usertext: If the new CEO of Octopus Cards has his way the physical Octopus probably won't be around much longer; https://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news/section/2/208778/Octopus-wants-to-be-on-every-phone,-says-new-CEO

subject: 10. Re: Use of Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch for Children
usertext: I don't see physical cards disappearing for many years yet - many elderly people don't use mobiles and there are still quite a few people around who have simple phones, not smartphones. And many people prefer not to support the surveillance state (and all the social credit scoring that it enables), preferring anonymous Octopus cards. Many people still use cash to pay for buses and trams. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 11. Re: Use of Octopus on iPhone or Apple Watch for Children
usertext: "If I have an Octopus card it scans it from my bag?" You need to position the Octopus card carefully in your wallet or bag and present the wallet/bag to the reader in the appropriate orientation. The card needs to be within about 1 cm of the reader.

subject: HK DisneyLand Admission
usertext: Hello everyone, Sorry for all these questions as we'll be in HK next month. My mom wants to come to Disneyland with us when we're there. Just wondering what's the admission for a 67-year-old. I noticed on their website, for 60-64 yrs old with a valid HKID, would only cost them $100 hkd. However, there's no mention of the 65 and over age group. She has no HKID, just a Canadian passport. Thanks in advance....greatly appreciated.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: HK DisneyLand Admission
usertext: 1-Day admission ticket for senior overseas visitor age 65 and over is HK$100 (unchanged for the last 12 years). HK residents with JoyYou Card are eligible for the HK$100 senior concession at age 60 instead of 65.

subject: 2. Re: HK DisneyLand Admission
usertext: Thank you for your reply....greatly appreciated. What's the best option to purchase the tickets? Online or at the gate? Is there MTR from Mongkong ( we're staying at the Holiday Inn Express ) to Disneyland? Or maybe we should just take a taxi instead? Thanks for all your help again!

subject: 3. Re: HK DisneyLand Admission
usertext: {Thank you for your reply....greatly appreciated. What's the best option to purchase the tickets? Online or at the gate?} If you want to be able to walk in when you arrive at the theme park than it is best to purchase online in advance. If you prefer to spend time in a queue making your ticket purchase when you arrive at the theme park then wait to make purchase on the day at the gate. {Is there MTR from Mongkong ( we're staying at the Holiday Inn Express ) to Disneyland?} Open up google maps and input Disneyland. Click Direction, then input Hong Kong Inn Express Mongkok. The search results will show you a couple of different MTR routes to the Park that require an initial walk over to Olympia MTR station or Yau Ma Tai MTR Station. Neither route is direct and requires 1-2 changes before arriving at the Disneyland Resort. I would also recommend downloading and making use of Citymapper app on your mobile phone if you will be using a data plan while in Hong Kong. Along with Google Maps, Citymapper is very useful for transportation planning around the city.

subject: 4. Re: HK DisneyLand Admission
usertext: MTR is more economical. But it requires 2 transfers. Walk from your hotel to the Mong Kok MTR Station (about 600m or 2000ft). Here is the walking map: https://maps.app.goo.gl/7BNqTvwmXFwV7LDk9 Take the Tsuen Wan Line to "Lai King" MTR Station. Cross-platform transfer to Tung Chung Line, to "Sunny Bay" MTR Station. One more transfer to Disneyland Resort Line to Disneyland Resort MTR Station. You are at the front entrance of Disneyland. Link to MTR System Map: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/system_map.html The single-journey fare is HKD $24.5 each adult. (Senior and kids half price). Using Octopus Card will get $3 discount on that fare. = = = = = For the 3 of you, or up to 5 individuals, taking a taxi may make more sense because of the comfort and convenience. Taxi fare is about HKD $200 total (this included the Lantau Link toll).

subject: 5. Re: HK DisneyLand Admission
usertext: Thank you everyone! It is sure helpful to find out all the info beforehand, with a 67-year-old senior and a 4-year-old energetic child. You guys are ROCK...thanks!!

subject: 6. Re: HK DisneyLand Admission
usertext: This interests me also, but I have not seen a senior ticket for sale on line. Can it be purchased at the gate ? I am 75 years old and a visitor to H K.

subject: 7. Re: HK DisneyLand Admission

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Airport transit times
usertext: Hi, we are travelling to Thailand via Hong Kong in January (and returning same route in Feb). We arrive at 17.45 to HK t1 on a BA flight and hope to depart to Phuket at 20.50. We'd need to clear immigration and potentially pick up luggage (though may simply bring hand luggage). Then check back in again to an Air Asia flight to Phuket. Is this too tight a turnaround? We have a similar turnaround time on the return leg. Would appreciate your views. Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Airport transit times
usertext: I think you are fine. HKG is highly efficient.

subject: 2. Re: Airport transit times
usertext: We usually recommend being at the airport 2 hours prior to scheduled departures. If you flight arrives on time, you will be fine. Immigration and customs clearance is extremely fast in HK compared to European and UK airports but it still can take 30-40 minutes for luggage to arrival on the carousel and be heading out of the airport. As such, assuming no flight arrival delays with your inbound BA flight, you will have plenty to time to make check-in for your Air Asia flight to Thailand.

subject: 3. Re: Airport transit times
usertext: If you can avoid check-in baggage and just have hand baggage, you will have an ample cushion, even in case of a typical flight delay.

subject: Hotel suggestion
usertext: Looking for hotel in Kawloon. Any suggestions on the hotel for stay with breakfast. Hotel should be closer to sight seeing location n also metro. We are 2 adults and one kid. Need it from 20th to 23rd.

subject: 2. Re: Hotel suggestion
usertext: Just about all hotels in Kowloon fit your requirements. A more sensible approach: open up your favourite hotel booking website, enter your dates and requirements, and see what's available.

subject: 3. Re: Hotel suggestion
usertext: Booked The Kowloon Hotel. Thanks.

subject: Transit through Hong Kong
usertext: In a couple of weeks, I will arrive HKIA at 7am and depart at 5pm. What should I do for the day? I am very flexible but a little nervous about making it back to the airport as I dont know HK and how easy it is to get around. Should I get airport train to Kowloon or HK Island? Do I need to purchase ticket in advance? Can I change money at the airport, or can I use apple pay to cover expenses? Maybe a food tour? I see there is a free walking tour from Central MTR station at 11am, would this be a good choice? I am open to any suggestions, thank you!

subject: 1. Re: Transit through Hong Kong
usertext: a) withdraw a bit of cash from an ATM at the airport. (Apple Pay is not universally accepted) b) take the airport express train to Hong Kong Station. (25 minutes and very reliable) No need to buy ticket in advance -- buy it at the airport ticket desk. Get a one-day return ticket (with that, the return to the airport is free). c) Walk around the harbor area. Take the Star Ferry to Kowloon and back. If time permits, visit Sheung Wan (15-20 minute walk away) and see the traditional shops for dried seafood, tea, and other goods. d) For a 5 pm flight departure, give yourself a bit of a cushion and plan on being back on the airport express train at 3 pm.

subject: 2. Re: Transit through Hong Kong
usertext: I would take the Peak Tram up to the Victoria Peak (if the weather is clear) for an iconic view of HK.

subject: 3. Re: Transit through Hong Kong
usertext: Thanks so much, very helpful!

subject: One Meal in HK
usertext: Curious to see what people would say is the one must-try food item/restaurant that is a must try if you only can have only one meal in HK? Looking forward to all the tasty suggestions!

subject: 1. Re: One Meal in HK
usertext: HK is probably one of the worst cities for this kind of question, as the choices are so vast. I can tell you that for me and many of my friends, the first meal after flying back to HK would be a bowl of wonton noodle.

subject: 2. Re: One Meal in HK
usertext: We've never tried wonton noodles during previous trips - any recommendations in particular?

subject: 3. Re: One Meal in HK
usertext: It's a very common item, just about any noodle restaurant has it. Another item to try would be the egg tart. Preferably fresh from the oven, still warm.

subject: 4. Re: One Meal in HK
usertext: Wonton noodles: Mak's (), Tsim Tsai Kee (), Mak Man Kee ().

subject: 5. Re: One Meal in HK
usertext: These made it to a MG mentioned: https://guide.michelin.com/hk/en/best-of/best-wonton-noodles-hong-kong

subject: 6. Re: One Meal in HK
usertext: Besides wonton noodle, try egg tart and Chinese donut at Tai Cheong Bakery.

subject: 7. Re: One Meal in HK
usertext: Five famous wonton noodle shops in HK. All of them follow the same chef wonton techniques from Guangzhou. They are: Mak Man Kee Mak's Noodle Mak An Kee Noodle Ho Hung Kee Tasty Congee & Noodle

subject: 8. Re: One Meal in HK

subject: 11. Re: One Meal in HK
usertext: Two reasons. Wonton noodles to me are comfort food. It reminds me of the good times when I lived in HK. Besides, for some reason the noodles here in the US don't taste the same as those in HK. I can have dim sum here that's similar in quality to HK. Roast goose, to me, is a special meal.

subject: 12. Re: One Meal in HK
usertext: A little history of wonton: Despite the love that Hong Kong people have for the dish it has been available in the city only since the early 1940s. Wonton noodles originated in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou during the Qing dynasty (1644-1911) and were introduced to Hong Kong by the Guangzhou wonton legend Mak Woon-chi, who went on to open the famous Mak's Noodle. https://www.scmp.com/magazines/style/leisure/article/3022402/how-does-hong-kongs-version-wonton-noodles-compare Mak Man Kee, Mak's Noodle, Mak An Kee Noodle all are operated by Guangzhou wonton legend Mak Woon-chi's son and relatives. Ho Hung Kee was Mak Woon-chi's major crew and pupil. Tasty Congee & Noodle is operated by Ho Hung Kee's son.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

subject: Best app to use for public transport navigation
usertext: Hi all. Which is the best app to use to navigate public transport routes in HK? I usually use moovit or citymapper but I understand that different cities may have different apps that work better. Thanks in advance

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Best app to use for public transport navigation
usertext: You can use the Transport Department's HKeMobility app for point to point public transport journey planning, fares etc; https://www.td.gov.hk/en/public_services/hong_kong_emobility/index.html and website; https://www.hkemobility.gov.hk/en/route-search/pt

subject: 2. Re: Best app to use for public transport navigation
usertext: No one single "app" is good for Hong Kong transportation (which is quite complicated because of lots of options, and sometimes get peculiarity.) They all have their good features and short-coming. Just for example. The HKeMobility app mentioned above. Try to use the web version of it. Let's say I want to go from "Holiday Inn Golden Mile" to "Disneyland". Which is typical of what a tourist would like to ask. You type in those 2 strings as From and To. You will get... Sorry! No options are found.Please locate the "Origin" or "Destination" to places nearer to public transport stops and search again. Or to break up the trip so that the transfer involved is less than two times. Huh??? From what I gathered, it really takes someone who is familiar with places in Hong Kong to use that app. For example, if you just type "Tsim Sha Tsui" (the area name) as the From, to Disneyland. You still get the "No options are found" error. You need to pin down to a particular MTR Station, a particular bus stop? How can a tourist use this? = = = = = Google Map in general works okay. I like their interface, and the generality (I don't need to know an exact point, but the general neighborhood, Google can "best guess" the missing details, and *generally* works well. But the options Google Map presents may not be the best. It is at least getting your somewhere. Google Map also has an un-stated default that you are taking the transportation NOW. Not at a particular time (which you can specify but you need to change that explicitly. Also note that if you are planning your trip from a different country, Google Map uses your computer's time (in your timezone) to map the best available transportation, which in Hong Kong may be the middle of the night, and the public transportation suggestions may be very different than what to use during the day time.

subject: 3. Re: Best app to use for public transport navigation
usertext: I use a combination of Google Maps and Citymapper. They are generally like for like but at times, one seems to provide better route options than the other.

subject: 4. Re: Best app to use for public transport navigation
usertext: Thank you so much everyone. Very helpful

subject: Getting to China from HK
usertext: I'm just wondering what's the best option for me to get to China from HK. I have a HKID and passport, but I live in Australia (also have Aus passport). Would it be better to just get a China Visa in Australia? I'm not sure if I'm eligible for a Home Return Permit because I don't have a HK address. Thanks.

subject: 1. Re: Getting to China from HK
usertext: All Chinese citizens of Hong Kong are able to get a Home Return permit; assuming that your HKID has *** on it then you are likely (but not definitively) a Chinese citizen. But the process takes months; moreover if you've never had an HRP before then I believe the process now requires you to obtain a HK Passport first (although I am not Chinese, so I may be corrected on this by others). Assuming you don't have the months needed to do all that then your only option is a Chinese Visa in your Australian passport. This is best done in Australia; it is difficult to get a China Visa in HK for non-residents. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Getting to China from HK
usertext: Thanks so much for the information. Would you know if it also takes months to renew a HRP?

subject: 3. Re: Getting to China from HK
usertext: There has been a backlog post Covid. We really need input from some of the HK-Chinese posters here for the current situation.

subject: 5. Re: Getting to China from HK
usertext: If your purpose is go to China for a casual sight-seeing visit (vs planning on going to China frequently and regularly from this point forward), I think your time and money (which are related... time = money) are better spent just getting a China visa on your Australian passport to make your trip, and be done. While getting a Home Return Permit may be possible for you, it will take you a lot of time. First you need to make an appointment with CTS (which from the posts in this forum needs to be made months ahead of time). This appointment (an interview, face to face), needs to happen in Hong Kong. Really, the agent needs to see your face to verify you are who you said you are. Not something can be done online or just writing in. You make a special Australia-HongKong trip just for that? If all goes well, the interview itself is simple and will be done in ~15 minutes, if you have all the needed documents and information ready. But after the approval, it will take weeks to process and get your actual, physical Home Return Permit ready. That's where they need your Hong Kong address where they can send you the notification that your permit is ready for pick-up. If you have a close friend or relative living in Hong Kong, you can sign an authorization paper to authorize that person to pick up your Permit(s) for you. Then what? They would need to use a carrier to forward that to you in Australia? Or wait until your Australia-HongKong Trip#2 to pick up from them? Or you stay in Hong Kong for a few WEEKS more racking up hotel bills (I don't know exactly how long, for mine, done a few years ago, took a few weeks, not sure about now), so that you can go to CTS office to pick them up, and then go on to your tour in China?

subject: 6. Re: Getting to China from HK
usertext: Also you need to be careful you don't disclose you have an Oz passport. I have friends who have gone through the process and that did not seem to be the problem, so long as nothing was mentioned about a foreign passport. China does not recognize dual citizenship. I think having a foreign passport disqualifies you from having a home return permit.

subject: Hk car hire help
usertext: Hello everyone, I will be going to HK in nov, will reach HK on the 17, and will stay there for a week. We are four adults and one 27-month-old baby. As we are traveling with a little one, i was looking to hire a 6-hour daily taxi for us so that we dont have to be involved in the struggle of booking a taxi for sightseeing; however, a travel agent from HK quoted us USD 469 per person for five days taxi, each day it will be with us for 6 hours, so that makes $1876 for five days, 6-hour daily car dedicated for us, please suggest your views on this plan, i feel it is costly.

subject: 1. Re: Hk car hire help
usertext: Please note that in Hong Kong we don't use USD. We use Hong Kong dollars (HKD) so best to use and to refer to our local currency when providing figures in your posts here on the Hong Kong forum. Spending HK$3,600+ (US$469 you mentioned above) is enormous amount to spend for 6 hours of transportation in Hong Kong. To this point, there is really no need to hire a single taxi to be on stand by for 6 hours a day. That is a huge and seriously unnecessary expenditure. It makes much more sense to just hail a taxi when and where you need one.

subject: 2. Re: Hk car hire help
usertext: As BradJill says, this is absurd. Taxis are readily available, and the public transport system (MTR/subway, buses, tram, minibuses) are extremely frequent, efficient and cheap.

subject: 3. Re: Hk car hire help
usertext: Unlike countries like Thailand, holding onto a taxi all day is very expensive. Taxis are usually readily available. If not, you can use Uber to call a taxi or car.

subject: 4. Re: Hk car hire help
usertext: Having a regular taxi for a day would be far less than the amount given above (but I don't think many drivers would be interested, tbh, as waiting for you is far less profitable than driving another fare). Cost is $1.9 per minute or $114/hr, but by then the fare per minute is down to 1.3 giving an hourly waiting rate of just $78 (USD 10). For a day I guess you could manage to rack up some $500 for the distance travelled - add a few hours waiting that'd come to maybe $800 or so. That's just over USD 100. A fraction of the cost you metioned above. But then it doesn't really make sense to have the taxi waiting for you, they can't park near where you'll like to be anyway. Added issue: if you want to ride the Peak Tram or the Star Ferry; you want them to drive around to pick you up on the other end? Or you come down the same way? Neither is great - getting another taxi on the other end is a more sensible option.

subject: 5. Re: Hk car hire help
usertext: Thanks, everyone, for your valuable suggestions. We have decided not to book a taxi for the whole day and will be using public transport

subject: 6. Re: Hk car hire help
usertext: Good call. At 27 months (under 3 years) the infant travels for free on public transport. Just get Octopus cards for each of the adults and you'll be fine. If any are over 65 years then get Elder Octopus cards for them.

subject: 7. Re: Hk car hire help

subject: 9. Re: Still possible to get Visa On Arrival at Lo Wu?
usertext: Norwegian citizens, along with the citizens of other European countries are those with the best success results in obtaining a Shenzhen visa on arrival. He should not doubt a second about it. However, since Shenzhen VOA is in huge demand, he should arrive at Lo Wu border crossing, if possible, even before the opening of visa office. Visa office opens at 09:00 and its opening hours are until 16:00 or 16:30. It is important to know that it is possible that he will witness the situation where a quota will be formed for a particular day, so this is the reason why he should appear as soon as possible at the border crossing. The price for Norwegian citizens is 275 CNY. Recent experiences point out that the payments are done in cashless form. In the end, when he is over with his visit to Shenzhen, he can return by taking any border crossing and by any mean of transport. He can even take a high speed train directly to Kowloon West station in Hong Kong. Edited: 1 year ago

usertext: Thank you so much for your time - do you think I should take the cable car and then try to find my way to Buddha monastery and fishing village or book a tour

subject: 5. Re: Help with planning itinerary
usertext: No need to book a tour. It is very easy to do your tour at your own pace. You take MTR (Hong Kong's subway) from wherever you are to Tung Chung MTR Station. Then you walk (5 minutes) to the Ngong Ping Cable Car Tung Chung Station. Take cable car up to Ngong Ping (it is point to point). You are at Ngong Ping. You can see the Big Buddha Statue from afar. (You don't even need to "try" finding it) The Po Lin Monastery is at the foot of that small hill. It will be very obvious when you get there. And there are signs everywhere because it is one of Hong Kong's top tourists' spots. Afterwards, you can walk to the Ngong Ping Bus Terminus (just right next to Ngong Ping Village - the mock ancient village that houses many small shops and some eateries). You can take Lantao Bus #21 from Ngong Ping to Tai O - which is a very small fishing village. You alight at the end Bus Terminus. Tour Tai O. Take a short boat tour or something. Walk around. Have a meal if you like. Afterwards, you can have 3 ways to get back to the city: #1) Take Lantao Bus #21 back to Ngong Ping. And then take cable car again, this time downhill. Then from Tung Chung MTR Station take MTR back to the city. #2) Or you can take Lantao Bus #23 directly from Tai O back to Tung Chung MTR Station without going back to Ngong Ping. #3) Or you can take a different route: take Lantao Bus #1 from Tai O to Mui Wo Ferry Pier. There are frequent ferries from there to Central Pier at Central District on Hong Kong Island. The ferry ride is scenic. Different scenery. At Central Pier, you can walk to Hong Kong MTR Station or Central MTR Station (these 2 stations are connected underground too), you can then take MTR to wherever you want to go. Or ride the Star Ferry from Central Pier #7 to Tsim Sha Tsui on the Kowloon side. Another sight-seeing activity. Lots of options. On Lantau Island, you can also opt to take the Blue Taxi instead of taking the Lantao Bus too. Up to you. Transportation in Hong Kong is very convenient. Link (Lantao Bus Company routes): https://www.nlb.com.hk/route Link (Ferry ride from Mui Wo to Central): https://www.sunferry.com.hk/en/route-and-fare/timetable?route=central-to-mui-wo Link (Hong Kong's MTR System Map): https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/system_map.html Link (Star Ferry): https://www.starferry.com.hk/en/service

subject: 6. Re: Help with planning itinerary
usertext: Again thank you so much for your reply. I will do as you suggest because as you say we can do it at our own pace stopping for seat drink instead of at a tour group pace. Many thanks

subject: 7. Re: Help with planning itinerary
usertext: Note the Lantau bus #21 between Ngong Ping and Tai O only runs once per hour on weekdays, so you should plan you stay at the Big Buddha around that.

subject: Arriving at 1AM in Hongkong Airport,Can I still get Octopus?
usertext: I am going to arrive at Hongkong Airport at 1AM midnight, and plning to take nightbus to the city. Is there still any shop open to get an octopus card, or where can I buy a one way bus ticket? Thank you

subject: 1. Re: Arriving at 1AM in Hongkong Airport,Can I still get Octopus?
usertext: If you have a contactless credit card then you can use that on all buses. You can also buy a sold Octopus at various places in the airport (for HKD cash only I believe), but this has a non-refundable cost of HK$39 in addition to whatever value you load it with. https://www.octopus.com.hk/en/consumer/tourist/channels/air/index.html With a 1am arrival the MTR Customer Service desk at the airport will be closed. If you have an iPhone then you can download the Octopus App for Tourists (not the same as the Octopus app for HK residents) and use that: https://apps.apple.com/us/app/id1505492952 You can also pay for the bus with HK$ cash, but no change is given. You can get HK$ cash from several ATM machines at the airport.

subject: 1 small question !
usertext: This may sound a little trivial, but I would appreciate your help, is it possible to get a good Eggs Benedict in the TST-Jordan area ?

subject: 1. Re: 1 small question !
usertext: No doubt. A few suggestions here: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/restaurants?whatwhere=eggs%20benedict&sortBy=ORScoreDesc&districtId=2008&tabIndex=0&tabType= At least two of them even advertise the dish explicitly: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/r-reaction-coffee-roasters-tsim-sha-tsui-western-r689514 https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/r-brick-lane-gallery-tsim-sha-tsui-british-all-day-breakfast-r102168 Check the listings and reviews for more details; I haven't tried those restaurants myself, Just far too many in HK to ever try even a small portion of them :-) Enjoy!

subject: 2. Re: 1 small question !
usertext: Jordan? That is a tough ask but TST you have a few options. Reaction Coffee Roasters on Mody Rd mentioned above is a really good little place for brekky the place I'd try first. They do a good Eggs Bene and a great Avo on toast. Coffee is better than your average cup on TST as well. Second choice for me would be the Coffee Academics at Harbour City. They are open fairly early 8am on weekdays and do a pretty good Bene. To be honest, I prefer the pancake stack though, that usually my order choice here.

subject: 3. Re: 1 small question !

subject: restaurants -vegetarian options near The Peak dinner
usertext: Looking for restaurants with vegetarian or fish options near the Peak for dinner after 7 or 8 pm. outdoor dining possible?

subject: 1. Re: restaurants -vegetarian options near The Peak dinner
usertext: That basically has to be The Peak Lookout https://www.peaklookout.com.hk/ Not cheap, but a really nice environment. I haven't eaten there post-Covid, so I won't comment on the food/service.

subject: 2. Re: restaurants -vegetarian options near The Peak dinner
usertext: Or the Peak Galleria, the mall next to it. https://www.hanglungmalls.com/en/peak-galleria/dining

subject: 3. Re: restaurants -vegetarian options near The Peak dinner
usertext: There are a few outdoor dining options; they may have some vegetarian food options as well but likely very limited choice.

subject: 4. Re: restaurants -vegetarian options near The Peak dinner
usertext: Mostly very casual or tourist restaurants up at the Peak. Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. might be a worth a look-see. If you want nicer dining environs, just have a nice time taking in the views at The Peak and then return to Central for a better quality veg or seafood dinner.

subject: 5. Re: restaurants -vegetarian options near The Peak dinner
usertext: I guess i was thinking a restaurant in that particular area, once we have gotten down from the Peak? walking distance or perhaps we have to take a cab to a different area? Thanks all!!

subject: 6. Re: restaurants -vegetarian options near The Peak dinner
usertext: I think you've misunderstood the geography. "The Peak" is not actually at the top of a hill. It's just the top of the Peak Tram with a mall/restaurants/tourist stuff (Tussauds etc). It's about 80% of the way up Victoria Peak. I still think The Peak Lookout has the best outdoor environment there, which is what the OP requested. There are thousands of restaurants all over Hong Kong. If what you're looking for is competent veggie/seafood food then you can find something wherever you are. If the point of your evening is a high-class memorable meal then yes a short journey by cab or other transport my be necessary.

subject: 7. Re: restaurants -vegetarian options near The Peak dinner
usertext: You could of course walk down to Mid-levels, about half an hour along Old Peak Road, and from there the escalator through Soho and surrounding areas where you can find tons of food. Whether that's walking distance is your call. Not recommended at night if you don't know the route yet (also far less to see at that time of day), and it's very steep so even going down it's seriously demanding.

subject: 8. Re: restaurants -vegetarian options near The Peak dinner
usertext: The Peak Lookout should satisfy all your requirements. The ambiance isn't bad either due to the dim lighting and a more traditional look interior (though you want to sit outdoors). Except on certain festive days, it's pretty easy to get a table. For food quality, I rate them as average--nothing spectacular but nothing terrible.

subject: bird watching tour in English
usertext: Looking for a group tour in English for beginner bird watcher in Kowloon Park or elsewhere. I know there is one every day but it is not in English!

subject: 1. Re: bird watching tour in English
usertext: Check out the WWF activities at Mai Po Nature Reserve. They have various outdoor activities including bird watching, some are in English. https://apps.wwf.org.hk/cf/centres?lang=en

subject: 2. Re: bird watching tour in English
usertext: Do note that they have limited English language tours at Mai Po Wetlands and they book up rather quickly with locals so it can be difficult to arrange unless doing so fairly well in advance. We've taken the Cantonese tours a couple times and the tour guides were pretty good about providing some very basics in English on the tours after they have conducted the normal Cantonese instructions/discussions. In short, if you are looking for comprehensive details or guidance, do try to book an English language tour, if you just want to be outside and sight birds with your binoculars, the Cantonese language tours are fine for that purpose.

subject: Money exchange near ferry terminal sheung wan
usertext: I am returning from macao in eve thru ferry , and have a late night flight . Is there a good money exchange counter near sheung wan ferry terminal

subject: 1. Re: Money exchange near ferry terminal sheung wan
usertext: There are several near Sheung Wan MTR station. Don't know their rates. What currency are you exchanging? If it's MOP, you should do it while in Macau.

subject: 2. Re: Money exchange near ferry terminal sheung wan
usertext: May be some open late but a lot of money changers seem to close fairly early.

subject: 3. Re: Money exchange near ferry terminal sheung wan
usertext: Hkd to usd Wht is fairly closing time of shops

subject: 4. Re: Money exchange near ferry terminal sheung wan
usertext: If you are returning from Macau to Hk and have a late night flight, is there a reason that you sailing to Sheung Wan on HK Island? It was make so much more sense to just take bus transportation over the HZM Bridge between Macau and HK. The bridge arrives in HK just next to the airport and is also much less expensive than taking ferry into the city.

subject: 5. Re: Money exchange near ferry terminal sheung wan
usertext: Yes u r right. I will take a bus thats best , near to airport . Do u recommend booking bus tickets 15 days advance ? Or is there a booking counter near cotai strip i can book it same day

subject: 6. Re: Money exchange near ferry terminal sheung wan
usertext: Just buy your tickets at the bridgehead. The buses run frequent, you won't have to wait long (unless there's a typhoon incoming and suddenly everybody wants to go home early, which won't normally happen in winter).

subject: 7. Re: Money exchange near ferry terminal sheung wan
usertext: {Do u recommend booking bus tickets 15 days advance ? } No need. The Golden Shuttle buses run 24 hours a day with departures every 5 minutes or so during the main hours of the day. Just show up at the Macau Port Building on the Macau side, buy your ticket MOP65 and join the queue for those boarding shuttle buses over to the Hong Kong side. It is that easy and simple. No need to reserve anything in advance.

subject: 8. Re: Money exchange near ferry terminal sheung wan
usertext: Check out a few shops before you commit. USD is one of the currencies where the spread should be small which indicates a good rate.

subject: 9. Re: Money exchange near ferry terminal sheung wan
usertext: To state the obvious, avoid patacas in Macau. You won't get a good rate for them in Hong Kong and they'll be essentially worthless anyplace else.

subject: Staying at Marriott Ocean Park for visiting the city?
usertext: Hi there. I'm visiting Hong Kong soon and planning to do the usual tourist activities, visiting usual tourist spots in the city. I have a special discount for Marriott Ocean Park and considering staying there. I know the location of the hotel and how to reach the city by MTR. Everything seem OK on the book, but in real life, would it make sense? With the same price, I could only get a hostel or something in like Jordan area. Would you think it is feasible to stay at Ocean Park? Thanks for your comment.

subject: 1. Re: Staying at Marriott Ocean Park for visiting the city?
usertext: If the the Marriott Ocean Park or a hostel in Jordan is your choice then yes, take the Marriott - it's only a couple of minutes walk from Ocean Park MTR, so for most tourist places you're adding at most 20 mins to your journey time. For me that's worth a 5* hotel rather than a hostel.

subject: 2. Re: Staying at Marriott Ocean Park for visiting the city?
usertext: Ocean Park MTR to Admiralty MTR is just a few minutes, and then another 10 mins or so to get to Jordan. That's how far the two places are apart, really. So for some tourist destinations (especially on Hong Kong Island) it's a little closer than Jordan, for others (in Kowloon) it's a little further. Doesn't matter much. One major difference is that in Jordan you'll be spoiled for choice with restaurants right outside your accommodation; while around Ocean Park there's very little, so you'll likely end up taking the MTR to e.g. Wong Chuk Hang for options.

subject: 3. Re: Staying at Marriott Ocean Park for visiting the city?
usertext: After a day of sightseeing, if you are somewhere in HK not at the south side of the Island near your hotel, I suggest you eat dinner before you go back. You will have many more choices of all budgets.

subject: 4. Re: Staying at Marriott Ocean Park for visiting the city?
usertext: Thank you everyone for your comment. Very appreciate. I guess Marriott it is then :)

subject: Macau to HK via Turbojet
usertext: HI all I plan to take the turbojet from Macau to HK in mid Dec at around 7pm (checked the ferry schedule and there is a 7pm slot). Qtn is, should I book the tickets in advance? also how much time will it take for me to arrive at my hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui, taking into consideration time on the ferry, time to clear immigration etc? There are 3 of us so we may just take a cab from the ferry terminal at HK to our hotel. Thanks in advance

subject: 1. Re: Macau to HK via Turbojet
usertext: Unless it's a Sat or Sun evening, really no need to book in advance. If full, you just take the first available ferry (one or two later) and you can still stand-by for earlier ones. From arrival at the terminal, maybe 20 mins for clearing immigration and some 10-15 mins on the MTR to Tsim Sha Tsui, plus however far it's to walk to your hotel. Taxi may be a little faster, depending on traffic at the XHT. On Fri/Sat evenings it can be really bad.

subject: When does the new Hong Kong id card expire?
usertext: Hi guys, just got my new smart Hong Kong id card and it doesn't have an expiry date on it. Usually it's 10 years then you have to renew correct? Or will this card be valid until the government introduce a new card?

subject: 1. Re: When does the new Hong Kong id card expire?
usertext: Yes. There is no real expiry otherwise. >>>will this card be valid until the government introduce a new card?

subject: 2. Re: When does the new Hong Kong id card expire?
usertext: There has not been a fixed expiry date on HKID cards in at least the last 30 years. You may be confusing them with Home Return Permits, which do have a life of 10 years.

subject: 3. Re: When does the new Hong Kong id card expire?
usertext: Indeed I don't believe HKID expires. I was born and raised in Hong Kong and have gotten several generations of HKID. I had immigrated to the USA for a long time and only did renew my HKID card (because of their new designs) if I happened to be in Hong Kong. I don't recall ever seeing my HKIDs from old to new having an expiration date. Unless they are starting something new. Just my date of birth and the date of issue of the card. The latest one I am holding is from 2009, which is one generation older than the latest one. As mentioned, China's Mainland Travel Permit for Hong Kong and Macao Residents do have a 10-year expiration. I found an online sample on wiki. No expiration date. Just date of birth and date of issue: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong_identity_card Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: When does the new Hong Kong id card expire?
usertext: Sorry yes you are correct guys, it was the china travel permit I was getting mixed up with. On another note renewing the Hong Kong id card was a bit of a nightmare. Waiting and queueing, all together took 3 hours in total. A lot of people turned up extra early for their appointments but were turned away for arriving too early.

subject: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: Hi all, As the title states, I am visiting Ngong Ping 360 via one way cable car and want to visit Tai O Village and Victoria Peak Tram the same day. So I need to ask: 1. Is the bus from Ngong Ping 360 to get to Tai O village available once we use the cable car? Or must we return back down in order to take the bus to Tai O Village? 2. From Tai O Village, what would be the best way to reach Victoria Peak or Victoria Peak Tram? 3. Is Victoria Peak Tram worth the return trip? Or is it best just doing one way since the second time would be overkill? Would it be faster to take the bus back down (if a bus is possible to use to get down)? Those who have experienced this, would you recommend the way up and down for a return ticket? TIA for any assistance! All help is appreciated :)

subject: 1. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: I also forgot to add: 1. Will it be easily recognisable to find the bus to get to Tai O Village (and then to Victoria Peak)? 2. Are boats in Tai O worth it the experience would you say? Can these easily be booked or very obvious signs indicating these are available?

subject: 2. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: Partial answers: At the top of the NP360 cable car, there's an open-air bus terminal nearby. Hard to miss it. Yes, there are buses from there to Tai O. From Tai O to Central, either take a bus to Mui Wo then a ferry, OR take a bus to Tung Chung (where you started) then MTR. I think the bus ride to/from "the peak" is more scenic than the tram. Take it at least one direction.

subject: 3. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: This is a recent post I have submitted to a poster with very similar questions. Here are the details (reply #5): https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14559806-Help_with_planning_itinerary-Hong_Kong.html#119062694 = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = To answer your questions: RE: "1. Is the bus from Ngong Ping 360 to get to Tai O village available once we use the cable car? Or must we return back down in order to take the bus to Tai O Village? = = = = = Yes. The Ngong Ping Bus Terminus is virtually next to the upper cable car station. Taxi stand too. They are all there to provide transportation for visitors. You don't need to take cable car back down to Tung Chung just to take another bus from Tung Chung to Tai O. You can take a different bus route from Ngong Ping to Tai O directly. = = = = = RE: "2. From Tai O Village, what would be the best way to reach Victoria Peak or Victoria Peak Tram?" In my other post, I have outlined 2 routes: Take Lantao Bus #23 from Tai O to Tung Chung MTR Station, then take the MTR to Hong Kong Station. Then you can take Bus 15C from the Central Pier (outside Hong Kong MTR Station) to Lower Peak Tram Terminus to take the Peak Tram. Or you can also walk from Hong Kong MTR Station, underground to Central MTR Station (they are connected), then use one of their exits and walk to Lower Peak Tram Terminus. The overall walking time is about 20 to 30 minutes depending on how fast you walk. It is not too far, about 1.5 km but the last 0.5 km is lightly uphill. Or you can take the Lantao Bus #1 from Tai O to Mui Wo Ferry Pier, take a ferry from there to Central Pier (#5). You are at the same point as if you take the MTR to Hong Kong Station from Tung Chung. Which way is best? MTR is fast. Ferry may be more scenic, a different look of Hong Kong from the water instead of a train underground. But slowerl = = = = = RE: "3. Is Victoria Peak Tram worth the return trip? Or is it best just doing one way since the second time would be overkill? Would it be faster to take the bus back down (if a bus is possible to use to get down)? Those who have experienced this, would you recommend the way up and down for a return ticket?" You can take the Peak Tram down as you go up. But it is going backwards (the slope is too steep to face forward, so all passengers are facing uphill when the tram car is going downhill. You have to turn your head around to see the harbour scenery. If you want to change to a different experience, you can take the Bus #15 from The Peak bus terminus down to Central Pier #5 (or you can alight at the bus stop mid-route to go to use the MTR (Central MTR Station) instead of riding to the end, the majority of the bus passengers will do that, instead of riding to the end. Up to you. Personally I would recommend taking bus #15 down to experience a different scenery. But it is up to you.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: I don't know how fit you are but we walked down from the top of Victoria peak to HKU MTR Station and it was lovely afterbtaking the tram up. Take Harlech road / morning trail, then Hillier Road, then the HK University signed path. The roads are paved paths, not actual roads and go through wonderful peaceful forest. Take 10 mins to look at the Pinewood battery and its history as well. We had a great time doing this walk. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: Just a cautionary note about walking from the Peak down to HKU (or wherever depending on the foot trail you take): #1) Walking down from the Peak is steep. It may not be for everybody. #2) Since you plan to visit Ngong Ping, then Tai O, and the go to Central to go to the Peak. You may take some of the slow routes. In most likelihood, by the time you leave the Peak it will be night time. I would strongly advise not to attempt walking down from The Peak, not matter which trail you take, at night. As a foreign visitor, you will likely be lost on those trails at night.

subject: 6. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: Thank you all for helping out with my itinerary planning so much! Very helpful to know all this as we were not too sure how it all worker, never being there before or in HK for that matter. So it's looking like we will take the one way up only then to Ngong Ping then bus from there when we finish to Tai O. Definitely suitable and cheaper for our current budget too. Considering booking a return tram ticket or one way then bus given that we're aiming for a sunset arrival and night return. Hopefully not such long lines for this weekday we're planning to go but will be booking everything in advance except for the public transport parts. Thanks again everyone!

subject: 7. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: Also, just for some further clarification, have a few questions as I am planning it out: 1. Tai O Village bus stop where we get off is the same bus stop to get to the next stop on the way to the Victoria Peak Tram entrance correct? 2. How long should I expect for the journey times (bus to Tai O, Tai O to Victoria Peak, etc) 3. Roughly how much time do you think we'll be spending for an enjoyable time at each location, while reaching Victoria Peak for sunset or around this time for a comfortable journey 4. Do you recommend having lunch at Ngong Ping or Tai O? Or having some from both areas? Thank you again!

subject: 8. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: @JV: I understand this is your first time to Hong Kong. It may help if you take a look a map online on Hong Kong's geography. May be ask a friend to help if you are not familiar with reading maps. Just the basic overall. You can appreciate more on how to plan itinerary for Hong Kong. You get the idea of doing Ngong Ping + Tai O, and do the Victoria Peak on the same day from somewhere, right? What do they say? Ngong Ping and Tai O are close to each other. Doing them together makes sense. And most tourists do. But those places are on Lantau Island. Historically Lantau is a big island in Hong Kong where one can only take a ferry to reach, plus the local buses. But since the build-out of the new Hong Kong Airport at Chek Lap Kok, bridges have been built, and subway (MTR) has been built to reach Lantau Island. Thus they are land-linked. From Lantau Island to reach the rest of the city in Hong Kong got much faster. However, because historically it is an island by itself, vehicular access to the rest of Lantau Island besides Hong Kong Airport has been quite restrictive. Buses and taxis serving Lantau Island don't go out of Lantau Island. Even if you take a taxi from Tai O to Tung Chung (blue taxi), you would need to alight and switch to a red taxi to go back to other places in Hong Kong. Taxi licensing issues. These all come down to one point: It takes time for the activities at Ngong Ping and Tai O. For a lot of tourists that's a bulk of their touring day. Combining that with Victoria Peak is doable, though a bit rushed. Especially if you want to take the scenic route, using buses (some are 1 departure per hour during weekdays) and ferries. Thus I anticipated you will reach top of Victoria Peak probably around evening time. Back to your questions: = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = RE: "1. Tai O Village bus stop where we get off is the same bus stop to get to the next stop on the way to the Victoria Peak Tram entrance correct?" As said above, they are totally separate. The buses run by Lantao Bus Company serve only Lantau Island, not outside the island. There is no "same bus stop to get to the next stop on the way to Victoria Peak Tram entrance". Re-read what I posted on the details of the 3 options, in the post linked to in reply #3. = = = = = RE: "2. How long should I expect for the journey times (bus to Tai O, Tai O to Victoria Peak, etc)" As said, you cannot go from Tai O to Victoria Peak directly. You ride the bus from Tai O back to Tung Chung, take the MTR (Hong Kong's train/subway) from Tung Chung to Hong Kong MTR Station. Then you either walk, or take a different bus - run by a different company - Bus 15C from Central Pier #5 or #7 to Lower Peak Tram Terminus, then you can ride the Peak Tram up Victoria Peak. It can take 3 to 4 hours. One way. (There may be a long queue to ride the Peak Tram). = = = = = RE: "3. Roughly how much time do you think we'll be spending for an enjoyable time at each location, while reaching Victoria Peak for sunset or around this time for a comfortable journey" A typical tourist's pace - NOT COUNTING transportation time from one place to another - Ngong Ping (Big Buddha + Po Lin Monastery), about 2 hours. More if other things interest you. Tai O: about 2 hours. If you take the boat ride, plus walk deep into the small village, may be longer. Victoria Peak: typically 1 to 2 hours for sight-seeing, more if you walk around the peak's trails, more if you have a meal at a view restaurant. = = = = = RE: 4. Do you recommend having lunch at Ngong Ping or Tai O? Or having some from both areas?" Ngong Ping - inside the Po Lin Monastery there is only set lunch (vegetarian). No individual ordering. You can eat at the nearby eateries inside the "Ngong Ping Village", a mock-classical Chinese village but actually is a shopping mall. Or you can eat at some of the small eateries at the real Ngong Ping Village next to the Piazza. I think they serve regular non-vegetarian menus. But be warned that some of those eateries are run by the people who live there, may be borderline hole-in-the-wall environment. Tai O too. It is a small fishing village. Don't expect modern, ultra trendy types of outfits. At Tai O there will be more choices. But adjust your expectations. The place to have good food and modern settings would be in Tung Chung. There is a big mall (Citygate) and many eateries inside, including a food court. But that would be before you take the Ngong Ping 360 cable car or after you come back from Tai O (if you go that route, returning to Tung Chung).

subject: 9. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: Happyfeet (post #3) {You can take the Peak Tram down as you go up. But it is going backwards (the slope is too steep to face forward, so all passengers are facing uphill when the tram car is going downhill. You have to turn your head around to see the harbour scenery.} Just an FYI, with the newest (6th) generation of Peak Tram, there is a front car with forward facing seats. Note, people do tend to bunch up near the front for awaiting trams and grab up these seats pretty quickly for downward journeys.... but at least there are seats facing downhill for the journey back down. Here is a YouTube vid of the experience. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RjZS-ZU4y0I

subject: 10. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: +1 for taking the Mui Wo - Central ferry on your way back. Do try to time it to get an ordinary (slow) ferry for the much better views. Most have outdoor areas that you can sit, relax, and enjoy the ride. Also in this case you may take bus 15 from Central Ferry Piers up to The Peak, and later the Peak Tram down. Lines at the upper terminal tend to be much shorter than at the lower terminal, except shortly past sunset when the crowds want to go down.

subject: 11. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: Clearing up potential confusion: You use the same bus stop for both entering and leaving Tai O. (Queues may look horrendous, but they move well, and I believe the company adds buses as needed.) PS, I like the restaurants at Mui Wo, beside the bus- and ferry stops. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 12. Re: How to get from Ngong Ping 360 to Tai O Village and more?
usertext: Seeing ViajeroPerdido's post, I think I have misunderstood in my reply #8. To clarify further, at Tai O (a very, VERY small village), that's Bus Terminus. Not a bus stop mid-route. That is the end of the bus route. Literally the end of the road at the bus terminus. The bus will stop and everybody gets off. The driver rests. The driver will start the bus again in the reverse direction and the scheduled departure time.

subject: How long before flight should I arrive at HK airport?
usertext: Hi, I am travelling from HK to Vietnam next month on a 7:35 AM flight (terminal 1). The Airport Express is not running that early, and I found that the earliest bus (NA11) leaves at 4:50 from North Point and takes 80 minutes - so it should arrive at HK airport at around 6:10. I don't need to check in any baggage, but I'm worried that it might take long to go through immigration (I have a HK training visa) and/or maybe it's a long walk to the gates? Do you think I would make it on time, or should I take a taxi? I kinda wanted to avoid that option as it's far more expensive. Thanks in advance! Giulia

subject: 1. Re: How long before flight should I arrive at HK airport?
usertext: You can contact your airline to ask and confirm when they close the check-in for departing flights out of HKG airport. I believe most do so 60 minutes before departure. Further, if you don't have luggage to drop off and your airline provides online check-in before the flight, you can do that and use the boarding pass barcode on my mobile devise to proceed straight into the immigration/customs and restricted departure area as soon as your bus arrives at the airport. In that case, arriving an at 6.10am for a 7.35am flight is perfectly fine. Otherwise, you may be cutting it fairly close if you need to use the physical check-in counter to check into your flight and/or drop off luggage.

subject: 2. Re: How long before flight should I arrive at HK airport?
usertext: The first airport express departs HK at 05:50, so arrives around 06:20. This is plenty early enough for an 07:35 flight, particularly if you have no check-in bags and if you have been able to do an online check-in and got a boarding pass.

subject: Immigration to hongkong from macau
usertext: Hi. I am travelling from India to hongkong. I plan to go to macau first then to hongkong. Is it possible to do immigration from any of the ferry terminals in hongkong or do I need to come back to airport for immigration into hongkong after returning from macau

subject: 2. Re: Immigration to hongkong from macau
usertext: The ferry terminals and the HZM Bridge are ports of entry into/out of Hong Kong and Macau. No different than the two cities airports and land border crossings with mainland China. You will need to be processed into/out of both Macau and Hong Kong through separate and different immigration passport control and customs.

subject: Airport to Ngong Ping(with Luggage) & then Holiday Inn TST
usertext: Morning Folks, We're arriving around Noon on Friday and since hotel check in is at 3pm...can we straight away go to Ngong Ping from the airport and then to our Hotel(Golden Mile / TST)? We would've our luggage with us so we're guessing the cable car station woudlve storage option? cost? We're open to having a private taxi who we can boom prior to take us from the airport to the cable car station ...wait there and then take us to our hotel @ TST? Any recommendations? Thanks in advance

subject: 1. Re: Airport to Ngong Ping(with Luggage) & then Holiday Inn TST
usertext: It is tempting because of the proximity. But none of those options would be good. You will find that you have to spend a lot of extra money (taxi, luggage storage fee, etc.) and at the end, it is more effort to get to your hotel (e.g. When you get back down to Tung Chung and get ready to go to Holiday Inn Golden Mile, taking the MTR, would need a transfer at Lai King and it is often crowded). 3pm check-in is not bad. By the time you reach TST, the hotel area, it will be already 2 pm unless you take a taxi. From the airport, you can take the Airport Bus A21 from the bus terminus, with your luggage, and go to Tsim Sha Tsui, alight at bus stop #15 "Middle Road, Nathan Road", walk to your hotel Holiday Inn Golden Mile Hong Kong is only 600 ft / 200 m. Even taxi can only save you 200m. Fare is HKD $34.6 per adult while taxi fare is about HKD $270 plus HKD $6 per luggage. Bus A21 only takes a little longer. This Airport Bus option will not be available if you go to Ngong Ping first. If you can switch, do Ngong Ping another day without the luggage burden may be better.

subject: 2. Re: Airport to Ngong Ping(with Luggage) & then Holiday Inn TST
usertext: Makes Sense.....Thank you!

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Visiting Shenzhen -- Visa on Arrival
usertext: SCMP has now amended the article to reflect current visa on arrival fees for UK (834 yuan) and US citizens (1295 yuan). The current "standard" fee for most nationalities eligible for the visa is 275 yuan. The author has kindly supplied a photo showing list of current fees for those nationalities eligible for the visa where "non-standard" fees apply; https://flic.kr/p/2pbjLvZ

subject: 5. Re: Visiting Shenzhen -- Visa on Arrival
usertext: This thread including SCMP news article is talking about a VOA, however my understanding is that visa issued at the Luohu border point is not a VOA but an entry visa issued to eligible travelers prior to arrival in Shenzhen. Please clarify what is correct?

subject: 6. Re: Visiting Shenzhen -- Visa on Arrival
usertext: That's a rather subtle distinction. The visa is issued by mainland Chinese authorities in China just before passing through immigration control. The only difference between that and a VOA as done at some other countries is that the person issuing the visa is separate from the person stamping you in to the country. This is necessary, I guess because the VOA is not free and Immigration Officers at the stamping in counter are deemed unsuitable for handling payments. Other countries which have "VOA with a fee" generally have a similar arrangement (e.g. Indonesia, Thailand, etc) - queue once for the visa, then again to be stamped in. Most people in common parlance regard these ase VOA. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: Visiting Shenzhen -- Visa on Arrival
usertext: It is issued on arrival at the border. This is a. VOA to me as compared to the visa issued by a Chinese embassy that is already in your passport when you arrive at the border.
