Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: Hi all. I'm planning a day trip from Hong Kong to Macau next March. Thinking on going on a Monday in the hope it won't be quite as busy as a weekend? I'm staying at North Point and looking at getting the bus over and the ferry back. What's the quickest way to the bridge port? AirPort Express to airport then shuttle bus or MTR to Sunny Bay then shuttle bus? Is the bus situation quite smooth as I know I have to get the golden bus over the bridge then a local bus at the other side? For the ferry back how early should you arrive there before your allotted time? Will probably get one of the free casino buses to the ferry port. Thanks for your help!!

subject: 1. Re: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: RE: "Thinking on going on a Monday in the hope it won't be quite as busy as a weekend?" = = = = = Yes. Mon-Thu typically are quiet. = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = RE: "I'm staying at North Point and looking at getting the bus over and the ferry back. What's the quickest way to the bridge port? AirPort Express to airport then shuttle bus or MTR to Sunny Bay then shuttle bus?" = = = = = None of those you were thinking. Very simple: hop on an airport bus (both A11 or A12 would work, depending on where you are at North Point. A12 is quicker for your purpose, because it starts express non-stop after passing Victoria Park. A11 will meander through the heart of Causeway Bay, Wan Chai, etc before taking the Western Tunnel to shoot to the Airport. All Airport Bus, A11 and A12 included of course, make stop at the Hong Kong Port (to Exit Hong Kong Immigration and take the Golden Bus). You don't need any transfer. However, these buses will all make a stop at the Hong Kong Airport Terminal 1 (Departure Level) first where most of the passengers catching a plane will alight. Do not alight the bus at that point. Once you alight, you won't be able to catch another airport bus to Hong Kong Port because they are designed for Alight Only, no boarding (to Hong Kong Port, and then loop back to the Airport's Bus Terminus on ground level). = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = RE: "Is the bus situation quite smooth as I know I have to get the golden bus over the bridge then a local bus at the other side?" = = = = = Yes, once you have cross the border and Enter Macau, at that port facility you will find public buses 101X and 102X. And you will see the free hotel shuttle buses as well. However, these free hotel buses do not take you to the casino/hotel of your choice directly. They only take you to Macau Outer Harbour Ferry Terminal (MOHFT), or Taipa Ferry Terminal (2 routes). Then you need to alight and get on a different free hotel shuttle bus to your target hotel/casino. A 2-step process. So you are looking at a Bus-BorderCheck-Bus-BorderCheck-Bus-Bus journey. = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = RE: "For the ferry back how early should you arrive there before your allotted time? Will probably get one of the free casino buses to the ferry port." = = = = = About 15 to 20 minutes before the scheduled departure time should be fine. Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: Thanks for all the info! Staying at the harbour grand so I think airport bus A11 is our closest although I'll check the map for A12 and see how far away the stop is if it's a more direct journey. Might be worth a short stroll. Do we need to complete arrival cards or anything at either side for immigration? Thanks!

subject: 3. Re: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: Fastest way to get to the port is of course taking a taxi, but it costs a lot more. The bus is the most sensible transit option, as it's direct and inexpensive.

subject: 4. Re: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: RE: "Staying at the harbour grand so I think airport bus A11 is our closest " = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = @Angel2707: You are staying at Harbour Grand Hong Kong Hotel on Oil Street? Sorry you are right that A12 would not work. The bus stop it makes last before getting on the expressway is near North Point Pier. Too far for your hotel. Take A11 for sure. Go to the bus stop outside of Fortress Hill MTR Station Exit, on King's Road. Walk straight on Oil Street towards it. Bus stop #4 "Fortress Hill Station, King's Road". Link to bus route details of A11: https://mobile.citybus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=A11&dsmode=1&l=1

subject: 5. Re: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: Any busses from Central that go straight to Macau?

subject: 6. Re: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: No. There are no buses that cross the borders. There's a quota for some 50 private vehicles (cars, not buses) that can make the trip from Hong Kong to Macau...

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: There are no cross-border buses from Central or elsewhere on HK Island to Macau as far as I am aware. There are cross-border buses from Kowloon to Macau but if you're staying in North Point these wouldn't be very convenient and you'd better sticking with the A11 as previously suggested. OneBus operates services from Jordan Station on Canton Road; https://www.onebus.hk/en Trans-Island ChinaLink (TIL) operates services from Elements Mall Coach Station, (above Kowloon MTR Station), China Hong Kong City on Canton Road and Prince Edward (Shanghai Street); https://www.tilchinalink.com/stations.php# However, you have to disembark from the bus at both HK exit and Macau entry immigration control points and then rejoin the same bus after completing immigration formalities.

subject: 8. Re: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: One thing I learned: it is cheaper to combine an E5 shuttle bus (or the one between Sunny Bay station and the checkpoint) and MTR trip to HK station rather than the Airport flyer bus from the checkpoint to Central directly (or vice versa). The former is $26, the latter is $41 (one way).

subject: 9. Re: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: True, those A routes are fairly expensive (by Hong Kong measures). On the other hand, the airport bus is probably faster overall, and certainly more comfortable as you can sit and don't have to change (multiple times depending on where your journey starts).

subject: 10. Re: Macau Bus & Ferry
usertext: One can say "A" routes are faster in that the trip between the checkpoint and Sunny Bay feels a bit like an eternity. And in many cases you get USB chargers per seat.

subject: Hong Kong on a Monday
usertext: We arrive to Hong Kong on Monday 6th November and have an 11 hour layover. We arrive at 6am and will take the airport express into the city by 7am. Is it better to first go to the avenue of stars/the promenade at that time, or first go to Victoria Peak? I see the sky terrace at Victoria peak only opens at 10am, so I am worried if we go too early we will miss out, and the shops might not be open. If we go later, there might be a line - but if I book on klook can I avoid the line? Are there nice places for breakfast at the avenue of stars?

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong on a Monday
usertext: If you go to the Peak you'll find more places to enjoy the view - such as the Lion's Pavilion, or along the Lugard Road/Harlech Road walk (takes just over an hour at a leisurely pace). It will be really quiet at that time of day, mostly locals doing their morning jog on that trail. At the Avenue of Stars is not much when it comes to food, but a few streets further into Tsim Sha Tsui you'll find yourself spoilt for choice.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong on a Monday
usertext: I've never seen the Sky Terrace (i.e. going on the roof of the building) as something worth paying money for - there are plenty of other free viewing points that are open 24/7 as wvmarle mentioned. The shops won't be open, but they're just full of cheap tourist tat anyway. There's not much to do at that time of the morning, so starting by going up to The Peak (on the Peak Tram), doing the circular walk on Lugard/Harlech Roads and then coming back down into town on the #15 bus (get a seat upstairs in the front row if possible) would be a good way to start the day.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong on a Monday
usertext: Check to make sure the sky is clear, or you won't get a good view up at the Peak. Don't go there for the shops or the Sky Terrace. It's the view you want.

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong on a Monday
usertext: Go to Tsim Sha Tsui first may be a good idea. RE: "Are there nice places for breakfast at the avenue of stars?" Right on the Avenue of Stars - actually there is a Starbucks Coffee (yes, the American brand). Link: https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong/r-starbucks-coffee-tsim-sha-tsui-american-salad-r38199 They have some breakfast items. And they sell coffee, I think.  The big bonus: They have a 2/F patio seating (take the elevator up IIRC). It offers a killer view of the Victoria Harbour, close up. I encourage you to try them. Otherwise, all eateris are tugged inside some malls. There are 5-star hotel view restaurants with 5-star prices if you want some suggestions. At Star House (name of a building, next to Star Ferry), there are fast food at the basement (McDonalds, I think). Dim sum restaurant inside Hong Kong Cultural Centre. Along Canton Road, there are many restaurants along the street. Inside Harbour City (a shopping mall), there are restaurants. Or else walk along Ashley Road, Hankow Road, Lock Road - 3 short streets. There are many local eateries. Those are the areas closest to Avenue of the Stars (harbourfront).

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong on a Monday
usertext: I have gone up Sky Terrace many times when it used to be free. Ever since they started charging, it's just not worth the money in my books. Getting to HK this early, I agree with taking the Peak Tram to start your day. since it starts running at 7:30am. If you choose to do the Lugard Road walk, it takes roughly an hour. If you choose to go up higher, you can hike up Mt. Austin Road which should take 15-20 minutes. Avenue of Stars is often crowded but Mondays should be fine. For lunch, if you want dim sum, you can eat at one of the Star House restaurants or back at the Island side at Maxim's Palce at City Hall. There are a lot of other choices though.

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong on a Monday
usertext: Just got back from Hong Kong - did the whole trip around Kowloon and Central, had dim sum and hotpot but I didnt get to shop. It was a shame I didnt get to visit the vintage stores as I heard so much good things about them. My local contact set me up with Luna_luxsunny on Instagram and I was happy to find them. In case anyone is the same situation as me - on a day trip and on tight schedule like me, they are a nice alternative online as well.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: "Discover Greater Bay Area"
usertext: For visitors to HK that wish to consider exploring other cities in the Greater Bay Area (Macau, Zhuhai, Shenzhen, Dongguan, Guangzhou, Huizhou, Foshan, Zhongshan, Zhaoqing, Jiangmen), HK Tourism Board has collaborated with Macau and Guangdong Province tourist authorities to launch a new thematic joint website "Discover Greater Bay Area" detailing various attractions, activities and useful information aimed at promoting tourism to the GBA; https://www.discovergreaterbayarea.com/eng/index.html

subject: 1. Re: "Discover Greater Bay Area"

Macau is the exception, it's visa free for many nationalities, more so even than Hong Kong, and Macau is of course already a popular side destination for visitors to Hong Kong

subject: Waiting for my taxi
usertext: Hi Waiting for my taxi to Heathrow for my Cathay Pacific flight to Hong Kong later today. Thanks to everyone on the Forum for their help over the last 8 months. subject: 1. Re: Waiting for my taxi
usertext: You can still get the Octopus Elder Card if you qualify and enjoy senior fares (basically half price). But the $2 concession them now is for "JoyYou" card only, essentially closed off to Hong Kong residents only. Link to the $2 scheme: https://www.td.gov.hk/en/gov_public_transport_fare_concession/index.html

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Waiting for my taxi
usertext: At this point in time the $2 concession still applies to Elder Octopus users. The date on which the $2 scheme will cease to apply to Elder Octopus has not yet been announced but is probably imminent as roll-out of JoyYou cards to eligible HK residents is almost complete (see "How to enjoy the concession" - persons age 65 and above at the link provided by HappyFeet). Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Waiting for my taxi

subject: Best way Kowloon to Macau
usertext: What is best way Kowloon to Macau for day trip Senior female. Tend to get seasick. Interest in primarily Portuguese area.

subject: 1. Re: Best way Kowloon to Macau
usertext: Are you willing to trade money for comfort? Most comfortable: Take a taxi for Hong Kong Port (near the Airport). Exit Hong Kong Immigration. Take the Golden Bus from Hong Kong Port via the HongKong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge to Macau Port on the Macau side. Enter Macau Immmigration. On the other side (Macau), take a Macau taxi to where you want to go. There is no "Portuguese area" per se. You will find Macau is a small city with a mix of modern and old (buildings). There are obvious Portuguese influences with some of the old buildings, Portuguese Cobblestone streets, lamp posts and street name plaques. Those you can still find mainly in the "heart" of Macau around the Senado Square area. But no one area for "Portuguese Only". Do your research, plan to go to Senado Square, walk around and visit Ruins of St Pauls.

subject: 2. Re: Best way Kowloon to Macau
usertext: Writeup on the various travel methods to Macau https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html

subject: Elderly Octopus Card
usertext: Is there any recent news if elderly 65 years+ but NON-RESIDENT or visitors in HK can still avail of this type of card to benefit from discounted fare? I am traveling the 1st week of Nov. The thread I read about the topic was since July 2023 and some mentioned that a change may occur towards end 2023. Or, will it be best to inquire about this in the airport when I buy a card?

subject: 1. Re: Elderly Octopus Card
usertext: There won't be any sudden change so buying and using the card in November shouldn't be a problem. (Withdrawing the $2 fare from the Elderly Octopus affects not just tourists but HK people who haven't yet switched to the new residents-only card. So there'll almost certainly be a "last-chance" to convert campaign, and that hasn't started yet.)

subject: 2. Re: Elderly Octopus Card
usertext: Thank you for your info. So, do I take it to mean that I, an elderly (defined as at least 65 years old) tourist in HK this November can buy this Elderly Octopus card to enjoy the fixed HK$2 fare extended to HK elderly residents? This would certainly be a welcome treat!! I read in another site (can't recall which site it was) that this benefit is ONLY for HK residents and it even cited the regulations covered by this benefit so am a bit confused.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Elderly Octopus Card
usertext: Hong Kong residents with a JoyYou Card benefit from the $2 fare concession at age 60. Users of Elder Octopus, residents and non-residents benefit from the $2 concession at age 65. Sometime after the roll-out of JoyYou cards to HK residents has been completed at the end of this month the $2 concession will be withdrawn from Elder Octopus but that date has not yet been announced. Elder Octopus will still provide concessionary fares to users age 65 and over including non-residents but this will be limited to the transport operators own concession, usually half adult fare, rather than the government subsidised $2 concession.

subject: 4. Re: Elderly Octopus Card
usertext: It's a little confusing because there are two different cards. The old anybody-can-get-it Elder Octopus and the new residents-only Joy You card.

subject: Octopus card
usertext: Is it worth getting an octopus card for a 12 hour layover? We will be taking the mtr and busses to explore the city

subject: 1. Re: Octopus card
usertext: You can if you like. Obtaining Octopus card and returning it is very convenient. The Airport Express (part of MTR) Customer Service counter is right there at Hong Kong Airport's Arrival Hall. Save the hassle of keeping track of the small bills and coins. And you get some discounts using Octopus to pay for MTR rides. It's only a small admin fee when you return your card to get the unused balance refund. But if you are thinking of using Airport Express train to get out of the airport and get back in, buying the group discount tickets (2 to 4 persons) is cheaper than paying individually for your rides with Octopus cards. Worth considering: Link: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/tickets/promotions_4persons.html

subject: Arriving in HongKong, travelling straight to Shenzhen
usertext: Thought we would mix up our next trip to Hong Kong and spend a couple of nights in Shenzhen at the start. Are we able to go directly into China upon arriving at the airport ? Would we go through immigration in Hong Kong first, or is there a separate counter for the mainland? Would the hotel we book able to provide a driver ? My apologies for all the questions, I have tried googling , but can't seem to find the answer. Travelling from Australia:)

subject: 1. Re: Arriving in HongKong, travelling straight to Shenzhen
usertext: RE: "Are we able to go directly into China upon arriving at the airport ?" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = It depends on the mode of transportation of your choosing. The only method that you are not required to enter Hong Kong Immigration is to take a direct ferry to Shekou from HKIA via SkyPier. CKS is the operator. Here is the schedule of their ferry departures: Link: https://www.cksp.com.hk/#/main/shipline/ship2 Note the process in Hong Kong International Airport - before you go through Hong Kong Immigration: Link: https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/mainland-connection/ferry-transfer.page All other methods, including to take a bus from HKIA to Shenzhen via one of the land ports (Huanggang or Shenzhen Bay Borders), you need to Enter Hong Kong (Immigration), then take bus to the Shenzhen Border, Exit Hong Kong Immigration, and enter Shenzhen (China) Immigration on the other side, and then board a Shenzhen-based bus to the drop-off point of your choicing. Or any of the other methods on your own, public buses, taxi, train and a combination of them, you need to enter and exit Hong Kong.

subject: 2. Re: Arriving in HongKong, travelling straight to Shenzhen
usertext: Great information, thank you :)

subject: 3. Re: Arriving in HongKong, travelling straight to Shenzhen
usertext: Will also point out that Shekou is on the far western edge of Shenzhen and not very convenient if you're heading to more central Shenzhen. There's also the high-speed rail connection in which both HK and Mainland immigration procedures are done at the West Kowloon Station.

subject: 4. Re: Arriving in HongKong, travelling straight to Shenzhen
usertext: Do you have a visa for China? If not and you plan to get a visa on arrival, the high-speed rail option in the post above does not work.

subject: 5. Re: Arriving in HongKong, travelling straight to Shenzhen
usertext: And if they are getting a VOA they need to be aware that the VOA offices close quite early and that there have been reports that the offices only handle a set quota of visas each day. Further, if they are getting a VOA and are taking a cross-border bus from HKIA, they need to take a bus which goes to Huanggang, not Shenzhen Bay. No VOA given at Shenzhen Bay.

subject: 6. Re: Arriving in HongKong, travelling straight to Shenzhen
usertext: I would organise the visas prior to leaving Australia. We are looking at staying around the Luohu area so perhaps the West Kowloon station option maybe effective ? Our flight arrives around 16.00 .

subject: 7. Re: Arriving in HongKong, travelling straight to Shenzhen
usertext: The bus service from airport to Shenzhen is probably your best option. Huanggang port, taxi or metro or other bus from there. Via West Kowloon is a major detour (do have a look at the map!)

subject: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: Hello everyone, We will be visiting Hong Kong & Macau in May 2024 and I am already in the planning our travel for the same. We would be flying with Cathay Pacific from Bombay to Hong Kong. As we would like to visit Macau first, the initial plan was to stay a night in Hong Kong and take a ferry the next day to Macau. However, a friend of mine informed me that one can book a ferry ticket in advance and present it to the Cathay Pacific check in counter at Bombay and Cathay Pacific will facilitate our onward journey to Macau where our bags will be tagged directly to Macau. This would save me a day and cost of staying a night in Hong Kong. I called the Cathay Pacific Customer Care but they claim that I will have to collect my bags from Hong Kong itself and proceed to the ferry for Macau. I am a bit confused on what the facts are. Also, is there a jetty at the Hong Kong airport that can take me directly to Macau or would I require to stay a night at Hong Kong?

subject: 1. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: RE: "I am a bit confused on what the facts are. " = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = @Garfield S: Your friend's information was a fact. But it is outdated. It was good a few years ago. Cathay's information is the current fact. Since they opened the HongKong-Zhuha-Macau Bridge, it becomes a ferry business killer. Passengers opt for land transportation over ferry directly from Airport to Macau. It is less expensive. Now Turbojet (ferry company) only runs HKIA to Macau with 1 sailing every Mon, Wed and Fri. Practically it is close to zero. You can still go from HKIA directly to Macau immediately. No need to stay in Hong Kong for one extra night. Going from the airport directly will save you a lot of time too. From the Airport, take B4 bus to the Hong Kong Port. Exit Hong Kong. Take Golden Bus to Macau Port using the HZM Bridge. Enter Macau. Then take taxi, public buses 101X or 102X, or 2-step hotel/casino free shuttle buses to your Macau destination. Takes a while, but no need to stay a night in Hong Kong first. Read this not-so-long ago thread (5 pages). You will pick up a lot of details on how to do it. Link: https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14356859-HongKong_airport_to_Macau-Macau.html

subject: 2. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: See this thread regarding how to travel to Macau from Hong Kong. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html Note that in the old days there was regular direct ferry transportation from the SkyPier ferry terminal at the HK Airport. That is probably what your friend is talking about. However, they only have 3 sailings per week now (12.45am on Tues, Wed & Fri) so not very useful for most travellers going straight to Macau these days. You can see that sailing schedule on the TurboJet sailing schedule HKIA to/from Taipa ferry terminal in Macau below https://www.turbojet.com.hk/en/routing-sailing-schedule/hk-airport-macau/sailing-schedule-fares.aspx Note that they now have direct bus service from SkyPier at Hong Kong airport directly to the Macau side of the HZM Bridge that allows you to travel directly to Macau without passing through HK Immigration. This is a very new service and they are still working through how to make it work correctly but it is a substitute for the old SkyPier ferries that use the HZM Bridge (opened in 2018) just next to the airport. See link https://www.hongkongairport.com/en/transport/mainland-connection/transfer-coach-service.page Otherwise, if you want to spend less, you can exit the HK airport by passing through immigration, collecting your luggage and taking a short circular bus (B4) over over to the bridge. Then you use the Golden Shuttle Bus that runs 24 hours a day, directly to Macau. It is pretty quick, quite simple and much cheaper thand the direct SkyPier Airport transfer, but you do have to clear both HK and Macau immigration and carry your luggage yourself. That is the trade off. This is explained in the link I posted at the top near the top in the section called 'How to travel directly from HKIA (airport) to Macau. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: @HappyFeet1234 @BradJill Thank you for the detailed information like always. So our flight will depart Bombay at 1:30 am and arrive in Hong Kong at 10:00 am which would already make this a tiring affair and since we are travelling with our 7 year old daughter I think it would be a better option to take the ferry from the airport rather than the bus which would require us to exit the airport and switch multiple transport on the way especially since we would be carrying our luggage ourselves as well. Also, since we will arrive at Hong Kong at 10:00 am, we will have enough time to catch the 12:45 pm ferry as well. I can have our hotel in Macau pick us up from the ferry terminal. I checked out the TurboJet website but cannot seem to find online booking option for HKIA to Macau Outer Harbour Ferry Terminal. There is only an option for HKIA to Macau (Taipa) which would be a bit of a distance from our hotel located in Old Macau area. Am I missing something?

subject: 4. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: {There is only an option for HKIA to Macau (Taipa) which would be a bit of a distance from our hotel located in Old Macau area. Am I missing something?} You are not missing anything. With the vastly reduced sailing schedule, the HKIA to/from Taipa route is the only one left so you would have to sail there and then transfer with bus/taxi to the Macau peninsula if you are staying in a hotel there.

subject: 5. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: If you are worried about being tired, then you should stay in HK for at least one day on arrival. Traveling to Macau involves an additional couple of immigration checks (exit HK, enter Macau), which would add to your already long travel time.

subject: 6. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: @ThanksSocialSecurity As per what I have understood and read online; if one requires to travel directly from HKIA to Macau through ferry, then there is no need to go through the immigration at HKIA. On arriving at HKIA, one must go directly to the Skypier ferry terminal and board the ferry to Macau. It is in Macau that immigration check will be done as entry point. Please let me know if the above is correct?

subject: 7. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: That is correct. If you use the SkyPier ferry or new SkyPier direct bus (see post #2 above), you will skip HK Immigration and only be processed only by Macau immigration. Here is direct link to the bus company providing the HKG to/from Macau direct bus service that skips HK Immigration. All information (schedule, bus fare, and diagram flow of how to buy tickets and find the buses within the restricted area of HKG airport included) https://www.macauhkairportbus.com/index.php?lang=en

subject: 8. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: So we are having second thoughts on actually spending 5 nights at Macau due to feedback from friends and family that there isn't much for kids. It is more suited to casino and night life. Atleast, the 5 nights are not required. So we are thinking, why not stay in Hong Kong for say 07 nights and in between do a couple of day trips to Macau through ferry? Is this possible? Do we require a separate visa for Macau? Do we require to go through customs again on entry to Macau everytime?

subject: 9. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: "So we are thinking, why not stay in Hong Kong for say 07 nights and in between do a couple of day trips to Macau through ferry? Is this possible?" It's possible, but not enjoyable. Bear in mind that each day trip will use roughly four hours of your time. (Getting to the ferry or bus, making the trip, going through immigration at BOTH ends each time.) A better course of action would be to reduce your Macau plans to a single stay, of one night or two. And spend the rest of the time in Hong Kong. "Do we require a separate visa for Macau?" Macau is a separate international jurisdiction. Just like going from India to Bangladesh. You require entry permission and will go through immigration every time you enter or leave. I don't THINK Indians require a visa in advance, but I would urge you to confirm this with experts on the Macau forum (or the Macau Immigration website.) "Do we require to go through customs again on entry to Macau everytime?" Yes. You will go through a check on both ends every time you travel HK-MC-HK. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 10. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: {So we are thinking, why not stay in Hong Kong for say 07 nights and in between do a couple of day trips to Macau through ferry? Is this possible?} & {"Do we require to go through customs again on entry to Macau everytime?"} Of course it is possible but day trips to Macau can be very tiring if you are unfamiliar with the city streets & transportation around Macau and have children with you. Just to make the trip, be ready for 4-5 hours of transportation and 4 immigration crossings (HK & Macau twice) per day trip. If you do two day trips, that 8-10 hours of transportation and 8 immigration crossings for something like 3-6 hours sightseeing each day, depending on how early you start and what mode of transportation you take back to HK. This can be very tiring and without a hotel in Macau to retreat to and rest, your kiddos might get really worn out, especially if you try to do this twice. This is why it makes a lot more sense, especially with children to just spend a night or two in Macau instead of making repeated day trips. If you really want to just stay at your hotel in Hong Kong. I would suggest just doing a single day trip to Macau. Have a look around, get one really big day there and then concentrate the rest of your time on sightseeing around Hong Kong. "Do we require a separate visa for Macau?" No prearranged visa nor PAR required for Indian Nationals. You will be granted 30 day stay limits for each entry into Macau. See Macau immigration details here https://www.gov.mo/en/services/ps-1474/ps-1474b/

subject: 11. Re: Ferry from Hong Kong Airport to Macau
usertext: @HK_Observer & @BradJill Thank you for the detailed information. In such a case I will look at a maximum of 3 nights (including day of arrival) in Macau which would actually give me a whole full days to explore the area.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Day trip to Kadoorie Farm and Tai Po
usertext: Hi, Having been foiled in our attempt to visit Kadoorie Farm on my last trip to HK in Nov '19, I'm determined to do it this time. I shall check and double check they're open before setting off! But what I'm wondering is whether we could combine it with a visit to Tai Po too, or would we be pushing it? I'd hate to shorten either visit but it might be too much to spend 2 days allocated to that area. If we did combine it, what's the best travel logistics? ie which one first? We're staying in TST East so it'll be a little bit of a slog to get there, hence wanting to maximise our visit. Thanks in advance.

subject: 1. Re: Day trip to Kadoorie Farm and Tai Po
usertext: I'd suggest you start off by taking the MTR to Kam Sheung Road station, and the 64K bus from there to Kadoorie Farm. The visit to the farm will take something like 2-3 hours typically. Then take the 64K again, continue to Tai Po. Get off at Ping On Lane, maybe visit the nearby Tin Hau temple, and walk towards Tai Po Central - that area is the beating heart of Tai Po. On the roof terrace of Tai Yuen Market is a nice selection of restaurants for a (late) lunch. Also very much worth visiting are Fu Shin Street with the Man Mo Temple and the railway museum and Tai Ming Lane Square and Tai Po Hui Market. That again is fairly close to Tai Po Market MTR station for a convenient trip back to TST. The 64K is one of the most scenic bus routes of Hong Kong, which is why I suggest to first go to Kam Sheung Road MTR. Kadoorie Farm is fine in the morning; Tai Po is much more lively in the afternoon and evening which is why this is my suggested order.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Day trip to Kadoorie Farm and Tai Po
usertext: That's excellent advice, much appreciated. I will pre-warn my husband there won't be a lie in that day so we can get to Kadoorie Farm for 10am to give us plenty of time at both places.

subject: 3. Re: Travelling to HK tips

subject: 4. Re: Travelling to HK tips

subject: 5. Re: Travelling to HK tips
usertext: "Local people think of it as a firetrap, and worse." That's actually code for "many local people are too scared to go there because most of the people there are brown". It's no more of a firetrap than many of HK's older buildings, and it's recognised as a place for cheap accommodation, cheap South Asian food, and good rates at money changers.

subject: 6. Re: Travelling to HK tips
usertext: Chungkin Mansion is a large building with a good number of guest houses. It's also located at a very convenient location at TST on Nathan Road. Note that I don't view Chungking Mansion as a fire trap. It does have a bit of a seedy reputation for various reasons. If you just mind your own business, it's not unsafe overall. However, you can easily find similar guest houses in many locations, especially up and down Nathan Road and between TST all the way up to Mong Kok and Prince Edward.

subject: 7. Re: Travelling to HK tips
usertext: Thank you! Do you think I can just walk in or and get a room? or book it in advance?

subject: 8. Re: Travelling to HK tips
usertext: I recommend you book. Otherwise, you never know about availability and price.

subject: 9. Re: Travelling to HK tips
usertext: Just walk into CKM and you're blind. You'll have no idea about the places there. You'll be prey to a hustler. If that's where you really want to be, then pick a place on the basis of reviews, pics and ratings on the booking sites.

subject: 10. Re: Travelling to HK tips
usertext: I won't worry about Chungkin Mansion firetrap unless you go to the illegal restaurants inside. However, there were a few cases of murders and rapes inside. There are many other guesthouses in TST, Jordan, mongkok area. YHA Mei Ho House is also nice.

subject: 11. Re: Travelling to HK tips
usertext: As a local, I find Chungking Mansion just fine but I would say its not the easiest place to try and find a hostel if you have just arrived in HK with luggage for the first time. You will have to endure the worst of our city touts as well. I would definitely have a booking at one of the hostels there in advance if this is your first time around. If you prefer to be in Mongkok, I like Dragon Hostel. It is a normal residential building, fairly close to MTR and famous Ladies Market, no touts and nobody will care that you are there. They've been around for over 20 years now, we've put people here from time to time over the past 15 years and found them to be a good setup for budget, spartan accommodation in Mongkok. http://www.dragonhostel.com/

subject: 16. Re: Travelling to HK tips
usertext: 80% residents in Chungking mansion are from South East Asia, Africa or Indian. Chungking Mansions features guesthouses, curry restaurants, African bistros, clothing shops, sari stores, and foreign exchange offices. It often acts as a large gathering place for some of the ethnic minorities in Hong Kong, particularly South Asians (Indians, Nepalese, Pakistanis, Bangladeshis and Sri Lankans), Middle Eastern people, Nigerians, Europeans, Americans, and many other peoples of the world. Peter Shadbolt of CNN stated that the complex was the "unofficial African quarter of Hong Kong". https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chungking_Mansions

"both had knife" - that tells me that it's not a simple robbery. More likely some conflict between two people, and they generally prefer to fight those fights in private so little chance of witnessing it. What I have seen in other buildings (somewhere in Yaumatei) that - at the time, this was several years BC - were home to a number of guest houses, is signs like "ladies please do not walk around the public areas in your underwear". Never seen anything like that in CK.

subject: Cheung Chau ferry- sea sick?
usertext: I really want to take the Fast Cheung Chau ferry. If anyone has taken it recently, can you tell me if it is very choppy? Actually, slow movements are probably the worst. I suppose it depends on the day. is there any way of finding out what the water will be like? I would definitely sit outside and look at the horizon, and other things I might do on an airplane to prevent motion sickness. They have worked quite well. Thanks so much.

subject: 1. Re: Cheung Chau ferry- sea sick?
usertext: Who can say for sure. It depends on the choppiness of the water that particular day. But in general seasickness does not seem a problem on HK ferries.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Cheung Chau ferry- sea sick?
usertext: You can't sit outside on the Fast Ferry to Cheung Chau. If you want to sit outside on an open deck you'll need to take the Ordinary (slow) Ferry and travel in deluxe class which has an open deck at the rear of the triple-deck ferry. Ordinary class also has a partially open deck at the rear of most boats.

subject: One morning in Hong Kong - is this even possible
usertext: So I'm trying to google map and HK Tramways map and... I'm confused. Saturday, February 3, I want to taxi to Victoria Peak for the sunRISE.... tram ride down @ 730. Get to the mid rise escalator, by walking seems to be best way and walk back down? Hop on a ding ding (perhaps a quick round trip) and get the Star Ferry back to Kowloon. Who knows where I end up on Kowloon but will try to get to my hotel by noonish? I know it's possible but trying to calculate this by myself is driving me mostly wonky. And yes, I am an over planner and yes, taking the tram up is the best and the weather will probably be lousy and I will be grumbling to myself the whole time about how stupid I am but that's me. Any help by a sane person would be much appreciated

subject: 1. Re: One morning in Hong Kong - is this even possible
usertext: If I were you I would cut out the mid-levels escalator. At 7:30 am the restaurants, bars, and shops will all be boarded up so the area is a lot less interesting. AND the escalator runs in the downhill direction until about 10 am, which will complicate your movements considerably. It's not worth the trouble, IMHO. Just go from the Peak to the ding ding tram. I would suggest a round-trip from Central to Kennedy Town and back -- that will take you through some of the interesting districts west of Central. The alternative is to go east of Central and perhaps turn around in Causeway Bay -- but again at that hour of the morning the shops in CWB will mostly be closed.

subject: 2. Re: One morning in Hong Kong - is this even possible
usertext: Sounds like a great idea!! Bummed about missing the mid-levels however, I will keep it flexible and see how the morning progresses. I can always circle back if time is good.

subject: 3. Re: One morning in Hong Kong - is this even possible
usertext: Be sure to check the weather to make sure it's not cloudy on the day you want to see sunrise.

subject: 4. Re: One morning in Hong Kong - is this even possible
usertext: The area adjacent to the mid-levels escalator is just a dead zone of shuttered properties and lots of rubbish bags waiting to be collected until about 11am. And in any case it's not really a tourist destination in my opinion - you're not missing much.

subject: 5. Re: One morning in Hong Kong - is this even possible
usertext: Yes, the Mid-Levels escalator is not worth it. Coming off the Peak Tram and heading down be sure to wander through Hong Kong Park. Supposedly the walk-through aviary will be open again by next February. If so, don't miss it. Riding the upper deck of the HK tram is a great experience. I'd suggest riding eastward the entire length to Shaukeiwan then catching the MTR back. Just be sure to get on a tram marked "Shaukeiwan." With reclamation pushing the Star Ferry pier practically to Kowloon, it's no longer what it was. So if time is short just take the MTR to Kowloon side.

subject: 6. Re: One morning in Hong Kong - is this even possible
usertext: The escalator itself isn't really an attraction. Places around that you might find interesting are the wet market, galleries, smaller shops, cafes and murals as you reach SoHo. Some might be interesting in PMQ as well which similar to the Central Market, houses various shops and restaurants. Tai Kwun (former police station with jail facilities) has tours and historical buildings. There are also museums around the area. Overall, I don't think there is one star attraction that is a must. But when you put the list together, it might offer you a pleasant 1/2+ day. However, it's something to be done later in the day when things start to open.

subject: 7. Re: One morning in Hong Kong - is this even possible
usertext: Great advice! Thank you!

subject: Travelling with young children
usertext: Please could I have some tips and advice for travelling around HK with young children?! A 2.5 year old toddler who doesn't like walking much and a 7 month old baby who is heavy! We are staying at the Royal Plaza in Mong Kok. We are planning on bringing two compact, foldable strollers and a baby carrier, but I'm not sure how long I can use the carrier for. Any issues with using strollers on the MTR? Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Travelling with young children
usertext: That can be a problem. There are lot of walking involved in getting around in HK, despite having one of the best public transportation systems in the world. The MTR can be crowded, and manipulating strollers up and down buses won't be easy.

subject: 2. Re: Travelling with young children
usertext: I will avoid rush hour and the busier MTR stations. Will be going to Tai Po to visit relatives.

subject: 3. Re: Travelling with young children
usertext: MTR off peak is definitely fine. MTR during peak hours can be a bit difficult depending on the traveling direction. You will have to be patient. Alternatively, fold up the strollers and squeeze inside. Use taxis strategically though it's best to use the MTR to cross the harbor. If you want to go to Tai Po on a weekday, go in the morning to early afternoon hours against the flow of passenger traffic. You will be able to find seats. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Travelling with young children
usertext: Useful advice, thank you. Do you have any recommendations for any apps for taxis?

subject: 5. Re: Travelling with young children
usertext: You can use the Uber (HK) app to order taxis

subject: 6. Re: Travelling with young children
usertext: Also mind that many MTR stations have very limited lift service; many entrances even only have stairs, no escalators. So that's going to be a lot of carrying up and down stairs. On the East Rail Line you may also consider taking the first class - get a first class ticket or register your Octopus at the first class reader before boarding the train. Seats are not guaranteed in rush hour, but at least it'll be much less packed.

subject: 7. Re: Travelling with young children
usertext: I will try and use the baby carrier and fold up the strollers, they can be pulled along like cabin suitcase. First class sounds like a good idea!

subject: 8. Re: Travelling with young children
usertext: HKers are pretty good at giving up seats to people with babes in arms though, so I wouldn't worry too much about that.

subject: 9. Re: Travelling with young children
usertext: That's good to know. I'm super excited but nervous to be travelling with young children. Any other tips would be great, thanks.

subject: Bus from airport
usertext: We will be coming to HK in two weeks time after 12 years! Very excited, will have lots of questions to ask I expect before we arrive. First one is : our first hotel is Hotel Jen, I understand we can take A10 bus from airport, which would be best stop to get off for hotel? Also do the buses have information screens onboard to let you know when you are near your stop? Thank you for all replies!

subject: 1. Re: Bus from airport
usertext: {First one is : our first hotel is Hotel Jen, I understand we can take A10 bus from airport, which would be best stop to get off for hotel? } Have you looked at google maps to see the bus route A10 from the airport to Hotel Jen? It shows a very good visual of the last stop which is about 40 metres from the hotel. Have a look and hopefully all will be clear for using the airport bus for travelling into the city from HKG airport.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Bus from airport
usertext: For Hotel Jen, from the airport you can take CityFlyer bus A10 and disembark at stop 6 "Chiu Kwong Street, Queen's Road West". Bus stop numbers and names are announced audibly and visually displayed inside the bus. See; https://www.citybus.com.hk/routes/airport-bus/hotel/index.aspx?intLangID=1 and then click on the route number for an interactive map showing bus stops.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Bus from airport
usertext: Ah, thank you. Did find route map but not sure if it was stop 6 or 7, didn't find the list of hotels when I looked before. Very useful.

subject: 4. Re: Bus from airport
usertext: Note though that the A10 currently has a rather limited frequency, departing from the airport at 06:50, 08:50, 10:50, 12:20, 13:20, 14:20, 15:20, 16:20, 16:50, 17:20, 17:50, 18:20, 19:20, 20:20, 21:20, 22:20, 23:20. With a slightly longer (maybe 400m) walk you could also get route A12 to stop 5. Ka On Street, Des Voeux Road West. That departs every hour from 07:45 to 23:45, with an additional departure Mondays-Fridays at 17:15. This would be better than waiting an hour for the next A10 if you just miss one, assuming you can manage your bags that far.

subject: 5. Re: Bus from airport
usertext: Note that the bus stop numbers for the various hotels listed on https://www.citybus.com.hk/routes/airport-bus/hotel/index.aspx?intLangID=1 for the route A12 are currently wrong - the page has not been updated to reflect the fact that the bus now stops additionally at the HZMB port. So for Hotel Jen, for example, you need stop 5, not stop 4 as currently stated on that page. I have pointed this out to CityBus, so I guess it will be updated soon. In the meantime, use the name of the bus stop, not the number to guide you. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Bus from airport
usertext: For perhaps the first time ever, SolentTraveller has made a mistake here. The numbers for route A10 also need incrementing by 1. The stop you need for Hotel Jen is now stop 7, Shek Tong Tsui Complex, Queen's Road West. That used to be stop 6, and again the web page has not been updated. Go by the name, not the number. Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: Bus from airport
usertext: Well spotted ! Apologies for the error.

subject: 9. Re: Bus from airport

subject: Hiking
usertext: Hi, I'll be in HK mid November for a couple of days (work) and am looking for a day hike that's safe for a single lady and has great views of HK's scenery. I'm interested in the Maclehose trail but was wondering which sections would be good? I was reading up on section 2 but given that I'm based in HK island, travelling to and fro + hike may not be the best idea. Would Dragon's back be more appropriate in this case?

subject: 1. Re: Hiking
usertext: It's perfectly possible to Mac2 as a day trip from Central although it requires some careful transport planning. Dragon's Back is somewhat easier, shorter and simpler from a transport perspective. It's more of a half-day trip. If you would like to hike with other people then go on Meetup.com and look for the Hong Kong Hiking Meetup. They have hikes almost every day. There are also several other hiking groups there, but with not so many weekday hikes. Bear in mind (coming from Singapore) that we have significant hills here, so you may find hikes harder than anticipated unless you are used to hiking elsewhere. If the weather is clear then a great viewing point is the Ngong Ping Plateau above Sai Kung (a different one from the Ngong Ping on Lantau Island where the Big Buddha is). It is on both Stage 4 of the Maclehose Trail, and on the Ma On Shan Country Trail. Of course if you know you can do big hills then combining a trip (by cable car from Tung Chung) to the Big Buddha with a climb over Lantau Peak (Lantau Trail Stage 3 backwards) and then either over (Lantau Trail Stage 2 backwards) or round (South Lantau Country Trail, backwards) Sunset Peak to Nam Shan and then finishing (via the Nam Shan Village Trail) in Mui Wo for food then a ferry back to Central is good. There are literally hundreds of possibilities, so some guidance on distance, hill-climbing experience/ability and so on might enable us to narrow it down a bit.

subject: 2. Re: Hiking
usertext: If you go hiking in Hong Kong, you must be prepared. That means good shoes, clothing and headgear appropriate for the weather (bearing in mind that trails are often exposed), map, mobile and water. And your Octopus card. Stage 2 is indeed beautiful and not very difficult. But transport to/from the south end can be a problem, so finish at the north end where there'll always be a bus back to Sai Kung even in evening. It's very easy to get a late start if you're not familiar with Hong Kong, then find the trail takes longer than you expected and end up hiking in the dark. So start as early as possible and bring a torch.

subject: 3. Re: Hiking
usertext: If you want to keep it short and simple, then just head up to Jardine's Lookout, which has a spectacular view of the harbour, skyline and hills. Do it as a quick round-trip from Parkview. Google for details.

subject: Christmas Decorations in HK

subject: 1. Re: Christmas Decorations in HK
usertext: Some of the skyscrapers on Victoria Harbour will have Xmas displays which you can see after dark. Some malls will start putting up decorations towards the end of the month as well. Dates for those participating in the Christmas Festivities will be coming shortly as well. You can watch for them on Discover Hong Kong website https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/what-s-new/events/dhk-highlighted-events/hong-kong-winterfest.html and here as well. https://www.hong-kong-traveller.com/2023-december-hong-kong-festivals-events.html

subject: urgent help
usertext: Hi all just booked a last minute trip to hongkong due urgent matters . Staying at The Kowloon Hotel off Nathan Road tsim sha tsui . How do i travel from Hong kong airport to the hotel ? i see taking bus is the cheapest option and would like that option but concern if i am able to catch the bus to hotel as my flight arrival time is 2245hrs and after immgration clearance etc too late for last bus out from airport ? Any info would be very much appreciated at this point . Thank you

subject: 1. Re: urgent help
usertext: The last A21 bus (which is the one you need, cost HK$34.6, can use contactless credit card - alight at the stop "15. Middle Road, Nathan Road") departs the airport at midnight. If your flight is on time you shouldn't have any problem catching that one, or even the 23:40 departure. If you have only cabin bags then the 23:20 might be possible. Otherwise your option is the Airport Express to Kowloon Station (cost HK$105) and then get a cab (cost ~HK$40 depending on how many bags in the trunk @ $6 each). The last Airport Express train departs the airport at 00:48. If you're very badly delayed and miss the last train then your only option is a cab, which should cost about HK$270 + $6/bag in the trunk. Cabs are cash only. There are ATMs at the airport - use one from a recognised bank (HSBC Bank of China, Citibank, Hang Seng Bank). Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: urgent help
usertext: There's also the NA21 bus leaving the airport at 01:25. Get off at Sai Yeung Choi Street South and take a quick taxi down Nathan Road to your hotel.

subject: 3. Re: urgent help
usertext: Hi HK Ga Yau thank you so much for the prompt reply . Q1) May i know the difference between taking bus A21 Vs the Airport Express ? Q2) And where can i find the A21 bus station/ Airport Express station after i clear immgration and bag collection ? i only have 1 small check- in luagge as i,l only be in hongkong for 2 days . Q3) And also how best do i travel back from hotel > airport on the day of return , any bus A21 stop or express bus location nearest to my hotel ? thank you once again

subject: 4. Re: urgent help
usertext: The Airport Express is a train. The station's a bit far to walk to your hotel so you'd need a taxi for the final leg. The A21 is a bus and better because there's a stop near your hotel. The Airport Express is pretty much right in front of you as you exit customs. Don't forget to buy a ticket or Octopus card first if you take the train. For the A21, just follow the signs to the bus centre. You can't get lost, but basically head more or less straight after you exit customs then turn right down a long passage to the buses. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: urgent help
usertext: Q3) The A21 is the express bus. The Airport Express is a train. For your return the A21 stop on Nathan Road is about 300m from your hotel. With just a small bag that's probably the best option. The Kowloon Hotel is a proper hotel, so the concierge can give you directions.

subject: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: Hi all, I have read some articles saying that there are several routes to take for Tai Mo Shan hike, which is the one you guys would recommend that is not too difficult? Also is it possible to do a breakfast at Tuen Kee Dim Sum before doing the hike? Want to kill 2 birds with 1 stone heh.

subject: 1. Re: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: Assuming you mean what is normally called Duen Kee in Chuen Lung, then yes. But bear in mind that, whichever way you go, there is at least 600m of ascent from there to the top of Tai Mo Shan. That's like going from sea level to the highest point in Singapore 4 times. So it depends on your definition of "too difficult". You also need to be able to navigate with a map. A difficulty with starting at Chuen Lung is that the natural place to finish is then back down at Route Twisk where the only public transport on weekdays is a bus that goes once per hour. There are dozens of routes you could do. How good are you at navigating from a map? Will you even have a map?

subject: 2. Re: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: RE: " Want to kill 2 birds with 1 stone heh" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Possible? Of course it is possible. It is your outing. You can even have a buffet breakfast to stuff yourself up before you hike. I think you should have a little discipline. One should take the hike more seriously, especially to take the challenge of climbing (then descending) Hong Kong's tallest peak. For most people, that's at least a moderate level hiking exercise. You may want to stay with the light-weight energy-rich hiking food and drink water. Stuffing yourself with dim sum, lots of water intake to your body. You are carrying these extra pounds up 1000'-2000' (300m-700m). You may want to stay with eat-light, hike at a moderate pace. After you have finished the hike, go for a celebratory nice dinner.

subject: 3. Re: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: It's actually not the best hike in Hong Kong. Some of the trails up can be unexexpectedly treacherous after rain and the summit itself is not very attractive and kind of disappointing. As well, the road -- which you'll probably take in one direction -- is pretty boring.

subject: 4. Re: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: I would definitely agree with that - you can't get to the actual summit because there's a PLA radar station there, and the road up or down is very boring.

subject: 5. Re: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: Oh I thought its one of the most recommended hikes in HK. Definition of a map? Does Google Maps help there? Or I need to download a map somewhere online? I read something like from the Dim Sum place you can hike to Rotary Park then up towards the viewpoint or the radar station, then can head down another route where you can take a bus to MTR. And yes am planning to do so in December, so its not really recommended? Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 6. Re: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: Like we said, it really isn't the best. But reluctant to suggest an alternative without knowing your hiking experience, familiarity getting around HK by yourself, and what you're looking for. The Government's Countryside series maps are the best for hiking. Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: You may find the AFCD's "Enjoy Hiking" website and app useful if you wish to consider alternatives to Tai Mo Shan. You can sort routes by area, level of difficulty, distance, duration and see route maps and transport information etc; https://www.hiking.gov.hk/trail

subject: 8. Re: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: This is a pretty good breakdown of one of the easiest paths to Tai Mo Shan, its a good starter route for those trying for the first time. https://droneandslr.com/travel-blog/hong-kong/tai-mo-shan-hike-via-visitor-centre/

subject: 9. Re: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: I've always found Google Maps to be quite useless for hiking (and it's continued to degrade over the past decade or so for general use), if not outright misleading by showing non-existing paths. For hikes, use Open Street Map - best use the Cycle Map overlay as it shows contour lines, so you know what gradient to expect.

subject: 10. Re: Tai Mo Shan Hike
usertext: {I've always found Google Maps to be quite useless for hiking} I'm less critical of google maps for popular trails but don't rely on them solely for any when hiking in HK once you get off the paved roads and paths. We use HikingTrailHK app and find it much more useful.

subject: cross harbor tunnel
usertext: Hi. How is the traffic inside the cross harbor tunnel these days? Is there a time when the tunnel has very light traffic during weekdays? I am visiting HongKong end of the month from Thursday - Saturday and am quite worried about the crossing. Since I am quite claustrophobic. Is there any other way to get to Causeway Bay without going through the tunnel? I am planning to take a taxi.

subject: 1. Re: cross harbor tunnel
usertext: {Is there any other way to get to Causeway Bay without going through the tunnel?} You can take ferry from Star Ferry from TST to Wanchai which is one district over from CWB. Or take MTR over from the Kowloon Peninsula to Causeway Bay.

subject: 2. Re: cross harbor tunnel
usertext: If you are "quite claustrophobic", does that also prevent you from taking the subway? If so, then your best option may be the Star Ferry.

subject: 3. Re: cross harbor tunnel
usertext: MTR is more packed generally than buses - and a large section of it is in tunnels. If riding a bus through the tunnel is too much for you, you really should avoid the MTR. On the other hand if the MTR is fine, the bus should cause no issues. Also not only cross harbour routes are tunnels, there are quite a few more in Hong Kong, crossing various mountains. Or if you must you could opt for the Western Harbour Crossing. A wider tunnel with generally the lightest traffic of all.

subject: 4. Re: cross harbor tunnel
usertext: You can take the ferry to Wanchai from Tsim Sha Tsui or Hung Hom.

subject: 5. Re: cross harbor tunnel
usertext: "You can take the ferry to Wanchai from Tsim Sha Tsui or Hung Hom." The ferry from Wanchai to Hung Hom ceased service several years ago.

subject: 6. Re: cross harbor tunnel
usertext: Oops... then the ferry from Tsim Sha Tsui to Wan Chai could be a reasonable route.

subject: Luggage Transfer Service

subject: 3. Re: Suggestion for Hotel in Hongkong

subject: 4. Re: Suggestion for Hotel in Hongkong
usertext: There are lots of hotels in Hong Kong, and just about all 4-star hotels will fall in the "decent" (or higher) category by most people's standards. Also just about all of them are in an area full of restaurants and shops - this for the simple reason that, except for the rural areas and country parks, all of Hong Kong is full of restaurants and shops. By the way, you'll have a hard time getting accommodation for just kids that age. Hotels will demand a responsible adult to be present, too.

subject: 5. Re: Suggestion for Hotel in Hongkong
usertext: I believe they are looking for a single room able to accommodate the 2 adults and 2 kids. I assume the budget of HK$2500-3000 is per night, because if that's for all 3 nights then 4* is probably a bit of a stretch. You really, really, need to get your head around using the world's best public transport system: it's much less hassle, and gives you much more flwxibility than any big group tours (and if they exist at all then the functional language of such a tour is likely to be Mandarin Chinese). For me the best location would be at Admiralty. Although the hotels there are 5* they are on top of the MTR station which means travel to Ocean Park and Disney is trivial, and you're also on the ding-ding tram and adjacent to the Peak Tram. It depends on your dates, but I see the J W Marriott at Admiralty/Pacific Place coming in at about $3000/night for a room for the 4 of you.

subject: 6. Re: Suggestion for Hotel in Hongkong

JW seems a great option from the reviews.There are other comparable options nearby also We can now close this . Two more points.. subject: 7. Re: Suggestion for Hotel in Hongkong
usertext: One day each is enough for Disney and Ocean Park. Third party resellers such as indeed Klook may offer discounted tickets, though they may be for a specific date. Check the description of the listing before paying.

subject: 8. Re: Suggestion for Hotel in Hongkong

Out of four days available, ( including day of arrival, reaching Hotel around 12 noon) , we need day 2 and day 3 for Ocean Park and Disney. Any suggestion on how to utilise the other two days ( day 1 and 4) covering places of attractions like Victoria peak, Sky line, Laser show, Buddha statue, anything else? Basically we are not sure how to sequence them. Also, are all these places free or need tickets?

subject: 9. Re: Suggestion for Hotel in Hongkong
usertext: The Peak area takes maybe 2 hours including roundtrip Peak Tram rides. If you decide to walk the Lugard Road loop or hike up Mt. Austin Road, allow an additional hour each. Avoid weekend afternoons when you are most likely to see a lot of people and potentially, Peak Tram queues. After the Peak Tram, you can perhaps take a ding ding tram ride on the Island side and visit an area like Wan Chai for a bit. Get yourself back to Central eventually for the Star Ferry to cross the harbour. From TST Star Ferry Pier, it should take no more than 30 minutes to walk the Avenue of Stars at the TST promenade. It's probably worthwhile to walk it during the day and then come back for the light show at 8pm. On another day head to Tung Chung for the cable car. The service starts at 10am. If you wake up early, you can look for a place for morning dim sum before your visit. After the cable car up, visit the Buddha and Po Lin Monastery. Tai O, a fishing village, is optional in my books but you might find it enjoyable. For the second half of that day, it depends on your other interests. Do you want to shop? See some museums? Go see Nan Lian Garden and Chi Lin Nunnery?

subject: Affordable/Cheap Bars near Victoria Harbor?
usertext: Hi everyone! Me and my fianc are going to Hon Kong this December. We have overlooked how expensive it is going on a vacation there, but everything is already booked and in place (flights, hotels, wedding). We will be celebrating New Year's Eve for the first time together and I read that Victoria Harbor will hold a countdown event. I would like to ask if you know any cheap or affordable bars near the harbor where we can celebrate together and just savor the moment. I would like to thank you in advance, it would mean so much for us :)

subject: 2. Re: Affordable/Cheap Bars near Victoria Harbor?
usertext: If there were cheap or affordable bars near the harbour, they would be absolutely choke full of people, especially on NYE when the fireworks traditionally bring tens of thousands of people to the waterfront to watch the fireworks. Skybars with good views will re fantastically expensive and you probably need to be making reservations now. Further to what HK Ga Yau mentions, if you want to save on night, buy your own beer, take it with you to one of the waterfront places mentioned and enjoy it together with the hordes or other people waiting for the countdown. Also keep in mind that this is the first NYE fireworks for us since 31 Dec 2018 so the promenades will probably be very crowded with both tourists and locals who have 5 years of pent up cheers and midnight screams that need to let out.....

subject: 3. Re: Affordable/Cheap Bars near Victoria Harbor?
usertext: Thank you for your insights, HK Ga Yau and BradJill! I didn't thought that there is a park where we can stay and buy our own drinks. This will definitely help us :) Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Tourist day pass
usertext: Researching my trip for December I have come across this: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/tickets/day_pass_tourist.html Can anyone confirm this is currently available? If it is can I use it on the S1 airport bus ? Thank you

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: The pass is available but can't be used on the S1 bus which is a Citybus circular shuttle service operating between the airport and Tung Chung. The only bus services provided by the pass are MTR bus services which operate in the the northwest New Territories mainly providing feeder services to MTR stations.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: Thank you for this reply.

subject: 3. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: In general the MTR Tourist passes are poor value unless you intend to make VERY intensive use of the MTR.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: We bought these on first two days of our trip while we finding our way and thought they were excellent value and extremely convenient. H$65 per day (GBP 7) but we are used to London prices so thought this was fine. Once we had some cash (notes & coins) we then bought single fare tickets which were about H$5-6

subject: 5. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: Considerig a typical MTR ride costs $3-10 you have to use it excessively (including half a dozen cross harbour trips) to make up for that $65. It's just a way of making money off naive tourists.

subject: 6. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: up to now, can we use physical credit card to get on/off in airport express and MTR? I searched this forum, this topic was discussed 3-4 yrs ago, I wish this has happened now.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: Not at the moment. MTR is, however, currently in the process of installing new platform entry gates which accept contactless credit card payment but the option will not be available until the end of this year at the earliest; https://www.mtr.com.hk/archive/corporate/en/press_release/PR-23-017-E.pdf

subject: 8. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: You can however buy tickets for the Airport Express using a credit card at the MTR Customer Service desks at Airport Express Stations.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 9. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: Yes, thanks for the correction. Airport Express tickets can also be purchased with credit card from MTR Ticket and Octopus Selling Machines in the airport arrival hall, near the exits to Airport Station; https://www.flickr.com/photos/hongkongviews/53355029850/in/dateposted-public/ Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 10. Re: Tourist day pass

subject: 11. Re: Tourist day pass

subject: 12. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: one more question, I will go to TST from airport, firstly, I will get off at Tsing Yi station to change other MTR, how can I buy MTR ticket? is there ticket machine at interchange point? if yes, the machine can accept oversea credit card? thanks in advance

subject: 13. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: You should think of the Airport Express as a totally separate service. When you leave the airport express at Tsing Yi station, you will have to walk to the "MTR side" of the station. (There are plenty of signs.) There, you will encounter MTR fare gates. You will need to acquire an MTR ticket of some sort -- there are ticket machines. They take HKD cash only.

subject: 14. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: very clear, thanks a lot.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 15. Re: Tourist day pass
usertext: If you use Octopus Card for your Airport Express journey from the airport your connecting MTR journey at Tsing Yi is free provided the connection is made within one hour and you use the same Octopus at the platform entry barrier for the MTR; https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/complom_connections.html#

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Hong Kong Interntl airport to Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park
usertext: Grateful to know the best way by public transport from Hong Kong International Airport to our hotel which is close to Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park. Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Interntl airport to Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park
usertext: Airport bus A10 will take you to Sheung Wan, where the Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park is. Which hotel?

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Interntl airport to Sun Yat Sen Memorial Park
usertext: I live right opposite the Sun Yat Sen Park. If the timing is good then the A10 to Connaught Gardens is perfect. Otherwise the A11 to the Macau ferry terminal, but depending on exactly which hotel and how much luggage you have that is a long-ish walk. What we tend to do if the A10 isn't conveniently timed is get an A11 or A12 to the Western Harbour Tunnel bus interchange, and then switch to one of the several buses from there to Connaught Gardens or the SunYat Sen Memorial Park itself. But this requires you to be comfortable working with the CityBus App and its facilities for checking buses in real time. To get back to the airport you need to walk to the Queen St/Connaught Road bus stop and get the A11. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3 days in December
usertext: We will arrive in Hong Kong on a cruise and disembark at Kai Tak Cruise Terminal on a Sunday 10 December. Would appreciate some help with the following: 1. Getting a taxi from Kai Tak cruise terminal remains a problem. If the Q is long and there are no taxis, what would be a good way to get to our hotel at Ibis Central & Sheung Wan, 28 Des Voeux Road West. Taxi is our first choice. 2. Are there shuttle buses (free or chargeable?) to a MTR station where we can catch a taxi ? With luggages, it is unlikely that we would take the MTR. 3. After dropping off our luggages, we would like to explore Central Market and Tai Ping Shan. Is this a good idea, as I read that many shops and eateries are closed on Saturdays & Sundays. 4. Next day we would like to take Star ferry from Central Pier 4 to Lamma Island. Take to Yong Shue Wan, walk the Family Trail and finnish at Sok Kwu Wan. Do I need a map for the walk? Is it tree shaded ? 5. At night, thinking of taking the Star Ferry's Harbour Tour from Central pier and see the Symphony of Lights show if possible. Otherwise a night tour of the Harbour would still be good. Do I need to book tickets online ? Can I book on our arrival in HK? 6. We have been to Stanley Village before on a day trip. Is it worth doing a late afternoon trip, have dinner and return at night? Is night life in Stanley Village worth seeing? 7. Looks like we still have a day left to explore. Any suggestion? Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: 1. I would try using the HKTaxi app to book a taxi (once they know that you are going cross-harbour, not just to, say, TST, then you should have no problem getting one to come for you). You can also book a taxi through the Uber app. 2. Yes, there are (chargeable) buses going to Kai Tak MTR. You can pay with contactless credit cards (I believe you would need one card per person). I've no idea how easy it would be to get a taxi at Kai Tak MTR. 3. I wouldn't be surprised if some of the outlets within Central Market are closed on Sunday since the vast bulk of their trade will be from office workers. By Tai Ping Shan do you mean the street in Sheung Wan, or Victoria Peak itself? 4. No you don't really need a map. Not much of the route is shaded. Note that on weekdays the ferries from Sok Kwu Wan are not that frequent so you need to plan around that. https://hkkf.com.hk/en/timetables/ 5. I'm not sure about tickets, but I'm not convinced the harbour tour is worth the money. The waterfront promenade is walkable on both sides of the harbour, and you can simply take the normal Star Ferry for a small fraction of the price of the harbour tour in order to get across and back. 6. No. 7. Lantau Island and the Big Buddha/Tai O?

subject: 2. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: 4. Make sure you have access to OpenStreetMap and you'll be just fine exploring a little beyond the main trail. The route itself is signposted as well, and easy to follow. 5. I've done the cruise and enjoyed it. It's a hour of relaxation. Whether it's worth the price, is up to you. I definitely wouldn't pay extra for the Symphony of Lights. 6. what night life? A few ex-pat bars maybe. That'll be all in that area.

subject: 3. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: I looked and saw several HK taxi apps. Which one would you recommend? HK taxi Hailing / eTaxi / Fly taxi / Take taxi. Booking a taxi, I would need to give them a pickup point. But I am not familiar with Kai Tak cruise terminal. Another question, I would need to set up my payment method with a credit card. Or do they take cash? By Tai Ping Shan - I am referring to the street in Sheung Wan. Since shops and some eateries do not open in weekends, then perhaps I should go to Lamma Island on Sunday and keep Central Market and Tai Ping Shan for weekdays ? I read somewhere that it may be better to start the Family Trail walk from Sok Kwu Wan and end in Yong Shue Wan as there are more ferries this end. What do you think? Will there be more people in Lamma Island walking on a Sunday? Are there clear directional signages? One will not get lost walking the trail ?

subject: 4. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: This app: https://app.hktaxiapp.com/en/app/ You can pay cash or through a card linked to the app as you prefer. The driver will contact you to confirm the pickup point, although I'm not sure how that works if you don't have a HK phone number. Maybe others here can confirm? Some eateries not opening on Sunday is quite specific to Central Market, just because of their location in the office district - pretty much everywhere else is open on Sunday. Lamma on Sunday means more ferries to/from Sok Kwu Wan, but also more people on the trail. You won't get lost. The restaurants in Sok Kwu are entirely seafood based. There is a wider range in Yung Shue Wan, although some people say that if seafood is what you want then Sok Kwu Wan is better.

subject: 5. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: HKTaxi app - As far as I know you need a local phone number just to register and setup your account. We use the app probably 8-10 times a year, every driver who picks up your ride request is going to call you on that local number to confirm pickup location.

subject: 6. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: Lamma Island Map - Agreed. There is no critical need for a map for this high traffic trail but you do have some options. If you start the hike at Yung Shue Wan and hike south and east to Sok Kwu Wan, there is a large island map just outside the main ferry pier that you can study and take a picture of to reference along the way. See image below https://en.tripadvisor.com.hk/LocationPhotoDirectLink-g294217-i143642849-Hong_Kong.html Unfortunately, I can't recall right now if they have the same posted map near the Sok Kwu Wan ferry piers or not. You can definitely get away with just following the signs however or use Google Maps just to feel extra comfortable with where you are going and where you are at any point in time during your hike. If you might want to go a bit off script and try a less trafficked splinter trail, definitely upload more details map apps like what wvmarle mentioned above or HikingTrailHK these will have you covered if you want to get a bit off the main grid on Lamma Island. Last simple island trail maps option is to simply reference online maps beforehand and download them to your mobile phone. Here is one that marks the main route and most highlight stops well. It sort passes over the Lo So Shing Beach which I personally like more than the popular Hung Shing Yeh Beach. Worth a look if you are interested in Lamma Island beaches. https://www.hellohongkong.com.hk/blog/lamma-island-hike

subject: 7. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: But taxi drivers taking booking on the app would surely come across tourists with foreign numbers. I wonder how they call to confirm for tourists calls. Do the taxi drivers speak English? I have the name and address of the hotel in chinese which I can show then when they arrive. If I download Uber app, are Uber drivers also going to call to confirm pickup point?

subject: 8. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: No. They go to the designated meeting spot. Make sure you know exactly where you should stand and keep looking for the car model, color and license plate. I have had friends who wasted valuable waiting time and money because they weren't aware the Uber driver was waiting right around the corner. Also, Uber has a messaging function and also, the ability to track where your driver is. Always allow some extra time though as I often see them getting lost trying to get to my pick up point. >>>If I download Uber app, are Uber drivers also going to call to confirm pickup point?

subject: 9. Re: 3 days in December
