subject: 10. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: Private car pick-up is on 1/F. That's where an Uber will go to pick you up. The cruise exit point is on G/F near the bus stops and taxi stand. There are no shops or so in the car parking areas. It's seemingly designed to be as barren and uninviting as possible.

subject: 17. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: That are two different locations. The park is next to the cruise terminal; mind that the terminal itself is huge: at least 5 mins brisk walk to get from one end to the other (it's about 600 meters long). Ship exit is roughly in the middle on G/F, the car park right above that. Upon exiting the glass doors turn left to the lifts that take you up to the 1/F car park.

subject: 21. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: "I read/saw YouTube, the taxi wait could be 2 hrs !" Well if there are 2000 people getting off a cruise ship and they want to take 1000 taxis then, even if there are 1000 taxis available, and there are, say, 10 simultaneous taxi loading bays, and if it takes a minute to load the bags into each taxi and tell the driver where to go, then it's going to take 100 minutes for all those people to get in to a taxi and leave the terminal. I've never been on a cruise, but I wonder how other ports manage several thousand people all wanting to get off a ship and get away at the same time? Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 22. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: The ship docks at 6am. Quite likely by before 7am, passengers can start leaving. By 9am all have to leave the ship so they can turn around for the next lot of passengers. The night before, all passengers receive luggage tags staggering the disembarkation. By the time we are down, the luggages are unloaded and arranged by colour codes. For those going joining the ship's transport to the airport, buses will be there waiting. Quite often there is a short excursion for them before going to the airport. Very convenient. We usually opt for this choice. But this trip, we are staying on in Hong Kong for 3 more days. There are always lots of taxis waiting and this has never been a problem. Cruising is a lovely way to take a holiday. You should try it !

subject: 23. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: We have 3 days in Hong Kong. And I had no firm plan for Day 3, but now I do have. My outline is as follows: Day 1 : Lamma island to hike the Family Trail. Eat seafood at Sok Kwu Wan before returning. At night - take the HK$20 Hong Kong Big Bus night tour. Day 2 : Central Market and Tai Ping Shan street at Sheung Wan. At night take the Star Ferry A Symphony of Lights cruise. Day 3 : Sham Shui Po. Read an article on it. Sounds like a good flavour of Hong Kong - the street shops/stalls and the local eateries ! https://www.discoverhongkong.com/season/explore/neighbourhoods/sham-shui-po/simple-flavours.html At night, have dinner at Yat Lok roast goose ! What do you think ? Not over doing it, I hope. Thank you.

subject: 24. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: Bizarrely that Discover Hong Kong page on SSP is 404 for me. But https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/neighbourhoods/sham-shui-po/simple-flavours.html works. I can see Central Market and Tai Ping Shan Street taking up maybe 2 hours of the day, What about the rest? subject: 25. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: My family and I extended our stay in HK too, after our cruise in 2019. We just took taxis from the taxi rank. Yes, the queue was long, but the taxis were plenty as well, so the queue moved pretty fast. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 26. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: Day 1: realistically it'll be about 13:00, maybe closer to 14:00 by the time you arrive on Lamma to start your walk, so the seafood part is going to be dinner: off the ship by 9, at your hotel maybe 10, check in, settle in, make your way to the ferry pier, by when it'll be past noon. With a little luck you just miss your ferry and have to wait half an hour for the next. With a stop for lunch and some sight-seeing/shopping in Yung Shue Wan you're talking about dinner for your seafood, and with the ferry ride back (they're infrequent from Sok Kwu Wan) easily 21:00 by the time you can board the bus. What you have planned for day 2 is not much; I suggest you to swap those two days. Walk the streets of Central on your first day (when you really only have the afternoon), and take a mid-morning ferry to Lamma on your second day. Gives you much more time to enjoy this little island. On a nice day you may even hang out on the beach for a while, in the sun it can be really nice even in December. I like the Star Ferry cruise but wouldn't pay extra for the Symphony of Lights. Rather watch that from the shore. I don't think it's that impressive anyway; the lit-up skyline itself is what it's about, really. As it's December it'll be dark well before 18:00 so you may consider an earlier evening cruise ending in TST, then if you don't have enough of it watch the Symphony of Lights from the TST waterfront, and have a late dinner.

subject: 27. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: Thanks for the comments. Will tweak the programme a little. Day 1 Sunday: Central market & Tai Ping Shan street with lunch. Night time HK$20 Big Bus night tour. (Comment: I had originally planned Central Market for Sunday but read that shops/eateries may be closed on Sunday, hence switched the programme). Day 2 Monday: Lamma island. Since it could be mid morning on arrival, will ferry to Sok Kwu Wan for early seafood lunch. By the time reach Yung Shu Wan, browse and teatime since this end has more eateries and also more ferries back. Night time, take Star Ferry for evening cruise. Keeping an open mind for the Symphony of Lights cruise. (Comments: originally planned Lamma Island for Monday, but switched it to Sunday as there will be more crowd on Sunday, so I won't get lost on the Family Trail. Maybe I am over thinking it). Day 3 Tuesday): walk Sham Shui Po. . Dinner at Yat Lok Roast goose at the Central outlet. (Comments: I was trying to look for the price of 1/2 goose but couldn't find it. Help - anyone? Husband and I just want a feast ! ). On a previous trip, we went up to Stanley. Took the cable car, went to Lantau Island and the Big Buddha, hence not repeating them. Thank you.

subject: 28. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: Ohfound the price of Yat Lok's goose. One whole goose HK$680. Half a goose HK$340.

subject: 29. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: Just an update to those following the chat. We disembarked from our cruise on Sunday around 8.30am. After immigration, we walked out and there was a portable Oyster Card booth where we bought our Seniors card. Lots of taxis waiting. Took us less than 5 mins to get a taxi. Suggest you get the hotel name and address in chinese so you just show it to the taxi driver. We were too early to check in at hotel. Dropped our luggage snd took Star Ferry to Sok Ku Wan. Had an early seafood lunch - yummy ! Then hiked Family Trail to Yong Shu Wan. Did a slow walk. Took us nearly 2 hrs. Most parts had tree shade. December weather was not hot. But lots of uphill and downhill slopes. Not for those on wheelchairs or walking sticks. Met children on the walk. Not easy for them either. They were tired. Day 2: had early lunch at Yat Lok roast goose. Long Q at the door but it moved fast. Then we went to Sham Shui Po. Interesting local market and stalls. Much like what we see on TV chinese serials. Day 3 - didn't go to Tai Ping Shan street as planned. Took mtr to Wanchai, then Causeway Bay snd then Jordan where we had milk pudding at the Australian Diary. It was supper crowded. For meals, we ate at local eateries which had a crowd. Decided not to Google and hunt for those with good reviews. Those with reviews are usually submitted by tourists. Where the locals eat - that's good enough for us. Enjoy yourselves !

subject: 30. Re: 3 days in December
usertext: Thanks for the report. Just to clarify for anyone reading who may be confused, the Star Ferry runs from TST to Central and Wanchai. The ferry from Central to Sok Kwu Wan is a service from Hong Kong & Kowloon Ferries. https://hkkf.com.hk/en/

subject: Big Buddha and Citygate Outlets in same day?
usertext: Hi all, staying in Tsim Sha Tsui in Feb next year, trying to work out if 1. Can visit both of these locations in the same day to save a trip given we'll be heading out there yet again another day to do Disneyland 2. Most cost effective way, is it worth/ possible getting MTR to Citygate and taxi/ uber to Big Buddha, spend an hour there then taxi/ uber back to Citygate for lunch/ shopping. Any help is appreciated!!

subject: 1. Re: Big Buddha and Citygate Outlets in same day?
usertext: 1. & 2. - Yes, you can conveniently visit both. The Ngong Ping 360 cable car lower terminus is just a few minutes walk from the Citygate Outlets and Tung Chung MTR Station. You can take the 10am cable car up to the Ngong Ping Village, spend an hour or so and then head back down to have a late lunch at Citygate before heading back to TST in early afternoon. If you want to do a more cost effective trip, take public bus from Tung Chung bus terminus instead of the Ngong Ping cable car. This will take 45-55 minutes depending on how many stops made in route. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: Do I take the MTR to Hong Kong Central and get off at the Admiralty to Lo Wu? I am a bit lost for how to get to Lo Wu from the airport.

subject: 1. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: You want to go to Lo Wu because you want to cross into Shenzhen or some other parts of China? There are buses that you can take that go from HKIA into various parts of Guangdong province.

subject: 2. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: Thanks,i want to go to Shenzhen as my hotel is nearer there.

subject: 3. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: Shenzhen is a HUGE place and there are several border crossing points to reach it. It really depends on where exactly in Shenzhen you want to go.

subject: 4. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: I know Shenzhen is a huge place. I want to cross the customs border through LoWu and take a train to my hotel from there. I have done that many years back. Is that the way to go by MTR?

subject: 5. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: MTR is the way to go because you need it to do the last leg to Lo Wu Border. No other public transportation is allowed except MTR trains. But using MTR via the Central Station (I think you meant Hong Kong Station from the Airport) is a big round-about way. A more efficient way is to take Airport Bus A43 (Long Wan Bus Company), from the Airport Bus Terminus. It pretty much runs express to Sheung Shui MTR Station, where you alight, walk into the MTR Station to buy tickets and take the MTR train for 1 stop from Sheung Shui to Lo Wu. Then you walk across the border to Shenzhen. Link to LWB route search, enter "A43" for details: https://search.kmb.hk/kmbwebsite/index.aspx?lang=en

subject: 6. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: Thanks, HappyFeet1234, for your advice to go to Lo Wu. For Airport Bus A43, how long is the trip, and does it have luggage placement as we have 2 luggage to carry to Shenzhen? Is Sheung Shui MTR Station a busy station to take to Lo Wu? My brother told me to a bus to Hung Hom and then take the MTR to Lo Wu. Which is a better way?

subject: 7. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: Those airport buses have large luggage racks on the lower deck. Being airport buses they're designed for air passengers who often carry lots of luggage. Again depending on where exactly in Shenzhen your hotel is, you may be better off taking a bus from the airport direct to that district. Or a bus from airport to the Lok Ma Chau crossing, and Shenzhen Metro or taxi from there.

subject: 8. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: Thanks, My hotel in Shenzhen is one stop from Lo Wu. after crossing the custom.

subject: 9. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: As Hong Kong DE wvmarle mentioned, these airport buses are equipped with luggage racks. No worry about bringing your luggage onboard. RE: your brother's suggestion - " My brother told me to a bus to Hung Hom and then take the MTR to Lo Wu." That is a pretty big round-about way. You are taking a different airport bus (A21) to go east, and then a train to go north. The total time: headway for A21 is maybe 15 minutes, riding time ~90 minutes. transfer time 10 minutes to MTR. Riding time from MTR to Sheung Shui (and then Lo Wu) is another 50 minutes or so. They all make intermediate stops. You are looking at a 2.5 hour plus journey. With A43 airport bus, headway may be long (30 minute per departure), but once the bus departs, that's pretty much, virtually, non-stop going north-east to Sheung Shui MTR Station. The bus ride is about 40 minutes or so. You walk into the MTR Station at Sheung Shui, 10 minutes. As for Sheung Shui MTR Station being busy... yes it is. But most of the riders of the train alight at Sheung Shui Station, not to the border at Lo Wu. You may not get a seat on this MTR ride, but you certainly can get on the train (it is a metro, short-haul subway/train). The ride from there to Lo Wu is really short. Maybe 3 minutes. Even if you need to stand, it is just 3 minutes! Given your Shenzhen hotel's location, I would proceed with taking MTR to Lo Wu like you originally envisioned. Going to Lo Ma Chau / Futian crossing will not help you.

subject: 10. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: Thank you so much for your explanation. I would appreciate if you could let me know if Sheung Shui station is the last stop for the A43 airport bus. Also the route for the A43 airport bus and timetable.

subject: 12. Re: HK airport to lo Wu .
usertext: RE: " if Sheung Shui station is the last stop for the A43 airport bus. Also the route for the A43 airport bus and timetable." = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Quite the opposite. Sheung Shui MTR Station bus stop is near the beginning of a long list of bus stops. That's what I said in both #5 and #9. I said that two times: once the bus departs, that's pretty much, virtually, non-stop going north-east to Sheung Shui MTR Station. Please slow down your reading and try to comprehend. The link to the details for A43 was provided in #5. I re-post here: Link to LWB route search, enter "A43" for details: https://search.kmb.hk/kmbwebsite/index.aspx?lang=en Bus stop information, time-table, fares. You need to do some work yourself to click on the link, and enter "A43" as the bus route to pull up the information.

My brother normally leads the way.I have some ideas now with your suggestion, I will do it your way to get to Lo Wu . Thanks again.

subject: 1. Re: Deciding which time to go for my situation
usertext: November is usually better than spring in HK. November tends to see dryer weather. Normally, it should be in the mid 20's C (70's F) now, but perhaps due to global warming, it's been hovering at the lower 80's F mostly. Still, November is almost always comfortable. For spring, it depends on exactly when. Starting mid-March, we sometimes get days of foggy and humid weather, possibly through some time in April. By the beginning of May, it will hit 80+ F again but this time, with some humidity to boot.

subject: Regarding visa for Indian
usertext: Hi I'm from India and I'm planning to visit hong kong on March 2024 for Indians it is visa free stay for 30 days, my stay is just for 2 weeks inbetween this i plan to visit Macau for 2 days and again return back to hong kong, in this case will I need a special visa or 30 days visa free stay is applicable And do I need to get pre arrival registration two times one when I enter hong kong for the first time and other one when I enter hong kong from Macau, any clarification would be greatly appreciated Thankyou

subject: 1. Re: Regarding visa for Indian
usertext: Everything you need to know about the Pre-Arrival Registration (PAR) for Indian Nationals (see link). See Validity of Registration - PAR is valid for six months and covers multiple different entries into Hong Kong during that period. https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/visas/pre-arrival_registration_for_indian_nationals.html

subject: 2. Re: Regarding visa for Indian
usertext: Normally upon return to HK from Macau you'll get another 14 days. Just remember to keep a copy of your return or onward flight ticket at hand. Just don't try to do this multiple times. If you do so, immigration may give you a hard time.

subject: From Hyatt centric to Hotel Icon
usertext: Will be moving from Hyatt Centric to Icon hotel for last part of our trip. Can anyone suggest best way to get there please? If we get a taxi how much roughly would it cost? I notice there's a ferry terminal near Hyatt which goes across to Hung Hom, will that be another way of getting there and then getting a taxi from the pier? That might be cheapest way? thanks.

subject: 1. Re: From Hyatt centric to Hotel Icon
usertext: If you haven't already, it is a good idea to become familiar with Google Maps for viewing transportation options around the city. Once you in Hong Kong, you can use CityMapper app on your mobile phone as well. It provides point-to-point taxi cost estimates which Google Maps doesn't. If you have a lot of luggage, it will be somewhat difficult to use public transportation to cross the harbour from one side to the other. Otherwise, no direct routes by way of bus or MTR so will require a change or two and some walking as well. As it seems you have learned so far, there is Sun Ferry service from North Point to Hung Hom (see sailing schedule link below). While it is not convenient to walk, especially with luggage, all the way to Hotel Icon, the Hung Hom Pier is right in front of the Kerry Hotel which would be an easy location to pick up taxi for the short ride over to Hotel Icon. https://www.sunferry.com.hk/assets/files/T_NP_HH_2023.pdf

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: From Hyatt centric to Hotel Icon
usertext: Thank you, very useful. have made a note of timetable.

subject: 3. Re: From Hyatt centric to Hotel Icon
usertext: Taxi would be the most convenient. Fare $120-150 I'd guess, including tunnel and luggage fees.

subject: 4. Re: From Hyatt centric to Hotel Icon
usertext: I don't recommend the ferry in this particular case. The walkway (gangplank) is narrow. It also moves around quite a bit as you board. There will also be points where you will need to lift your luggage to get inside the cabin. The ride just isn't very comfortable especially if you have bags. I supposed if you really want to go cheap, you could take the MTR to Admiralty station and change to the East Rail Line. Disembark at Hung Hom station and walk towards TST East. You should reach Hotel Icon in <10 minutes. Cross Harbour Tunnel buses do not allow large bags. Sticking to a taxi is my recommendation. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Visiting Central Market and PMQ on a Sunday
usertext: Hi i plan to visit Central Mkt and PMQ on a Sunday, is it a good idea? will most of the shops be closed? i dont plan to eat there but rather, to visit the other retail shops. thanks

subject: 1. Re: Visiting Central Market and PMQ on a Sunday
usertext: You can view individual shops & restaurants details on both the Central Market and PMQ websites. Most businesses are open on Sundays. Best to target lunch time or later if you want to catch highest percentage of businesses being open. Some don't bother until 11am(ish). Central Market https://www.centralmarket.hk/en/shops-directory PMQ https://www.pmq.org.hk/studios-shops-restaurants/?lang=en&cat=home-lifestyle

subject: 2. Re: Visiting Central Market and PMQ on a Sunday
usertext: PMQ is normally quite quiet on weekdays so I am sure all shops will be open to maximize business on weekends. To get there, be sure to take the pedestrian escalator up to Staunton St and then cut across. Otherwise, you will face a very steep uphill walk at Aberdeen St.

subject: 3. Re: Visiting Central Market and PMQ on a Sunday

subject: Two free days in Hongkong
usertext: Hi we shall spend four days in Hongkong this month, including day of arrival ( reaching early in our Hotel in Kawloon). The second and third day will be for Dusneyland and Ocean Park ( booking from their website) . Can someone suggest how best to utilise the first and fourth day? We would like to cover Victoria peak, Sky line, Laser show etc ( + any other interesting spot) but not sure how to sequence it. Also, do these places require any ticket / advance booking? Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Two free days in Hongkong
usertext: {Can someone suggest how best to utilise the first and fourth day?} Have a good look through the Discover Hong Kong website to get a feel for what sort of places or activities around the city are most interesting to you (see link). https://www.discoverhongkong.com/ Personally, I adore the Star Ferry, ride it several times a month and take all my visiting friends and family for a ride. You mentioned Victoria Peak. Great, the Peak Tram is really fun. Go first thing in the morning if you don't want to queue at the Lower Terminus. Go in the evening or night for the skyline views, expect a queue (or just take bus 15 up to the Peak). Walking the TST Promenade at night to view the magnificent Hong Kong Island skyline on a clear night is great. The evening laser show is not personally interesting to me but some like it. We have some surprisingly good quality museums in Hong Kong and some really good light hiking/walking opportunities, some with amazing views if you want to spend some time outdoors. Its all up to you to thinnk about and decide for your trip.

subject: 2. Re: Two free days in Hongkong
usertext: Harbourside lunch at Sai Kung, walk up Nathan Road and explore the street markets at Shamshuipo, then early evening ferry and dinner on Lamma make a great day. Oh, add dim sum breakfast somewhere near your hotel.

subject: 3. Re: Two free days in Hongkong
usertext: My three "must do's" in HK include the Star Ferry, The Peak, and the Ding Ding Tram. After you settle down at your hotel, take the Star Ferry to HK Island. Then ride the length of the Ding Ding Tram. If the weather is nice (i.e no cloud cover), go up to the Peak. I prefer an evening visit, to see the city lights come on for an iconic view of HK.

subject: 4. Re: Two free days in Hongkong
usertext: I caught the bus over to Stanley when I was in HK last week. I thought it was nice, and a different side of HK than most of the city.

subject: Ngong Ping Cable Car
usertext: My wife and I have a meeting on Hong Kong Island this Friday near the Govt center at 11 am, hopefully done by noon. Afterwards we were hoping to head over to Lantau and do the Cable Car. However, I'm wondering if just an afternoon is sufficient time-wise, especially if the que is an hour and MRT takes an hour to get there? We don't have to go to the Tai O village. But we'd like to go up to the Buddha. Normally we would go at the opening time to avoid crowds, but we have this meeting. Perhaps take a Taxi instead of MRT? Thanks for any suggestions.

subject: 1. Re: Ngong Ping Cable Car
usertext: Are you set on taking the cable car up the mountain? If you want to avoid the queue problem of visiting during afternoon, what I might suggest is going up by way of bus and then taking the Ngong Ping cable car back down instead. There is rarely a queue issue coming down. From Central you could do this by taking ferry from the Central Ferry Pier over to Mui Wo on Lantau Island. Right outside the Mui Wo ferry pier, just take bus route 2 directly to the Ngong Ping Village. This is where you see the Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery. You can then take the Ngong Ping cable car back down the mountain to Tung Chung. The ride back is just as nice as the right up in my honest opinion. https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/detail/4

subject: 2. Re: Ngong Ping Cable Car
usertext: hi all pls allow me to jump into this thread too cause i plan to take the cable car at around 11am on a Saturday in December. will there be long queues at that time of the day on a Saturday? thanks

subject: 3. Re: Ngong Ping Cable Car
usertext: Thanks BradJill - great suggestion to head directly to Ngong Ping Village and simply take the Cable Car back down. We are not at all married to the ride up. So doing so on the return down might be a better use of our time. The ferry and bus sounds good although it will take quite a while. What would be a good way to take the MRT to somewhere on Lantau and then take a taxi up to Ngong Ping?

subject: 4. Re: Ngong Ping Cable Car
usertext: You can take the MTR to Tung Chung (orange line) and get to the Buddha by bus 23. This is probably the fastest option. Few taxis can go to the Buddha.

subject: 5. Re: Ngong Ping Cable Car
usertext: @octopusmum (post 2) {around 11am on a Saturday in December. will there be long queues } Given that you are going on a Saturday, unless the weather is poor, there will probably long queue. Note that there are two different queues. One to purchase tickets and the other to board the cable car. If you purchase your tickets in advance online, you can skip the first queue. This can save you some time. @dw732 {The ferry and bus sounds good although it will take quite a while. What would be a good way to take the MRT to somewhere on Lantau and then take a taxi up to Ngong Ping?} If you use Google Maps and search Ngong Ping 360 Village, Directions from Central Ferry Pier you will see the ferry + bus 2 route (roughly 2 hours) and the MTR to Tung Chung + bus 23 route (roughly 1 hr 23 min). The ferry is a fun and at times beautiful ride when sky conditions are favourable where the MTR is a boring ride over to Tung Chung. But 'yes' definitely faster use the MTR approach.

subject: 6. Re: Ngong Ping Cable Car
usertext: Thank you for all these tips. Bottom line seems to be that there's no "relatively quick" way to get to Ngong Ping from Admiralty Station (where we'll be) except by car the whole way. And even that is probably over an hour. Any public transport will be an hour to Tung Chung and then a choice of queing for the Cable Car up, or take the bus. Maybe same amount of time at around 1pm on a Friday.

subject: 7. Re: Ngong Ping Cable Car
usertext: >> except by car the whole way. And even that is probably over an hour. And that only works if the car in question has a Lantau permit!

subject: 10. Re: Ngong Ping Cable Car
usertext: From Tai O, you best take a bus direct to Tung Chung rather than up to Ngong Ping to take the cable car. Best do Ngong Ping in the morning, Tai O in the afternoon - then the village is much more lively. Before 11ish it's pretty dead, well that's the situation BC, now with fewer tourists it will be worse.

subject: HKIA to Marco Polo Prince Hotel via city flyer
usertext: Are there buses from the airport to Marco Polo Prince Hotel?

subject: 1. Re: HKIA to Marco Polo Prince Hotel via city flyer
usertext: You can take Airport Bus A21. Alight at either Bus Stop #14 (Cameron Road, Nathan Road), or Bus Stop #15 (Middle Road, Nathan Road). About the same distance... find Haiphong Road (at 90-degree to Nathan Road). Take it to Canton Road and walk along Canton Road a little bit to Prince Hotel. The drawback is Haiphong Road and Canton Road are often crowded with pedestrian. Especially during late afternoon and evening commuting hours. Walking with luggage among the crowd is a bit uneasy.

subject: 2. Re: HKIA to Marco Polo Prince Hotel via city flyer
usertext: Thank you. I assume that the airport shuttles from AirPort Express Kowloon station haven't resumed. But if the hotel shuttles are back in operation, I would take the AirPort Express. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: HKIA to Marco Polo Prince Hotel via city flyer
usertext: I remember reading those shuttles have been cancelled permanently. Your alternative is if course a short taxi ride (MUCH faster than that shuttle). The bus in however is far cheaper than the Airport Express.

subject: 4. Re: HKIA to Marco Polo Prince Hotel via city flyer
usertext: If you use the A bus to Nathan Road, disembark around Cameron Road. The street crossing nearby at Haiphong Road is more straightforward. You can actually see the Harbourcity complex all the way down at Canton Road. Haiphong Road isn't as crowded as in years past. Once you cross Nathan Road, make the extra crossing to walk on the right side of the street heading west. The sidewalk is wider and there won't be another street crossing until you reach Canton Road. The Airport Express free shuttles are indeed gone for good. Still, if you want the easiest trip, using Airport Express + taxi is the best choice. Allow roughly $50 for the taxi ride plus any luggage fees. The ride should take about 10-15 minutes depending on your exact arrival day and time.

subject: Octopus transport card

When you leave Hong Kong, simply return it at the customer service station for a refund." Can I return that card at any store or only at some points? subject: 1. Re: Octopus transport card
usertext: Not at stores. You can return it at any MTR Station Customer Service counter. Depending on which ferry pier you plan to use to go to Macau. If Macau Ferry Terminal in Sheung Wan, then use Sheung Wan MTR Station (about 300 meters in underground pedestrian walkpath connection.) If using China Ferry Terminal in Tsim Sha Tsui, either Austin MTR Station or Tsim Sha Tsui MTR Station will be the closest. Tsim Sha Tsui Station maybe a tad closer.

subject: 3. Re: Octopus transport card
usertext: {As far as I am aware, ferries to Macau are currently only departing from the Sheung Wan terminal. } That is my understanding as well. I'm not aware of any sailing companies offering the Kowloon to Macau or Taipa route from the China Ferry Terminal on Canton Road in TST anymore.

subject: Transportation From HKG Airport to Kowloon?
usertext: Easiest mode of transportation from HKG airport to Kerry Hotel in Kowloon?

subject: 1. Re: Transportation From HKG Airport to Kowloon?
usertext: Easiest by far: taxi

subject: 2. Re: Transportation From HKG Airport to Kowloon?
usertext: USRGiants, Best to become familiar with Google maps before your trip to HK (see link) https://www.google.com/maps Type in Kerry Hotel and then click the direction button while viewing the hotel location on the map. You can then type in where you are coming from. Type in Hong Kong International Airport. Google Maps will then create a direction map with various options including (foot, car, train and bus) so you can review different transportation recommendations to the hotel. You can adjust travel time as well while reviewing transportation options when deciding which is the best transportation option for you personally. Note, I'd also recommend downloading CityMapper to your mobile phone. https://citymapper.com When you arrive in Hong Kong, open the app and it will set for Hong Kong. This is a useful app to use locally and functions similarly to Google Maps but also provides estimated taxi fares which can be useful if you plan on using this form of transport while in the city. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Transportation From HKG Airport to Kowloon?
usertext: There is a bus that gets to Hung Hom South Road which is then probably a 10-minute walk to your hotel. I don't rate this option as practical since you will likely get lost and not like dragging bags for this sort of distance. If you want to go cheap then, take A21 bus to Hung Hom station and change to a taxi there. The cost difference at the end is probably around HKD100-120. Taxi is the easiest for sure. Pay by the meter plus luggage fee. No need to tip.

subject: 4. Re: Transportation From HKG Airport to Kowloon?

subject: HKIA to Regal Riverside Hotel Sha Tin
usertext: We are a family of 4, 2 adults, 2 kids, 13 & 10 - with 4 hold luggage & hand luggage - is there a bus that will get us from airport to near our hotel please? We'll arrive in hk 21.30 do it will likely be 22.00 by the time we exit the airport. Or is a taxi preferable? Thanks in advance!

subject: 1. Re: HKIA to Regal Riverside Hotel Sha Tin
usertext: For this particular hotel, the Airport Bus A41 works well. They have a bus stop named "Regal Riverside Hotel" right across the street from the hotel. Couldn't be any better. You walk down to the ground level (on a ramp) or take the elevator to the ground level from the Arrival Hall. Follow the signs for "Bus". The airport bus terminus is right at the bottom of the ramp. Find the bay for A41. There are luggage racks on the these airport buses. It is okay to roll your free luggage carts (from the Baggage Claim Carousels) with your bags all the way down the ramp to the Bus Terminus. No problem. You leave those empty luggage carts at the bus terminus and some airport workers will take care of retrieving them. You need some local cash (HKD) to pay for the bus fare. Children below age of 12 pays half price. No extra charge for the luggage. Or you can get your Octopus Cards (one car per person, the child aged 10 gets the Child Octopus Card) at the airport and use Octopus Cards to pay for the bus fares. This link will send you to the KMB's (the bus company) route search page. Click on the bus icon for search. Enter "A41" and you will see all the bus stop details and the route plotted on a map. Link: https://search.kmb.hk/KMBWebSite/?action=routesearch&route=A41&lang=en Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: HKIA to Regal Riverside Hotel Sha Tin
usertext: Airport bus A41. Stop #8 is your hotel.

subject: 3. Re: HKIA to Regal Riverside Hotel Sha Tin
usertext: Rachel S, Best to familiarise yourself with google maps and CityMapper and download these apps on your mobile phone in order to plot your transportation needs around Hong Kong. In addition to routes like the airport to Regal Riverside both can be used to identify preferred modes of transportation (foot, car, bus, MTR and ferry) throughout the city. Best of luck with the rest of your trip planning and hope your family enjoys HK.

subject: 1. Re: Cultural dinner experience recommendations
usertext: From my own experience, these types of dinners are geared towards tour groups. I have never joined a tour group in HK, so I am not aware of any such dinner. I am bumping this post up so maybe others have some ideas.

subject: 2. Re: Cultural dinner experience recommendations
usertext: I am afraid there is almost none of these kinds of dinner experience for you. You may take a look of this website 7 places to discover Cantonese Opera in Hong Kong https://www.discoverhongkong.com/hk-eng/explore/arts/discover-cantonese-opera-in-hong-kong.html Xiqu Centre A purpose-built venue for Cantonese opera as well as other forms of Chinese traditional theatre (known as xiqu in Mandarin), Xiqu Centre in West Kowloon Cultural District is the ideal place for an introduction to the genre. Immerse yourself in world-class performances at the Grand Theatre, or sit back and enjoy tea and dim sum at the cosy Tea House Theatre as you take in 90-minute excerpts of all-time favourites performed by the resident troupe. Featuring expert narration, the intimate venue is designed to recreate the down-to-earth experience enjoyed in the 20th century. Should you be inspired to deepen your knowledge, be sure to check out the latest screenings, workshops, talks and exhibitions at the centre.

subject: Buying octopus tourist card at HKIA
usertext: Hi all I will be touching down at the HKIA at round 5.20am. understand that i can buy the octopus tourist card at the 7 eleven store in the airport but read somewhere that it is always out of stock. Also, the ones sold at the 7 eleven store do not have any value so i still need to top it up. so the other alternative place where i can get the card will be the MTR octopus card selling machines at the airport station (according to the MTR website). just to confirm, are these automated ticketing machines? and i just have to find my way to the airport express station to find these machines? if i manage to buy the card at 7 eleven, can i top it up in the 7 eleven store itself using credit card? thanks in advance

subject: 1. Re: Buying octopus tourist card at HKIA
usertext: By the time you're out in arrivals, the MTR customer service centre will be open already. You can just go there to get your Octopus cards. Octopus cards can be topped up only by cash, unless you have a local credit card in which case you can link your Octopus to it for automatic top-up.

subject: 2. Re: Buying octopus tourist card at HKIA
usertext: Can the initial purchase & loading be done by card or must I find an ATM or money changer first? Also what time does the MTR Service Centre close? I arrive at approximately 10pm. Thank you.

subject: 3. Re: Buying octopus tourist card at HKIA
usertext: The MTR service centre is open until the last train, which is at 00:54. Yes - you need to use one of the many ATMs to get HK$ cash first. Use one from a reputable bank (HSBC, Citibank, Bank of China, Hang Seng) to avoid the risk of ATM fees.

subject: 4. Re: Buying octopus tourist card at HKIA
usertext: Thank you

subject: Will the HK taxi reject me if the taxi ride is very short (1
usertext: I am planning a trip to Hong Kong. From the airport, will take the express train to Hong Kong station. From there, take a taxi to the hotel which is less than 1 km. Will appreciate your advice whether the taxi can reject me. Will he be angry. Thank you.

subject: 1. Re: Will the HK taxi reject me if the taxi ride is very short (1
usertext: I don't think you need to worry about it too much. #1) Refusing service after a passenger has gotten in the cabin and stated the destination which is within the service zone of that taxi color (red, green, blue), basically red taxi can go everywhere except the Lantau Island, is against the rules. The driver can face investigation and consequences if the passengers complain. #2) Typically what makes a taxi driver reluctant to make a run is that if he has been waiting a long time in a taxi queue (such as the Hong Kong Airport), and then get a short-distance order (such as going to the Marriott SkyCity Hotel at the airport), then he may have to go back to queue again for another 30 minutes or whatever to get his turn. In your case it is very different. Your hotel, close to the Hong Kong Station, is very much a busy part of Hong Kong. He would not have worries on whether he can pick up other passengers after dropping you off.

subject: 2. Re: Will the HK taxi reject me if the taxi ride is very short (1
usertext: Thank you for your reply. I am more reassured now.

subject: Best area to stay?
usertext: Hello, Im spending new year in Hong Kong with 2 friends and was wondering where is best to stay out of sai ying pun and wan chai district. We enjoy going and socialising/having fun etc any recommendations welcome!

subject: 1. Re: Best area to stay?
usertext: As long as you are fairly near an MTR Station it doesn't really matter that much. Both are on the Island line and pretty just a few stops away from each other. In Wanchai you are one station away from Admiralty which is a major MTR hub. Sai Ying Pun on the other hand is two short stops from Central MTR and Hong Kong Station another major hub.

subject: 2. Re: Best area to stay?
usertext: Ever since Sai Ying Pun got MTR service, it's become a good location. Both locations are good nowadays.

subject: 3. Re: Best area to stay?
usertext: Agree, both areas are fine. Wan Chai is more crowded in general, a mix if residential and offices, Sai Ying Pun has a more residential feel. Overall start by looking for hotels in both areas and see which catch your fancy.

subject: Hong Kong Pre Arrival Registration query
usertext: I'm an Indian National living and working in Canada, and hold a Canada PR visa. While filling out the Pre-arrival Registration form, do I need to put the Residential address of Canada or Indian Address in my Indian Passport?

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Pre Arrival Registration query
usertext: I would put my actual residential address - i.e. the one in Canada. It is well understood outside India that the address where you happened to live when you last renewed your passport is not a particularly useful piece of information. (It is, by the way, perfectly possible to put your Canadian address in your passport next time you renew it, but that's no more likely to be true several years later either!)

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Pre Arrival Registration query
usertext: I believe on the PAR application you have to indicate if your residential address is in India or not. If not, you are supposed to complete a different section for Residential address other than India, in your case - Canada.

subject: Travel across the sea without flying
usertext: Hi everyone! How can I travel from the Philippines to Hong Kong and back without flying?

subject: 1. Re: Travel across the sea without flying
usertext: Yes. Take a cruise.

subject: 2. Re: Travel across the sea without flying
usertext: I don't think you will find a regular passenger cruise service (between the Philippines and Hong Kong) as I don't think the demand is there. But you can look into freight ship travel, where a freight ship will offer passenger transport from A to B (limited "seats"). Those are short-haul (a few hundred miles or so), which will only take a couple of days for the voyage.

subject: 3. Re: Travel across the sea without flying
usertext: I'm unaware of any cruises departing from Manila that come to Hong Kong

subject: 4. Re: Travel across the sea without flying
usertext: People also sail regularly between the two - if you have any experience of sailing then I guess you might be able to crew on such a boat, but I have no idea of how you go about finding them - I guess maybe ask at one of the bigger yacht clubs in the Philippines.

subject: 5. Re: Travel across the sea without flying
usertext: Cruises - if they exist they will be a relatively expensive and slow way to travel, calling in intermediate ports. I'd actually be a bit surprised if there are none that call in both Philippines and Hong Kong, though there may be no one way trips between the two places. All in all I'd not see that as a sensible option if all you're looking for is to get from A to B. Cargo ships indeed also take passengers - honestly no idea where to find information on that. Crew on a yacht? I wonder who would want to hire someone for a few days on one way trip, especially if this someone has no experience whatsoever in the field. There is quite certainly no ocean line between the two places, those services are very rare nowadays for any distance longer than a day or two (and those are primarily for trucks and people wanting to bring their car along for international travel, which is quite a common thing in Europe).

subject: 6. Re: Travel across the sea without flying
usertext: Sure there are. Holland America has cruises to and from HK, visiting the Philippines.

subject: Travel Insurance
usertext: I will be travelling to Hong Kong on 16 th of this month from INDIA. I will stay there for 3 (three) months. Do I need TRAVEL INSURANCE. If so then which company's insurance would be good for me?

subject: 1. Re: Travel Insurance
usertext: Yes, it is better to have travel insurance. Usually traveler buy travel insurance in their own country.

subject: 2. Re: Travel Insurance
usertext: {Do I need TRAVEL INSURANCE.} For Indian Nationals, you are required to arrange a Pre Arrival Registration (PAR) prior to travelling to Hong Kong (see link). Travel Insurance on the otherhand is highly recommended by not compulsory for entry into Hong Kong. https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/visas/pre-arrival_registration_for_indian_nationals.html

subject: 3. Re: Travel Insurance
usertext: Whoa - sorry to correct BradJill, but a PAR is not sufficient for a stay of 3 months. You need to apply for a visa. So if you haven't already done so then you have a problem because there's no way you will get a visa in 48 hours. Without a visa then a PAR will get you access for 14 days. Without a PAR you will (or at least should) be denied boarding on the aircraft. If you do not have a PAR or a visa and manage to board the aircraft then you will be refused entry and sent on the next plane back whence you came. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Travel Insurance
usertext: >>> Whoa - sorry to correct BradJill, LOL that doesn't happen much! Must be a very special feeling :-) The way OP writes it I assume the paperwork has been taken care of. Travel insurance is not mandatory but highly recommended. The main thing I think you should be worried about is medical expenses: if you have an accident or fall ill, you will have to pay full fare for the hospitals, and that will get expensive, fast. Now it is entirely possible that this is covered by your local health insurance (I have no idea how that works in India), if so there is in my opinion far less reason to take travel insurance. Other key benefits are cancellations and evacuations, both which are not usually an issue for a 3-month stay which for its length I suppose is not basic tourism.

subject: 5. Re: Travel Insurance
usertext: {Whoa - sorry to correct BradJill, but a PAR is not sufficient for a stay of 3 months. You need to apply for a visa.} Don't be sorry. It was a glaring omission.

subject: Car hire company
usertext: Can someone please suggest a good car hire company in HK?

subject: 1. Re: Car hire company
usertext: Try to see reviews on klook.

subject: 2. Re: Car hire company
usertext: Hiring a car (assuming you mean self-drive) really isn't a thing in Hong Kong. We have the world's best public transport system (by far) so there really isn't much of a market for it. Bear in mind that parking cars in Hong Kong is can be very hard unless you take long term rental on car park spaces in/under buildings.

subject: 4. Re: Car hire company
usertext: No things won't change, I am asking about self drive car here

subject: 5. Re: Car hire company
usertext: It exists, but as mentioned above it's just a terrible idea, unless you like spending most of your time finding a place to park. Use taxis instead. No worries about finding your way, no need to find a place to park the thing making your trips much faster, and likely far cheaper to boot. Or regular transit. About as fast as driving your car - provided you know exactly where to park and so.

subject: 6. Re: Car hire company
usertext: A normal person living in central HK where they can access the MTR network within a 10-minute walk has no need for a car. Car rental, parking and fuel are all very expensive. Also, the roads are often congested. Even if you use Google Map to navigate, you are still going to get lost and possibly, break traffic laws because Google Map is known to have bugs. It has asked me to make illegal turns in the past. To expand on traffic laws, the police do pull people over for various transgressions that might not be strictly enforced overseas. They include crossing solid lines, driving in bus lanes, and staying in the fast lane for a prolonged period not overtaking. There are also many red light and speed cameras. Illegal parking and stopping are strictly enforced nowadays. I don't dare to leave my car for more than a few minutes now. Finally, even if feel you have gotten lucky with something illegal, many drivers around you have car cameras installed. You might still get reported and fined at a later date through your rental company. Overall, driving is a bad idea if you don't know the local customs. Aside from public transport and taxis, if you are going somewhere remote so you are worried about getting a ride back, you can call a car on Uber. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: first time Hongkong-December or February
usertext: Dear Honkong experts, I would like to visit Hongkong (for 1 week), I am not sure about the weather. Is December sunnier than February? Is the air pollution (seasonal) different? Would you stay on HK island or in Kowloon area? Thank you very much!

subject: 2. Re: first time Hongkong-December or February
usertext: I would avoid visiting HK during the Lunar New Year period, which will be in February next year. Yes, things will be more decorated and there will be a big fireworks display but otherwise, a lot of places will be shut down and people visiting their families. It's not a good time to be a tourist there who doesn't know anybody. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: first time Hongkong-December or February
usertext: Thank you very much!

subject: 4. Re: first time Hongkong-December or February
usertext: That's only an issue for the first few days of the new year. The two weeks right before new year are great, with decorations and new year markets and so all over the place - you can actually very well compare it with how we celebrate Christmas in Europe. The weeks before is where the fun is, Christmas day and a few days after everything is shut down.

subject: 5. Re: first time Hongkong-December or February
usertext: Weather-wise, I like December better. February seems to have more variation. As to the impact of CNY, the most obvious effect only lasts one day which is CNY day itself. Though some places might still be closed starting on day 2 for one or even a few more days, enough shops and restaurants will be open that you won't feel too much of a difference. On CNY day itself, plan activities like hikes, theme parks or most attractions. Just don't plan on any major shopping. For Christmas and 1/1, just about all places operate just as normal.

subject: 6. Re: first time Hongkong-December or February
usertext: Thank you!I have to say, February sounds also very good

subject: 7. Re: first time Hongkong-December or February
usertext: I use this site often for checking weather in advance; works world-wide. Notice the "tourism score" section toward the bottom. https://weatherspark.com/y/127942/Average-Weather-in-Hong-Kong-Hong-Kong-SAR-China-Year-Round I just booked flights to HK over CNY, oops, forgot about that detail. So I quickly booked accommodation for the CNY part, ouch pricey. Ah well, it should be an experience. :)

The menu shows a special daily set per week day and the menu shows the entire Disney Dim Sum Set available weekends and public holidays only; however, the actual Disney Crystal Lotus website states that the menu is available daily. Emailing Disneyland HK customer service has not been helpful. I'm asking because our only weekend day there is the day we're leaving so if need be, we'll be booking out a flight much later so that I can get my full Disney Dim Sum Set experience but if the entire set is available every day then we could do it another day and won't need to fly out so late so I wanted to make sure before booking our flight home.

subject: 1. Re: Crystal Lotus HK Disneyland Disney Dim Sum
usertext: I'm sure the good folk of HK DIsneyland know. It's their thing after all. If e-mailing doesn't work, try calling.

subject: Multiple entries visa for Vietnamese nationals
usertext: As I know, Hong Kong SAR has relaxed the visa policy for Vietnamese nationals since October 2023. Now Vietnamese can apply for 2-years multiple entry visa instead of single entry ones. On the Immigration Department website, they stated that applicants should have "related business activities" in Hong Kong as a reason to visit Hong Kong frequently. I actually do not have any business activities there, but I love Hong Kong and have visited three times. So I wrote an email for the Immigration Department to ask whether I can use the reason that "I love Hong Kong and want so spend times visiting the city" to apply for multiple entries visa. But 8 days have passed since I sent the email and I haven't received any response. Is it a normal waiting time? Maybe because this is a new visa policy so the Immigration Department will take more time to reply? Should I send them another email to remind them about my case, or should I just simply wait ? The relevant statement of Immigration Department about new visa policy for Vietnamese nationals could be found at the link below: (Q16) https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/faq/visit-transit.html

subject: 1. Re: Multiple entries visa for Vietnamese nationals
usertext: The wording of these things tend to be quite precise: you must demonstrate a *need* to visit HK frequently. I'm not very confident that wanting to visit as a tourist is a "need". 8 days is quite short. Give them at least 2 clear weeks to reply. HK Government departments don't generally take kindly to chasers unless you have a genuine *urgent* need.

subject: 2. Re: Multiple entries visa for Vietnamese nationals
usertext: Yeah, I totally understand that they will need time. I just want to explain a bit: in June 2023 I also emailed Immigration Department to make an enquiry about my e-visa, and the replied after 3 days. The e-visa was a much more straightforward case, though. Yes I also understand that the need to visit as a tourist may not be considered a genuine "need" in normal terms, but I love to travel (I have made three trips overseas in this year, all with my family) and Hong Kong is the closest global city from my hometown (Hanoi). So, for me, a people who do leisure travel quite a lot, having a multiple entry visa to Hong Kong is a genuine "need", as it would allow me to reach a global city after just 2 hour flight. I will be able to take a Friday night flight to Hong Kong and spend the weekend chilling there before fly back home in Sunday night. Currently, without a multiple entry visa to Hong Kong, the closest Tier 1 global city I can reach is Singapore, after a 4-hours flight. I can reach Taipei after 3 hours, but I consider Taipei to be Tier 2. All other global cities such as Tokyo, Seoul, Sydney.... will be at least 4.5 hours away from me and I cannot do a quick trip there in the weekend. So, to make it short, as a active traveller, I have a genuine need to visit a global city every month just to chill there and stay far away from all the work-related stress, and having a multiple entry visa to Hong Kong will be a game changer for me, because Hong Kong is pretty close to my hometown.

subject: 3. Re: Multiple entries visa for Vietnamese nationals
usertext: RE: "I have a genuine need to visit a global city every month just to chill there and stay far away from all the work-related stress" = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Your "need" is not a need. Just a wish. Immigration officers have their own priorities and focus. And their criteria.

subject: 4. Re: Multiple entries visa for Vietnamese nationals
usertext: I sympathise with your situation but fear your case will fall on uninterested ears when it comes to HK immigration. The recent relaxing of the visa rules is specifically designed to attract talent (work force) to Hong Kong. Your case of wanting to travel here more freely, while genuine to you personally, doesn't seem to fit the design or purpose of the updated visa rules & regulations as they are likely to be understood by HK Immigration. Perhaps you'll get lucky and hear something positive from them but I wouldn't get my hopes up unfortunately.

subject: 5. Re: Multiple entries visa for Vietnamese nationals
usertext: I understand your perspectives and it is great to hear from you guys. Just want to explain a bit, that I have done some research about the visa policy. The Post (https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/hong-kong-economy/article/3239501/hong-kongs-eased-visas-rules-vietnamese-first-step-more-travel-relaxations-and-open-access-inflow) stated that "a new multiple-entry visas will allow Vietnamese travellers to visit the city for a maximum of 14 days each time". Xinhuanet (https://english.news.cn/20231025/6996017b39524dcdb3137b9fe177c221/c.html) also quoted John Lee's words such as "The HKSAR will relax the visa policy in respect of employment for Vietnamese talents and the criteria for Vietnamese applying for "multiple-entry visas" for business and travel". So, in my opinion, this new and more relaxed visa policy will be applied for employment, business and travel purpose. The texts on Immigration Department website are as below: (FAQ): I am a Vietnamese national who require to come to Hong Kong frequently for visit or business purpose. What type of visa can I apply for? With effective from 25 October 2023, Vietnamese nationals who can meet the following criteria may apply for multiple-journey visit visa to come to Hong Kong They specifically mentioned "visit" (which I interpreted as "travel") and "business" as two purpose that can being used to apply for a multiple entry visa. But yes, maybe my interpretation is a bit off. And I can always apply for the single entry visa, so there is no problem at all. Thank you so much.

subject: 6. Re: Multiple entries visa for Vietnamese nationals
usertext: OK you have me convinced. I'll grant you a multiple entry visa. Oops, I am not HK immigration. Neither is anyone here on this forum. None of our opinions matter.

subject: 7. Re: Multiple entries visa for Vietnamese nationals
usertext: All of your opinion matters to me. It is great to hear from you.

subject: Hong Kong trip report with kids June 2023
usertext: We set no alarms for Saturday morning and no one suffered any disrupted sleep from jetlag. so we rather bemusedly rolled out of bed around eleven in the morning. This didn't present a problem as we didn't have much on our agenda for our three full days in Hong Kong. The hotel was just a couple of blocks from the Fa Yuen street market which is best known for discounted clothing but also has plenty of fruits stands where we immediately loaded up on lychees and yang mei. After lunch we met up with another one of Mei Ling's old friends and his family and spent the afternoon bumming around Sham Shui Po, another busy commercial neighborhood just north of Mong Kok. There was another multilevel food market here called Pei Ho with its own food court. After dinner we made an exhausting climb up hundreds of stairs to the top of Woh Chai Shan, an incongruous forested hill adjacent to the busy commercial district of Sham Shui Po. Standing among the trees gazing out on the dense rows of residential apartment towers gave a new perspective on the term "urban jungle". On Sunday morning we roused ourselves at a more reasonable time in order to spend the day on Lantau Island with another of Mei Ling's old friends. This mountainous, sparsely populated island is best known to foreigners as the site of Hong Kong Disneyland but also has a famous monastery and several small fishing villages. We took Hong Kong's efficient and clean metro to a heavily developed section of the island called Tung Chung where the departure station of the Ngong Ping cable car is located. The cable car travels three and a half miles to the top of the Ngong Ping plateau, the highest point on Lantau. We paid a little extra for a Crystal Cabin which has a glass floor and floor-to-ceiling glass walls. It was well worth the extra expense because the panoramic views of Lantau were spectacular. It was like King Kong's island with clusters of towering white skyscrapers. Below us we could see more intrepid travelers making the journey up the mountain by foot. After lunch at a noddle restaurant we made our way to the main attraction of the plateau, the Po Lin monastery. This Buddhist monastery was found just a century ago by traveling monks from Jiangsu province. The Tian Tan Buddha was completed in 1993 and has already become one of Hong Kong's most well-known features. The statue is over a hundred feet tall and sits atop a platform that can only be reached by climbing two hundred and sixty-eight steps upward from the monastery. It was quite a brutal ascent but eventually we all made it and spent a few minutes catching our breath at the top. Back at Ngong Ping we boarded a bus to Tai O village. The colorful fishing boats and wooden houses on stilts had lots of visual appeal and were dutifully being photographed by clumps of tourists at every vantage point. The village has a daily market that is largely dedicated to souvenirs, herbal remedies, and street foods and probably isn't very useful to the residents aside from being a source of income. We did try the local specialty of fish maw soup which was quite tasty. We had a pleasant ferry ride between Lantau and Hong Kong Island with interesting close-up views of some of the smaller uninhabited islands. The skyline of the island was as impressive as I remembered it from my last visit in 2008. We checked out a few of the most famous streets in the Central neighborhood which featured some impressive street art. One memorable spot was Wing Lee Street which was actually a pedestrian walkway through a 1950's housing development. Ultimately we decided we would just eat in Mong Kok again and we made our way back to Central Pier for the short ferry ride across Victoria Harbor. I knew there was a nightly light show at the harbor called "A Symphony of Lights" at eight but I didn't know exactly what it was or the best place to see it. The best thing we could think of for our last few hours in Hong Kong was to walk all the way down to Tsim Sha Tsui on the waterfront. The only notable stop we made on the walk down was at the Nelson Street wet market, one of the largest outdoor markets in Hong Kong and probably the most enjoyable for us on this visit. It was a short walk to the Harbour Promenade, which is all that many visitors see of Kowloon. A statuesque bronze replica of the Hong Kong Film Awards statue marked the entrance to the Avenue of Stars, a knockoff of the Hollywood Walk of Fame that features the handprints of over a hundred Chinese movie stars set at intervals along the waterfront. We had a similar view of the Hong Kong Island skyline that we had from the ferry but more time to appreciate it from a variety of angles. Behind the Avenue of Stars was the K11 Musea shopping mall which prominently featured several luxury brands and a large empty space in the center that a small plane could have flown through. We hooked around the mall to find a route back to Nathan Street from which we could get a double decker bus back to Mong Kok. Here there was one more open plaza with a backdrop of futuristic Kowloon skyscrapers, our final taste of Hong Kong's postmodern edge. For full report and photos https://zzlangerhans.travellerspoint.com/971/

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong trip report with kids June 2023
usertext: Thanks for the report. " the top of the Ngong Ping plateau, the highest point on Lantau" is a bit odd though - if you looked around you would see that the plateau stands less than half way up a big hill known as Lantau Peak, which is actually the highest point on Lantau (and the second highest point in Hong Kong).

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong trip report with kids June 2023
usertext: Very nice report and photos. Glad you and your family had a good time.

subject: Older couple, post cruise Hong Kong at Christmas
usertext: We are a couple in our 70's and 80's and will be ending a cruise in Hong Kong on 22 Dec. 2024. We don't want to fly directly home to the U.S. at that time, due to the heavy pre-Christmas traffic, etc., but staying in Hong Kong seems a bit daunting, especially for my husband who has early dementia and crowds and noise upset him. So, we seem stuck. Can anyone suggest a good quiet, safe area in which we could stay for a few days and then fly home on Christmas Day, when things might be quieter. Thank you very much.

subject: 1. Re: Older couple, post cruise Hong Kong at Christmas
usertext: Sorry to hear about your husband's condition. HK is one of the most crowded cities in the world, and people are always hurrying everywhere. However, you can stay outside the city center. For example, Auberge Discovery Bay Hong Kong is located on Lantau Island, away from the hustle of the central city. Check the reviews to see if this suits you.

subject: 2. Re: Older couple, post cruise Hong Kong at Christmas
usertext: The 4-star Auberge is a good one indeed. DB is a fairly upmarket residential area, the hotel is next to one of the main shopping areas of the district. You may also look at the more basic 3-star Silvermine Beach Resort in Mui Wo. Also at a beach, a little out of the village, I expect it to be quieter than DB. A longer trek from the cruise terminal than DB, and a little longer trek from there to the airport. DB which is full of expats is likely to be far more Christmassy than the more local Mui Wo. Then the 5-star Hyatt Regency at University MTR station is a good hotel at a rather quiet location, but no sight-seeing or even restaurant options in the direct area. You'll need to travel a lot. Other rather quiet hotels but I think not good for you (just adding it for completion) include the Warwick on the island of Cheung Chau, and the heritage hotel in Tai O - no direct taxi access, it's a 20-minute walk or a short speed boat ride from the bus/taxi stop. Both those areas will get crowded on weekends and you happen to be there on a weekend. There's also a hotel near Sai Kung, which is quite far from the airport and also crowded on weekends. Not a great place for you to stay.

subject: 3. Re: Older couple, post cruise Hong Kong at Christmas
usertext: "Quiet" - are you picturing you both staying inside the hotel room for that few days? Do you plan to go out at all? Because once you go out of your hotel, just about anywhere you go (if you care to go there) will likely not be quiet.

subject: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: I am from Singapore, can I buy an Elder Octopus Card? I am over 65 years of age.

subject: 1. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Yes. In fact anyone can buy an Elder Octopus card. The age qualification is subject to checking on usage, not purchase; you should carry some form of photo ID showing your age when using one. Currently an Elder Octopus card gets the $2 concession fare (the remainder being paid by the government) on all public transport (except the ding-ding tram where the elder fare is $1.3). At some (as yet undefined) point in the future Elder Octopus cards will revert to simply getting whatever elder concession is offered by the transport operator (most often it's half the adult fare).

subject: 2. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Thanks, Ga Yau, So how much for the Elder Octopus card and where i can get one?

subject: 3. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: The card is a stored value card. The initial price is HK$100, which must be paid in HK$ cash only. This includes a $50 deposit and a stored value of HK$50. Assuming you are arriving by air, then you should get it at the MTR Customer Service desk at the centre of the Arrivals Hall of HK Airport. You can add more stored value either at the initial purchase or later; this can be done at any MTR station, or any 7-Eleven or CircleK convenience store. Add values must be in multiples of $50. When you leave HK you can return the card to the MTR Customer Service Centre at the airport and you will be refunded any remaining value, plus the initial $50 deposit, less an $11 handling fee; this will be in HK$ cash.

subject: 4. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Thanks again.

subject: 5. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: We are arriving by Ship at Kai Tak cruise terminal. Can I buy the Elder card at the cruise terminal? Thank you?

subject: 6. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: No, there is nowhere to buy an on-loan Elder Octopus Card at the cruise terminal. You can buy one from the customer service desk at any MTR station.

subject: 7. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: When we bought our Elder Octopus cards at HKIA on our arrival, we were asked about our ages. However, they didn't ask us to show our our passports (or IDs). While using it on MTR our proof of age was never checked.

subject: 8. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Maybe you were never checked, but checking is indeed done randomly. I was checked a couple of times when I was younger (still over 65) because I guess at that time I looked young. Friends of mine have also been checked. When you tag your Octopus card, the Elder card sounds differently than the regular cards. So anyone within earshot would know that you are using an Elder card.

subject: 9. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Just an update. We disembarked at Kai Tak Cruise Terminal on a Sunday. After immigration, walking out to the taxi queue, there was a portable Oyster Card booth. We bought our Seniors Card there. There were lots of taxis. Got a taxi within 5 mins. Suggest you have the name of your hotel in chinese to show the driver. Everything went smoothly.

subject: 11. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: Yes. It was unexpected that they would set up a portable booth. It was not a permanently built up booth but one with just a big banner that they could fold up and leave. But it served its purpose.

subject: 12. Re: Elder Octopus Card
usertext: I follow the local news, and remember the politicians being determined to fix transport bottlenecks at Kai Tak. To judge from the above, they've made some improvements, bravo!

subject: Which Luxury Hotel?
usertext: Planning a trip to Hong Kong for 2 nights as part of a longer Asia trip. I have narrowed it down to my top 4 hotels. Which is the best in terms of location, service, and views? 1) The Mandarin Oriental (not the landmark) 2) The Peninsula 3) The Rosewood 4) The Four Seasons Thanks in advance for your input!

subject: 1. Re: Which Luxury Hotel?
usertext: They're all pretty good. The "classic" view of the HK harbour skyline is from the TsimSha Tsui side, so you would want the Peninsula or the Rosewood for that. But the Four Seasons and the Mandarin also have good views (the Mandarin's harbour view is a little bit more cluttered than the others these days). Higher floors give significantly better views in the Peninsula and the Mandarin; doesn't make so much difference in the Four Seasons and the Rosewood. The Peninsula and the Mandarin are seen as slightly more "traditional" in their service. The Peninsula and the Rosewood are located in TST which is a bustling commercial area. The Mandarin and the Four Seasons are adjacent to the central business district. All are reasonably well-located for public transport (primarily the MTR/subway); it's a slightly longer walk from the Four Seasons to the main MTR line but it's adjacent to the city terminaus of the express railway in from the airport. All four have high end (and high price) restaurants; which is you prefer might depend on your choice of cuisine if you intend to eat in the hotel. But these are all minor issues - fundamentally you can't really go wrong with any of them.

subject: 2. Re: Which Luxury Hotel?
usertext: 2) The Peninsula, with its afternoon tea.

subject: 3. Re: Which Luxury Hotel?
usertext: Rosewood is the newest with a great view. However, the service is known to be spotty, not just at the hotel but also at reception and various dining outlets. The others are all fine depending on the area vibe you want.

subject: 4. Re: Which Luxury Hotel?
usertext: The Peninsula.

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong in town check-in
usertext: That is the current situation. Also worth note, the Kowloon Station check-in is still not operational even for Cathay Pacific passengers, just HK Station. https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/complom_checkin.html

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong in town check-in
usertext: Thanks Aussie. I haven't used this service before. Are there any disadvantages or 'traps for newbies' to be aware of, or is it a clear case of 'if you can, you should'? In other words, any possible reason NOT to use it that I should know about?

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong in town check-in
usertext: #2, @JackMiles: The in-town check-in is a wonderful service. There is no reason not to use it, when operational. This service has been suspended since the border closing after Covid-19 broke out. Even when the HKG airport had re-opened, and many flights gradually resumed operation, this in-town check-in service had not fully re-opened, as you note from Hong Kong DE BradJill's post (#1). It is just not available for many travelers.

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong in town check-in
usertext: There are no disadvantages to in-town check-in when available. The only caveat is you have to buy an Airport Express ticket to use the service.

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong in town check-in
usertext: Thanks HappyFeet & Sammy. Good to hear.

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong in town check-in
usertext: I think it is a fantastic service. Having said that, I would recommend you keep these things in mind: 1. allow sufficient time - perhaps 3-4 hours prior to the flight at the latest - to ensure your bags make it in time (you do not need to take the train immediately after you drop your bags) 2. monitor the number of Octopus card transactions after you check in (if you plan to use it to pay for your fare) and before you tap in for your train - you may want to keep it to a minimum to avoid hassles when you enter the platform area

subject: 7. Re: Hong Kong in town check-in
usertext: "allow sufficient time - perhaps 3-4 hours prior to the flight at the latest - to ensure your bags make it in time (you do not need to take the train immediately after you drop your bags)" This is absurd. ITCI closes 90 minutes before the departure of your flight. You bags will make it if you do ITCI. I've checked bags there dozens of times within 5 minutes of the check-in deadline and they have never once missed the flight.

subject: 8. Re: Hong Kong in town check-in
usertext: {allow sufficient time - perhaps 3-4 hours prior to the flight at the latest - to ensure your bags make it in time (you do not need to take the train immediately after you drop your bags)} I understand the thinking behind this very long time allowance if you've experienced hiccups at other international airports but it is really not necessary here in Hong Kong. The In-Town check-in has always worked like a charm and since you are right there at Airport Express (Hong Kong Station) which will have you at the airport in scheduled 24 minutes. As such, as long as you meet the 90 minute check-in requirement for In Town check-in, you really are good to go.

subject: 9. Re: Hong Kong in town check-in
usertext: When using in-town check-in, you definitely don't need to allow 3-4 hours before your flight time for your bags to get to your plane. I usually get to the station roughly 2 hours before my flight, drop off my bags and pick up my boarding passes. By the time my train gets to the airport, I should have about 75-90 minutes left which is always more than enough. HKG outbound processes are very efficient.
