subject: ATMs without additional fee
usertext: Hi all, We have a credit card that doesn't charge extra for withdrawing money. What are the best ATMs to use (ideally at HongKong Airport) that do not charge an additional ATM fee? Thanks!

subject: 1. Re: ATMs without additional fee
usertext: HK banks don't charge ATM fees. Just make sure the ATM machine is from a bank. BTW, I don't know about your credit card, but my credit card company considers cash withdrawal as "cash advance", meaning they charge interest as soon as I withdraw the cash. Their interest rate is pretty stratospheric. So I never use a credit card to withdraw cash, but instead use my bank ATM card.

subject: 2. Re: ATMs without additional fee
usertext: RE: "a credit card that doesn't charge extra for withdrawing money." Are you sure? It seems to defy common sense. Because with that, you can get free money (take money out of the credit card and invest in a high-interest money market fund or something).

subject: 4. Re: ATMs without additional fee
usertext: Cash advance via a credit card withdrawal is typically considered a laon. You almost always incur a very high interest rate. The only trick that might avoid the charge is if you prepay some money into the credit card in advance. However, it's much simpler to use a *dedicated* ATM debit card. Many years ago, I had a combo credit/debit card that allowed me to pull money using the debit function at home. Once overseas, the debit options disappeared on the foreign ATM screen so I was left with credit card advance (loan) as the only expensive option. With a debit card, if it has the Plus, Cirrus or Union Pay logos, then you can withdraw at bank machines with no additional charges locally. Note that even if your home bank doesn't charge a transaction fee, you will still be pay a small premium for the currency exchange which is no big deal.

subject: 5. Re: ATMs without additional fee
usertext: Yes, withdrawing money from a credit card equals a loan. The fee includes: interest, additional fee - different banks, and international withdrawing fee...

subject: 6. Re: ATMs without additional fee
usertext: For credit card cash withdrawals at ATMs you would need a PIN code otherwise only over-the-counter cash advances are possible. My credit card from Mega Bank Taiwan doesn't have a PIN code and they also don't offer any PIN code upon request. This could be problematic in Europe as they don't have over-the-counter cash advances in Europe. The best in order to get cash are debit cards. Each debit card has a PIN code so they work at ATMs. Also ATMs should usually work 24 hours whereas over-the-counter cash advances are probably not available during late night

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 7. Re: ATMs without additional fee
usertext: I think that all credit cards charge interest on cash withdrawals from the moment the cash is withdrawn. So even if you aren't charged a withdrawal fee, you will be paying interest of something like 25% APR until you pay it back - and if you already have an outstanding balance on your card, the withdrawal won't be paid back until the rest of the balance is cleared! It's much better to look for a debit card with a zero or low fee for foreign currency transactions.

subject: HK to Macau via Chinalink
usertext: How long is the travel time from HK to Macau (Venetian) via bus? Will the bus stop for immigration? So how long will be the total time need to allocate to get there? I have an 11am sched in TeamLab, so checking what time need to take the bus. Thanks!

subject: 1. Re: HK to Macau via Chinalink
usertext: See this One Bus direct service to Macau. https://www.onebus.hk/download/images/OB%20SCHEDULE_01SEP2023_LON.jpg This is one of the companies that offers the cross boundary bus rides offered by Chinalink. The journey takes 3 hours 5 minutes due to need to cross immigration and customs. With a large group riding the bus, it can take a bit of time. However, One Bus, which I believe has the earliest departure at 8am would put in a bit late for the TeamLab time slot of 11am at Venetian. As such, I'd recommend just making way to the HKZ Bridge near HKIA airport and using the 24 hour Golden Shuttle Bus service over the bridge to Macau. The ride is 45 minutes, allow 15 minutes to clear immigration, purchase bus ticket and board on the Hong Kong side. Departures are every 3-5 minutes in the morning so you won't have to wait long to be on your way. On the Macau side, allow 15 minutes to clear immigration and exit the building. As of my trip last week, I was seeing Venetian shuttle buses at the HZMB Macau Port. You should be able to use them for direct free transfer to the Venetian. Departures are probably every 15 minutes or so and the ride is around 15-20 minutes to Venetian. Otherwise, take a taxi from the Macau Port, it will similarly take around 15-20 minutes to the Venetian. Regardless, if you leave by 7am from your hotel in Hong Kong, you will make it to the Venetian with plenty of time to spare. If earlier than you like, find the Lord Stow's at Venetian for a morning tart.

subject: 3. Re: HK to Macau via Chinalink
usertext: Thank you so much for the input! I learned that TeamLab is not a timed entry similar to Japan. I don't see any scheds in their website except for the opening and closing time. So I guess it wont hurt much if I will be late. But let me assess the DIY shuttle too =)

subject: NA11 bus Hong Kong
usertext: Hello everyone! I'm supposed to catch a flight from Hong Kong airport on Friday at 7:35am. I'd like to avoid taking a taxi so as not to spend too much money, and I've seen that the only alternative is the NA11 bus that leaves North Point at 4:50. On the company's website, Citybus, it seems that the journey time is 70-80 minutes, as it makes many stops; elsewhere I found a 35-minute journey time. Does anyone know how long it actually takes? I don't think it would stop at every single stop, especially at that time... what do you think? If the duration was really 70-80 minutes, I'd be really tight on time and wouldn't risk it. Thanks!

subject: 1. Re: NA11 bus Hong Kong
usertext: It will take 80 minutes from where the bus start to reach the airport. The company who operates the bus knows best: Link: https://mobile.citybus.com.hk/nwp3/?f=1&ds=NA11&dsmode=1&l=1 35 minute journey time, sure, if you board the bus at Sheung Wan or Central. After that, the bus will express to the airport virtually. In the end, everybody arrives the airport at about 6:10 am.

subject: 2. Re: NA11 bus Hong Kong
usertext: Eh? Even if it takes 80 minutes you would be at the airport at 6:10am, which is plenty of time. The check-in counter for HK Express (the only airline with flights at 07:35 on Friday) closes 60 minutes before departure. At that time of the morning I guess it might take ~60 minutes, but there's no way the 35 minute figure is plausible all the way from North Point. Do online check-in and you can either go straight to the gate if you have no checked bags or to the bag-drop counter if you have bags to drop off. But if that stresses you too much then there is in N11 bus if that fits with wherever it is that you are actually coming from. That runs every hour through the night. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: NA11 bus Hong Kong
usertext: Even a taxi won't do that trip in 35 mins. I'd guess 45-50 mins, though light early morning traffic does help. 70-80 mins for the bus sounds very plausible to me.

subject: 4. Re: NA11 bus Hong Kong
usertext: My personal experience is that with no traffic, it takes roughly 30 minutes from west Kowloon near Kowloon station and the airport itself. As a whole, 70 minutes sound about right give or take. Don't expect anything much quicker.

subject: 1. Re: Advice for Solo trip
usertext: There are several areas in general that are considered to be "convenient", depending on your visit itinerary. These areas include Tsim sha tsui, Yau Ma Tei, Mongkok (on the Kowloon side), and Causeway Bay, Wan Chai, Sheung Wan, on the HK Island side. HK is an imminently walkable city, and yet with one of the best public transportation systems in the world, a great combination. Immigration is usually a breeze. Don't know anything about Zoloft.

subject: 2. Re: Advice for Solo trip
usertext: Zoloft (Setraline) is a prescription-only drug in Hong Kong. Visitors may personally bring the small quantity necessary for their trip but should bring a copy of the prescription from a medical doctor under which it was supplied. See here, inter alia: https://www.news.gov.hk/eng/2023/01/20230106/20230106_181939_828.html Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: Hello. I am visiting Hong Kong for 4 days in December for a conference. I am an Indian and looking for a good hotel to stay. My budget is between 5-6k per day. Moreover I am looking for Vegetarian Food. I prefer a hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui Area. Also, I needed suggestions on what mode of transactions is generally preferred should I take Cash or Go with Forex Cards. If forex cards, any particular bank that provides low exhcange rates?

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: {My budget is between 5-6k per day.} For HK$5-6K per day, you can pretty much stay anywhere in the city. This will cover standard rooms in our 5 star hotels including those in TST. {Moreover I am looking for Vegetarian Food. } Use OpenRice website and insert vegetarian and the district you want to find them. https://www.openrice.com/zh/hongkong HappyCow is another good source for Vegan and Veggie dining in the city (see link) https://www.happycow.net/asia/china/hong_kong/ {Also, I needed suggestions on what mode of transactions is generally preferred should I take Cash or Go with Forex Cards.} You can use cash or credit card in most places throughout the city. It is generally recommended to obtain an On Loan Octopus (smart card) at the airport when you arrive (see link) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14482045-Octopus_Card_2023-Hong_Kong.html or you can download the Octopus for Tourist app on your iPhone or Huawei mobile phone https://www.octopus.com.hk/dl/tourist-app/index.html You can use Octopus Card for simple and quick transactions for public transportation, convenient stores, most casual eateries and some retail stores.

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: Thank you for the suggestions. Sorry, that budget is in INR which roughly equals to 500-600HKD per day. I am looking for Tsim Sha Tsui as my conference location is in that area. I will check the remaining links you provided. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: Best to have a look at hotel booking websites like booking.com and agoda to see what is available in TST area in that price range during the dates of your visit. That is the quickest way to see what is available that means your personal requirements.

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: It doesn't really matter which bank's ATMs you use in HK. They don't add on their own fees and the rate is set by Visa or MC so it'll be the same across all the banks' ATMs.

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: Just to manage your expectations, HK$5-600/day doesn't get you a "good hotel" by most people's understanding of that term. It gets you some sort of hostel room, but is probably sufficient to get your own small shower/toilet.

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: Booking now for December, I think most "better" hotels will charge at least $1,500. Some options for you to consider that might fit your budget: Prudential Ibis Dorsett Ibis and Dorsett have multiple locations so their prices differ. Also, with your limited budget, you can't be too picky about having to end up at Tsim Sha Tsui. In fact, your budget most likely gives you hostels at the likes of Chungking Mansion only.

subject: 7. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: And be aware also that you can't just get on a plane and come to HK - Indian nationals need to have completed Pre-Arrival Registration in advance. https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/visas/pre-arrival_registration_for_indian_nationals.html

subject: 8. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: Thank you, @BradJill @HKGaYau,@SammyFD, and @Alamigos, for your reply. I have completed the pre-arrival registration form, which is accepted. Since my budget is limited, I can't extend it. I am looking at TST as that's where my conference will be. I wanted to know a good hotel. It's fine, if not luxurious, but at least I can live without issues for a few days. What's your suggestion for Ramada Hong Kong Grand and Best Western Plus Hotel Kowloon?

subject: 9. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: The Ramada is nothing to complain about at US$65 total/night on the booking sites.

subject: 10. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: Chungking Mansions, mentioned above, has something like 50 or 60 guesthouses within its towers, and if you approach the entrance with luggage, you'll be invited to stay at some of them. Prices are among the lowest in Hong Kong (don't expect much), the location couldn't be better (directly above TST station), and has been called HK's Little India (many curry houses). It's also the best place in town to change money. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 11. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: Again, Prudential Hotel at Jordan might fit your budget. If that's the case, it's going to be much better than staying at any hostel. Jordan is right next to TST so you probably won't have more than 15 minutes to walk to your conference. Ramada and Best Western are much more beat up overall. Prudential definitely gets better reviews.

subject: 12. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: @Alamigo and others, I am attending a conference visit. However, while filling out the pre-arrival registration form, I selected the purpose of the visit as a leisure visit as I was unaware that the conference was considered business. What should I do while being questioned at Immigration?

subject: 13. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: Presumably, you are not being paid to attend the conference and you are not going to earn any money in Hong Kong? (for example, you're not a paid speaker at the conference?) Assuming that is true, if the immigration officer asks what you're going to be doing in HK, say you are planning to see the city, visit tourist sites, see the Palace Museum, sample local food....and while you are here you also found this interesting conference to attend. (It is perfectly legitimate to mix a conference with tourist activities, and the question of which is your primary reason for coming to HK is up to you.)

subject: 14. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: I will be presenting my research work and yes I haven't been paid for the same. I have paid for registration and all other expenses from my pocket. Also, Should I show them conference invitation?

subject: 15. Re: Hong Kong Visit
usertext: Only when asked.

subject: Hong Kong transit Visa required for US passports?
usertext: I'm looking take a flight to Bangkok Thailand from (LAX) Los Angeles Airport. There's a 4 hour layover in (HKG) Hong Kong aiport. I'm wondering would I need to apply for a transit visa for the Hong Kong layover?

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong transit Visa required for US passports?
usertext: Start here (see link) for information related to tourist and transit visa matters as stipulated by the HK immigration department https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14479683-Hong_Kong_Visa_Requirements_2023-Hong_Kong.html#118350396

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong transit Visa required for US passports?
usertext: As a US passport holder, you don't need to apply for a visa on a short term vist. 4 hours aren't a lot though if you still need to net off inbound and outbound processing time. It might not be worthwhile to stray far from the airport. The airport's unsecured area (landside) has more affordable restaurants. Nearby at Tung Chung, there is an outlet mall and restaurants.

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong transit Visa required for US passports?
usertext: I wouldn't go to Tung Chung if the transit time is only 4 hours as the time is probably not enough to do anything there. Only taking the bus from HKIA to Tung Chung and going back to HKIA immediately isn't worth it. Leaving the transit area of the Hong Kong International Airport is possible with a layover of 4 hours though but I don't recommend to leave the airport completely. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong transit Visa required for US passports?
usertext: US passport holders do not need a visa for Hong Kong for stays up to 90 days, so no transit visa required for your Hong Kong layover.

subject: Ride Sharing in Hong Kong and Taxis
usertext: 1) We are arriving on Tuesday, December 5 going from Hong Kong Airport to our hotel in Sha Tin, Hong Kong. Is UBER/GRAB or other ride sharing available in Hong Kong? 2) If ride sharing is not available do taxis in Hong Kong take credit cards. I have been told that taxis only accept Hong Kong currency ie cash? Thanks Howard

subject: 1. Re: Ride Sharing in Hong Kong and Taxis
usertext: 1) Yes. Uber operates in Hong Kong. Here is their website which can be found through basic google search -> https://www.uber.com/hk/en/ride/ubertaxi/ No, GRAB doesn't operate here. 2) You can arrange taxi rides through the Uber HK app and pay by way of credit card linked to the app but if you are going to hail a taxi on the street or pick one up from the airport, you will need be ready to pay with (HK$) cash.

subject: 2. Re: Ride Sharing in Hong Kong and Taxis
usertext: Thanks BradJill for the advice. Howard

subject: 3. Re: Ride Sharing in Hong Kong and Taxis
usertext: HI may i know if taking Uber is cheaper than taxis in HK?

subject: 4. Re: Ride Sharing in Hong Kong and Taxis
usertext: I recall a few times seeing Uber quotes that were similar to taxi but not cheaper. Usually I'd expect to pay 10-15% higher for Uber cars than taxi here in Hong Kong.

subject: 5. Re: Ride Sharing in Hong Kong and Taxis
usertext: Uber prices fluctuate. During normal traffic conditions, I would say their rates are similar to perhaps 10% or so premium for Uber. I have seen the same route price double if Uber decides at that moment that it needs to charge more. Interestingly, I have then waited for an extra 5 minutes and got the rate without the premium.

subject: Same octopus card for all
usertext: hi If we buy one octopus on loan card, can we use same card for 3 adults? or do we need to buy 3 separate cards?

subject: 1. Re: Same octopus card for all
usertext: You need one card per person.

subject: 2. Re: Same octopus card for all
usertext: When using the MTR, fares are calculated based on the specific route. You need to tap in a the starting point and tap out at the destination station. That's why each person needs his/her own card.

subject: 3. Re: Same octopus card for all
usertext: One person one card. For metro, the card records the stations you in and out to calculate the ticket price. In other cities of China, the public traffic card records the time you take the bus. Because if you change to another bus in one hour, the second one is free.

subject: Uber in Hongkong with Credit Card based payment
usertext: I am regular user of Uber taxi in India with Credit Card mode of payment. My saved credit card has all International transaction permissions. My specific question: 1. When I change existing Indian SIM card with Local Hongkong SIM after reaching Hongkong whether same current details be used for booking Uber taxi in Hongkong 2. Whether uber app can charge to my Indian credit already saved without any issues OR I will be forced to pay in cash

subject: 1. Re: Uber in Hongkong with Credit Card based payment
usertext: This are questions that you better ask Uber. In Hong Kong you may also use taxis. So much simpler, as they're all over the place (no waiting and searching for your ride), and generally cheaper than Uber to boot. Taxis are cash only, by the way.

subject: 2. Re: Uber in Hongkong with Credit Card based payment
usertext: Not quite "all over the place". After waiting an hour once for a taxi at Chai Wan station, in a very short queue, I'm quite ready to try Uber myself. And Sai Kung, lordy, Uber Taxi might be a lifeline after a long hike there. So I'm quite curious to know the answer to #1 especially.

subject: 3. Re: Uber in Hongkong with Credit Card based payment
usertext: Normally, the same apps should still be usable. Therefore, you should have no issues calling an Uber and settling the payment via credit card through the app. In fact, the first time I downloaded Uber and used it was at Amsterdam. I have since used other SIM's in my phone and called Uber in HK and a few other countries. Note that there is an Uber Taxi option here in HK so you could still end up sitting in a taxi. As to taxi availability, it depends on the time of day, where you are waiting and the specific route. Should you use a regular taxi on the street, ensure they charge you based on the metered rate (plus tunnels, bridges, luggage, etc where applicable).

subject: 4. Re: Uber in Hongkong with Credit Card based payment
usertext: Past experience: friends trying to get an Uber in Sai Kung while taxis were in short supply, couldn't get one - unless they were willing to pay the highly inflated "surge" price of Uber - and even then it's not guaranteed that there will be a driver available for the ride.

subject: 5. Re: Uber in Hongkong with Credit Card based payment
usertext: @SammyFD....thanks for response... u have answered to my query

subject: 6. Re: Uber in Hongkong with Credit Card based payment
usertext: @wvmarle {Past experience: friends trying to get an Uber in Sai Kung while taxis were in short supply, couldn't get one - unless they were willing to pay the highly inflated "surge" price of Uber - and even then it's not guaranteed that there will be a driver available for the ride.} Taxi or bus out of Sai Kung village has never been a problem for me. However, out in the country parks which have controlled vehicle entrance beyond Pak Tam Chung things can get tricky, especially on late weekend afternoons when day visitors and hikers come crawling out of the country parks to the main roads seeking a ride back into Sai Kung village. Even calling in a taxi can take an extraordinary amount of time.

subject: 7. Re: Uber in Hongkong with Credit Card based payment
usertext: True, that's the tricky bit. Though with the minibus service from East Dam the situation should have improved. And with the closed roads, definitely no Uber there!

subject: 8. Re: Uber in Hongkong with Credit Card based payment

subject: 9. Re: Uber in Hongkong with Credit Card based payment
usertext: >>> Assuming one wants to show up. That's the problem... A few years ago it was normal to offer $100 extra to taxis to come and pick you up there (basically pay a bit for the long ride there as well).

subject: Transit at Hong Kong
usertext: I have 8 hours transit at Hong Kong airport midnight until 8 in the morning. Is there a day room for rent? The Cathay Business lounge will be close during these times.

subject: 2. Re: Transit at Hong Kong
usertext: It's not day from midnight to 8am! You could get a room at the Regal Airport Hotel which is walking distance from the terminal (and from your name you probably don't need a visa to enter HK for a few hours). Otherwise just the Plaza Premium Lounge which has resting areas overnight.

subject: 3. Re: Transit at Hong Kong
usertext: I'll have the same problem in March when I'm flying Sanya - Hong Kong - Taipei. I'm arriving in HKG at midnight and leaving HKG at 9 A.M. I've booked an additional night in Sanya though so I can try to sleep before my late night flight. Also I'm planning to sleep on my flight from SYX to HKG. There are many late night buses from HKIA to the city which are quite affordable. Walking around in Downtown Hong Kong during the night is quite safe in my opinion. If I would feel too tired for going to the city I could also sleep on some chairs in HKIA though.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Lantau Sightseeing Bus
usertext: Big Bus Tours and Ngong Ping 360 have partnered to introduce an open-top Lantau sightseeing bus tour operating seven times daily from today, 29th November. There are two routes (AM & PM) which take about 60 minutes to cover and passengers can "hop off and on" at stops throughout the day. A promotional ticket price of HK$120 applies until 31st December with no concession for child or senior after which the regular price of HK$150 applies. Anybody expecting to see the best of Lantau is likely to be disappointed however as this tour is confined to Tung Chung, the airport maintenance area, 11 Skies (the large new leisure, retail and dining complex opposite AsiaWorld-Expo which is currently only partially open), hotels in the vicinity of the airport and Tung Chung, and the Disneyland coach park; https://www.np360.com.hk/en/LantauSightseeingBus

subject: 1. Re: Lantau Sightseeing Bus
usertext: "Best of Lantau" might still be the regular public bus over the steep hump to Tai O, and/or up the second big hill to Ngong Ping. I suppose the sightseeing buses are too top-heavy for that wiggly steep road. It's scary enough on a low-rider bus, if you look down. :)

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Lantau Sightseeing Bus
usertext: I think one of the best bus rides in HK is the upper deck of route 3M on Lantau between Tung Chung and Mui Wo since double-deckers were finally allowed to operate on that route a few years ago after several years of trials following the rebuilding of Tung Chung Road across the island. There are some pretty spectacular views over the south Lantau coastline as the bus crawls up and over the mountains around Pak Tam Au and escape lanes in case vehicles lose control on the very steep descent. Double deckers also now operate on route 4 along the south coast between Mui Wo and Tong Fuk although thats not a frequent service.

subject: 3. Re: Lantau Sightseeing Bus
usertext: Thank you for an interesting update, ST! I looked at your linked webpage immediately, fancying sitting on an open-top double-decker bus riding from Tung Chung up to the Big Buddha, or at least to Mui Wo. That would be interesting. But... no... I don't usually do this, and especially when wearing a badge being a DE of Hong Kong. Let me take off the badge and take off my uniform for a few minutes here....  But I really need to blast the marketing people who dreamed up this operation. If this is not a deceiving marketing ploy, I don't know what is. HKD $150 for "sightseeing, hop-on/hop-off". What a lie. This is a glorified hotel shuttle bus (with the top-deck frontal shelf removed). Instead of offering free (or 'built-in") hotel shuttle service, like many of the hotel/casino shuttle buses in Macau do, they charge you $150 pp for hotel shuttling. Sheraton, SkyCity Marriott, Regala, Disneyland and NP360. Where is the "sight-seeing" part? It is all riding on expressways and local streets. They touted: "The Aircraft Maintenance Area The aircraft maintenance area of Hong Kong International Airport is one of the must-visit places for photography enthusiasts. You can enjoy the endless sea view and enjoy the sunset without the obstruction of high-rise buildings. " Right... the fine print is "(No boarding or alighting)". Enjoy the sunset on a moving bus. And only the last run P3. Instead of paying local bus prices (under HKD $10) to go around, $150 please. Or in the case of Disneyland to NP360, $150 x 4 = $600 for a family of 4, instead of taking a taxi for ~$140. Transportation service. I just see this in the same light as the Kai-Tak Macau Seaplane project. Only time will tell. Maybe they have enough churning of unsuspecting clueless visitors riding on the hop-on/hop-off fame to bite.

subject: 4. Re: Lantau Sightseeing Bus
usertext: I heartily agree with HF and the more moderately stated opinions above! What a total, idiotic, rip-off. It would be cheaper even to catch taxis (except maybe to Disney, but there's an MTR for that). For REAL Lantau sightseeing at reasonable prices the regular buses make much more sense - or even (if you can get one of the "slow" ferries) the ferry ride between Tung Chung and Tai O.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

usertext: For HK$3.7 the S1 bus covers most of the route except the stretch between Tung Chung and Disneyland, much of which is dominated by the vast reclamation and construction work currently going on for the housing projects associated with the expansion of Tung Chung.

subject: 6. Re: Lantau Sightseeing Bus
usertext: As noted above, this is an absurd rip-off.

subject: Hongkong in Christmas

subject: 1. Re: Hongkong in Christmas
usertext: Everything will be open as normal. Malls have Xmas decorations. Some buildings have Xmas lights. Winter is the best season in HK to get out in the countryside - there's excellent hiking. Also two major theme parks, cable car rides, various cultural attractions, some world class museums and galleries... If you're an Indian passport holder then you need to complete online Pre-Arrival Registration in advance. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Hongkong in Christmas

subject: 3. Re: Hongkong in Christmas

subject: 4. Re: Hongkong in Christmas

You just need to do more research via guidebooks or websites. Also, check out the older posts in this forum for itineraries. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Layover Hotel thoughts?
usertext: Land 4pm leave 9am next day Thinking airport express to Kowloon or Hong Kong, get a room and head out. Ideally stay within walking distance of one of the stations; catch 1st train back to the airport in the morning. Since the hotel will just be for shower/couple hours sleep if lucky, looking under $150USD. OR should I just book hotel at/near airport, check in, buy RT airport express and take last train back to hotel. End of January if that matters

subject: 1. Re: Layover Hotel thoughts?
usertext: Hotels within walking distance of the AE stations are upmarket ones, not likely your budget works for those. At Kowloon AE station there's also not much to do, not a great place to stay for just one night. You will need additional transport to get to more interesting areas. Lots of hotels in the TST/Jordan/Yaumatei/Mongkok area that are just as easily reachable by airport bus, so don't limit yourself to the AE. Do a search on your favourite hotel booking site. Anything in those areas that's close to Nathan Road will be quick and easy to get to from the airport, and be in a pretty nice area with lots of shops and restaurants nearby. If you have a hotel or a few you like do post a response and the forum regulars will let you know which ones are convenient and how to get there.

subject: 2. Re: Layover Hotel thoughts?
usertext: If you aren't a night owl, staying at/around the airport might be a better idea given how short your layover is along with your morning flight departure time. There are Sheratons, Marriott , Novotel and Regal at or near the airport.

subject: 3. Re: Layover Hotel thoughts?
usertext: I can be a bit of a night owl but also would be fine with either getting last train back towards airport and trying to get a couple of hours sleep.. OR up early and getting 1st train @wvmarle I thought the airport express was the way to go. What's the best way to go from Nathan road back to the airport for a 6-630am arrival (at the airport). I figured taxi would be pricey and you mentioned airport bus but I didn't see much about them, will do a search later

subject: 4. Re: Layover Hotel thoughts?
usertext: {What's the best way to go from Nathan road back to the airport for a 6-630am arrival (at the airport).} That depends on how you define 'best'. Taxi is always an option and is most convenient. Airport buses are cheapest. Route A21 has quite a few stops along Nathan Road and starts running at 5.15am (see route details) https://www.travelchinaguide.com/cityguides/a21-bus-hongkong.htm Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: Layover Hotel thoughts?
usertext: Taxi to airport will cost about $250-280, That's less than AE tickets for three people. At that early hour it should take about half an hour, and taxis will be easy to find. Just ask the hotel concierge.

subject: 6. Re: Layover Hotel thoughts?
usertext: If you are staying at Kowloon, unless you are staying right at one of the two hotels atop the Kowloon station complex, there is little reason to use the Airport Express. You would have to take a taxi to get there anyway. So the two methods are down to the airport bus or taxi. The adult bus fare is around HKD35 per person.

subject: 7. Re: Layover Hotel thoughts?
usertext: Sounds like the answer is Taxi but not sure why I care the cost for 3 people hmmm :)

subject: 8. Re: Layover Hotel thoughts?
usertext: Maybe I was just adding that for reference - for other people reading this forum, or for you if you're with more than one person (the "I" doesn't necessarily mean you're travelling alone).

subject: 9. Re: Layover Hotel thoughts?
usertext: If you're awake enough to appreciate it, taxi or bus will have better views than the train. There's that one magnificent and quite long bridge, where the train goes through a viewless lower level, road vehicles on top. In case that tips the decision... :)

subject: 4. Re: Changing HKD
usertext: Pop out of TST station and look for the name on the building. If you choose the right exit, it's just across the street. The exchange shops are on the main floor, just inside the entrance, also take the escalator up one level for more. There's something like a dozen exchange shops in total, all competing against each other, so spreads are tight, rates excellent. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: MTR or Uber
usertext: Hi I am a first-time tourist to HK planning on 8 days to visit all the usual tourist spots. We are staying at Kowloon Harbourfront Hotel. Do you recommend MTR or Uber to get there from the airport? If MTR, then where do we jump off on the green line - Kowloon or Hong Kong? (I am checking https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/system_map.html). Is it generally better to use MTR for good pricing? What's cheaper to use in general? We are planning on visiting all over HK, Ocean Park, Peak, Lantau, etc. and it seems to me I can use the MTR and then take Ubers directly after. Also, if I want to take a boat trip to Macau, can this be planned from my hotel? I don't want to miss the boat, and I believe Uber waits can be quite random. thanks!

subject: 1. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: You obviously come from a country with no functioning public transport. If the MTR goes from where you are to where you want to be then that will always be by far the fastest and cheapest way. Having said that, you have, for whatever reason, picked a hotel which is several minutes walk from the nearest MTR station and not connected by airport bus service. Your choices from the airport are the Airport Express to Kowloon Station then a taxi, or a taxi direct, or (if you prefer to pay a premium and have extra hassle at the airport for no good reason) then Uber. Since there appears to be at least 2 of you then a taxi is probably the best option. The Macau Ferry terminal is attached to Sheung Wan MTR station. The MTR app gives very reliable timings for rides. Remember that Macau is a different "country" and you need to allow time to pass through HK outbound immigration.

subject: 2. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: >> Do you recommend MTR or Uber to get there from the airport? Neither. Taxi is my recommendation as well. Cost about $250 (HKD cash only; you can get some from one of the ATMs at the airport). Note that Uber drivers do not serve areas like Lantau Island (past Tung Chung/airport). Taxis do serve those areas. Taxis are generally easy to find right outside MTR stations, no need to try and book a car and hope they show up and hope you can talk to them on the phone (you need a local phone number for that part) well enough so they have the same idea about where exactly to pick you up as you. Of course you can use Uber if you prefer. I never bothered to even try. The knowledge that your taxi ride is fully legal and guaranteed insurance covered is also a plus over Uber.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: You can also book metered taxis via Uber (which has teamed up with HKTaxi) and pay by credit card, Apple Pay, Google Pay or Paypal; https://www.uber.com/en-HK/blog/uber-metered-taxi-launch/

subject: 4. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: Thank you for the responses. Booking the HK taxis via Uber and paying by card sounds the way to go for us, as it's four of us and I don't like the idea of cash. The MTR might be inefficient as we'd have to buy day passes for four people.

subject: 5. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: Good morning, the fastest way from the airport to Honk kong Station considering the traffic, road works etc. is by car (cab, UBER) or by subway? Thank you

subject: 6. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: Airport Express. (Part of the MTR system, as recommended in reply #1.) Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: #4 you can also buy single ride tickets for your MTR needs, or get everyone an Octopus card, also very easy. I don't know what you have against cash; I still think I don't use it as much as I should - no need for the banks to know your every move.

subject: 8. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: If anyone would like to know, here is my experience: Travelling with four people on MTR is not worth it due to the price. Uber was fine most places, but sometimes there is a confusion with the pickup point. Sometimes the app just not find a driver in time, so don't leave your travel plans for the last minute. Give yourself an extra 30 minutes. And as for the metered taxis, they are all cash and the experience is varied. Some do not want to speak English, and some do not speak English at all. Some drivers are rude and in a big hurry, so expect to be shooed off if they don't understand your destination or they just don't like your face. An aside note: people who have an expectation of paying with credit card for food and merchandise may be bitterly disappointed. Many stores do not take Mastercard, even one MacDonalds, so carry extra cash or use Octopus or Alipay. Seems to me a defiance against Western forms of payments. Also there is a 7% commission to exchange cash, so beware. And as for the person who said "You obviously come from a country with no functioning public transport" - my country's public transport functions just fine, thank you very much. I just wanted to know how yours functions. There was no need to be rude. Or maybe there is a need... maybe just a culture thing, if I have to go with the generally bad experience I had with metered taxis.

subject: 9. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: I'm sorry, but if you're claiming that 4 people on an MTR ride is more expensive than a taxi/uber ride then you're doing something wrong in almost every case. (The exception would be the Airport Express, but that's a special case, not really the core MTR). And why wait 30 minutes for a car? The MTR can get you between almost all the tourist areas in less time than that. Same for the 7% commission on currency exchange - you clearly were doing something wrong unless you were trying to exchange a rather rare and/or very volatile currency (for example the ZAR). Or maybe you made the rookie mistake of exchanging cash at the airport - that gets you terrible rate pretty much anywhere in the world. For USD I would expect the cash spread to be about 2%. For example here are the current rates from a local exchange: https://www.nkcl.com.hk/change.php

subject: 10. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: No it was US$ and once a small amount at the airport but thereafter at the nearest exchange North of the Tsim Shui terminal it was also 7%. Thereafter I just withdrew cash from an ATM with my credit card.

subject: 11. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: Withdrawing cash using your credit will cost you much more than 7%. Credit card companies consider cash withdrawal as "cash advance", which will subject you to immediate, eye watering, interest charges, maybe up to 20% depending on your card. I hope you mean you used your debit card, not credit card, to withdraw cash.

subject: 12. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: For USD cash exchange, even small quantities and small notes, I'm used to commissions of about 0.25% in Chungking Mansions (a bit of shopping around is sometimes needed). Locations like airport are far worse indeed.

subject: 13. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: Just for the benefit of future readers, if any currency exchange tries to give you a spread of 7% on USD to/from HKD then just move on - they're taking the mickey. The spread shouldn't be more than about 2% and such spreads are readily findable.

subject: 14. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: Just to add a real data point to this, as I walked past a local foreign exchange shop in Sai Ying Pun today (one of several) I noted that the buy and sell prices for USD cash were 7.78 and 7.83. So the spread was 0.64%.

subject: 15. Re: MTR or Uber
usertext: Major currencies like USD, JPY , and GBP should see a minimal spread. RMB also sees a small spread due to the HK-PRC financial flow. I can't recall what EUR rates are like. For other less popular currencies, expect a bigger spread. That's why it's best to pull money from an ATM where you should always get a fair exchange rate.

subject: 1. Re: Tsuen wan or Wanchai
usertext: Location wise I'd definitely go for the Ramada, with the Dorsett a good second and Silka just not. Silka Tsuen Wan is not easy to get to (other than by taxi) and far from anything of interest to a typical tourist. The other two are much more centrally located in much more interesting areas - Ramada right at the Tsun Ying Street market (where also trams squeeze through); the Dorsett a little out of the way near the racecourse. Lots of traffic there. Inside of the hotel: read the reviews on e.g. this site. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Daytrip Ngong ping, Tian Tan, Tai O from HK station
usertext: Good morning, could you please tell me if the itinerary I thought is feasible in one day (late February on Sunday, Monday or Tuesday): - departure from Hong kong station to Tung chung - Ngong ping cable car to Tian Tan Buddha - Po Lin monastery then by bus to Tai O - tour to Tai O with possible boat excursion and return by sea or cab to Tung chung All considering the crowds of tourists, queues and the time needed to enjoy the beauty of the places. Is it possible and recommended to book the cable car in advance? Thanks to all

subject: 1. Re: Daytrip Ngong ping, Tian Tan, Tai O from HK station
usertext: Very possible. Go Monday or Tuesday, there will be far fewer visitors those days than on a Sunday. You can consider booking the cable car in advance, it allows you to skip the ticketing line.

subject: 2. Re: Daytrip Ngong ping, Tian Tan, Tai O from HK station
usertext: I personally enjoy the ferry ride between Tai O and Tung Chung (particularly on the older, slower ferries that travel close to the shore) but if you want to do this route, do check the timetable - now that there is a road connection between the two places there are only 4 or so sailings a day on weekdays. The bus journey is also quite scenic, so don't worry if the ferry doesn't work for you.

subject: 3. Re: Daytrip Ngong ping, Tian Tan, Tai O from HK station
usertext: Yes possible to do in one day. You can google the 360 Ngong ping pass where u can book cable car tickets, bus tickets and a short boat ride in tai o. But you will still need to queue at the cable car to collect the physical tickets

subject: Mid trip report
usertext: We have been in Hongkong for the past 5 days and have another 4 days to go. Just a tip to others - there is no need to buy any express pass in Disneyland as the rides are mostly 5 mins wait only (we bought & could not refund) - we went on a weekday. We did not enjoy Tai O very much as there is pretty much nothing to do except for a boat ride and most shops are closed. We are worried that Cheung Chau Island would be the same as Tai O. Would you please advise if Cheung Chau Island would be very similar to Tai O or if Sai Kung would be more interesting instead? We will be going this Monday. For food, we quite enjoyed Hay Wong in Mongkok and  in Tai Kok Tsui but we are really disappointed by One Dim Sum - none of the items we ordered are nice except for the congee. Crossing Boat restaurant food at Tai O is great but expensive. We also went to Xinjinyuan dapaidang in Tai Kok Tsui Cooked Food Center - food is alright but price point is very affordable for such big portions. Can you recommend really nice restaurants in Tai Kok Tsui & Mongkok area especially for roast geese or speciality hk food? We will be going to HK Science Museum today and maybe Museum of History today. Can anyone recommend a very nice restaurant in the area? Thanks! Also, what specialty food products should we be buying back from HK? Which area would be good for shopping? Things seem to be more expensive in Hongkong compared to Singapore and I really do not know what we should be buying unlike other trips where we would often buy in bulk back local products. HK seems to be awfully similar to SG maybe that's the reason why. Oh ya I couldn't find any stationery or book shop in Mongkok or Tai Kok Tsui which is very strange. Usually where are these shops located? They don't seem to appear in malls.

subject: 9. Re: Mid trip report
usertext: Small, basic cha-chaan-teng tend to be cash only, as are those cheap noodle shops and the like. Well other than cash many will accept Octopus which is effectively equivalent, as Octopus is topped up by cash. Anything above that (including indeed most restaurants in malls) will take credit cards.

subject: 10. Re: Mid trip report
usertext: Very generally, the "mom-and-pop" small eateries will not take credit cards. For the reasons that they need to install extra machinery to process credit cards, have to deal with fraud/no-payment headache, and the commission rates charged by the credit card companies. All these cut into their profit margins for their small business. Those would be like any local eateries you can walk by and hop-in from the streets (especially in non-tourist areas). The chained, big corporate-run restaurants/fast-food would likely take credit cards. Especially those set up in malls. It is usually easy to tell: if they take credit cards, usually they stick those credit card company logos (Visa, Mastercard, American Express, as well as some Japanese/European brands) in front of the reception counter, cashier counter, or on the window pane or by the entrance door where you can see them before you walk in. If not sure, just ask. Language barrier? Just fish out your credit card, point to it and wave and prompt "Yes? No". Not that hard.

subject: 11. Re: Mid trip report
usertext: You have to top Octopus cards with HKD cash. So that does not solve your cash problem.

subject: 12. Re: Mid trip report
usertext: {Can you recommend really nice restaurants in Tai Kok Tsui & Mongkok area especially for roast geese or speciality hk food?} Ming Court at Cordis Hotel in Mongkok

subject: 13. Re: Mid trip report
usertext: Tai O is a weekend place. On weekdays, there just isn't enough demand for some of the stores to open. Personally, I don't particularly rate Tai O as a must unless the visitor doesn't have much experience going to a fishing village in other places. Lamma is a good spot to go regardless of the day. In fact, weekdays are probably better due to lesser crowds. I like Lamma more than Cheung Chau myself as well. If you go to Lamma, take the ferry to one spot, hike the island and leave from the other side. Our spending habits vary. In HK though, most locals understand that you will need cash if you want to go to cha chann teng and many small eateries. Many of them (but not all) take Octopus nowadays. As a visitor, you will probably need cash to reload the Octopus. I do use a credit card to reload myself through a payment app. For stationery (but probably lean towards art supply), you can go to Chung Nam at 503 Nathan Road (Yau Ma Tei). Otherwise, if you just walk around Mong Kok, Yau Ma Tei, Jordan, etc, you will find small stores scattered here and there. For Eslite, they have a location at the Star House just a short walk from Star Ferry. For general books, search for Commercial Press locations. If you happen to be at the Island side, at Wan Chai's Johnston Road, go to Cosmos Books. For dim sum, I do recommend Reunion Garden at Hillwood Road between Jordan and Tsim Sha Tsui. It's a mid+ kind of place so not fancy but definitely not a dump. Another spot in Tsim Sha Tsui is New Bamboo Garden at Observatory Road. They are a little cheaper but surprisingly good.

subject: Dragon back - appropriate attire
usertext: hi all i am going to do a hike on the dragon's back in mid Dec. plan to be there at around 11am, would like to be earlier if possible . may i know would it be cold up there? weather forecast will be cloudy. any advice will be much appreciated. thanks

subject: 1. Re: Dragon back - appropriate attire
usertext: {may i know would it be cold up there?} Depends on the weather. Watch the HK Observatory a couple days before your hike. That is the only way to tell what sky (cloudy) and temperature conditions will be. What you wear is very much dependant on how susceptible you are to cooler temperatures in the early morning and the wind. Many of us hike in shorts and t-shirts on the main trails like Dragon's Back throughout the hiking season unless it is say... 12 degrees or below and early in the morning when it is much cooler than later in the morning after the sun comes up. At 11am, it should be fairly pleasant unless we are having a winter monsoon and that doesn't seem be in the forecast right now. If you have hiking pants with detachable legs, that can work really well if you are concerned about feeling cold. These allow you to start with legs in the early morning when its coolest and then detach, using shorts later on when you feel too warm.

subject: 2. Re: Dragon back - appropriate attire
usertext: Dragon's Back at its highest point is less than 300m up. I know that's enormous by Singaporean standards, but it's a minor hill - it will be about 2-3 degrees cooler than at sea level.

subject: 3. Re: Dragon back - appropriate attire
usertext: Parts are fairly exposed and right above the sea, so depending on the day it can be windy, and a light windbreaker might be handy.

subject: 4. Re: Dragon back - appropriate attire
usertext: Thank you all for the advice!

subject: 2. Re: Hong Kong Travel Agents/Tour Companies

subject: 3. Re: Hong Kong Travel Agents/Tour Companies

subject: 4. Re: Hong Kong Travel Agents/Tour Companies

I don't know about Vietnam but you can easily do a self-guided tour visiting Japan, especially the bigger cities. A flight to Tokyo takes around 4 hours. subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong entry with Turkish passport stamps?
usertext: Turkish Airline has 6 weekly direct flights between Istanbul and Hong Kong. A majority of those arriving passengers will have Turkish entry and exit stamps in their passports. I've never heard of any being denied entry into HK as such. Note also that HK Immigration allows Turkish Nationals 90-day visa free entry. These citizens of Turkey will certainly have Turkish stamps in their passports as well.

subject: 5. Re: Hong Kong entry with Turkish passport stamps?

subject: 6. Re: Hong Kong entry with Turkish passport stamps?

subject: 8. Re: Hong Kong entry with Turkish passport stamps?

subject: Refund of Security money in Octopus Card
usertext: I will be arriving HK Airport directly from Macau by Bus. Will enter departure terminal 1 . I had purchased Tourist Octopus Card from Klook from Counter A13 in Arrival Section when I arrived HK 5 days ago. Now while departing , from where I can get refund ? Can I go to arrival area from departure terminal freely for locating any MTR customer service Centre from where I can get refund .... OR Shud I go to Same counter A13 for getting refund.... OR any refund possibility from departure terminal itself ?

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Refund of Security money in Octopus Card
usertext: If by "security money" you mean deposit there is no deposit involved with Tourist Octopus. Any remaining credit value on the card is refundable but if you are arriving at HKIA via the direct bonded bus service from Macau you will be confined to the secure departures area and not be able to access the arrivals area to obtain any refund from any of the MTR Customer Service Centres. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Refund of Security money in Octopus Card
usertext: {OR any refund possibility from departure terminal itself ?} Just to add to SolentTraveller's response. Coming from Macau by bounded direct bus, you are bypassing HK immigration and arriving within the restricted area of HKIA airport. the MTR Customer Service counter is in the unrestricted area of the airport so unfortunately you won't have access to that area when arriving at the airport this way. Your best bet is to try to turn in your On Loan Octopus Card on the way out of Hong Kong to Macau. This can be done simply. Turn in your card prior to heading out to the HZMB or ferry terminal depending on how you plan to go to Macau. Pay bus fare or taxi with cash to get from your HK hotel to those border crossings.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Refund of Security money in Octopus Card
usertext: Just to clarify, a Tourist Octopus isn't an on-loan Octopus, it is purchased outright. The card can be taken to an MTR customer service centre for a refund of any unused stored value and the card is deactivated but the card is retained by the purchaser. If you're using the "golden bus" for your journey to Macau you could try and run down the stored value so there is just enough left to pay for ticket by Octopus Edited: 1 year ago

subject: length of stay in Hong Kong visa free for Malaysian passport
usertext: How long can I stay in Hong Kong visa free with a Malaysian passport?

subject: 1. Re: length of stay in Hong Kong visa free for Malaysian passport
usertext: See here. Hong Kong Immigration Department. Malaysian, visa free, up to 90 days. (Expand part II): Link: https://www.immd.gov.hk/eng/services/visas/visit-transit/visit-visa-entry-permit.html

subject: 2. Re: length of stay in Hong Kong visa free for Malaysian passport
usertext: For Malaysian passport holders Hong Kong is 90 days visa free and Macau is 30 days visa free in case if you want to combine Hong Kong and Macau. Additionally if you want to go to Mainland China as well you could enter Mainland China visa free for 30 days since December 1, 2023. The visa free entry to Mainland China for Malaysians is a temporary measure until November 30, 2024.

subject: 3. Re: length of stay in Hong Kong visa free for Malaysian passport
usertext: "...Additionally if you want to go to Mainland China as well you could enter Mainland China visa free for 30 days since December 1, 2023..." - as usual, Benjamin is wrong when commenting on Chinese visa. The exemption is for 15 days only.

subject: 4. Re: length of stay in Hong Kong visa free for Malaysian passport
usertext: Yes it's only 15 days visa free for Malaysians entering China but on the other hand it's 30 days visa free for Chinese entering Malaysia. I thought that China would be reciprocal but it seems not.

subject: 5. Re: length of stay in Hong Kong visa free for Malaysian passport
usertext: Benjamin, you are correct, but it seems that here we have two countries with very different visa policies. Malaysia has one of the most liberal visa policies globally compared to China that has one of the most rigid, although quite far from the rigidity of some other, mostly highly developed countries. In any case, it is visible that China reciprocate quite promptly, but in this case and for some reason they did not reciprocate by offering the same length of visa free stay within the country. Maybe we can compare the situation with the situation where EU allows the UK citizens to stay up to 90 days visa free compared to the UK that allows EU citizens to stay for up to 6 months visa free...

subject: 6. Re: length of stay in Hong Kong visa free for Malaysian passport
usertext: UK citizens with the right to abode in the UK can stay in Ireland for an unlimited period of stay though. Irish citizens can stay in the UK for an unlimited period of stay as well. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 7. Re: length of stay in Hong Kong visa free for Malaysian passport
usertext: Correct again, but Ireland is an isolated case for historical and practical reason called - Northern Ireland. In other words, Ireland has its cake and it is eating it too, successfully and contrary to the proverb.

subject: New Years Eve - First timer
usertext: It's my first time in Hong Kong and I will be traveling alone arriving on Dec 31st. I am open to any advice in general for a first timer and I have a few questions: 1 - Is it worth it for me to figure out the public transportation system when I'm only staying a couple days? Or easier for me to just use a cab? 2 - Is it safe for me to walk around everywhere? Are there areas I should avoid walking alone? 3 - What's the best place for me to view NYE fireworks? Any other NYE suggestions for a single person? Thanks in advance for your help and advice!

subject: 1. Re: New Years Eve - First timer
usertext: One more question... do I need cash for anything? Or can I use a credit card for all purchases and for transportation?

subject: 2. Re: New Years Eve - First timer
usertext: Taxis need cash. The MTR (subway) needs an Octopus card, which in turn needs cash. Buses and the ding-ding tram take contactless credit cards.

subject: 4. Re: New Years Eve - First timer
usertext: Of course it;s generally easier to use taxis but cost is higher and if you do a cross harbour trip it's usually slower than the MTR, Also after CNY fireworks there's basically no chance to get a taxi out of there. Just too much demand, and nearby roads will be closed to traffic. MTR is the way to go.

subject: 5. Re: New Years Eve - First timer
usertext: Keep in mind locals start crowding around the Tsim Sha Tsui waterfront hours before the fireworks kick off to lay claim to their small piece of ground, and it's bumper to bumper traffic. It's an awesome show but not for the faint-hearted dealing with the crowds. West Kowloon Cultural District is marginally better but will still be crowded.

subject: 6. Re: New Years Eve - First timer
usertext: The MTR is very easy to use, and chances are as a tourist, there's only a couple of lines you would use. You can use the MTR without an Octopus card, using either single ride tickets, or a tourist day ticket, but you need cash to pay for them.

subject: 7. Re: New Years Eve - First timer
usertext: Oops it looks like we're mixing up events NYE fireworks show is much smaller than the CNY show, but "smaller" is of course relative. In both cases there's extended crowd management in place, including closed roads and often some nearby MTR exits are closed to limit the inflow of people into the stations (and prevent overcrowding inside).

subject: 8. Re: New Years Eve - First timer
usertext: 1. HK public transport is brilliant. Sure you can get a taxi in addition to that. But be aware that NYE may be difficult or even impossible to get a taxi. 2. Not exactly "everywhere", but HK is one of the safest big cities in the world. There are some areas which may not be safe for a single person in the small hours of the night, but they are few and far between. In general, your biggest concern will be pickpockets, and don't get stupid drunk. 3. I don't do NYE's. The crowds are just too much for me to deal with. 4. Yes, you'll need cash. Use your bank ATM card to withdraw cash from a bank ATM.

subject: Kowloon to macau
usertext: Hi! We are staying at Shangri-la and in Macau we are staying at the St Regis. I am very confused where to take the ferry from and which company. On our way back we have to head back to the airport. Do we take the ferry from kowloon or from Sheung Wan ( which are easily available)and turbo jet or cotai ferry. Turbo jet is available on direct ferries. Really thankful for your advice

subject: 1. Re: Kowloon to macau
usertext: Which Shangri-La are you staying at? There are two in Hong Kong: Kowloon Shangri-La Hong Kong Shangri-La Regardless, you will likely be taking the MTR (subway) to Shun Tak Centre (aka "Macau Ferry Terminal" in Hong Kong). Ride the MTR to Sheung Wan MTR Station, use Exit D. It is a ~600 meter walk underground but you will directly exit to the Macau Ferry Terminal. Follow the signs. Or you can take a taxi there. Taxi is recommended if you stay at Hong Kong Shangri-La. Not as convenient and more expensive if you are staying at Kowloon Shangri-La because it needs to go through Cross Harbour Tunnel. But if you have a lot of luggage in tow, perhaps the taxi option is better. You have a decision to make: 2 options - ferry sailing to Macau Outer Harbour Ferry Terminal (MOHFT). Or to Taipa Ferry Terminal. Turbojet serves primarily MOHFT. Cotajet serves only Taipa Ferry Terminal. Schedule information here: Turbojet: https://www.turbojet.com.hk/en/routing-sailing-schedule/hong-kong-macau/sailing-schedule-fares.aspx Cotaijet: https://www.cotaiwaterjet.com/ferry-schedule/hongkong-macau-taipa.html Since you are going to St Regis, sailing to Taipa is highly recommended. It is much closer to your hotel, and you have more options to reach your hotel from the pier. There are free hotel shuttles (check St Regis Hotel website on the information). I think the shuttle service is pooled with other hotels under "Cotai Central" (that's the name of their complex, with 3 to 4 hotels). Or you can take a taxi there, it is not too far. To your hotel front door. Also available (though I don't recommend them because you need to walk a bit, with luggage): Macau's light rail "Macao LRT", and public buses. = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = Going from Macau to Hong Kong Airport: You can only take the ferry route if your airline supports SkyPier. if your airline doesn't support it, there is no check-in counter at SkyPier to check you in. You will not be eligible. Cotaijet will not sell you tickets to HKIA. You can use the HongKong-Macau-Zhuhai Bridge, take the Gold Bus and use other connections to reach the airport. Try not to take the ferry to Sheung Wan and then go to the airport as that would be inefficient.

subject: 2. Re: Kowloon to macau
usertext: From Macau to HKIA there are also direct bus services. Details here: https://www.macauhkairportbus.com/service.php If you want to use this, make sure your airline is in the list. Ferries from Macau to HKIA are very infrequent, only a few weekly sailings.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: Kowloon to macau
usertext: After lengthy suspension owing to covid, ferry services from Kowloon to Macau resumed on 1st December. However, there are currently just two each way daily sailings operated by Turbojet to Taipa Ferry Terminal in Macau. https://www.turbojet.com.hk/en/whats-new/kowloon-taipa_resumption.aspx The ferry terminal in Kowloon (China Ferry Terminal) is located on Canton Road, about 15 mins walk from Shangri-la or under 10 mins by taxi.

subject: 4. Re: Kowloon to macau
usertext: How to Visit Macau from Hong Kong (see link) https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html

subject: Diabetic traveller
usertext: Hi all. I'm looking to travel to Hong Kong next year for a holiday. I am a diabetic who will need to have insulin and needles with me. Do I need to declare these at the immigration check? Do I need supporting documentation?....Many thanks

subject: 1. Re: Diabetic traveller
usertext: It's nothing to do with Immigration - it's a Customs issue. Insulin is a prescription medicine. The rules are that you are allowed to bring a reasonable quantity prescription medications for personal use during your visit. You should carry a copy of the prescription or some other documentation to be checked if asked, but I believe that you can simply walk through the Green "nothing to declare" channel.

subject: 1. Re: passport for Disneyland?
usertext: As I understand it, to collect pre-booked tickets you need: 1) The credit card used to pay for the tickets 2) A photo ID matching the booking. This could be a passport or driving licence or similar (I guess in English if not a passport). You apparently also need to make a Reservation, which is separate from the ticket (tickets are not specific to a particular day).

subject: Gyms in Hong Kong
usertext: In recent years there have been a couple of queries posted in the forum as to where a visiting tourist might be able to use a good gym and get some exercise. The response has generally been that gyms in HK didn't market short-term entries -- they were focused on long-term contracts. I'm happy to say that on my current trip to HK, I've found a very workable solution. There's a new gym chain called Go24fitness that now has a series of gyms in many different parts of the SAR (but not Central). They welcome day visitors (for HK$200) , and they also sell weekly and one-month passes, which are much more economical. They are open 24 hours but to get set up with an entry pass I recommend going during their weekday business hours. Anybody who's interested can find full info by googling Go24fitness. They also have an upscale branch called Onyx, located in the Taikoo Place complex in Quarry Bay. That one is a tad more expensive but it is very nice indeed -- it has only been open a couple of months and so the machines are all new and the lockers/showers are immaculately clean.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Gyms in Hong Kong
usertext: Just had a look at the prices and they do seem decent. 12 months is $550 a month. Monthly is $638 plus $199 for access code. Although locations seem a little limited to 8 locations currently.

subject: getting from hong kong airport to macau at 21:30
usertext: Hello I need some help and i hope somebody can help me.. What is my best way to get from hong kong airport to macau at 21:30? Thank u so much

subject: 1. Re: getting from hong kong airport to macau at 21:30
usertext: i managed to find this so i guess i can go with taxi to hzm bridge and then with bus.. trying to understand if with the other method i can go at 21:30 First - Do It Yourself way of proceeding to HZM Bridge near the airport and proceeding by way of Golden Shuttle Bus over to Macau. This is the cheaper way (B4 Bus HK$9.1 + Golden Bus $65) service is frequent and regular and operates 24 hours a day. However, you have to go through HK Immigration twice (enter HK at the airport, exit at the bridge) before crossing over to Macau. Second - There is a new SkyPier direct coach service taking arriving passengers from HKIA straight to Macau over the bridge, bypassing HK Immigration altogether. This service operates on the hour, must be arranged at the SkyPier counter immediately upon arrival at HKIA (don't proceed through immigration). Cost is around HK$280 per adult. See details in the two links below.

subject: 2. Re: getting from hong kong airport to macau at 21:30
usertext: The last departure of that coach is 20:30 so you will have to do the taxi + bus (and clearing HK immigration twice) route. https://www.macauhkairportbus.com/service.php?lang=en

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 3. Re: getting from hong kong airport to macau at 21:30
usertext: There don't appear to be any links included in your post. The Skypier direct bonded bus service operates from HKIA at 30 minutes past the hour from 08-30 to 20-30 so you would be too late for that option; https://www.macauhkairportbus.com/service.php There is no other option to avoid having to pass HK Immigration both on entry at HK Airport and exit at the HZM Bridge. You do as you suggest, take bus B4 for the short journey to the bridge. It operates 24 hours at 15 min frequency until 1am then at 30 min frequency until 5am; https://www.nlb.com.hk/route/routemap/87 or you could take a taxi, fare probably about HK$50. Then take the "golden bus"shuttle across the bridge to Macau Port where you'll go through Macau Immigration procedures. From the bridge to your destination in Macau public bus 101X runs 24 hours and 102X runs until midnight; https://www.macauhkairportbus.com/infomation.php or take a taxi. There are also hotel/casino shuttles but I'm not sure how late they run

subject: Day trip to Macau in end Dec
usertext: Hi all My family and I are visiting Hong Kong for holidays during the Christmas to new year period. I like to add a day trip to Macau, must I pre-reserve my ferry tickets? Other then ferry, any other mode of transportation to & fro? We are staying at Tsim Sha Tsui area. Also will be advisable to book the return ferry tickets too? Or we can get it in the terminal so timing will be more flexible for us. Thank you

subject: 1. Re: Day trip to Macau in end Dec
usertext: Add on: Family of 4, 2 adults and 2 kids (8 & 9 years old).

subject: 2. Re: Day trip to Macau in end Dec
usertext: {I like to add a day trip to Macau, must I pre-reserve my ferry tickets?} On normal work days in HK I would say no need. However, if you are planning on going on a public holiday here in HK it would be a good idea to reserve tickets in advance. You don't want to show up at the ferry terminal and find out that there are no available tickets on sailings for the next couple of hours. Historically this has been a problem on public holidays such as Xmas, CNY and Mid-Autumn Festival. Also will be advisable to book the return ferry tickets too? Yes. You can reserve single or return tickets through the two major ferry company websites - TurboJet and CotaiWaterJet {Other then ferry, any other mode of transportation to & fro? } Absolutely, there is 24 hour shuttle service over the HZM Bridge that that runs with very high frequency, every 5 minutes or so during the peak of the day. See this thread on how to visit Macau from Hong Kong. Details and web resources are included. https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html

subject: 3. Re: Day trip to Macau in end Dec
usertext: Hi Thank you for the reply. I plan to visit Macau for a day trip and to take ferry to Macau from Hong Kong. We only plan to visit the city centre so taking ferry to Macau outer ferry terminal make it more convenient? But if we take ferry from China ferry terminal at harbour city will be nearer to our hotel in Kowloon but most of the ferries goes to Taipa. If from Taipa, what are the options that can take us to city centre? Plan to visit Senada square and surrounding place of interest. Thank you

subject: 4. Re: Day trip to Macau in end Dec
usertext: There are very, very few ferries from the China Ferry Terminal (two per day on Turbojet, none on CotaiWaterJet), so I would plan to go from Sheung Wan (HK Island). Or by bus over the bridge.

subject: 5. Re: Day trip to Macau in end Dec
usertext: Ok. If I travel on 26 or 27 Dec, will there be a lot of crowd for ferry? How long in advance I must arrive at Sheung Wan ferry terminal for check-in and immigration?

subject: 6. Re: Day trip to Macau in end Dec
usertext: Arriving some 20 mins in advance is enough. If you don't have a ticket, walk up to the counter and book the next available ferry - that was at least the standard method before the bridge, now with the vastly reduced ferry schedule it may be safer to book in advance.

subject: Google Maps Metro Details suddenly in Chinese
usertext: I've been using Google maps to get around the island without hassle but now somehow certain information is given in Chinese eg Central MTR Station name or exit on many MTRs or address details. Walking instructions etc are still in English but not which exit to take Didn't change any settings and double checked that my Google maps is set to English. This wasn't a problem till yesterday morning when it suddenly changed. Anyone else encountered this problem and knows how to fix it? Besides learning Chinese of course. I guess it changed because I was in China and Macau for day trips but again - I didn't change any settings and of course Google Maps in China wasn't an option anyway. Looking for advise!

subject: 1. Re: Google Maps Metro Details suddenly in Chinese
usertext: Your Google Map may have been unintentionally set to Chinese during your trip. If you are accessing their latest Google Map version: on the left hand side, you should see a vertical menu bar of sort. The "hamburger" symbol (signify it is a pop-up menu) should be at the top of that menu bar, click on it. Then a pop-up menu should appear. Down to the very bottom, then the third one back up, should be the Language Selection. Your choice may have been shown in Chinese characters. Anyway, click on that, a bigger-screen pop-up menu should appear offering you different languages. Select English or whatever language you prefer. See if this fixes it.

subject: 2. Re: Google Maps Metro Details suddenly in Chinese
usertext: Thanks but unfortunately doesn't change the issue.

subject: 4. Re: Google Maps Metro Details suddenly in Chinese
usertext: On the webpage version, I see the issue myself. The station itself (say "Tsim Sha Tsui") now only lists TST in Chinese characters. My maps are still set to English (US) though. However, it doesn't seem to be happening at every station. Prince Edward still shows both Chinese and English. Therefore, I think it's just a bug that will get fixed, hopefully. I have not gone to China for a while.

subject: 5. Re: Google Maps Metro Details suddenly in Chinese
usertext: Sorry iOS App
