subject: Wonton Noodles Review Maks , Tsim Chai Kee , Lau Sum Kee
usertext: Went to central to Maks noodles and Tsim Chai kee on Wellington Street. Maks for the price was very average, soup not much flavour, wontons ok. I think you get only 3 wontons which were again pretty average. Service ok but the male waiter was hovering over us like are you gonna leave now as soon as we finished our wontons when there was only 4 or 5 customers. In and out in 10-15 mins. When we were sitting in Maks we noticed across the road the massive line for Tsim Chai Kee so had to give it a go. Again soup and wontons were average, but the noodles were so hard and chewy not in a good way. But the fish paste ball was very nice and snappy and was my favourite item. Service is they want you in and out as quickly as possible. Dont see the hype to be honest. Next up was Lau Sum kee in sham shui po. These guys had the best wontons, the wontons had the snappy prawns from a har gau. A great bite and chew to them. But the soup and noodles were nothing special. What are some of your wonton noodle recommendations?

subject: 1. Re: Wonton Noodles Review Maks , Tsim Chai Kee , Lau Sum Kee
usertext: Tsim Chai kee may not be the wonton but it is normally the best value. This instant wonton actually is very good: https://www.hktvmall.com/hktv/en/main/THE-FOODIES/s/H1111001/Supermarket/Supermarket/Chilled-Frozen-Food/Dumpling-and-Wonton/Deluxe-Shrimp-Wonton-Frozen/p/H0888001_S_10018394?scrollTo=reviewTab

subject: Luggages on the MTR East rail line to Luohu
usertext: Hello and thank you in advance to everyone who took the time to read this message. I'm currently in Hong Kong and want to travel to Shenzhen via the Futian checkpoint. However, I will have a medium-sized suitcase that weighs over 16kg, a carry-on suitcase of around 6-7kg, and a backpack. I saw online that the MTR doesn't allow passengers to have multiple luggage and over 23kg. Do you have any idea if I can still take the MTR or any tips and advice?

subject: 1. Re: Luggages on the MTR East rail line to Luohu
usertext: I believe you are ok. I had the same luggages (by kg) as yours and took mtr to airport without any problems.

subject: 2. Re: Luggages on the MTR East rail line to Luohu
usertext: I have done it with more luggage than this.

subject: 3. Re: Luggages on the MTR East rail line to Luohu
usertext: I don't believe you're quoting the current MTR luggage rules, which changed in 2021: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/main/carriage_of_luggage.html

subject: 4. Re: Luggages on the MTR East rail line to Luohu
usertext: I can't advise for breaking any rules. But as a practical matter, with "medium-sized suitcase that weighs over 16kg, a carry-on suitcase of around 6-7kg, and a backpack. ", I don't think you need to worry about it. BTW: There are confusions in your opening post. You said "Luohu" in the title. But in the content you said "Futian". These are two distinct ports in Shenzhen. You use one or the other. You may want to double check which one you will be using. Futian connects to "Lok Ma Chau Spur Line" MTR Station on the Hong Kong side. Luohu connects to "Lo Wu" MTR Station on the Hong Kong side. Both Lok Ma Chau and Lo Wu are part of the MTR East Rail Line, just alternate end-points.

subject: Airport to Wharney
usertext: One month to takeoff! So I've changed my mind and have booked The Wharney in Wanchai instead. Arriving at 7 PM on a Tuesday night. Which is the best option for me as a single traveler with 2 medium bags. Bus A11 to Luard Road or AE and the H1 shuttle bus? Am a little concerned about what kind of clothes to bring in the late January? Do I need a jacket or similar at night? And doe spending a morning at Victoria Peak? TIA

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Airport to Wharney
usertext: The H1 shuttle bus from Hong Kong Station no longer operates, the service was permanently suspended from June 2020. You could take the Airport Express train to HK Station then complete your journey by taxi, taxi fare probably about HK$60. However bus A11 to Luard Road is a comfortable and cheaper option, fare HK$41.9, should take about 50 mins. Taxi from the airport direct to hotel should cost about HK$350. Yes, I would take a jacket especially if you're going to the Peak where the temperature can be several degrees cooler.

subject: 2. Re: Airport to Wharney
usertext: Indeed, no more AE shuttle bus to this hotel, at least for time being. A11 is good, the bus stop is not far away.

subject: From HKG airport to Kowloon Harbourfront Hotel?
usertext: Howto go from HKG international airport to Kowloon Harbourfront hotel by public transport at 7 pm? Thanks in advance.

subject: 1. Re: From HKG airport to Kowloon Harbourfront Hotel?
usertext: Take airport bus A21, alight at stop #20.

subject: 2. Re: From HKG airport to Kowloon Harbourfront Hotel?
usertext: Traveler, Make sure to download Goggle Maps and CityMapper to your mobile devise. You can use them throughout your stay in HK to plan routes around the city using various forms of public transportation.

subject: 3. Re: From HKG airport to Kowloon Harbourfront Hotel?
usertext: A21 airport bus will take you there. Bus Stop #20 is also their terminus, the end point of this route, Hung Hom MTR Station (and bus terminus). To set up a better expectation: my small warning: there is ~ 0.5 mile of walk from the bus terminus to this hotel, via some pedestrian walkways that can be not-straight-forward to navigate. You won't be walking on street surface but a series of connecting walkpaths. The building layout, roads, pedestrian paths in that corner of Hong Kong is one of the most confusing, from layers of add-ons through out several decades. You may want to research and rehearse how to walk from the bus terminus to this hotel. Or else on your travel day, and especially after dark (past 7 pm), I can bet you will be lost and had to back-track in some way trying to find your hotel. Maybe ask this hotel and see if they have written directions for guests to walk there from the Hung Hom Station.

subject: 4. Re: From HKG airport to Kowloon Harbourfront Hotel?
usertext: Thx a lot, but maybe it is better to take a taxi from Hung Hom MTR Station to the hotel? I hope, it will be a short way with a cab, not a city tour by night? :-) I remember Chittagong when I was very tired and took a taxi for a 5-minute walk. I fell asleep, and when I woke up 40 minutes later, we were still driving Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 5. Re: From HKG airport to Kowloon Harbourfront Hotel?
usertext: You'll have a very unhappy taxi driver for a 0.5 mile trip.

subject: 6. Re: From HKG airport to Kowloon Harbourfront Hotel?
usertext: The hotel offers a shuttle bus service that goes to Harbour Plaza Metropolis (near where A21 terminates) and Middle Road (which is a stop along the A21 route). Using the Middle Road stop is probably the easier and definitely faster solution if you can manage to cross Nathan Road and find the bus stop. Otherwise, the HP Metropolis Hotel is a sister hotel operation so they can surely guide you to the bus stop. Note that from the A21 terminus bus stop, you need to go up the elevator or the escalator, cross the bridge into the shopping mall, and then follow the signs to the hotel. https://www.harbour-plaza.com/kowloonharbourfront/files/brochure_files/224/en/KHFH%20ENG.pdf https://www.harbour-plaza.com/metropolis/files/brochure_files/222/en/Location%20Map%202021.pdf But if you do decide to walk from the bus stop, you also need to go into the mall first and then head out the other way near Hung Luen Road. Once you manage to get yourself down to street level, it's much easier to navigate using Google Map.

subject: deported from Hong Kong, can you visit diff country in a wk
usertext: Does anyone knows if someone get deported from a Hong Kong can you go to another foreign country like Malaysia, Veitnam or Singapore within the next few days?

subject: 1. Re: deported from Hong Kong, can you visit diff country in a wk
usertext: Assuming you hold Indian passport, you'll need a visa for entry into Vietnam and Singapore. I don't know what questions they ask on the visa application, but if they ask "have you been refused entry or been expelled from another country?", then I think you are going to have problems there. I understand that Indian passport holders don't require a visa to enter Malaysia. But will they ask similar questions at immigration? I don't know.

subject: 2. Re: deported from Hong Kong, can you visit diff country in a wk
usertext: It doesn't sound like that being deported from HK has any bearing on your entry to other countries. Of course, it might also depend on why you were deported. Each country makes its own admission decision.

subject: 3. Re: deported from Hong Kong, can you visit diff country in a wk
usertext: If HK Immigration stamps your passport "DEPORTED" or something like that it could affect your entry to other countries in the future.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: Our trip review 23Nov-5 Dec
usertext: This is a summary of our recent trip to HK, as pay back for all the browsing I did of other posts and direct help I got for advice re travel etc. Our trip was for 12 nights at the end of Nov. I appreciate this is much longer than most people come to HK for, but I used to live here and it's rarely going to be a trip for a few days if I can help it. On this occasion, my return was primarily to scatter my father's ashes in HK after he died nearly 3 years ago in Scotland. I won't go into the process of arranging it here (anyone who wants to know can message me privately) but in some ways it wasn't the most straightforward of tasks and I'm glad we had booked to stay for 12 nights as the process can take a wee while to organise. The relevant HK govt dept were, however, good at rushing through the paperwork to get the permission, once all the other hoops are jumped through. We stayed at the Royal Garden in TST East. We had stayed here before and we're quite happy with the location etc. I've posted a separate review of it but we enjoyed our stay. The weather was wonderful while we were there. A balmy mid 20s and not a spot of rain. A welcome relief after all we've endured for the last 9 months or so in Scotland. It might have been better if it had been blue skies all the time but I can't complain and it definitely felt warmer than past Novembers from my childhood. Always a haze so photos weren't as good as in the past. Admin aside, which took up chunks of a few days, as this was the 6th visit for my husband, I decided it might be nice to see and do things we've never done, and indeed places I've not been to in 40 odd years. We went to Kadoorie Farm, which was a nice change, boy was it a steep walk down from the top (we got the shuttle bus up)! We especially enjoyed the aviaries which have interesting notes about the birds' background and they are great enclosures, especially compared to the zoological gardens in HK Island. We went to Tai Po too and enjoyed wandering the markets there, much more fun than in the city although it was a big thumbs down from my husband for the train museum! We took a trip over to Lamma Island one day and did the walk from one ferry point to the other, nothing too arduous and enough to build up an appetite for lunch. Just a simple lunch of squid, vegetables and rice but utterly delicious. We went mid week in case it got a lot more crowded at the weekend. We went to Stanley one Saturday, not so much to see Stanley as it's not like it was 40 years ago, but the bus journey there is always enjoyable. I was concerned it might be very busy as we went on a Saturday, but it was so quiet it was quite peculiar, although very welcome. I was shocked by the amount of new buildings around that area and Repulse Bay, but then again it's been at least 10 years since I was there last so no doubt it has been a gradual progression. And the fancy boats in the bays-wow! Thankfully tourists numbers were not back to what they were at their peak and while the harbour had a buzz about it, we found most places comfortably busy, although I'm sure many shops and restaurants etc would prefer more customers. The Peak was heaving when we went, but once you start off on the circular route, the numbers peter out and there were spells where we were on our own (I did wish I had kept a little portion of ashes to scatter there rather than the Cape Collinson memorial gardens which held little meaning to me. But I know- not allowed!!) HK races- we have no great interest in horse racing but enjoy the spectacle that is Happy Valley. So off we went on a Wed night to discover the $10 entry fee was waived. Not sure if that's been the case for a while. We stayed for a few races but I was disappointed by the choice of food. It seemed to cater for the more international taste, which is fine, but there wasn't even a Chinese rice dish to enjoy. Still, an excuse to indulge in a rare Big Mac for me. Next time I think we will go for the later races as it was definitely getting busier as we left. The lovely egg tarts- we sampled many, since it's not something we often get here in Scotland of decent quality. They ranged in price from $12 in Central, to $4.50 (Sham Shui Po or Tai Po, I can't recall). Have to say the higher price one wasn't anything to write home about and the other ones were just as good, and probably better. We often skipped our dinner as we had a bigger than normal breakfast, followed by a late lunch. At the time it was fine, but in hindsight I realise now I should have taken every opportunity to enjoy even the simplest dinner of wonton meen. How I wish I had a bowl of it now!! We also visited the relatively new HK Palace Museum. Getting there was pretty straightforward. The return bus, however, was a long wait of 45 mins, not ideal. Should have hopped on a mini bus to the MTR station. That aside, it was an enjoyable few hours. We went as we had seen an ad for the National Gallery Botticelli exhibition and this appealed to my husband. We had a few spare days so it was a nice thing to do for a change. In hindsight I should have let him do that exhibition on his own as I was a tad bored, but I enjoyed the permanent exhibitions of HK ceramics and Forbidden City much more than he did. Due to the timings, we had to rush through these at the end (although I did still spend over an hour) but I would certainly go back to it. A striking building too. Speaking of museums, the HK history museum was unfortunately shut on this trip as I would have gone back to that. Next time! We also went to the maritime museum but I mainly enjoyed the more recent stuff. On our last day, as our flight was not until midnight, and my husband was not up for wandering through any more markets, we decided just to hop on the trams and watch the world go by. We went from Central to Whitty St depot, then a tram to way past Causeway Bay and then back again. It whiled away a few hours and was quite enjoyable. I personally would have preferred more wandering around Mong Kok and Sham Shiu Po but I wasn't going to push my luck! One final observation- my husband was able to make use of the Elderly Octopus card and it was incredibly good value to have most fares capped at $2, even the Lamma ferry. He wasn't smug at all! And the discounts for museums etc were great although still a bargain at full price. The MTR was great, as usual, and the Star Ferry was so quiet it seemed quite sad. Having said that, a running jump now could see you make it over the harbour. I'm not so keen on the ever increasing reclaimed land on HK island, but perhaps this is just what happens when you return and things change. In summary, a wonderful trip back to where I was born and brought up, and I was sad to leave. Our last visit was Nov'19 so this was quite a contrast with no protests to avoid etc, and the city did have more of a buzz to it, but thankfully, for us, it wasn't back to its peak tourist numbers. Wonder what things will be like when I return in hopefully 2-3 years.. Thanks again to all the regulars on this forum as I trawled for a while for relevant up to date information. This was meant to be brief but it's very long so I do apologise!

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Our trip review 23Nov-5 Dec
usertext: Thank you for the review! I was there for 13 days in early Nov after a break of 5 years. I too was born in HK but, sadly, not brought up there. A lot of what you have said resonated with me about the changes over the years. It's my wish that some of my ashes be scattered in HK (hopefully not soon!) so that's interesting, will need to do my research. Glad you had a good time.

subject: 3. Re: Our trip review 23Nov-5 Dec
usertext: I feel that Sai Kung offers more variety than Stanley. The best time to visit is on a weekend. Go there at roughly 10am in the morning before the roads and the area get crowded. Check out the boats selling seafood, visit some of the market stalls, and walk along the promenade. For food, choose from one of the seafood restaurants (not sure about quality but you can dine outdoors), many Western choices, or the smaller cafes in town. One can also take a boat to visit the Geopark.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 4. Re: Our trip review 23Nov-5 Dec
usertext: Thanks Sammy FD. Sai Kung was on my list too but we left it too late and I decided to save it for our next visit. It's nice to get away from the main parts of the city when you're there more than a few days.

subject: 5. Re: Our trip review 23Nov-5 Dec
usertext: Interesting trip. Thanks for your trip report.

subject: Trip Report  Hong Kong, Nov 2023  4 days
usertext: Thanks again to BradJill, SammyFD, wvmarle and others for all the helpful tips. 15 hours from takeoff in Los Angeles (United) and we were landing in Hong Kong. Our flight got in at 7:30 in the evening and baggage - immigration was pretty simple. After picking up our pre-reserved wifi hotspot, and getting some cash from an atm, we headed to the taxi stand which was very well organized. Getting cash at one of the multiple atms was simple. We were staying at the Courtyard Marriott (see review) in Sai Ying Pun in Hong Kong. So instead of trying to figure out the public transportation options, we opted to take a taxi which was relatively cheap. Make sure to take the red-colored taxis if going to HK island. The fare indicated was accurate at about 325 HKD (about $45 USD) if I recall correctly. We got to the hotel and checked in by 8:30pm. Since we were hungry we decided to walk a little ways to one of the multiple small restaurants still open and located on Des Voeux Rd next to the Courtyard- all locals. I had the mistaken impression that Mandarin had become more widely used in Hong Kong only to find that Cantonese was still the primary language. Not that it mattered because we don't speak either one despite being ethnically Chinese - American born. In any case, we found a small soup noodle shop and managed despite the language barrier (lots of pointing and observing what the locals were doing). Two large soup noodle bowls with pork for about 85 HKD ($11 US) - Very cheap! Note: We had pre-reserved a wifi hotspot and we found the kiosk pretty easily (directions on your confirmation) on the arrivals floor. We showed my confirmation email, received the hotspot, fired it up and it worked like a charm. What's nice about this is that both my wife and I could be connected whereas before we would each need to get a SIM. It allowed up to 5 devices, the speed was good throughout, and just needed to charge it overnight. It worked in Macau also. It was a great option if you have multiple family members needing connectivity. Day One: We had not yet purchased our Octopus card so we went to the Sai Ying Pun MRT station. We purchased them at the counter (had to use cash - no credit card). We had a 10 am meeting at Lippo Centre in Central, to tend to some family business. We were done by 11 and since we were already pretty close by, we took the short walk over to the Peak Tram. This was a Friday and it was overcast. So maybe this is why the que was not long at all -no waiting. Everyone got into the first tram available. The overcast conditions also made the overall weather pretty cool and bearable. The few times the sun came out I felt the heat and humidity pretty rapidly. We also purchased the ticket that included the Sky Terrace which I think was worthwhile. It gives you the best unencumbered view of everything below. And even though it wasn't too sunny or clear, the views are still pretty stunning. Too bad you couldn't see much beyond Kowloon very well. Predictably, it is very commercialized at the top with the mall, food shops and stores. We did hike along the Lugard Rd Hong Kong Trail a bit. But I think we turned back before reaching the Lugard Rd Lookout. We hadn't done our research well. In any case, we were getting hungry and wanted to go to a dimsum place. So back down the tram. So here is a warning on using Google maps. The app is great for directions and for letting you know which bus or train to take, etc. But while on foot, it is more challenging to follow, especially in a place like Hong Kong with lots of elevation. I didn't think we were getting good GPS location at times. Plus there are a lot of twisting intersection roads and underpasses - and Maps doesn't think in 3D. So beware. In retrospect, we might have used taxis more often. It took us 30 mins of walking to find the right bus stop to head towards Man Mo Dim Sum. Unfortunately we finally got there and found we needed reservations. So we walked a little further and found Ka Ho around the corner. This was a very very local Cantonese place - no English spoken and definitely no tourists. Luckily, ordering dimsum was off a picture menu otherwise we would have starved. Even so, the wait staff got a kick out of us for having the nerve (or ignorance) to enter and sit down. Imagine, Chinese people who speak no chinese! Luckily, I had already read about dipping the bowls/utensils in the hot water ritual. So maybe that got us some street cred. We made it through the meal - the dim sum was delicious although probably not the best HK has to offer. Afterwards, we went to the Central market area to get my wife a pair of shorts because she had forgotten to pack any. For dinner, we met two friends of ours for dinner who took us to a local place in Central. We took the "ding ding" light rail trains right outside the hotel pretty much everywhere.

subject: 1. Re: Trip Report  Hong Kong, Nov 2023  4 days
usertext: Day 2: We were meeting a cousin for lunch in Wan Chai. So in the morning we decided to take the Star ferry from Central pier across to Kowloon. Again, it wasn't a sunny clear day - a little rainy. But still worth doing. My wife had heard about the egg tarts at Bakehouse in Tsim Sha Tsui on the Kowloon side so we made the short walk to Hankow Rd. When we arrived at around 9:30 am, the line was all the way down the block. We waited about 20 mins, hardly moved, and decided we needed to invoke Plan B. Wife found another bakery whose name I forget. We had to take a 15 min taxi ride but it was easy. We got our egg tarts and headed back to the ferry. We got back to Wan Chai and had about 45 mins to walk through the market. It's always fun to see all the shops and especially the outdoor meat and seafood markets. I got some good video footage of the cage of live frogs for sale by the pound - you don't really see that back in the States. We met my cousin for dim sum at Sportful Garden in Wan Chai. The dim sum was good. We had never tried pigeon before but it was good to try. Very nice Chinese restaurant. Dinner that night was at Yat Lok on Stanley St for their Michelin Star roast goose. We had to wait but totally worth it. I posted a review here. Bottom line, I highly recommend as long as you do some research and know what sort of restaurant it is. It's not anything remotely close to fine dining. Just delicious roast goose in a crowded little restaurant. Day 3: This was our last full day and it was a choice between visiting Lantau and the Buddha or doing a day trip to Macau. Our friends had not been to Macau yet so we opted for that. We would've preferred to go to the Outer Harbor first but since we didn't book in advance, the next one was to Taipa so we opted for that. Once off the ferry, all the casinos have buses waiting to pick you up to take you to the hotels. So we hopped on the Wynn Palace shuttle and headed there. Only took about 15 mins. We spent the morning walking the Wynn, the Venetian, the relatively new Londoner and also the Parisien. The Venetian has a massive food court which suited us well for lunch. From the MGM, we took their shuttle over to the MGM Grand on the Peninsula side. From there we took a short taxi up to the Ruins at St Paul's and checked that out. Walking from there to Senado Sq, on a Sunday afternoon . . it was super crowded wall to wall people through the narrow streets. We made our way back to the Wynn Macau and hopped their free shuttle to the Outer Harbor terminal to catch a 5 pm ferry back. I don't know if coming or going to Macau is typically more smooth. But heading back to HK was a pretty rough ride. Day 4: Departure day - Our flight to Tokyo (next stop) wasn't until 11:30 am. So lo and behold, the wife found that Bakehouse has a store in Central, so we took a taxi there and got there when it opened at 8 am. So we were able to get our egg tarts after all, which, were a little better and fresher than the ones we got in Macau. We came straight back to the hotel, got our luggage, and took the Courtyard's free shuttle to Hong Kong station. From there we took the MRT out to the airport which, on a sunny day, was a pleasant trip. All in all, if we weren't there to see friends/family, we probably would have done and seen much more even in a short 4 day visit. That is actually our style. I definitely wanted to see the Buddha and spend a day on Lantau. But oh well, next time.

subject: 2. Re: Trip Report  Hong Kong, Nov 2023  4 days
usertext: Thanks very much for the excellent trip report. HK is pretty walkable - you could have walked from the bottom of the Peak Tram to Man Mo Dim Sum in less than the 30 minutes you took looking for a bus stop! (23 minutes according to Google Maps) The trick with Google Maps is to use it as a map, but not to rely on the GPS positioning when within high-rise buildings.

subject: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: Does Hong Kong have a place like Huaqiangbei like in Shenzhen?

subject: 1. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: Golden Computer Centre in Sham Shui Po district. Hong Kong MTR: Sham Shui Po Station, Exit D2

subject: 2. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: Thank you very much.

subject: 3. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: My thought: if you are going to Huaqiangbei in Shenzhen anyway, you may not need to visit Golden in Hong Kong. In Hong Kong, you may find a mix of parts made in China, Taiwan, South Korea, Japan, etc.. In Shenzhen, likely mostly those manufactured in China. They may (or likely may not) be parts used by brand name products, but after-market replacements, or "compatibles", or "something like". If you are looking for functional, generic parts, that's probably good. It is best if you know your stuff. I think you may find prices of parts higher in Hong Kong and a variety of prices. (Quality usually is proportional to price. You need to weigh that in your considerations.) Inside Hong Kong's Golden Computer Centre, shops and merchandises are very packed. Often those tiny shops do not have a comfortable "viewing" space. And the shop-keepers, being in Hong Kong, often just "go go go". Patience is not compatible with their business survival. Best is to hone in on what you are looking for, and compare offers and prices.

subject: 4. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: Golden is all about computers, phones, cameras, headphones and related accessories. Huaqiangbei has a lot more electronic parts for repair and even manufacturing use.

subject: 5. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: Yes, in Hong Kong you're sort of expected to somehow already know just what you're looking for. Shopowners can be impatient -- on occasion downright rude -- if you seem to dawdle. (To be fair, Huaqiangbei is much the same.) If you do go to Golden Centre, note that the whole district is packed with places, some of which are tucked upstairs.

subject: 6. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: I am actually looking for Android box . Are they available there?

subject: 7. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: Probably - it's pretty much in line with the rest. Otherwise try the shops at Apliu Street, that's another good area for electronics. And of course there are the regular chain stores - Fortress and the like. Good chance to find a generic item like that in those stores as well. Make sure you know the prices the item sells at in your home locality. Hong Kong is not necessarily cheaper. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 8. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: Thank you for the advice

subject: 9. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: You mean the TV boxes? The last time I went to Golden around 3 months ago, I hardly saw those, probably due to copyright reasons. Maybe you can find them over at Ap Liu St. Shop owner manners vary. I can tell you that the guy at the famed Lung Shing Dispensary is rude even by HK standards. Then there are other shops with very friendly folks, too.

subject: 10. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.

subject: 11. Re: Best electronic place that sell all.
usertext: It's at Sham Shui Po as well (same as Golden) so you can visit both on the same day. I believe it's exit C1. I don't have particular recommendations, but SSP has many small eateries serving various noodles and HK-style sandwiches (say corned beef and scrambled eggs). You can look up some of them online if interested.

subject: 1. Re: Hong Kong or Tokyo Disneyland
usertext: Important to note that Tokyo has both Disneyland and DisneySea theme parks while we have just Disneyland here in Hong Kong. Probably best to view all three theme parks to determine which is most interesting to you personally. Also consider how much other sightseeing you have lined up in both Hong Kong and Tokyo. This will help you think about which of these fits better into your travel schedule for your multi-city trip. Hong Kong Disneyland https://www.hongkongdisneyland.com/?located=true Tokyo Disneyland https://www.tokyodisneyresort.jp/en/index.html Tokyo DisneySea https://www.tokyodisneyresort.jp/en/tds/

subject: Straight from HKIA to Macau early AM?
usertext: Hi I arrive in HK at 6am for a 4 day visit. I would like to do one day and night in Macau and was thinking about going straight from HKIA airport on arrival to Macau then after a night get back to downtown HK. What are my transport options at that time in the morning? Is that reasonable to do? Or should I just try and head into HK and do some sort of normal trip to Macau?

subject: 1. Re: Straight from HKIA to Macau early AM?
usertext: If you go straight there, the major issue is you luggage. If you travel light, or with only 1 suitcase, that would be all right. If you have more, that may not be as easy. Using the HongKong-Macau-Zhuhai Bridge to go to Macau is accessible 24-hours. See details in this long thread: Link: https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14356859-HongKong_airport_to_Macau-Macau.html The Bonded Bus option can save you 2 times immigration checks (Enter Hong Kong, Exit Hong Kong). You can go directly from inside the Hong Kong International Airport. But the first bus departure is not until 8:30 am. See this link to the home page of the bus operator: Link: https://www.macauhkairportbus.com/service.php See these recent threads for some more details: Link: https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14610603-HKIA_to_Macau-Macau.html Link: https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g294217-i1496-k14559090-Hong_Kong_Airport_to_Macau-Hong_Kong.html

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Straight from HKIA to Macau early AM?
usertext: Many thanks for that info. I will be traveling light, but the times don't really work do they? Unless I find something to do at the airport? Arrive at 6am, first coach is 8:30.. :/ Alternatively, if I go through immigration early, is there a normal coach service I can use that early from the airport at that time? Thanks for the reply.

subject: 3. Re: Straight from HKIA to Macau early AM?
usertext: That early in the morning, go through Hong Kong Immigration is fine. Will be quick. There is no direct coach from the airport to Macau. Many people would wish there is. It is slightly more complicated. Read the whole thread (first one) linked in my reply #1. There are lots of details. Basically you Enter Hong Kong. From the Arrival Hall, walk down or elevator down to the ground level, find the bus stop to take the bus B4 to Hong Kong Port (of HongKong-Macau-Zhuhai Bridge). Exit Hong Kong (immigration). Ride the Golden Bus to Macau Port.

subject: 4. Re: Straight from HKIA to Macau early AM?
usertext: Personally with only 4 days, you might want to just focus on visiting Hong Kong. Also flight arrivals, followed by two consecutive days of crossing international borders and hotel check-ins is a big time and energy drain. You might be doing yourself and your group a big favour by going straight to your hotel in HK where and staying there all four nights. If you really want to visit Macau, no problem. Just do a day trip over using the 24 hour shuttle service over the HZM Bridge or use ferries between the two cities. This would be much more convenient than dragging your luggage over to Macau and checking into a hotel (usually 2-3pm check-ins in Macau) and having to repeat that experience again the next morning, taking all of your luggage back to HK to check into another hotel. I would only do something like this if I knew transportation around both cities very well and was traveling with very light luggage only.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 5. Re: Straight from HKIA to Macau early AM?
usertext: I think you could be right. On my final day in HK I need to be at the Airport for around 10pm to fly back to the UK. I could check out my hotel in Kowloon (Still don't know where to stay) and public transport to the Airport, then leave my luggage in left luggage and public transport to Macau and then back to the Airport later to go home?? I can't use that bonded bus on the return I guess as the left luggage is not airside? It will probably be just a large backback I think anyway,.

subject: 6. Re: Straight from HKIA to Macau early AM?
usertext: {and public transport to the Airport, then leave my luggage in left luggage and public transport to Macau and then back to the Airport later to go home??} Might be a bit busy of a day but it is very much doable with the easy and quick transportation over the HZM Bridge between Macau and HK Airport, especially with no luggage on the day. See this thread regarding travel between Hong Kong and Macau for information on how to use the Golden Shuttle Bus service back and forth. This puts you near HKIA where there is a regular circular route B4 (8 minute ride) to/from the HK Port building at HZM Bridge https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g664891-i12409-k14475822-Travel_between_Hong_Kong_Macau_2023-Macau.html

subject: Sai Kung
usertext: Hi, we plan to visit HK in January, we are staying in Hongkong Island . Can someone advise how to travel to Sai Kung from Hongkong island , Is there MRT to Sai Kung?

subject: 1. Re: Sai Kung
usertext: No MTR to Sai Kung, sorry. CityMapper is a good app for planning this. I entered a random place on HK Island, Sai Kung as destination, and it gave a variety of options, choice of 3 MTR lines to start, choice of 3 buses to finish. Since I don't know where you're starting, I don't know which to recommend; all looked similar for time: 90 minutes +. As to taxis, I'm not sure if you'd have to switch to a green taxi or not; they have territories. Edited: 1 year ago

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 2. Re: Sai Kung
usertext: Fastest route will most likely be MTR to Choi Hung Station then green minibus 1A from outside exit C2 of the station (destination Sai Kung Pier). The minibus is faster and much more frequent than franchised bus, operating 24 hours with a frequency of 5 minutes or less during the daytime.

subject: 3. Re: Sai Kung
usertext: CityMapper is a good tool for planning city routes using public transportation. You can use Google Maps as well. Both are fine for commonly visited places around the HK Island, Kowloon and areas around the N.T. with simple and regular transportation, like going to Sai Kung. There are indeed a fair number of MTR - bus combinations that will get you to Sai Kung Pier. If you are comfortable using the light green mini buses, I also think route 1 outside Choi Hung MTR Station is usually going to be your quickest overall route there.

subject: 4. Re: Sai Kung
usertext: If taking taxi you can take a red taxi all the way to Sai Kung - red taxis are allowed all over Hong Kong except the restricted part of Lantau. Green taxis on the other hand are limited to a specific part of the New Territories, and may not go to other places except destinations such as the airport and Disney. Also in Sai Kung you can usually find red taxis, at the main bus terminal there are separate stands for red and green taxis. A ride from Hong Kong Island to Sai Kung would cost around $350 or so, including tunnel fees.

subject: 5. Re: Sai Kung
usertext: Not disagreeing with what others have said, but particularly if staying towards the east of HK Island (North Point, Quarry Bay etc), you might find that the MTR to Hang Hau and then green minibus 101M is more convenient that going via Choi Hung and the 1A.

subject: 1. Re: Octopus Tourist Card or Tap and go Credit Card

subject: 2. Re: Octopus Tourist Card or Tap and go Credit Card
usertext: I've used the new visa tap a couple of times to see how it works. The physical card swipe is just as easy as using your octopus card going into and out of the MTR. Note, when exiting the MTR, you have to pull out your card and swipe again, the visa scanner doesn't seem to read through physical wallets. You can also use Iphone wallet linked visa card but its less convenient. You have to open your wallet, select card, scan and then double tap to confirm payment on the way into the MTR station. It is a bit quicker on the way of the MTR after your ride. Note: Not all entry gates have the visa scanners installed as of yet. You have to look for them. They have an extra scanner facing you with Visa shown above. Fairly easy to spot.

subject: Visit in Jan 2024

Is Jan a good time to visit from the perspective of weather there ? Is it very cold and does it rain during that period. Would appreciate any inputs Thanks

subject: 1. Re: Visit in Jan 2024
usertext: January is one of the driest months. No rain generally. Is it cold? It is subjective. To someone from Europe/Scandinavia, it may feel like summer to them. To someone from Singapore, it may feel like freezing. Generally expect temperature to be ~15'C to 20'C. When a cold front hits, temperature may drastically drop to ~5'C to 10'C overnight, and for a couple of days.

District: Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames

subject: The opening up of Shau Tau Kok
usertext: From 1st January, for the first time since 1951, individual tourists are able to visit the border town of Shau Tau Kok in the Frontier Closed Area between Hong Kong and Shenzhen. The town is famous for Chung Ying Street where one side of the street is located in Hong Kong and the other Mainland China, with the border being separated only by boundary stones. Although Chung Ying Street will remain closed to tourists for security reasons a viewpoint overlooking the street, Chung Ying Garden has been created and Hong Kong Tourism Board has launched a guide for tourists with details of other attractions in the area, how to apply for permits and how to get there. Individual visitors can apply for a Tourism Closed Area Permit up to three days in advance of proposed visit with a daily quota of 300 permits. Up to 700 daily visitors will also be allowed in group tours arranged by travel agencies. From last June designated tour groups have been allowed to access Shau Tau Kok Pier (HK's longest pier) by sightseeing vessels in order to visit some of the rural areas such as Lai Chi Wo and Kat O. Since 2012 the Frontier Closed Area has been gradually reduced from about 3,500 hectares to 400 hectares so that all that now remains is Shau Tau Kok Town, the Boundary Control Points and the boundary patrol road; https://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/explore/discover-sha-tau-kok.html Edited: 1 year ago

subject: Nice & delicious dim sum at TST
usertext: Hi all I'm staying at The Mira. Can I check what's a good recommendation for dim sum near my hotel? Reasonable price please. Serve breakfast or lunch. Look around in google map but can't determine. Thank you

subject: 1. Re: Nice & delicious dim sum at TST
usertext: We usually go to East Ocean inside The One shopping mall. Don't know whether it's "reasonable" or not.

subject: 2. Re: Nice & delicious dim sum at TST
usertext: For restaurants you can better have a look at https://www.openrice.com/en/hongkong, much more useful than Google Maps.

subject: 3. Re: Nice & delicious dim sum at TST
usertext: The Mira has  on the 3rd floor for dimsum, it is pretty good. But I usually go to Sheraton in TST for dimsum.

subject: 4. Re: Nice & delicious dim sum at TST
usertext: The restaurants mentioned in #3 are good for most people for sure but they do come in a top end pricing bracket. A more affordable place (but certainly not at the budget end) is Reunion Garden at Hillwood Road. It's very close to The Mira. Note that none of these are open for breakfast. If you want dim sum for breakfast, Very Good Restaurant at Nathan Road has been around for decades. They are renowned for their old style dim sum. I have never visited myself. You will also find more options at the side streets south of The Mira (Cameron Road, etc). They have places that specialize in all day dim sum dining.

subject: Airport Express
usertext: Sorry if this is a dumb newbie question, but it looks like the Airport Express is the best way to get close to my hotel. Is it super easy to find the right train at the airport? Can I just get on and pay with a credit card now? Or do I need a ticket in advance or to use an Octopus card? I will be tired from a super long flight so wanting to make sure it's clear before I arrive.

subject: 1. Re: Airport Express
usertext: There's only one train at the airport - the Airport Express, and yes it's super easy to find (follow the signs - it's essentially straight ahead in the middle of the arrivals hall). You need a ticket, but that can be bought with a credit card from the customer service desk or the ticketing machines in the arrivals hall at the airport. If a train is just about to depart you can just jump on and buy your ticket with a credit card at the customer service desk of whichever station you get off. There are automatic ticket barriers at Tsing Yi/Kowloon/Hong Kong stations, but no ticket barriers to get on the train. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Airport Express
usertext: Ok wow, that's super helpful. Thank you! I assume the train runs very frequently?

subject: 3. Re: Airport Express
usertext: Every 10 minutes: Link: https://www.mtr.com.hk/en/customer/services/train_service_index.html

subject: 4. Re: Airport Express
usertext: What is your hotel? Maybe there is a better way to get there. Airport bus is another possibility.

subject: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: Hello I have booked tickets to visit the Victoria Peak and Sky Terrace 428 by tram tomorrow, i.e. 31 December. As per the information on their website, the sky terrace closes by 10 pm and the peak by 11 pm. The last return tram leaves at 11 pm. However, I've seen many websites recommending that the Peak is one of the best places to watch the NYE fireworks show. How does that work? Will the peak's hours be extended for NYE? If anyone has any information, I'll be most grateful.

Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
subject: 1. Re: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: The Peak never closes, its a mountain accessible 24 hours a day. Public transport serving the Peak is bus numbers 15 and 15X, Peak Tram, green minibus number 1 and taxi.. Bus 15X operates a special express service after the fireworks from 00-20 to 1-30 from the Peak to Causeway Bay, Admiralty and Exchange Square in Central on New Year's Day; https://mobile.citybus.com.hk/pdf/E202301759a03.pdf The bus terminus is at ground level of the Peak Galleria (opposite the Peak Tower where the Peak Tram terminates). I would expect demand for taxis to be high (the taxi rank is adjacent to the bus terminus at the Peak Galleria) If need be you can also walk down from the Peak to Central in about 45 mins. https://www.discoverhongkong.com/content/dam/dhk/gohk/images/routes/the-peak/maps/ThePeak_Map_ENG.jpg Bear in mind that low cloud can sometimes impair the view from the Peak. Edited: 1 year ago

subject: 2. Re: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: People love to use confusing terminologies. The geographic location is called "Victoria Peak". The locals just generally refer to Victoria Peak as "The Peak", as if this is the one and only mountain peaks in Hong Kong. Then there is this group of business developers built a structure at the most popular spot in Victoria Peak and called it "The Peak Tower". Or some refers to it as "The Peak" Tower, or just "The Peak". Then gradually there is a mix of "The Peak" being a reference to Victoria Peak, or reference to "The Peak Tower". Link: https://www.thepeak.com.hk/en/the-peak-experience/the-peak-tower-overview Victoria Peak is a public place, big area. It never closes. Transportation is available 24 hours. The Peak Tower, which houses many restaurants/shops, with an observation platform (Sky Terrace) at the roof, and the Peak Tram Upper Terminus at the bottom on the southeast side, does have opening hours.

subject: 3. Re: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: {People love to use confusing terminologies.} Throw in 'Victoria Gap' and the 'Peak Lookout' into the conversation and you can really confuse visitors. ;-)

subject: 4. Re: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: Thank you. This is very helpful.

subject: 5. Re: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: Haha, yes. I was really confused until you made it so simple. Thank you.

subject: 6. Re: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: Be aware also that The Peak is above and about 2.5km from the fireworks, which are essentially designed to be viewed from below from the waterfront promenades on either side of the harbour (which are about 500m from the barges from which the fireworks are launched. Prepare to be underwhelmed - winds are very light at the moment which means that after the first minute or two you'll just be looking at a few vague flashes of light coming from within a distant pall of smoke, with the sounds following about 7 seconds behind the corresponding lights. If this is your only time watching HK fireworks I strongly recommend that you do it from the waterfront.

subject: 7. Re: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: Thank you for that insight. In that case, we will finish the Victoria Peak tour before 10 and head to the Victoria Harbour for the NYE show afterwards. Many thanks.

subject: 8. Re: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: Related question - what would be a good time to reach Victoria Harbour to find a decent spot before the fireworks start? Thanks again.

subject: 10. Re: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: Thank you. You've been very helpful.

subject: 11. Re: Victoria Peak - Timing for New Year's Eve
usertext: >>> after the first minute or two you'll just be looking at a few vague flashes of light coming from within a distant pall of smoke, with the sounds following about 7 seconds behind the corresponding lights. I've once watched the New Year fireworks from the road on Tate's Cairn. A bit higher up and a bit further away than The Peak. It was an interesting way of seeing it but along the waterfront is definitely better. The smoke of the fireworks is a major issue indeed.

subject: Which area to stay

subject: 1. Re: Which area to stay
usertext: For markets that are open late in the evening, Mongkok or a bit south (Yau Ma Tei) is pretty much the place to be. Temple Street, Fa Yuen Street, maybe Ladies' Markets has recovered, that'd be the main ones. Lots of hotels in the area, no doubt there is one that will fit your budget. Edited: 1 year ago
